Here he enjoyed his spirit and his solitude and for ten years he did not tire of it. But at last his heart transformed, \u2013 one morning he arose with the dawn, stepped before the sun and spoke thus to it:</p><p>\u201cYou great star! What would your happiness be if you had not those for whom you shine?</p><p>For ten years you have come up here to my cave: you would have tired of your light and of this route without me, my eagle and my snake.</p><p>But we awaited you every morning, took your overflow from you and blessed you for it.</p><p>Behold! I am weary of my wisdom, like a bee that has gathered too much honey. I need hands that reach out.</p><p>I want to bestow and distribute until the wise among human beings have once again enjoyed their folly, and the poor once again their wealth.</p><p>For this I must descend into the depths, as you do evenings when you go behind the sea and bring light even to the underworld, you super-rich star!</p><p>Like you, I must <em>go down</em> as the human beings say, to whom I want to descend.</p><p>So bless me now, you quiet eye that can look upon even an all too great happiness without envy!</p><p>Bless the cup that wants to flow over, such that water flows golden from it and everywhere carries the reflection of your bliss!</p><p>Behold! This cup wants to become empty again, and Zarathustra wants to become human again.\u201d</p><p>\u2013 Thus began Zarathustra\u2019s going under.</p>", "article_json": {"type": "doc", "content": [{"type": "heading", "attrs": {"level": 3}, "content": [{"text": "1", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "content": [{"text": "When Zarathustra was thirty years old he left his home and the lake of his home and went into the mountains. Here he enjoyed his spirit and his solitude and for ten years he did not tire of it. But at last his heart transformed, \u2013 one morning he arose with the dawn, stepped before the sun and spoke thus to it:\n\n\u201cYou great star! What would your happiness be if you had not those for whom you shine?\n\nFor ten years you have come up here to my cave: you would have tired of your light and of this route without me, my eagle and my snake.\n\nBut we awaited you every morning, took your overflow from you and blessed you for it.\n\nBehold! I am weary of my wisdom, like a bee that has gathered too much honey. I need hands that reach out.\n\nI want to bestow and distribute until the wise among human beings have once again enjoyed their folly, and the poor once again their wealth.\n\nFor this I must descend into the depths, as you do evenings when you go behind the sea and bring light even to the underworld, you super-rich star!\n\nLike you, I must go down as the human beings say, to whom I want to descend.\n\nSo bless me now, you quiet eye that can look upon even an all too great happiness without envy!\n\nBless the cup that wants to flow over, such that water flows golden from it and everywhere carries the reflection of your bliss!\n\nBehold! This cup wants to become empty again, and Zarathustra wants to become human again.\u201d\n\n\u2013 Thus began Zarathustra\u2019s going under."}, "id": 5}, {"data": {"uuid": "636fe5f2-8783-4301-84d6-336b612f7076", "user": 1, "title": "2", "created_on": "2023-05-03 17:52:43.565450+00:00", "updated_on": "2023-05-10 18:12:51.996756+00:00", "article_html": "<h3>2</h3><p>Zarathustra climbed down alone from the mountains and encountered no one. But when he came to the woods suddenly an old man stood before him, who had left his saintly hut in search of roots in the woods. And thus spoke the old man to Zarathustra:</p><p>\u201cThis wanderer is no stranger to me: many years ago he passed by here.  Zarathustra he was called; but he is transformed.</p><p>Back then you carried your ashes to the mountain: would you now carry your fire into the valley? Do you not fear the arsonist\u2019s punishment?</p><p>Yes, I recognize Zarathustra. His eyes are pure, and no disgust is visible around his mouth. Does he not stride like a dancer?</p><p>Zarathustra is transformed, Zarathustra has become a child, an awakened one is Zarathustra. What do you want now among the sleepers?</p><p>You lived in your solitude as if in the sea, and the sea carried you. Alas, you want to climb ashore? Alas, you want to drag your own body again?\u201d</p><p>Zarathustra answered: \u201cI love mankind.\u201d</p><p>\u201cWhy,\u201d asked the saint, \u201cdid I go into the woods and the wilder- ness in the first place? Was it not because I loved mankind all too much?</p><p>Now I love God: human beings I do not love. Human beings are too imperfect a thing for me. Love for human beings would kill me.\u201d</p><p>Zarathustra replied. \u201cWhy did I speak of love? I bring mankind a gift.\u201d</p><p>\u201cGive them nothing,\u201d said the saint. \u201cRather take something off them and help them to carry it \u2013 that will do them the most good, if only it does you good!</p><p>And if you want to give to them, then give nothing more than alms, and make them beg for that too!\u201d</p><p>\u201cNo,\u201d answered Zarathustra. \u201cI do not give alms. For that I am not poor enough.\u201d</p><p>The saint laughed at Zarathustra and spoke thus: \u201cThen see to it that they accept your treasures! They are mistrustful of hermits and do not believe that we come to give gifts.</p><p>To them our footsteps sound too lonely in the lanes. And if at night lying in their beds they hear a man walking outside, long before the sun rises, they probably ask themselves: where is the thief going?</p><p>Do not go to mankind and stay in the woods! Go even to the animals instead! Why do you not want to be like me \u2013 a bear among bears, a bird among birds?\u201d</p><p>\u201cAnd what does the saint do in the woods?\u201d asked Zarathustra.</p><p>The saint answered: \u201cI make songs and sing them, and when I make songs I laugh, weep and growl: thus I praise God.</p><p>With singing, weeping, laughing and growling I praise the god who is my god. But tell me, what do you bring us as a gift?\u201d</p><p>When Zarathustra had heard these words he took his leave of the saint and spoke: \u201cWhat would I have to give you! But let me leave quickly before I take something from you!\u201d \u2013 And so they parted, the oldster and the man, laughing like two boys laugh.</p><p>But when Zarathustra was alone he spoke thus to his heart: \u201cCould it be possible! This old saint in his woods has not yet heard the news that <em>God is dead</em>!\u201d \u2013</p>", "article_json": {"type": "doc", "content": [{"type": "heading", "attrs": {"level": 3}, "content": [{"text": "2", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "content": [{"text": "Zarathustra climbed down alone from the mountains and encountered no one. This old saint in his woods has not yet heard the news that God is dead!\u201d \u2013"}, "id": 6}, {"data": {"uuid": "4d912811-d251-4418-8acf-5c6738faf01a", "user": 1, "title": "3", "created_on": "2023-05-10 13:44:29.411580+00:00", "updated_on": "2023-05-10 18:14:13.844287+00:00", "article_html": "<h3>3</h3><p>When Zarathustra came into the nearest town lying on the edge of the forest, he found many people gathered in the market place, for it had been promised that a tightrope walker would perform. And Zarathustra spoke thus to the people:</p><p>\u201c<em>I teach you the overman</em>. Human being is something that must be overcome. What have you done to overcome him?</p><p>All creatures so far created something beyond themselves; and you want to be the ebb of this great flood and would even rather go back to animals than overcome humans?</p><p>What is the ape to a human? A laughing stock or a painful embarrassment. And that is precisely what the human shall be to the overman: a laughing stock or a painful embarrassment.</p><p>You have made your way from worm to human, and much in you is still worm. Once you were apes, and even now a human is still more ape than any ape.</p><p>But whoever is wisest among you is also just a conflict and a cross between plant and ghost. But do I implore you to become ghosts or plants?</p><p>Behold, I teach you the overman!</p><p>The overman is the meaning of the earth. Let your will say: the overman <em>shall be</em> the meaning of the earth!</p><p>I beseech you, my brothers, <em>remain faithful to the earth</em> and do not believe those who speak to you of extraterrestrial hopes! They are mixers of poisons whether they know it or not.</p><p>They are despisers of life, dying off and self-poisoned, of whom the earth is weary: so let them fade away!</p><p>Once the sacrilege against God was the greatest sacrilege, but God died, and then all these desecrators died. Now to desecrate the earth is the most terrible thing, and to esteem the bowels of the unfathomable higher than the meaning of the earth!</p><p>Once the soul gazed contemptuously at the body, and then such contempt was the highest thing: it wanted the body gaunt, ghastly, starved.  Thus it intended to escape the body and the earth.</p><p>Oh this soul was gaunt, ghastly and starved, and cruelty was the lust of this soul!</p><p>But you, too, my brothers, tell me: what does your body proclaim about your soul? Is your soul not poverty and filth and a pitiful contentment?</p><p>Truly, mankind is a polluted stream. One has to be a sea to take in a polluted stream without becoming unclean.</p><p>Behold, I teach you the overman: he is this sea, in him your great contempt can go under.</p><p>What is the greatest thing that you can experience? It is the hour of your great contempt. The hour in which even your happiness turns to nausea and likewise your reason and your virtue.</p><p>The hour in which you say: \u2018What matters my happiness? It is poverty and filth, and a pitiful contentment. But my happiness ought to justify existence itself!\u2019</p><p>The hour in which you say: \u2018What matters my reason? Does it crave knowledge like the lion its food? It is poverty and filth and a pitiful contentment!\u2019</p><p>The hour in which you say: \u2018What matters my virtue? It has not yet made me rage. How weary I am of my good and my evil! That is all poverty and filth and a pitiful contentment!\u2019</p><p>The hour in which you say: \u2018What matters my justice? I do not see that I am ember and coal. But the just person is ember and coal!\u2019</p><p>The hour in which you say: \u2018What matters my pity? Is pity not the cross on which he is nailed who loves humans? But my pity is no crucifixion.\u2019</p><p>Have you yet spoken thus? Have you yet cried out thus? Oh that I might have heard you cry out thus!</p><p>Not your sin \u2013 your modesty cries out to high heaven, your stinginess even in sinning cries out to high heaven!</p><p>Where is the lightning that would lick you with its tongue? Where is the madness with which you should be inoculated?</p><p>Behold, I teach you the overman: he is this lightning, he is this madness! \u2013\u201d</p><p>When Zarathustra had spoken thus someone from the crowd cried out:</p><p>\u201cWe have heard enough already about the tightrope walker, now let us see him too!\u201d And all the people laughed at Zarathustra. And Zarathustra spoke thus to the people:\n\n\u201cI teach you the overman. Human being is something that must be overcome. What have you done to overcome him?\n\nAll creatures so far created something beyond themselves; and you want to be the ebb of this great flood and would even rather go back to animals than overcome humans?\n\nWhat is the ape to a human? A laughing stock or a painful embarrassment. And that is precisely what the human shall be to the overman: a laughing stock or a painful embarrassment.\n\nYou have made your way from worm to human, and much in you is still worm. Once you were apes, and even now a human is still more ape than any ape.\n\nBut whoever is wisest among you is also just a conflict and a cross between plant and ghost. But do I implore you to become ghosts or plants?\n\nBehold, I teach you the overman!\n\nThe overman is the meaning of the earth. Let your will say: the overman shall be the meaning of the earth!\n\nI beseech you, my brothers, remain faithful to the earth and do not believe those who speak to you of extraterrestrial hopes! They are mixers of poisons whether they know it or not.\n\nThey are despisers of life, dying off and self-poisoned, of whom the earth is weary: so let them fade away!\n\nOnce the sacrilege against God was the greatest sacrilege, but God died, and then all these desecrators died. Now to desecrate the earth is the most terrible thing, and to esteem the bowels of the unfathomable higher than the meaning of the earth!\n\nOnce the soul gazed contemptuously at the body, and then such contempt was the highest thing: it wanted the body gaunt, ghastly, starved.  Thus it intended to escape the body and the earth.\n\nOh this soul was gaunt, ghastly and starved, and cruelty was the lust of this soul!\n\nBut you, too, my brothers, tell me: what does your body proclaim about your soul? Is your soul not poverty and filth and a pitiful contentment?\n\nTruly, mankind is a polluted stream. One has to be a sea to take in a polluted stream without becoming unclean.\n\nBehold, I teach you the overman: he is this sea, in him your great contempt can go under.\n\nWhat is the greatest thing that you can experience? It is the hour of your great contempt. The hour in which even your happiness turns to nausea and likewise your reason and your virtue.\n\nThe hour in which you say: \u2018What matters my happiness? It is poverty and filth, and a pitiful contentment. But my happiness ought to justify existence itself!\u2019\n\nThe hour in which you say: \u2018What matters my reason? Does it crave knowledge like the lion its food? It is poverty and filth and a pitiful contentment!\u2019\n\nThe hour in which you say: \u2018What matters my virtue? It has not yet made me rage. How weary I am of my good and my evil! That is all poverty and filth and a pitiful contentment!\u2019\n\nThe hour in which you say: \u2018What matters my justice? I do not see that I am ember and coal. But the just person is ember and coal!\u2019\n\nThe hour in which you say: \u2018What matters my pity? Is pity not the cross on which he is nailed who loves humans? But my pity is no crucifixion.\u2019\n\nHave you yet spoken thus? Have you yet cried out thus? Oh that I might have heard you cry out thus!\n\nNot your sin \u2013 your modesty cries out to high heaven, your stinginess even in sinning cries out to high heaven!\n\nWhere is the lightning that would lick you with its tongue? Where is the madness with which you should be inoculated?\n\nBehold, I teach you the overman: he is this lightning, he is this madness! \u2013\u201d\n\nWhen Zarathustra had spoken thus someone from the crowd cried out:\n\n\u201cWe have heard enough already about the tightrope walker, now let us see him too!\u201d And all the people laughed at Zarathustra. But the tightrope walker, believing that these words concerned him, got down to his work."}, "id": 7}, {"data": {"uuid": "c4c11a82-5eb7-4c3c-8ab6-91217dce833b", "user": 1, "title": "4", "created_on": "2023-05-10 13:54:56.584673+00:00", "updated_on": "2023-05-10 13:54:56.601690+00:00", "article_html": "<h3>4</h3><p>Now Zarathustra looked at the people and he was amazed. Then he spoke thus:</p><p>\u201cMankind is a rope fastened between animal and overman \u2013 a rope over an abyss.</p><p>A dangerous crossing, a dangerous on-the-way, a dangerous looking back, a dangerous shuddering and standing still.</p><p>What is great about human beings is that they are a bridge and not a purpose: what is lovable about human beings is that they are a crossing over and a going under.</p><p>I love those who do not know how to live unless by going under, for they are the ones who cross over.</p><p>I love the great despisers, because they are the great venerators and arrows of longing for the other shore.</p><p>I love those who do not first seek behind the stars for a reason to go under and be a sacrifice, who instead sacrifice themselves for the earth, so that the earth may one day become the overman\u2019s.</p><p>I love the one who lives in order to know, and who wants to know so that one day the overman may live. And so he wants his going under.</p><p>I love the one who works and invents in order to build a house for the overman and to prepare earth, animals and plants for him: for thus he wants his going under.</p><p>I love the one who loves his virtue: for virtue is the will to going under and an arrow of longing.</p><p>I love the one who does not hold back a single drop of spirit for himself, but wants instead to be entirely the spirit of his virtue: thus he strides as spirit over the bridge.</p><p>I love the one who makes of his virtue his desire and his doom: thus for the sake of his virtue he wants to live on and to live no more.</p><p>I love the one who does not want to have too many virtues. One virtue is more virtue than two, because it is more of a hook on which his doom may hang.</p><p>I love the one whose soul squanders itself, who wants no thanks and gives none back: for he always gives and does not want to preserve himself.</p><p>I love the one who is ashamed when the dice fall to his fortune and who then asks: am I a cheater? \u2013 For he wants to perish.</p><p>I love the one who casts golden words before his deeds and always does even more than he promises: for he wants his going under.</p><p>I love the one who justifies people of the future and redeems those of the past: for he wants to perish of those in the present.</p><p>I love the one who chastises his god, because he loves his god: for he must perish of the wrath of his god.</p><p>I love the one whose soul is deep even when wounded, and who can perish of a small experience: thus he goes gladly over the bridge.</p><p>I love the one whose soul is overfull, so that he forgets himself, and all things are in him: thus all things become his going under.</p><p>I love the one who is free of spirit and heart: thus his head is only the entrails of his heart, but his heart drives him to his going under.</p><p>I love all those who are like heavy drops falling individually from the dark cloud that hangs over humanity: they herald the coming of the lightning, and as heralds they perish.</p><p>Behold, I am a herald of the lightning and a heavy drop from the cloud: but this lightning is called overman. \u2013\u201d</p>", "article_json": {"type": "doc", "content": [{"type": "heading", "attrs": {"level": 3}, "content": [{"text": "4", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "content": [{"text": "Now Zarathustra looked at the people and he was amazed. Must one rattle like kettle drums and penitence preachers? Or do they believe only a stutterer?</p><p>They have something of which they are proud. And what do they call that which makes them proud? Education they call it, it distinguishes them from goatherds.</p><p>For that reason they hate to hear the word \u2018contempt\u2019 applied to them. So I shall address their pride instead.</p><p>Thus I shall speak to them of the most contemptible person: but he is the last human being.\u201d</p><p>And thus spoke Zarathustra to the people:</p><p>\u201cIt is time that mankind set themselves a goal. It is time that mankind plant the seed of their highest hope.</p><p>Their soil is still rich enough for this. But one day this soil will be poor and tame, and no tall tree will be able to grow from it anymore.</p><p>Beware! The time approaches when human beings no longer launch the arrow of their longing beyond the human, and the string of their bow will have forgotten how to whir!</p><p>I say to you: one must still have chaos in oneself in order to give birth to a dancing star. I say to you: you still have chaos in you.</p><p>Beware! The time approaches when human beings will no longer give birth to a dancing star. Beware! The time of the most contemptible human is coming, the one who can no longer have contempt for himself.</p><p>Behold! I show you the last human being.</p><p>\u2018What is love? What is creation? What is longing? What is a star?\u2019 \u2013 thus asks the last human being, blinking.</p><p>Then the earth has become small, and on it hops the last human being, who makes everything small. His kind is ineradicable, like the flea beetle; the last human being lives longest.</p><p>\u2018We invented happiness\u2019 \u2013 say the last human beings, blinking.</p><p>They abandoned the regions where it was hard to live: for one needs warmth. One still loves one\u2019s neighbor and rubs up against him: for one needs warmth.</p><p>Becoming ill and being mistrustful are considered sinful by them: one proceeds with caution. A fool who still stumbles over stones or humans!</p><p>A bit of poison once in a while; that makes for pleasant dreams. And much poison at the end, for a pleasant death.</p><p>One still works, for work is a form of entertainment. But one sees to it that the entertainment is not a strain.</p><p>One no longer becomes poor and rich: both are too burdensome. Who wants to rule anymore? Who wants to obey anymore? Both are too burdensome.</p><p>No shepherd and one herd! Each wants the same, each is the same, and whoever feels differently goes voluntarily into the insane asylum.</p><p>\u2018Formerly the whole world was insane\u2019 \u2013 the finest ones say, blinking.</p><p>One is clever and knows everything that has happened, and so there is no end to their mockery. People still quarrel but they reconcile quickly \u2013 otherwise it is bad for the stomach.</p><p>One has one\u2019s little pleasure for the day and one\u2019s little pleasure for the night: but one honors health. \u2018We invented happiness\u2019 say the last human beings, and they blink.\u201d</p><p>And here ended the first speech of Zarathustra, which is also called \u201cThe Prologue,\u201d for at this point he was interrupted by the yelling and merriment of the crowd. \u201cGive us this last human being, oh Zarathustra\u201d \u2013 thus they cried \u2013 \u201cmake us into these last human beings! Then we will make you a gift of the overman!\u201d And all the people jubilated and clicked their tongues. But Zarathustra grew sad and said to his heart:</p><p>\u201cThey do not understand me. I am not the mouth for these ears.</p><p>Too long apparently I lived in the mountains, too much I listened to brooks and trees: now I speak to them as to goatherds.</p><p>My soul is calm and bright as the morning mountains. But they believe I am cold, that I jeer, that I deal in terrible jests.</p><p>And now they look at me and laugh, and in laughing they hate me too. The time approaches when human beings no longer launch the arrow of their longing beyond the human, and the string of their bow will have forgotten how to whir!\r\n\r\nI say to you: one must still have chaos in oneself in order to give birth to a dancing star. I say to you: you still have chaos in you.\r\n\r\nBeware! The time approaches when human beings will no longer give birth to a dancing star. Beware! The time of the most contemptible human is coming, the one who can no longer have contempt for himself.\r\n\r\nBehold! I show you the last human being.\r\n\r\n\u2018What is love? What is creation? What is longing? What is a star?\u2019 \u2013 thus asks the last human being, blinking.\r\n\r\nThen the earth has become small, and on it hops the last human being, who makes everything small. His kind is ineradicable, like the flea beetle; the last human being lives longest.\r\n\r\n\u2018We invented happiness\u2019 \u2013 say the last human beings, blinking.\r\n\r\nThey abandoned the regions where it was hard to live: for one needs warmth. One still loves one\u2019s neighbor and rubs up against him: for one needs warmth.\r\n\r\nBecoming ill and being mistrustful are considered sinful by them: one proceeds with caution. A fool who still stumbles over stones or humans!\r\n\r\nA bit of poison once in a while; that makes for pleasant dreams. And much poison at the end, for a pleasant death.\r\n\r\nOne still works, for work is a form of entertainment. But one sees to it that the entertainment is not a strain.\r\n\r\nOne no longer becomes poor and rich: both are too burdensome. Who wants to rule anymore? Who wants to obey anymore? Both are too burdensome.\r\n\r\nNo shepherd and one herd! Each wants the same, each is the same, and whoever feels differently goes voluntarily into the insane asylum.\r\n\r\n\u2018Formerly the whole world was insane\u2019 \u2013 the finest ones say, blinking.\r\n\r\nOne is clever and knows everything that has happened, and so there is no end to their mockery. People still quarrel but they reconcile quickly \u2013 otherwise it is bad for the stomach.\r\n\r\nOne has one\u2019s little pleasure for the day and one\u2019s little pleasure for the night: but one honors health. \u2018We invented happiness\u2019 say the last human beings, and they blink.\u201d\r\n\r\nAnd here ended the first speech of Zarathustra, which is also called \u201cThe Prologue,\u201d for at this point he was interrupted by the yelling and merriment of the crowd. \u201cGive us this last human being, oh Zarathustra\u201d \u2013 thus they cried \u2013 \u201cmake us into these last human beings! Then we will make you a gift of the overman!\u201d And all the people jubilated and clicked their tongues. But Zarathustra grew sad and said to his heart:\r\n\r\n\u201cThey do not understand me. I am not the mouth for these ears.\r\n\r\nToo long apparently I lived in the mountains, too much I listened to brooks and trees: now I speak to them as to goatherds.\r\n\r\nMy soul is calm and bright as the morning mountains. But they believe I am cold, that I jeer, that I deal in terrible jests.\r\n\r\nAnd now they look at me and laugh, and in laughing they hate me too. Just as he was at the midpoint of his way, the little door opened once again and a colorful fellow resembling a jester leaped forth and hurried after the first man with quick steps. \u201cForward, sloth, smuggler, pale face! Or I\u2019ll tickle you with my heel! What business have you here between the towers? But when he was only one step behind him, the terrifying thing occurred that struck every mouth silent and forced all eyes to stare: \u2013 he let out a yell like a devil and leaped over the man who was in his way. This man, seeing his rival triumph in this manner, lost his head and the rope. He threw away his pole and plunged into the depths even faster than his pole, like a whirlwind of arms and legs. The market place and the people resembled the sea when a storm charges in: everyone fled apart and into one another, and especially in the spot where the body had to impact.</p><p>But Zarathustra stood still and the body landed right beside him, badly beaten and broken, but not yet dead. At last, however, he opened his eyes: amazed Zarathustra looked into the woods and the silence, amazed he looked into himself. Then he stood up quickly, like a seafarer who all at once sees land, and he rejoiced, for he saw a new truth. And thus he spoke to his heart:</p><p>\u201cIt dawned on me: I need companions, and living ones \u2013 not dead companions and corpses that I carry with me wherever I want.</p><p>Instead I need living companions who follow me because they want to follow themselves \u2013 wherever I want.</p><p>It dawned on me: let Zarathustra speak not to the people, but instead to companions! Zarathustra should not become the shepherd and dog of a herd!</p><p>To lure many away from the herd \u2013 for that I came. The people and herd shall be angry with me: Zarathustra wants to be called a robber by shepherds.</p><p>Shepherds I say, but they call themselves the good and the just. Shep- herds I say: but they call themselves the faithful of the true faith.</p><p>Look at the good and the just! Whom do they hate most? The one who breaks their tablets of values, the breaker, the lawbreaker \u2013 but he is the creative one.</p><p>Look at the faithful of all faiths! Whom do they hate most? The one who breaks their tablets of values, the breaker, the lawbreaker \u2013 but he is the creative one.</p><p>Companions the creative one seeks and not corpses, nor herds and believers. Fellow creators the creative one seeks, who will write new values on new tablets.</p><p>Companions the creative one seeks, and fellow harvesters; for to him everything stands ready for harvest. But he lacks the hundred scythes, and so he plucks out spikes and is angry.</p><p>Companions the creative one seeks, and those who know how to whet their scythes. They shall be called annihilators and despisers of good and evil. But they are the harvesters and the celebrators.</p><p>Fellow creators seeks Zarathustra, fellow harvesters and fellow celebrators Zarathustra seeks: what need does he have of herds and shepherds and corpses!</p><p>And you, my first companion, take care! I buried you well in your tree, I concealed you well from the wolves.</p><p>But I am leaving you, the time is up. Between dawn and dawn a new truth came to me.</p><p>I shall not be a shepherd, nor a gravedigger. I do not want to even speak again with the people \u2013 for the last time have I spoken to a dead person.</p><p>I shall join the creators, the harvesters, the celebrators: I shall show them the rainbow and all the steps to the overman.</p><p>I shall sing my song to lonesome and twosome hermits, and for him who still has ears for the unheard of, I shall make his heart heavy with my happiness.</p><p>I want to go to my goal, and I go my own way; over the hesitating and dawdling I shall leap. Its strength demands what is heavy and heaviest.</p><p>What is heavy? thus asks the carrying spirit. It kneels down like a camel and wants to be well loaded.</p><p>What is heaviest, you heroes? thus asks the carrying spirit, so that I might take it upon myself and rejoice in my strength.</p><p>Is it not this: lowering oneself in order to hurt one\u2019s pride? Letting one\u2019s foolishness glow in order to mock one\u2019s wisdom?</p><p>Or is it this: abandoning our cause when it celebrates victory? Climbing high mountains in order to tempt the tempter?</p><p>Or is it this: feeding on the acorns and grass of knowledge and for the sake of truth suffering hunger in one\u2019s soul?</p><p>Or is it this: being ill and sending the comforters home and making friends with the deaf who never hear what you want?</p><p>Or is it this: wading into dirty water when it is the water of truth, and not shrinking away from cold frogs and hot toads?</p><p>Or is it this: loving those who despise us, and extending a hand to the ghost when it wants to frighten us?</p><p>All of these heaviest things the carrying spirit takes upon itself, like a loaded camel that hurries into the desert, thus it hurries into its desert.</p><p>But in the loneliest desert the second metamorphosis occurs. Here the spirit becomes lion, it wants to hunt down its freedom and be master in its own desert.</p><p>Here it seeks its last master, and wants to fight him and its last god. For victory it wants to battle the great dragon.</p><p>Who is the great dragon whom the spirit no longer wants to call master and god? \u201cThou shalt\u201d is the name of the great dragon. But the spirit of the lion says \u201cI will.\u201d</p><p>\u201cThou shalt\u201d stands in its way, gleaming golden, a scaly animal, and upon every scale \u201cthou shalt!\u201d gleams like gold.</p><p>The values of millennia gleam on these scales, and thus speaks the most powerful of all dragons: \u201cthe value of all things \u2013 it gleams in me.</p><p>All value has already been created, and the value of all created things \u2013 that am I. Indeed, there shall be no more \u2018I will!\u2019\u201d Thus speaks the dragon.</p><p>My brothers, why is the lion required by the spirit? Why does the beast of burden, renouncing and reverent, not suffice?</p><p>To create new values \u2013 not even the lion is capable of that: but to create freedom for itself for new creation \u2013 that is within the power of the lion.</p><p>To create freedom for oneself and also a sacred No to duty: for that, my brothers, the lion is required.</p><p>To take the right to new values \u2013 that is the most terrible taking for a carrying and reverent spirit. Indeed, it is preying, and the work of a predatory animal.</p><p>Once it loved \u201cthou shalt\u201d as its most sacred, now it must find delusion and despotism even in what is most sacred to it, in order to wrest freedom from its love by preying. The lion is required for this preying.</p><p>But tell me, my brothers, of what is the child capable that even the lion is not? Why must the preying lion still become a child?</p><p>The child is innocence and forgetting, a new beginning, a game, a wheel rolling out of itself, a first movement, a sacred yes-saying.</p><p>Yes, for the game of creation my brothers a sacred yes-saying is required. The spirit wants its will, the one lost to the world now wins its own world.</p><p>Three metamorphoses of the spirit I named for you: how the spirit became a camel, and the camel a lion, and finally the lion a child. \u2013</p><p>Thus spoke Zarathustra. Its strength demands what is heavy and heaviest.\r\n\r\nWhat is heavy? thus asks the carrying spirit. It kneels down like a camel and wants to be well loaded.\r\n\r\nWhat is heaviest, you heroes? thus asks the carrying spirit, so that I might take it upon myself and rejoice in my strength.\r\n\r\nIs it not this: lowering oneself in order to hurt one\u2019s pride? Letting one\u2019s foolishness glow in order to mock one\u2019s wisdom?\r\n\r\nOr is it this: abandoning our cause when it celebrates victory? Climbing high mountains in order to tempt the tempter?\r\n\r\nOr is it this: feeding on the acorns and grass of knowledge and for the sake of truth suffering hunger in one\u2019s soul?\r\n\r\nOr is it this: being ill and sending the comforters home and making friends with the deaf who never hear what you want?\r\n\r\nOr is it this: wading into dirty water when it is the water of truth, and not shrinking away from cold frogs and hot toads?\r\n\r\nOr is it this: loving those who despise us, and extending a hand to the ghost when it wants to frighten us?\r\n\r\nAll of these heaviest things the carrying spirit takes upon itself, like a loaded camel that hurries into the desert, thus it hurries into its desert.\r\n\r\nBut in the loneliest desert the second metamorphosis occurs. Here the spirit becomes lion, it wants to hunt down its freedom and be master in its own desert.\r\n\r\nHere it seeks its last master, and wants to fight him and its last god. For victory it wants to battle the great dragon.\r\n\r\nWho is the great dragon whom the spirit no longer wants to call master and god? \u201cThou shalt\u201d is the name of the great dragon. But the spirit of the lion says \u201cI will.\u201d\r\n\r\n\u201cThou shalt\u201d stands in its way, gleaming golden, a scaly animal, and upon every scale \u201cthou shalt!\u201d gleams like gold.\r\n\r\nThe values of millennia gleam on these scales, and thus speaks the most powerful of all dragons: \u201cthe value of all things \u2013 it gleams in me.\r\n\r\nAll value has already been created, and the value of all created things \u2013 that am I. Indeed, there shall be no more \u2018I will!\u2019\u201d Thus speaks the dragon.\r\n\r\nMy brothers, why is the lion required by the spirit? Why does the beast of burden, renouncing and reverent, not suffice?\r\n\r\nTo create new values \u2013 not even the lion is capable of that: but to create freedom for itself for new creation \u2013 that is within the power of the lion.\r\n\r\nTo create freedom for oneself and also a sacred No to duty: for that, my brothers, the lion is required.\r\n\r\nTo take the right to new values \u2013 that is the most terrible taking for a carrying and reverent spirit. Indeed, it is preying, and the work of a predatory animal.\r\n\r\nOnce it loved \u201cthou shalt\u201d as its most sacred, now it must find delusion and despotism even in what is most sacred to it, in order to wrest freedom from its love by preying. The lion is required for this preying.\r\n\r\nBut tell me, my brothers, of what is the child capable that even the lion is not? Why must the preying lion still become a child?\r\n\r\nThe child is innocence and forgetting, a new beginning, a game, a wheel rolling out of itself, a first movement, a sacred yes-saying.\r\n\r\nYes, for the game of creation my brothers a sacred yes-saying is required. The spirit wants its will, the one lost to the world now wins its own world.\r\n\r\nThree metamorphoses of the spirit I named for you: how the spirit became a camel, and the camel a lion, and finally the lion a child. \u2013\r\n\r\nThus spoke Zarathustra. And then he sojourned in the town which is called The Motley Cow."}, "id": 16}, {"data": {"uuid": "7b0bc579-7266-4cf0-9b74-0f229cb3573d", "user": 1, "title": "On the Teachers of Virtue", "created_on": "2023-05-10 14:07:35.738338+00:00", "updated_on": "2023-05-10 14:07:35.751232+00:00", "article_html": "<h2>On the Teachers of Virtue</h2><p>A wise man was praised to Zarathustra who could speak well of sleep and of virtue. For this he was much honored and rewarded, and all the youths sat at his feet. Zarathustra went to him and sat at his feet with all the youths. And thus spoke the wise man:</p><p>\u201cHave honor and bashfulness for sleep! That is the first thing! And avoid all who sleep badly and remain awake nights!</p><p>Even the thief is bashful toward sleep; he constantly steals through the night, silently. But the watchman of the night is shameless, and shame- lessly he carries his horn.</p><p>Sleeping is no mean art, it is necessary to remain awake the entire day for it.</p><p>Ten times a day you must overcome yourself, that makes for a good weariness and is poppy for the soul.</p><p>Ten times you must reconcile yourself again with yourself, for over- coming causes bitterness and the unreconciled sleep badly.</p><p>Ten truths you must find by day, or else you will still be seeking truth by night and your soul will have remained hungry.</p><p>Ten times you must laugh by day and be cheerful, or else your stomach will bother you at night, this father of gloom.</p><p>Few know it but one must have all the virtues in order to sleep well. Shall I bear false witness? Shall I commit adultery?</p><p>Shall I covet my neighbor\u2019s maid? All that would be incompatible with good sleep.</p><p>And even when one has all the virtues, one must understand one more thing: how to send the virtues to sleep at the right time.</p><p>So that they do not quarrel with each other, the good little women! And quarrel over you, wretch!</p><p>At peace with God and neighbor, thus good sleep demands. And at peace too with the neighbor\u2019s devil! Otherwise he will be at your house at night.</p><p>Honor the authorities and practice obedience, even toward the crooked authorities! Thus good sleep demands. What can I do about it that the powers like to walk on crooked legs? He shall always be the best shepherd in my view who leads his sheep to the greenest pasture; this is compatible with good sleep.</p><p>I do not want many honors, nor great treasures \u2013 that inflames the spleen. But sleep is bad without a good name and a little treasure.</p><p>A little company is more welcome to me than evil company, but they must go and come at the right time, for this is compatible with good sleep.</p><p>I also like very much the poor in spirit, they promote sleep. Blessed are they, especially when they are always told they are right.</p><p>Thus passes the day for the virtuous one. Now when night comes I am careful not to summon sleep \u2013 the master of virtues does not like to be summoned!</p><p>Instead I think what I have done and thought throughout the day. Rumi- nating, I ask myself, patient as a cow; what then were my ten overcomings?</p><p>And what were the ten reconciliations and the ten truths and the ten laughters to which my heart treated itself?</p><p>In this manner reflecting and rocked by forty thoughts, sleep suddenly falls upon me, the unsummoned, the master of virtues.</p><p>Sleep knocks at my eyelids, and they become heavy. Sleeps brushes my mouth, and it stays open.</p><p>Truly, on soft soles it comes to me, the dearest of thieves, and steals my thoughts: stupid I stand there like this chair.</p><p>But then I am not standing for long, and soon I am lying.\u201d \u2013</p><p>When Zarathustra heard the wise man speak thus, he laughed inwardly in his heart, for something dawned on him, and he spoke thus to his heart:</p><p>\u201cThat wise man there with his forty thoughts is just a fool to me, but I believe that he well understands sleep.</p><p>Happy the one who lives even near this wise man! Such a sleep is infectious, and it infects even through a thick wall.</p><p>In this teacher nothing less than magic resides, and not in vain did youths sit at the feet of this preacher of virtue.</p><p>The meaning of his wisdom is: wake in order to sleep well. And truly, if life had no meaning and if I had to choose nonsense, then to me too this would be the worthiest nonsense I could choose.</p><p>Now I understand clearly what was once sought before all else when teachers of virtue were sought. Good sleep was sought and poppy- blossomed virtues to boot!</p><p>For all these highly praised wise men and teachers wisdom was the sleep without dreams: they knew no better meaning of life.</p><p>And still today there are a few like this preacher of virtue, and some not so honest. But their time is up, not for long will they be standing, and soon they\u2019ll be lying.</p><p>Blessed are these sleepy ones, for they shall soon nod off.\u201d \u2013</p><p>Thus spoke Zarathustra.</p>", "article_json": {"type": "doc", "content": [{"type": "heading", "attrs": {"level": 2}, "content": [{"text": "On the Teachers of Virtue", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "content": [{"text": "A wise man was praised to Zarathustra who could speak well of sleep and of virtue. And thus spoke the wise man:\r\n\r\n\u201cHave honor and bashfulness for sleep! That is the first thing! And avoid all who sleep badly and remain awake nights!\r\n\r\nEven the thief is bashful toward sleep; he constantly steals through the night, silently. But the watchman of the night is shameless, and shame- lessly he carries his horn.\r\n\r\nSleeping is no mean art, it is necessary to remain awake the entire day for it.\r\n\r\nTen times a day you must overcome yourself, that makes for a good weariness and is poppy for the soul.\r\n\r\nTen times you must reconcile yourself again with yourself, for over- coming causes bitterness and the unreconciled sleep badly.\r\n\r\nTen truths you must find by day, or else you will still be seeking truth by night and your soul will have remained hungry.\r\n\r\nTen times you must laugh by day and be cheerful, or else your stomach will bother you at night, this father of gloom.\r\n\r\nFew know it but one must have all the virtues in order to sleep well. Shall I bear false witness? Shall I commit adultery?\r\n\r\nShall I covet my neighbor\u2019s maid? All that would be incompatible with good sleep.\r\n\r\nAnd even when one has all the virtues, one must understand one more thing: how to send the virtues to sleep at the right time.\r\n\r\nSo that they do not quarrel with each other, the good little women! And quarrel over you, wretch!\r\n\r\nAt peace with God and neighbor, thus good sleep demands. And at peace too with the neighbor\u2019s devil! Otherwise he will be at your house at night.\r\n\r\nHonor the authorities and practice obedience, even toward the crooked authorities! Thus good sleep demands. What can I do about it that the powers like to walk on crooked legs? He shall always be the best shepherd in my view who leads his sheep to the greenest pasture; this is compatible with good sleep.\r\n\r\nI do not want many honors, nor great treasures \u2013 that inflames the spleen. But sleep is bad without a good name and a little treasure.\r\n\r\nA little company is more welcome to me than evil company, but they must go and come at the right time, for this is compatible with good sleep.\r\n\r\nI also like very much the poor in spirit, they promote sleep. Blessed are they, especially when they are always told they are right.\r\n\r\nThus passes the day for the virtuous one. Now when night comes I am careful not to summon sleep \u2013 the master of virtues does not like to be summoned!\r\n\r\nInstead I think what I have done and thought throughout the day. Rumi- nating, I ask myself, patient as a cow; what then were my ten overcomings?\r\n\r\nAnd what were the ten reconciliations and the ten truths and the ten laughters to which my heart treated itself?\r\n\r\nIn this manner reflecting and rocked by forty thoughts, sleep suddenly falls upon me, the unsummoned, the master of virtues.\r\n\r\nSleep knocks at my eyelids, and they become heavy. Sleeps brushes my mouth, and it stays open.\r\n\r\nTruly, on soft soles it comes to me, the dearest of thieves, and steals my thoughts: stupid I stand there like this chair.\r\n\r\nBut then I am not standing for long, and soon I am lying.\u201d \u2013\r\n\r\nWhen Zarathustra heard the wise man speak thus, he laughed inwardly in his heart, for something dawned on him, and he spoke thus to his heart:\r\n\r\n\u201cThat wise man there with his forty thoughts is just a fool to me, but I believe that he well understands sleep.\r\n\r\nHappy the one who lives even near this wise man! Such a sleep is infectious, and it infects even through a thick wall.\r\n\r\nIn this teacher nothing less than magic resides, and not in vain did youths sit at the feet of this preacher of virtue.\r\n\r\nThe meaning of his wisdom is: wake in order to sleep well. And truly, if life had no meaning and if I had to choose nonsense, then to me too this would be the worthiest nonsense I could choose.\r\n\r\nNow I understand clearly what was once sought before all else when teachers of virtue were sought. Good sleep was sought and poppy- blossomed virtues to boot!\r\n\r\nFor all these highly praised wise men and teachers wisdom was the sleep without dreams: they knew no better meaning of life.\r\n\r\nAnd still today there are a few like this preacher of virtue, and some not so honest. But their time is up, not for long will they be standing, and soon they\u2019ll be lying.\r\n\r\nBlessed are these sleepy ones, for they shall soon nod off.\u201d \u2013\r\n\r\nThus spoke Zarathustra."}, "id": 17}, {"data": {"uuid": "0a1bf821-7c8c-4c62-878e-504a1943f9ab", "user": 1, "title": "On the Hinterworldly", "created_on": "2023-05-10 14:08:23.056344+00:00", "updated_on": "2023-05-10 14:08:23.071957+00:00", "article_html": "<h2>On the Hinterworldly</h2><p>Once Zarathustra too cast his delusion beyond humans, like all hinterworldly. At that time the world seemed to me the work of a suffering and tortured god.</p><p>Then the world seemed a dream to me and the fiction of a god; colorful smoke before the eyes of a divine dissatisfied being.</p><p>Good and evil and joy and suffering and I and you \u2013 colorful smoke it seemed to me before creative eyes. The creator wanted to look away from himself and so he created the world.</p><p>It is drunken joy to the suffering one to look away from one\u2019s suffering and to lose oneself. Drunken joy and losing-oneself the world once seemed to me.</p><p>This world, the eternally imperfect, the mirror image and imperfect image of an eternal contradiction \u2013 a drunken joy to its imperfect creator: thus the world once seemed to me.</p><p>So I too once cast my delusion beyond humans, like all hinterworldly. Beyond humans in truth?</p><p>Oh my brothers, this god that I created was of human make and mad- ness, like all gods!</p><p>Human he was, and only a poor flake of human and ego. From my own ash and ember it came to me, this ghost, and truly! It did not come to me from beyond!</p><p>What happened, my brothers? I overcame myself, my suffering self, I carried my own ashes to the mountain, I invented a brighter flame for myself and behold! The ghost shrank from me!</p><p>Now it would be suffering and torture for the convalesced one to believe in such ghosts. Now it would be suffering and humiliation. Thus I speak to the hinterworldly.</p><p>It was suffering and incapacity that created all hinterworlds, and that brief madness of happiness that only the most suffering person experiences.</p><p>Weariness that wants its ultimate with one great leap, with a death leap; a poor unknowing weariness that no longer even wants to will: that created all gods and hinterworlds.</p><p>Believe me, my brothers! It was the body that despaired of the body \u2013 it probed with the fingers of a befooled spirit on the walls of the ultimate.</p><p>Believe me, my brothers! It was the body that despaired of the earth \u2013 then it heard the belly of being speaking to it.</p><p>And then it wanted to break head first through the ultimate walls, and not only with its head, beyond to \u201cthe other world.\u201d</p><p>But \u201cthe other world\u201d is well hidden from humans, that dehumaned, inhuman world that is a heavenly nothing. And the belly of being does not speak at all to humans, unless as a human.</p><p>Indeed, all being is hard to prove and hard to coax to speech. Tell me, my brothers, is not the strangest of all things still proven best?</p><p>Yes, this ego and the ego\u2019s contradiction and confusion still speak most honestly about its being; this creating, willing, valuing ego which is the measure and value of things.</p><p>And this most honest being, this ego \u2013 it speaks of love and it still wants the body, even when it poetizes and fantasizes and flutters with broken wings.</p><p>It learns to speak ever more honestly, this ego. And the more it learns, the more it finds words and honors for the body and the earth.</p><p>My ego taught me a new pride, I teach it to mankind: no longer bury your head in the sand of heavenly things, but bear it freely instead, an earthly head that creates a meaning for the earth!</p><p>I teach mankind a new will: to want the path that human beings have traveled blindly, to pronounce it good and no longer sneak to the side of it like the sick and the dying-out.</p><p>It was the sick and the dying-out who despised the body and the earth and invented the heavenly and its redeeming drops of blood. But even these sweet and shadowy poisons they took from the body and the earth!</p><p>They wanted to escape their misery and the stars were too distant for them. So they sighed \u201cOh if only there were heavenly paths on which to sneak into another being and happiness!\u201d \u2013 Then they invented their schemes and bloody little drinks!</p><p>Now they fancied themselves detached from this earth, these ingrates. But what did they have to thank for the fits and bliss of their detachment? Their body and this earth.</p><p>Zarathustra is gentle to the sick. Indeed, he is not angered by their ways of comfort and ingratitude. May they become convalescents and overcomers and create for themselves a higher body!</p><p>Nor is he angered by the convalescent when he tenderly gazes upon his delusion and sneaks around the grave of his God at midnight. But to me even his tears remain sickness and sick body.</p><p>There were always many sickly people among those who poetize and are addicted to God; with rage they hate the knowing ones and that youngest of virtues which is called honesty.</p><p>Backward they look always toward darker times, for then, truly, delusion and faith were another matter. Raving of reason was next to godliness, and doubting was sin.</p><p>All too well I know these next-to-godliness types: they want people to believe in them, and that doubting is sin. All too well I know also what they themselves believe in most.</p><p>Indeed, not in hinterworlds and redeeming blood drops, but instead they too believe most in the body, and their own body is to them their thing in itself.</p><p>But to them it is a sickly thing, and gladly would they jump out of their skin. Hence they listen to the preachers of death and they preach of hinterworlds themselves.</p><p>Hear my brothers, hear the voice of the healthy body: a more honest and purer voice is this.</p><p>More honestly and more purely speaks the healthy body, the perfect and perpendicular body, and it speaks of the meaning of the earth.</p><p>Thus spoke Zarathustra.</p>", "article_json": {"type": "doc", "content": [{"type": "heading", "attrs": {"level": 2}, "content": [{"text": "On the Hinterworldly", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "content": [{"text": "Once Zarathustra too cast his delusion beyond humans, like all hinterworldly. At that time the world seemed to me the work of a suffering and tortured god.\r\n\r\nThen the world seemed a dream to me and the fiction of a god; colorful smoke before the eyes of a divine dissatisfied being.\r\n\r\nGood and evil and joy and suffering and I and you \u2013 colorful smoke it seemed to me before creative eyes. The creator wanted to look away from himself and so he created the world.\r\n\r\nIt is drunken joy to the suffering one to look away from one\u2019s suffering and to lose oneself. Drunken joy and losing-oneself the world once seemed to me.\r\n\r\nThis world, the eternally imperfect, the mirror image and imperfect image of an eternal contradiction \u2013 a drunken joy to its imperfect creator: thus the world once seemed to me.\r\n\r\nSo I too once cast my delusion beyond humans, like all hinterworldly. Beyond humans in truth?\r\n\r\nOh my brothers, this god that I created was of human make and mad- ness, like all gods!\r\n\r\nHuman he was, and only a poor flake of human and ego. From my own ash and ember it came to me, this ghost, and truly! It did not come to me from beyond!\r\n\r\nWhat happened, my brothers? I overcame myself, my suffering self, I carried my own ashes to the mountain, I invented a brighter flame for myself and behold! The ghost shrank from me!\r\n\r\nNow it would be suffering and torture for the convalesced one to believe in such ghosts. Now it would be suffering and humiliation. Thus I speak to the hinterworldly.\r\n\r\nIt was suffering and incapacity that created all hinterworlds, and that brief madness of happiness that only the most suffering person experiences.\r\n\r\nWeariness that wants its ultimate with one great leap, with a death leap; a poor unknowing weariness that no longer even wants to will: that created all gods and hinterworlds.\r\n\r\nBelieve me, my brothers! It was the body that despaired of the body \u2013 it probed with the fingers of a befooled spirit on the walls of the ultimate.\r\n\r\nBelieve me, my brothers! It was the body that despaired of the earth \u2013 then it heard the belly of being speaking to it.\r\n\r\nAnd then it wanted to break head first through the ultimate walls, and not only with its head, beyond to \u201cthe other world.\u201d\r\n\r\nBut \u201cthe other world\u201d is well hidden from humans, that dehumaned, inhuman world that is a heavenly nothing. And the belly of being does not speak at all to humans, unless as a human.\r\n\r\nIndeed, all being is hard to prove and hard to coax to speech. Tell me, my brothers, is not the strangest of all things still proven best?\r\n\r\nYes, this ego and the ego\u2019s contradiction and confusion still speak most honestly about its being; this creating, willing, valuing ego which is the measure and value of things.\r\n\r\nAnd this most honest being, this ego \u2013 it speaks of love and it still wants the body, even when it poetizes and fantasizes and flutters with broken wings.\r\n\r\nIt learns to speak ever more honestly, this ego. And the more it learns, the more it finds words and honors for the body and the earth.\r\n\r\nMy ego taught me a new pride, I teach it to mankind: no longer bury your head in the sand of heavenly things, but bear it freely instead, an earthly head that creates a meaning for the earth!\r\n\r\nI teach mankind a new will: to want the path that human beings have traveled blindly, to pronounce it good and no longer sneak to the side of it like the sick and the dying-out.\r\n\r\nIt was the sick and the dying-out who despised the body and the earth and invented the heavenly and its redeeming drops of blood. But even these sweet and shadowy poisons they took from the body and the earth!\r\n\r\nThey wanted to escape their misery and the stars were too distant for them. So they sighed \u201cOh if only there were heavenly paths on which to sneak into another being and happiness!\u201d \u2013 Then they invented their schemes and bloody little drinks!\r\n\r\nNow they fancied themselves detached from this earth, these ingrates. But what did they have to thank for the fits and bliss of their detachment? Their body and this earth.\r\n\r\nZarathustra is gentle to the sick. Indeed, he is not angered by their ways of comfort and ingratitude. May they become convalescents and overcomers and create for themselves a higher body!\r\n\r\nNor is he angered by the convalescent when he tenderly gazes upon his delusion and sneaks around the grave of his God at midnight. But to me even his tears remain sickness and sick body.\r\n\r\nThere were always many sickly people among those who poetize and are addicted to God; with rage they hate the knowing ones and that youngest of virtues which is called honesty.\r\n\r\nBackward they look always toward darker times, for then, truly, delusion and faith were another matter. Raving of reason was next to godliness, and doubting was sin.\r\n\r\nAll too well I know these next-to-godliness types: they want people to believe in them, and that doubting is sin. All too well I know also what they themselves believe in most.\r\n\r\nIndeed, not in hinterworlds and redeeming blood drops, but instead they too believe most in the body, and their own body is to them their thing in itself.\r\n\r\nBut to them it is a sickly thing, and gladly would they jump out of their skin. Hence they listen to the preachers of death and they preach of hinterworlds themselves.\r\n\r\nHear my brothers, hear the voice of the healthy body: a more honest and purer voice is this.\r\n\r\nMore honestly and more purely speaks the healthy body, the perfect and perpendicular body, and it speaks of the meaning of the earth.\r\n\r\nThus spoke Zarathustra."}, "id": 18}, {"data": {"uuid": "1c48ddd8-096e-4dcd-8bdc-3a2080336469", "user": 1, "title": "On the Despisers of the Body", "created_on": "2023-05-10 14:09:18.619158+00:00", "updated_on": "2023-05-10 14:09:18.633258+00:00", "article_html": "<h2>On the Despisers of the Body</h2><p>To the despisers of the body I want to say my words. I do not think they should relearn and teach differently, instead they should bid their own bodies farewell \u2013 and thus fall silent.</p><p>\u201cBody am I and soul\u201d \u2013 so speaks a child. And why should one not speak like children?</p><p>But the awakened, the knowing one says: body am I through and through, and nothing besides; and soul is just a word for something on the body.</p><p>The body is a great reason, a multiplicity with one sense, a war and a peace, one herd and one shepherd.</p><p>Your small reason, what you call \u201cspirit\u201d is also a tool of your body, my brother, a small work- and plaything of your great reason.</p><p>\u201cI\u201d you say and are proud of this word. But what is greater is that in which you do not want to believe \u2013 your body and its great reason. It does not say I, but does I.</p><p>What the sense feels, what the spirit knows, in itself that will never have an end. But sense and spirit would like to persuade you that they are the end of all things: so vain are they.</p><p>Work- and plaything are sense and spirit, behind them still lies the self. The self also seeks with the eyes of the senses, it listens also with the ears of the spirit.</p><p>Always the self listens and seeks: it compares, compels, conquers, destroys. It rules and is also the ruler of the ego.</p><p>Behind your thoughts and feelings, my brother, stands a powerful com- mander, an unknown wise man \u2013 he is called self. He lives in your body, he is your body.</p><p>There is more reason in your body than in your best wisdom. And who knows then to what end your body requires precisely your best wisdom?</p><p>Your self laughs at your ego and its proud leaps. \u201cWhat are these leaps and flights of thought to me?\u201d it says to itself. \u201cA detour to my purpose. I am the leading strings of the ego and the prompter of its concepts.\u201d</p><p>The self says to the ego: \u201cFeel pain here!\u201d And then it suffers and reflects on how it might suffer no more \u2013 and just for that purpose it is supposed to think.</p><p>The self says to the ego: \u201cFeel pleasure here!\u201d Then it is pleased and reflects on how it might feel pleased more often \u2013 and for that purpose it is supposed to think!</p><p>To the despisers of the body I want to say a word. That they disrespect is based on their respect. What is it that created respect and disrespect and value and will?</p><p>The creative self created respect and disrespect for itself, it created pleasure and pain for itself. The creative body created spirit for itself as the hand of its will.</p><p>Even in your folly and your contempt, you despisers of the body, you serve your self. I say to you: your self itself wants to die and turns away from life.</p><p>No longer is it capable of that which it wants most: to create beyond itself. This it wants most of all, this is its entire fervor. But now it is too late for that, and so your self wants to go under, you despisers of the body.</p><p>Your self wants to go under, and for this reason you became despisers of the body! For you no longer are capable of creating beyond yourselves.</p><p>And that is why you are angry now at life and earth. There is an unknown envy in the looking askance of your contempt.</p><p>I will not go your way, you despisers of the body! You are not my bridges to the overman! \u2013</p><p>Thus spoke Zarathustra.</p>", "article_json": {"type": "doc", "content": [{"type": "heading", "attrs": {"level": 2}, "content": [{"text": "On the Despisers of the Body", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "content": [{"text": "To the despisers of the body I want to say my words. Now you have her name in common with the people and have become the people and the herd with your virtue!</p><p>You would do better to say: \u201cUnspeakable and nameless is that which causes my soul agony and sweetness and is even the hunger of my entrails.\u201d</p><p>Let your virtue be too high for the familiarity of names, and if you must speak of it, then do not be ashamed to stammer about it.</p><p>Then speak and stammer: \u201cThis is my good, I love this, thus I like it entirely, thus alone do I want the good.</p><p>I do not want it as a divine law, I do not want is as a human statute and requirement. It shall be no signpost for me to overearths and paradises.</p><p>It is an earthly virtue that I love: there is little prudence in it and least of all the reason of the many.</p><p>But this bird built its nest in my house, therefore I love and caress it, now it sits next to me on its golden eggs.\u201d</p><p>Thus you should stammer and praise your virtue.</p><p>Once you had passions and named them evil. But now you have only your virtues: they grew out of your passions.</p><p>You set your highest goal at the heart of these passions, and then they became your virtues and passions of pleasure.</p><p>And whether you stemmed from the clan of the irascible or the lasciv- ious or the fanatic or the vengeful:</p><p>Ultimately all your passions became virtues and all your devils became angels.</p><p>Once you had wild dogs in your cellar, but ultimately they transformed into birds and lovely singers.</p><p>Out of your poisons you brewed your balsam; your cow, melancholy, you milked \u2013 now you drink the sweet milk of its udder.</p><p>And now nothing evil grows anymore out of you, unless it is the evil that grows from the struggle among your virtues.</p><p>My brother, if you are lucky then you have one virtue and no more: thus will you go more easily over the bridge.</p><p>It is distinguishing to have many virtues, but it is a hard lot. And many went into the desert and killed themselves because they were weary of being the battle and battlefield of virtues. My brother, are war and battle evil? But this evil is necessary, envy and mistrust and slander among your virtues are necessary.</p><p>Look, how each of your virtues is greedy for the highest. It wants your entire spirit, to be its herald; it wants your entire strength in rage, hatred and love.</p><p>Each virtue is jealous of the other, and jealousy is a terrible thing. Even virtues can perish of jealousy.</p><p>Whoever is ringed by the flame of jealousy in the end will turn his poisonous stinger upon himself, like the scorpion.</p><p>Oh my brother, have you never seen a virtue slander and stab itself?</p><p>Human being is something that must be overcome, and therefore you should love your virtues \u2013 for of them you will perish. \u2013</p><p>Thus spoke Zarathustra.</p>", "article_json": {"type": "doc", "content": [{"type": "heading", "attrs": {"level": 2}, "content": [{"text": "On the Passions of Pleasure and Pain", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "content": [{"text": "My brother, if you have one virtue, and it is your virtue, then you have it in common with no one.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "content": [{"text": "To be sure, you want to call her by name and caress her; you want to tug at her ear and have fun with her.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "content": [{"text": "And behold! Now you have her name in common with the people and have become the people and the herd with your virtue!\r\n\r\nYou would do better to say: \u201cUnspeakable and nameless is that which causes my soul agony and sweetness and is even the hunger of my entrails.\u201d\r\n\r\nLet your virtue be too high for the familiarity of names, and if you must speak of it, then do not be ashamed to stammer about it.\r\n\r\nThen speak and stammer: \u201cThis is my good, I love this, thus I like it entirely, thus alone do I want the good.\r\n\r\nI do not want it as a divine law, I do not want is as a human statute and requirement. It shall be no signpost for me to overearths and paradises.\r\n\r\nIt is an earthly virtue that I love: there is little prudence in it and least of all the reason of the many.\r\n\r\nBut this bird built its nest in my house, therefore I love and caress it, now it sits next to me on its golden eggs.\u201d\r\n\r\nThus you should stammer and praise your virtue.\r\n\r\nOnce you had passions and named them evil. But now you have only your virtues: they grew out of your passions.\r\n\r\nYou set your highest goal at the heart of these passions, and then they became your virtues and passions of pleasure.\r\n\r\nAnd whether you stemmed from the clan of the irascible or the lasciv- ious or the fanatic or the vengeful:\r\n\r\nUltimately all your passions became virtues and all your devils became angels.\r\n\r\nOnce you had wild dogs in your cellar, but ultimately they transformed into birds and lovely singers.\r\n\r\nOut of your poisons you brewed your balsam; your cow, melancholy, you milked \u2013 now you drink the sweet milk of its udder.\r\n\r\nAnd now nothing evil grows anymore out of you, unless it is the evil that grows from the struggle among your virtues.\r\n\r\nMy brother, if you are lucky then you have one virtue and no more: thus will you go more easily over the bridge.\r\n\r\nIt is distinguishing to have many virtues, but it is a hard lot. And many went into the desert and killed themselves because they were weary of being the battle and battlefield of virtues. My brother, are war and battle evil? But this evil is necessary, envy and mistrust and slander among your virtues are necessary.\r\n\r\nLook, how each of your virtues is greedy for the highest. It wants your entire spirit, to be its herald; it wants your entire strength in rage, hatred and love.\r\n\r\nEach virtue is jealous of the other, and jealousy is a terrible thing. Even virtues can perish of jealousy.\r\n\r\nWhoever is ringed by the flame of jealousy in the end will turn his poisonous stinger upon himself, like the scorpion.\r\n\r\nOh my brother, have you never seen a virtue slander and stab itself?\r\n\r\nHuman being is something that must be overcome, and therefore you should love your virtues \u2013 for of them you will perish. \u2013\r\n\r\nThus spoke Zarathustra."}, "id": 20}, {"data": {"uuid": "82fffcf6-ef05-4499-881f-43625a0a2333", "user": 1, "title": "On the Pale Criminal", "created_on": "2023-05-10 14:14:20.150489+00:00", "updated_on": "2023-05-10 14:14:20.167007+00:00", "article_html": "<h2>On the Pale Criminal</h2><p>You do want to kill, you judges and sacrificers, until the animal has nodded? Behold, the pale criminal has nodded: from his eyes speaks the great contempt.</p><p>\u201cMy ego is something that shall be overcome: my ego is to me the great contempt for mankind,\u201d so speak these eyes.</p><p>That he condemned himself was his highest moment: do not allow the sublime one to return to his baseness!</p><p>There is no redemption for one who suffers so from himself, unless it were the quick death.</p><p>Your killing, you judges, should be pity and not revenge. And insofar as you kill, see to it that you yourselves justify life!</p><p>It is not enough that you reconcile yourself with the one you kill. Let your sadness be love for the overman \u2013 thus you justify that you still live!</p><p>\u201cEnemy\u201d you should say, but not \u201cvillain\u201d; \u201csick man\u201d you should say, but not \u201cscoundrel\u201d; \u201cfool\u201d you should say, but not \u201csinner.\u201d</p><p>And you, red judge, if you were to speak aloud all the things you have already done in your thoughts, then everyone would cry: \u201cAway with this filth and poisonous worm!\u201d</p><p>But thought is one thing, and deed another, and the image of a deed yet another. The wheel of motive does not roll between them.</p><p>An image made this pale human pale. He was equal to his deed when he committed it, but he could not bear its image once he had done it.</p><p>From then on he always saw himself as the doer of one deed. I call this madness: the exception reversed itself to the essence.</p><p>A streak in the dirt stops a hen cold; the stroke he executed stopped his poor reason cold \u2013 madness after the deed I call this.</p><p>Listen, you judges! There is still another madness, and it is before the deed. Oh, you did not crawl deeply enough into this soul!</p><p>Thus speaks the red judge: \u201cWhy did this criminal kill? He wanted to rob.\u201d But I say to you: his soul wanted blood, not robbery. He thirsted for the bliss of the knife!</p><p>But his poor reason did not comprehend this madness and it persuaded him. \u201cWhat does blood matter?\u201d it said. \u201cDon\u2019t you at least want to commit robbery in the process? Take revenge?\u201d</p><p>And so he listened to his poor reason, like lead its speech lay upon him \u2013 and he robbed as he murdered. He did not want to be ashamed of his madness.</p><p>And now the lead of his guilt lies on him again, and again his poor reason is so stiff, so paralyzed, so heavy.</p><p>If only he could shake his head, then his burden would roll off \u2013 but who could shake this head?</p><p>What is this human being? A pile of illnesses that reach out into the world through his spirit: there they seek their prey.</p><p>What is this human being? A ball of wild snakes that seldom have peace from each other \u2013 so they go forth for themselves and seek prey in the world.</p><p>Behold this poor body! What it suffered and craved this poor soul interpreted for itself \u2013 it interpreted it as murderous lust and greed for the bliss of the knife.</p><p>Whoever grows ill now is befallen by the evil that is evil now; he wants to hurt with that which makes him hurt. But there have been other ages and another evil and good.</p><p>Once doubt was evil and the will to self. Back then sick people became heretics and witches: as heretics and witches they suffered and wanted to cause suffering.</p><p>But this does not want to get to your ears: it harms your good people, you say to me. But what matter your good people to me!</p><p>There is much about your good people that makes me disgusted, and verily not their evil. I wish they had a madness from which they would perish, like this pale criminal!</p><p>Indeed, I wish their madness were called truth or loyalty or justice \u2013 but they have their virtue in order to live long and in pitiful contentment.</p><p>I am a railing by the torrent: grasp me whoever is able to grasp me! But your crutch I am not. \u2013</p><p>Thus spoke Zarathustra.</p>", "article_json": {"type": "doc", "content": [{"type": "heading", "attrs": {"level": 2}, "content": [{"text": "On the Pale Criminal", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "content": [{"text": "You do want to kill, you judges and sacrificers, until the animal has nodded? Write with blood, and you will experience that blood is spirit.</p><p>It is not easily possible to understand the blood of another: I hate the reading idlers.</p><p>Whoever knows the reader will do nothing more for the reader. One more century of readers \u2013 and the spirit itself will stink.</p><p>That everyone is allowed to learn to read ruins not only writing in the long run, but thinking too.</p><p>Once the spirit was God, then it became human and now it is even becoming rabble.</p><p>Whoever writes in blood and proverbs does not want to be read, but to be learned by heart.</p><p>In the mountains the shortest way is from peak to peak, but for that one must have long legs. Proverbs should be peaks, and those who are addressed should be great and tall.</p><p>The air thin and pure, danger near and the spirit full of cheerful spite: these fit together well.</p><p>I want to have goblins around me, for I am courageous. Courage that scares off ghosts creates its own goblins \u2013 courage wants to laugh.</p><p>I no longer sympathize with you; this cloud beneath me, this black and heavy thing at which I laugh \u2013 precisely this is your thundercloud.</p><p>You look upward when you long for elevation. And I look down because I am elevated.</p><p>Who among you can laugh and be elevated at the same time?</p><p>Whoever climbs the highest mountain laughs at all tragic plays and tragic realities.</p><p>Courageous, unconcerned, sarcastic, violent \u2013 thus wisdom wants us: she is a woman and always loves only a warrior.</p><p>You say to me: \u201cLife is hard to bear.\u201d But why would you have your pride in the morning and your resignation in the evening?</p><p>Life is hard to bear: but then do not carry on so tenderly! We are all of us handsome, load bearing jack- and jillasses.</p><p>What have we in common with the rosebud that trembles because a drop of dew lies on its body?</p><p>It is true: we love life not because we are accustomed to life but because we are accustomed to love.</p><p>There is always some madness in love. But there is also always some reason in madness.</p><p>And even to me, one who likes life, it seems butterflies and soap bubbles and whatever is of their kind among human beings know most about happiness.</p><p>To see these light, foolish, delicate, sensitive little souls fluttering \u2013 that seduces Zarathustra to tears and songs.</p><p>I would only believe in a god who knew how to dance.</p><p>And when I saw my devil, there I found him earnest, thorough, deep, somber: it was the spirit of gravity \u2013 through him all things fall.</p><p>Not by wrath does one kill, but by laughing. Up, let us kill the spirit of gravity!</p><p>I learned to walk, since then I let myself run. I learned to fly, since then I do not wait to be pushed to move from the spot.</p><p>Now I am light, now I fly, now I see myself beneath me, now a god dances through me.</p><p>Thus spoke Zarathustra.</p>", "article_json": {"type": "doc", "content": [{"type": "heading", "attrs": {"level": 2}, "content": [{"text": "On Reading and Writing", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "content": [{"text": "Of all that is written I love only that which one writes with his blood.
