Then an adder came along and bit him in the neck, so that Zarathustra cried out in pain. When he had taken his arm from his face he looked at the snake; it recognized the eyes of Zarathustra, turned around awkwardly and tried to get away. \u201cNot so fast,\u201d spoke Zarathustra. \u201cYou have not yet accepted my thanks! You waked me in time, my way is still long.\u201d \u201cYour way is still short,\u201d said the adder sadly: \u201cMy poison kills.\u201d Zarathustra smiled. \u201cSince when did a dragon ever die of snake poison?\u201d he said. \u201cBut take back your poison! You are not rich enough to give it to me.\u201d Then the snake fell upon his neck once again and licked his wound.</p><p>When Zarathustra once told this to his disciples they asked: \u201cAnd what, oh Zarathustra, is the moral of your story?\u201d To which Zarathustra responded thus:</p><p>\u201cThe annihilator of morals the good and just call me: my story is immoral.</p><p>If you should have an enemy, then do not requite him evil with good, for that would shame him. Instead prove that he has does you some good.</p><p>And be angry rather than shaming someone! And if you are cursed at, I do not like it that you want to bless. Better to curse along a bit!</p><p>And if a great wrong befell you, then quickly add five small ones to it! Ghastly to behold is a person who suffers a wrong all by himself.</p><p>Did you know this already? A wrong shared is half a right. And the one who should take a wrong upon himself is the one who can bear it!</p><p>A small revenge is more humane than no revenge at all. And if the punishment is not also a right and an honor for the transgressor, then I do not like your punishing either.</p><p>It is more noble to pronounce oneself wrong than to remain right, especially if one is right. Only one has to be rich enough for that.</p><p>I do not like your cold justice; and from the eyes of your judges gazes always the executioner and his cold steel.</p><p>Tell me, where is the justice found that is love with seeing eyes?</p><p>Then invent me the kind of love that not only bears all punishment but also all guilt!</p><p>Then invent me the kind of justice that pardons everyone, except the one who judges!</p><p>And do you want to hear this too? In the person who would be thor- oughly just, even lies become philanthropy.</p><p>But how could I want to be thoroughly just! How can I give to each his own! Let this be enough for me: I give to each my own.</p><p>Finally, my brothers, beware of doing wrong to any hermits! How could a hermit forget? How could he requite?</p><p>A hermit is like a deep well. It is easy to throw in a stone; but once it has sunk to the bottom, tell me: who would fetch it up again?</p><p>Beware of offending the hermit! But I ask you: are you a person who has a right to wish for a child?</p><p>Are you the victor, the self conqueror, the master of your senses, the ruler of your virtues? Thus I ask you.</p><p>Or do the animal and neediness speak out of your wish? Or loneliness? Or discord with yourself?</p><p>I want your victory and your freedom to long for a child. You should build living monuments to your victory and your liberation.</p><p>Your should build over and beyond yourself. But first I want you built yourselves, square in body and soul.</p><p>You should not only reproduce, but surproduce! May the garden of marriage help you to that!</p><p>You should create a higher body, a first movement, a wheel rolling out of itself \u2013 a creator you should create.</p><p>Marriage: that is what I call the will by two for creating the one who is more than those who created it. Respect for one another I call marriage, and respect for the one who wills such a willing.</p><p>Let this be the meaning and the truth of your marriage. But that which the far-too-many call marriage, these superfluous ones \u2013 oh, what do I call that?</p><p>Oh, this poverty of the soul by two! Oh, this filth of the soul by two!</p><p>Oh, this pitiful contentment by two!</p><p>Marriage they call all this; and they say their marriages are made in heaven.</p><p>Well, I do not like it, this heaven of the superfluous! No, I do not like them, these animals tangled in the heavenly net!</p><p>And may the God stay away from me who limps up to bless what he has not joined together!</p><p>Do not laugh at such marriages! Which child would not have reason to weep about its parents?</p><p>Worthy this man seemed to me, and ripe for the meaning of the earth; but when I saw his woman, the earth seemed to me a house for the senseless.</p><p>Indeed, I wish the earth would quake in convulsions whenever a saint and a goose mate.</p><p>This one went forth like a hero seeking truths, and finally he bagged himself a little dressed up lie. He calls it his marriage.</p><p>That one was socially reserved and a choosy chooser. But all at once he ruined his company once and for all: he calls it his marriage.</p><p>That one sought a maid with the virtues of an angel. But all at once he became the maid of a woman and now he even has to turn himself into an angel.</p><p>Cautious I found all buyers now, and all have cunning eyes. But even the cunning man still buys his wife in a poke.</p><p>Many brief follies \u2013 that is what you call love. And your marriage makes an end of many brief follies, as one long stupidity.</p><p>Your love of woman and woman\u2019s love of man, oh! If only it were compassion for suffering and for disguised gods! But mostly it is two animals discovering each other.</p><p>But even your best love is merely an ecstatic parable and a painful smolder. It is a torch that should light you to higher ways.</p><p>Over and beyond yourselves you must someday love! Thus learn first to love! And therefore you must drink the bitter cup of your love.</p><p>There is bitterness in the cup of even the best love: thus it causes longing for the overman, thus it causes your thirst, you creator!</p><p>Thirst for the creator, arrow and longing for the overman: speak, my brother, is this your will to marriage?</p><p>Holy I pronounce such a will and such a marriage. \u2013</p><p>Thus spoke Zarathustra.</p>", "article_json": {"type": "doc", "content": [{"type": "heading", "attrs": {"level": 2}, "content": [{"text": "On Child and Marriage", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "content": [{"text": "I have a question for you alone, my brother: like a plumb bob I cast this question into your soul, in order to know how deep it is.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "content": [{"text": "You are young and wish for a child and marriage for yourself. The doctrine still sounds strange: \u201cDie at the right time!\u201d</p><p>Die at the right time: thus Zarathustra teaches it.</p><p>To be sure, how could the person who never lives at the right time ever die at the right time? Would that he were never born! \u2013 Thus I advise the superfluous.</p><p>But even the superfluous boast about their dying, and even the hollowest nut still wants to be cracked.</p><p>Everyone regards dying as important; but death is not yet a festival. As of yet people have not learned how to consecrate the most beautiful festivals.</p><p>I show you the consummating death that becomes a goad and a promise to the living.</p><p>The consummated one dies his death, victorious, surrounded by those who hope and promise.</p><p>Thus one should learn to die; and there should be no festival where such a dying person does not swear oaths to the living!</p><p>To die thus is best; second best, however, is to die fighting and to squander a great soul.</p><p>But your grinning death, the one that creeps up like a thief and yet comes as master \u2013 it is hated as much by the fighter as by the victor.</p><p>My death I praise to you, the free death that comes to me because I want.</p><p>And when will I want it? \u2013 Whoever has a goal and an heir wants death at the right time for his goal and heir.</p><p>And out of reverence for his goal and heir he will no longer hang withered wreaths in the sanctuary of life.</p><p>Indeed, I do not want to be like the rope makers: they stretch out their threads and in doing so always walk backwards.</p><p>Some become too old even for their truths and victories; a toothless mouth no longer has the right to every truth.</p><p>And everyone who wants to have fame must take leave of honor from time to time and practice the difficult art of leaving \u2013 at the right time.</p><p>One must stop letting oneself be eaten when one tastes best; this is known by those who want to be loved for a long time.</p><p>There are sour apples, to be sure, whose lot demands that they wait for the last day of autumn; and immediately they become ripe, yellow and wrinkled.</p><p>With some the heart ages first and with others the mind. A few are hoary in their youth, but the late young stay long young.</p><p>For some life fails: a poisonous worm eats its way to their heart. Let them see to it that their dying succeeds all the more.</p><p>Some never become sweet, they rot already in summer. It is cowardice that keeps them clinging to the branch.</p><p>Far too many live and far too long they hang on their branches. Would that a storm came to shake all this rot and worm-food from the tree!</p><p>Would that preachers of the quick death came! They would be the right storms and shakers of the trees of life for me! But I hear only preaching of the slow death and patience with all things \u201cearthly.\u201d</p><p>Indeed, you preach patience with earthly things? It is the earthly things that have too much patience with you, you slanderers!</p><p>Truly, too early did that Hebrew die, the one who is honored by the preachers of slow death; and for many it has since become their doom that he died too early.</p><p>He still knew only tears and the melancholy of the Hebrews, together with the hatred of the good and just \u2013 the Hebrew Jesus; then longing for death overcame him.</p><p>If only he had remained in the desert and far away from the good and the just! Perhaps he would have learned to live and to love the earth \u2013 and even to laugh!</p><p>Believe me, my brothers! He died too early; he himself would have recanted his teaching if he had reached my age! He was noble enough for recanting!</p><p>But he had not yet matured. A youth loves immaturely, and immaturely too he hates mankind and earth. Still tethered and heavy to him are his mind and the wings of his spirit.</p><p>But in a man there is more child than in a youth, and less melancholy; he knows more about death and life.</p><p>Free for death and free in death, a sacred nay-sayer when it is no longer time for yes: thus he knows about death and life.</p><p>Do not allow your death to be a slander against mankind and earth, my friends: that I beseech of the honey of your soul.</p><p>In your dying your spirit and your virtue should still glow, like a sunset around the earth; or else your dying has failed you.</p><p>Thus I myself want to die, so that you my friends love the earth more for my sake; and I want to become earth again, so that I may have peace in the one who bore me.</p><p>Truly, Zarathustra had a goal, he threw his ball. Now you my friends are the heirs of my goal, to you I throw the golden ball.</p><p>More than anything I like to see you, my friends, throwing the golden ball! And so I linger yet a bit on earth: forgive me that!</p><p>Thus spoke Zarathustra.</p>", "article_json": {"type": "doc", "content": [{"type": "heading", "attrs": {"level": 2}, "content": [{"text": "On Free Death", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "content": [{"text": "Many die too late, and some die too early. The doctrine still sounds strange: \u201cDie at the right time!\u201d\r\n\r\nDie at the right time: thus Zarathustra teaches it.\r\n\r\nTo be sure, how could the person who never lives at the right time ever die at the right time? Would that he were never born! \u2013 Thus I advise the superfluous.\r\n\r\nBut even the superfluous boast about their dying, and even the hollowest nut still wants to be cracked.\r\n\r\nEveryone regards dying as important; but death is not yet a festival. As of yet people have not learned how to consecrate the most beautiful festivals.\r\n\r\nI show you the consummating death that becomes a goad and a promise to the living.\r\n\r\nThe consummated one dies his death, victorious, surrounded by those who hope and promise.\r\n\r\nThus one should learn to die; and there should be no festival where such a dying person does not swear oaths to the living!\r\n\r\nTo die thus is best; second best, however, is to die fighting and to squander a great soul.\r\n\r\nBut your grinning death, the one that creeps up like a thief and yet comes as master \u2013 it is hated as much by the fighter as by the victor.\r\n\r\nMy death I praise to you, the free death that comes to me because I want.\r\n\r\nAnd when will I want it? \u2013 Whoever has a goal and an heir wants death at the right time for his goal and heir.\r\n\r\nAnd out of reverence for his goal and heir he will no longer hang withered wreaths in the sanctuary of life.\r\n\r\nIndeed, I do not want to be like the rope makers: they stretch out their threads and in doing so always walk backwards.\r\n\r\nSome become too old even for their truths and victories; a toothless mouth no longer has the right to every truth.\r\n\r\nAnd everyone who wants to have fame must take leave of honor from time to time and practice the difficult art of leaving \u2013 at the right time.\r\n\r\nOne must stop letting oneself be eaten when one tastes best; this is known by those who want to be loved for a long time.\r\n\r\nThere are sour apples, to be sure, whose lot demands that they wait for the last day of autumn; and immediately they become ripe, yellow and wrinkled.\r\n\r\nWith some the heart ages first and with others the mind. A few are hoary in their youth, but the late young stay long young.\r\n\r\nFor some life fails: a poisonous worm eats its way to their heart. Let them see to it that their dying succeeds all the more.\r\n\r\nSome never become sweet, they rot already in summer. It is cowardice that keeps them clinging to the branch.\r\n\r\nFar too many live and far too long they hang on their branches. Would that a storm came to shake all this rot and worm-food from the tree!\r\n\r\nWould that preachers of the quick death came! They would be the right storms and shakers of the trees of life for me! But I hear only preaching of the slow death and patience with all things \u201cearthly.\u201d\r\n\r\nIndeed, you preach patience with earthly things? It is the earthly things that have too much patience with you, you slanderers!\r\n\r\nTruly, too early did that Hebrew die, the one who is honored by the preachers of slow death; and for many it has since become their doom that he died too early.\r\n\r\nHe still knew only tears and the melancholy of the Hebrews, together with the hatred of the good and just \u2013 the Hebrew Jesus; then longing for death overcame him.\r\n\r\nIf only he had remained in the desert and far away from the good and the just! Perhaps he would have learned to live and to love the earth \u2013 and even to laugh!\r\n\r\nBelieve me, my brothers! He died too early; he himself would have recanted his teaching if he had reached my age! He was noble enough for recanting!\r\n\r\nBut he had not yet matured. A youth loves immaturely, and immaturely too he hates mankind and earth. Still tethered and heavy to him are his mind and the wings of his spirit.\r\n\r\nBut in a man there is more child than in a youth, and less melancholy; he knows more about death and life.\r\n\r\nFree for death and free in death, a sacred nay-sayer when it is no longer time for yes: thus he knows about death and life.\r\n\r\nDo not allow your death to be a slander against mankind and earth, my friends: that I beseech of the honey of your soul.\r\n\r\nIn your dying your spirit and your virtue should still glow, like a sunset around the earth; or else your dying has failed you.\r\n\r\nThus I myself want to die, so that you my friends love the earth more for my sake; and I want to become earth again, so that I may have peace in the one who bore me.\r\n\r\nTruly, Zarathustra had a goal, he threw his ball. Now you my friends are the heirs of my goal, to you I throw the golden ball.\r\n\r\nMore than anything I like to see you, my friends, throwing the golden ball! And so I linger yet a bit on earth: forgive me that!\r\n\r\nThus spoke Zarathustra."}, "id": 36}, {"data": {"uuid": "61f44b62-3d65-49a9-8af6-b12476caece8", "user": 1, "title": "On the Bestowing Virtue", "created_on": "2023-05-10 14:28:24.348083+00:00", "updated_on": "2023-05-10 14:28:24.366703+00:00", "article_html": "<h2>On the Bestowing Virtue</h2><h3>1</h3><p>When Zarathustra had taken leave of the city, which was dear to his heart and whose name was The Motley Cow, many who called themselves his disciples followed him, and they provided him escort. Thus they came to a crossroads; then Zarathustra told them he wanted to walk alone now, for he was a friend of walking alone. In parting, however, his disciples presented him with a staff upon whose golden knob a snake encircled the sun. Zarathustra was delighted with the staff and leaned on it; then he spoke thus to his disciples.</p><p>Tell me now: how did gold come to have the highest value? Because it is uncommon and useless and gleaming and mild in its luster; it bestows itself always.</p><p>Only as the image of the highest virtue did gold come to have the highest value. Goldlike gleams the gaze of the bestower. Golden luster makes peace between moon and sun.</p><p>Uncommon is the highest virtue and useless, it is gleaming and mild in its luster: a bestowing virtue is the highest virtue.</p><p>Truly, I guess you well, my disciples: like me you strive for the bestowing virtue. What would you have in common with cats or wolves?</p><p>This is your thirst: to become sacrifices and gifts yourselves, and there- fore you thirst to amass all riches in your soul.</p><p>Insatiably your soul strives for treasures and gems, because your virtue is insatiable in wanting to bestow.</p><p>You compel all things to and into yourselves, so that they may gush back from your well as the gifts of your love.</p><p>Indeed, such a bestowing love must become a robber of all values, but hale and holy I call this selfishness.</p><p>There is another selfishness, one all too poor, a hungering one that always wants to steal; that selfishness of the sick, the sick selfishness.</p><p>With the eye of the thief it looks at all that gleams; with the greed of hunger it eyes those with ample food; and always it creeps around the table of the bestowers.</p><p>Sickness speaks out of such craving and invisible degeneration; the thieving greed of this selfishness speaks of a diseased body.</p><p>Tell me, my brothers: what do we regard as bad and worst? Is it not degeneration? \u2013 And we always diagnose degeneration where the bestowing soul is absent.</p><p>Upward goes our way, over from genus to super-genus. But a horror to us is the degenerating sense which speaks: \u201cEverything for me.\u201d</p><p>Upward flies our sense; thus it is a parable of our body, a parable of elevation. Such elevation parables are the names of the virtues.</p><p>Thus the body goes through history, becoming and fighting. And the spirit \u2013 what is it to the body? The herald of its fights and victories, companion and echo.</p><p>Parables are all names of good and evil: they do not express, they only hint. A fool who wants to know of them!</p><p>Pay attention, my brothers, to every hour where your spirit wants to speak in parables: there is the origin of your virtue.</p><p>There your body is elevated and resurrected; with its bliss it delights the spirit, which becomes creator and esteemer and lover and benefactor of all things.</p><p>When your heart flows broad and full like a river, a blessing and a danger to adjacent dwellers: there is the origin of your virtue.</p><p>When you are sublimely above praise and blame, and your will wants to command all things, as the will of a lover: there is the origin of your virtue.</p><p>When you despise pleasantness and the soft bed, and cannot bed down far enough away from the softies: there is the origin of your virtue.</p><p>When you are the ones who will with a single will, and this turning point of all need points to your necessity: there is the origin of your virtue.</p><p>Indeed, it is a new good and evil! Indeed, a new, deep rushing and the voice of a new spring!</p><p>It is power, this new virtue; it is a ruling thought and around it a wise soul: a golden sun and around it the snake of knowledge.</p><h3>2</h3><p>Here Zarathustra was silent for a while and looked with love at his disci- ples. Then he continued to speak thus \u2013 and his voice had transformed.</p><p>Remain faithful to the earth, my brothers, with the power of your virtue! Let your bestowing love and your knowledge serve the meaning of the earth! Thus I beg and beseech you.</p><p>Do not let it fly away from earthly things and beat against eternal walls with its wings! Oh, there has always been so much virtue that flew away!</p><p>Like me, guide the virtue that has flown away back to the earth \u2013 yes, back to the body and life: so that it may give the earth its meaning, a human meaning!</p><p>In a hundred ways thus far the spirit as well as virtue has flown away and failed. Oh, in our body now all this delusion and failure dwells: there they have become body and will.</p><p>In a hundred ways thus far spirit as well as virtue has essayed and erred. Indeed, human beings were an experiment. Alas, much ignorance and error have become embodied in us!</p><p>Not only the reason of millennia \u2013 their madness too breaks out in us. It is dangerous to be an heir.</p><p>Still we struggle step by step with the giant called accident, and over all humanity thus far nonsense has ruled, the sense-less.</p><p>Let your spirit and your virtue serve the meaning of the earth, my brothers: and the value of all things will be posited newly by you! Therefore you shall be fighters! Therefore you shall be creators!</p><p>Knowingly the body purifies itself; experimenting with knowledge it elevates itself; all instincts become sacred in the seeker of knowledge; the soul of the elevated one becomes gay.</p><p>Physician, help yourself: thus also you help your sick. Let that be his best help, that he sees with his own eyes the one who heals himself.</p><p>There are a thousand paths that have never yet been walked; a thousand healths and hidden islands of life. Human being and human earth are still unexhausted and undiscovered.</p><p>Wake and listen, you lonely ones! From the future come winds with secretive wingbeats; good tidings are issued to delicate ears.</p><p>You lonely of today, you withdrawing ones, one day you shall be a people: from you who have chosen yourselves a chosen people shall grow \u2013 and from them the overman.</p><p>Indeed, the earth shall yet become a site of recovery! And already a new fragrance lies about it, salubrious \u2013 and a new hope!</p><h3>3</h3><p>When Zarathustra had said these words, he grew silent like one who has</p><p>not spoken his last word. Long he weighed the staff in his hand, doubtfully.</p><p>Finally he spoke thus, and his voice had transformed.</p><p>\u201cAlone I go now, my disciples! You also should go now, and alone! Thus</p><p>I want it.</p><p>Indeed, I counsel you to go away from me and guard yourselves against Zarathustra! And even better: be ashamed of him! Perhaps he deceived you.</p><p>The person of knowledge must not only be able to love his enemies, but to hate his friends too.</p><p>One repays a teacher badly if one always remains a pupil only. And why would you not want to pluck at my wreath?</p><p>You revere me, but what if your reverence falls down some day? Beware that you are not killed by a statue!</p><p>You say you believe in Zarathustra? But what matters Zarathustra! You are my believers, but what matter all believers!</p><p>You had not yet sought yourselves, then you found me. All believers do this; that\u2019s why all faith amounts to so little.</p><p>Now I bid you lose me and find yourselves; and only when you have all denied me will I return to you.</p><p>Indeed, with different eyes, my brothers, will I then seek my lost ones; with a different love will I love you then.</p><p>And one day again you shall become my friends and children of a single hope; then I shall be with you a third time, to celebrate the great noon with you.</p><p>And that is the great noon, where human beings stand at the midpoint of their course between animal and overman and celebrate their way to evening as their highest hope: for it is the way to a new morning.</p><p>Then the one who goes under will bless himself, that he is one who crosses over; and the sun of his knowledge will stand at noon for him.</p><p>\u2018Dead are all gods: now we want the overman to live.\u2019 \u2013 Let this be our last will at the great noon!\u201d \u2013</p><p>Thus spoke Zarathustra.</p>", "article_json": {"type": "doc", "content": [{"type": "heading", "attrs": {"level": 2}, "content": [{"text": "On the Bestowing Virtue", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "heading", "attrs": {"level": 3}, "content": [{"text": "1", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "content": [{"text": "When Zarathustra had taken leave of the city, which was dear to his heart and whose name was The Motley Cow, many who called themselves his disciples followed him, and they provided him escort. Thus they came to a crossroads; then Zarathustra told them he wanted to walk alone now, for he was a friend of walking alone. In parting, however, his disciples presented him with a staff upon whose golden knob a snake encircled the sun. Zarathustra was delighted with the staff and leaned on it; then he spoke thus to his disciples.\r\n\r\nTell me now: how did gold come to have the highest value? Because it is uncommon and useless and gleaming and mild in its luster; it bestows itself always.\r\n\r\nOnly as the image of the highest virtue did gold come to have the highest value. Goldlike gleams the gaze of the bestower. Golden luster makes peace between moon and sun.\r\n\r\nUncommon is the highest virtue and useless, it is gleaming and mild in its luster: a bestowing virtue is the highest virtue.\r\n\r\nTruly, I guess you well, my disciples: like me you strive for the bestowing virtue. What would you have in common with cats or wolves?\r\n\r\nThis is your thirst: to become sacrifices and gifts yourselves, and there- fore you thirst to amass all riches in your soul.\r\n\r\nInsatiably your soul strives for treasures and gems, because your virtue is insatiable in wanting to bestow.\r\n\r\nYou compel all things to and into yourselves, so that they may gush back from your well as the gifts of your love.\r\n\r\nIndeed, such a bestowing love must become a robber of all values, but hale and holy I call this selfishness.\r\n\r\nThere is another selfishness, one all too poor, a hungering one that always wants to steal; that selfishness of the sick, the sick selfishness.\r\n\r\nWith the eye of the thief it looks at all that gleams; with the greed of hunger it eyes those with ample food; and always it creeps around the table of the bestowers.\r\n\r\nSickness speaks out of such craving and invisible degeneration; the thieving greed of this selfishness speaks of a diseased body.\r\n\r\nTell me, my brothers: what do we regard as bad and worst? Is it not degeneration? \u2013 And we always diagnose degeneration where the bestowing soul is absent.\r\n\r\nUpward goes our way, over from genus to super-genus. But a horror to us is the degenerating sense which speaks: \u201cEverything for me.\u201d\r\n\r\nUpward flies our sense; thus it is a parable of our body, a parable of elevation. Such elevation parables are the names of the virtues.\r\n\r\nThus the body goes through history, becoming and fighting. And the spirit \u2013 what is it to the body? The herald of its fights and victories, companion and echo.\r\n\r\nParables are all names of good and evil: they do not express, they only hint. A fool who wants to know of them!\r\n\r\nPay attention, my brothers, to every hour where your spirit wants to speak in parables: there is the origin of your virtue.\r\n\r\nThere your body is elevated and resurrected; with its bliss it delights the spirit, which becomes creator and esteemer and lover and benefactor of all things.\r\n\r\nWhen your heart flows broad and full like a river, a blessing and a danger to adjacent dwellers: there is the origin of your virtue.\r\n\r\nWhen you are sublimely above praise and blame, and your will wants to command all things, as the will of a lover: there is the origin of your virtue.\r\n\r\nWhen you despise pleasantness and the soft bed, and cannot bed down far enough away from the softies: there is the origin of your virtue.\r\n\r\nWhen you are the ones who will with a single will, and this turning point of all need points to your necessity: there is the origin of your virtue.\r\n\r\nIndeed, it is a new good and evil! Indeed, a new, deep rushing and the voice of a new spring!\r\n\r\nIt is power, this new virtue; it is a ruling thought and around it a wise soul: a golden sun and around it the snake of knowledge.\r\n\r\n2\r\n\r\nHere Zarathustra was silent for a while and looked with love at his disci- ples. Then he continued to speak thus \u2013 and his voice had transformed.\r\n\r\nRemain faithful to the earth, my brothers, with the power of your virtue! Let your bestowing love and your knowledge serve the meaning of the earth! Thus I beg and beseech you.\r\n\r\nDo not let it fly away from earthly things and beat against eternal walls with its wings! Oh, there has always been so much virtue that flew away!\r\n\r\nLike me, guide the virtue that has flown away back to the earth \u2013 yes, back to the body and life: so that it may give the earth its meaning, a human meaning!\r\n\r\nIn a hundred ways thus far the spirit as well as virtue has flown away and failed. Oh, in our body now all this delusion and failure dwells: there they have become body and will.\r\n\r\nIn a hundred ways thus far spirit as well as virtue has essayed and erred. Indeed, human beings were an experiment. Alas, much ignorance and error have become embodied in us!\r\n\r\nNot only the reason of millennia \u2013 their madness too breaks out in us. It is dangerous to be an heir.\r\n\r\nStill we struggle step by step with the giant called accident, and over all humanity thus far nonsense has ruled, the sense-less.\r\n\r\nLet your spirit and your virtue serve the meaning of the earth, my brothers: and the value of all things will be posited newly by you! Therefore you shall be fighters! Therefore you shall be creators!\r\n\r\nKnowingly the body purifies itself; experimenting with knowledge it elevates itself; all instincts become sacred in the seeker of knowledge; the soul of the elevated one becomes gay.\r\n\r\nPhysician, help yourself: thus also you help your sick. Let that be his best help, that he sees with his own eyes the one who heals himself.\r\n\r\nThere are a thousand paths that have never yet been walked; a thousand healths and hidden islands of life. Human being and human earth are still unexhausted and undiscovered.\r\n\r\nWake and listen, you lonely ones! From the future come winds with secretive wingbeats; good tidings are issued to delicate ears.\r\n\r\nYou lonely of today, you withdrawing ones, one day you shall be a people: from you who have chosen yourselves a chosen people shall grow \u2013 and from them the overman.\r\n\r\nIndeed, the earth shall yet become a site of recovery! And already a new fragrance lies about it, salubrious \u2013 and a new hope!\r\n\r\n3\r\n\r\nWhen Zarathustra had said these words, he grew silent like one who has\r\n\r\nnot spoken his last word. Long he weighed the staff in his hand, doubtfully.\r\n\r\nFinally he spoke thus, and his voice had transformed.\r\n\r\n\u201cAlone I go now, my disciples! You also should go now, and alone! Thus\r\n\r\nI want it.\r\n\r\nIndeed, I counsel you to go away from me and guard yourselves against Zarathustra! And even better: be ashamed of him! Perhaps he deceived you.\r\n\r\nThe person of knowledge must not only be able to love his enemies, but to hate his friends too.\r\n\r\nOne repays a teacher badly if one always remains a pupil only. And why would you not want to pluck at my wreath?\r\n\r\nYou revere me, but what if your reverence falls down some day? Beware that you are not killed by a statue!\r\n\r\nYou say you believe in Zarathustra? But what matters Zarathustra! You are my believers, but what matter all believers!\r\n\r\nYou had not yet sought yourselves, then you found me. All believers do this; that\u2019s why all faith amounts to so little.\r\n\r\nNow I bid you lose me and find yourselves; and only when you have all denied me will I return to you.\r\n\r\nIndeed, with different eyes, my brothers, will I then seek my lost ones; with a different love will I love you then.\r\n\r\nAnd one day again you shall become my friends and children of a single hope; then I shall be with you a third time, to celebrate the great noon with you.\r\n\r\nAnd that is the great noon, where human beings stand at the midpoint of their course between animal and overman and celebrate their way to evening as their highest hope: for it is the way to a new morning.\r\n\r\nThen the one who goes under will bless himself, that he is one who crosses over; and the sun of his knowledge will stand at noon for him.\r\n\r\n\u2018Dead are all gods: now we want the overman to live.\u2019 \u2013 Let this be our last will at the great noon!\u201d \u2013\r\n\r\nThus spoke Zarathustra."}, "id": 37}]}, {"data": {"uuid": "b488c649-dfa4-4899-b11f-7b67833f7447", "user": 1, "title": "Second Part", "created_on": "2023-05-10 15:19:01.875130+00:00", "updated_on": "2023-05-10 15:19:01.887164+00:00", "article_html": "<h1>Second Part</h1>", "article_json": {"type": "doc", "content": [{"type": "heading", "attrs": {"level": 1}, "content": [{"text": "Second Part", "type": "text"}]}]}, "article_text": "Second Part"}, "id": 38, "children": [{"data": {"uuid": "cffec51a-e886-4a1e-8b97-dbb9903a435f", "user": 1, "title": "The Child with the Mirror", "created_on": "2023-05-10 15:19:53.991551+00:00", "updated_on": "2023-05-10 15:19:54.005551+00:00", "article_html": "<h2>The Child with the Mirror</h2><p>At this time Zarathustra returned again to the mountains and to the solitude of his cave and withdrew from mankind, waiting like a sower who has cast his seeds. But his soul grew full of impatience and desire for those whom he loved, because he still had much to give them. For this is the hardest thing: to close the open hand out of love, and to preserve a sense of shame as a bestower.</p><p>Thus moons and years passed for the lonely one; but his wisdom grew and its fullness caused him pain.</p><p>But one morning he woke already before dawn, reflected for a long time on his bed and at last spoke to his heart:</p><p>What frightened me so in my dream that it waked me? Did not a child approach me carrying a mirror?</p><p>\u201cOh Zarathustra\u201d \u2013 spoke the child to me \u2013 \u201clook at yourself in the mirror!\u201d</p><p>But when I looked into the mirror I cried out, and my heart was shaken; for I did not see myself there, but a devil\u2019s grimace and scornful laughter.</p><p>Indeed, all too well I understand the dream\u2019s sign and warning: my teaching is in danger, weeds want to be wheat!</p><p>My enemies have become powerful and have distorted the image of my teaching, so that those dearest to me must be ashamed of the gifts I gave them.</p><p>My friends are lost to me; the hour has arrived to seek my lost ones! \u2013</p><p>With these words Zarathustra leaped to his feet, but not like a fright- ened person fighting for air, but instead more like a seer and a singer on whom the spirit has descended. In amazement his eagle and his snake looked at him, for like the dawn an impending happiness lay upon his face.</p><p>What just happened to me, my animals? \u2013 said Zarathustra. Am I not transformed? Did bliss not come to me like a storm wind?</p><p>Foolish is my happiness and it will speak foolish things: it is still too young \u2013 so have patience with it!</p><p>I am wounded by my happiness: all sufferers shall be physicians to me!</p><p>Once again I may descend to my friends and also to my enemies! Zarathustra may speak again and bestow and do what he loves best for loved ones!</p><p>My impatient love floods over in torrents, downward, toward sunrise and sunset. From silent mountains and thunderheads of pain my soul roars into the valleys.</p><p>Too long have I longed and gazed into the distance. Too long I belonged to solitude \u2013 thus I forgot how to be silent.</p><p>I have become mouth through and through, and a brook\u2019s bound- ing from high boulders: I want to plunge my speech down into the valleys.</p><p>And may my torrent of love plunge into impasses! How could a torrent not finally make its way to the sea!</p><p>Truly, there is a lake in me, a hermit-like and self-sufficient lake; but my torrent of love tears it along \u2013 down to the sea!</p><p>New ways I go, a new speech comes to me; I became weary, like all creators, of old tongues. My spirit no longer wants to wander on worn soles.</p><p>All speech runs too slowly for me: \u2013 I leap into your chariot, storm! And I shall whip even you with the whip of my malice!</p><p>Like a shout and a jubilation I want to journey over broad seas until I find the blessed isles where my friends dwell \u2013</p><p>And my enemies among them! How I love everyone now, with whom I may simply speak! Even my enemies belong to my bliss.</p><p>And when I want to mount my wildest horse, then my spear always helps me up best: it is the ever-ready servant of my foot \u2013</p><p>The spear I hurl against my enemies! How I thank my enemies that at last I may hurl it!</p><p>Too great was the tension of my cloud: between lightning peals of laughter I shall throw hail showers into the depths.</p><p>Violently my chest will heave then, violently it will blow its storm over mountains: thus relief comes to it.</p><p>Indeed, my happiness and my freedom come like a storm! But my enemies should believe the evil one is raging over their heads.</p><p>Indeed, you too will be frightened, my friends, because of my wild wisdom; and perhaps you will flee from it together with my enemies.</p><p>Oh, if only I understood how to lure you back with shepherds\u2019 flutes! Oh, if only my lioness-wisdom could learn to roar tenderly! And much we have already learned with each other!</p><p>My wild wisdom wound up pregnant on lonely mountains; on naked stones she bore her young, her youngest.</p><p>Now she runs foolishly through harsh desert and seeks and seeks gentle turf \u2013 my old wild wisdom!</p><p>Upon the gentle turf of your hearts, my friends! \u2013 upon your love she would like to bed her most beloved!</p><p>Thus spoke Zarathustra.</p>", "article_json": {"type": "doc", "content": [{"type": "heading", "attrs": {"level": 2}, "content": [{"text": "The Child with the Mirror", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "content": [{"text": "At this time Zarathustra returned again to the mountains and to the solitude of his cave and withdrew from mankind, waiting like a sower who has cast his seeds. I am a north wind to ripe figs.</p><p>Thus, like figs, these teachings fall to you, my friends: now drink their juice and their sweet flesh! It is autumn all around and pure sky and afternoon.</p><p>See what fullness is around us! And from such superabundance it is beautiful to look out upon distant seas.</p><p>Once people said God when they gazed upon distant seas; but now I have taught you to say: overman.</p><p>God is a conjecture, but I want that your conjecturing not reach further than your creating will.</p><p>Could you create a god? \u2013 Then be silent about any gods! But you could well create the overman.</p><p>Not you yourselves perhaps, my brothers! But you could recreate yourselves into fathers and forefathers of the overman: and this shall be your best creating! \u2013</p><p>God is a conjecture: but I want your conjecturing to be limited to what is thinkable.</p><p>Could you think a God? \u2013 But let this mean will to truth to you; that everything be transformed into what is humanly thinkable, humanly visible, humanly feelable! You should think your own senses to their conclusion!</p><p>And what you called world, that should first be created by you: your reason, your image, your will, your love itself it should become! And truly, for your own bliss, you seekers of knowledge!</p><p>And how would you bear life without this hope, you seekers of knowledge? Neither into the incomprehensible nor into the irrational could you have been born.</p><p>But to reveal my entire heart to you, my friends: if there were gods, how could I stand not to be a god! Therefore there are no gods.</p><p>I drew this conclusion to be sure; but now it draws me. \u2013</p><p>God is a conjecture: but who could drink all the agony of this conjecture without dying? Should the creating person\u2019s faith be taken, and from the eagle its soaring in eagle heights?</p><p>God is a thought that makes crooked everything that is straight, and causes everything that stands to turn. What? Should time be gone, and all that is not everlasting be merely a lie?</p><p>To think this causes whirling and dizziness to human bones and even vomiting to the stomach: indeed, the turning disease I call it, to conjecture such things.</p><p>Evil I call it and misanthropic: all this teaching of the one and the plenum and the unmoved and the sated and the everlasting!</p><p>All that is everlasting \u2013 that is merely a parable! And the poets lie too much.</p><p>But the best parables should speak about time and becoming: they should be praise and justification of all that is not everlasting!</p><p>Creating \u2013 that is the great redemption from suffering, and life\u2019s becoming light. But in order for the creator to be, suffering is needed and much transformation.</p><p>Indeed, much bitter dying must be in your life, you creators! Therefore you are advocates and justifiers of all that is not everlasting.</p><p>In order for the creator himself to be the child who is newly born, he must also want to be the birth-giver and the pain of giving birth.</p><p>Indeed, through a hundred souls I went my way and through a hundred cradles and pangs of birth. Many a farewell have I taken already; I know the heartbreaking final hours.</p><p>But thus my creating will wills it, my destiny. Or, to tell it more honestly to you: just such a destiny \u2013 my will wills.</p><p>Everything that feels, suffers in me and is in prison; but my will always comes to me as my liberator and bringer of joy.</p><p>Willing liberates: that is the true teaching of will and liberty \u2013 thus Zarathustra teaches it.</p><p>No more willing and no more esteeming and no more creating! Oh, if only this great weariness would always keep away from me!</p><p>Even in knowing I feel only my will\u2019s lust to beget and to become; and if there is innocence in my knowledge, then this happens because the will to beget is in it.</p><p>Away from God and gods this will lured me; what would there be to create, after all, if there were gods?</p><p>But I am always driven anew to human beings by my ardent will to create; thus the hammer is driven toward the stone.</p><p>Oh you human beings, in the stone sleeps an image, the image of my images! A shame it must sleep in the hardest, ugliest stone!</p><p>Now my hammer rages cruelly against its prison. Shards shower from the stone: what do I care?</p><p>I want to perfect it, for a shadow came to me \u2013 the stillest and lightest of all things once came to me!</p><p>The overman\u2019s beauty came to me as a shadow. Oh, my brothers! Of what concern to me anymore \u2013 are gods! \u2013</p><p>Thus spoke Zarathustra.</p>", "article_json": {"type": "doc", "content": [{"type": "heading", "attrs": {"level": 2}, "content": [{"text": "On the Blessed Isles", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "content": [{"text": "The figs fall from the trees, they are good and sweet; and as they fall, their red skin ruptures. I am a north wind to ripe figs.\r\n\r\nThus, like figs, these teachings fall to you, my friends: now drink their juice and their sweet flesh! It is autumn all around and pure sky and afternoon.\r\n\r\nSee what fullness is around us! And from such superabundance it is beautiful to look out upon distant seas.\r\n\r\nOnce people said God when they gazed upon distant seas; but now I have taught you to say: overman.\r\n\r\nGod is a conjecture, but I want that your conjecturing not reach further than your creating will.\r\n\r\nCould you create a god? \u2013 Then be silent about any gods! But you could well create the overman.\r\n\r\nNot you yourselves perhaps, my brothers! But you could recreate yourselves into fathers and forefathers of the overman: and this shall be your best creating! \u2013\r\n\r\nGod is a conjecture: but I want your conjecturing to be limited to what is thinkable.\r\n\r\nCould you think a God? \u2013 But let this mean will to truth to you; that everything be transformed into what is humanly thinkable, humanly visible, humanly feelable! You should think your own senses to their conclusion!\r\n\r\nAnd what you called world, that should first be created by you: your reason, your image, your will, your love itself it should become! And truly, for your own bliss, you seekers of knowledge!\r\n\r\nAnd how would you bear life without this hope, you seekers of knowledge? Neither into the incomprehensible nor into the irrational could you have been born.\r\n\r\nBut to reveal my entire heart to you, my friends: if there were gods, how could I stand not to be a god! Therefore there are no gods.\r\n\r\nI drew this conclusion to be sure; but now it draws me. \u2013\r\n\r\nGod is a conjecture: but who could drink all the agony of this conjecture without dying? Should the creating person\u2019s faith be taken, and from the eagle its soaring in eagle heights?\r\n\r\nGod is a thought that makes crooked everything that is straight, and causes everything that stands to turn. What? Should time be gone, and all that is not everlasting be merely a lie?\r\n\r\nTo think this causes whirling and dizziness to human bones and even vomiting to the stomach: indeed, the turning disease I call it, to conjecture such things.\r\n\r\nEvil I call it and misanthropic: all this teaching of the one and the plenum and the unmoved and the sated and the everlasting!\r\n\r\nAll that is everlasting \u2013 that is merely a parable! And the poets lie too much.\r\n\r\nBut the best parables should speak about time and becoming: they should be praise and justification of all that is not everlasting!\r\n\r\nCreating \u2013 that is the great redemption from suffering, and life\u2019s becoming light. But in order for the creator to be, suffering is needed and much transformation.\r\n\r\nIndeed, much bitter dying must be in your life, you creators! Therefore you are advocates and justifiers of all that is not everlasting.\r\n\r\nIn order for the creator himself to be the child who is newly born, he must also want to be the birth-giver and the pain of giving birth.\r\n\r\nIndeed, through a hundred souls I went my way and through a hundred cradles and pangs of birth. Many a farewell have I taken already; I know the heartbreaking final hours.\r\n\r\nBut thus my creating will wills it, my destiny. Or, to tell it more honestly to you: just such a destiny \u2013 my will wills.\r\n\r\nEverything that feels, suffers in me and is in prison; but my will always comes to me as my liberator and bringer of joy.\r\n\r\nWilling liberates: that is the true teaching of will and liberty \u2013 thus Zarathustra teaches it.\r\n\r\nNo more willing and no more esteeming and no more creating! Oh, if only this great weariness would always keep away from me!\r\n\r\nEven in knowing I feel only my will\u2019s lust to beget and to become; and if there is innocence in my knowledge, then this happens because the will to beget is in it.\r\n\r\nAway from God and gods this will lured me; what would there be to create, after all, if there were gods?\r\n\r\nBut I am always driven anew to human beings by my ardent will to create; thus the hammer is driven toward the stone.\r\n\r\nOh you human beings, in the stone sleeps an image, the image of my images! A shame it must sleep in the hardest, ugliest stone!\r\n\r\nNow my hammer rages cruelly against its prison. Shards shower from the stone: what do I care?\r\n\r\nI want to perfect it, for a shadow came to me \u2013 the stillest and lightest of all things once came to me!\r\n\r\nThe overman\u2019s beauty came to me as a shadow. Oh, my brothers! Of what concern to me anymore \u2013 are gods! \u2013\r\n\r\nThus spoke Zarathustra."}, "id": 40}, {"data": {"uuid": "0e6d731c-0bcc-4896-9989-02f35abbfae2", "user": 1, "title": "On the Pitying", "created_on": "2023-05-10 15:21:34.653747+00:00", "updated_on": "2023-05-10 15:21:34.670380+00:00", "article_html": "<h2>On the Pitying</h2><p>My friends, a gibe was told to your friend: \u201cJust look at Zarathustra! Does he not wander among us like we were animals?\u201d</p><p>But it is better said this way: \u201cThe seeker of knowledge wanders among human beings as among animals.\u201d</p><p>Human beings themselves, however, the seeker of knowledge calls: the animal that has red cheeks.</p><p>How did this happen? Is it not because they have had to be ashamed so often?</p><p>Oh my friends! Thus speaks the seeker of knowledge: Shame, shame, shame \u2013 that is the history of human beings!</p><p>And that is why the noble person commands himself not to shame; shame he demands of himself before all sufferers.</p><p>Indeed, I do not like them, the merciful who are blissful in their pitying: they lack too much in shame.</p><p>If I must be pitying, then I certainly do not want to be called such; and if I am, then preferably from a distance.</p><p>Gladly would I cover my head and flee before I am recognized, and thus I bid you do as well, my friends!</p><p>May my destiny always lead those like you, who do not suffer, across my path, and those with whom I may share hope and meal and honey!</p><p>Indeed, I probably did this and that for sufferers, but I always seemed to do myself better when I learned to enjoy myself better.</p><p>Ever since there have been humans, the human being has enjoyed himself too little: That alone, my brothers, is our original sin!</p><p>And if we learn to enjoy ourselves better, then we forget best how to hurt others and plot hurt for them.</p><p>Therefore I wash the hand that helped the sufferer, therefore too I wipe even my soul.</p><p>For inasmuch as I saw the sufferer suffering, I was ashamed for the sake of his shame; and when I helped him I severely violated his pride.</p><p>Great indebtedness does not make people thankful, but vengeful instead; and if the small kindness is not forgotten then it will become a gnawing worm.</p><p>\u201cBe cold in accepting! Let your accepting serve to distinguish!\u201d \u2013 Thus I counsel those who have nothing to give away.</p><p>I, however, am a bestower. Gladly I bestow as friend to friends. But strangers and poor people may pluck the fruit from my tree themselves: that way there is less shame.</p><p>But beggars should be abolished completely! Indeed, one is angered in giving and angered in not giving to them.</p><p>And the same for sinners and bad consciences! Believe me, my friends, bites of conscience teach people to bite.</p><p>Worst, however, are petty thoughts. Indeed, better to do evil than to think small!</p><p>You say, to be sure: \u201cPleasure in small mischief saves us many a great evil deed.\u201d But here one should not want to save.</p><p>An evil deed is like a sore: it itches and scratches and ruptures \u2013 it speaks honestly.</p><p>\u201cBehold, I am sickness\u201d \u2013 thus speaks the evil deed, that is its honesty.</p><p>But a petty thought is like a fungus; it creeps and crouches and does not want to be anywhere \u2013 until the whole body is rotten and wilted with little fungi.</p><p>To the one who is possessed by the devil, however, I whisper these words in his ear: \u201cBetter to raise your devil until it is big! Even for you there is still a way to greatness!\u201d \u2013</p><p>Oh my brothers! One knows a bit too much about everyone! And though some become transparent to us, we can by no means pass through them on that account.</p><p>It is difficult to live with people because remaining silent is so difficult.</p><p>And we are not most unfair toward those who are repugnant to us, but toward those who do not at all concern us.</p><p>But if you have a suffering friend, then be a resting place to his suffering, yet at the same time a hard bed, a camp bed: thus you will be most useful to him.</p><p>And if a friend does evil to you, then say: \u201cI forgive you what you have done to me; but that you did it to yourself \u2013 how could I forgive that!\u201d</p><p>Thus speaks all great love; it overcomes even forgiveness and pitying.</p><p>One should hold on firmly to one\u2019s heart, for if one lets it go, how quickly one then loses one\u2019s head!</p><p>Oh, where in the world has greater folly occurred than among the pitying? And what in the world causes more suffering than the folly of the pitying?</p><p>Woe to all lovers who do not yet have an elevation that is above their pitying!</p><p>Thus the devil once spoke to me: \u201cEven God has his hell: it is his love for mankind.\u201d</p><p>And recently I heard him say these words: \u201cGod is dead; God died of his pity for mankind.\u201d</p><p>Thus I warn you against pity: from it a heavy cloud is coming to mankind! Indeed, I understand weather forecasting!</p><p>But note these words too: all great love is above even all its pitying, for it still wants to create the beloved!</p><p>\u201cI offer myself to my love, and my neighbor as myself\u201d \u2013 thus it is said of all creators.</p><p>But all creators are hard. \u2013</p><p>Thus spoke Zarathustra.</p>", "article_json": {"type": "doc", "content": [{"type": "heading", "attrs": {"level": 2}, "content": [{"text": "On the Pitying", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "content": [{"text": "My friends, a gibe was told to your friend: \u201cJust look at Zarathustra! Does he not wander among us like we were animals?\u201d\r\n\r\nBut it is better said this way: \u201cThe seeker of knowledge wanders among human beings as among animals.\u201d\r\n\r\nHuman beings themselves, however, the seeker of knowledge calls: the animal that has red cheeks.\r\n\r\nHow did this happen? Is it not because they have had to be ashamed so often?\r\n\r\nOh my friends! Thus speaks the seeker of knowledge: Shame, shame, shame \u2013 that is the history of human beings!\r\n\r\nAnd that is why the noble person commands himself not to shame; shame he demands of himself before all sufferers.\r\n\r\nIndeed, I do not like them, the merciful who are blissful in their pitying: they lack too much in shame.\r\n\r\nIf I must be pitying, then I certainly do not want to be called such; and if I am, then preferably from a distance.\r\n\r\nGladly would I cover my head and flee before I am recognized, and thus I bid you do as well, my friends!\r\n\r\nMay my destiny always lead those like you, who do not suffer, across my path, and those with whom I may share hope and meal and honey!\r\n\r\nIndeed, I probably did this and that for sufferers, but I always seemed to do myself better when I learned to enjoy myself better.\r\n\r\nEver since there have been humans, the human being has enjoyed himself too little: That alone, my brothers, is our original sin!\r\n\r\nAnd if we learn to enjoy ourselves better, then we forget best how to hurt others and plot hurt for them.\r\n\r\nTherefore I wash the hand that helped the sufferer, therefore too I wipe even my soul.\r\n\r\nFor inasmuch as I saw the sufferer suffering, I was ashamed for the sake of his shame; and when I helped him I severely violated his pride.\r\n\r\nGreat indebtedness does not make people thankful, but vengeful instead; and if the small kindness is not forgotten then it will become a gnawing worm.\r\n\r\n\u201cBe cold in accepting! Let your accepting serve to distinguish!\u201d \u2013 Thus I counsel those who have nothing to give away.\r\n\r\nI, however, am a bestower. Gladly I bestow as friend to friends. But strangers and poor people may pluck the fruit from my tree themselves: that way there is less shame.\r\n\r\nBut beggars should be abolished completely! Indeed, one is angered in giving and angered in not giving to them.\r\n\r\nAnd the same for sinners and bad consciences! Believe me, my friends, bites of conscience teach people to bite.\r\n\r\nWorst, however, are petty thoughts. Indeed, better to do evil than to think small!\r\n\r\nYou say, to be sure: \u201cPleasure in small mischief saves us many a great evil deed.\u201d But here one should not want to save.\r\n\r\nAn evil deed is like a sore: it itches and scratches and ruptures \u2013 it speaks honestly.\r\n\r\n\u201cBehold, I am sickness\u201d \u2013 thus speaks the evil deed, that is its honesty.\r\n\r\nBut a petty thought is like a fungus; it creeps and crouches and does not want to be anywhere \u2013 until the whole body is rotten and wilted with little fungi.\r\n\r\nTo the one who is possessed by the devil, however, I whisper these words in his ear: \u201cBetter to raise your devil until it is big! Even for you there is still a way to greatness!\u201d \u2013\r\n\r\nOh my brothers! One knows a bit too much about everyone! And though some become transparent to us, we can by no means pass through them on that account.\r\n\r\nIt is difficult to live with people because remaining silent is so difficult.\r\n\r\nAnd we are not most unfair toward those who are repugnant to us, but toward those who do not at all concern us.\r\n\r\nBut if you have a suffering friend, then be a resting place to his suffering, yet at the same time a hard bed, a camp bed: thus you will be most useful to him.\r\n\r\nAnd if a friend does evil to you, then say: \u201cI forgive you what you have done to me; but that you did it to yourself \u2013 how could I forgive that!\u201d\r\n\r\nThus speaks all great love; it overcomes even forgiveness and pitying.\r\n\r\nOne should hold on firmly to one\u2019s heart, for if one lets it go, how quickly one then loses one\u2019s head!\r\n\r\nOh, where in the world has greater folly occurred than among the pitying? And what in the world causes more suffering than the folly of the pitying?\r\n\r\nWoe to all lovers who do not yet have an elevation that is above their pitying!\r\n\r\nThus the devil once spoke to me: \u201cEven God has his hell: it is his love for mankind.\u201d\r\n\r\nAnd recently I heard him say these words: \u201cGod is dead; God died of his pity for mankind.\u201d\r\n\r\nThus I warn you against pity: from it a heavy cloud is coming to mankind! Indeed, I understand weather forecasting!\r\n\r\nBut note these words too: all great love is above even all its pitying, for it still wants to create the beloved!\r\n\r\n\u201cI offer myself to my love, and my neighbor as myself\u201d \u2013 thus it is said of all creators.\r\n\r\nBut all creators are hard. \u2013\r\n\r\nThus spoke Zarathustra."}, "id": 41}, {"data": {"uuid": "93ae12c4-8afb-4ad5-a3c3-b31d07203ff8", "user": 1, "title": "On Priests", "created_on": "2023-05-10 15:22:20.350884+00:00", "updated_on": "2023-05-10 15:22:20.365985+00:00", "article_html": "<h2>On Priests</h2><p>And once Zarathustra gave a sign to his disciples and spoke these words to them:</p><p>\u201cHere are priests, and though they are my enemies, go quietly past them and with sleeping swords!</p><p>Among them too there are heroes; many of them suffered too much, so they want to make others suffer.</p><p>They are evil enemies: nothing is more vengeful than their humility. And whoever attacks them is easily besmirched.</p><p>But my blood is related to theirs, and I want to know that my blood is honored even in theirs.\u201d</p><p>And when they had passed by Zarathustra was seized by pain; and not long had he wrestled with his pain when he rose and began to speak thus:</p><p>\u201cI feel for these priests. And though I also find them distasteful, that is the least of my concerns since I have been among human beings.</p><p>But I suffer and suffered with them; to me they are prisoners and marked men. The one they call redeemer clapped them in irons: \u2013</p><p>In irons of false values and words of delusion! Oh that someone would yet redeem them from their redeemer!</p><p>Once they believed they landed on an island as the sea tossed them around; but see, it was a sleeping monster!</p><p>False values and words of delusion: these are the worst monsters for mortals \u2013 long does doom sleep and wait in them.</p><p>But at last it comes and wakes and devours and gulps whatever built itself huts upon it.</p><p>Oh look at these huts that the priests built themselves! Churches they call their sweet smelling caves.</p><p>Oh how repulsive is this falsified light, this stale air! Here, where the soul to its height \u2013 is denied flight!</p><p>Instead their faith commands: \u2018Up the stairs on your knees, you sinners!\u2019</p><p>Indeed, I would rather see the shameless than the rolled back eyes of their shame and devotion!</p><p>Who created such caves and stairs of penitence? Were they not those who wanted to hide and were ashamed beneath the pure sky?</p><p>And only when the pure sky peeks again through broken ceilings and down upon grass and red poppy and broken walls \u2013 only then will I turn my heart again to the sites of this God.</p><p>They called God what contradicted and hurt them, and truly, there was much heroics in their adoration!</p><p>And they knew no other way to love their God than to nail the human being to a cross!</p><p>They intended to live as corpses, they decked out their corpse in black; from their speeches I still smell the rotten spice of death chambers.</p><p>And whoever lives near them lives near black ponds, out of which the toad sings its song with sweet melancholy.</p><p>Better songs they will have to sing for me before I learn to believe in their redeemer; more redeemed his disciples would have to look!</p><p>I would like to see them naked, for beauty alone should preach peni- tence. But who is persuaded anyway by this masked gloom!</p><p>Indeed, their redeemers themselves did not come from freedom and the freedom of seventh heaven! Indeed, they themselves never walked on the carpets of knowledge!</p><p>The spirit of these redeemers consisted of gaps; but into every gap they had plugged a delusion, their stopgap, whom they named God.</p><p>Their spirit drowned in their pitying, and when they swelled and overswelled with pity, always a great folly floated on top.</p><p>Zealously and with shouting they drove their herd along their path, as if there were only one path to the future! Indeed, these shepherds, too, still belonged among the sheep!</p><p>Small spirits and roomy souls these shepherds had, but my brothers; what small countries even the roomiest souls have been so far!</p><p>Blood-signs they wrote along the way that they walked, and their folly taught that one proves the truth with blood.</p><p>But blood is the worst witness of truth; blood poisons even the purest teaching into delusion and hatred of the heart.</p><p>And if someone goes through fire for his teaching \u2013 what does this prove? Indeed, it means more when one\u2019s own teaching comes out of one\u2019s own fire!</p><p>A sultry heart and a cold head: where these come together the howling wind originates, the \u2018redeemer.\u2019</p><p>There have been greater ones, to be sure, and higher born than those whom the people call redeemers, these sweeping howling winds!</p><p>And you must be redeemed even from those greater than all redeemers, my brothers, if you want to find your way to freedom!</p><p>Never yet has there been an overman. Naked I saw both, the greatest and the smallest human being \u2013</p><p>All too similar they are to one another. Truly, even the greatest I found \u2013 all too human!\u201d</p><p>Thus spoke Zarathustra.</p>", "article_json": {"type": "doc", "content": [{"type": "heading", "attrs": {"level": 2}, "content": [{"text": "On Priests", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "content": [{"text": "And once Zarathustra gave a sign to his disciples and spoke these words to them:", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "content": [{"text": "\u201cHere are priests, and though they are my enemies, go quietly past them and with sleeping swords!", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "content": [{"text": "Among them too there are heroes; many of them suffered too much, so they want to make others suffer.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "content": [{"text": "They are evil enemies: nothing is more vengeful than their humility. And whoever attacks them is easily besmirched.\r\n\r\nBut my blood is related to theirs, and I want to know that my blood is honored even in theirs.\u201d\r\n\r\nAnd when they had passed by Zarathustra was seized by pain; and not long had he wrestled with his pain when he rose and began to speak thus:\r\n\r\n\u201cI feel for these priests. And though I also find them distasteful, that is the least of my concerns since I have been among human beings.\r\n\r\nBut I suffer and suffered with them; to me they are prisoners and marked men. The one they call redeemer clapped them in irons: \u2013\r\n\r\nIn irons of false values and words of delusion! Oh that someone would yet redeem them from their redeemer!\r\n\r\nOnce they believed they landed on an island as the sea tossed them around; but see, it was a sleeping monster!\r\n\r\nFalse values and words of delusion: these are the worst monsters for mortals \u2013 long does doom sleep and wait in them.\r\n\r\nBut at last it comes and wakes and devours and gulps whatever built itself huts upon it.\r\n\r\nOh look at these huts that the priests built themselves! Churches they call their sweet smelling caves.\r\n\r\nOh how repulsive is this falsified light, this stale air! Here, where the soul to its height \u2013 is denied flight!\r\n\r\nInstead their faith commands: \u2018Up the stairs on your knees, you sinners!\u2019\r\n\r\nIndeed, I would rather see the shameless than the rolled back eyes of their shame and devotion!\r\n\r\nWho created such caves and stairs of penitence? Were they not those who wanted to hide and were ashamed beneath the pure sky?\r\n\r\nAnd only when the pure sky peeks again through broken ceilings and down upon grass and red poppy and broken walls \u2013 only then will I turn my heart again to the sites of this God.\r\n\r\nThey called God what contradicted and hurt them, and truly, there was much heroics in their adoration!\r\n\r\nAnd they knew no other way to love their God than to nail the human being to a cross!\r\n\r\nThey intended to live as corpses, they decked out their corpse in black; from their speeches I still smell the rotten spice of death chambers.\r\n\r\nAnd whoever lives near them lives near black ponds, out of which the toad sings its song with sweet melancholy.\r\n\r\nBetter songs they will have to sing for me before I learn to believe in their redeemer; more redeemed his disciples would have to look!\r\n\r\nI would like to see them naked, for beauty alone should preach peni- tence. But who is persuaded anyway by this masked gloom!\r\n\r\nIndeed, their redeemers themselves did not come from freedom and the freedom of seventh heaven! Indeed, they themselves never walked on the carpets of knowledge!\r\n\r\nThe spirit of these redeemers consisted of gaps; but into every gap they had plugged a delusion, their stopgap, whom they named God.\r\n\r\nTheir spirit drowned in their pitying, and when they swelled and overswelled with pity, always a great folly floated on top.\r\n\r\nZealously and with shouting they drove their herd along their path, as if there were only one path to the future! Indeed, these shepherds, too, still belonged among the sheep!\r\n\r\nSmall spirits and roomy souls these shepherds had, but my brothers; what small countries even the roomiest souls have been so far!\r\n\r\nBlood-signs they wrote along the way that they walked, and their folly taught that one proves the truth with blood.\r\n\r\nBut blood is the worst witness of truth; blood poisons even the purest teaching into delusion and hatred of the heart.\r\n\r\nAnd if someone goes through fire for his teaching \u2013 what does this prove? Indeed, it means more when one\u2019s own teaching comes out of one\u2019s own fire!\r\n\r\nA sultry heart and a cold head: where these come together the howling wind originates, the \u2018redeemer.\u2019\r\n\r\nThere have been greater ones, to be sure, and higher born than those whom the people call redeemers, these sweeping howling winds!\r\n\r\nAnd you must be redeemed even from those greater than all redeemers, my brothers, if you want to find your way to freedom!\r\n\r\nNever yet has there been an overman. Naked I saw both, the greatest and the smallest human being \u2013\r\n\r\nAll too similar they are to one another. Truly, even the greatest I found \u2013 all too human!\u201d\r\n\r\nThus spoke Zarathustra."}, "id": 42}, {"data": {"uuid": "8297ef9f-a5db-4923-85f9-b0083d7f790f", "user": 1, "title": "On the Virtuous", "created_on": "2023-05-10 15:23:02.084673+00:00", "updated_on": "2023-05-10 15:23:02.104540+00:00", "article_html": "<h2>On the Virtuous</h2><p>With thunder and heavenly fireworks one must speak to slack and sleeping senses.</p><p>But the voice of beauty speaks softly; it creeps only into the most awakened souls.</p><p>Softly today my shield trembled and laughed; it is the holy laughter and trembling of beauty.</p><p>At you, virtuous ones, my beauty laughed today. And thus its voice came to me: \u201cThey still want \u2013 to be paid!\u201d</p><p>You still want to be paid, you virtuous! Want to have reward for virtue, and heaven for earth, and eternity for your today?</p><p>And now you\u2019re angry with me for teaching that there is no reward and paymaster? And truly, I do not even teach that virtue is its own reward.</p><p>Oh, this is my sorrow; reward and punishment have been lied into the ground of things \u2013 and now even into the ground of your souls, you virtuous!</p><p>But like the snout of a boar my words shall tear open the ground of your souls; a plowshare I shall be to you.</p><p>All the secrets of your ground shall be brought to light; and when you lie uprooted and broken in the sun, your lie also will be separated from your truth.</p><p>For this is your truth: you are too pure for the filth of the words revenge, punishment, reward, retribution.</p><p>You love your virtue as the mother her child; but when did anyone ever hear that a mother wanted to be paid for her love?</p><p>Your virtue is your dearest self. The ring\u2019s thirst is in you; every ring struggles and turns to reach itself again.</p><p>And each work of your virtue is like the star that dies out; always its light is still on its way and wandering \u2013 and when will it no longer be on its way?</p><p>Thus the light of your virtue is still underway, even when the work is done. And even if now forgotten and dead, its ray of light still lives and wanders.</p><p>Your virtue should be your self and not a foreign thing, a skin, a cloaking: that is the truth from the ground of your soul, you virtuous! \u2013</p><p>But surely there are those who equate virtue with spasm under a whip, and you have listened too much to their cries!</p><p>And there are others who call it virtue when their vices grow lazy; and when their hatred and their jealousy stretch their limbs for once, their \u201cjustice\u201d perks up and rubs its sleepy eyes.</p><p>And there are others who are pulled down, their devil pulls them. But the more they sink the more ardently glow their eyes and the craving for their god.</p><p>Oh, their cries too penetrated your ears, you virtuous: \u201cWhat I am not, that, that is God and virtue to me!\u201d</p><p>And there are others who come along heavy and creaking like wagons carting stones downhill: they speak much of dignity and virtue \u2013 they call their brake virtue!</p><p>And there are others who are like run of the mill clocks that have been wound up: they go tick-tock and want to have their tic called virtue.</p><p>Indeed, I have my fun with these; wherever I find such clocks I will wind them up with my mockery, and make them whir for me!</p><p>And others are proud of their handful of justice, and for its sake they commit outrage against all things, such that the world is drowned in their injustice.</p><p>Oh, how foul the word \u201cvirtue\u201d sounds coming from their mouths! And when they say: \u201cI am just,\u201d then it sounds always like: \u201cI am just avenged!\u201d</p><p>With their virtue they want to scratch out the eyes of their enemies; and they elevate themselves only to degrade others.</p><p>And then again there are those who sit in their swamp and speak thus from out of the reeds: \u201cVirtue \u2013 that means sitting quietly in the swamp.</p><p>We bite no one and avoid anyone who wants to bite; and in all matters we have that opinion that is given us.\u201d</p><p>And then again there are those who love gestures and think: virtue is a kind of gesture.</p><p>Their knees always adore and their hands are extolments of virtue, but their hearts know nothing of it.</p><p>And then again there are those who consider it virtue to say: \u201cVirtue is necessity\u201d; but at bottom they believe only that the police are a necessity.</p><p>And some who cannot see the high in people call it virtue that they see the low all too near, thus they call their evil eye virtue.</p><p>And a few want to be edified and built up and call that virtue; and others want to be toppled \u2013 and call that virtue too.</p><p>And in this manner almost all believe they have a share of virtue; and at the very least each person wants to be an expert on \u201cgood\u201d and \u201cevil.\u201d</p><p>But Zarathustra has not come to say to all these liars and fools: \u201cWhat do you know about virtue! What could you know about virtue!\u201d \u2013</p><p>Instead, my friends, I wish you would grow weary of the old words you have learned from the fools and liars:</p><p>Grow weary of the words \u201creward,\u201d \u201cretribution,\u201d \u201cpunishment,\u201d \u201crevenge in justice\u201d \u2013</p><p>Grow weary of saying: \u201cWhat makes a deed good is that it is selfless.\u201d</p><p>Oh my friends! I wish your self were in the deed like the mother is in the child: let that be your word on virtue!</p><p>Indeed, I may have taken from you a hundred words and your virtue\u2019s favorite toys; and now you are angry with me as children become angry.</p><p>They played by the sea \u2013 then the wave came and tore their toys into the deep: now they weep.</p><p>But the same wave shall bring them new toys and lavish new colorful shells before them!</p><p>Thus will they be consoled; and like them you, too, my friends shall have your consolations \u2013 and new colorful shells! \u2013</p><p>Thus spoke Zarathustra.</p>", "article_json": {"type": "doc", "content": [{"type": "heading", "attrs": {"level": 2}, "content": [{"text": "On the Virtuous", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "content": [{"text": "With thunder and heavenly fireworks one must speak to slack and sleeping senses.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "content": [{"text": "But the voice of beauty speaks softly; it creeps only into the most awakened souls.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "content": [{"text": "Softly today my shield trembled and laughed; it is the holy laughter and trembling of beauty.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "content": [{"text": "At you, virtuous ones, my beauty laughed today.
