And thus its voice came to me: \u201cThey still want \u2013 to be paid!\u201d\r\n\r\nYou still want to be paid, you virtuous! Want to have reward for virtue, and heaven for earth, and eternity for your today?\r\n\r\nAnd now you\u2019re angry with me for teaching that there is no reward and paymaster? And truly, I do not even teach that virtue is its own reward.\r\n\r\nOh, this is my sorrow; reward and punishment have been lied into the ground of things \u2013 and now even into the ground of your souls, you virtuous!\r\n\r\nBut like the snout of a boar my words shall tear open the ground of your souls; a plowshare I shall be to you.\r\n\r\nAll the secrets of your ground shall be brought to light; and when you lie uprooted and broken in the sun, your lie also will be separated from your truth.\r\n\r\nFor this is your truth: you are too pure for the filth of the words revenge, punishment, reward, retribution.\r\n\r\nYou love your virtue as the mother her child; but when did anyone ever hear that a mother wanted to be paid for her love?\r\n\r\nYour virtue is your dearest self. The ring\u2019s thirst is in you; every ring struggles and turns to reach itself again.\r\n\r\nAnd each work of your virtue is like the star that dies out; always its light is still on its way and wandering \u2013 and when will it no longer be on its way?\r\n\r\nThus the light of your virtue is still underway, even when the work is done. And even if now forgotten and dead, its ray of light still lives and wanders.\r\n\r\nYour virtue should be your self and not a foreign thing, a skin, a cloaking: that is the truth from the ground of your soul, you virtuous! \u2013\r\n\r\nBut surely there are those who equate virtue with spasm under a whip, and you have listened too much to their cries!\r\n\r\nAnd there are others who call it virtue when their vices grow lazy; and when their hatred and their jealousy stretch their limbs for once, their \u201cjustice\u201d perks up and rubs its sleepy eyes.\r\n\r\nAnd there are others who are pulled down, their devil pulls them. But the more they sink the more ardently glow their eyes and the craving for their god.\r\n\r\nOh, their cries too penetrated your ears, you virtuous: \u201cWhat I am not, that, that is God and virtue to me!\u201d\r\n\r\nAnd there are others who come along heavy and creaking like wagons carting stones downhill: they speak much of dignity and virtue \u2013 they call their brake virtue!\r\n\r\nAnd there are others who are like run of the mill clocks that have been wound up: they go tick-tock and want to have their tic called virtue.\r\n\r\nIndeed, I have my fun with these; wherever I find such clocks I will wind them up with my mockery, and make them whir for me!\r\n\r\nAnd others are proud of their handful of justice, and for its sake they commit outrage against all things, such that the world is drowned in their injustice.\r\n\r\nOh, how foul the word \u201cvirtue\u201d sounds coming from their mouths! And when they say: \u201cI am just,\u201d then it sounds always like: \u201cI am just avenged!\u201d\r\n\r\nWith their virtue they want to scratch out the eyes of their enemies; and they elevate themselves only to degrade others.\r\n\r\nAnd then again there are those who sit in their swamp and speak thus from out of the reeds: \u201cVirtue \u2013 that means sitting quietly in the swamp.\r\n\r\nWe bite no one and avoid anyone who wants to bite; and in all matters we have that opinion that is given us.\u201d\r\n\r\nAnd then again there are those who love gestures and think: virtue is a kind of gesture.\r\n\r\nTheir knees always adore and their hands are extolments of virtue, but their hearts know nothing of it.\r\n\r\nAnd then again there are those who consider it virtue to say: \u201cVirtue is necessity\u201d; but at bottom they believe only that the police are a necessity.\r\n\r\nAnd some who cannot see the high in people call it virtue that they see the low all too near, thus they call their evil eye virtue.\r\n\r\nAnd a few want to be edified and built up and call that virtue; and others want to be toppled \u2013 and call that virtue too.\r\n\r\nAnd in this manner almost all believe they have a share of virtue; and at the very least each person wants to be an expert on \u201cgood\u201d and \u201cevil.\u201d\r\n\r\nBut Zarathustra has not come to say to all these liars and fools: \u201cWhat do you know about virtue! What could you know about virtue!\u201d \u2013\r\n\r\nInstead, my friends, I wish you would grow weary of the old words you have learned from the fools and liars:\r\n\r\nGrow weary of the words \u201creward,\u201d \u201cretribution,\u201d \u201cpunishment,\u201d \u201crevenge in justice\u201d \u2013\r\n\r\nGrow weary of saying: \u201cWhat makes a deed good is that it is selfless.\u201d\r\n\r\nOh my friends! I wish your self were in the deed like the mother is in the child: let that be your word on virtue!\r\n\r\nIndeed, I may have taken from you a hundred words and your virtue\u2019s favorite toys; and now you are angry with me as children become angry.\r\n\r\nThey played by the sea \u2013 then the wave came and tore their toys into the deep: now they weep.\r\n\r\nBut the same wave shall bring them new toys and lavish new colorful shells before them!\r\n\r\nThus will they be consoled; and like them you, too, my friends shall have your consolations \u2013 and new colorful shells! \u2013\r\n\r\nThus spoke Zarathustra."}, "id": 43}, {"data": {"uuid": "5872686d-e15a-471a-9d4f-7f44fb38144f", "user": 1, "title": "On the Rabble", "created_on": "2023-05-10 15:24:11.532567+00:00", "updated_on": "2023-05-10 15:24:11.548568+00:00", "article_html": "<h2>On the Rabble</h2><p>Life is a well of joy; but where the rabble also drinks, there all wells are poisoned.</p><p>I appreciate all that is clean; but I do not like to see the grinning snouts and the thirst of the unclean.</p><p>They cast their eyes down into the well; now their disgusting smile reflects back up to me from the well.</p><p>They have poisoned the holy water with their lustfulness; and when they called their filthy dreams joy, they poisoned even words.</p><p>The flame shrinks when they put their dank hearts on the fire; the spirit itself seethes and smokes wherever the rabble approaches the fire.</p><p>In their hands fruits becomes sickly sweet and overripe; their gaze makes fruit trees prone to windfall and withered at the crown.</p><p>And some who turned away from life only turned away from the rabble, not wanting to share well and flame and fruit with the rabble.</p><p>And some who went into the wilderness and suffered thirst with beasts of prey simply did not want to sit around the cistern with filthy camel drivers.</p><p>And some who came along like annihilators and like a hailstorm to all orchards merely wanted to plant their foot into the maw of the rabble to stuff its throat.</p><p>And the bite I gagged on most was not the knowledge that life itself requires hostility and dying and torture crosses \u2013</p><p>Instead I once asked, and almost choked on my question: What? Does life also require the rabble?</p><p>Are poisoned wells and stinking fires and soiled dreams and maggots required in life\u2019s bread?</p><p>Not my hatred but my nausea fed hungrily on my life! Oh, I often grew weary of the spirit when I found even the rabble had wit!</p><p>And I turned my back on the rulers when I saw what they call ruling today: haggling and bartering for power \u2013 with the rabble!</p><p>Among peoples of foreign tongues I lived, with my ears closed, so that the haggling of their tongue and their bartering for power would remain foreign to me. And holding my nose I walked annoyed through all yesterday and today; truly, all yesterday and today smell foul of the writing rabble!</p><p>Like a cripple who became deaf and blind and dumb; thus I lived for a long time, so as not to live with the power-, the scribble-, the pleasure- rabble.</p><p>Laboriously my spirit climbed steps, and cautiously; alms of joy were its refreshment; for the blind man life crept by as if on a cane.</p><p>But what happened to me? How did I redeem myself from nausea? Who rejuvenated my eyes? How did I manage to fly to the height where no more rabble sits at the well?</p><p>Did my nausea itself create wings for me and water-divining powers? Truly, into the highest regions I had to fly in order to rediscover the wellspring of joy!</p><p>Oh I found it, my brothers! Here in the highest regions the wellspring of joy gushes for me! And there is a life from which no rabble drinks!</p><p>Almost too forcefully you flow, well of joy! And often you empty the cup again in wanting to fill it!</p><p>And I must still learn to approach you more modestly; all too forcefully my heart still streams toward you \u2013</p><p>My heart, upon which my summer burns, the brief, hot, melancholy, superblissful summer; how my summer heart yearns for your coolness!</p><p>Gone the hesitating gloom of my spring! Gone the malice of my snowflakes in June! I have become summer and summer noon entirely!</p><p>A summer in the highest regions with cold springs and blissful silence: Oh come, my friends, and let the silence become even more blissful!</p><p>For it is our height and our homeland; too high and steep we live here for all the unclean and their thirst.</p><p>Cast your pure eyes into the wellspring of my joy, you friends! How could it become murky from that! It shall laugh back at you with its purity.</p><p>We build our nest in the tree called future; eagles shall bring us solitary ones food in their beaks!</p><p>Truly, no food in which the unclean are allowed to share! They would think they were devouring fire and burn their snouts!</p><p>Truly, we keep no homesteads ready here for the unclean! To their bodies and to their minds our happiness would seem a cave of ice!</p><p>And like strong winds we want to live above them, neighbors to eagles, neighbors to snow, neighbors to the sun: thus live strong winds.</p><p>And some day I want to blow among them like a wind and steal their breath away with my spirit: thus my future wills it.</p><p>Indeed, Zarathustra is a strong wind to all lowlands; and this counsel he gives to his enemies and to everything that spits and spews: \u201cBeware of spitting against the wind!\u201d</p><p>Thus spoke Zarathustra.</p>", "article_json": {"type": "doc", "content": [{"type": "heading", "attrs": {"level": 2}, "content": [{"text": "On the Rabble", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "content": [{"text": "Life is a well of joy; the spirit itself seethes and smokes wherever the rabble approaches the fire.\r\n\r\nIn their hands fruits becomes sickly sweet and overripe; their gaze makes fruit trees prone to windfall and withered at the crown.\r\n\r\nAnd some who turned away from life only turned away from the rabble, not wanting to share well and flame and fruit with the rabble.\r\n\r\nAnd some who went into the wilderness and suffered thirst with beasts of prey simply did not want to sit around the cistern with filthy camel drivers.\r\n\r\nAnd some who came along like annihilators and like a hailstorm to all orchards merely wanted to plant their foot into the maw of the rabble to stuff its throat.\r\n\r\nAnd the bite I gagged on most was not the knowledge that life itself requires hostility and dying and torture crosses \u2013\r\n\r\nInstead I once asked, and almost choked on my question: What? Does life also require the rabble?\r\n\r\nAre poisoned wells and stinking fires and soiled dreams and maggots required in life\u2019s bread?\r\n\r\nNot my hatred but my nausea fed hungrily on my life! Oh, I often grew weary of the spirit when I found even the rabble had wit!\r\n\r\nAnd I turned my back on the rulers when I saw what they call ruling today: haggling and bartering for power \u2013 with the rabble!\r\n\r\nAmong peoples of foreign tongues I lived, with my ears closed, so that the haggling of their tongue and their bartering for power would remain foreign to me. And holding my nose I walked annoyed through all yesterday and today; truly, all yesterday and today smell foul of the writing rabble!\r\n\r\nLike a cripple who became deaf and blind and dumb; thus I lived for a long time, so as not to live with the power-, the scribble-, the pleasure- rabble.\r\n\r\nLaboriously my spirit climbed steps, and cautiously; alms of joy were its refreshment; for the blind man life crept by as if on a cane.\r\n\r\nBut what happened to me? How did I redeem myself from nausea? Who rejuvenated my eyes? How did I manage to fly to the height where no more rabble sits at the well?\r\n\r\nDid my nausea itself create wings for me and water-divining powers? Truly, into the highest regions I had to fly in order to rediscover the wellspring of joy!\r\n\r\nOh I found it, my brothers! Here in the highest regions the wellspring of joy gushes for me! And there is a life from which no rabble drinks!\r\n\r\nAlmost too forcefully you flow, well of joy! And often you empty the cup again in wanting to fill it!\r\n\r\nAnd I must still learn to approach you more modestly; all too forcefully my heart still streams toward you \u2013\r\n\r\nMy heart, upon which my summer burns, the brief, hot, melancholy, superblissful summer; how my summer heart yearns for your coolness!\r\n\r\nGone the hesitating gloom of my spring! Gone the malice of my snowflakes in June! I have become summer and summer noon entirely!\r\n\r\nA summer in the highest regions with cold springs and blissful silence: Oh come, my friends, and let the silence become even more blissful!\r\n\r\nFor it is our height and our homeland; too high and steep we live here for all the unclean and their thirst.\r\n\r\nCast your pure eyes into the wellspring of my joy, you friends! How could it become murky from that! It shall laugh back at you with its purity.\r\n\r\nWe build our nest in the tree called future; eagles shall bring us solitary ones food in their beaks!\r\n\r\nTruly, no food in which the unclean are allowed to share! They would think they were devouring fire and burn their snouts!\r\n\r\nTruly, we keep no homesteads ready here for the unclean! To their bodies and to their minds our happiness would seem a cave of ice!\r\n\r\nAnd like strong winds we want to live above them, neighbors to eagles, neighbors to snow, neighbors to the sun: thus live strong winds.\r\n\r\nAnd some day I want to blow among them like a wind and steal their breath away with my spirit: thus my future wills it.\r\n\r\nIndeed, Zarathustra is a strong wind to all lowlands; and this counsel he gives to his enemies and to everything that spits and spews: \u201cBeware of spitting against the wind!\u201d\r\n\r\nThus spoke Zarathustra."}, "id": 44}, {"data": {"uuid": "cf3f5778-99cc-46f5-ad3d-5aba41586cc1", "user": 1, "title": "On the Tarantulas", "created_on": "2023-05-10 15:25:21.397976+00:00", "updated_on": "2023-05-10 15:25:21.412500+00:00", "article_html": "<h2>On the Tarantulas</h2><p>Look here, this is the hole of the tarantula! Do you want to see the tarantula itself? Its web hangs here; touch it, make it tremble.</p><p>Here it comes, willingly \u2013 welcome, tarantula! On your back your triangle and mark sits in black; and I know too what sits in your soul.</p><p>Revenge sits in your soul: wherever you bite, there black scabs grow; your poison makes the soul whirl with revenge!</p><p>So I speak to you in parables, you who cause the souls to whirl, you preachers of equality! Tarantulas you are to me and hidden avengers!</p><p>But I want to expose your hiding places to the light; therefore I laugh into your face my laughter of the heights.</p><p>Therefore I tear at your web, so that your rage might lure you from your lie-hole lair, and your revenge might spring forth from behind your word \u201cjustice.\u201d For that mankind be redeemed from revenge: that to me is the bridge to the highest hope and a rainbow after long thunderstorms.</p><p>But the tarantulas want it otherwise, to be sure. \u201cThat the world become full of the thunderstorms of our revenge, precisely that we would regard as justice,\u201d \u2013 thus they speak with one another.</p><p>\u201cWe want to exact revenge and heap insult on all whose equals we are not\u201d \u2013 thus vow the tarantula hearts.</p><p>\u201cAnd \u2018will to equality\u2019 \u2013 that itself from now on shall be the name for virtue; and against everything that has power we shall raise our clamor!\u201d</p><p>You preachers of equality, the tyrant\u2019s madness of impotence cries thus out of you for \u201cequality\u201d: your secret tyrant\u2019s cravings mask themselves thus in your words of virtue!</p><p>Aggrieved conceit, repressed envy, perhaps the conceit and envy of your fathers: it erupts from you like a flame and the madness of revenge.</p><p>What is silent in the father learns to speak in the son; and often I found the son to be the father\u2019s exposed secret.</p><p>They resemble the inspired, but it is not the heart that inspires them \u2013 but revenge. And when they are refined and cold, it is not the spirit but envy that makes them refined and cold.</p><p>Their jealousy even leads them along the thinkers\u2019 path; and this is the mark of their jealousy \u2013 they always go too far, such that their exhaustion must ultimately lay itself to sleep in snow.</p><p>From each of their laments revenge sounds, in each of their praisings there is harm, and being the judge is bliss to them.</p><p>But thus I counsel you my friends: mistrust all in whom the drive to punish is strong!</p><p>Those are people of bad kind and kin; in their faces the hangman and the bloodhound are visible.</p><p>Mistrust all those who speak much of their justice! Indeed, their souls are lacking not only honey.</p><p>And when they call themselves \u201cthe good and the just,\u201d then do not forget that all they lack to be pharisees is \u2013 power!</p><p>My friends, I do not want not be mixed in with and mistaken for others.</p><p>There are those who preach my doctrine of life, and at the same time they are preachers of equality and tarantulas.</p><p>They speak in favor of life, these poisonous spiders, even though they are sitting in their holes and have turned against life, because they want to do harm.</p><p>They want to harm those who hold power today, for among them the sermon on death is still most at home.</p><p>If it were otherwise, then the tarantulas would teach otherwise; and they after all were formerly the best world slanderers and burners of heretics.</p><p>I do not want to be mixed in with and mistaken for these preachers of equality. For thus justice speaks to me: \u201chumans are not equal.\u201d</p><p>And they shouldn\u2019t become so either! What would my love for the overman be if I spoke otherwise?</p><p>On a thousand bridges and paths they shall throng to the future, and ever more war and inequality shall be set between them: thus my great love commands me to speak!</p><p>Inventors of images and ghosts shall they become in their hostility, and with their images and ghosts they shall yet fight the highest fight against each other!</p><p>Good and evil, and rich and poor, and high and trifling, and all the names of values: they shall be weapons and clanging signs that life must overcome itself again and again!</p><p>Life itself wants to build itself into the heights with pillars and steps; it wants to gaze into vast distances and out upon halcyon beauties \u2013 therefore it needs height!</p><p>And because it needs height, it needs steps and contradiction between steps and climbers! Life wants to climb and to overcome itself by climbing.</p><p>And look here, my friends! Here, where the tarantula\u2019s hole is, the ruins of an ancient temple are rising \u2013 look here now with enlightened eyes!</p><p>Indeed, the one who once heaped his thoughts skyward here in stone \u2013 he knew the secret of all life like the most wise!</p><p>That struggle and inequality and war for power and supremacy are found even in beauty: he teaches us that here in the clearest parable.</p><p>How divinely the vault and the arch bend and break each other as they wrestle; how they struggle against each other with light and shadow, these divinely struggling ones \u2013</p><p>In this manner sure and beautiful let us also be enemies, my friends! Divinely let us struggle against each other!</p><p>Alas! Then the tarantula bit me, my old enemy! Divinely sure and beautiful it bit me on the finger!</p><p>\u201cPunishment and justice must be\u201d \u2013 thus it thinks. \u201cNot for nothing shall he sing his songs in honor of hostility here!\u201d</p><p>Yes, it has avenged itself! And alas! Now it will also make my soul whirl with revenge!</p><p>But so that I do not whirl, my friends, bind me fast to this pillar here! I would rather be a stylite than a whirlwind of revenge!</p><p>Indeed, Zarathustra is no tornado or whirlwind; and if he is a dancer, nevermore a tarantella dancer! \u2013</p><p>Thus spoke Zarathustra.</p>", "article_json": {"type": "doc", "content": [{"type": "heading", "attrs": {"level": 2}, "content": [{"text": "On the Tarantulas", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "content": [{"text": "Look here, this is the hole of the tarantula! Do you want to see the tarantula itself? Its web hangs here; touch it, make it tremble.\r\n\r\nHere it comes, willingly \u2013 welcome, tarantula! On your back your triangle and mark sits in black; and I know too what sits in your soul.\r\n\r\nRevenge sits in your soul: wherever you bite, there black scabs grow; your poison makes the soul whirl with revenge!\r\n\r\nSo I speak to you in parables, you who cause the souls to whirl, you preachers of equality! Tarantulas you are to me and hidden avengers!\r\n\r\nBut I want to expose your hiding places to the light; therefore I laugh into your face my laughter of the heights.\r\n\r\nTherefore I tear at your web, so that your rage might lure you from your lie-hole lair, and your revenge might spring forth from behind your word \u201cjustice.\u201d For that mankind be redeemed from revenge: that to me is the bridge to the highest hope and a rainbow after long thunderstorms.\r\n\r\nBut the tarantulas want it otherwise, to be sure. \u201cThat the world become full of the thunderstorms of our revenge, precisely that we would regard as justice,\u201d \u2013 thus they speak with one another.\r\n\r\n\u201cWe want to exact revenge and heap insult on all whose equals we are not\u201d \u2013 thus vow the tarantula hearts.\r\n\r\n\u201cAnd \u2018will to equality\u2019 \u2013 that itself from now on shall be the name for virtue; and against everything that has power we shall raise our clamor!\u201d\r\n\r\nYou preachers of equality, the tyrant\u2019s madness of impotence cries thus out of you for \u201cequality\u201d: your secret tyrant\u2019s cravings mask themselves thus in your words of virtue!\r\n\r\nAggrieved conceit, repressed envy, perhaps the conceit and envy of your fathers: it erupts from you like a flame and the madness of revenge.\r\n\r\nWhat is silent in the father learns to speak in the son; and often I found the son to be the father\u2019s exposed secret.\r\n\r\nThey resemble the inspired, but it is not the heart that inspires them \u2013 but revenge. And when they are refined and cold, it is not the spirit but envy that makes them refined and cold.\r\n\r\nTheir jealousy even leads them along the thinkers\u2019 path; and this is the mark of their jealousy \u2013 they always go too far, such that their exhaustion must ultimately lay itself to sleep in snow.\r\n\r\nFrom each of their laments revenge sounds, in each of their praisings there is harm, and being the judge is bliss to them.\r\n\r\nBut thus I counsel you my friends: mistrust all in whom the drive to punish is strong!\r\n\r\nThose are people of bad kind and kin; in their faces the hangman and the bloodhound are visible.\r\n\r\nMistrust all those who speak much of their justice! Indeed, their souls are lacking not only honey.\r\n\r\nAnd when they call themselves \u201cthe good and the just,\u201d then do not forget that all they lack to be pharisees is \u2013 power!\r\n\r\nMy friends, I do not want not be mixed in with and mistaken for others.\r\n\r\nThere are those who preach my doctrine of life, and at the same time they are preachers of equality and tarantulas.\r\n\r\nThey speak in favor of life, these poisonous spiders, even though they are sitting in their holes and have turned against life, because they want to do harm.\r\n\r\nThey want to harm those who hold power today, for among them the sermon on death is still most at home.\r\n\r\nIf it were otherwise, then the tarantulas would teach otherwise; and they after all were formerly the best world slanderers and burners of heretics.\r\n\r\nI do not want to be mixed in with and mistaken for these preachers of equality. For thus justice speaks to me: \u201chumans are not equal.\u201d\r\n\r\nAnd they shouldn\u2019t become so either! What would my love for the overman be if I spoke otherwise?\r\n\r\nOn a thousand bridges and paths they shall throng to the future, and ever more war and inequality shall be set between them: thus my great love commands me to speak!\r\n\r\nInventors of images and ghosts shall they become in their hostility, and with their images and ghosts they shall yet fight the highest fight against each other!\r\n\r\nGood and evil, and rich and poor, and high and trifling, and all the names of values: they shall be weapons and clanging signs that life must overcome itself again and again!\r\n\r\nLife itself wants to build itself into the heights with pillars and steps; it wants to gaze into vast distances and out upon halcyon beauties \u2013 therefore it needs height!\r\n\r\nAnd because it needs height, it needs steps and contradiction between steps and climbers! Life wants to climb and to overcome itself by climbing.\r\n\r\nAnd look here, my friends! Here, where the tarantula\u2019s hole is, the ruins of an ancient temple are rising \u2013 look here now with enlightened eyes!\r\n\r\nIndeed, the one who once heaped his thoughts skyward here in stone \u2013 he knew the secret of all life like the most wise!\r\n\r\nThat struggle and inequality and war for power and supremacy are found even in beauty: he teaches us that here in the clearest parable.\r\n\r\nHow divinely the vault and the arch bend and break each other as they wrestle; how they struggle against each other with light and shadow, these divinely struggling ones \u2013\r\n\r\nIn this manner sure and beautiful let us also be enemies, my friends! Divinely let us struggle against each other!\r\n\r\nAlas! Then the tarantula bit me, my old enemy! Divinely sure and beautiful it bit me on the finger!\r\n\r\n\u201cPunishment and justice must be\u201d \u2013 thus it thinks. \u201cNot for nothing shall he sing his songs in honor of hostility here!\u201d\r\n\r\nYes, it has avenged itself! And alas! Now it will also make my soul whirl with revenge!\r\n\r\nBut so that I do not whirl, my friends, bind me fast to this pillar here! I would rather be a stylite than a whirlwind of revenge!\r\n\r\nIndeed, Zarathustra is no tornado or whirlwind; and if he is a dancer, nevermore a tarantella dancer! \u2013\r\n\r\nThus spoke Zarathustra."}, "id": 45}, {"data": {"uuid": "c7faf514-9c48-458d-a54e-a53c9ad8626e", "user": 1, "title": "On the Famous Wise Men", "created_on": "2023-05-10 15:26:03.433889+00:00", "updated_on": "2023-05-10 15:26:03.448736+00:00", "article_html": "<h2>On the Famous Wise Men</h2><p>The people you have served and the people\u2019s superstition, all you famous wise men! \u2013 and not the truth! And precisely on that account you were accorded respect.</p><p>And for this reason too they tolerated your lack of faith, because it was a joke and a jog to the people. Thus does the master allow his slaves to have their way, delighting all the while in their frolicking.</p><p>But whoever is despised by the people like a wolf by dogs; this is the free spirit, the foe of fetters, the non-adorer, the one who houses in the woods.</p><p>Hunting him out of his lair \u2013 to the people this has always meant \u201ca sense of what is right.\u201d On him the people have always sicced their dogs with the sharpest teeth.</p><p>\u201cFor the truth is here if only the people are here! Woe, woe to the seekers!\u201d \u2013 Thus it has echoed for all time.</p><p>You wanted to justify your people\u2019s reverence; that is what you called \u201cwill to truth,\u201d you famous wise men!</p><p>And your heart always said to itself: \u201cFrom the people I came: from there too God\u2019s voice came to me.\u201d</p><p>As advocates of the people you were always stiff-necked and clever, like asses.</p><p>And many a powerful one who wanted to travel well with the people harnessed a little ass in front of his horses, a famous wise man.</p><p>And now, you famous wise men, I wish you would finally throw off the lion skin completely!</p><p>The mottled skin of the predator, and the mane of the explorer, the searcher, the conqueror!</p><p>Oh, before I would learn to believe in your \u201ctruthfulness\u201d you would first have to break your revering will.</p><p>Truthful \u2013 thus I call the one who goes into godless deserts and has broken his revering heart.</p><p>In the yellow sand and burned by the sun he may squint thirstily at islands rich with springs, where living things rest beneath dark trees.</p><p>But his thirst does not persuade him to become the same as these comfortable ones; for where there are oases, there are idols as well.</p><p>Hungry, violent, lonely, godless; thus the lion-will wants itself.</p><p>Free from the happiness of the servant, redeemed of gods and ado- rations, fearless and fearsome, great and lonely; thus is the will of the truthful.</p><p>In the desert the truthful have always dwelled, the free spirits, as the rulers of the desert; but in the cities dwell the well-fed, famous wise men \u2013 the draft animals.</p><p>For they, as asses, always pull \u2013 the people\u2019s cart!</p><p>Not that I am angry with them for it; but to me they remain servants and harnessed, even if they gleam in golden harnesses.</p><p>And often they were good servants and praiseworthy. For virtue speaks thus: \u201cIf you must serve, then seek the one who benefits most from your service!</p><p>The spirit and virtue of your master shall grow from your being his servant; thus you yourself grow with his spirit and his virtue!\u201d</p><p>And truly, you famous wise men, you servants of the people! You yourselves grew with the people\u2019s spirit and virtue \u2013 and the people through you! I say this in your honor!</p><p>But to me you remain the people even in your virtues, the people with stupid eyes \u2013 the people who don\u2019t know what spirit is!</p><p>Spirit is life that itself cuts into life; by its own agony it increases its own knowledge \u2013 did you know that?</p><p>And the happiness of spirit is this: to be anointed and consecrated by tears to serve as a sacrificial animal \u2013 did you know that?</p><p>And the blindness of the blind, and his seeking and probing shall yet testify to the power of the sun into which he gazed \u2013 did you know that?</p><p>And the seeker of knowledge shall learn to build with mountains! It means little that the spirit moves mountains \u2013 did you know that?</p><p>You know only the spark of the spirit, but you do not see the anvil that it is, nor the cruelty of its hammer!</p><p>Indeed, you do not know the pride of the spirit! But even less would you be able to bear the spirit\u2019s modesty, if it ever wanted to speak!</p><p>And never yet have you been permitted to throw your spirit into a pit of snow; you are not hot enough for that! And so you do not know the thrills of its coldness.</p><p>But in all things you act too familiarly with the spirit, and wisdom you often make into a poorhouse and hospital for bad poets.</p><p>You are no eagles, thus you have not experienced the happiness in the terror of the spirit. And whoever is not a bird should not build nests over abysses.</p><p>To me you are lukewarm, but every deep knowledge flows cold. Ice- cold are the innermost wells of the spirit, invigorating for hot hands and human doers.</p><p>Honorable you stand there, and stiff with ramrod backs, you famous wise men! \u2013 You are not driven by strong wind and will.</p><p>Have you never seen a sail go over the sea, rounded and billowed and trembling with the vehemence of the wind?</p><p>Like the sail, trembling with the vehemence of the spirit, my wisdom goes over the sea \u2013 my wild wisdom!</p><p>But you servants of the people, you famous wise men \u2013 how could you go with me! \u2013</p><p>Thus spoke Zarathustra.</p>", "article_json": {"type": "doc", "content": [{"type": "heading", "attrs": {"level": 2}, "content": [{"text": "On the Famous Wise Men", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "content": [{"text": "The people you have served and the people\u2019s superstition, all you famous wise men! \u2013 and not the truth! And precisely on that account you were accorded respect.\r\n\r\nAnd for this reason too they tolerated your lack of faith, because it was a joke and a jog to the people. Thus does the master allow his slaves to have their way, delighting all the while in their frolicking.\r\n\r\nBut whoever is despised by the people like a wolf by dogs; this is the free spirit, the foe of fetters, the non-adorer, the one who houses in the woods.\r\n\r\nHunting him out of his lair \u2013 to the people this has always meant \u201ca sense of what is right.\u201d On him the people have always sicced their dogs with the sharpest teeth.\r\n\r\n\u201cFor the truth is here if only the people are here! Woe, woe to the seekers!\u201d \u2013 Thus it has echoed for all time.\r\n\r\nYou wanted to justify your people\u2019s reverence; that is what you called \u201cwill to truth,\u201d you famous wise men!\r\n\r\nAnd your heart always said to itself: \u201cFrom the people I came: from there too God\u2019s voice came to me.\u201d\r\n\r\nAs advocates of the people you were always stiff-necked and clever, like asses.\r\n\r\nAnd many a powerful one who wanted to travel well with the people harnessed a little ass in front of his horses, a famous wise man.\r\n\r\nAnd now, you famous wise men, I wish you would finally throw off the lion skin completely!\r\n\r\nThe mottled skin of the predator, and the mane of the explorer, the searcher, the conqueror!\r\n\r\nOh, before I would learn to believe in your \u201ctruthfulness\u201d you would first have to break your revering will.\r\n\r\nTruthful \u2013 thus I call the one who goes into godless deserts and has broken his revering heart.\r\n\r\nIn the yellow sand and burned by the sun he may squint thirstily at islands rich with springs, where living things rest beneath dark trees.\r\n\r\nBut his thirst does not persuade him to become the same as these comfortable ones; for where there are oases, there are idols as well.\r\n\r\nHungry, violent, lonely, godless; thus the lion-will wants itself.\r\n\r\nFree from the happiness of the servant, redeemed of gods and ado- rations, fearless and fearsome, great and lonely; thus is the will of the truthful.\r\n\r\nIn the desert the truthful have always dwelled, the free spirits, as the rulers of the desert; but in the cities dwell the well-fed, famous wise men \u2013 the draft animals.\r\n\r\nFor they, as asses, always pull \u2013 the people\u2019s cart!\r\n\r\nNot that I am angry with them for it; but to me they remain servants and harnessed, even if they gleam in golden harnesses.\r\n\r\nAnd often they were good servants and praiseworthy. For virtue speaks thus: \u201cIf you must serve, then seek the one who benefits most from your service!\r\n\r\nThe spirit and virtue of your master shall grow from your being his servant; thus you yourself grow with his spirit and his virtue!\u201d\r\n\r\nAnd truly, you famous wise men, you servants of the people! You yourselves grew with the people\u2019s spirit and virtue \u2013 and the people through you! I say this in your honor!\r\n\r\nBut to me you remain the people even in your virtues, the people with stupid eyes \u2013 the people who don\u2019t know what spirit is!\r\n\r\nSpirit is life that itself cuts into life; by its own agony it increases its own knowledge \u2013 did you know that?\r\n\r\nAnd the happiness of spirit is this: to be anointed and consecrated by tears to serve as a sacrificial animal \u2013 did you know that?\r\n\r\nAnd the blindness of the blind, and his seeking and probing shall yet testify to the power of the sun into which he gazed \u2013 did you know that?\r\n\r\nAnd the seeker of knowledge shall learn to build with mountains! It means little that the spirit moves mountains \u2013 did you know that?\r\n\r\nYou know only the spark of the spirit, but you do not see the anvil that it is, nor the cruelty of its hammer!\r\n\r\nIndeed, you do not know the pride of the spirit! But even less would you be able to bear the spirit\u2019s modesty, if it ever wanted to speak!\r\n\r\nAnd never yet have you been permitted to throw your spirit into a pit of snow; you are not hot enough for that! And so you do not know the thrills of its coldness.\r\n\r\nBut in all things you act too familiarly with the spirit, and wisdom you often make into a poorhouse and hospital for bad poets.\r\n\r\nYou are no eagles, thus you have not experienced the happiness in the terror of the spirit. And whoever is not a bird should not build nests over abysses.\r\n\r\nTo me you are lukewarm, but every deep knowledge flows cold. Ice- cold are the innermost wells of the spirit, invigorating for hot hands and human doers.\r\n\r\nHonorable you stand there, and stiff with ramrod backs, you famous wise men! \u2013 You are not driven by strong wind and will.\r\n\r\nHave you never seen a sail go over the sea, rounded and billowed and trembling with the vehemence of the wind?\r\n\r\nLike the sail, trembling with the vehemence of the spirit, my wisdom goes over the sea \u2013 my wild wisdom!\r\n\r\nBut you servants of the people, you famous wise men \u2013 how could you go with me! \u2013\r\n\r\nThus spoke Zarathustra."}, "id": 46}, {"data": {"uuid": "ad52b392-2a37-4b78-ac13-21be48e0bc6e", "user": 1, "title": "The Night Song", "created_on": "2023-05-10 15:26:46.092125+00:00", "updated_on": "2023-05-10 15:26:46.108439+00:00", "article_html": "<h2>The Night Song</h2><p>It is night: now all fountains speak more loudly. And my soul too is a fountain.</p><p>It is night: only now all the songs of the lovers awaken. And my soul too is the song of a lover.</p><p>An unstilled, an unstillable something is in me; it wants to be heard. A craving for love is in me, which itself speaks the language of love.</p><p>I am light; oh that I were night! But this is my loneliness, that I am girded by light.</p><p>Oh that I were dark and nocturnal! How I would suck at the breasts of light!</p><p>And even you I would bless, you little twinkling stars and glowworms up there! \u2013 And be blissful for your gift of light.</p><p>But I live in my own light, I drink back into myself the flames that break out of me.</p><p>I do not the know the happiness of receiving; and often I dreamed that stealing must be more blessed than receiving.</p><p>This is my poverty, that my hand never rests from bestowing; this is my envy, that I see waiting eyes and the illuminated nights of longing.</p><p>Oh misery of all bestowers! Oh darkening of my sun! Oh craving to crave! Oh ravenous hunger in satiety!</p><p>They receive from me, but do I still touch their souls? There is a cleft between giving and receiving; and the closest cleft is the last to be bridged.</p><p>A hunger grows out of my beauty; I wish to harm those for whom I shine, I wish to rob those on whom I have bestowed: \u2013 thus I hunger for malice.</p><p>Withdrawing my hand when a hand already reaches for it; hesitating like the waterfall that hesitates even while plunging \u2013 thus I hunger for malice.</p><p>My fullness plots such vengeance; such trickery gushes from my loneliness.</p><p>My happiness in bestowing died in bestowing, my virtue wearied of itself in its superabundance!</p><p>For one who always bestows, the danger is loss of shame; whoever dispenses always has calloused hands and heart from sheer dispensing.</p><p>My eye no longer wells up at the shame of those who beg; my hand became too hard for the trembling of filled hands.</p><p>Where have the tears of my eye and the down of my heart gone? Oh loneliness of all bestowers! Oh muteness of all who shine!</p><p>Many suns revolve in desolate space. To everything that is dark they speak with their light \u2013 to me they are mute.</p><p>Oh this is the enmity of light toward that which shines; mercilessly it goes its orbit.</p><p>Unjust in its deepest heart toward that which shines: cold toward suns \u2013 thus every sun goes.</p><p>Like a storm the suns fly their orbit, that is their motion. They follow their inexorable will; that is their coldness.</p><p>Oh it is you only, you dark ones, you nocturnal ones, who create warmth out of that which shines! Oh it is you only who drink milk and refreshment from the udders of light!</p><p>Alas, ice surrounds me, my hand burns itself on iciness! Alas, there is thirst in me that yearns for your thirst!</p><p>It is night: alas that I must be light! And thirst for the nocturnal! And loneliness!</p><p>It is night: now my longing breaks out of me like a well \u2013 I long to speak.</p><p>It is night: now all fountains speak more loudly. And my soul too is a fountain.</p><p>It is night: only now all the songs of the lovers awaken. As soon as the girls recognized Zarathustra, they stopped dancing; but Zarathustra approached them with a friendly gesture and spoke these words:</p><p>\u201cDo not stop dancing, you lovely girls! No spoil sport has come to you with his evil eye, no enemy of girls.</p><p>God\u2019s advocate before the devil am I; but the devil is the spirit of gravity. How could I be hostile toward godlike dancing, you light ones? Or toward</p><p>girls\u2019 feet with pretty ankles? I may well be a wood and a night of dark trees, yet whoever does not shrink from my darkness will also find rose slopes under my</p><p>cypresses. And he will also find the little god, surely, who is the favorite of girls; he lies next to the well, still, with closed eyes.</p><p>Indeed, he fell asleep in broad daylight, the loafer! Did he chase too much after butterflies?</p><p>Do not be angry with me, you beautiful dancing girls, if I chastise the little god a bit! He will probably yell and weep \u2013 but he is comical even when weeping!</p><p>And with tears in his eyes he shall ask you for a dance, and I myself will sing a song to his dance:</p><p>A dance and a mocking song to the spirit of gravity, my supreme highest and most powerful devil, of whom it is said that he is \u2018the ruler of the world.\u2019 \u201d \u2013</p><p>And this is the song that Zarathustra sang as Cupid and the girls danced together.</p><p>Into your eye I gazed recently, oh life! And then into the unfathomable I seemed to sink.</p><p>But you pulled me out with your golden fishing rod; you laughed mockingly when I called you unfathomable.</p><p>\u201cThus sounds the speech of all fish,\u201d you said. \u201cWhat they do not fathom, is unfathomable.</p><p>But I am merely fickle and wild and in all things a woman, and no virtuous one:</p><p>Whether to you men I am called \u2018profundity\u2019 or \u2018fidelity,\u2019 \u2018eternity\u2019 or \u2018secrecy.\u2019</p><p>But you men always bestow on us your own virtues \u2013 oh, you virtuous men!\u201d</p><p>Thus she laughed, the incredible one, but I never believe her and her laughing when she speaks ill of herself.</p><p>And when I spoke in confidence with my wild wisdom, she said to me angrily: \u201cYou will, you covet, you love, and only therefore do you praise life!\u201d</p><p>Then I almost answered maliciously and told the angry woman the truth; and one can not answer more maliciously than when one \u201ctells the truth\u201d to one\u2019s wisdom.</p><p>Thus matters stand between the three of us. At bottom I love only life \u2013 and verily, most when I hate it!</p><p>But that I am fond of wisdom and often too fond; that is because she reminds me so much of life!</p><p>She has her eyes, her laugh and even her little golden fishing rod \u2013 is it my fault that the two look so much alike?</p><p>And when life once asked me: \u201cWho is this wisdom anyway?\u201d\u2013 I has- tened to reply: \u201cOh yes! Wisdom!</p><p>One thirsts for her and does not become sated, one peeks through veils, one snatches through nets.</p><p>Is she beautiful? What do I know! But even the oldest carps are baited by her.</p><p>She is fickle and stubborn; often I saw her bite her lip and comb her hair against the grain.</p><p>Perhaps she is evil and false, and in all things a female; but when she speaks ill of herself, precisely then she seduces the most.\u201d</p><p>When I had said this to life she laughed sarcastically and closed her eyes: \u201cWhom are you talking about?\u201d she said. \u201cSurely about me?</p><p>And even if you are right \u2013 does one say that to my face? But now speak too of your own wisdom!\u201d</p><p>Oh, and now you opened your eyes again, oh beloved life! And again I seemed to sink into the unfathomable. \u2013</p><p>Thus sang Zarathustra. But when the dance had ended and the girls departed, he became sad.</p><p>\u201cThe sun set long ago,\u201d he remarked at last. \u201cThe meadow is moist, coolness emanates from the woods.</p><p>Something unknown is around me and it gazes pensively. What \u2013 you are still alive, Zarathustra?</p><p>Why? Wherefore? Whereby? Whither? Where? How? Is it not folly to continue living? \u2013</p><p>Alas, my friends, it is the evening whose questions emerge from me. Forgive me my sadness!</p><p>Evening came: forgive me that evening came!\u201d</p><p>Thus spoke Zarathustra.</p>", "article_json": {"type": "doc", "content": [{"type": "heading", "attrs": {"level": 2}, "content": [{"text": "The Dance Song", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "content": [{"text": "One evening Zarathustra walked through the woods with his disciples, and as he searched for a well, behold, he then came upon a green meadow that was silently bordered by trees and shrubs; upon it girls danced with each other. As soon as the girls recognized Zarathustra, they stopped dancing; but Zarathustra approached them with a friendly gesture and spoke these words:\r\n\r\n\u201cDo not stop dancing, you lovely girls! No spoil sport has come to you with his evil eye, no enemy of girls.\r\n\r\nGod\u2019s advocate before the devil am I; but the devil is the spirit of gravity. How could I be hostile toward godlike dancing, you light ones? Or toward\r\n\r\ngirls\u2019 feet with pretty ankles? I may well be a wood and a night of dark trees, yet whoever does not shrink from my darkness will also find rose slopes under my\r\n\r\ncypresses. And he will also find the little god, surely, who is the favorite of girls; he lies next to the well, still, with closed eyes.\r\n\r\nIndeed, he fell asleep in broad daylight, the loafer! Did he chase too much after butterflies?\r\n\r\nDo not be angry with me, you beautiful dancing girls, if I chastise the little god a bit! He will probably yell and weep \u2013 but he is comical even when weeping!\r\n\r\nAnd with tears in his eyes he shall ask you for a dance, and I myself will sing a song to his dance:\r\n\r\nA dance and a mocking song to the spirit of gravity, my supreme highest and most powerful devil, of whom it is said that he is \u2018the ruler of the world.\u2019 \u201d \u2013\r\n\r\nAnd this is the song that Zarathustra sang as Cupid and the girls danced together.\r\n\r\nInto your eye I gazed recently, oh life! And then into the unfathomable I seemed to sink.\r\n\r\nBut you pulled me out with your golden fishing rod; you laughed mockingly when I called you unfathomable.\r\n\r\n\u201cThus sounds the speech of all fish,\u201d you said. \u201cWhat they do not fathom, is unfathomable.\r\n\r\nBut I am merely fickle and wild and in all things a woman, and no virtuous one:\r\n\r\nWhether to you men I am called \u2018profundity\u2019 or \u2018fidelity,\u2019 \u2018eternity\u2019 or \u2018secrecy.\u2019\r\n\r\nBut you men always bestow on us your own virtues \u2013 oh, you virtuous men!\u201d\r\n\r\nThus she laughed, the incredible one, but I never believe her and her laughing when she speaks ill of herself.\r\n\r\nAnd when I spoke in confidence with my wild wisdom, she said to me angrily: \u201cYou will, you covet, you love, and only therefore do you praise life!\u201d\r\n\r\nThen I almost answered maliciously and told the angry woman the truth; and one can not answer more maliciously than when one \u201ctells the truth\u201d to one\u2019s wisdom.\r\n\r\nThus matters stand between the three of us. At bottom I love only life \u2013 and verily, most when I hate it!\r\n\r\nBut that I am fond of wisdom and often too fond; that is because she reminds me so much of life!\r\n\r\nShe has her eyes, her laugh and even her little golden fishing rod \u2013 is it my fault that the two look so much alike?\r\n\r\nAnd when life once asked me: \u201cWho is this wisdom anyway?\u201d\u2013 I has- tened to reply: \u201cOh yes! Wisdom!\r\n\r\nOne thirsts for her and does not become sated, one peeks through veils, one snatches through nets.\r\n\r\nIs she beautiful? What do I know! But even the oldest carps are baited by her.\r\n\r\nShe is fickle and stubborn; often I saw her bite her lip and comb her hair against the grain.\r\n\r\nPerhaps she is evil and false, and in all things a female; but when she speaks ill of herself, precisely then she seduces the most.\u201d\r\n\r\nWhen I had said this to life she laughed sarcastically and closed her eyes: \u201cWhom are you talking about?\u201d she said. \u201cSurely about me?\r\n\r\nAnd even if you are right \u2013 does one say that to my face? But now speak too of your own wisdom!\u201d\r\n\r\nOh, and now you opened your eyes again, oh beloved life! And again I seemed to sink into the unfathomable. \u2013\r\n\r\nThus sang Zarathustra. But when the dance had ended and the girls departed, he became sad.\r\n\r\n\u201cThe sun set long ago,\u201d he remarked at last. \u201cThe meadow is moist, coolness emanates from the woods.\r\n\r\nSomething unknown is around me and it gazes pensively. What \u2013 you are still alive, Zarathustra?\r\n\r\nWhy? Wherefore? Whereby? Whither? Where? How? Is it not folly to continue living? \u2013\r\n\r\nAlas, my friends, it is the evening whose questions emerge from me. Forgive me my sadness!\r\n\r\nEvening came: forgive me that evening came!\u201d\r\n\r\nThus spoke Zarathustra."}, "id": 48}, {"data": {"uuid": "7dcd8cbd-39dd-4dba-980c-1fc6b792d0f8", "user": 1, "title": "The Grave Song", "created_on": "2023-05-10 15:29:53.542331+00:00", "updated_on": "2023-05-10 15:29:53.559806+00:00", "article_html": "<h2>The Grave Song</h2><p>\u201cThere is the island of graves, the silent one; there too are the graves of my youth. There I shall carry an evergreen wreath of life.\u201d</p><p>Resolving thus in my heart I crossed the sea. \u2013</p><p>Oh you visions and apparitions of my youth! Oh all you glances of love, you godlike glancing moments! How quickly you died! I remember you today like my dead.</p><p>From you, from my dearest departed, comes a sweet fragrance, releasing my tears and my heart. Indeed, it shakes and releases the heart of this lonely seafarer.</p><p>I am still the richest and the one to be envied most \u2013 I the loneliest one! For I had you once, and you have me still: tell me, for whom did such rosy apples fall from the tree as for me?</p><p>I am still the heir and earth of your love, blossoming in remembrance of you with colorful, wild-growing virtues, oh you most beloved!</p><p>Indeed, we were made to stay close to each other, you noble, strange wonders; and not like skittish birds did you come to me and to my desire \u2013 no, as trusting ones to a trusting one!</p><p>Yes, made for loyalty, like me, and for tender eternities; I must now refer to you by your disloyalty, you godlike glances and glancing moments, for I\u2019ve learned no other name yet.</p><p>Indeed, you died too soon for me, you fugitives. Yet you did not flee me, nor did I flee you: we are mutually innocent in our disloyalty.</p><p>To kill me they strangled you, you songbirds of my hopes! Yes, at you, my dearest ones, malice always shot its arrows \u2013 to strike my heart!</p><p>And it struck! For you were always closest to my heart, my posses- sion and what possessed me: for that you had to die young and all too early!</p><p>The arrow was shot at the most vulnerable thing that I possessed; that was you, whose skin is like down and even more like a smile that dies of a glance!</p><p>But these words I shall speak to my enemies: what is all murder of human beings compared to what you did to me!</p><p>More evil you did to me than all murder of human beings. You took from me what was irretrievable \u2013 thus I speak to you, my enemies!</p><p>For you murdered my youth\u2019s visions and dearest wonders! You took my playmates from me, the blessed spirits! In remembrance of them I lay down this wreath and this curse.</p><p>This curse against you, my enemies! For you cut my eternity short, like a sound breaks off in cold night! It barely reached me as the flash of godlike eyes \u2013 as a glancing moment!</p><p>Thus at a good hour my purity once spoke to me: \u201cGodlike shall all beings be to me.\u201d</p><p>Then you fell upon me with filthy ghosts; alas, where now has that good hour fled? \u201cAll days shall be holy to me\u201d \u2013 so spoke the wisdom of my youth, once; truly, the speech of a gay wisdom!</p><p>But then you enemies stole my nights and sold them into sleepless agony; alas, where now has my gay wisdom fled?</p><p>Once I yearned for happy signs from birds; then you led an owl abom- ination across my path, a repulsive one. Alas, where then did my tender yearning flee?</p><p>Once I pledged to renounce all nausea; then you transformed those near and nearest me into boils of pus. Alas, where then did my noblest pledge flee?</p><p>As a blind man I once walked blessed paths; then you tossed filth onto the path of the blind man, and now he is repulsed by the old blind man\u2019s footpath.</p><p>And when I did what was hardest for me and celebrated the victory of my overcomings; then you made those who loved me cry out that I hurt them most.</p><p>Indeed, that was always your doing; you turned to gall my best honey and the hard work of my best bees.</p><p>You always dispatched the most impudent beggars to my charity; you always crowded the incurably shameless around my pity. Thus you wounded my virtue in its faith.</p><p>And when I laid down even what was holiest to me as a sacrifice; instantly your \u201cpiety\u201d placed its fatter gifts on top, such that what was holiest to me choked in the smoke of your fat.</p><p>And once I wanted to dance as I had never danced before; over and beyond all heavens I wanted to dance. Then you swayed my favorite singer.</p><p>And then he struck up a horrid, dreadful tune; indeed, he tooted in my ears like a mournful horn!</p><p>Murderous singer, tool of malice, most innocent one! Already I stood poised for my best dance; then you murdered my enchantment with your tones!</p><p>Only in dance do I know how to speak the parables of the highest things \u2013 and now my highest parable remained unspoken in my limbs!</p><p>My highest hope remained unspoken and unredeemed! And all the visions and comforts of my youth died.</p><p>How did I bear it? How did I overturn and overcome such wounds? How did my soul rise again from these graves?</p><p>Yes, there is something invulnerable, unburiable in me, something that explodes boulders: it is called my will. Silently and unchanged it strides through the years.</p><p>It wants to walk its course on my feet, my old will; its mind is heart- hardened and invulnerable.</p><p>Invulnerable am I only in the heel. You still live and are the same, most patient one! You have always broken through all graves!</p><p>In you what is unredeemed of my youth lives on; and as life and youth you sit here hoping upon greying ruins of graves.</p><p>Yes, to me you are still the shatterer of all graves: Hail to you, my will! And only where there are graves are there resurrections. \u2013</p><p>Thus sang Zarathustra. \u2013</p>", "article_json": {"type": "doc", "content": [{"type": "heading", "attrs": {"level": 2}, "content": [{"text": "The Grave Song", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "content": [{"text": "\u201cThere is the island of graves, the silent one; there too are the graves of my youth. There I shall carry an evergreen wreath of life.\u201d\r\n\r\nResolving thus in my heart I crossed the sea. \u2013\r\n\r\nOh you visions and apparitions of my youth! Oh all you glances of love, you godlike glancing moments! How quickly you died! I remember you today like my dead.\r\n\r\nFrom you, from my dearest departed, comes a sweet fragrance, releasing my tears and my heart. Indeed, it shakes and releases the heart of this lonely seafarer.\r\n\r\nI am still the richest and the one to be envied most \u2013 I the loneliest one! For I had you once, and you have me still: tell me, for whom did such rosy apples fall from the tree as for me?\r\n\r\nI am still the heir and earth of your love, blossoming in remembrance of you with colorful, wild-growing virtues, oh you most beloved!\r\n\r\nIndeed, we were made to stay close to each other, you noble, strange wonders; and not like skittish birds did you come to me and to my desire \u2013 no, as trusting ones to a trusting one!\r\n\r\nYes, made for loyalty, like me, and for tender eternities; I must now refer to you by your disloyalty, you godlike glances and glancing moments, for I\u2019ve learned no other name yet.\r\n\r\nIndeed, you died too soon for me, you fugitives. Yet you did not flee me, nor did I flee you: we are mutually innocent in our disloyalty.\r\n\r\nTo kill me they strangled you, you songbirds of my hopes! Yes, at you, my dearest ones, malice always shot its arrows \u2013 to strike my heart!\r\n\r\nAnd it struck! For you were always closest to my heart, my posses- sion and what possessed me: for that you had to die young and all too early!\r\n\r\nThe arrow was shot at the most vulnerable thing that I possessed; that was you, whose skin is like down and even more like a smile that dies of a glance!\r\n\r\nBut these words I shall speak to my enemies: what is all murder of human beings compared to what you did to me!\r\n\r\nMore evil you did to me than all murder of human beings. You took from me what was irretrievable \u2013 thus I speak to you, my enemies!\r\n\r\nFor you murdered my youth\u2019s visions and dearest wonders! You took my playmates from me, the blessed spirits! In remembrance of them I lay down this wreath and this curse.\r\n\r\nThis curse against you, my enemies! For you cut my eternity short, like a sound breaks off in cold night! It barely reached me as the flash of godlike eyes \u2013 as a glancing moment!\r\n\r\nThus at a good hour my purity once spoke to me: \u201cGodlike shall all beings be to me.\u201d\r\n\r\nThen you fell upon me with filthy ghosts; alas, where now has that good hour fled? \u201cAll days shall be holy to me\u201d \u2013 so spoke the wisdom of my youth, once; truly, the speech of a gay wisdom!\r\n\r\nBut then you enemies stole my nights and sold them into sleepless agony; alas, where now has my gay wisdom fled?\r\n\r\nOnce I yearned for happy signs from birds; then you led an owl abom- ination across my path, a repulsive one. Alas, where then did my tender yearning flee?\r\n\r\nOnce I pledged to renounce all nausea; then you transformed those near and nearest me into boils of pus. Alas, where then did my noblest pledge flee?\r\n\r\nAs a blind man I once walked blessed paths; then you tossed filth onto the path of the blind man, and now he is repulsed by the old blind man\u2019s footpath.\r\n\r\nAnd when I did what was hardest for me and celebrated the victory of my overcomings; then you made those who loved me cry out that I hurt them most.\r\n\r\nIndeed, that was always your doing; you turned to gall my best honey and the hard work of my best bees.\r\n\r\nYou always dispatched the most impudent beggars to my charity; you always crowded the incurably shameless around my pity. Thus you wounded my virtue in its faith.\r\n\r\nAnd when I laid down even what was holiest to me as a sacrifice; instantly your \u201cpiety\u201d placed its fatter gifts on top, such that what was holiest to me choked in the smoke of your fat.\r\n\r\nAnd once I wanted to dance as I had never danced before; over and beyond all heavens I wanted to dance. Then you swayed my favorite singer.\r\n\r\nAnd then he struck up a horrid, dreadful tune; indeed, he tooted in my ears like a mournful horn!\r\n\r\nMurderous singer, tool of malice, most innocent one! Already I stood poised for my best dance; then you murdered my enchantment with your tones!\r\n\r\nOnly in dance do I know how to speak the parables of the highest things \u2013 and now my highest parable remained unspoken in my limbs!\r\n\r\nMy highest hope remained unspoken and unredeemed! And all the visions and comforts of my youth died.\r\n\r\nHow did I bear it? How did I overturn and overcome such wounds? How did my soul rise again from these graves?\r\n\r\nYes, there is something invulnerable, unburiable in me, something that explodes boulders: it is called my will. Silently and unchanged it strides through the years.\r\n\r\nIt wants to walk its course on my feet, my old will; its mind is heart- hardened and invulnerable.\r\n\r\nInvulnerable am I only in the heel. You still live and are the same, most patient one! You have always broken through all graves!\r\n\r\nIn you what is unredeemed of my youth lives on; and as life and youth you sit here hoping upon greying ruins of graves.\r\n\r\nYes, to me you are still the shatterer of all graves: Hail to you, my will! And only where there are graves are there resurrections. \u2013\r\n\r\nThus sang Zarathustra. \u2013"}, "id": 49}, {"data": {"uuid": "74c79f74-74c3-4d91-a251-14f42c35ec3b", "user": 1, "title": "On Self-Overcoming", "created_on": "2023-05-10 15:31:01.878692+00:00", "updated_on": "2023-05-10 15:31:01.900636+00:00", "article_html": "<h2>On Self-Overcoming</h2><p>\u201cWill to truth\u201d you call that which drives you and makes you lustful, you wisest ones?</p><p>Will to thinkability of all being, that\u2019s what I call your will!</p><p>You first want to make all being thinkable, because you doubt, with proper suspicion, whether it is even thinkable.</p><p>But for you it shall behave and bend! Thus your will wants it. It shall become smooth and subservient to the spirit, as its mirror and reflection.</p><p>That is your entire will, you wisest ones, as a will to power; and even when you speak of good and evil and of valuations.</p><p>You still want to create the world before which you could kneel: this is your ultimate hope and intoxication.</p><p>The unwise, to be sure, the people \u2013 they are like a river on which a skiff floats; valuations are seated in the skiff, solemn and cloaked.</p><p>Your will and your values you set upon the river of becoming; what the people believe to be good and evil reveals to me an ancient will to power.</p><p>It was you, you wisest ones, who placed such guests into the skiff and gave them pomp and proud names \u2013 you and your dominating will!</p><p>Now the river carries your skiff along: it has to carry it. It matters little whether the breaking wave foams and angrily opposes the keel!</p><p>The river is not your danger and the end of your good and evil, you wisest ones; but this will itself, the will to power \u2013 the unexhausted begetting will of life.</p><p>But in order that you understand my words on good and evil, I also want to tell you my words on life and on the nature of all that lives.</p><p>I pursued the living, I walked the greatest and the smallest paths in order to know its nature.</p><p>With a hundredfold mirror I captured even its glance, when its mouth was closed, so that its eyes could speak to me. And its eyes spoke to me.</p><p>However, wherever I found the living, there too I heard the speech on obedience. All living is an obeying.</p><p>And this is the second thing that I heard: the one who cannot obey himself is commanded. Such is the nature of the living.</p><p>This however is the third thing that I heard: that commanding is harder than obeying. And not only that the commander bears the burden of all obeyers, and that this burden easily crushes him: \u2013</p><p>In all commanding it seemed to me there is an experiment and a risk; and always when it commands, the living risks itself in doing so.</p><p>Indeed, even when it commands itself, even then it must pay for its commanding. It must become the judge and avenger and victim of its own law.</p><p>How does this happen? I asked myself. What persuades the living to obey and command, and to still practice obedience while commanding?</p><p>Hear my words, you wisest ones! Check seriously to see whether I crept into the very heart of life and into the roots of its heart!</p><p>Wherever I found the living, there I found the will to power; and even in the will of the serving I found the will to be master.</p><p>The weaker is persuaded by its own will to serve the stronger, because it wants to be master over what is still weaker: this is the only pleasure it is incapable of renouncing.</p><p>And as the smaller gives way to the greater, in order for it to have its pleasure and power over the smallest, so too the greatest gives way, and for the sake of power it risks \u2013 life itself.</p><p>That is the giving-way of the greatest, that it is a risk and a danger and a tossing of dice unto death.</p><p>And where there are sacrificing and favors and love-looks, there too is the will to be master. Along secret passages the weaker sneaks into the fortress and straight to the heart of the more powerful \u2013 and there it steals power.</p><p>And this secret life itself spoke to me: \u201cBehold,\u201d it said, \u201cI am that which must always overcome itself.</p><p>To be sure, you call it will to beget or drive to a purpose, to something higher, more distant, more manifold: but all this is one, and one secret.</p><p>I would rather perish than renounce this one thing; and truly, wher- ever there is decline and the falling of leaves, behold, there life sacrifices itself \u2013 for power!</p><p>That I must be struggle and becoming and purpose and the contradiction of purposes \u2013 alas, whoever guesses my will guesses also on what crooked paths it must walk!</p><p>Whatever I may create and however I may love it \u2013 soon I must oppose it and my love, thus my will wants it.</p><p>And even you, seeker of knowledge, are only a path and footstep of my will; indeed, my will to power follows also on the heels of your will to truth!</p><p>Indeed, the one who shot at truth with the words \u2018will to existence\u2019 did not hit it: this will \u2013 does not exist!</p><p>For, what is not can not will; but what is in existence, how could this still will to exist!</p><p>Only where life is, is there also will; but not will to life, instead \u2013 thus I teach you \u2013 will to power!</p><p>Much is esteemed more highly by life than life itself; yet out of esteeming itself speaks \u2013 the will to power!\u201d \u2013</p><p>Thus life once taught me, and from this I shall yet solve the riddle of your heart, you wisest ones.</p><p>Truly, I say to you: good and evil that would be everlasting \u2013 there is no such thing! They must overcome themselves out of themselves again and again.</p><p>You do violence with your values and words of good and evil, you valuators; and this is your hidden love and the gleaming, trembling and flowing-over of your souls.</p><p>But a stronger force grows out of your values and a new overcoming; upon it egg and eggshell break.</p><p>And whoever must be a creator in good and evil \u2013 truly, he must first be an annihilator and break values.</p><p>Thus the highest evil belongs to the highest goodness, but this is the creative one. \u2013</p><p>Let us speak of this, you wisest ones, even if it is bad to do so. Keeping silent is worse; all truths that are kept silent become poisonous.</p><p>And may everything break that can possibly be broken by our truths! Many a house has yet to be built!</p><p>Thus spoke Zarathustra.</p>", "article_json": {"type": "doc", "content": [{"type": "heading", "attrs": {"level": 2}, "content": [{"text": "On Self-Overcoming", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "content": [{"text": "\u201cWill to truth\u201d you call that which drives you and makes you lustful, you wisest ones?", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "content": [{"text": "Will to thinkability of all being, that\u2019s what I call your will!", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "content": [{"text": "You first want to make all being thinkable, because you doubt, with proper suspicion, whether it is even thinkable.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "content": [{"text": "But for you it shall behave and bend! Gloomy this hunter returned from the woods of knowledge.</p><p>He returned home from his battle with wild animals; but from his earnestness too a wild animal gazes \u2013 an unconquered one!</p><p>And he stands there like a tiger that wants to spring; but I don\u2019t like these tense souls, my taste is hostile to all these retiring types.</p><p>And you tell me, friends, that taste and tasting are nothing to be disputed? But all life is disputing of taste and tasting!</p><p>Taste: that is simultaneously weight and scale and weigher, and woe to all that would live without disputing weight and scale and weighers!</p><p>If he would tire of his sublimity, this sublime one; only then would his beauty arise \u2013 and only then shall I taste him and find him tasteful.</p><p>And only when he turns away from himself will he leap over his own shadow \u2013 and truly! into his own sun.</p><p>All too long he sat in the shadows, and the cheeks of this ascetic of the spirit grew pale; he nearly starved on his expectations.</p><p>There is still contempt in his eyes, and nausea lingers on his lips. He is peaceful now, to be sure, but his peace has not yet laid itself in the sun.</p><p>He should act like a bull; and his happiness should smell of earth and not of contempt for the earth.</p><p>I want to see him as a white bull, snorting and bellowing ahead of the plow \u2013 and his bellowing should praise everything earthly!</p><p>His face is still dark; the shadow of the hand still plays upon him. His sense of sight is still overshadowed.</p><p>His deed itself is still the shadow on him; the hand darkens the doer. He has not yet overcome his deed.</p><p>I do love the bull\u2019s neck on him, but now I also want to see the angel\u2019s eyes.</p><p>He must also unlearn his hero\u2019s will; he shall be elevated, not merely sublime \u2013 the ether itself shall elevate him, the will-less one!</p><p>He subdued monsters, he solved riddles, but he should also solve his own monsters and riddles; he should transform them into heavenly children.</p><p>As of yet his knowledge has not learned to smile and to be without jealousy; his torrential passion has not yet become calm in its beauty.</p><p>Indeed, not in satiety shall his yearning keep silent and submerge, but in beauty! Grace belongs to the graciousness of the great-minded.</p><p>With his arm laid across his head \u2013 thus the hero should rest, thus too he should overcome even his resting.</p><p>But precisely for the hero beauty is the most difficult of all things. Beauty is not be wrested by any violent willing.</p><p>A little more, a little less: right here this means much, here this means the most.</p><p>To stand with muscles relaxed and with an unharnessed will: this is most difficult for all of you sublime ones!</p><p>When power becomes gracious and descends into view: beauty I call such descending.</p><p>And from no one do I want beauty as I do from just you, you powerful one: let your kindness be your ultimate self-conquest.</p><p>I know you capable of all evil \u2013 therefore from you I want the good.</p><p>Indeed, I often laughed at the weaklings who believe themselves good because their paws are lame!</p><p>You shall strive to emulate the virtue of a column; ever more beautiful and delicate it becomes, the higher it rises, but inwardly harder and more resistant.</p><p>Yes, you sublime one, one day you shall be beautiful and shall hold the mirror up to your own beauty.</p><p>Then your soul will shudder with divine desires, and even in your vanity there will be adoration!</p><p>For this is the secret of the soul: only when the hero abandons her, she is approached in dream by \u2013 the over-hero.</p><p>Thus spoke Zarathustra.</p>", "article_json": {"type": "doc", "content": [{"type": "heading", "attrs": {"level": 2}, "content": [{"text": "On the Sublime Ones", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "content": [{"text": "The bottom of my sea is calm \u2013 who would guess that it conceals playful monsters?", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "content": [{"text": "My depth is unfathomable, but it gleams with swimming riddles and laughters.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "content": [{"text": "I saw a sublime one today, a solemn one, an ascetic of the spirit;
