oh how my soul laughed at his ugliness!\r\n\r\nWith his chest sticking out like those who hold their breath he stood there, the sublime one, silently:\r\n\r\nAdorned with ugly truths, his hunter\u2019s spoils, and rich in tattered clothing; many thorns clung to him also \u2013 but I saw nary a rose.\r\n\r\nHe had not yet learned laughing and beauty. Gloomy this hunter returned from the woods of knowledge.\r\n\r\nHe returned home from his battle with wild animals; but from his earnestness too a wild animal gazes \u2013 an unconquered one!\r\n\r\nAnd he stands there like a tiger that wants to spring; but I don\u2019t like these tense souls, my taste is hostile to all these retiring types.\r\n\r\nAnd you tell me, friends, that taste and tasting are nothing to be disputed? But all life is disputing of taste and tasting!\r\n\r\nTaste: that is simultaneously weight and scale and weigher, and woe to all that would live without disputing weight and scale and weighers!\r\n\r\nIf he would tire of his sublimity, this sublime one; only then would his beauty arise \u2013 and only then shall I taste him and find him tasteful.\r\n\r\nAnd only when he turns away from himself will he leap over his own shadow \u2013 and truly! into his own sun.\r\n\r\nAll too long he sat in the shadows, and the cheeks of this ascetic of the spirit grew pale; he nearly starved on his expectations.\r\n\r\nThere is still contempt in his eyes, and nausea lingers on his lips. He is peaceful now, to be sure, but his peace has not yet laid itself in the sun.\r\n\r\nHe should act like a bull; and his happiness should smell of earth and not of contempt for the earth.\r\n\r\nI want to see him as a white bull, snorting and bellowing ahead of the plow \u2013 and his bellowing should praise everything earthly!\r\n\r\nHis face is still dark; the shadow of the hand still plays upon him. His sense of sight is still overshadowed.\r\n\r\nHis deed itself is still the shadow on him; the hand darkens the doer. He has not yet overcome his deed.\r\n\r\nI do love the bull\u2019s neck on him, but now I also want to see the angel\u2019s eyes.\r\n\r\nHe must also unlearn his hero\u2019s will; he shall be elevated, not merely sublime \u2013 the ether itself shall elevate him, the will-less one!\r\n\r\nHe subdued monsters, he solved riddles, but he should also solve his own monsters and riddles; he should transform them into heavenly children.\r\n\r\nAs of yet his knowledge has not learned to smile and to be without jealousy; his torrential passion has not yet become calm in its beauty.\r\n\r\nIndeed, not in satiety shall his yearning keep silent and submerge, but in beauty! Grace belongs to the graciousness of the great-minded.\r\n\r\nWith his arm laid across his head \u2013 thus the hero should rest, thus too he should overcome even his resting.\r\n\r\nBut precisely for the hero beauty is the most difficult of all things. Beauty is not be wrested by any violent willing.\r\n\r\nA little more, a little less: right here this means much, here this means the most.\r\n\r\nTo stand with muscles relaxed and with an unharnessed will: this is most difficult for all of you sublime ones!\r\n\r\nWhen power becomes gracious and descends into view: beauty I call such descending.\r\n\r\nAnd from no one do I want beauty as I do from just you, you powerful one: let your kindness be your ultimate self-conquest.\r\n\r\nI know you capable of all evil \u2013 therefore from you I want the good.\r\n\r\nIndeed, I often laughed at the weaklings who believe themselves good because their paws are lame!\r\n\r\nYou shall strive to emulate the virtue of a column; ever more beautiful and delicate it becomes, the higher it rises, but inwardly harder and more resistant.\r\n\r\nYes, you sublime one, one day you shall be beautiful and shall hold the mirror up to your own beauty.\r\n\r\nThen your soul will shudder with divine desires, and even in your vanity there will be adoration!\r\n\r\nFor this is the secret of the soul: only when the hero abandons her, she is approached in dream by \u2013 the over-hero.\r\n\r\nThus spoke Zarathustra."}, "id": 51}, {"data": {"uuid": "7d5283d5-dc9c-4905-84da-0994d3db7128", "user": 1, "title": "On the Land of Education", "created_on": "2023-05-10 15:32:59.209354+00:00", "updated_on": "2023-05-10 15:32:59.234143+00:00", "article_html": "<h2>On the Land of Education</h2><p>Too far into the future did I fly; dread fell upon me.</p><p>And when I looked around, behold! Then time was my only contemporary.</p><p>Then I fled backward, homeward \u2013 with ever greater haste. Thus I came to you, you of the present, and into the land of education.</p><p>For the first time I brought along eyes for you, and a strong desire; indeed, I came with longing in my heart.</p><p>But what happened to me? As frightened as I was \u2013 I had to laugh! Never had my eyes seen anything so splattered with colors!</p><p>I laughed and laughed, while my foot still trembled and my heart as well: \u201cThis must be the home of all paint pots!\u201d I said.</p><p>With fifty blotches painted on your face and limbs, thus you sat there to my amazement, you people of the present!</p><p>And with fifty mirrors around you, flattering and echoing your play of colors!</p><p>Indeed, you couldn\u2019t wear a better mask, you people of today, than that of your own face! Who could recognize you!</p><p>Written full with the characters of the past, and even these characters painted over with new characters: thus you have hidden yourselves well from all interpreters of characters!</p><p>And even if one were to give you a physical examination, who would even believe you have a body? You seem to be baked from colors and paper slips glued together.</p><p>Motley, all ages and peoples peek from your veils; motley, all customs and beliefs speak from your gestures.</p><p>If one were to pull away veil and wrap and color and gesture from you, there would be just enough left over to scare away the crows.</p><p>Indeed, I myself am the scared crow who once saw you naked and without color; and I flew away when the skeleton beckoned amorously.</p><p>I would rather be a day laborer in the underworld and among the shades of yore! \u2013 Even the underworldly are fatter and fuller than you!</p><p>This, oh this is bitterness for my bowels, that I can stand you neither naked nor clothed, you people of the present!</p><p>All uncanniness of the future, and whatever caused flown birds to shudder, is truly homelier and more familiar than your \u201creality.\u201d</p><p>For you speak thus: \u201cWe are real entirely, and without beliefs and superstition.\u201d Thus you stick out your chests \u2013 alas, even without chests!</p><p>Indeed, how should you be capable of believing, you color-splattered ones \u2013 you who are paintings of everything that has ever been believed!</p><p>Rambling refutations of belief itself are you, and the limb-fracturing of every thought. Unbelievable is what I call you, you so-called real ones!</p><p>All ages prattle against each other in your minds; and the dreams and prattling of all ages were more real than even your waking is!</p><p>You are sterile: therefore you lack beliefs. But whoever had to create also always had his prophetic dreams and astrological signs \u2013 and believed in believing! \u2013</p><p>You are half-open gates, at which the gravediggers wait. And this is your reality: \u201cEverything deserves to perish.\u201d</p><p>Oh how you stand there, you sterile ones, how skinny in the ribs! And some one of you probably realized this on his own.</p><p>And he spoke: \u201cSurely some god secretly removed something from me while I slept? Indeed, enough to form himself a little woman from it!</p><p>Wondrous is the poverty of my ribs!\u201d Thus spoke many a person of the present.</p><p>Indeed, you make me laugh, you people of the present! And especially when you are amazed at yourselves!</p><p>And woe to me if I couldn\u2019t laugh at your amazement, and had to drink down all the repugnant contents of your bowls!</p><p>So I shall take you more lightly, as I have a heavy burden; and what does it matter to me if beetles and winged worms still land on my bundle?</p><p>Indeed, it will not become any heavier for that! And not from you, you people of the present, shall my great weariness come. \u2013</p><p>Alas, where shall I climb now with my longing! From all mountains I look out for father- and motherlands.</p><p>But nowhere did I find home; I am unsettled in every settlement, and a departure at every gate.</p><p>Foreign to me and a mockery are these people of the present to whom my heart recently drove me; and I am driven out of father- and motherlands.</p><p>Thus I love only my children\u2019s land, the undiscovered land in the furthest sea: for it I command my sails to seek and seek.</p><p>I want to make it up to my children for being the child of my fathers; and to all the future \u2013 for the existence of this present!</p><p>Thus spoke Zarathustra.</p>", "article_json": {"type": "doc", "content": [{"type": "heading", "attrs": {"level": 2}, "content": [{"text": "On the Land of Education", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "content": [{"text": "Too far into the future did I fly; dread fell upon me.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "content": [{"text": "And when I looked around, behold! Then time was my only contemporary.\r\n\r\nThen I fled backward, homeward \u2013 with ever greater haste. Thus I came to you, you of the present, and into the land of education.\r\n\r\nFor the first time I brought along eyes for you, and a strong desire; indeed, I came with longing in my heart.\r\n\r\nBut what happened to me? As frightened as I was \u2013 I had to laugh! Never had my eyes seen anything so splattered with colors!\r\n\r\nI laughed and laughed, while my foot still trembled and my heart as well: \u201cThis must be the home of all paint pots!\u201d I said.\r\n\r\nWith fifty blotches painted on your face and limbs, thus you sat there to my amazement, you people of the present!\r\n\r\nAnd with fifty mirrors around you, flattering and echoing your play of colors!\r\n\r\nIndeed, you couldn\u2019t wear a better mask, you people of today, than that of your own face! Who could recognize you!\r\n\r\nWritten full with the characters of the past, and even these characters painted over with new characters: thus you have hidden yourselves well from all interpreters of characters!\r\n\r\nAnd even if one were to give you a physical examination, who would even believe you have a body? You seem to be baked from colors and paper slips glued together.\r\n\r\nMotley, all ages and peoples peek from your veils; motley, all customs and beliefs speak from your gestures.\r\n\r\nIf one were to pull away veil and wrap and color and gesture from you, there would be just enough left over to scare away the crows.\r\n\r\nIndeed, I myself am the scared crow who once saw you naked and without color; and I flew away when the skeleton beckoned amorously.\r\n\r\nI would rather be a day laborer in the underworld and among the shades of yore! \u2013 Even the underworldly are fatter and fuller than you!\r\n\r\nThis, oh this is bitterness for my bowels, that I can stand you neither naked nor clothed, you people of the present!\r\n\r\nAll uncanniness of the future, and whatever caused flown birds to shudder, is truly homelier and more familiar than your \u201creality.\u201d\r\n\r\nFor you speak thus: \u201cWe are real entirely, and without beliefs and superstition.\u201d Thus you stick out your chests \u2013 alas, even without chests!\r\n\r\nIndeed, how should you be capable of believing, you color-splattered ones \u2013 you who are paintings of everything that has ever been believed!\r\n\r\nRambling refutations of belief itself are you, and the limb-fracturing of every thought. Unbelievable is what I call you, you so-called real ones!\r\n\r\nAll ages prattle against each other in your minds; and the dreams and prattling of all ages were more real than even your waking is!\r\n\r\nYou are sterile: therefore you lack beliefs. But whoever had to create also always had his prophetic dreams and astrological signs \u2013 and believed in believing! \u2013\r\n\r\nYou are half-open gates, at which the gravediggers wait. And this is your reality: \u201cEverything deserves to perish.\u201d\r\n\r\nOh how you stand there, you sterile ones, how skinny in the ribs! And some one of you probably realized this on his own.\r\n\r\nAnd he spoke: \u201cSurely some god secretly removed something from me while I slept? Indeed, enough to form himself a little woman from it!\r\n\r\nWondrous is the poverty of my ribs!\u201d Thus spoke many a person of the present.\r\n\r\nIndeed, you make me laugh, you people of the present! And especially when you are amazed at yourselves!\r\n\r\nAnd woe to me if I couldn\u2019t laugh at your amazement, and had to drink down all the repugnant contents of your bowls!\r\n\r\nSo I shall take you more lightly, as I have a heavy burden; and what does it matter to me if beetles and winged worms still land on my bundle?\r\n\r\nIndeed, it will not become any heavier for that! And not from you, you people of the present, shall my great weariness come. \u2013\r\n\r\nAlas, where shall I climb now with my longing! From all mountains I look out for father- and motherlands.\r\n\r\nBut nowhere did I find home; I am unsettled in every settlement, and a departure at every gate.\r\n\r\nForeign to me and a mockery are these people of the present to whom my heart recently drove me; and I am driven out of father- and motherlands.\r\n\r\nThus I love only my children\u2019s land, the undiscovered land in the furthest sea: for it I command my sails to seek and seek.\r\n\r\nI want to make it up to my children for being the child of my fathers; and to all the future \u2013 for the existence of this present!\r\n\r\nThus spoke Zarathustra."}, "id": 52}, {"data": {"uuid": "ff6b0e28-8c34-45be-9bf4-22c5c9771726", "user": 1, "title": "On Immaculate Perception", "created_on": "2023-05-10 15:33:47.266660+00:00", "updated_on": "2023-05-10 15:33:47.281540+00:00", "article_html": "<h2>On Immaculate Perception</h2><p>When the moon rose yesterday I imagined that it wanted to give birth to a sun, so broad and pregnant it lay there on the horizon.</p><p>But it lied to me with its pregnancy; and sooner would I believe in the man in the moon than in the woman.</p><p>Indeed, he is not much of a man either, this timid nocturnal rhapsodist. Truly, with a bad conscience he wanders over the rooftops.</p><p>For he is lecherous and jealous, this monk in the moon, lecherous for the earth and for all the joys of lovers.</p><p>No, I do not like him, this tomcat on the rooftops! I am disgusted by all who creep around half-closed windows!</p><p>Pious and silent he wanders his way on starry carpets \u2013 but I do not like any soft-stepping man\u2019s foot on which a spur does not jingle too.</p><p>Every honest step speaks; but a cat steals away across the ground. Observe, catlike the moon approaches, and dishonestly. \u2013</p><p>This parable I give to you sentimental hypocrites, you \u201cpure perceivers!\u201d I call you \u2013 lechers!</p><p>You too love the earth and the earthly; I found you out! \u2013 But there is shame in your love and bad conscience \u2013 you resemble the moon!</p><p>Your spirit was persuaded to despise the earthly, but not your entrails; and they are the strongest part of you!</p><p>And now your spirit is ashamed to do the bidding of your entrails, and out of its own shame it takes the paths that sneak and lie.</p><p>\u201cFor me what is highest\u201d \u2013 thus speaks your lying spirit to itself \u2013 \u201cwould be to look upon life without desire and not like a dog with its tongue hanging out:</p><p>To be content in viewing, with dead will, without the grasp and greed of selfishness \u2013 cold and ashen grey in my whole body, but with drunken mooning eyes!</p><p>To me the dearest thing would be\u201d \u2013 thus the seducer seduces himself \u2013 \u201cto love the earth as the moon loves it, and to touch its beauty only with the eyes.</p><p>And to me the immaculate perception of all things would be that I desire nothing from things, except that I might lie there before them like a mirror with a hundred eyes.\u201d \u2013</p><p>Oh you sentimental hypocrites, you lechers! Your desire lacks innocence, and now therefore you slander all desiring!</p><p>Indeed, you do not love the earth as creators, begetters, and enjoyers of becoming!</p><p>Where is innocence? Where there is will to beget. And whoever wants to create over and beyond himself, he has the purest will.</p><p>Where is beauty? Where I must will with my entire will; where I want to love and perish so that an image does not remain merely an image.</p><p>Loving and perishing: these have gone together since the beginning of time. Will to love: that means being willing also for death. Thus I speak to you cowards!</p><p>But now your emasculated leering wants to be called \u201ccontemplation!\u201d And whatever allows itself to be touched by cowardly eyes is supposed to be christened \u201cbeautiful!\u201d Oh you besmirchers of noble names!</p><p>But that shall be your curse, you immaculate, you pure-perceiving ones, that you shall never give birth; and even if you lie broad and pregnant on the horizon!</p><p>Indeed, you take a mouthful of noble words, and we are supposed to believe that your heart is overflowing, you liars?</p><p>But my words are meager, despised, crooked words; gladly do I pick up what falls beneath the table during your meal.</p><p>For with them I can still \u2013 tell hypocrites the truth! Yes, my fish bones, mussel shells and thorny leaves shall tickle the noses of hypocrites!</p><p>There is always foul air around you and your meals; after all, your lecherous thoughts, your lies and secrets are in the air!</p><p>Dare for once to believe yourselves \u2013 yourselves and your entrails! Whoever cannot believe himself always lies.</p><p>A god\u2019s mask you don before yourselves, you \u201cpure ones.\u201d Into a god\u2019s mask your horrid worm has crawled.</p><p>Indeed, you deceive, you \u201ccontemplative ones!\u201d Zarathustra too was once the fool of your godlike skins; he had not discovered the coils of snakes with which they were stuffed.</p><p>I once imagined seeing a god\u2019s soul playing in your play, you pure perceivers! Once I imagined no better art than your arts!</p><p>The distance concealed snake-filth and foul odor from me, and that the guile of a lizard lecherously crawled around here.</p><p>But I came near you: then daylight came to me \u2013 and now it comes to you \u2013 the moon\u2019s fling is at an end!</p><p>Look there! Chagrined and pale he stands there \u2013 before the dawn!</p><p>For she is coming already, the glowing one \u2013 her love for the earth is coming! Innocence and the creator\u2019s desire is all solar love!</p><p>Look there, how she glides impatiently across the sea! Do you not feel her thirst and the hot breath of her love?</p><p>She would suck at the sea and drink its depths into herself in the heights; now the sea\u2019s desire rises with a thousand breasts.</p><p>It wants to be kissed and sucked by the thirst of the sun; it wants to become air and height and footpath of light and light itself!</p><p>Indeed, like the sun I love life and all deep seas.</p><p>And this I call perception: all that is deep shall rise \u2013 to my height!</p><p>Thus spoke Zarathustra.</p>", "article_json": {"type": "doc", "content": [{"type": "heading", "attrs": {"level": 2}, "content": [{"text": "On Immaculate Perception", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "content": [{"text": "When the moon rose yesterday I imagined that it wanted to give birth to a sun, so broad and pregnant it lay there on the horizon.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "content": [{"text": "But it lied to me with its pregnancy; and sooner would I believe in the man in the moon than in the woman.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "content": [{"text": "Indeed, he is not much of a man either, this timid nocturnal rhapsodist. A child told it to me.</p><p>I like to lie here where the children play, by the crumbling wall, beneath thistles and red poppies.</p><p>I am still a scholar to the children and also to the thistles and the red poppies. They are innocent, even in their spite.</p><p>But to the sheep I am no longer a scholar, thus my fate wants it \u2013 blessed be it!</p><p>For this is the truth: I have moved out of the house of the scholars, and I slammed the door on my way out.</p><p>Too long my soul sat hungry at their table; unlike them, I am not trained to approach knowledge as if cracking nuts.</p><p>I love freedom and the air over fresh earth; and I would rather sleep on ox hides than on their honors and reputations.</p><p>I am too hot and burned up by my own thoughts; often it steals my breath away. Then I have to go out into the open and away from all dusty chambers.</p><p>But they sit cool in their cool shade; in all things they want to be mere spectators and they take care not to sit where the sun burns on the steps.</p><p>Just like those who stand in the street and gape at the people who pass by; thus too they wait and gape at thoughts that others have thought.</p><p>When grasped they puff out clouds of dust like sacks of flour, involuntarily; but who would guess that their dust comes from grain and from the yellow bliss of summer fields?</p><p>When they pose as wise, I am chilled by their little proverbs and truths; often there is an odor to their wisdom, as if it came from the swamp, and truly, I have already heard the frog croaking out of it!</p><p>They are skilled, they have clever fingers; why would my simplicity want to be near their multiplicity? Their fingers know how to do all manner of threading and knotting and weaving, and thus they knit the stockings of the spirit!</p><p>They are good clockworks, only one has to see to it that they are properly wound! Then they indicate the hour faithfully and make only a modest noise.</p><p>Like mills and stamps they work; one need only toss them one\u2019s grain \u2013 they know how to grind down kernels and make white dust out of them! They are good at spying on, and are not the best at trusting one another. Inventive in petty cleverness they lie in wait for those whose knowledge walks on lame feet \u2013 they lie in wait like spiders.</p><p>I have always seen them prepare poison with caution, and always they donned gloves of glass for their fingers.</p><p>And they also know how to play with loaded dice; and I found them so ardent in their play that they sweated.</p><p>We are strangers to one another, and their virtues are even more repug- nant to me than their falseness and false dice.</p><p>And when I dwelled among them, I dwelled over them. For this they bore a grudge against me.</p><p>They will hear nothing of it that someone strolls over their heads; and so they placed wood and earth and filth between me and their heads.</p><p>Thus they muffled the sound of my steps; and up till now the ones to hear me least have been the most scholarly.</p><p>All that is substandard and weakness in humans they laid between themselves and me \u2013 \u201csub-floor\u201d they call it in their houses.</p><p>But despite this I stroll with my thoughts over their heads; and even if I wanted to stroll atop my own mistakes, I would still be over them and their heads.</p><p>For human beings are not equal: thus speaks justice. And what I want, they would not be permitted to want!</p><p>Thus spoke Zarathustra.</p>", "article_json": {"type": "doc", "content": [{"type": "heading", "attrs": {"level": 2}, "content": [{"text": "On Scholars", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "content": [{"text": "As I lay sleeping a sheep munched at the ivy wreath on my head \u2013 munched and spoke: \u201cZarathustra is no longer a scholar.\u201d", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "content": [{"text": "Spoke it and walked away, reproving and proud. A child told it to me.\r\n\r\nI like to lie here where the children play, by the crumbling wall, beneath thistles and red poppies.\r\n\r\nI am still a scholar to the children and also to the thistles and the red poppies. They are innocent, even in their spite.\r\n\r\nBut to the sheep I am no longer a scholar, thus my fate wants it \u2013 blessed be it!\r\n\r\nFor this is the truth: I have moved out of the house of the scholars, and I slammed the door on my way out.\r\n\r\nToo long my soul sat hungry at their table; unlike them, I am not trained to approach knowledge as if cracking nuts.\r\n\r\nI love freedom and the air over fresh earth; and I would rather sleep on ox hides than on their honors and reputations.\r\n\r\nI am too hot and burned up by my own thoughts; often it steals my breath away. Then I have to go out into the open and away from all dusty chambers.\r\n\r\nBut they sit cool in their cool shade; in all things they want to be mere spectators and they take care not to sit where the sun burns on the steps.\r\n\r\nJust like those who stand in the street and gape at the people who pass by; thus too they wait and gape at thoughts that others have thought.\r\n\r\nWhen grasped they puff out clouds of dust like sacks of flour, involuntarily; but who would guess that their dust comes from grain and from the yellow bliss of summer fields?\r\n\r\nWhen they pose as wise, I am chilled by their little proverbs and truths; often there is an odor to their wisdom, as if it came from the swamp, and truly, I have already heard the frog croaking out of it!\r\n\r\nThey are skilled, they have clever fingers; why would my simplicity want to be near their multiplicity? Their fingers know how to do all manner of threading and knotting and weaving, and thus they knit the stockings of the spirit!\r\n\r\nThey are good clockworks, only one has to see to it that they are properly wound! Then they indicate the hour faithfully and make only a modest noise.\r\n\r\nLike mills and stamps they work; one need only toss them one\u2019s grain \u2013 they know how to grind down kernels and make white dust out of them! They are good at spying on, and are not the best at trusting one another. Inventive in petty cleverness they lie in wait for those whose knowledge walks on lame feet \u2013 they lie in wait like spiders.\r\n\r\nI have always seen them prepare poison with caution, and always they donned gloves of glass for their fingers.\r\n\r\nAnd they also know how to play with loaded dice; and I found them so ardent in their play that they sweated.\r\n\r\nWe are strangers to one another, and their virtues are even more repug- nant to me than their falseness and false dice.\r\n\r\nAnd when I dwelled among them, I dwelled over them. For this they bore a grudge against me.\r\n\r\nThey will hear nothing of it that someone strolls over their heads; and so they placed wood and earth and filth between me and their heads.\r\n\r\nThus they muffled the sound of my steps; and up till now the ones to hear me least have been the most scholarly.\r\n\r\nAll that is substandard and weakness in humans they laid between themselves and me \u2013 \u201csub-floor\u201d they call it in their houses.\r\n\r\nBut despite this I stroll with my thoughts over their heads; and even if I wanted to stroll atop my own mistakes, I would still be over them and their heads.\r\n\r\nFor human beings are not equal: thus speaks justice. And what I want, they would not be permitted to want!\r\n\r\nThus spoke Zarathustra."}, "id": 54}, {"data": {"uuid": "360ec38f-7dd0-4fe2-9ac6-57372258906c", "user": 1, "title": "On Poets", "created_on": "2023-05-10 15:35:17.432111+00:00", "updated_on": "2023-05-10 15:35:17.452832+00:00", "article_html": "<h2>On Poets</h2><p>\u201cSince I have come to know the body better\u201d \u2013 Zarathustra said to one of his disciples \u2013 \u201cthe spirit is only a hypothetical spirit to me; and all that is \u2018everlasting\u2019 \u2013 that too is only a parable.\u201d</p><p>\u201cThus I heard you speak once before,\u201d answered the disciple, \u201cand at that time you added: \u2018But the poets lie too much.\u2019 Why then did you say that the poets lie too much?\u201d</p><p>\u201cWhy?\u201d said Zarathustra. \u201cYou ask why? I do not belong to those whose Why may be questioned.</p><p>Is my experience of yesterday? It has been a long time since I experi- enced the reasons of my opinions.</p><p>Would I not have to be a keg of memory if I were also to have my reasons with me?</p><p>It is already too much for me to keep my own opinions, and many a bird flies away.</p><p>And occasionally I find in my dovecot an animal that has flown to me, a strange one that trembles when I lay my hand upon it.</p><p>Yet what did Zarathustra once say to you? That the poets lie too much? \u2013 But Zarathustra too is a poet.</p><p>Do you believe now that he speaks the truth here? Why do you believe that?\u201d</p><p>The disciple answered: \u201cI believe in Zarathustra.\u201d But Zarathustra shook his head and smiled.</p><p>\u201cFaith does not make me blessed,\u201d he said. \u201cEspecially not faith in me.</p><p>But supposing that someone said in all earnestness that the poets lie too much: he is right \u2013 we lie too much.</p><p>We also know too little and are bad learners, thus we simply have to lie.</p><p>And who of us poets has not watered down his wine? Many a poisonous hodgepodge took place in our cellars, much that is indescribable was enacted there.</p><p>And because we know little, we take a hearty liking to the spiritually impoverished, especially when they are little young women!</p><p>And we are even keen for those things that little old women tell each other evenings. Within ourselves we call that \u2018the eternal feminine.\u2019</p><p>And as if there were a special, secret portal to knowledge that becomes blocked to those who learn something, thus we believe in the people and their \u2018wisdom.\u2019</p><p>But this is what all poets believe: that whoever pricks up his ears while lying in the grass or on a lonely slope will divine something about the things that are situated between heaven and earth.</p><p>And if tender stirrings come to them, then the poets always think that nature herself is in love with them:</p><p>And she creeps up to their ears to tell them secrets and enamored flatteries, the like of which makes them boastful and bloated before all mortals!</p><p>Indeed, there are so many things between heaven and earth of which only the poets have dreamed!</p><p>And especially above the heavens, for all gods are poets\u2019 parable, poets\u2019 cock and bull!</p><p>Indeed, always it lifts us up \u2013 namely to the kingdom of the clouds; atop these we set our motley bastards and then call them gods and overmen \u2013</p><p>And they are just light enough for these chairs \u2013 all these gods and overmen!</p><p>Oh how I am weary of all this imperfection that is supposed to become an event at any cost!\u201d</p><p>When Zarathustra had spoken thus, his disciple was angry with him, but he remained silent. And Zarathustra too remained silent, and his gaze had turned inward, as if he were gazing into vast distances. At last he sighed and took a breath.</p><p>\u201cI am of today and of the past,\u201d he said then. \u201cBut there is something in me that is of tomorrow and the day after tomorrow and of days to come.</p><p>I became weary of the poets, the old and the new; superficial they all are to me and shallow seas.</p><p>They did not think sufficiently to the depths, therefore their feeling did not get to the bottom.</p><p>A bit of lust and a bit of boredom \u2013 that so far has been their best contemplation.</p><p>Ghost whispers and whisking I consider all their harp jingle jangle; what have they ever known of the ardor of tones! \u2013</p><p>Nor are they clean enough for me; they all muddy their water to make it seem deep.</p><p>And though they gladly pose as reconcilers, to me they remain middle- men mixers and half-and-halfs and unclean! \u2013</p><p>Indeed, I cast my net into their seas and wanted to catch good fish; but always I hauled in an ancient god\u2019s head.</p><p>Thus the sea gave a stone to the hungry. And the poets themselves may well come from the sea.</p><p>To be sure, one finds pearls in them, and they are all the more similar to hard shellfish. And instead of a soul I often found salty slime in them.</p><p>They also learned vanity from the sea; isn\u2019t the sea the peacock of peacocks?</p><p>Even before the ugliest of all buffaloes it fans its tail, it never tires of its silver and silky fans of lace.</p><p>Defiantly the buffalo looks on, in his soul close to the sand, still closer to the thicket, but closest to the swamp.</p><p>What does he care of beauty and sea and peacock\u2019s finery? This parable I say to the poets.</p><p>Truly, their spirit itself is this peacock of peacocks and a sea of vanity!</p><p>The spirit of the poet wants spectators: even if they have to be buffaloes! \u2013</p><p>But I became weary of this spirit, and I foresee that it will become weary of itself.</p><p>Transformed I have already seen the poets, and turning their gaze against themselves.</p><p>I saw ascetics of the spirit approaching; they grew out of the poets.\u201d</p><p>Thus spoke Zarathustra.</p>", "article_json": {"type": "doc", "content": [{"type": "heading", "attrs": {"level": 2}, "content": [{"text": "On Poets", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "content": [{"text": "\u201cSince I have come to know the body better\u201d \u2013 Zarathustra said to one of his disciples \u2013 \u201cthe spirit is only a hypothetical spirit to me; and all that is \u2018everlasting\u2019 \u2013 that too is only a parable.\u201d", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "content": [{"text": "\u201cThus I heard you speak once before,\u201d answered the disciple, \u201cand at that time you added: \u2018But the poets lie too much.\u2019 Why then did you say that the poets lie too much?\u201d", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "content": [{"text": "\u201cWhy?\u201d said Zarathustra. \u201cYou ask why? I do not belong to those whose Why may be questioned.\r\n\r\nIs my experience of yesterday? It has been a long time since I experi- enced the reasons of my opinions.\r\n\r\nWould I not have to be a keg of memory if I were also to have my reasons with me?\r\n\r\nIt is already too much for me to keep my own opinions, and many a bird flies away.\r\n\r\nAnd occasionally I find in my dovecot an animal that has flown to me, a strange one that trembles when I lay my hand upon it.\r\n\r\nYet what did Zarathustra once say to you? That the poets lie too much? \u2013 But Zarathustra too is a poet.\r\n\r\nDo you believe now that he speaks the truth here? Why do you believe that?\u201d\r\n\r\nThe disciple answered: \u201cI believe in Zarathustra.\u201d But Zarathustra shook his head and smiled.\r\n\r\n\u201cFaith does not make me blessed,\u201d he said. \u201cEspecially not faith in me.\r\n\r\nBut supposing that someone said in all earnestness that the poets lie too much: he is right \u2013 we lie too much.\r\n\r\nWe also know too little and are bad learners, thus we simply have to lie.\r\n\r\nAnd who of us poets has not watered down his wine? Many a poisonous hodgepodge took place in our cellars, much that is indescribable was enacted there.\r\n\r\nAnd because we know little, we take a hearty liking to the spiritually impoverished, especially when they are little young women!\r\n\r\nAnd we are even keen for those things that little old women tell each other evenings. Within ourselves we call that \u2018the eternal feminine.\u2019\r\n\r\nAnd as if there were a special, secret portal to knowledge that becomes blocked to those who learn something, thus we believe in the people and their \u2018wisdom.\u2019\r\n\r\nBut this is what all poets believe: that whoever pricks up his ears while lying in the grass or on a lonely slope will divine something about the things that are situated between heaven and earth.\r\n\r\nAnd if tender stirrings come to them, then the poets always think that nature herself is in love with them:\r\n\r\nAnd she creeps up to their ears to tell them secrets and enamored flatteries, the like of which makes them boastful and bloated before all mortals!\r\n\r\nIndeed, there are so many things between heaven and earth of which only the poets have dreamed!\r\n\r\nAnd especially above the heavens, for all gods are poets\u2019 parable, poets\u2019 cock and bull!\r\n\r\nIndeed, always it lifts us up \u2013 namely to the kingdom of the clouds; atop these we set our motley bastards and then call them gods and overmen \u2013\r\n\r\nAnd they are just light enough for these chairs \u2013 all these gods and overmen!\r\n\r\nOh how I am weary of all this imperfection that is supposed to become an event at any cost!\u201d\r\n\r\nWhen Zarathustra had spoken thus, his disciple was angry with him, but he remained silent. And Zarathustra too remained silent, and his gaze had turned inward, as if he were gazing into vast distances. At last he sighed and took a breath.\r\n\r\n\u201cI am of today and of the past,\u201d he said then. \u201cBut there is something in me that is of tomorrow and the day after tomorrow and of days to come.\r\n\r\nI became weary of the poets, the old and the new; superficial they all are to me and shallow seas.\r\n\r\nThey did not think sufficiently to the depths, therefore their feeling did not get to the bottom.\r\n\r\nA bit of lust and a bit of boredom \u2013 that so far has been their best contemplation.\r\n\r\nGhost whispers and whisking I consider all their harp jingle jangle; what have they ever known of the ardor of tones! \u2013\r\n\r\nNor are they clean enough for me; they all muddy their water to make it seem deep.\r\n\r\nAnd though they gladly pose as reconcilers, to me they remain middle- men mixers and half-and-halfs and unclean! \u2013\r\n\r\nIndeed, I cast my net into their seas and wanted to catch good fish; but always I hauled in an ancient god\u2019s head.\r\n\r\nThus the sea gave a stone to the hungry. And the poets themselves may well come from the sea.\r\n\r\nTo be sure, one finds pearls in them, and they are all the more similar to hard shellfish. And instead of a soul I often found salty slime in them.\r\n\r\nThey also learned vanity from the sea; isn\u2019t the sea the peacock of peacocks?\r\n\r\nEven before the ugliest of all buffaloes it fans its tail, it never tires of its silver and silky fans of lace.\r\n\r\nDefiantly the buffalo looks on, in his soul close to the sand, still closer to the thicket, but closest to the swamp.\r\n\r\nWhat does he care of beauty and sea and peacock\u2019s finery? This parable I say to the poets.\r\n\r\nTruly, their spirit itself is this peacock of peacocks and a sea of vanity!\r\n\r\nThe spirit of the poet wants spectators: even if they have to be buffaloes! \u2013\r\n\r\nBut I became weary of this spirit, and I foresee that it will become weary of itself.\r\n\r\nTransformed I have already seen the poets, and turning their gaze against themselves.\r\n\r\nI saw ascetics of the spirit approaching; they grew out of the poets.\u201d\r\n\r\nThus spoke Zarathustra."}, "id": 55}, {"data": {"uuid": "9ba0b923-cc0b-4431-93d2-98a4970a7dcf", "user": 1, "title": "On Great Events", "created_on": "2023-05-10 15:36:11.464385+00:00", "updated_on": "2023-05-10 15:36:11.482268+00:00", "article_html": "<h2>On Great Events</h2><p>There is an island in the sea \u2013 not far from the blessed isles of Zarathustra \u2013 on which a fiery mountain smokes continually; the people say of it, and especially the little old women among the people say of it, that it was placed like a huge boulder before the gate to the underworld: but through the fiery mountain itself leads the narrow path that winds downward to this gate of the underworld.</p><p>Now it was around the time that Zarathustra sojourned on the blessed isles that a ship dropped anchor at the island on which the smoking mountain stands, and its crew went ashore to shoot rabbits. Toward the hour of noon, however, as the captain and his people were together again, they suddenly saw a man approaching them through the air, and a voice clearly said: \u201cIt is time! It is high time!\u201d As the figure came closest to them \u2013 and it flew past quickly like a shadow in the direction of the fiery mountain \u2013 they recognized with the greatest dismay that it was Zarathustra; for all of them had seen him before, except for the captain himself, and they loved him as the people love, with equal parts of love and awe.</p><p>\u201cJust look!\u201d said the old helmsman, \u201cthere goes Zarathustra off to hell!\u201d \u2013</p><p>Around the same time that these sailors landed on the fiery island the rumor was circulating that Zarathustra had disappeared; and when people asked his friends, they related how he had departed by ship at night, without saying where he would be traveling.</p><p>Thus a restlessness arose, but three days later this restlessness was increased by the sailors\u2019 story \u2013 and now all the people were saying that the devil had fetched Zarathustra. His disciples laughed at this news, to be sure, and one of them even said: \u201cI would sooner believe that Zarathustra fetched himself the devil.\u201d But at the bottom of their souls all of them were filled with worry and longing, and so their joy was great when on the fifth day Zarathustra appeared among them.</p><p>And this is the story of Zarathustra\u2019s conversation with the fire hound.</p><p>\u201cThe earth,\u201d he said, \u201chas a skin; and this skin has diseases. One of these diseases for example is called: \u2018Human being.\u2019</p><p>And another of these diseases is called \u2018fire hound\u2019; about him people have told each other many lies and allowed themselves to be lied to much.</p><p>To fathom this mystery I went over the sea, and I saw the naked truth, indeed, barefoot up to its throat!</p><p>Now I know what the fire hound is all about, and likewise all the underhanded and overthrowing scum-devils of whom not only little old women are afraid.</p><p>\u2018Out with you, fire hound, out of your depth!\u2019 I cried, \u2018and confess how deep is this depth! Where did you get what you are snorting there?</p><p>You drink deeply from the sea; your salty eloquence betrays that! Really, for a hound of the depths you take your nourishment too much from the surface!</p><p>At best I could regard you as the ventriloquist of the earth; and always when I heard overthrowing and underhanded scum-devils speaking, I found them to be the same as you: salty, lying and superficial.</p><p>You know how to bellow and to darken with ashes! You are the best big mouths, and you\u2019ve learned more than enough about bringing mud to a boil.</p><p>Wherever you are, there mud always has to be close by, and much that is spongy, pitted, squeezed, and wants to break free.</p><p>\u201cFreedom\u201d the lot of you are best at bellowing, but I lose faith in \u201cgreat events\u201d as soon as they are surrounded by much bellowing and smoke.</p><p>And just believe me, friend Infernal Racket! The greatest events \u2013 these are not our loudest, but our stillest hours.</p><p>Not around the inventors of new noise does the world revolve, but around the inventors of new values; inaudibly it revolves.</p><p>And just confess! When your noise and smoke cleared, it was always very little that had happened. What does it matter that a town becomes a mummy and a statue lies in the mud!</p><p>And these words I say to all overthrowers of statues. Surely it is the greatest folly to throw salt into the sea and statues into the mud.</p><p>In the mud of your contempt lay the statue, but precisely this is its law, that out of contempt life and living beauty grow back to it!</p><p>It stands up again with even more godlike features, seductive in its suffering, and truly! It will yet thank you for overthrowing it, you overthrowers!</p><p>But this advice I give to kings and churches and to all that is feeble with age and feeble in virtue \u2013 just let yourselves be overthrown! So that you might come to life again, and to you \u2013 virtue!\u2019 \u2013</p><p>Thus I spoke before the fire hound, then it interrupted me sullenly and asked: \u2018Church? What is that?\u2019</p><p>\u2018Church?\u2019 I answered, \u2018that is a kind of state, and in fact the most lying kind. But be silent, you hypocrite hound! You already know your kind best!</p><p>Like you yourself the state is a hypocrite hound; like you it likes to speak with smoke and bellowing \u2013 to make believe, like you, that it speaks from the belly of things.</p><p>For it wants absolutely to be the most important animal on earth, this state; and people believe it, too.\u2019 \u2013</p><p>When I finished saying this the fire hound behaved as though out of his mind with envy. \u2018What?\u2019 it shouted, \u2018the most important animal on earth? And they believe it too?\u2019 And then so much steam and so many horrid voices emanated from his throat that I thought he would choke to death from anger and envy.</p><p>At last he grew calmer and his panting let up; but as soon as he was calm I said laughing:</p><p>\u2018You are angry, fire hound, therefore I am right about you!</p><p>And so that I also remain right, hear now about another fire hound: one who really speaks from the heart of the earth.</p><p>His breath exhales gold and golden rain \u2013 thus his heart wants it. What are ash and smoke and hot slime to him!</p><p>Laughter flutters out of him like a colorful cloud; he is ill disposed toward your gurgling and spitting and the growling of your bowels!</p><p>But gold and laughter \u2013 that he takes from the heart of the earth; for you should know \u2013 the heart of the earth is made of gold.\u2019</p><p>When the fire hound heard this he could no longer stand to listen to me. Ashamed, he tucked in his tail and barked a feeble \u2018bow-wow,\u2019 then he crawled down into his cave.\u201d \u2013</p><p>Thus recounted Zarathustra. But his disciples scarcely listened to him, so great was their desire to tell him about the sailors, the rabbits and the flying man.</p><p>\u201cWhat am I supposed to think of that?\u201d he said. \u201cAm I some kind of ghost?</p><p>But it must have been my shadow. You must have heard something before about a wanderer and his shadow?</p><p>What is certain, however, is that I must keep him shorter \u2013 otherwise he will ruin my reputation.\u201d</p><p>And once again Zarathustra shook his head and wondered. \u201cWhat am I supposed to think of that?\u201d he said once more.</p><p>\u201cWhy did the ghost shout: \u2018It is time! It is high time!\u2019</p><p>For what then is it \u2013 high time?\u201d \u2013</p><p>Thus spoke Zarathustra.</p>", "article_json": {"type": "doc", "content": [{"type": "heading", "attrs": {"level": 2}, "content": [{"text": "On Great Events", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "content": [{"text": "There is an island in the sea \u2013 not far from the blessed isles of Zarathustra \u2013 on which a fiery mountain smokes continually; the people say of it, and especially the little old women among the people say of it, that it was placed like a huge boulder before the gate to the underworld: but through the fiery mountain itself leads the narrow path that winds downward to this gate of the underworld.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "content": [{"text": "Now it was around the time that Zarathustra sojourned on the blessed isles that a ship dropped anchor at the island on which the smoking mountain stands, and its crew went ashore to shoot rabbits. Toward the hour of noon, however, as the captain and his people were together again, they suddenly saw a man approaching them through the air, and a voice clearly said: \u201cIt is time! It is high time!\u201d As the figure came closest to them \u2013 and it flew past quickly like a shadow in the direction of the fiery mountain \u2013 they recognized with the greatest dismay that it was Zarathustra; for all of them had seen him before, except for the captain himself, and they loved him as the people love, with equal parts of love and awe.\r\n\r\n\u201cJust look!\u201d said the old helmsman, \u201cthere goes Zarathustra off to hell!\u201d \u2013\r\n\r\nAround the same time that these sailors landed on the fiery island the rumor was circulating that Zarathustra had disappeared; and when people asked his friends, they related how he had departed by ship at night, without saying where he would be traveling.\r\n\r\nThus a restlessness arose, but three days later this restlessness was increased by the sailors\u2019 story \u2013 and now all the people were saying that the devil had fetched Zarathustra. His disciples laughed at this news, to be sure, and one of them even said: \u201cI would sooner believe that Zarathustra fetched himself the devil.\u201d But at the bottom of their souls all of them were filled with worry and longing, and so their joy was great when on the fifth day Zarathustra appeared among them.\r\n\r\nAnd this is the story of Zarathustra\u2019s conversation with the fire hound.\r\n\r\n\u201cThe earth,\u201d he said, \u201chas a skin; and this skin has diseases. One of these diseases for example is called: \u2018Human being.\u2019\r\n\r\nAnd another of these diseases is called \u2018fire hound\u2019; about him people have told each other many lies and allowed themselves to be lied to much.\r\n\r\nTo fathom this mystery I went over the sea, and I saw the naked truth, indeed, barefoot up to its throat!\r\n\r\nNow I know what the fire hound is all about, and likewise all the underhanded and overthrowing scum-devils of whom not only little old women are afraid.\r\n\r\n\u2018Out with you, fire hound, out of your depth!\u2019 I cried, \u2018and confess how deep is this depth! Where did you get what you are snorting there?\r\n\r\nYou drink deeply from the sea; your salty eloquence betrays that! Really, for a hound of the depths you take your nourishment too much from the surface!\r\n\r\nAt best I could regard you as the ventriloquist of the earth; and always when I heard overthrowing and underhanded scum-devils speaking, I found them to be the same as you: salty, lying and superficial.\r\n\r\nYou know how to bellow and to darken with ashes! The greatest events \u2013 these are not our loudest, but our stillest hours.\r\n\r\nNot around the inventors of new noise does the world revolve, but around the inventors of new values; inaudibly it revolves.\r\n\r\nAnd just confess! When your noise and smoke cleared, it was always very little that had happened. What does it matter that a town becomes a mummy and a statue lies in the mud!\r\n\r\nAnd these words I say to all overthrowers of statues. Surely it is the greatest folly to throw salt into the sea and statues into the mud.\r\n\r\nIn the mud of your contempt lay the statue, but precisely this is its law, that out of contempt life and living beauty grow back to it!\r\n\r\nIt stands up again with even more godlike features, seductive in its suffering, and truly! It will yet thank you for overthrowing it, you overthrowers!\r\n\r\nBut this advice I give to kings and churches and to all that is feeble with age and feeble in virtue \u2013 just let yourselves be overthrown! So that you might come to life again, and to you \u2013 virtue!\u2019 \u2013\r\n\r\nThus I spoke before the fire hound, then it interrupted me sullenly and asked: \u2018Church? What is that?\u2019\r\n\r\n\u2018Church?\u2019 I answered, \u2018that is a kind of state, and in fact the most lying kind. But be silent, you hypocrite hound! You already know your kind best!\r\n\r\nLike you yourself the state is a hypocrite hound; like you it likes to speak with smoke and bellowing \u2013 to make believe, like you, that it speaks from the belly of things.\r\n\r\nFor it wants absolutely to be the most important animal on earth, this state; and people believe it, too.\u2019 \u2013\r\n\r\nWhen I finished saying this the fire hound behaved as though out of his mind with envy. \u2018What?\u2019 it shouted, \u2018the most important animal on earth? And they believe it too?\u2019 And then so much steam and so many horrid voices emanated from his throat that I thought he would choke to death from anger and envy.\r\n\r\nAt last he grew calmer and his panting let up; but as soon as he was calm I said laughing:\r\n\r\n\u2018You are angry, fire hound, therefore I am right about you!\r\n\r\nAnd so that I also remain right, hear now about another fire hound: one who really speaks from the heart of the earth.\r\n\r\nHis breath exhales gold and golden rain \u2013 thus his heart wants it. What are ash and smoke and hot slime to him!\r\n\r\nLaughter flutters out of him like a colorful cloud; he is ill disposed toward your gurgling and spitting and the growling of your bowels!\r\n\r\nBut gold and laughter \u2013 that he takes from the heart of the earth; for you should know \u2013 the heart of the earth is made of gold.\u2019\r\n\r\nWhen the fire hound heard this he could no longer stand to listen to me. Ashamed, he tucked in his tail and barked a feeble \u2018bow-wow,\u2019 then he crawled down into his cave.\u201d \u2013\r\n\r\nThus recounted Zarathustra. But his disciples scarcely listened to him, so great was their desire to tell him about the sailors, the rabbits and the flying man.\r\n\r\n\u201cWhat am I supposed to think of that?\u201d he said. \u201cAm I some kind of ghost?\r\n\r\nBut it must have been my shadow. You must have heard something before about a wanderer and his shadow?\r\n\r\nWhat is certain, however, is that I must keep him shorter \u2013 otherwise he will ruin my reputation.\u201d\r\n\r\nAnd once again Zarathustra shook his head and wondered. \u201cWhat am I supposed to think of that?\u201d he said once more.\r\n\r\n\u201cWhy did the ghost shout: \u2018It is time! It is high time!\u2019\r\n\r\nFor what then is it \u2013 high time?\u201d \u2013\r\n\r\nThus spoke Zarathustra."}, "id": 56}, {"data": {"uuid": "19fafeaa-5ed7-48b0-8df1-a5a644dcf567", "user": 1, "title": "The Soothsayer", "created_on": "2023-05-10 15:37:15.543442+00:00", "updated_on": "2023-05-10 15:37:15.562650+00:00", "article_html": "<h2>The Soothsayer</h2><p>\u201c\u2013 and I saw a great sadness descend over humanity. The best became weary of their works.</p><p>A doctrine circulated, a belief accompanied it: \u2018Everything is empty, everything is the same, everything was!\u2019</p><p>And from every hilltop it rang out: \u2018Everything is empty, everything is the same, everything was!\u2019</p><p>We harvested well, but why did all our fruits turn foul and brown? What fell down from the evil moon last night?</p><p>All work was for naught, our wine has become poison, the evil eye seared yellow our fields and hearts.</p><p>All of us became dry, and if fire were to touch us, then we would turn to dust like ashes \u2013 yes, fire itself we have made weary.</p><p>All our wells dried up, even the sea retreated. All firm ground wants to crack, but the depths do not want to devour!</p><p>\u2018Oh where is there still a sea in which one could drown?\u2019 \u2013 thus rings our lament \u2013 out across the shallow swamps.</p><p>Indeed, we have already become too weary to die; now we continue to wake and we live on \u2013 in burial chambers!\u201d \u2013</p><p>Thus Zarathustra heard a soothsayer speaking; and his prophecy went straight to his heart and transformed him. Sadly he went about and weary; and he became like those of whom the soothsayer had spoken.</p><p>\u201cIndeed,\u201d thus he spoke to his disciples, \u201cit lacks but little and this long twilight will come. Alas, how shall I rescue my light to the other side!</p><p>It must not suffocate in this sadness! It shall be light to more distant worlds and most distant nights!\u201d</p><p>Grieving thus in his heart Zarathustra walked about; and for three days he took no drink and no food, had no rest and lost his speech. At last it came to pass that he fell into a deep sleep. But his disciplines sat around him on long night watches and they waited anxiously for him to wake and speak again, and recover from his melancholy.</p><p>This, however, is the speech that Zarathustra spoke when he awoke; but his voice came to his disciples as if from far away.</p><p>\u201cHear this dream that I dreamed, my friends, and help me to understand its meaning!</p><p>It is still an enigma to me, this dream; its meaning is hidden in it and locked away and it does not yet fly above it on free wings.</p><p>I had renounced all life, thus I dreamed. I had become a night watchman and guardian of graves, there on the lonely mountain fortress of death.</p><p>Up there I guarded his coffins; the musty vaults stood full of such symbols of conquest. From glass coffins, conquered life looked out at me.</p><p>I breathed the odor of eternities turned to dust; my soul lay clammy and dusty, and who could have aired his soul in such a place!</p><p>The brightness of midnight was about me always, loneliness crouched beside her, and thirdly, death-rattle silence, the worst of my three lady friends.</p><p>I carried keys, the rustiest of all keys; and with them I knew how to open the creakiest of all gates.</p><p>Like a bitterly evil croaking the sound penetrated through the long corridors as the gate\u2019s wings swung open; hideously this bird screeched, defiant in being awakened.</p><p>But even more terrible and heart-constricting was the silence that set in around me when the gate fell quiet, and I sat alone in this treacherous silence.</p><p>Thus the time passed and crept by me, if time existed anymore \u2013 what do I know! But at last something happened that awakened me.</p><p>Three times there were blows at the door, like thundering, and the vaults echoed and howled three times in return; then I went to the gate.</p><p>\u2018Alpa!\u2019 I cried. \u2018Who bears his ashes to the mountain? Alpa! Alpa! Who bears his ashes to the mountain?\u2019</p><p>And I pressed the key and lifted on the gate and strained. But it would not open even the width of a finger:</p><p>Then a roaring wind tore its wings apart; whistling, shrilling and whipping it threw down a black coffin before me:</p><p>And amidst the roaring and whistling and shrilling the coffin burst open and spewed forth thousandfold laughter.</p><p>And it laughed and mocked and roared against me from a thousand grimaces of children, angels, owls, fools and butterflies the size of children.</p><p>I was horribly frightened; it threw me to the ground. And I cried out in terror as I have never cried before.</p><p>But my own cries awakened me \u2013 and I came to. \u2013\u201d</p><p>Thus Zarathustra related his dream and then he was silent, for he did not yet know the interpretation of his dream. But the disciple whom he loved most quickly stood up, took hold of Zarathustra\u2019s hand and said:</p><p>\u201cYour life itself interprets this dream for us, oh Zarathustra!</p><p>Are you yourself not the wind with its shrill whistling, that tears open the gates of the fortresses of death?</p><p>Are you yourself not the coffin full of colorful sarcasms and the angelic grimaces of life?</p><p>Indeed, like thousandfold children\u2019s laughter Zarathustra comes into all burial chambers, laughing at these night watchmen and grave guardians, and whoever else rattles about with dingy keys.</p><p>You will frighten and lay them low with your laughter; your power over them will be proven by their swooning and awakening.</p><p>And even if the long twilight comes and the weariness unto death, you will not set in our sky, you advocate of life!</p><p>You allowed us to see new stars and new splendors of the night; indeed, you spanned laughter itself above us like a colorful tent.</p><p>Children\u2019s laughter will well up from coffins from now on; a strong wind will come triumphantly to all weariness unto death from now on: of this you yourself are our guarantor and soothsayer!</p><p>Indeed, you yourself dreamed them, your enemies: that was your hardest dream!</p><p>But as you awakened from them and came to yourself, thus shall they awaken from themselves \u2013 and come to you!\u201d \u2013</p><p>Thus spoke the disciple, and all the others now crowded around Zarathustra and took him by the hands and wanted to persuade him to abandon his bed and his sadness and to return to them. But Zarathustra sat upright on his bed and with a strange look. Like someone who returns home from long sojourns abroad, he gazed at his disciples and examined their faces; and still he did not recognize them. But as they lifted him and helped him to his feet, behold, all at once his eyes transformed; he comprehended all that had happened, stroked his beard and said in a strong voice:</p><p>\u201cWell then! This has its time; but for now see to it, my disciples, that we prepare a good meal, and quickly! Thus I plan to do penance for bad dreams!</p><p>But the soothsayer shall eat and drink beside me; and truly, I will yet show him a sea in which he can drown!\u201d</p><p>Thus spoke Zarathustra. Then, however, he gazed long into the face of the disciple who had served as the dream interpreter, and he shook his head. \u2013</p>", "article_json": {"type": "doc", "content": [{"type": "heading", "attrs": {"level": 2}, "content": [{"text": "The Soothsayer", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "content": [{"text": "\u201c\u2013 and I saw a great sadness descend over humanity. The best became weary of their works.\r\n\r\nA doctrine circulated, a belief accompanied it: \u2018Everything is empty, everything is the same, everything was!\u2019\r\n\r\nAnd from every hilltop it rang out: \u2018Everything is empty, everything is the same, everything was!\u2019\r\n\r\nWe harvested well, but why did all our fruits turn foul and brown? What fell down from the evil moon last night?\r\n\r\nAll work was for naught, our wine has become poison, the evil eye seared yellow our fields and hearts.\r\n\r\nAll of us became dry, and if fire were to touch us, then we would turn to dust like ashes \u2013 yes, fire itself we have made weary.\r\n\r\nAll our wells dried up, even the sea retreated. All firm ground wants to crack, but the depths do not want to devour!\r\n\r\n\u2018Oh where is there still a sea in which one could drown?\u2019 \u2013 thus rings our lament \u2013 out across the shallow swamps.\r\n\r\nIndeed, we have already become too weary to die; now we continue to wake and we live on \u2013 in burial chambers!\u201d \u2013\r\n\r\nThus Zarathustra heard a soothsayer speaking; and his prophecy went straight to his heart and transformed him. Sadly he went about and weary; and he became like those of whom the soothsayer had spoken.\r\n\r\n\u201cIndeed,\u201d thus he spoke to his disciples, \u201cit lacks but little and this long twilight will come. Alas, how shall I rescue my light to the other side!\r\n\r\nIt must not suffocate in this sadness! It shall be light to more distant worlds and most distant nights!\u201d\r\n\r\nGrieving thus in his heart Zarathustra walked about; and for three days he took no drink and no food, had no rest and lost his speech. At last it came to pass that he fell into a deep sleep. But his disciplines sat around him on long night watches and they waited anxiously for him to wake and speak again, and recover from his melancholy.\r\n\r\nThis, however, is the speech that Zarathustra spoke when he awoke; but his voice came to his disciples as if from far away.\r\n\r\n\u201cHear this dream that I dreamed, my friends, and help me to understand its meaning!\r\n\r\nIt is still an enigma to me, this dream; its meaning is hidden in it and locked away and it does not yet fly above it on free wings.\r\n\r\nI had renounced all life, thus I dreamed. I had become a night watchman and guardian of graves, there on the lonely mountain fortress of death.\r\n\r\nUp there I guarded his coffins; the musty vaults stood full of such symbols of conquest. From glass coffins, conquered life looked out at me.\r\n\r\nI breathed the odor of eternities turned to dust; my soul lay clammy and dusty, and who could have aired his soul in such a place!\r\n\r\nThe brightness of midnight was about me always, loneliness crouched beside her, and thirdly, death-rattle silence, the worst of my three lady friends.\r\n\r\nI carried keys, the rustiest of all keys; and with them I knew how to open the creakiest of all gates.\r\n\r\nLike a bitterly evil croaking the sound penetrated through the long corridors as the gate\u2019s wings swung open; hideously this bird screeched, defiant in being awakened.\r\n\r\nBut even more terrible and heart-constricting was the silence that set in around me when the gate fell quiet, and I sat alone in this treacherous silence.\r\n\r\nThus the time passed and crept by me, if time existed anymore \u2013 what do I know! But at last something happened that awakened me.\r\n\r\nThree times there were blows at the door, like thundering, and the vaults echoed and howled three times in return; then I went to the gate.\r\n\r\n\u2018Alpa!\u2019 I cried. \u2018Who bears his ashes to the mountain? Alpa! Alpa! Who bears his ashes to the mountain?\u2019\r\n\r\nAnd I pressed the key and lifted on the gate and strained. But it would not open even the width of a finger:\r\n\r\nThen a roaring wind tore its wings apart; whistling, shrilling and whipping it threw down a black coffin before me:\r\n\r\nAnd amidst the roaring and whistling and shrilling the coffin burst open and spewed forth thousandfold laughter.\r\n\r\nAnd it laughed and mocked and roared against me from a thousand grimaces of children, angels, owls, fools and butterflies the size of children.\r\n\r\nI was horribly frightened; it threw me to the ground. And I cried out in terror as I have never cried before.\r\n\r\nBut my own cries awakened me \u2013 and I came to. \u2013\u201d\r\n\r\nThus Zarathustra related his dream and then he was silent, for he did not yet know the interpretation of his dream. But the disciple whom he loved most quickly stood up, took hold of Zarathustra\u2019s hand and said:\r\n\r\n\u201cYour life itself interprets this dream for us, oh Zarathustra!\r\n\r\nAre you yourself not the wind with its shrill whistling, that tears open the gates of the fortresses of death?\r\n\r\nAre you yourself not the coffin full of colorful sarcasms and the angelic grimaces of life?\r\n\r\nIndeed, like thousandfold children\u2019s laughter Zarathustra comes into all burial chambers, laughing at these night watchmen and grave guardians, and whoever else rattles about with dingy keys.\r\n\r\nYou will frighten and lay them low with your laughter; your power over them will be proven by their swooning and awakening.\r\n\r\nAnd even if the long twilight comes and the weariness unto death, you will not set in our sky, you advocate of life!\r\n\r\nYou allowed us to see new stars and new splendors of the night; indeed, you spanned laughter itself above us like a colorful tent.\r\n\r\nChildren\u2019s laughter will well up from coffins from now on; a strong wind will come triumphantly to all weariness unto death from now on: of this you yourself are our guarantor and soothsayer!\r\n\r\nIndeed, you yourself dreamed them, your enemies: that was your hardest dream!\r\n\r\nBut as you awakened from them and came to yourself, thus shall they awaken from themselves \u2013 and come to you!\u201d \u2013\r\n\r\nThus spoke the disciple, and all the others now crowded around Zarathustra and took him by the hands and wanted to persuade him to abandon his bed and his sadness and to return to them. But Zarathustra sat upright on his bed and with a strange look. Like someone who returns home from long sojourns abroad, he gazed at his disciples and examined their faces; and still he did not recognize them. But as they lifted him and helped him to his feet, behold, all at once his eyes transformed; he comprehended all that had happened, stroked his beard and said in a strong voice:\r\n\r\n\u201cWell then! This has its time; but for now see to it, my disciples, that we prepare a good meal, and quickly! Thus I plan to do penance for bad dreams!\r\n\r\nBut the soothsayer shall eat and drink beside me; and truly, I will yet show him a sea in which he can drown!\u201d\r\n\r\nThus spoke Zarathustra. Then, however, he gazed long into the face of the disciple who had served as the dream interpreter, and he shook his head. \u2013"}, "id": 57}, {"data": {"uuid": "03860f26-5495-4bb2-a8e5-6166af3eafb6", "user": 1, "title": "On Redemption", "created_on": "2023-05-10 15:38:11.943799+00:00", "updated_on": "2023-05-10 15:38:11.968864+00:00", "article_html": "<h2>On Redemption</h2><p>As Zarathustra crossed over the great bridge one day, the cripples and the beggars surrounded him and a hunchback spoke thus to him:</p><p>\u201cBehold, Zarathustra! The people too learn from you and are gaining faith in your teaching; but in order to believe you completely, they need one more thing \u2013 you must first persuade us cripples! Here you have a fine selection and truly, an opportunity with more than one scruff ! You can heal the blind and make the lame walk; and for the one who has too much behind him, you could surely take a bit away \u2013 that, I believe, would be the right way to make the cripples believe in Zarathustra!\u201d</p><p>Zarathustra, however, responded to the speaker thus: \u201cIf one takes the hump from the hunchback, then one takes his spirit too \u2013 thus teach the people. And if one gives the blind man his eyesight, then he sees too many bad things on earth, such that he curses the one who healed him. But the one who makes the lame walk causes him the greatest harm, for scarcely does he begin to walk when his vices run away with him \u2013 thus teach the people about cripples. And why should Zarathustra not learn also from the people, if the people learn from Zarathustra?</p><p>But it is the least thing to me, since I have been among human beings, when I see \u2018This one is missing an eye and That one an ear and the Third one a leg, and there are Others who lost their tongue or their nose or their head.\u2019</p><p>I see and have seen worse, and some of it so hideous that I do not want to speak of everything, and of a few things I do not even want to remain silent; namely human beings who were missing everything except the one thing they have too much of \u2013 human beings who are nothing more than one big eye, or one big maw or one big belly or some other big thing \u2013 inverse cripples I call such types.</p><p>And as I came out of my solitude and crossed over this bridge the first time, then I didn\u2019t believe my eyes and I looked and I looked again and said at last: \u2018That is an ear! An ear as big as a person!\u2019 And I looked more closely, and really, beneath the ear something was moving that was pitifully small and pathetic and thin. And, in truth, the gigantic ear sat upon a little slender stalk \u2013 but the stalk was a human being! If one used a magnifying glass one could even recognize a tiny, envious miniature face; even a bloated little soul dangling on the stalk. But the people told me that the big ear was not only a human being, but a great human being, a genius. But I have never believed the people when they speak of great human beings \u2013 and I maintained my belief that it was an inverse cripple who had too little of everything and too much of one thing.\u201d</p><p>When Zarathustra had spoken thus to the hunchback and to those for whom he had served as mouthpiece and advocate, he turned deeply upset to his disciples and said:</p><p>\u201cTruly, my friends, I walk among human beings as among the fragments and limbs of human beings!</p><p>This is what is most frightening to my eyes, that I find mankind in ruins and scattered about as if on a battle field or a butcher field.</p><p>And if my gaze flees from the now to the past; it always finds the same: fragments and limbs and grisly accidents \u2013 but no human beings!</p><p>The now and the past on earth \u2013 alas, my friends \u2013 that is what is most unbearable to me. And I would not know how to live if I were not also a seer of that which must come.</p><p>A seer, a willer, a creator, a future himself and a bridge to the future \u2013 and alas, at the same time a cripple at this bridge: all that is Zarathustra.</p><p>And you too asked yourselves often: \u2018Who is Zarathustra to us? How shall he be known to us?\u2019 And like me you gave yourselves questions for answers.</p><p>Is he a promiser? Or a fulfiller? A conqueror? Or an inheritor? An autumn? Or a plow? A physician? Or a convalescent?</p><p>Is he a poet? Or a truthful man? A liberator? Or a tamer? A good man? Or an evil man?</p><p>I walk among human beings as among the fragments of the future; that future that I see.</p><p>And all my creating and striving amounts to this, that I create and piece together into one, what is now fragment and riddle and grisly accident.</p><p>And how could I bear to be a human being if mankind were not also creator and solver of riddles and redeemer of accident?</p><p>To redeem those who are the past and to recreate all \u2018it was\u2019 into \u2018thus I willed it!\u2019 \u2013 only that would I call redemption!</p><p>Will \u2013 thus the liberator and joy bringer is called; thus I taught you, my friends! And now learn this in addition: the will itself is still a prisoner.</p><p>Willing liberates, but what is that called, which claps even the liberator in chains?</p><p>\u2018It was\u2019: thus is called the will\u2019s gnashing of teeth and loneliest misery. Impotent against that which has been \u2013 it is an angry spectator of everything past.</p><p>The will cannot will backward; that it cannot break time and time\u2019s greed \u2013 that is the will\u2019s loneliest misery.</p><p>Willing liberates; what does willing plan in order to rid itself of its misery and mock its dungeon?</p><p>Alas, every prisoner becomes a fool! Foolishly as well the imprisoned will redeems itself.</p><p>That time does not run backward, that is its wrath. \u2018That which was\u2019 \u2013 thus the stone is called, which it cannot roll aside.</p><p>And so it rolls stones around out of wrath and annoyance, and wreaks revenge on that which does not feel wrath and annoyance as it does.</p><p>Thus the will, the liberator, became a doer of harm; and on everything that is capable of suffering it avenges itself for not being able to go back.</p><p>This, yes this alone is revenge itself: the will\u2019s unwillingness toward time and time\u2019s \u2018it was.\u2019</p><p>Indeed, a great folly lives in our will; and it became the curse of all humankind that this folly acquired spirit!</p><p>The spirit of revenge: my friends, that so far has been what mankind contemplate best; and wherever there was suffering, punishment was always supposed to be there as well.</p><p>For \u2018punishment\u2019 is what revenge calls itself; with a lying word it hypocritically asserts its good conscience.</p><p>And because in willing itself there is suffering, based on its inability to will backward \u2013 thus all willing itself and all living is supposed to be \u2013 punishment!</p><p>And now cloud upon cloud rolled in over the spirit, until at last madness preached: \u2018Everything passes away, therefore everything deserves to pass away!</p><p>And this itself is justice, this law of time that it must devour its own children\u2019 \u2013 thus preached madness.</p><p>\u2018All things are ordained ethically according to justice and punishment. Alas, where is redemption from the flux of things and from the punishment called existence?\u2019 Thus preached madness.</p><p>\u2018Can there be redemption, if there is eternal justice? Alas, the stone \u201cit was\u201d is unmoveable; all punishments too must be eternal!\u2019 Thus preached madness.</p><p>\u2018No deed can be annihilated; how could it be undone through punishment? This, this is what is eternal about the punishment called existence, that existence must also eternally be deed and guilt again!</p><p>Unless the will were to finally redeem itself and willing became not-willing \u2013 \u2019; but my brothers, you know this fable song of madness!</p><p>Away from these fable songs I steered you when I taught you: \u2018The will is a creator.\u2019</p><p>All \u2018it was\u2019 is a fragment, a riddle, a grisly accident \u2013 until the creating will says to it: \u2018But I will it thus! I shall will it thus!\u2019</p><p>But has it ever spoken thus? And when will this happen? Is the will already unharnessed from its own folly?</p><p>Has the will already become its own redeemer and joy bringer? Has it unlearned the spirit of revenge and all gnashing of teeth?</p><p>And who taught it reconciliation with time, and what is higher than any reconciliation?</p><p>That will which is the will to power must will something higher than any reconciliation \u2013</p><p>but how shall this happen? Who would teach it to also will backward?\u201d</p><p>\u2013 But at this point in his speech Zarathustra suddenly broke off and looked entirely like one who is appalled in the extreme. Appalled he looked at his disciples, his eyes penetrated their thoughts and their secret thoughts as if with arrows. But after a little while he laughed again and said, more calmly:</p><p>\u201cIt\u2019s difficult to live with people because keeping silent is so hard. Especially for someone who is talkative.\u201d \u2013</p><p>Thus spoke Zarathustra. The hunchback meanwhile had listened to the conversation with his face covered, but when he heard Zarathustra laugh he looked up inquisitively and slowly said:</p><p>\u201cBut why does Zarathustra speak otherwise to us than to his disciples?\u201d</p><p>Zarathustra answered: \u201cWhat\u2019s to wonder about in that!
