The people too learn from you and are gaining faith in your teaching; but in order to believe you completely, they need one more thing \u2013 you must first persuade us cripples! Here you have a fine selection and truly, an opportunity with more than one scruff ! You can heal the blind and make the lame walk; and for the one who has too much behind him, you could surely take a bit away \u2013 that, I believe, would be the right way to make the cripples believe in Zarathustra!\u201d\r\n\r\nZarathustra, however, responded to the speaker thus: \u201cIf one takes the hump from the hunchback, then one takes his spirit too \u2013 thus teach the people. And if one gives the blind man his eyesight, then he sees too many bad things on earth, such that he curses the one who healed him. But the one who makes the lame walk causes him the greatest harm, for scarcely does he begin to walk when his vices run away with him \u2013 thus teach the people about cripples. And why should Zarathustra not learn also from the people, if the people learn from Zarathustra?\r\n\r\nBut it is the least thing to me, since I have been among human beings, when I see \u2018This one is missing an eye and That one an ear and the Third one a leg, and there are Others who lost their tongue or their nose or their head.\u2019\r\n\r\nI see and have seen worse, and some of it so hideous that I do not want to speak of everything, and of a few things I do not even want to remain silent; namely human beings who were missing everything except the one thing they have too much of \u2013 human beings who are nothing more than one big eye, or one big maw or one big belly or some other big thing \u2013 inverse cripples I call such types.\r\n\r\nAnd as I came out of my solitude and crossed over this bridge the first time, then I didn\u2019t believe my eyes and I looked and I looked again and said at last: \u2018That is an ear! An ear as big as a person!\u2019 And I looked more closely, and really, beneath the ear something was moving that was pitifully small and pathetic and thin. And, in truth, the gigantic ear sat upon a little slender stalk \u2013 but the stalk was a human being! If one used a magnifying glass one could even recognize a tiny, envious miniature face; even a bloated little soul dangling on the stalk. But the people told me that the big ear was not only a human being, but a great human being, a genius. But I have never believed the people when they speak of great human beings \u2013 and I maintained my belief that it was an inverse cripple who had too little of everything and too much of one thing.\u201d\r\n\r\nWhen Zarathustra had spoken thus to the hunchback and to those for whom he had served as mouthpiece and advocate, he turned deeply upset to his disciples and said:\r\n\r\n\u201cTruly, my friends, I walk among human beings as among the fragments and limbs of human beings!\r\n\r\nThis is what is most frightening to my eyes, that I find mankind in ruins and scattered about as if on a battle field or a butcher field.\r\n\r\nAnd if my gaze flees from the now to the past; it always finds the same: fragments and limbs and grisly accidents \u2013 but no human beings!\r\n\r\nThe now and the past on earth \u2013 alas, my friends \u2013 that is what is most unbearable to me. And I would not know how to live if I were not also a seer of that which must come.\r\n\r\nA seer, a willer, a creator, a future himself and a bridge to the future \u2013 and alas, at the same time a cripple at this bridge: all that is Zarathustra.\r\n\r\nAnd you too asked yourselves often: \u2018Who is Zarathustra to us? How shall he be known to us?\u2019 And like me you gave yourselves questions for answers.\r\n\r\nIs he a promiser? Or a fulfiller? A conqueror? Or an inheritor? An autumn? Or a plow? A physician? Or a convalescent?\r\n\r\nIs he a poet? Or a truthful man? A liberator? Or a tamer? A good man? Or an evil man?\r\n\r\nI walk among human beings as among the fragments of the future; that future that I see.\r\n\r\nAnd all my creating and striving amounts to this, that I create and piece together into one, what is now fragment and riddle and grisly accident.\r\n\r\nAnd how could I bear to be a human being if mankind were not also creator and solver of riddles and redeemer of accident?\r\n\r\nTo redeem those who are the past and to recreate all \u2018it was\u2019 into \u2018thus I willed it!\u2019 \u2013 only that would I call redemption!\r\n\r\nWill \u2013 thus the liberator and joy bringer is called; thus I taught you, my friends! And now learn this in addition: the will itself is still a prisoner.\r\n\r\nWilling liberates, but what is that called, which claps even the liberator in chains?\r\n\r\n\u2018It was\u2019: thus is called the will\u2019s gnashing of teeth and loneliest misery. Impotent against that which has been \u2013 it is an angry spectator of everything past.\r\n\r\nThe will cannot will backward; that it cannot break time and time\u2019s greed \u2013 that is the will\u2019s loneliest misery.\r\n\r\nWilling liberates; what does willing plan in order to rid itself of its misery and mock its dungeon?\r\n\r\nAlas, every prisoner becomes a fool! Foolishly as well the imprisoned will redeems itself.\r\n\r\nThat time does not run backward, that is its wrath. \u2018That which was\u2019 \u2013 thus the stone is called, which it cannot roll aside.\r\n\r\nAnd so it rolls stones around out of wrath and annoyance, and wreaks revenge on that which does not feel wrath and annoyance as it does.\r\n\r\nThus the will, the liberator, became a doer of harm; and on everything that is capable of suffering it avenges itself for not being able to go back.\r\n\r\nThis, yes this alone is revenge itself: the will\u2019s unwillingness toward time and time\u2019s \u2018it was.\u2019\r\n\r\nIndeed, a great folly lives in our will; and it became the curse of all humankind that this folly acquired spirit!\r\n\r\nThe spirit of revenge: my friends, that so far has been what mankind contemplate best; and wherever there was suffering, punishment was always supposed to be there as well.\r\n\r\nFor \u2018punishment\u2019 is what revenge calls itself; with a lying word it hypocritically asserts its good conscience.\r\n\r\nAnd because in willing itself there is suffering, based on its inability to will backward \u2013 thus all willing itself and all living is supposed to be \u2013 punishment!\r\n\r\nAnd now cloud upon cloud rolled in over the spirit, until at last madness preached: \u2018Everything passes away, therefore everything deserves to pass away!\r\n\r\nAnd this itself is justice, this law of time that it must devour its own children\u2019 \u2013 thus preached madness.\r\n\r\n\u2018All things are ordained ethically according to justice and punishment. Alas, where is redemption from the flux of things and from the punishment called existence?\u2019 Thus preached madness.\r\n\r\n\u2018Can there be redemption, if there is eternal justice? Alas, the stone \u201cit was\u201d is unmoveable; all punishments too must be eternal!\u2019 Thus preached madness.\r\n\r\n\u2018No deed can be annihilated; how could it be undone through punishment? This, this is what is eternal about the punishment called existence, that existence must also eternally be deed and guilt again!\r\n\r\nUnless the will were to finally redeem itself and willing became not-willing \u2013 \u2019; but my brothers, you know this fable song of madness!\r\n\r\nAway from these fable songs I steered you when I taught you: \u2018The will is a creator.\u2019\r\n\r\nAll \u2018it was\u2019 is a fragment, a riddle, a grisly accident \u2013 until the creating will says to it: \u2018But I will it thus! I shall will it thus!\u2019\r\n\r\nBut has it ever spoken thus? And when will this happen? Is the will already unharnessed from its own folly?\r\n\r\nHas the will already become its own redeemer and joy bringer? Has it unlearned the spirit of revenge and all gnashing of teeth?\r\n\r\nAnd who taught it reconciliation with time, and what is higher than any reconciliation?\r\n\r\nThat will which is the will to power must will something higher than any reconciliation \u2013\r\n\r\nbut how shall this happen? Who would teach it to also will backward?\u201d\r\n\r\n\u2013 But at this point in his speech Zarathustra suddenly broke off and looked entirely like one who is appalled in the extreme. Appalled he looked at his disciples, his eyes penetrated their thoughts and their secret thoughts as if with arrows. But after a little while he laughed again and said, more calmly:\r\n\r\n\u201cIt\u2019s difficult to live with people because keeping silent is so hard. Especially for someone who is talkative.\u201d \u2013\r\n\r\nThus spoke Zarathustra. The hunchback meanwhile had listened to the conversation with his face covered, but when he heard Zarathustra laugh he looked up inquisitively and slowly said:\r\n\r\n\u201cBut why does Zarathustra speak otherwise to us than to his disciples?\u201d\r\n\r\nZarathustra answered: \u201cWhat\u2019s to wonder about in that! One is allowed to speak hunched with hunchbacks!\u201d\r\n\r\n\u201cGood,\u201d said the hunchback, \u201cand with pupils one may tell tales out of school.\r\n\r\nBut why does Zarathustra speak otherwise to his pupils \u2013 than to himself?\u201d \u2013"}, "id": 58}, {"data": {"uuid": "93f5776b-5c0c-46cf-9717-bbd69a65bf41", "user": 1, "title": "On Human Prudence", "created_on": "2023-05-10 15:39:08.507474+00:00", "updated_on": "2023-05-10 15:39:08.523856+00:00", "article_html": "<h2>On Human Prudence</h2><p>Not the height: the precipice is what is terrible!</p><p>The precipice, where one\u2019s gaze plunges downward and one\u2019s hand grasps upward. There the heart is dizzy from its double will.</p><p>Oh my friends, can you guess even my heart\u2019s double will?</p><p>This, this is my precipice and my danger, that my gaze plunges into the heights and that my hand must hold to and support itself \u2013 on the depths!</p><p>My will clings to mankind, I bind myself with chains to mankind because I am drawn upward to the overman; for there my other will wills me.</p><p>And for this I live blind among people, just as if I did not know them: so that my hand does not entirely lose its faith in the firm.</p><p>I do not know you human beings; this darkness and solace are often spread around me.</p><p>I sit at the gateway for every rogue and ask: who wants to deceive me?</p><p>That is my first human prudence, that I allow myself to be deceived, in order to not be on the lookout for deceivers.</p><p>Indeed, if I were on the lookout for mankind, how could mankind be an anchor to my ball? Too easily I would be swept up and away!</p><p>This providence lies over my destiny, that I cannot be provident.</p><p>And whoever would not die of thirst among human beings must learn to drink from all glasses; and whoever would remain clean among human beings must understand how to wash himself even with dirty water.</p><p>And thus I often spoke to comfort myself: \u201cWell then! Cheer up, old heart! One misfortune failed you; enjoy this as your \u2013 fortune!\u201d</p><p>But this is my other human prudence: I spare the vain more than the proud.</p><p>Is wounded vanity not the mother of all tragedies? But where pride is wounded, there something even better than pride grows.</p><p>For life to be a proper spectacle, its play must be well-played; but for this good play actors are needed.</p><p>I found all vain people to be good actors; they play and want to be spectacular \u2013 all their spirit is focused in this willing.</p><p>They perform themselves, they invent themselves; in their proximity I love to be a spectator of life \u2013 it heals me of my melancholy.</p><p>Therefore I spare the vain, because they are physicians for my melan- choly and keep me riveted to people as if to a play.</p><p>And then: who could measure the full depth of the vain man\u2019s modesty! I mean him well and pity him his modesty.</p><p>From you he wants to acquire his faith in himself; he nourishes himself from your glances, he eats praise from your hands.</p><p>He even believes your lies, when you lie well about him; for at bottom his heart sighs: \u201cwhat am I?\u201d</p><p>And if the truest virtue is the one that is not aware of itself, well; the vain man knows nothing of his modesty! \u2013</p><p>But this is my third human prudence, that I do not allow my view of the evil ones to be spoiled by your fearfulness.</p><p>I am enchanted to see the wonders hatched by a hot sun: tigers and palm trees and rattle snakes.</p><p>Even among human beings there is a beautiful brood of the hot sun and much that is wonderworthy in those who are evil.</p><p>To be sure, just as your wisest did not strike me as quite so wise, so too I found the malice of human beings unequal to its reputation.</p><p>And often I shook my head and asked: Why do you keep rattling, you rattle snakes?</p><p>Indeed, even for evil there is still a future! And the hottest south has not yet been discovered for mankind.</p><p>How much is regarded today as the most egregious malice when in fact it is only twelve shoes wide and three months long! But some day bigger dragons will come into the world.</p><p>For in order for the overman to not lack his dragon, the over- dragon that is worthy of him, much hot sun must yet glow on humid jungle!</p><p>Your wild cats must first have turned to tigers and your poisonous toads to crocodiles; for the good hunter shall have a good hunt!</p><p>And truly, you good and just! In you there is much to laugh at and especially your fear of what up till now has been called \u201cdevil!\u201d</p><p>So estranged from greatness are you in your souls that the overman would seem terrible to you in his kindness!</p><p>And you wise and knowing ones, you would flee from the sunburn of wisdom in which the overman joyfully bathes his nakedness!</p><p>You highest human beings whom I have ever laid eyes on \u2013 this is my doubt in you and my secret laughter: I suspect you would call my overman \u2013 devil!</p><p>Oh, I became weary of these highest and best; from their \u201cheight\u201d I longed upward, outward, and away to the overman!</p><p>A dread overcame me when I saw these best human beings naked: then I sprouted wings to soar away into distant futures.</p><p>Into more distant futures, into more southern souths than ever a painter dreamed; there, where gods are ashamed of all clothing!</p><p>But I want to see you costumed, you neighbors and fellow human beings, and well groomed, and vain, and dignified, as \u201cthe good and the just\u201d \u2013</p><p>And costumed I myself want to sit among you \u2013 so that I might not recognize you and myself; for that is my final human prudence.</p><p>Thus spoke Zarathustra.</p>", "article_json": {"type": "doc", "content": [{"type": "heading", "attrs": {"level": 2}, "content": [{"text": "On Human Prudence", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "content": [{"text": "Not the height: the precipice is what is terrible!", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "content": [{"text": "The precipice, where one\u2019s gaze plunges downward and one\u2019s hand grasps upward. There the heart is dizzy from its double will.\r\n\r\nOh my friends, can you guess even my heart\u2019s double will?\r\n\r\nThis, this is my precipice and my danger, that my gaze plunges into the heights and that my hand must hold to and support itself \u2013 on the depths!\r\n\r\nMy will clings to mankind, I bind myself with chains to mankind because I am drawn upward to the overman; for there my other will wills me.\r\n\r\nAnd for this I live blind among people, just as if I did not know them: so that my hand does not entirely lose its faith in the firm.\r\n\r\nI do not know you human beings; this darkness and solace are often spread around me.\r\n\r\nI sit at the gateway for every rogue and ask: who wants to deceive me?\r\n\r\nThat is my first human prudence, that I allow myself to be deceived, in order to not be on the lookout for deceivers.\r\n\r\nIndeed, if I were on the lookout for mankind, how could mankind be an anchor to my ball? Too easily I would be swept up and away!\r\n\r\nThis providence lies over my destiny, that I cannot be provident.\r\n\r\nAnd whoever would not die of thirst among human beings must learn to drink from all glasses; and whoever would remain clean among human beings must understand how to wash himself even with dirty water.\r\n\r\nAnd thus I often spoke to comfort myself: \u201cWell then! Cheer up, old heart! One misfortune failed you; enjoy this as your \u2013 fortune!\u201d\r\n\r\nBut this is my other human prudence: I spare the vain more than the proud.\r\n\r\nIs wounded vanity not the mother of all tragedies? But where pride is wounded, there something even better than pride grows.\r\n\r\nFor life to be a proper spectacle, its play must be well-played; but for this good play actors are needed.\r\n\r\nI found all vain people to be good actors; they play and want to be spectacular \u2013 all their spirit is focused in this willing.\r\n\r\nThey perform themselves, they invent themselves; in their proximity I love to be a spectator of life \u2013 it heals me of my melancholy.\r\n\r\nTherefore I spare the vain, because they are physicians for my melan- choly and keep me riveted to people as if to a play.\r\n\r\nAnd then: who could measure the full depth of the vain man\u2019s modesty! I mean him well and pity him his modesty.\r\n\r\nFrom you he wants to acquire his faith in himself; he nourishes himself from your glances, he eats praise from your hands.\r\n\r\nHe even believes your lies, when you lie well about him; for at bottom his heart sighs: \u201cwhat am I?\u201d\r\n\r\nAnd if the truest virtue is the one that is not aware of itself, well; the vain man knows nothing of his modesty! \u2013\r\n\r\nBut this is my third human prudence, that I do not allow my view of the evil ones to be spoiled by your fearfulness.\r\n\r\nI am enchanted to see the wonders hatched by a hot sun: tigers and palm trees and rattle snakes.\r\n\r\nEven among human beings there is a beautiful brood of the hot sun and much that is wonderworthy in those who are evil.\r\n\r\nTo be sure, just as your wisest did not strike me as quite so wise, so too I found the malice of human beings unequal to its reputation.\r\n\r\nAnd often I shook my head and asked: Why do you keep rattling, you rattle snakes?\r\n\r\nIndeed, even for evil there is still a future! And the hottest south has not yet been discovered for mankind.\r\n\r\nHow much is regarded today as the most egregious malice when in fact it is only twelve shoes wide and three months long! But some day bigger dragons will come into the world.\r\n\r\nFor in order for the overman to not lack his dragon, the over- dragon that is worthy of him, much hot sun must yet glow on humid jungle!\r\n\r\nYour wild cats must first have turned to tigers and your poisonous toads to crocodiles; for the good hunter shall have a good hunt!\r\n\r\nAnd truly, you good and just! In you there is much to laugh at and especially your fear of what up till now has been called \u201cdevil!\u201d\r\n\r\nSo estranged from greatness are you in your souls that the overman would seem terrible to you in his kindness!\r\n\r\nAnd you wise and knowing ones, you would flee from the sunburn of wisdom in which the overman joyfully bathes his nakedness!\r\n\r\nYou highest human beings whom I have ever laid eyes on \u2013 this is my doubt in you and my secret laughter: I suspect you would call my overman \u2013 devil!\r\n\r\nOh, I became weary of these highest and best; from their \u201cheight\u201d I longed upward, outward, and away to the overman!\r\n\r\nA dread overcame me when I saw these best human beings naked: then I sprouted wings to soar away into distant futures.\r\n\r\nInto more distant futures, into more southern souths than ever a painter dreamed; there, where gods are ashamed of all clothing!\r\n\r\nBut I want to see you costumed, you neighbors and fellow human beings, and well groomed, and vain, and dignified, as \u201cthe good and the just\u201d \u2013\r\n\r\nAnd costumed I myself want to sit among you \u2013 so that I might not recognize you and myself; for that is my final human prudence.\r\n\r\nThus spoke Zarathustra."}, "id": 59}, {"data": {"uuid": "53b2115e-23f9-42b9-a42c-651a993af741", "user": 1, "title": "The Stillest Hour", "created_on": "2023-05-10 15:39:55.504897+00:00", "updated_on": "2023-05-10 15:39:55.519882+00:00", "article_html": "<h2>The Stillest Hour</h2><p>What happened to me, my friends? You see me distraught, chased away, reluctantly obedient, prepared to go \u2013 alas, to go away from you!</p><p>Yes, once again Zarathustra must return to his solitude; but this time the bear returns to his cave unwillingly!</p><p>What happened to me? Who commanded this? \u2013 Alas, my angry mistress wills it so, she spoke to me \u2013 did I ever mention her name to you?</p><p>Yesterday toward evening my stillest hour spoke to me: that is the name of my terrible mistress.</p><p>And this is how it happened \u2013 for I must tell you everything, so your hearts do not harden against the one who must depart abruptly!</p><p>Do you know the terror of the one who is falling asleep? \u2013</p><p>He is stricken with terror down to his toes because the ground is fading and the dream begins.</p><p>This I say to you as a parable. Yesterday, at the stillest hour, the ground faded from me, the dream began.</p><p>The hand advanced, the clock of my life drew a breath \u2013 never had I heard such stillness around me, so that my heart was terrified.</p><p>Then without voice it spoke to me: \u201cYou know it, Zarathustra?\u201d \u2013</p><p>And I cried out in terror on hearing this whispering, and the blood drained from my face, but I kept silent.</p><p>Then it spoke to me once more without voice: \u201cYou know it Zarathustra, but you do not speak it!\u201d \u2013</p><p>And at last I answered defiantly: \u201cIndeed, I know it, but I do not want to speak it!\u201d</p><p>Then it spoke to me again without voice: \u201cYou do not want to, Zarathustra? Is this even true? Do not hide in your defiance!\u201d \u2013</p><p>And I wept and trembled like a child and spoke: \u201cOh, I wanted to, yes, but how can I? Spare me this one thing! It is beyond my strength!\u201d</p><p>Then it spoke to me again without voice: \u201cWhat do you matter, Zarathustra? Speak your word and break!\u201d \u2013</p><p>And I answered: \u201cAlas, is it my word? Who am I? I am waiting for one more worthy; I am not worthy even of breaking under it.\u201d</p><p>Then it spoke to me again without voice: \u201cWhat do you matter? You are not yet humble enough for me. Humility has the toughest hide.\u201d \u2013</p><p>And I answered: \u201cWhat has the hide of my humility not borne already! I dwell at the foot of my height; how high are my peaks? No one yet has told me. But well do I know my valleys.\u201d</p><p>Then it spoke to me again without voice: \u201cOh Zarathustra, whoever has mountains to move must also move valleys and hollows.\u201d \u2013</p><p>And I answered: \u201cAs of yet my words have moved no mountains, and what I spoke did not reach mankind. I went to human beings, to be sure, but I have not yet arrived among them.\u201d</p><p>Then it spoke to me again without voice: \u201cWhat do you know of that! The dew lands on the grass when the night is most silent.\u201d \u2013</p><p>And I answered: \u201cThey mocked me when I found and walked my own way; and in truth my feet trembled at that time.</p><p>And thus they spoke to me: \u2018You have forgotten the way, and now you are forgetting how to walk too!\u2019\u201d</p><p>Then it spoke to me again without voice: \u201cWhat does their mock- ery matter! You are one who has forgotten how to obey; now you shall command!</p><p>Do you not know who is needed most by everyone? The one who commands great things.</p><p>To accomplish great things is difficult; but what is even more difficult is to command great things.</p><p>That is what is most unforgivable in you: you have the power, and you do not want to rule.\u201d \u2013</p><p>And I answered: \u201cI lack the lion\u2019s voice for all commanding.\u201d</p><p>Then it spoke to me again like a whispering: \u201cThe stillest words are those that bring the storm. Thoughts that come on the feet of doves steer the world.</p><p>Oh Zarathustra, you shall go as a shadow of that which must come; thus you will command and lead the way commanding.\u201d \u2013</p><p>And I answered: \u201cI am ashamed.\u201d</p><p>Then it spoke to me again without voice: \u201cYou must become a child again and without shame.</p><p>The pride of youth is still on you, you became young at a late time; but whoever would become a child must also overcome his youth.\u201d \u2013</p><p>And I thought for a long time and trembled. At last however I said what I had said at first: \u201cI do not want to.\u201d</p><p>Then laughter broke out around me. Alas, how this laughter tore my entrails and slit open my heart!</p><p>And it spoke to me one last time: \u201cOh Zarathustra, your fruits are ripe but you are not ripe for your fruits!</p><p>Thus you must return to your solitude, for you shall yet become mellow.\u201d \u2013</p><p>And again there was laughing and it vanished; then it became still around me as if with twofold stillness. But I lay on the ground and the sweat poured from my limbs.</p><p>\u2013 Now you have heard everything, and why I must return to my solitude. I withheld nothing from you, my friends.</p><p>But hear this from me as well, I who am still the most tightlipped of human beings \u2013 and want to be so!</p><p>Oh my friends! There is still something I could tell you, there is still something I could give you! Why do I not give it? Am I stingy? \u2013</p><p>But when Zarathustra had spoken these words he was overcome by the force of his pain and the nearness of parting from his friends, so that he wept out loud; and no one was able to comfort him. At night, however, he went away alone and left his friends.</p>", "article_json": {"type": "doc", "content": [{"type": "heading", "attrs": {"level": 2}, "content": [{"text": "The Stillest Hour", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "content": [{"text": "What happened to me, my friends? You see me distraught, chased away, reluctantly obedient, prepared to go \u2013 alas, to go away from you!\r\n\r\nYes, once again Zarathustra must return to his solitude; but this time the bear returns to his cave unwillingly!\r\n\r\nWhat happened to me? Who commanded this? \u2013 Alas, my angry mistress wills it so, she spoke to me \u2013 did I ever mention her name to you?\r\n\r\nYesterday toward evening my stillest hour spoke to me: that is the name of my terrible mistress.\r\n\r\nAnd this is how it happened \u2013 for I must tell you everything, so your hearts do not harden against the one who must depart abruptly!\r\n\r\nDo you know the terror of the one who is falling asleep? \u2013\r\n\r\nHe is stricken with terror down to his toes because the ground is fading and the dream begins.\r\n\r\nThis I say to you as a parable. Yesterday, at the stillest hour, the ground faded from me, the dream began.\r\n\r\nThe hand advanced, the clock of my life drew a breath \u2013 never had I heard such stillness around me, so that my heart was terrified.\r\n\r\nThen without voice it spoke to me: \u201cYou know it, Zarathustra?\u201d \u2013\r\n\r\nAnd I cried out in terror on hearing this whispering, and the blood drained from my face, but I kept silent.\r\n\r\nThen it spoke to me once more without voice: \u201cYou know it Zarathustra, but you do not speak it!\u201d \u2013\r\n\r\nAnd at last I answered defiantly: \u201cIndeed, I know it, but I do not want to speak it!\u201d\r\n\r\nThen it spoke to me again without voice: \u201cYou do not want to, Zarathustra? Is this even true? Do not hide in your defiance!\u201d \u2013\r\n\r\nAnd I wept and trembled like a child and spoke: \u201cOh, I wanted to, yes, but how can I? Spare me this one thing! It is beyond my strength!\u201d\r\n\r\nThen it spoke to me again without voice: \u201cWhat do you matter, Zarathustra? Speak your word and break!\u201d \u2013\r\n\r\nAnd I answered: \u201cAlas, is it my word? Who am I? I am waiting for one more worthy; I am not worthy even of breaking under it.\u201d\r\n\r\nThen it spoke to me again without voice: \u201cWhat do you matter? You are not yet humble enough for me. Humility has the toughest hide.\u201d \u2013\r\n\r\nAnd I answered: \u201cWhat has the hide of my humility not borne already! I dwell at the foot of my height; how high are my peaks? No one yet has told me. But well do I know my valleys.\u201d\r\n\r\nThen it spoke to me again without voice: \u201cOh Zarathustra, whoever has mountains to move must also move valleys and hollows.\u201d \u2013\r\n\r\nAnd I answered: \u201cAs of yet my words have moved no mountains, and what I spoke did not reach mankind. I went to human beings, to be sure, but I have not yet arrived among them.\u201d\r\n\r\nThen it spoke to me again without voice: \u201cWhat do you know of that! The dew lands on the grass when the night is most silent.\u201d \u2013\r\n\r\nAnd I answered: \u201cThey mocked me when I found and walked my own way; and in truth my feet trembled at that time.\r\n\r\nAnd thus they spoke to me: \u2018You have forgotten the way, and now you are forgetting how to walk too!\u2019\u201d\r\n\r\nThen it spoke to me again without voice: \u201cWhat does their mock- ery matter! You are one who has forgotten how to obey; now you shall command!\r\n\r\nDo you not know who is needed most by everyone? The one who commands great things.\r\n\r\nTo accomplish great things is difficult; but what is even more difficult is to command great things.\r\n\r\nThat is what is most unforgivable in you: you have the power, and you do not want to rule.\u201d \u2013\r\n\r\nAnd I answered: \u201cI lack the lion\u2019s voice for all commanding.\u201d\r\n\r\nThen it spoke to me again like a whispering: \u201cThe stillest words are those that bring the storm. Thoughts that come on the feet of doves steer the world.\r\n\r\nOh Zarathustra, you shall go as a shadow of that which must come; thus you will command and lead the way commanding.\u201d \u2013\r\n\r\nAnd I answered: \u201cI am ashamed.\u201d\r\n\r\nThen it spoke to me again without voice: \u201cYou must become a child again and without shame.\r\n\r\nThe pride of youth is still on you, you became young at a late time; but whoever would become a child must also overcome his youth.\u201d \u2013\r\n\r\nAnd I thought for a long time and trembled. At last however I said what I had said at first: \u201cI do not want to.\u201d\r\n\r\nThen laughter broke out around me. Alas, how this laughter tore my entrails and slit open my heart!\r\n\r\nAnd it spoke to me one last time: \u201cOh Zarathustra, your fruits are ripe but you are not ripe for your fruits!\r\n\r\nThus you must return to your solitude, for you shall yet become mellow.\u201d \u2013\r\n\r\nAnd again there was laughing and it vanished; then it became still around me as if with twofold stillness. But I lay on the ground and the sweat poured from my limbs.\r\n\r\n\u2013 Now you have heard everything, and why I must return to my solitude. I withheld nothing from you, my friends.\r\n\r\nBut hear this from me as well, I who am still the most tightlipped of human beings \u2013 and want to be so!\r\n\r\nOh my friends! There is still something I could tell you, there is still something I could give you! Why do I not give it? Am I stingy? \u2013\r\n\r\nBut when Zarathustra had spoken these words he was overcome by the force of his pain and the nearness of parting from his friends, so that he wept out loud; and no one was able to comfort him. At night, however, he went away alone and left his friends."}, "id": 60}]}, {"data": {"uuid": "6ef92b09-bedd-42e5-a3ef-3dcf1bb2fb09", "user": 1, "title": "Third Part", "created_on": "2023-05-10 15:44:44.537697+00:00", "updated_on": "2023-05-10 15:44:44.552240+00:00", "article_html": "<h1>Third Part</h1>", "article_json": {"type": "doc", "content": [{"type": "heading", "attrs": {"level": 1}, "content": [{"text": "Third Part", "type": "text"}]}]}, "article_text": "Third Part"}, "id": 61, "children": [{"data": {"uuid": "ca1640f9-e09f-4e0a-84db-0444fb683b17", "user": 1, "title": "The Wanderer", "created_on": "2023-05-10 15:45:39.890977+00:00", "updated_on": "2023-05-10 15:45:39.908444+00:00", "article_html": "<h2>The Wanderer</h2><p>It was around midnight that Zarathustra started his route over the ridge of the island, in order to arrive at the other coast by early morning; for there he intended to board a ship. At that location there was safe harborage where even foreign ships liked to anchor; these would take the occasional passenger who wanted to cross the sea from the blessed isles. Now as Zarathustra climbed up the mountain he thought as he traveled about his many lonely wanderings since the time of his youth, and about how many mountains and ridges and peaks he had already climbed.</p><p>I am a wanderer and a mountain climber, he said to his heart. I do not like the plains and it seems I cannot sit still for long.</p><p>And whatever may come to me now as destiny and experience \u2013 it will involve wandering and mountain climbing: ultimately one experiences only oneself.</p><p>The time has passed in which accidents could still befall me, and what could fall to me now that is not already my own?</p><p>It merely returns, it finally comes home to me \u2013 my own self and everything in it that has long been abroad and scattered among all things and accidents.</p><p>And I know one more thing: I am standing now before my last peak and before what has been saved for me for the longest time. Indeed, I must start my hardest path! Indeed, I have begun my loneliest hike!</p><p>But whoever is of my kind does not escape such an hour, the hour that speaks to him: \u201cOnly now do you go your way of greatness! Peak and abyss \u2013 they are now merged as one!</p><p>You go your way of greatness; now what was formerly your ultimate danger has become your ultimate refuge!</p><p>You go your way of greatness; now it must be your best courage that there is no longer a way behind you!</p><p>You go your way of greatness; here no one shall sneak along after you! Your foot itself erased the path behind you, and above it stands written: impossibility.</p><p>And if now all ladders should fail, then you must know how to climb on your own head \u2013 how else would you climb upward?</p><p>On your own head and over and beyond your own heart! I do not praise the land where butter and honey flow!</p><p>It is necessary to look away from oneself in order to see much: this hardness is needed by every mountain climber.</p><p>But whoever is importunate with his eyes as a seeker of knowledge \u2013 how could he see more of things than their foregrounds?</p><p>But you, Zarathustra, you wanted to see the ground and background of all things, and so you must climb over yourself \u2013 up, upward, until you have even your stars beneath you!\u201d</p><p>Yes, look down on myself and even on my stars: only that would I call my peak, that remains to me as my ultimate peak! \u2013</p><p>Thus Zarathustra spoke to himself as he climbed, comforting his heart with hard sayings, for he was sore in his heart as never before. And as he came to the top of the mountain ridge, behold, there lay the other sea stretching before him, and he stood still and silent for a long time. But at this altitude the night was cold and clear and bright with stars.</p><p>I recognize my lot, he said at last, with sorrow. Well then! I am ready. Just now my ultimate solitude began.</p><p>Oh this black sad sea beneath me! Oh this pregnant nocturnal moroseness! My destiny wills it so: Well then! I am ready.</p><p>Where did the highest mountains come from? Thus I once asked. From the deepest the highest must come into its height. \u2013</p><p>Thus spoke Zarathustra at the pinnacle of the mountain, where it was cold. But as he came near to the sea and stood at last alone among the cliffs, then he had grown weary from his travels and felt even greater longing than before.</p><p>Everything is still sleeping, he said; even the sea sleeps. Drunk with sleep and strangely it looks at me.</p><p>But it breathes warmly, that I feel. And I also feel that it is dreaming. Dreaming it tosses on hard pillows.</p><p>Listen! Listen! How it moans with evil memories \u2013 or evil forebodings?</p><p>Yes, I am sad along with you, you dark monster, and for your sake annoyed even with myself.</p><p>Oh that my hand does not possess sufficient strength! At that location there was safe harborage where even foreign ships liked to anchor; these would take the occasional passenger who wanted to cross the sea from the blessed isles. Now as Zarathustra climbed up the mountain he thought as he traveled about his many lonely wanderings since the time of his youth, and about how many mountains and ridges and peaks he had already climbed.\r\n\r\nI am a wanderer and a mountain climber, he said to his heart. I do not like the plains and it seems I cannot sit still for long.\r\n\r\nAnd whatever may come to me now as destiny and experience \u2013 it will involve wandering and mountain climbing: ultimately one experiences only oneself.\r\n\r\nThe time has passed in which accidents could still befall me, and what could fall to me now that is not already my own?\r\n\r\nIt merely returns, it finally comes home to me \u2013 my own self and everything in it that has long been abroad and scattered among all things and accidents.\r\n\r\nAnd I know one more thing: I am standing now before my last peak and before what has been saved for me for the longest time. Indeed, I must start my hardest path! Indeed, I have begun my loneliest hike!\r\n\r\nBut whoever is of my kind does not escape such an hour, the hour that speaks to him: \u201cOnly now do you go your way of greatness! Peak and abyss \u2013 they are now merged as one!\r\n\r\nYou go your way of greatness; now what was formerly your ultimate danger has become your ultimate refuge!\r\n\r\nYou go your way of greatness; now it must be your best courage that there is no longer a way behind you!\r\n\r\nYou go your way of greatness; here no one shall sneak along after you! Your foot itself erased the path behind you, and above it stands written: impossibility.\r\n\r\nAnd if now all ladders should fail, then you must know how to climb on your own head \u2013 how else would you climb upward?\r\n\r\nOn your own head and over and beyond your own heart! Now what is mildest in you must become hardest.\r\n\r\nWhoever has always spared himself much gets sick in the end from so much coddling. Praised be whatever makes hard! I do not praise the land where butter and honey flow!\r\n\r\nIt is necessary to look away from oneself in order to see much: this hardness is needed by every mountain climber.\r\n\r\nBut whoever is importunate with his eyes as a seeker of knowledge \u2013 how could he see more of things than their foregrounds?\r\n\r\nBut you, Zarathustra, you wanted to see the ground and background of all things, and so you must climb over yourself \u2013 up, upward, until you have even your stars beneath you!\u201d\r\n\r\nYes, look down on myself and even on my stars: only that would I call my peak, that remains to me as my ultimate peak! \u2013\r\n\r\nThus Zarathustra spoke to himself as he climbed, comforting his heart with hard sayings, for he was sore in his heart as never before. And as he came to the top of the mountain ridge, behold, there lay the other sea stretching before him, and he stood still and silent for a long time. But at this altitude the night was cold and clear and bright with stars.\r\n\r\nI recognize my lot, he said at last, with sorrow. Well then! I am ready. Just now my ultimate solitude began.\r\n\r\nOh this black sad sea beneath me! Oh this pregnant nocturnal moroseness! Oh destiny and sea \u2013 now I must descend to you!\r\n\r\nI stand before my highest mountains and before my longest hike: therefore I must descend deeper than I ever climbed before:\r\n\r\n\u2013 descend deeper into suffering than I ever climbed before, down into its blackest flood! My destiny wills it so: Well then! I am ready.\r\n\r\nWhere did the highest mountains come from? Thus I once asked. Then I learned that they come from the sea.\r\n\r\nThis testimony is written into their stone and onto the walls of their peaks. From the deepest the highest must come into its height. \u2013\r\n\r\nThus spoke Zarathustra at the pinnacle of the mountain, where it was cold. But as he came near to the sea and stood at last alone among the cliffs, then he had grown weary from his travels and felt even greater longing than before.\r\n\r\nEverything is still sleeping, he said; even the sea sleeps. Drunk with sleep and strangely it looks at me.\r\n\r\nBut it breathes warmly, that I feel. And I also feel that it is dreaming. Dreaming it tosses on hard pillows.\r\n\r\nListen! Listen! How it moans with evil memories \u2013 or evil forebodings?\r\n\r\nYes, I am sad along with you, you dark monster, and for your sake annoyed even with myself.\r\n\r\nOh that my hand does not possess sufficient strength! Gladly indeed would I redeem you from evil dreams! \u2013\r\n\r\nAnd as Zarathustra spoke thus he laughed at himself with melancholy and bitterness. \u201cWhat, Zarathustra!\u201d he said. \u201cDo you want to sing comfort even to the sea?\r\n\r\nOh you loving fool Zarathustra, you who are over-blessed with trust! But you have always been so; always you came trustingly to all that is terrible.\r\n\r\nYou wanted to caress every monster. A hint of warm breath, a bit of soft shag on the paw \u2013 and already you were prepared to love it and lure it.\r\n\r\nLove is the danger of the loneliest one, love of everything if only it lives! Laughable indeed are my folly and my modesty in love!\u201d \u2013\r\n\r\nThus spoke Zarathustra and he laughed once again. But then he remembered the friends he left behind \u2013 and as if he had violated them with his thoughts, he became angry for his thoughts. And suddenly the laughing one began to weep \u2013 for wrath and longing Zarathustra wept bitterly."}, "id": 62}, {"data": {"uuid": "d407761d-90a0-4f3c-8772-d61369af51ce", "user": 1, "title": "On the Vision and the Riddle", "created_on": "2023-05-10 15:46:43.031196+00:00", "updated_on": "2023-05-10 15:46:43.051258+00:00", "article_html": "<h2>On the Vision and the Riddle</h2><h3>1</h3><p>When it was rumored among the sailors that Zarathustra was on the ship \u2013 for a man who came from the blessed isles went on board at the same time as him \u2013 then a great curiosity and anticipation arose. But Zarathustra kept silent for two days and was cold and deaf with sadness, such that he answered neither to glances nor questions. On the evening of the second day, however, he opened his ears again, even though he continued to be silent; for there was much that was peculiar and dangerous to be heard on this ship, which had come from far away and wanted to go still farther. But Zarathustra was a friend of all who make distant journeys and do not like to live without danger, and so, finally, his own tongue was freed while listening, and the ice of his heart broke: then he began to speak thus:</p><p>To you, bold searchers, researchers, and whoever put to terrible seas with cunning sails \u2013</p><p>to you, the riddle-drunk, the twilight-happy whose souls are lured by flutes to every maelstrom:</p><p>\u2013 because you do not want to probe along a thread with cowardly hands; and because where you can guess, there you hate to deduce \u2013</p><p>to you alone I tell the riddle that I saw \u2013 the vision of the loneliest one. \u2013</p><p>Darkly I walked recently through cadaver-colored twilight \u2013 darkly and hard, biting my lip. Not only one sun had set for me.</p><p>A path that climbed defiantly through boulders, a malicious, lonely path consoled neither by weed nor shrub \u2013 a mountain path crunched under the defiance of my foot.</p><p>Striding mutely over the mocking clatter of pebbles, crushing the rock that caused it to slip; thus my foot forced its way upward.</p><p>Upward \u2013 in defiance of the spirit that pulled it downward, the spirit of gravity, my devil and arch-enemy.</p><p>Upward \u2013 even though he sat atop me, half dwarf, half mole, lame, paralyzing, dripping lead into my ear, lead-drop thoughts into my brain.</p><p>\u201cOh Zarathustra,\u201d he murmured scornfully, syllable by syllable. \u201cYou stone of wisdom! You hurled yourself high, but every hurled stone must \u2013 fall!</p><p>Oh Zarathustra, you stone of wisdom, you sling stone, you star crusher! You hurled yourself so high \u2013 but every hurled stone \u2013 must fall!</p><p>Sentenced to yourself and to your own stoning; oh Zarathustra, far indeed you hurled the stone \u2013 but it will fall back down upon you!\u201d</p><p>Then the dwarf became silent, and that lasted a long time. But his silence oppressed me, and being at two in such a way truly makes one lonelier than being at one!</p><p>I climbed, I climbed, I dreamed, I thought \u2013 but everything oppressed me. I resembled a sick person whose severe agonies make him weary, and who is then jarred out of falling asleep by an even worse dream. \u2013</p><p>But there is something in me that I call courage: this so far has slain my every discourage. This courage at last commanded me to stand still and to say: \u201cDwarf \u2013 you or I!\u201d \u2013</p><p>Courage after all is the best slayer \u2013 courage that attacks; for in every attack there is sounding brass.</p><p>But the human being is the most courageous animal, and so it overcame every animal. With sounding brass it even overcame every pain, but human pain is the deepest pain.</p><p>Courage also slays dizziness at the abyss; and where do human beings not stand at the abyss? Is seeing itself not \u2013 seeing the abyss?</p><p>Courage is the best slayer; courage slays even pity. But pity is the deepest abyss, and as deeply as human beings look into life, so deeply too they look into suffering.</p><p>But courage is the best slayer, courage that attacks; it slays even death, for it says: \u201cWas that life? Well then! One More Time!\u201d</p><p>In such a saying, however, there is much sounding brass. He who has ears to hear, let him hear!</p><h3>2</h3><p>\u201cStop, dwarf!\u201d I said. \u201cI \u2013 or you! But I am the stronger of us two \u2013 you do not know my abysmal thought! That \u2013 you could not bear!\u201d \u2013</p><p>Then something happened that made me lighter, for the dwarf jumped down from my shoulder, the inquisitive one, and he crouched upon a stone there before me. But right there where we stopped was a gateway.</p><p>\u201cSee this gateway, dwarf!\u201d I continued. \u201cIt has two faces. Two paths come together here; no one has yet walked them to the end.</p><p>This long lane back: it lasts an eternity. And that long lane outward \u2013 that is another eternity.</p><p>They contradict each other, these paths; they blatantly offend each other \u2013 and here at this gateway is where they come together. The name of the gateway is inscribed at the top: \u2018Moment.\u2019</p><p>But whoever were to walk one of them further \u2013 and ever further and ever on: do you believe, dwarf, that these paths contradict each other eternally?\u201d \u2013</p><p>\u201cAll that is straight lies,\u201d murmured the dwarf contemptuously. \u201cAll truth is crooked, time itself is a circle.\u201d</p><p>\u201cYou spirit of gravity!\u201d I said, angrily. \u201cDo not make it too easy on yourself! Or I shall leave you crouching here where you crouch, lamefoot \u2013 and I bore you this high!</p><p>See this moment!\u201d I continued. \u201cFrom this gateway Moment a long eternal lane stretches backward: behind us lies an eternity.</p><p>Must not whatever can already have passed this way before? Must not whatever can happen, already have happened, been done, passed by before?</p><p>And if everything has already been here before, what do you think of this moment, dwarf? Must this gateway too not already \u2013 have been here?</p><p>And are not all things firmly knotted together in such a way that this moment draws after it all things to come? Therefore \u2013 itself as well?</p><p>For, whatever can run, even in this long lane outward \u2013 must run it once more! \u2013</p><p>And this slow spider that creeps in the moonlight, and this moonlight itself, and I and you in the gateway whispering together, whispering of eternal things \u2013 must not all of us have been here before?</p><p>\u2013 And return and run in that other lane, outward, before us, in this long, eerie lane \u2013 must we not return eternally? \u2013\u201d</p><p>Thus I spoke, softer and softer, for I was afraid of my own thought and secret thoughts. Then, suddenly, I heard a dog howl nearby.</p><p>Had I ever heard a dog howl like this? My thoughts raced back. Yes! When I was a child, in my most distant childhood:</p><p>\u2013 then I heard a dog howl like this. And I saw it too, bristling, its head up, trembling in the stillest midnight when even dogs believe in ghosts:</p><p>\u2013 so that I felt pity. For the full moon had passed over the house, silent as death, and it had just stopped, a round smolder \u2013 stopped on the flat roof just as if on a stranger\u2019s property \u2013</p><p>that is the why the dog was so horror-stricken, because dogs believe in thieves and ghosts. And when I heard it howl like this again, I felt pity once more.</p><p>Where now was the dwarf? And the gateway? And the spider? And all the whispering? Was I dreaming? Was I waking? I stood all of a sudden among wild cliffs, alone, desolate, in the most desolate moonlight.</p><p>But there lay a human being! And there! The dog jumping, bristling, whining \u2013 now it saw me coming \u2013 then it howled again, it screamed: had I ever heard a dog scream like this for help?</p><p>And truly, I saw something the like of which I had never seen before. A young shepherd I saw; writhing, choking, twitching, his face distorted, with a thick black snake hanging from his mouth.</p><p>Had I ever seen so much nausea and pale dread in one face? Surely he must have fallen asleep? Then the snake crawled into his throat \u2013 where it bit down firmly.</p><p>My hand tore at the snake and tore \u2013 in vain! It could not tear the snake from his throat. Then it cried out of me: \u201cBite down! Bite down!</p><p>Bite off the head! Bite down!\u201d \u2013 Thus it cried out of me, my dread, my hatred, my nausea, my pity, all my good and bad cried out of me with one shout. \u2013</p><p>You bold ones around me! You searchers, researchers and whoever among you ever shipped out with cunning sails onto unexplored seas! You riddle-happy ones!</p><p>Now guess me this riddle that I saw back then, now interpret me this vision of the loneliest one!</p><p>For it was a vision and a foreseeing: what did I see then as a parable? And who is it that must some day come?</p><p>Who is the shepherd into whose throat the snake crawled this way? Who is the human being into whose throat everything that is heaviest, blackest will crawl?</p><p>\u2013 Meanwhile the shepherd bit down as my shout advised him; he bit with a good bite! Far away he spat the head of the snake \u2013 and he leaped to his feet. \u2013</p><p>No longer shepherd, no longer human \u2013 a transformed, illuminated, laughing being!</p><p>Never yet on earth had I heard a human being laugh as he laughed!</p><p>Oh my brothers, I heard a laughter that was no human laughter \u2013 and now a thirst gnaws at me, a longing that will never be still.</p><p>My longing for this laughter gnaws at me; oh how can I bear to go on living! And how could I bear to die now! \u2013</p><p>Thus spoke Zarathustra.</p>", "article_json": {"type": "doc", "content": [{"type": "heading", "attrs": {"level": 2}, "content": [{"text": "On the Vision and the Riddle", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "heading", "attrs": {"level": 3}, "content": [{"text": "1", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "content": [{"text": "When it was rumored among the sailors that Zarathustra was on the ship \u2013 for a man who came from the blessed isles went on board at the same time as him \u2013 then a great curiosity and anticipation arose. But Zarathustra kept silent for two days and was cold and deaf with sadness, such that he answered neither to glances nor questions. On the evening of the second day, however, he opened his ears again, even though he continued to be silent; for there was much that was peculiar and dangerous to be heard on this ship, which had come from far away and wanted to go still farther. But Zarathustra was a friend of all who make distant journeys and do not like to live without danger, and so, finally, his own tongue was freed while listening, and the ice of his heart broke: then he began to speak thus:\r\n\r\nTo you, bold searchers, researchers, and whoever put to terrible seas with cunning sails \u2013\r\n\r\nto you, the riddle-drunk, the twilight-happy whose souls are lured by flutes to every maelstrom:\r\n\r\n\u2013 because you do not want to probe along a thread with cowardly hands; and because where you can guess, there you hate to deduce \u2013\r\n\r\nto you alone I tell the riddle that I saw \u2013 the vision of the loneliest one. \u2013\r\n\r\nDarkly I walked recently through cadaver-colored twilight \u2013 darkly and hard, biting my lip. Not only one sun had set for me.\r\n\r\nA path that climbed defiantly through boulders, a malicious, lonely path consoled neither by weed nor shrub \u2013 a mountain path crunched under the defiance of my foot.\r\n\r\nStriding mutely over the mocking clatter of pebbles, crushing the rock that caused it to slip; thus my foot forced its way upward.\r\n\r\nUpward \u2013 in defiance of the spirit that pulled it downward, the spirit of gravity, my devil and arch-enemy.\r\n\r\nUpward \u2013 even though he sat atop me, half dwarf, half mole, lame, paralyzing, dripping lead into my ear, lead-drop thoughts into my brain.\r\n\r\n\u201cOh Zarathustra,\u201d he murmured scornfully, syllable by syllable. \u201cYou stone of wisdom! You hurled yourself high, but every hurled stone must \u2013 fall!\r\n\r\nOh Zarathustra, you stone of wisdom, you sling stone, you star crusher! You hurled yourself so high \u2013 but every hurled stone \u2013 must fall!\r\n\r\nSentenced to yourself and to your own stoning; oh Zarathustra, far indeed you hurled the stone \u2013 but it will fall back down upon you!\u201d\r\n\r\nThen the dwarf became silent, and that lasted a long time. But his silence oppressed me, and being at two in such a way truly makes one lonelier than being at one!\r\n\r\nI climbed, I climbed, I dreamed, I thought \u2013 but everything oppressed me. I resembled a sick person whose severe agonies make him weary, and who is then jarred out of falling asleep by an even worse dream. \u2013\r\n\r\nBut there is something in me that I call courage: this so far has slain my every discourage. This courage at last commanded me to stand still and to say: \u201cDwarf \u2013 you or I!\u201d \u2013\r\n\r\nCourage after all is the best slayer \u2013 courage that attacks; for in every attack there is sounding brass.\r\n\r\nBut the human being is the most courageous animal, and so it overcame every animal. With sounding brass it even overcame every pain, but human pain is the deepest pain.\r\n\r\nCourage also slays dizziness at the abyss; and where do human beings not stand at the abyss? Is seeing itself not \u2013 seeing the abyss?\r\n\r\nCourage is the best slayer; courage slays even pity. But pity is the deepest abyss, and as deeply as human beings look into life, so deeply too they look into suffering.\r\n\r\nBut courage is the best slayer, courage that attacks; it slays even death, for it says: \u201cWas that life? Well then! One More Time!\u201d\r\n\r\nIn such a saying, however, there is much sounding brass. He who has ears to hear, let him hear!\r\n\r\n2\r\n\r\n\u201cStop, dwarf!\u201d I said. \u201cI \u2013 or you! But I am the stronger of us two \u2013 you do not know my abysmal thought! That \u2013 you could not bear!\u201d \u2013\r\n\r\nThen something happened that made me lighter, for the dwarf jumped down from my shoulder, the inquisitive one, and he crouched upon a stone there before me. But right there where we stopped was a gateway.\r\n\r\n\u201cSee this gateway, dwarf!\u201d I continued. \u201cIt has two faces. Two paths come together here; no one has yet walked them to the end.\r\n\r\nThis long lane back: it lasts an eternity. And that long lane outward \u2013 that is another eternity.\r\n\r\nThey contradict each other, these paths; they blatantly offend each other \u2013 and here at this gateway is where they come together. The name of the gateway is inscribed at the top: \u2018Moment.\u2019\r\n\r\nBut whoever were to walk one of them further \u2013 and ever further and ever on: do you believe, dwarf, that these paths contradict each other eternally?\u201d \u2013\r\n\r\n\u201cAll that is straight lies,\u201d murmured the dwarf contemptuously. \u201cAll truth is crooked, time itself is a circle.\u201d\r\n\r\n\u201cYou spirit of gravity!\u201d I said, angrily. \u201cDo not make it too easy on yourself! Or I shall leave you crouching here where you crouch, lamefoot \u2013 and I bore you this high!\r\n\r\nSee this moment!\u201d I continued. \u201cFrom this gateway Moment a long eternal lane stretches backward: behind us lies an eternity.\r\n\r\nMust not whatever can already have passed this way before? Must not whatever can happen, already have happened, been done, passed by before?\r\n\r\nAnd if everything has already been here before, what do you think of this moment, dwarf? Must this gateway too not already \u2013 have been here?\r\n\r\nAnd are not all things firmly knotted together in such a way that this moment draws after it all things to come? Therefore \u2013 itself as well?\r\n\r\nFor, whatever can run, even in this long lane outward \u2013 must run it once more! \u2013\r\n\r\nAnd this slow spider that creeps in the moonlight, and this moonlight itself, and I and you in the gateway whispering together, whispering of eternal things \u2013 must not all of us have been here before?\r\n\r\n\u2013 And return and run in that other lane, outward, before us, in this long, eerie lane \u2013 must we not return eternally? \u2013\u201d\r\n\r\nThus I spoke, softer and softer, for I was afraid of my own thought and secret thoughts. Then, suddenly, I heard a dog howl nearby.\r\n\r\nHad I ever heard a dog howl like this? My thoughts raced back. Yes! When I was a child, in my most distant childhood:\r\n\r\n\u2013 then I heard a dog howl like this. And I saw it too, bristling, its head up, trembling in the stillest midnight when even dogs believe in ghosts:\r\n\r\n\u2013 so that I felt pity. For the full moon had passed over the house, silent as death, and it had just stopped, a round smolder \u2013 stopped on the flat roof just as if on a stranger\u2019s property \u2013\r\n\r\nthat is the why the dog was so horror-stricken, because dogs believe in thieves and ghosts. And when I heard it howl like this again, I felt pity once more.\r\n\r\nWhere now was the dwarf? And the gateway? And the spider? And all the whispering? Was I dreaming? Was I waking? I stood all of a sudden among wild cliffs, alone, desolate, in the most desolate moonlight.\r\n\r\nBut there lay a human being! And there! The dog jumping, bristling, whining \u2013 now it saw me coming \u2013 then it howled again, it screamed: had I ever heard a dog scream like this for help?\r\n\r\nAnd truly, I saw something the like of which I had never seen before. A young shepherd I saw; writhing, choking, twitching, his face distorted, with a thick black snake hanging from his mouth.\r\n\r\nHad I ever seen so much nausea and pale dread in one face? Surely he must have fallen asleep? Then the snake crawled into his throat \u2013 where it bit down firmly.\r\n\r\nMy hand tore at the snake and tore \u2013 in vain! It could not tear the snake from his throat. Then it cried out of me: \u201cBite down! Bite down!\r\n\r\nBite off the head! Bite down!\u201d \u2013 Thus it cried out of me, my dread, my hatred, my nausea, my pity, all my good and bad cried out of me with one shout. \u2013\r\n\r\nYou bold ones around me! You searchers, researchers and whoever among you ever shipped out with cunning sails onto unexplored seas! You riddle-happy ones!\r\n\r\nNow guess me this riddle that I saw back then, now interpret me this vision of the loneliest one!\r\n\r\nFor it was a vision and a foreseeing: what did I see then as a parable? And who is it that must some day come?\r\n\r\nWho is the shepherd into whose throat the snake crawled this way? Who is the human being into whose throat everything that is heaviest, blackest will crawl?\r\n\r\n\u2013 Meanwhile the shepherd bit down as my shout advised him; he bit with a good bite! Far away he spat the head of the snake \u2013 and he leaped to his feet. \u2013\r\n\r\nNo longer shepherd, no longer human \u2013 a transformed, illuminated, laughing being!\r\n\r\nNever yet on earth had I heard a human being laugh as he laughed!\r\n\r\nOh my brothers, I heard a laughter that was no human laughter \u2013 and now a thirst gnaws at me, a longing that will never be still.\r\n\r\nMy longing for this laughter gnaws at me; oh how can I bear to go on living! And how could I bear to die now! \u2013\r\n\r\nThus spoke Zarathustra."}, "id": 63}, {"data": {"uuid": "3b56a55d-99b2-49cc-8c43-ef41075d23c0", "user": 1, "title": "On Unwilling Bliss", "created_on": "2023-05-10 15:47:40.961831+00:00", "updated_on": "2023-05-10 15:47:40.981229+00:00", "article_html": "<h2>On Unwilling Bliss</h2><p>With such riddles and bitterness in his heart Zarathustra traveled across the sea. But when he was four days removed from the blessed isles and from his friends, he had overcome all of his pain: triumphant and with firm footing he stood once again upon his destiny. And then Zarathustra spoke thus to his jubilating conscience:</p><p>I am alone again and want to be, alone with pure sky and open sea; and again it is afternoon around me.</p><p>In the afternoon I once found my friends for the first time, in the afternoon then a second time: at the hour when all light grows stiller.</p><p>For whatever happiness is still underway between sky and earth, it now seeks shelter for itself in a bright soul: out of happiness now all light has become stiller.</p><p>Oh afternoon of my life! Once my happiness too climbed to the valley to seek itself a shelter; there it found these open, hospitable souls.</p><p>Oh afternoon of my life! What have I not given up to have this one thing: this lively plantation of my thoughts and this morning light of my highest hope!</p><p>Companions the creator once sought and children of his hope, and truly, it turned out that he could not find them unless he first created them himself.</p><p>And so I am in the middle of my work, going to my children and returning from them; for the sake of his children Zarathustra must complete himself.</p><p>For at bottom one loves only one\u2019s own child and work; and where there is great love for oneself it is the hallmark of pregnancy \u2013 this is what I found.</p><p>My children are still greening in their first spring, standing close to one another and shaken by a common wind, the trees of my garden and best plot of soil.</p><p>And truly, where such trees stand next to one another, there are blessed isles!</p><p>But at some point I want to dig them up and set each one apart, so that it learns solitude and defiance and caution.</p><p>Gnarled and crooked and with pliant hardness it shall stand then beside the sea, a living lighthouse of invincible life.</p><p>There, where the storms plunge down into the sea and the mountain\u2019s trunk drinks water, there each one shall someday have his day and night watches, for his own testing and knowledge.</p><p>He shall be known and tested as to whether he is of my kind and kin \u2013 whether he is the master of a long will, taciturn even when he speaks, and yielding in such a way that he takes in giving \u2013</p><p>\u2013 so that he might one day become my companion and a fellow creator and fellow celebrator of Zarathustra: the kind who writes my will on my tablets for the fuller completion of all things.</p><p>And for his sake and his kind I must complete myself; therefore I now avoid my happiness and offer myself to all unhappiness \u2013 for my ultimate testing and knowledge.</p><p>And truly, it was time that I left, and the wanderer\u2019s shadow and the bitterest boredom and the stillest hour \u2013 all of them said to me: \u201cit is high time!\u201d</p><p>The wind blew through my keyhole and said: \u201ccome!\u201d The door sprang open slyly and said: \u201cgo!\u201d</p><p>But I lay chained to the love of my children; desire set this snare for me, desire for love, that I might become the prey of my children and lose myself to them.</p><p>Desire \u2013 to me that means: to have lost myself. I have you, my children! In this having, everything shall be certain and nothing shall be desire.</p><p>But the sun lay brooding on my love, and Zarathustra cooked in his own juice \u2013 then shadows and doubts flew over and past me.</p><p>I craved frost and winter: \u201cOh if only frost and winter made me snap and crunch again!\u201d I sighed \u2013 then icy fog rose up out of me.</p><p>My past broke open its graves; many a pain that had been buried alive awakened \u2013 it had merely had a good night\u2019s sleep, hidden in burial shrouds.</p><p>Thus everything cried out to me in signs: \u201cit is time!\u201d \u2013 But I \u2013 did not hear. Until at last my abyss stirred and my thought bit me.</p><p>Oh, abysmal thought, you who are my thought! When will I find the strength to hear you digging without trembling?</p><p>My heart pounds all the way up to my head when I hear you digging! Even your silence wants to strangle me, you abysmally silent one!</p><p>Never yet have I dared to summon you up; it is enough that I carried you around with me! As yet I have not been strong enough for the lion\u2019s final overreaching and cheeky mischief.</p><p>Your gravity alone was always terrible enough for me; but one day I shall yet find the strength and the lion\u2019s voice to summon you up!</p><p>When I have once overcome that challenge, then I want to overcome one still greater; and a triumph shall be the seal of my completion! \u2013</p><p>Meanwhile I still drift on uncertain seas; accident flatters me with its smooth tongue, and though I look forward and backward, I still see no end.</p><p>As yet the hour of my final struggle has not come \u2013 or does it come just now? Indeed, with treacherous beauty the surrounding sea and life gaze at me!</p><p>Oh afternoon of my life! Oh happiness before evening! Oh harbor on the high sea! Oh peace in uncertainty! How I mistrust you all!</p><p>Indeed, I am mistrustful of your treacherous beauty! I resemble the lover who mistrusts the all too velvety smile.</p><p>As he pushes his most beloved before him, tender even in his hardness, the jealous one \u2013 so too I push this blissful hour before me.</p><p>Away with you, you blissful hour! Along with you an unwilling bliss came to me. Willing to take my deepest pain I stand here: you came at the wrong time!</p><p>Away with you, you blissful hour! Rather take shelter there \u2013 with my children! Hurry! And bless them before evening with my happiness!</p><p>The evening is coming now, the sun is sinking. Gone \u2013 my happiness! \u2013</p><p>Thus spoke Zarathustra. And he waited for his unhappiness the whole night, but he waited in vain. The night remained bright and still, and happiness itself came closer and closer to him. Toward morning, however, Zarathustra laughed in his heart and said mockingly: \u201cHappiness chases after me, and that is because I do not chase after women. But happiness is a woman.\u201d"}, "id": 64}, {"data": {"uuid": "175f74c8-bae2-4dc9-a50f-61ee8d367ca6", "user": 1, "title": "Before Sunrise", "created_on": "2023-05-10 15:48:37.719417+00:00", "updated_on": "2023-05-10 15:48:37.738739+00:00", "article_html": "<h2>Before Sunrise</h2><p>Oh sky above me, you pure, you deep one! You abyss of light! Gazing at you I shudder with godlike desires.</p><p>To hurl myself into your height \u2013 that is my depth! To hide myself in your purity \u2013 that is my innocence.</p><p>The god is veiled by his beauty; thus you conceal your stars. You do not speak; thus you make your wisdom known to me.</p><p>Mutely you rose for me today over the roaring sea, your love and your modesty speak revelation to my roaring soul.</p><p>That you came to me beautiful, veiled in your beauty; that you speak to me mutely, revealed in your wisdom \u2013</p><p>oh how could I not guess all that is modesty in your soul! Before the sun you came to me, the loneliest one.</p><p>We are friends from the beginning; we have grief and ghastliness and ground in common; even the sun we have in common.</p><p>We do not speak to one another because we know too much: we are silent to one another, we smile our knowledge to one another.</p><p>Are you not the light to my fire? Do you not have the sister soul to my insight?</p><p>Together we learned everything; together we learned to climb up to ourselves by climbing over ourselves, and to smile cloudlessly:</p><p>\u2013 smile down cloudlessly from bright eyes and from a distance of miles, when beneath us pressure and purpose and guilt steam like rain.</p><p>And if I wandered alone \u2013 for whom did my soul thirst in nights and on wrong paths? And if I climbed mountains, whom did I ever seek if not you on mountains?</p><p>And all my wandering and mountain climbing: they were only a necessity and a help to the helpless one \u2013 the only thing my will wants is to fly, to fly into you!</p><p>And whom did I hate more than drifting clouds and everything that stains you? And I hated even my own hatred because it stained you!</p><p>I grudge these drifting clouds, these creeping predator-cats; they take from you and me what we have in common \u2013 our awesome infinite saying of Yes and Amen.</p><p>We grudge these middle-men and mixers, these drifting clouds, these half-and-halfs who learned neither to bless, nor to curse whole heartedly.</p><p>I would rather sit in a barrel under a closed sky, would rather sit in an abyss without sky than see you, sky of light, stained by drifting clouds!</p><p>And often I wanted to tie them together with the jagged gold wires of lightning, and beat their kettle bellies like thunder \u2013</p><p>\u2013 an angry kettle drummer because they rob me of your Yes! and Amen! \u2013 you sky above me, you pure, you bright one! You abyss of light! \u2013 Because they rob you of my Yes! and Amen!</p><p>For I would rather have din and thunder and stormy cursing than this deliberate, dubious cat calm; and even among humans the ones I hate most are the soft steppers and half-and-halfs and dubious, dawdling drift-clouds.</p><p>And \u201cwhoever cannot bless, let him learn to curse!\u201d \u2013 this bright teaching fell to me from the bright sky, this star stands in my sky even in black nights.</p><p>I am a blesser and a Yes-sayer if only you are around me, you pure, you bright one, you abyss of light! Into all abysses then I carry my Yes-saying that blesses.</p><p>I have become a blesser and a Yes-sayer, and for this I wrestled long and was a wrestler, in order to free my hands one day for blessing.</p><p>But this is my blessing: to stand over each thing as its own sky, as its round roof, its azure bell and eternal security \u2013 and blessed is he who blesses so!</p><p>For all things are baptized at the well of eternity and beyond good and evil; good and evil themselves, however, are only shadows in between and damp glooms and drift-clouds.</p><p>Truly it is a blessing and no blasphemy when I teach: \u201cOver all things stands the sky accident, the sky innocence, the sky chance, the sky mischief.\u201d</p><p>\u201cBy chance\u201d \u2013 that is the oldest nobility in the world, I gave it back to all things, I redeemed them from their servitude under purpose.</p><p>This freedom and cheerfulness of the sky I placed like an azure bell over all things when I taught that over them and through them no \u201ceternal will\u201d \u2013 wills.</p><p>This mischief and this folly I placed in place of that will when I taught: \u201cWith all things one thing is impossible \u2013 rationality!\u201d</p><p>A bit of reason to be sure, a seed of wisdom sprinkled from star to star \u2013 this sourdough is mixed into all things: for the sake of folly, wisdom is mixed into all things!</p><p>A bit of wisdom is indeed possible; but I found this blessed certainty in all things: that on the feet of accident they would rather \u2013 dance.</p><p>Oh sky above me, you pure, you exalted one! This your purity is to me now, that there is no eternal spider and spider web of reason:</p><p>\u2013 that you are my dance floor for divine accident, that you are my gods\u2019 table for divine dice throws and dice players! \u2013</p><p>But you blush? Did I speak the unspeakable? Did I blaspheme when I wanted to bless you?</p><p>Or is it the shame of us two that made you blush? \u2013 Do you command me to go and be silent because now \u2013 the day is coming?</p><p>The world is deep \u2013 and deeper than the day has ever grasped. Not everything may be permitted to speak before day. But the day is coming, and so let us part now!</p><p>Oh sky above me, you bashful, you glowing one! Oh you my happiness before sunrise! The day is coming, and so let us part now! \u2013</p><p>Thus spoke Zarathustra.</p>", "article_json": {"type": "doc", "content": [{"type": "heading", "attrs": {"level": 2}, "content": [{"text": "Before Sunrise", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "content": [{"text": "Oh sky above me, you pure, you deep one! You abyss of light! Gazing at you I shudder with godlike desires.\r\n\r\nTo hurl myself into your height \u2013 that is my depth! To hide myself in your purity \u2013 that is my innocence.\r\n\r\nThe god is veiled by his beauty; thus you conceal your stars. You do not speak; thus you make your wisdom known to me.\r\n\r\nMutely you rose for me today over the roaring sea, your love and your modesty speak revelation to my roaring soul.\r\n\r\nThat you came to me beautiful, veiled in your beauty; that you speak to me mutely, revealed in your wisdom \u2013\r\n\r\noh how could I not guess all that is modesty in your soul! Before the sun you came to me, the loneliest one.\r\n\r\nWe are friends from the beginning; we have grief and ghastliness and ground in common; even the sun we have in common.\r\n\r\nWe do not speak to one another because we know too much: we are silent to one another, we smile our knowledge to one another.\r\n\r\nAre you not the light to my fire? Do you not have the sister soul to my insight?\r\n\r\nTogether we learned everything; together we learned to climb up to ourselves by climbing over ourselves, and to smile cloudlessly:\r\n\r\n\u2013 smile down cloudlessly from bright eyes and from a distance of miles, when beneath us pressure and purpose and guilt steam like rain.\r\n\r\nAnd if I wandered alone \u2013 for whom did my soul thirst in nights and on wrong paths? And if I climbed mountains, whom did I ever seek if not you on mountains?\r\n\r\nAnd all my wandering and mountain climbing: they were only a necessity and a help to the helpless one \u2013 the only thing my will wants is to fly, to fly into you!\r\n\r\nAnd whom did I hate more than drifting clouds and everything that stains you? And I hated even my own hatred because it stained you!\r\n\r\nI grudge these drifting clouds, these creeping predator-cats; they take from you and me what we have in common \u2013 our awesome infinite saying of Yes and Amen.\r\n\r\nWe grudge these middle-men and mixers, these drifting clouds, these half-and-halfs who learned neither to bless, nor to curse whole heartedly.\r\n\r\nI would rather sit in a barrel under a closed sky, would rather sit in an abyss without sky than see you, sky of light, stained by drifting clouds!\r\n\r\nAnd often I wanted to tie them together with the jagged gold wires of lightning, and beat their kettle bellies like thunder \u2013\r\n\r\n\u2013 an angry kettle drummer because they rob me of your Yes! and Amen! \u2013 you sky above me, you pure, you bright one! You abyss of light! \u2013 Because they rob you of my Yes! and Amen!\r\n\r\nFor I would rather have din and thunder and stormy cursing than this deliberate, dubious cat calm; and even among humans the ones I hate most are the soft steppers and half-and-halfs and dubious, dawdling drift-clouds.\r\n\r\nAnd \u201cwhoever cannot bless, let him learn to curse!\u201d \u2013 this bright teaching fell to me from the bright sky, this star stands in my sky even in black nights.\r\n\r\nI am a blesser and a Yes-sayer if only you are around me, you pure, you bright one, you abyss of light! Did I blaspheme when I wanted to bless you?\r\n\r\nOr is it the shame of us two that made you blush? \u2013 Do you command me to go and be silent because now \u2013 the day is coming?\r\n\r\nThe world is deep \u2013 and deeper than the day has ever grasped.
