And once he saw a row of new houses, and he was amazed then and he said:</p><p>\u201cWhat do these houses mean? Truly, no great soul placed them here, as a parable of itself!</p><p>Probably some feeble-minded child took them out of its toy box? If only another child would put them back into its toy box!</p><p>And these parlors and chambers; can men go in and out here? To me they seem made for satin dolls, or for nibblers who probably let themselves be nibbled.\u201d</p><p>And Zarathustra stood still and reflected. At last he said sadly: \u201cEverything has become smaller!</p><p>Everywhere I see lower gateways; whoever is like me can still pass through, but \u2013 he has to stoop!</p><p>Oh when will I return to my homeland where I no longer have to stoop \u2013 no longer have to stoop before the small ones!\u201d \u2013 And Zarathustra sighed and gazed into the distance. \u2013</p><p>On the same day, however, he delivered his speech on virtue that makes small.</p><h3>2</h3><p>I walk among these people and keep my eyes open; they do not forgive me that I am not envious of their virtues.</p><p>They bite at me because I say to them: for small people small virtues are necessary \u2013 and because I find it hard to grasp that small people are necessary!</p><p>I still resemble the rooster here in a strange barnyard, whom even the hens bite; and yet I am not bad to the hens because of that.</p><p>I am courteous toward them as toward all small annoyances; to be prickly toward what is small strikes me as wisdom for porcupines.</p><p>They all talk about me when they sit around the fire evenings \u2013 they talk about me, but no one thinks \u2013 about me!</p><p>This is the new stillness that I learned: their noise concerning me spreads a cloak over my thoughts.</p><p>They make noise among themselves: \u201cWhat does this dark cloud want with us? Let\u2019s see to it that it does not bring us a plague!\u201d</p><p>And recently a woman snatched her child to herself, who wanted to come to me: \u201cTake the children away!\u201d she shouted. \u201cSuch eyes singe children\u2019s souls.\u201d</p><p>They cough when I speak, they think that coughing is an objection to strong wind \u2013 they guess nothing of the roaring of my happiness! \u201cWe still have no time for Zarathustra\u201d \u2013 thus they object; but what</p><p>does any time matter which \u201chas no time\u201d for Zarathustra? And even if they were to praise me, how could I fall asleep on their</p><p>praise? Their praise is a belt of thorns to me; it scratches me even when I take it off.</p><p>And this also I learned among them: the one who praises pretends that he is giving back, but in truth he wants to be given even more!</p><p>Ask my foot whether it likes their tune of praise and palaver! Indeed, to such a beat and tick-tock it wants neither to dance nor to stand still.</p><p>They want to palaver and praise me to their small virtue; they would like to persuade my foot to the tick-tock of their small happiness.</p><p>I walk among these people and keep my eyes open; they have become smaller and are becoming ever smaller: but this is because of their teaching on happiness and virtue.</p><p>For they are modest even in their virtue \u2013 because they want contentment. But only modest virtue goes along with contentment.</p><p>Even they, of course, learn to stride and to stride forward in their way \u2013 this is what I call their hobbling. This way they become an obstacle to anyone who is in a hurry.</p><p>And some of them look backward stiff-necked while walking forward; these I like to run into.</p><p>Foot and eye should not lie, nor rub each other\u2019s faces in their lies. But there is much lying among the small people.</p><p>A few of them will, but most of them are merely willed. A few of them are genuine, but most of them are bad actors.</p><p>There are unknowing actors among them and unwilling actors among them \u2013 the genuine are always rare, especially the genuine actors.</p><p>There is little here of the man, therefore their women masculinize themselves. For only he who is man enough will redeem the woman in woman.</p><p>And this hypocrisy I found to be the worst among them; that even those who command feign the virtues of those who serve.</p><p>\u201cI serve, you serve, we serve\u201d \u2013 this is how even the hypocrisy of the rulers prays here \u2013 and watch out if the first lord is only the first servant!</p><p>Oh, into their hypocrisies too the curiosity of my eyes flew astray, and well did I guess all their fly-happiness and their buzzing around sunny windowpanes.</p><p>So much kindness, so much weakness I see. So much justice and pity, so much weakness.</p><p>Round, righteous and kind they are to one another, like grains of sand are round, righteous and kind to one another.</p><p>To modestly embrace a small happiness \u2013 that they call \u201cresignation\u201d and already they are squinting around modestly for a new small happiness.</p><p>At bottom these simple ones want one simple thing: that no one harm them. And so they beat everyone to it by doing them a good deed.</p><p>But this is cowardice, even if it is called \u201cvirtue.\u201d \u2013</p><p>And if they ever speak gruffly, these small people, I hear only their hoarseness \u2013 for every puff of wind makes them hoarse.</p><p>They are clever, and their virtues have clever fingers. But they lack fists; their fingers do not know how to form into fists.</p><p>To them virtue is whatever makes modest and tame; this is how they made the wolf into a dog and mankind himself into mankind\u2019s favorite pet.</p><p>\u201cWe place our chair in the middle\u201d \u2013 that is what their grinning says to me \u2013 \u201cand just as far away from dying fighters as from contented sows.\u201d</p><p>But this is \u2013 mediocrity: even if it is called moderation. \u2013</p><h3>3</h3><p>I walk among these people and let many a word fall, but they know neither to take nor to keep.</p><p>They are amazed that I did not come to lambast lusting and malignancy, and truly, nor did I come to warn of pick-pockets!</p><p>They are amazed that I am not prepared to make their cleverness wittier and prettier, as if they did not have enough cleverlings already, whose voices scrape me like chalk on slate!</p><p>And when I shout: \u201cA curse on all cowardly devils in you, who like to whine and fold their hands and worship,\u201d then they shout: \u201cZarathustra is godless.\u201d</p><p>And especially their teachers of resignation shout it \u2013 but they are precisely the ones into whose ears I like to shout: \u201cYes! I am Zarathustra, the godless one!\u201d</p><p>These teachers of resignation! Wherever there is pettiness and sickness and scabs, they crawl to it like lice; and only my disgust prevents me from cracking them.</p><p>Well then! This is my sermon for their ears: I am Zarathustra, the godless, who says: \u201cWho is more godless than I, so that I can enjoy his instruction?\u201d</p><p>I am Zarathustra, the godless: where do I find my equal? And all those are my equal who give themselves their own will and put aside all resig- nation.</p><p>I am Zarathustra, the godless: I still cook every chance in my pot. And only when it has been well cooked in there do I welcome it as my food.</p><p>And truly, many a chance came to me imperiously, but my will spoke to it even more imperiously \u2013 and already it lay begging on its knees \u2013</p><p>\u2013 begging me for protection and affection and addressing me with flattery: \u201cLook, oh Zarathustra, it\u2019s only a friend coming to a friend!\u201d \u2013</p><p>But why do I speak where no one has my ears! And so I want to shout it out to the four winds:</p><p>You are becoming smaller and smaller, you small people! You are crumbling, you contented ones! You will yet perish \u2013</p><p>\u2013 of your many small virtues, of your many small abstentions, of your many small resignations!</p><p>Too sparing, too yielding \u2013 that is your soil! But in order for a tree to grow tall, it needs to put down hard roots amid hard rock!</p><p>And even what you abstain from weaves at the web of all future humanity; even your nothing is a spider web and a spider that lives off the blood of the future.</p><p>And when you take, it\u2019s like stealing, you small-virtued ones; and even among rogues honor says: \u201cOne should only steal where one can not rob.\u201d</p><p>\u201cIt will give\u201d \u2013 that too is a teaching of resignation. But I say to you contented people: it will take and it will take more and more from you!</p><p>Oh if only you would put aside all half willing and become as resolute in your sloth as in your deeds!</p><p>Oh if only you understood my words: \u201cGo ahead and do whatever you will \u2013 but first be the kind of people who can will!</p><p>Go ahead and love your neighbors as you love yourselves \u2013 but first be the kind of people who love themselves \u2013</p><p>love with the great love, love with the great contempt!\u201d Thus speaks Zarathustra the godless. \u2013</p><p>But why do I speak where no one has my ears! Here it is still one hour too early for me.</p><p>I am my own forerunner among these people, my own cock-crow through dark lanes.</p><p>But their hour is coming! And mine will come too! By the hour they become smaller, poorer, more sterile \u2013 poor weeds! Poor soil!</p><p>And soon they shall stand there before me like parched grass and steppe, and truly, weary of themselves \u2013 and yearning for fire more than for water!</p><p>Oh blessed hour of lightning! Oh secret before noon! \u2013 Wild fires I want to make of them some day and heralds with tongues of fire \u2013</p><p>\u2013 some day they shall proclaim with tongues of fire: It is coming, it is near, the great noon!</p><p>Thus spoke Zarathustra.</p>", "article_json": {"type": "doc", "content": [{"type": "heading", "attrs": {"level": 2}, "content": [{"text": "On Virtue that Makes Small", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "heading", "attrs": {"level": 3}, "content": [{"text": "1", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "content": [{"text": "When Zarathustra was on dry land again he did not go directly to his mountains and his cave, but instead took many ways and asked many questions and found out about this and that, saying of himself jokingly: \u201cLook at the river that flows back to its source in many windings!\u201d For he wanted to learn what had transpired in the meantime among human beings; whether they had become bigger or smaller. And once he saw a row of new houses, and he was amazed then and he said:\r\n\r\n\u201cWhat do these houses mean? Truly, no great soul placed them here, as a parable of itself!\r\n\r\nProbably some feeble-minded child took them out of its toy box? If only another child would put them back into its toy box!\r\n\r\nAnd these parlors and chambers; can men go in and out here? To me they seem made for satin dolls, or for nibblers who probably let themselves be nibbled.\u201d\r\n\r\nAnd Zarathustra stood still and reflected. At last he said sadly: \u201cEverything has become smaller!\r\n\r\nEverywhere I see lower gateways; whoever is like me can still pass through, but \u2013 he has to stoop!\r\n\r\nOh when will I return to my homeland where I no longer have to stoop \u2013 no longer have to stoop before the small ones!\u201d \u2013 And Zarathustra sighed and gazed into the distance. \u2013\r\n\r\nOn the same day, however, he delivered his speech on virtue that makes small.\r\n\r\n2\r\n\r\nI walk among these people and keep my eyes open; they do not forgive me that I am not envious of their virtues.\r\n\r\nThey bite at me because I say to them: for small people small virtues are necessary \u2013 and because I find it hard to grasp that small people are necessary!\r\n\r\nI still resemble the rooster here in a strange barnyard, whom even the hens bite; and yet I am not bad to the hens because of that.\r\n\r\nI am courteous toward them as toward all small annoyances; to be prickly toward what is small strikes me as wisdom for porcupines.\r\n\r\nThey all talk about me when they sit around the fire evenings \u2013 they talk about me, but no one thinks \u2013 about me!\r\n\r\nThis is the new stillness that I learned: their noise concerning me spreads a cloak over my thoughts.\r\n\r\nThey make noise among themselves: \u201cWhat does this dark cloud want with us? Let\u2019s see to it that it does not bring us a plague!\u201d\r\n\r\nAnd recently a woman snatched her child to herself, who wanted to come to me: \u201cTake the children away!\u201d she shouted. \u201cSuch eyes singe children\u2019s souls.\u201d\r\n\r\nThey cough when I speak, they think that coughing is an objection to strong wind \u2013 they guess nothing of the roaring of my happiness! \u201cWe still have no time for Zarathustra\u201d \u2013 thus they object; but what\r\n\r\ndoes any time matter which \u201chas no time\u201d for Zarathustra? And even if they were to praise me, how could I fall asleep on their\r\n\r\npraise? Their praise is a belt of thorns to me; it scratches me even when I take it off.\r\n\r\nAnd this also I learned among them: the one who praises pretends that he is giving back, but in truth he wants to be given even more!\r\n\r\nAsk my foot whether it likes their tune of praise and palaver! Indeed, to such a beat and tick-tock it wants neither to dance nor to stand still.\r\n\r\nThey want to palaver and praise me to their small virtue; they would like to persuade my foot to the tick-tock of their small happiness.\r\n\r\nI walk among these people and keep my eyes open; they have become smaller and are becoming ever smaller: but this is because of their teaching on happiness and virtue.\r\n\r\nFor they are modest even in their virtue \u2013 because they want contentment. But only modest virtue goes along with contentment.\r\n\r\nEven they, of course, learn to stride and to stride forward in their way \u2013 this is what I call their hobbling. This way they become an obstacle to anyone who is in a hurry.\r\n\r\nAnd some of them look backward stiff-necked while walking forward; these I like to run into.\r\n\r\nFoot and eye should not lie, nor rub each other\u2019s faces in their lies. But there is much lying among the small people.\r\n\r\nA few of them will, but most of them are merely willed. A few of them are genuine, but most of them are bad actors.\r\n\r\nThere are unknowing actors among them and unwilling actors among them \u2013 the genuine are always rare, especially the genuine actors.\r\n\r\nThere is little here of the man, therefore their women masculinize themselves. For only he who is man enough will redeem the woman in woman.\r\n\r\nAnd this hypocrisy I found to be the worst among them; that even those who command feign the virtues of those who serve.\r\n\r\n\u201cI serve, you serve, we serve\u201d \u2013 this is how even the hypocrisy of the rulers prays here \u2013 and watch out if the first lord is only the first servant!\r\n\r\nOh, into their hypocrisies too the curiosity of my eyes flew astray, and well did I guess all their fly-happiness and their buzzing around sunny windowpanes.\r\n\r\nSo much kindness, so much weakness I see. So much justice and pity, so much weakness.\r\n\r\nRound, righteous and kind they are to one another, like grains of sand are round, righteous and kind to one another.\r\n\r\nTo modestly embrace a small happiness \u2013 that they call \u201cresignation\u201d and already they are squinting around modestly for a new small happiness.\r\n\r\nAt bottom these simple ones want one simple thing: that no one harm them. And so they beat everyone to it by doing them a good deed.\r\n\r\nBut this is cowardice, even if it is called \u201cvirtue.\u201d \u2013\r\n\r\nAnd if they ever speak gruffly, these small people, I hear only their hoarseness \u2013 for every puff of wind makes them hoarse.\r\n\r\nThey are clever, and their virtues have clever fingers. But they lack fists; their fingers do not know how to form into fists.\r\n\r\nTo them virtue is whatever makes modest and tame; this is how they made the wolf into a dog and mankind himself into mankind\u2019s favorite pet.\r\n\r\n\u201cWe place our chair in the middle\u201d \u2013 that is what their grinning says to me \u2013 \u201cand just as far away from dying fighters as from contented sows.\u201d\r\n\r\nBut this is \u2013 mediocrity: even if it is called moderation. \u2013\r\n\r\n3\r\n\r\nI walk among these people and let many a word fall, but they know neither to take nor to keep.\r\n\r\nThey are amazed that I did not come to lambast lusting and malignancy, and truly, nor did I come to warn of pick-pockets!\r\n\r\nThey are amazed that I am not prepared to make their cleverness wittier and prettier, as if they did not have enough cleverlings already, whose voices scrape me like chalk on slate!\r\n\r\nAnd when I shout: \u201cA curse on all cowardly devils in you, who like to whine and fold their hands and worship,\u201d then they shout: \u201cZarathustra is godless.\u201d\r\n\r\nAnd especially their teachers of resignation shout it \u2013 but they are precisely the ones into whose ears I like to shout: \u201cYes! I am Zarathustra, the godless one!\u201d\r\n\r\nThese teachers of resignation! Wherever there is pettiness and sickness and scabs, they crawl to it like lice; and only my disgust prevents me from cracking them.\r\n\r\nWell then! This is my sermon for their ears: I am Zarathustra, the godless, who says: \u201cWho is more godless than I, so that I can enjoy his instruction?\u201d\r\n\r\nI am Zarathustra, the godless: where do I find my equal? And all those are my equal who give themselves their own will and put aside all resig- nation.\r\n\r\nI am Zarathustra, the godless: I still cook every chance in my pot. And only when it has been well cooked in there do I welcome it as my food.\r\n\r\nAnd truly, many a chance came to me imperiously, but my will spoke to it even more imperiously \u2013 and already it lay begging on its knees \u2013\r\n\r\n\u2013 begging me for protection and affection and addressing me with flattery: \u201cLook, oh Zarathustra, it\u2019s only a friend coming to a friend!\u201d \u2013\r\n\r\nBut why do I speak where no one has my ears! And so I want to shout it out to the four winds:\r\n\r\nYou are becoming smaller and smaller, you small people! You are crumbling, you contented ones! You will yet perish \u2013\r\n\r\n\u2013 of your many small virtues, of your many small abstentions, of your many small resignations!\r\n\r\nToo sparing, too yielding \u2013 that is your soil! But in order for a tree to grow tall, it needs to put down hard roots amid hard rock!\r\n\r\nAnd even what you abstain from weaves at the web of all future humanity; even your nothing is a spider web and a spider that lives off the blood of the future.\r\n\r\nAnd when you take, it\u2019s like stealing, you small-virtued ones; and even among rogues honor says: \u201cOne should only steal where one can not rob.\u201d\r\n\r\n\u201cIt will give\u201d \u2013 that too is a teaching of resignation. But I say to you contented people: it will take and it will take more and more from you!\r\n\r\nOh if only you would put aside all half willing and become as resolute in your sloth as in your deeds!\r\n\r\nOh if only you understood my words: \u201cGo ahead and do whatever you will \u2013 but first be the kind of people who can will!\r\n\r\nGo ahead and love your neighbors as you love yourselves \u2013 but first be the kind of people who love themselves \u2013\r\n\r\nlove with the great love, love with the great contempt!\u201d Thus speaks Zarathustra the godless. \u2013\r\n\r\nBut why do I speak where no one has my ears! Here it is still one hour too early for me.\r\n\r\nI am my own forerunner among these people, my own cock-crow through dark lanes.\r\n\r\nBut their hour is coming! And mine will come too! By the hour they become smaller, poorer, more sterile \u2013 poor weeds! Poor soil!\r\n\r\nAnd soon they shall stand there before me like parched grass and steppe, and truly, weary of themselves \u2013 and yearning for fire more than for water!\r\n\r\nOh blessed hour of lightning! Oh secret before noon! \u2013 Wild fires I want to make of them some day and heralds with tongues of fire \u2013\r\n\r\n\u2013 some day they shall proclaim with tongues of fire: It is coming, it is near, the great noon!\r\n\r\nThus spoke Zarathustra."}, "id": 66}, {"data": {"uuid": "9fa4382f-791c-44bf-b95b-f6bbaed47c51", "user": 1, "title": "On the Mount of Olives", "created_on": "2023-05-10 15:50:18.569405+00:00", "updated_on": "2023-05-10 15:50:18.590200+00:00", "article_html": "<h2>On the Mount of Olives</h2><p>The winter, a wicked guest, sits in my house; my hands are blue from his friendly handshake.</p><p>I honor him, this wicked guest, but I gladly let him sit alone. Gladly I run away from him, and if one runs well, then one can escape him!</p><p>With warm feet and warm thoughts I run to where the wind is calm \u2013 to the sunny spot of my mount of olives.</p><p>There I laugh at my fierce guest and still think well of him for catching the flies in my house and silencing much small noise.</p><p>For he does not tolerate it when a mosquito or two wants to sing; he also makes the lane so lonely that the moonlight is afraid in it at night.</p><p>A hard guest is he \u2013 but I honor him, and I do not pray to the pot-bellied fire idol like the weaklings.</p><p>Rather a bit of teeth chattering than worshiping idols \u2013 that is how my kind wants it! And I especially grudge all horny, steamy, musty fire idols.</p><p>Whomever I love, I love better in winter than in summer; better and more heartily I now mock my enemies since winter sits at home with me.</p><p>Heartily indeed, even when I crawl to bed \u2013 then even my hiding happiness laughs and makes mischief; even my lying dream laughs.</p><p>I, a crawler? Never in my life have I crawled before the mighty; and if I ever lied, then I lied out of love. That is why I am cheerful even in my winter bed.</p><p>A meager bed warms me more than a rich one, for I am jealous of my poverty, and in winter it is most faithful to me.</p><p>Each day I begin with a malice; I mock winter with a cold bath \u2013 that makes my fierce house guest growl.</p><p>I also like to tickle him with a little wax candle, so that finally he will release the sky from ashen grey twilight.</p><p>In the morning I am especially malicious, in the early hour when the pail clatters at the well and the horses whinny warmly through grey lanes:</p><p>Impatiently I wait for the bright sky to open at last, the snow-bearded winter sky, the old man and white-head \u2013</p><p>\u2013 the winter sky, the silent one who often keeps even his sun silent!</p><p>Did I learn my long bright silence from him? Or did he learn it from me? Or did each of us invent it on his own?</p><p>The origin of all good things is thousandfold \u2013 all good mischievous things leap for joy into existence: so how are they supposed to do this \u2013 only once?</p><p>Long silence too is a good mischievous thing, and looking out of a round-eyed face like the winter sky \u2013</p><p>\u2013 to be silent like the winter sky about one\u2019s sun and one\u2019s uncompromising solar will: indeed, this art and this winter mischief I learned well!</p><p>My favorite malice and art is that my silence learned not to betray itself through silence.</p><p>Rattling with diction and dice I outwit the solemn waiting ones; my will and purpose shall elude all these fierce watchers.</p><p>To prevent anyone from looking down into my ground and ultimate will, I invented my long bright silence.</p><p>Many a clever one I found, who veiled his face and muddied his water so that no one could see through him and down into him.</p><p>But precisely to him came the more clever mistrustful ones and nut crackers; precisely his most hidden fish they fished out of him!</p><p>But to me the bright, courageous, transparent ones are the most clever of those who keep silent; those whose ground is so deep that even the brightest water does not \u2013 betray it.</p><p>You snow-bearded silent winter sky, you round-eyed white-head above me! Oh you heavenly parable of my soul and its mischief!</p><p>And must I not conceal myself like someone who has swallowed gold \u2013 so that they do not slit open my soul?</p><p>Must I not wear stilts so that they overlook my long legs \u2013 all these plain jealous and pain zealous who surround me?</p><p>These smoky, room-temperature, used up, greened-out, grief ridden souls \u2013 how could their envy bear my happiness!</p><p>And so I show them only the ice and the winter on my peaks \u2013 and not that my mountain winds all the belts of the sun around itself!</p><p>They hear only my winter storms whistling, and not that I also glide over warm seas like longing, heavy, sultry south winds.</p><p>They still have mercy on my accidents and coincidences: but my words say: \u201cLet accident come to me: it is innocent, like a little child!\u201d</p><p>How could they bear my happiness if I did not cover my happiness with accidents and winter emergencies and polar bear caps and snow-sky sheets?</p><p>\u2013 If I myself didn\u2019t have mercy on their pity: the pity of these who are plain jealous and pain zealous!</p><p>\u2013 If I myself didn\u2019t sigh before them, teeth chattering, and patiently allow myself to be wrapped in their pity!</p><p>It is the wise mischief and benevolence of my soul that it does not conceal its winter and its ice storms; nor does it conceal its frostbites.</p><p>One person\u2019s loneliness is the escape of the sick; another\u2019s loneliness is the escape from the sick.</p><p>Let them hear me chatter and sigh from winter cold, all these wretched, leering rascals around me! With such sighing and chattering I still escape their heated rooms.</p><p>Let them sympathize and sympasigh about my frostbite: \u201cHe will freeze yet from the ice of knowledge!\u201d \u2013 so they lament.</p><p>Meanwhile I run with warm feet crisscross on my mount of olives; in the sunny spot of my mount of olives I sing and mock all pitying. \u2013</p>", "article_json": {"type": "doc", "content": [{"type": "heading", "attrs": {"level": 2}, "content": [{"text": "On the Mount of Olives", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "content": [{"text": "The winter, a wicked guest, sits in my house; my hands are blue from his friendly handshake.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "content": [{"text": "I honor him, this wicked guest, but I gladly let him sit alone. Gladly I run away from him, and if one runs well, then one can escape him!\r\n\r\nWith warm feet and warm thoughts I run to where the wind is calm \u2013 to the sunny spot of my mount of olives.\r\n\r\nThere I laugh at my fierce guest and still think well of him for catching the flies in my house and silencing much small noise.\r\n\r\nFor he does not tolerate it when a mosquito or two wants to sing; he also makes the lane so lonely that the moonlight is afraid in it at night.\r\n\r\nA hard guest is he \u2013 but I honor him, and I do not pray to the pot-bellied fire idol like the weaklings.\r\n\r\nRather a bit of teeth chattering than worshiping idols \u2013 that is how my kind wants it! And I especially grudge all horny, steamy, musty fire idols.\r\n\r\nWhomever I love, I love better in winter than in summer; better and more heartily I now mock my enemies since winter sits at home with me.\r\n\r\nHeartily indeed, even when I crawl to bed \u2013 then even my hiding happiness laughs and makes mischief; even my lying dream laughs.\r\n\r\nI, a crawler? Never in my life have I crawled before the mighty; and if I ever lied, then I lied out of love. That is why I am cheerful even in my winter bed.\r\n\r\nA meager bed warms me more than a rich one, for I am jealous of my poverty, and in winter it is most faithful to me.\r\n\r\nEach day I begin with a malice; I mock winter with a cold bath \u2013 that makes my fierce house guest growl.\r\n\r\nI also like to tickle him with a little wax candle, so that finally he will release the sky from ashen grey twilight.\r\n\r\nIn the morning I am especially malicious, in the early hour when the pail clatters at the well and the horses whinny warmly through grey lanes:\r\n\r\nImpatiently I wait for the bright sky to open at last, the snow-bearded winter sky, the old man and white-head \u2013\r\n\r\n\u2013 the winter sky, the silent one who often keeps even his sun silent!\r\n\r\nDid I learn my long bright silence from him? Or did he learn it from me? Or did each of us invent it on his own?\r\n\r\nThe origin of all good things is thousandfold \u2013 all good mischievous things leap for joy into existence: so how are they supposed to do this \u2013 only once?\r\n\r\nLong silence too is a good mischievous thing, and looking out of a round-eyed face like the winter sky \u2013\r\n\r\n\u2013 to be silent like the winter sky about one\u2019s sun and one\u2019s uncompromising solar will: indeed, this art and this winter mischief I learned well!\r\n\r\nMy favorite malice and art is that my silence learned not to betray itself through silence.\r\n\r\nRattling with diction and dice I outwit the solemn waiting ones; my will and purpose shall elude all these fierce watchers.\r\n\r\nTo prevent anyone from looking down into my ground and ultimate will, I invented my long bright silence.\r\n\r\nMany a clever one I found, who veiled his face and muddied his water so that no one could see through him and down into him.\r\n\r\nBut precisely to him came the more clever mistrustful ones and nut crackers; precisely his most hidden fish they fished out of him!\r\n\r\nBut to me the bright, courageous, transparent ones are the most clever of those who keep silent; those whose ground is so deep that even the brightest water does not \u2013 betray it.\r\n\r\nYou snow-bearded silent winter sky, you round-eyed white-head above me! Oh you heavenly parable of my soul and its mischief!\r\n\r\nAnd must I not conceal myself like someone who has swallowed gold \u2013 so that they do not slit open my soul?\r\n\r\nMust I not wear stilts so that they overlook my long legs \u2013 all these plain jealous and pain zealous who surround me?\r\n\r\nThese smoky, room-temperature, used up, greened-out, grief ridden souls \u2013 how could their envy bear my happiness!\r\n\r\nAnd so I show them only the ice and the winter on my peaks \u2013 and not that my mountain winds all the belts of the sun around itself!\r\n\r\nThey hear only my winter storms whistling, and not that I also glide over warm seas like longing, heavy, sultry south winds.\r\n\r\nThey still have mercy on my accidents and coincidences: but my words say: \u201cLet accident come to me: it is innocent, like a little child!\u201d\r\n\r\nHow could they bear my happiness if I did not cover my happiness with accidents and winter emergencies and polar bear caps and snow-sky sheets?\r\n\r\n\u2013 If I myself didn\u2019t have mercy on their pity: the pity of these who are plain jealous and pain zealous!\r\n\r\n\u2013 If I myself didn\u2019t sigh before them, teeth chattering, and patiently allow myself to be wrapped in their pity!\r\n\r\nIt is the wise mischief and benevolence of my soul that it does not conceal its winter and its ice storms; nor does it conceal its frostbites.\r\n\r\nOne person\u2019s loneliness is the escape of the sick; another\u2019s loneliness is the escape from the sick.\r\n\r\nLet them hear me chatter and sigh from winter cold, all these wretched, leering rascals around me! With such sighing and chattering I still escape their heated rooms.\r\n\r\nLet them sympathize and sympasigh about my frostbite: \u201cHe will freeze yet from the ice of knowledge!\u201d \u2013 so they lament.\r\n\r\nMeanwhile I run with warm feet crisscross on my mount of olives; in the sunny spot of my mount of olives I sing and mock all pitying. \u2013"}, "id": 67}, {"data": {"uuid": "642a347f-c2d3-4d68-8b8f-ff46b6d0b7b7", "user": 1, "title": "On Passing By", "created_on": "2023-05-10 15:51:10.804288+00:00", "updated_on": "2023-05-10 15:51:10.819711+00:00", "article_html": "<h2>On Passing By</h2><p>In this manner, hiking slowly through many peoples and towns, Zarathustra returned the long way to his mountains and his cave. And then, unexpectedly, he also arrived at the gate of the big city. Here, however, a foaming fool with outstretched hands leaped toward him and blocked his path. And this was the same fool whom the people called \u201cZarathustra\u2019s ape,\u201d because he had memorized some of the phrasing and tone of Zarathustra\u2019s speaking and also liked to borrow from the treasure of his wisdom. The fool spoke thus to Zarathustra:</p><p>\u201cOh Zarathustra, this is the big city: here you have nothing to gain and everything to lose.</p><p>Why do you want to wade through this mud? Have pity on your feet! Spit on the city gate instead and \u2013 turn around!</p><p>Here is hell for hermit\u2019s thoughts; here great thoughts are boiled alive and cooked till they are small.</p><p>Here all great feelings rot; here only tiny, rattlebone feelings are allowed to rattle!</p><p>Do you not already smell the slaughter houses and kitchens of the spirit? Does this town not steam with the reek of slaughtered spirit?</p><p>Do you not see the souls hanging like limp dirty rags? \u2013 And they even make newspapers out of these rags!</p><p>Do you not hear how the spirit here turned into wordplay? It vomits dirty dish-word water! \u2013 And they even make newspapers out of this dirty dish-word water.</p><p>They hurry each other and know not where to. They heat each other up and know not why. They jingle with their tin, they jangle with their gold.</p><p>They are cold and they seek warmth in distilled liquors; they are over- heated and seek coolness in frozen spirits; they are all sick and addicted to public opinion.</p><p>All lusting and malignancy are at home here; but here there are also virtuous types, there is much effective and affected virtue: \u2013</p><p>Much effective virtue with scribble fingers and hard sit-and-wait flesh, blessed with little stars on their chests and padded fannyless daughters.</p><p>There is also much piety here and much devout spittle lick quaking and flatter cake baking before the God of Hosts.</p><p>\u2018From on high\u2019 the star trickles down, and the merciful spittle; every starless chest meanwhile longs to get up high.</p><p>The moon has its farm, and the farm has its mooncalves; but the beggarly people and all effective beggarly virtue pray to everything that comes from the farm.</p><p>\u2018I serve, you serve, we serve\u2019 \u2013 so begs all effective virtue to the prince, hoping that the deserved star will finally cling to the narrow chest!</p><p>But the moon still revolves around all that is earthly, and the prince too still revolves around what is most earthly \u2013 and that is the gold of the shopkeepers.</p><p>The God of Hosts is no God of gold bars; the prince proposes, but the shopkeeper \u2013 disposes!</p><p>By all that is bright and strong and good in you, oh Zarathustra, spit on this city of the shopkeepers and turn around!</p><p>Here all blood flows tainted and tepid and frothy decrepit through all veins; spit on the big city which is the big scum trap where all spumy crap spumes together!</p><p>Spit on this city of broken down souls and narrow chests, of prying eyes, of sticky fingers \u2013</p><p>\u2013 on this city of the obtrusive, the insolent, the pencil- and roughnecks, the overheated and ambition eaten:</p><p>\u2013 where everything that is crumbly, corrupted, lusty, dusky, overly mushy and pussy festers together confederately: \u2013</p><p>\u2013 spit on the big city and turn around!\u201d \u2013</p><p>At this point, however, Zarathustra interrupted the foaming fool and clapped his hand over the fool\u2019s mouth.</p><p>\u201cStop at last!\u201d cried Zarathustra. \u201cYour speech and your ways have nauseated me for a long time already!</p><p>Why have you lived so long near the swamp, that you yourself had to turn into a frog and a toad?</p><p>Doesn\u2019t tainted and frothy, decrepit swamp blood flow in your own veins now, since you have learned to croak and lambast this way?</p><p>Why didn\u2019t you go into the woods? Or plow the earth? Isn\u2019t the sea full of green islands?</p><p>I despise your despising; and if you warned me \u2013 why didn\u2019t you warn yourself?</p><p>Out of love alone shall my despising and my warning bird fly up: but not out of the swamp! \u2013</p><p>They call you my ape, you foaming fool; but I call you my grunting swine \u2013 by grunting you will yet spoil my praise of folly.</p><p>What was it after all that made you start grunting? That no one flattered you enough \u2013 so you sat down to this garbage in order to have reason to grunt a lot \u2013</p><p>\u2013 in order to have reason for a lot of revenge! Indeed, all your foaming is revenge, you vain fool; I guessed you well!</p><p>But your fool\u2019s words injure me, even where you are right! And if Zarathustra\u2019s words were right even a hundred times: you would always do wrong with my words!\u201d</p><p>Thus spoke Zarathustra, and he looked at the big city, sighed, and kept silent for a long time. Finally he spoke thus:</p><p>\u201cI am nauseated too by this big city and not only by this fool. Here as there nothing can be bettered, nothing can be worsened.</p><p>Woe to this big city! \u2013 And I wish I already saw the pillar of fire in which it will burn!</p><p>For such pillars of fire must precede the great noon. But this has its own time and its own destiny. \u2013</p><p>Meanwhile, you fool, I give you this lesson in parting: where one can no longer love, there one should \u2013 pass by!\u201d \u2013</p><p>Thus spoke Zarathustra and he passed by the fool and the big city.</p>", "article_json": {"type": "doc", "content": [{"type": "heading", "attrs": {"level": 2}, "content": [{"text": "On Passing By", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "content": [{"text": "In this manner, hiking slowly through many peoples and towns, Zarathustra returned the long way to his mountains and his cave. And then, unexpectedly, he also arrived at the gate of the big city. Here, however, a foaming fool with outstretched hands leaped toward him and blocked his path. And this was the same fool whom the people called \u201cZarathustra\u2019s ape,\u201d because he had memorized some of the phrasing and tone of Zarathustra\u2019s speaking and also liked to borrow from the treasure of his wisdom. The fool spoke thus to Zarathustra:\r\n\r\n\u201cOh Zarathustra, this is the big city: here you have nothing to gain and everything to lose.\r\n\r\nWhy do you want to wade through this mud? Have pity on your feet! Spit on the city gate instead and \u2013 turn around!\r\n\r\nHere is hell for hermit\u2019s thoughts; here great thoughts are boiled alive and cooked till they are small.\r\n\r\nHere all great feelings rot; here only tiny, rattlebone feelings are allowed to rattle!\r\n\r\nDo you not already smell the slaughter houses and kitchens of the spirit? Does this town not steam with the reek of slaughtered spirit?\r\n\r\nDo you not see the souls hanging like limp dirty rags? \u2013 And they even make newspapers out of these rags!\r\n\r\nDo you not hear how the spirit here turned into wordplay? It vomits dirty dish-word water! \u2013 And they even make newspapers out of this dirty dish-word water.\r\n\r\nThey hurry each other and know not where to. They heat each other up and know not why. They jingle with their tin, they jangle with their gold.\r\n\r\nThey are cold and they seek warmth in distilled liquors; they are over- heated and seek coolness in frozen spirits; they are all sick and addicted to public opinion.\r\n\r\nAll lusting and malignancy are at home here; but here there are also virtuous types, there is much effective and affected virtue: \u2013\r\n\r\nMuch effective virtue with scribble fingers and hard sit-and-wait flesh, blessed with little stars on their chests and padded fannyless daughters.\r\n\r\nThere is also much piety here and much devout spittle lick quaking and flatter cake baking before the God of Hosts.\r\n\r\n\u2018From on high\u2019 the star trickles down, and the merciful spittle; every starless chest meanwhile longs to get up high.\r\n\r\nThe moon has its farm, and the farm has its mooncalves; but the beggarly people and all effective beggarly virtue pray to everything that comes from the farm.\r\n\r\n\u2018I serve, you serve, we serve\u2019 \u2013 so begs all effective virtue to the prince, hoping that the deserved star will finally cling to the narrow chest!\r\n\r\nBut the moon still revolves around all that is earthly, and the prince too still revolves around what is most earthly \u2013 and that is the gold of the shopkeepers.\r\n\r\nThe God of Hosts is no God of gold bars; the prince proposes, but the shopkeeper \u2013 disposes!\r\n\r\nBy all that is bright and strong and good in you, oh Zarathustra, spit on this city of the shopkeepers and turn around!\r\n\r\nHere all blood flows tainted and tepid and frothy decrepit through all veins; spit on the big city which is the big scum trap where all spumy crap spumes together!\r\n\r\nSpit on this city of broken down souls and narrow chests, of prying eyes, of sticky fingers \u2013\r\n\r\n\u2013 on this city of the obtrusive, the insolent, the pencil- and roughnecks, the overheated and ambition eaten:\r\n\r\n\u2013 where everything that is crumbly, corrupted, lusty, dusky, overly mushy and pussy festers together confederately: \u2013\r\n\r\n\u2013 spit on the big city and turn around!\u201d \u2013\r\n\r\nAt this point, however, Zarathustra interrupted the foaming fool and clapped his hand over the fool\u2019s mouth.\r\n\r\n\u201cStop at last!\u201d cried Zarathustra. \u201cYour speech and your ways have nauseated me for a long time already!\r\n\r\nWhy have you lived so long near the swamp, that you yourself had to turn into a frog and a toad?\r\n\r\nDoesn\u2019t tainted and frothy, decrepit swamp blood flow in your own veins now, since you have learned to croak and lambast this way?\r\n\r\nWhy didn\u2019t you go into the woods? Or plow the earth? Isn\u2019t the sea full of green islands?\r\n\r\nI despise your despising; and if you warned me \u2013 why didn\u2019t you warn yourself?\r\n\r\nOut of love alone shall my despising and my warning bird fly up: but not out of the swamp! \u2013\r\n\r\nThey call you my ape, you foaming fool; but I call you my grunting swine \u2013 by grunting you will yet spoil my praise of folly.\r\n\r\nWhat was it after all that made you start grunting? That no one flattered you enough \u2013 so you sat down to this garbage in order to have reason to grunt a lot \u2013\r\n\r\n\u2013 in order to have reason for a lot of revenge! Indeed, all your foaming is revenge, you vain fool; I guessed you well!\r\n\r\nBut your fool\u2019s words injure me, even where you are right! And if Zarathustra\u2019s words were right even a hundred times: you would always do wrong with my words!\u201d\r\n\r\nThus spoke Zarathustra, and he looked at the big city, sighed, and kept silent for a long time. Finally he spoke thus:\r\n\r\n\u201cI am nauseated too by this big city and not only by this fool. Here as there nothing can be bettered, nothing can be worsened.\r\n\r\nWoe to this big city! \u2013 And I wish I already saw the pillar of fire in which it will burn!\r\n\r\nFor such pillars of fire must precede the great noon. But this has its own time and its own destiny. \u2013\r\n\r\nMeanwhile, you fool, I give you this lesson in parting: where one can no longer love, there one should \u2013 pass by!\u201d \u2013\r\n\r\nThus spoke Zarathustra and he passed by the fool and the big city."}, "id": 68}, {"data": {"uuid": "3a8425ff-8c91-4a8c-83a5-8ad185da65a9", "user": 1, "title": "On Apostates", "created_on": "2023-05-10 15:51:56.489739+00:00", "updated_on": "2023-05-10 15:51:56.513414+00:00", "article_html": "<h2>On Apostates</h2><h3>1</h3><p>Alas, does everything lie wilted and grey that only recently stood green and colorful in this meadow? And how much honey of hope I carried from here to my beehives!</p><p>All these young hearts have already grown old \u2013 and not even old! Only weary, common, comfortable \u2013 as they put it: \u201cWe have become pious again.\u201d</p><p>Just recently I saw them set out by early morning on brave feet, but their feet of knowledge grew weary, and now they slander even their braveness of the morning!</p><p>Truly, many a one used to raise his legs like a dancer; the laughter in my wisdom beckoned to him \u2013 then he reconsidered. Just now I saw him crooked \u2013 and crawling to the cross.</p><p>Once they fluttered around light and freedom like gnats and young poets. A bit older, a bit colder, and already they monger rumors in the dark, thronging around the stove.</p><p>Did their hearts falter perhaps because solitude swallowed me like a whale? Did their ears listen perhaps longingly long in vain for me and my trumpet and herald calls?</p><p>Too bad! Those whose hearts have long courage and encourage mischief are always few; and in such the spirit too remains patient. But the rest are cowardly.</p><p>The rest: these are always the most by far, the day to day, the superfluous, the far-too-many \u2013 all of these are cowardly!</p><p>Whoever is of my kind also encounters my kind of experiences along the way, so that his first companions have to be corpses and jesters.</p><p>His second companions, however \u2013 they will call themselves his believers: a living swarm, much love, much folly, much beardless veneration.</p><p>Whoever is of my kind among human beings should not tie his heart to these believers; whoever knows capricious, cowardly humankind should not believe in these spring times and colorful meadows!</p><p>If they could do otherwise, then they would also will otherwise. Half-and-halfs spoil all that is whole. That leaves will wilt \u2013 what is to be lamented here!</p><p>Let them fly and fall, oh Zarathustra, and do not lament! Better yet blow among them with rustling wind \u2013</p><p>\u2013 blow among these leaves, oh Zarathustra, so that everything wilted runs away from you even faster! \u2013</p><h3>2</h3><p>\u201cWe have become pious again\u201d \u2013 so these apostates confess, and some of them are still too cowardly to confess in this manner.</p><p>I look them in the eye \u2013 I tell them to their faces and to their blushing cheeks: You are the kind who pray again!</p><p>But it is a disgrace to pray! Not for everyone, but for you and me and whoever still has a conscience in his head. For you it is a disgrace to pray!</p><p>You know it well; your cowardly devil in you, who likes to fold his hands and lay his hands in his lap and wants to have it easier \u2013 this cowardly devil exhorts you: \u201cThere is a God!\u201d</p><p>With that however you belong to the shade-loving variety who are never left in peace by light; now every day you must stick your head deeper into night and mist!</p><p>And truly, you chose the hour well, for just now the night birds are flying out. The hour has come for all shade-loving folk, the evening and commemoration hour when they do not \u201ccommemorate.\u201d</p><p>I hear and smell it: their hour came for the hunt and the procession, not for a wild hunt, to be sure, but for a tame, lame, snooping, up-buttering prayer muttering hunt \u2013</p><p>\u2013 for a hunt for soulful mousy yes-men; all the heart\u2019s mousetraps have now been set again! And wherever I lift a curtain, a little night moth comes fluttering out.</p><p>Did it perhaps crouch there with another little night moth? For everywhere I smell little communities that have crept away; and where there are little rooms there are new Holy Joes in them and the reek of Holy Joes.</p><p>They sit long evenings together and say: \u201cLet us become as little children again and say \u2018dear God\u2019!\u201d \u2013 their mouths and stomachs ruined by pious confectioners.</p><p>Or they watch long evenings the cunning lurking cross spider, which preaches cleverness to the spiders themselves and thus teaches: \u201cThere is good spinning among crosses!\u201d</p><p>Or they sit the whole day with fishing rods at swamps and consider themselves deep for doing so; but whoever fishes where there are no fish \u2013 him I cannot even call superficial!</p><p>Or they learn piously, joyously to stroke the harp, from a writer of songs who would gladly harp his way into the hearts of little young women \u2013 having grown weary of the little old women and their praise.</p><p>Or they learn to shudder from a learned half-madman who waits in dark rooms for the spirits to come to him \u2013 and for the spirit to run away altogether!</p><p>Or they listen to an old wandering harebrained whistler, who learned the triste of tones from tristful winds; now he whistles after the wind and preaches triste in tristful tones.</p><p>And some of them have even become night watchmen; now they know how to blow into their horns and go around at night waking up old things that have long ago gone to sleep.</p><p>I heard five expressions of old things yesterday night at the garden wall \u2013 they came from such old, saddened, dried up night watchmen.</p><p>\u201cFor a father he doesn\u2019t care enough about his children: human fathers do this better!\u201d \u2013</p><p>\u201cHe is too old! He does not even care about his children at all anymore\u201d \u2013 thus answered the other night watchman.</p><p>\u201cDoes he even have children? No one can prove it, if he himself doesn\u2019t prove it! I wish he would just go ahead and prove it properly for once.\u201d</p><p>\u201cProve it? As if he had ever proven anything! Proving is hard for him; he treasures instead that people have faith in him.\u201d</p><p>\u201cIndeed! Indeed! Faith makes him blessed, faith in him. That\u2019s just the way of old people! That\u2019s how it is with us too!\u201d \u2013</p><p>\u2013 Thus the two old night watchmen and light chasers spoke to one another, and they tooted their horns sadly; so it was yesterday at the garden wall.</p><p>But my heart convulsed with laughter and wanted to break and did not know what next, and it sank into my diaphragm.</p><p>Indeed, this will be the death of me, that I choke from laughter when I see asses drunk and hear night watchmen doubting God\u2019s existence like this.</p><p>Has the time not long since past even for all such doubting? Who is allowed anymore to wake up such old, sleeping, shade-loving things!</p><p>It has been over for the old gods for a long time now \u2013 and truly, they had a good cheerful gods\u2019 end!</p><p>They did not \u201ctwilight\u201d themselves to death \u2013 that is surely a lie! Instead, they just one day up and laughed themselves to death!</p><p>This happened when the most godless words were uttered by a god himself \u2013 the words: \u201cThere is one god. Thou shalt have no other god before me!\u201d \u2013</p><p>\u2013 an old grim-beard of a god, a jealous one forgot himself in this way: And all the gods laughed then and rocked in their chairs and cried: \u201cIs godliness not precisely that there are gods but no God?\u201d</p><p>He who has ears to hear, let him hear. \u2013</p><p>Thus spoke Zarathustra in the town that he loved and which is called The Motley Cow. From here he had only two more days to go to return to his cave and his animals, and his soul jubilated constantly at the nearness of his homecoming. \u2013</p>", "article_json": {"type": "doc", "content": [{"type": "heading", "attrs": {"level": 2}, "content": [{"text": "On Apostates", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "heading", "attrs": {"level": 3}, "content": [{"text": "1", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "content": [{"text": "Alas, does everything lie wilted and grey that only recently stood green and colorful in this meadow? And how much honey of hope I carried from here to my beehives!\r\n\r\nAll these young hearts have already grown old \u2013 and not even old! Only weary, common, comfortable \u2013 as they put it: \u201cWe have become pious again.\u201d\r\n\r\nJust recently I saw them set out by early morning on brave feet, but their feet of knowledge grew weary, and now they slander even their braveness of the morning!\r\n\r\nTruly, many a one used to raise his legs like a dancer; the laughter in my wisdom beckoned to him \u2013 then he reconsidered. Just now I saw him crooked \u2013 and crawling to the cross.\r\n\r\nOnce they fluttered around light and freedom like gnats and young poets. A bit older, a bit colder, and already they monger rumors in the dark, thronging around the stove.\r\n\r\nDid their hearts falter perhaps because solitude swallowed me like a whale? Did their ears listen perhaps longingly long in vain for me and my trumpet and herald calls?\r\n\r\nToo bad! Those whose hearts have long courage and encourage mischief are always few; and in such the spirit too remains patient. But the rest are cowardly.\r\n\r\nThe rest: these are always the most by far, the day to day, the superfluous, the far-too-many \u2013 all of these are cowardly!\r\n\r\nWhoever is of my kind also encounters my kind of experiences along the way, so that his first companions have to be corpses and jesters.\r\n\r\nHis second companions, however \u2013 they will call themselves his believers: a living swarm, much love, much folly, much beardless veneration.\r\n\r\nWhoever is of my kind among human beings should not tie his heart to these believers; whoever knows capricious, cowardly humankind should not believe in these spring times and colorful meadows!\r\n\r\nIf they could do otherwise, then they would also will otherwise. Half-and-halfs spoil all that is whole. That leaves will wilt \u2013 what is to be lamented here!\r\n\r\nLet them fly and fall, oh Zarathustra, and do not lament! Better yet blow among them with rustling wind \u2013\r\n\r\n\u2013 blow among these leaves, oh Zarathustra, so that everything wilted runs away from you even faster! \u2013\r\n\r\n2\r\n\r\n\u201cWe have become pious again\u201d \u2013 so these apostates confess, and some of them are still too cowardly to confess in this manner.\r\n\r\nI look them in the eye \u2013 I tell them to their faces and to their blushing cheeks: You are the kind who pray again!\r\n\r\nBut it is a disgrace to pray! Not for everyone, but for you and me and whoever still has a conscience in his head. For you it is a disgrace to pray!\r\n\r\nYou know it well; your cowardly devil in you, who likes to fold his hands and lay his hands in his lap and wants to have it easier \u2013 this cowardly devil exhorts you: \u201cThere is a God!\u201d\r\n\r\nWith that however you belong to the shade-loving variety who are never left in peace by light; now every day you must stick your head deeper into night and mist!\r\n\r\nAnd truly, you chose the hour well, for just now the night birds are flying out. The hour has come for all shade-loving folk, the evening and commemoration hour when they do not \u201ccommemorate.\u201d\r\n\r\nI hear and smell it: their hour came for the hunt and the procession, not for a wild hunt, to be sure, but for a tame, lame, snooping, up-buttering prayer muttering hunt \u2013\r\n\r\n\u2013 for a hunt for soulful mousy yes-men; all the heart\u2019s mousetraps have now been set again! And wherever I lift a curtain, a little night moth comes fluttering out.\r\n\r\nDid it perhaps crouch there with another little night moth? For everywhere I smell little communities that have crept away; and where there are little rooms there are new Holy Joes in them and the reek of Holy Joes.\r\n\r\nThey sit long evenings together and say: \u201cLet us become as little children again and say \u2018dear God\u2019!\u201d \u2013 their mouths and stomachs ruined by pious confectioners.\r\n\r\nOr they watch long evenings the cunning lurking cross spider, which preaches cleverness to the spiders themselves and thus teaches: \u201cThere is good spinning among crosses!\u201d\r\n\r\nOr they sit the whole day with fishing rods at swamps and consider themselves deep for doing so; but whoever fishes where there are no fish \u2013 him I cannot even call superficial!\r\n\r\nOr they learn piously, joyously to stroke the harp, from a writer of songs who would gladly harp his way into the hearts of little young women \u2013 having grown weary of the little old women and their praise.\r\n\r\nOr they learn to shudder from a learned half-madman who waits in dark rooms for the spirits to come to him \u2013 and for the spirit to run away altogether!\r\n\r\nOr they listen to an old wandering harebrained whistler, who learned the triste of tones from tristful winds; now he whistles after the wind and preaches triste in tristful tones.\r\n\r\nAnd some of them have even become night watchmen; now they know how to blow into their horns and go around at night waking up old things that have long ago gone to sleep.\r\n\r\nI heard five expressions of old things yesterday night at the garden wall \u2013 they came from such old, saddened, dried up night watchmen.\r\n\r\n\u201cFor a father he doesn\u2019t care enough about his children: human fathers do this better!\u201d \u2013\r\n\r\n\u201cHe is too old! He does not even care about his children at all anymore\u201d \u2013 thus answered the other night watchman.\r\n\r\n\u201cDoes he even have children? No one can prove it, if he himself doesn\u2019t prove it! I wish he would just go ahead and prove it properly for once.\u201d\r\n\r\n\u201cProve it? As if he had ever proven anything! Proving is hard for him; he treasures instead that people have faith in him.\u201d\r\n\r\n\u201cIndeed! Indeed! Faith makes him blessed, faith in him. That\u2019s just the way of old people! That\u2019s how it is with us too!\u201d \u2013\r\n\r\n\u2013 Thus the two old night watchmen and light chasers spoke to one another, and they tooted their horns sadly; so it was yesterday at the garden wall.\r\n\r\nBut my heart convulsed with laughter and wanted to break and did not know what next, and it sank into my diaphragm.\r\n\r\nIndeed, this will be the death of me, that I choke from laughter when I see asses drunk and hear night watchmen doubting God\u2019s existence like this.\r\n\r\nHas the time not long since past even for all such doubting? Who is allowed anymore to wake up such old, sleeping, shade-loving things!\r\n\r\nIt has been over for the old gods for a long time now \u2013 and truly, they had a good cheerful gods\u2019 end!\r\n\r\nThey did not \u201ctwilight\u201d themselves to death \u2013 that is surely a lie! Instead, they just one day up and laughed themselves to death!\r\n\r\nThis happened when the most godless words were uttered by a god himself \u2013 the words: \u201cThere is one god. Thou shalt have no other god before me!\u201d \u2013\r\n\r\n\u2013 an old grim-beard of a god, a jealous one forgot himself in this way: And all the gods laughed then and rocked in their chairs and cried: \u201cIs godliness not precisely that there are gods but no God?\u201d\r\n\r\nHe who has ears to hear, let him hear. \u2013\r\n\r\nThus spoke Zarathustra in the town that he loved and which is called The Motley Cow. From here he had only two more days to go to return to his cave and his animals, and his soul jubilated constantly at the nearness of his homecoming. \u2013"}, "id": 69}, {"data": {"uuid": "e6a6d3e1-1920-45f9-8617-073f0b2b48d0", "user": 1, "title": "The Homecoming", "created_on": "2023-05-10 15:52:43.311405+00:00", "updated_on": "2023-05-10 15:52:43.331444+00:00", "article_html": "<h2>The Homecoming</h2><p>Oh solitude! Oh you my home solitude! I lived wild too long in wild foreign lands to not return to you with tears!</p><p>Now go ahead and threaten me with your finger, like mothers threaten; now smile at me, like mothers smile; now say to me: \u201cAnd who was it that once stormed out on me like a storm wind? \u2013</p><p>\u2013 who called out in leaving: \u2018too long have I sat with solitude, and I have forgotten how to keep silent!\u2019 That \u2013 you have learned now?</p><p>Oh Zarathustra, I know everything, and that you were more forsaken among the many, you solitary one, than ever with me!</p><p>Being forsaken is one thing, solitude is another: that \u2013 you have now learned! And that among human beings you will always be wild and foreign.</p><p>Wild and foreign even when they love you; for what they want above all is to be spared!</p><p>But here you are in your own home and house; here you can speak everything out and pour out all the reasons, nothing here is ashamed of obscure, obstinate feelings.</p><p>Here all things come caressingly to your rhetoric and they flatter you, for they want to ride on your back. Here you ride on every parable to every truth.</p><p>Here you may speak uprightly and forthrightly to all things, and truly, it rings like praise in their ears that someone talks straight with all things!</p><p>But being forsaken is another matter. For do you still recall, oh Zarathustra, when your bird called above you, when you stood in the woods, hesitating about which way to go, close to a corpse? \u2013</p><p>When you spoke: \u2018May my animals guide me! I found it more dangerous among human beings than among animals\u2019 \u2013 that was forsaken!</p><p>And do you still recall, oh Zarathustra, when you sat on your island, a well of wine among empty buckets, giving and giving away, among the thirsty bestowing and flowing:</p><p>\u2013 until at last you alone sat thirsty among the drunk and lamented at night: \u2018is receiving not more blessed than giving? And stealing even more blessed than receiving?\u2019 \u2013 That was forsaken!</p><p>And do you still recall, oh Zarathustra, when your stillest hour came and drove you away from yourself, when with evil whispers it said: \u2018Speak and break!\u2019 \u2013</p><p>\u2013 when it made you sorry for all your waiting and silence and discour- aged your cautious courage: that was forsaken!\u201d \u2013</p><p>Oh solitude! You my home solitude! How blissfully and tenderly your voice speaks to me!</p><p>We do not implore one another, we do not deplore one another, we walk openly with one another through open doors.</p><p>For at your house it is open and bright, and even the hours run here on lighter feet. In darkness, after all, time is heavier to bear than in the light.</p><p>Here all of being\u2019s words and word shrines burst open; here all being wants to become word, here all becoming wants to learn from me how to speak.</p><p>But down there \u2013 there all speaking is in vain! There forgetting and passing by are the best wisdom: that \u2013 I have now learned!</p><p>Whoever wanted to comprehend everything among human beings would have to apprehend everything. But for that my hands are too clean.</p><p>I cannot stand even to inhale their breath; too bad that I have lived so long among their noise and bad breath!</p><p>Oh blissful silence around me! Oh clean fragrances around me ! Oh how this silence takes a deep clean breath! Oh how it listens, this blissful silence!</p><p>But down there \u2013 everyone talks there, everyone is ignored there. One could ring in his wisdom with bells, and the shopkeepers in the market place would jingle it out with pennies.</p><p>Everyone talks among them, no one knows any more how to understand. Everything falls in the water, nothing falls anymore into deep wells.</p><p>Everyone talks among them, nothing works out anymore and comes to an end. Everyone cackles, but who wants to sit still in the nest anymore and hatch eggs?</p><p>Everyone talks among them, everything gets talked to death. And whatever was still too hard yesterday for time itself and for its tooth, today it hangs scraped up and chewed up from the snouts of today\u2019s people.</p><p>Everyone talks among them, everything is betrayed. And what was once called secret and secrecy of deep souls, today it belongs to the street trumpeters and other butterflies.</p><p>Oh human nature, you strange thing! You noise in dark lanes! Now you lie behind me again \u2013 my greatest danger lies behind me!</p><p>In sparing and pitying my greatest danger always lay; and all human nature wants to be spared and pitied.</p><p>With concealed truths, with a fool\u2019s hand and a fooled, infatuated heart, rich in pity\u2019s petty lies \u2013 this is how I lived among human beings.</p><p>Disguised I sat among them, ready to misjudge myself in order to stand them, and gladly urging myself: \u201cYou fool, you do not know human beings!\u201d</p><p>One forgets about human beings when one lives among human beings; there is too much foreground in all human beings \u2013 what use are far- sighted, far-seeking eyes there!</p><p>And when they misjudged me, I, fool, spared them more than myself, since I am accustomed to hardness, and often I even took revenge on myself for being so sparing.</p><p>Covered in bites by poisonous flies and hollowed out, like a stone, by many drops of malice, I sat among them and still I told myself: \u201cEverything small is innocent of its smallness!\u201d</p><p>Especially those who call themselves \u201cthe good,\u201d I found to be the most poisonous flies; they sting in all innocence, they lie in all innocence \u2013 how could they be just toward me!</p><p>Whoever lives among the good is taught by pity to lie. Pity fouls the air for all free souls. The stupidity of the good, after all, is unfathomable.</p><p>To conceal myself and my wealth \u2013 that is what I learned down there, for I found each of them poor in spirit. And it was the lie of my pitying that I knew with each one,</p><p>\u2013 that I saw and smelled with each one, what was enough spirit for him and what was already too much!</p><p>Their stiff wise men \u2013 I call them wise, not stiff \u2013 that is how I learned to swallow words. Their gravediggers \u2013 I called them researchers and testers \u2013 that is how I learned to switch words.</p><p>The gravediggers dig themselves diseases. Under ancient ruins rest noxious fumes. One should not stir up the morass. One should live on mountains.</p><p>With blissful nostrils I once again breathe mountain freedom! My nose is finally redeemed of the odor of all human nature!</p><p>Tickled by sharp breezes as if by sparkling wines, my soul sneezes \u2013 sneezes and jubilates to itself: Gesundheit!</p><p>Thus spoke Zarathustra.</p>", "article_json": {"type": "doc", "content": [{"type": "heading", "attrs": {"level": 2}, "content": [{"text": "The Homecoming", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "content": [{"text": "Oh solitude!
