Oh you my home solitude! I lived wild too long in wild foreign lands to not return to you with tears!\r\n\r\nNow go ahead and threaten me with your finger, like mothers threaten; now smile at me, like mothers smile; now say to me: \u201cAnd who was it that once stormed out on me like a storm wind? \u2013\r\n\r\n\u2013 who called out in leaving: \u2018too long have I sat with solitude, and I have forgotten how to keep silent!\u2019 That \u2013 you have learned now?\r\n\r\nOh Zarathustra, I know everything, and that you were more forsaken among the many, you solitary one, than ever with me!\r\n\r\nBeing forsaken is one thing, solitude is another: that \u2013 you have now learned! And that among human beings you will always be wild and foreign.\r\n\r\nWild and foreign even when they love you; for what they want above all is to be spared!\r\n\r\nBut here you are in your own home and house; here you can speak everything out and pour out all the reasons, nothing here is ashamed of obscure, obstinate feelings.\r\n\r\nHere all things come caressingly to your rhetoric and they flatter you, for they want to ride on your back. Here you ride on every parable to every truth.\r\n\r\nHere you may speak uprightly and forthrightly to all things, and truly, it rings like praise in their ears that someone talks straight with all things!\r\n\r\nBut being forsaken is another matter. For do you still recall, oh Zarathustra, when your bird called above you, when you stood in the woods, hesitating about which way to go, close to a corpse? \u2013\r\n\r\nWhen you spoke: \u2018May my animals guide me! I found it more dangerous among human beings than among animals\u2019 \u2013 that was forsaken!\r\n\r\nAnd do you still recall, oh Zarathustra, when you sat on your island, a well of wine among empty buckets, giving and giving away, among the thirsty bestowing and flowing:\r\n\r\n\u2013 until at last you alone sat thirsty among the drunk and lamented at night: \u2018is receiving not more blessed than giving? And stealing even more blessed than receiving?\u2019 \u2013 That was forsaken!\r\n\r\nAnd do you still recall, oh Zarathustra, when your stillest hour came and drove you away from yourself, when with evil whispers it said: \u2018Speak and break!\u2019 \u2013\r\n\r\n\u2013 when it made you sorry for all your waiting and silence and discour- aged your cautious courage: that was forsaken!\u201d \u2013\r\n\r\nOh solitude! You my home solitude! How blissfully and tenderly your voice speaks to me!\r\n\r\nWe do not implore one another, we do not deplore one another, we walk openly with one another through open doors.\r\n\r\nFor at your house it is open and bright, and even the hours run here on lighter feet. In darkness, after all, time is heavier to bear than in the light.\r\n\r\nHere all of being\u2019s words and word shrines burst open; here all being wants to become word, here all becoming wants to learn from me how to speak.\r\n\r\nBut down there \u2013 there all speaking is in vain! There forgetting and passing by are the best wisdom: that \u2013 I have now learned!\r\n\r\nWhoever wanted to comprehend everything among human beings would have to apprehend everything. But for that my hands are too clean.\r\n\r\nI cannot stand even to inhale their breath; too bad that I have lived so long among their noise and bad breath!\r\n\r\nOh blissful silence around me! Oh clean fragrances around me ! Oh how this silence takes a deep clean breath! Oh how it listens, this blissful silence!\r\n\r\nBut down there \u2013 everyone talks there, everyone is ignored there. One could ring in his wisdom with bells, and the shopkeepers in the market place would jingle it out with pennies.\r\n\r\nEveryone talks among them, no one knows any more how to understand. Everything falls in the water, nothing falls anymore into deep wells.\r\n\r\nEveryone talks among them, nothing works out anymore and comes to an end. Everyone cackles, but who wants to sit still in the nest anymore and hatch eggs?\r\n\r\nEveryone talks among them, everything gets talked to death. And whatever was still too hard yesterday for time itself and for its tooth, today it hangs scraped up and chewed up from the snouts of today\u2019s people.\r\n\r\nEveryone talks among them, everything is betrayed. And what was once called secret and secrecy of deep souls, today it belongs to the street trumpeters and other butterflies.\r\n\r\nOh human nature, you strange thing! You noise in dark lanes! Now you lie behind me again \u2013 my greatest danger lies behind me!\r\n\r\nIn sparing and pitying my greatest danger always lay; and all human nature wants to be spared and pitied.\r\n\r\nWith concealed truths, with a fool\u2019s hand and a fooled, infatuated heart, rich in pity\u2019s petty lies \u2013 this is how I lived among human beings.\r\n\r\nDisguised I sat among them, ready to misjudge myself in order to stand them, and gladly urging myself: \u201cYou fool, you do not know human beings!\u201d\r\n\r\nOne forgets about human beings when one lives among human beings; there is too much foreground in all human beings \u2013 what use are far- sighted, far-seeking eyes there!\r\n\r\nAnd when they misjudged me, I, fool, spared them more than myself, since I am accustomed to hardness, and often I even took revenge on myself for being so sparing.\r\n\r\nCovered in bites by poisonous flies and hollowed out, like a stone, by many drops of malice, I sat among them and still I told myself: \u201cEverything small is innocent of its smallness!\u201d\r\n\r\nEspecially those who call themselves \u201cthe good,\u201d I found to be the most poisonous flies; they sting in all innocence, they lie in all innocence \u2013 how could they be just toward me!\r\n\r\nWhoever lives among the good is taught by pity to lie. Pity fouls the air for all free souls. The stupidity of the good, after all, is unfathomable.\r\n\r\nTo conceal myself and my wealth \u2013 that is what I learned down there, for I found each of them poor in spirit. And it was the lie of my pitying that I knew with each one,\r\n\r\n\u2013 that I saw and smelled with each one, what was enough spirit for him and what was already too much!\r\n\r\nTheir stiff wise men \u2013 I call them wise, not stiff \u2013 that is how I learned to swallow words. Their gravediggers \u2013 I called them researchers and testers \u2013 that is how I learned to switch words.\r\n\r\nThe gravediggers dig themselves diseases. Under ancient ruins rest noxious fumes. One should not stir up the morass. One should live on mountains.\r\n\r\nWith blissful nostrils I once again breathe mountain freedom! My nose is finally redeemed of the odor of all human nature!\r\n\r\nTickled by sharp breezes as if by sparkling wines, my soul sneezes \u2013 sneezes and jubilates to itself: Gesundheit!\r\n\r\nThus spoke Zarathustra."}, "id": 70}, {"data": {"uuid": "61d0341a-0509-4662-bee4-ceaa96f425b2", "user": 1, "title": "On the Three Evils", "created_on": "2023-05-10 15:53:37.660189+00:00", "updated_on": "2023-05-10 15:53:37.679722+00:00", "article_html": "<h2>On the Three Evils</h2><h3>1</h3><p>In a dream, in the last dream of morning I stood today on a foothill \u2013 beyond the world, holding a scale, and I weighed the world.</p><p>But the dawn came too early, and glowed me awake, this jealous one! She is always jealous of my morning dream embers.</p><p>Measurable for the one who has time, weighable for a good weigher, flyable for strong wings, guessable for divine nut crackers: thus my dream found the world.</p><p>My dream, a daring sailor, half ship, half whirlwind, silent as butterflies, impatient as falcons: how did it have the patience and while today for world-weighing?</p><p>Did my wisdom perhaps encourage it, my laughing, waking day wisdom, which mocks all \u201cinfinite worlds\u201d? For it says: \u201cWhere there is force, number will become the master: it has more force.\u201d</p><p>How certainly my dream looked upon this finite world, not inquisitively, not curiously, not incuriously, not fearfully, not beseechingly:</p><p>\u2013 as if a plump apple offered itself to my hand, a ripe golden apple, with cool soft velvety peel \u2013 thus the world offered itself to me:</p><p>\u2013 as if a tree waved to me, a broad-limbed, strong-willed tree, bent as a support and even as a footrest for the weary traveler: thus stood the world on my foothill:</p><p>\u2013 as if delicate hands carried a shrine toward me \u2013 a shrine open for the delight of bashful, venerating eyes: thus the world offered itself to me today:</p><p>\u2013 not riddle enough to chase away human love, not solution enough to lull human wisdom to sleep \u2013 a humanly good thing the world was for me today, of which so much evil is spoken!</p><p>How do I thank my morning dream for allowing me to weigh the world early this morning? As a humanly good thing it came to me, this dream and consoler of the heart!</p><p>And in order to do by day what it does, and to imitate it and learn its best, I now want to place the three most evil things on the scale and weigh them humanly well.</p><p>He that taught to bless here also taught to curse: what are the three best-cursed things in the world? These I want to place on the scale.</p><p>Sex, lust to rule, selfishness: these three have been cursed best and slandered and lied about most so far \u2013 these three I want to weigh humanly well.</p><p>Well then! Here is my foothill and there is the sea; it rolls up to me, shaggy, flattering, the faithful old hundred-headed behemoth hound that I love.</p><p>Well then! Here I want to hold the scale over rolling seas, and I also choose a witness to look on \u2013 you, you hermit tree, you strongly fragrant, broadly vaulted tree that I love!</p><p>On what bridge does the now get to the someday? By what compulsion does the high compel itself to the low? And what commands even the highest \u2013 to grow higher?</p><p>Now the scale stands balanced and still: three weighty questions I threw into it, three weighty answers are borne by the other pan.</p><h3>2</h3><p>Sex: the thorn and stake of all hair-shirted body despisers, and cursed as \u201cworld\u201d among all hinterworldly, because it mocks and fools all teachers of muddle and mistakes.</p><p>Sex: the slow fire on which the rabble are burned, the ready rut and rolling boil oven of all wormy wood, all stinking rags.</p><p>Sex: innocent and free for free hearts, the garden happiness of earth, all the future\u2019s exuberant gratitude for the now.</p><p>Sex: a sweetish poison only for the wilted, but for the lion-willed a great fortifying of the heart, and the respectfully reserved wine of wines.</p><p>Sex: the great parable-happiness for higher happiness and highest hope. For to many marriage is promised and more than marriage \u2013</p><p>\u2013 To many who are stranger to one another than man and woman \u2013 and who has ever completely grasped how strange man and woman are to one another!</p><p>Sex \u2013 but I want fences around my thoughts and around my words too, so that the pigs and the partiers do not break into my garden! \u2013</p><p>Lust to rule: the searing scourge of the hardest of the hard hearted, the creepy torture that is reserved for the very cruelest person, the dark flame of living funeral pyres.</p><p>Lust to rule: the grim gadfly imposed on the vainest peoples, the mocker of all insecure virtue, the rider on every horse and every pride.</p><p>Lust to rule: the earthquake that breaks and breaks open everything rotten and hollow, the rolling, growling, punishing smasher of whitewashed tombs, the flashing question mark next to premature answers.</p><p>Lust to rule: before whose gaze human beings crawl and cower and drudge and become lower than snake and swine \u2013 until at last the great contempt cries out of them \u2013</p><p>Lust to rule: the terrible teacher of the great contempt who preaches \u201caway with you!\u201d to the faces of cities and empires \u2013 until they themselves cry out \u201caway with me!\u201d</p><p>Lust to rule: which also ascends luringly to the pure and the solitary and into self-sufficient heights, glowing like a love that luringly paints purple bliss on earth\u2019s skies.</p><p>Lust to rule: but who would call it lust when the high longs downward for power! Indeed, there is nothing sick and addicted in such longing and descending!</p><p>That the solitary height not isolate and suffice itself eternally; that the mountain come to the valley and the winds of the height to the lowlands \u2013</p><p>Oh who would find the right christening and glistening name for such longing! \u201cBestowing virtue\u201d \u2013 thus Zarathustra once named the unname- able.</p><p>And it was then that it happened \u2013 indeed happened for the first time! \u2013 that his words pronounced selfishness blessed, the sound, healthy self- ishness that wells from a powerful soul \u2013</p><p>\u2013 from a powerful soul to which the high body belongs, the beauti- ful, triumphant, invigorating body, around which every manner of thing becomes mirror:</p><p>\u2013 the supple persuading body, the dancer whose parable and epitome is the self-joyous soul. Such self-joy of body and soul calls itself: \u201cVirtue.\u201d</p><p>With its words of good and bad such self-joy shields itself as if with sacred groves; with the names of its happiness it banishes from itself everything contemptible.</p><p>From itself it banishes all that is cowardly, saying: \u201cBad \u2013 that is cowardly!\u201d It considers contemptible those who always worry, sigh, complain, and whoever picks up even the smallest advantages.</p><p>It also despises all woe-wallowing wisdom, for indeed, there is also wisdom that blossoms in darkness, a night shadow wisdom that always sighs: \u201cAll is vain!\u201d</p><p>It holds shy mistrust in low esteem, and everyone who wants oaths instead of gazes and hands; and all wisdom that is all too mistrustful \u2013 because this is the way of cowardly souls.</p><p>Even lower it esteems those quick to please, the dog-like who lie on their backs right away, the humble; and there is wisdom too that is humble and dog-like and pious and quick to please.</p><p>Utterly disgusting and despicable to it are those who never defend themselves, who swallow poisonous spittle and evil stares; the all too patient, all-enduring, all-complacent: for they are the servile kind.</p><p>Whether a person is servile before gods and gods\u2019 kicks, or before human beings and stupid human opinions: all servile kind it spits on, this blissful selfishness!</p><p>Bad: that is what it calls everything that is struck down, stingy and servile; fettered blinking eyes, oppressed hearts, and those false, yielding types who kiss with broad cowardly lips.</p><p>And pseudo-wisdom: that is what it calls everything that servants and old men and weary people witticize; and especially the whole nasty nitwitted, twitwitted foolishness of priests!</p><p>The pseudo-wise, however, all the priests, the world weary and whoever\u2019s souls are of the woman\u2019s and servant\u2019s kind \u2013 oh how their game has always played tricks on selfishness!</p><p>And precisely that was supposed to be virtue and be called virtue, that they played evil tricks on selfishness! And \u201cselfless\u201d \u2013 that is how they wished themselves, with good reason, all these world-weary cowards and cross spiders!</p><p>But for all of them now the day is coming, the transformation, the judgement sword, the great noon: then much shall be revealed!</p><p>And whoever pronounces the ego hale and holy and selfishness blessed, indeed, he tells what he knows, this foreteller: \u201cLook, it is coming, it is near, the great noon!\u201d</p><p>Thus spoke Zarathustra.</p>", "article_json": {"type": "doc", "content": [{"type": "heading", "attrs": {"level": 2}, "content": [{"text": "On the Three Evils", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "heading", "attrs": {"level": 3}, "content": [{"text": "1", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "content": [{"text": "In a dream, in the last dream of morning I stood today on a foothill \u2013 beyond the world, holding a scale, and I weighed the world.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "content": [{"text": "But the dawn came too early, and glowed me awake, this jealous one! And what commands even the highest \u2013 to grow higher?\r\n\r\nNow the scale stands balanced and still: three weighty questions I threw into it, three weighty answers are borne by the other pan.\r\n\r\n2\r\n\r\nSex: the thorn and stake of all hair-shirted body despisers, and cursed as \u201cworld\u201d among all hinterworldly, because it mocks and fools all teachers of muddle and mistakes.\r\n\r\nSex: the slow fire on which the rabble are burned, the ready rut and rolling boil oven of all wormy wood, all stinking rags.\r\n\r\nSex: innocent and free for free hearts, the garden happiness of earth, all the future\u2019s exuberant gratitude for the now.\r\n\r\nSex: a sweetish poison only for the wilted, but for the lion-willed a great fortifying of the heart, and the respectfully reserved wine of wines.\r\n\r\nSex: the great parable-happiness for higher happiness and highest hope. For to many marriage is promised and more than marriage \u2013\r\n\r\n\u2013 To many who are stranger to one another than man and woman \u2013 and who has ever completely grasped how strange man and woman are to one another!\r\n\r\nSex \u2013 but I want fences around my thoughts and around my words too, so that the pigs and the partiers do not break into my garden! \u2013\r\n\r\nLust to rule: the searing scourge of the hardest of the hard hearted, the creepy torture that is reserved for the very cruelest person, the dark flame of living funeral pyres.\r\n\r\nLust to rule: the grim gadfly imposed on the vainest peoples, the mocker of all insecure virtue, the rider on every horse and every pride.\r\n\r\nLust to rule: the earthquake that breaks and breaks open everything rotten and hollow, the rolling, growling, punishing smasher of whitewashed tombs, the flashing question mark next to premature answers.\r\n\r\nLust to rule: before whose gaze human beings crawl and cower and drudge and become lower than snake and swine \u2013 until at last the great contempt cries out of them \u2013\r\n\r\nLust to rule: the terrible teacher of the great contempt who preaches \u201caway with you!\u201d to the faces of cities and empires \u2013 until they themselves cry out \u201caway with me!\u201d\r\n\r\nLust to rule: which also ascends luringly to the pure and the solitary and into self-sufficient heights, glowing like a love that luringly paints purple bliss on earth\u2019s skies.\r\n\r\nLust to rule: but who would call it lust when the high longs downward for power! Indeed, there is nothing sick and addicted in such longing and descending!\r\n\r\nThat the solitary height not isolate and suffice itself eternally; that the mountain come to the valley and the winds of the height to the lowlands \u2013\r\n\r\nOh who would find the right christening and glistening name for such longing! \u201cBestowing virtue\u201d \u2013 thus Zarathustra once named the unname- able.\r\n\r\nAnd it was then that it happened \u2013 indeed happened for the first time! \u2013 that his words pronounced selfishness blessed, the sound, healthy self- ishness that wells from a powerful soul \u2013\r\n\r\n\u2013 from a powerful soul to which the high body belongs, the beauti- ful, triumphant, invigorating body, around which every manner of thing becomes mirror:\r\n\r\n\u2013 the supple persuading body, the dancer whose parable and epitome is the self-joyous soul. Such self-joy of body and soul calls itself: \u201cVirtue.\u201d\r\n\r\nWith its words of good and bad such self-joy shields itself as if with sacred groves; with the names of its happiness it banishes from itself everything contemptible.\r\n\r\nFrom itself it banishes all that is cowardly, saying: \u201cBad \u2013 that is cowardly!\u201d It considers contemptible those who always worry, sigh, complain, and whoever picks up even the smallest advantages.\r\n\r\nIt also despises all woe-wallowing wisdom, for indeed, there is also wisdom that blossoms in darkness, a night shadow wisdom that always sighs: \u201cAll is vain!\u201d\r\n\r\nIt holds shy mistrust in low esteem, and everyone who wants oaths instead of gazes and hands; and all wisdom that is all too mistrustful \u2013 because this is the way of cowardly souls.\r\n\r\nEven lower it esteems those quick to please, the dog-like who lie on their backs right away, the humble; and there is wisdom too that is humble and dog-like and pious and quick to please.\r\n\r\nUtterly disgusting and despicable to it are those who never defend themselves, who swallow poisonous spittle and evil stares; the all too patient, all-enduring, all-complacent: for they are the servile kind.\r\n\r\nWhether a person is servile before gods and gods\u2019 kicks, or before human beings and stupid human opinions: all servile kind it spits on, this blissful selfishness!\r\n\r\nBad: that is what it calls everything that is struck down, stingy and servile; fettered blinking eyes, oppressed hearts, and those false, yielding types who kiss with broad cowardly lips.\r\n\r\nAnd pseudo-wisdom: that is what it calls everything that servants and old men and weary people witticize; and especially the whole nasty nitwitted, twitwitted foolishness of priests!\r\n\r\nThe pseudo-wise, however, all the priests, the world weary and whoever\u2019s souls are of the woman\u2019s and servant\u2019s kind \u2013 oh how their game has always played tricks on selfishness!\r\n\r\nAnd precisely that was supposed to be virtue and be called virtue, that they played evil tricks on selfishness! And \u201cselfless\u201d \u2013 that is how they wished themselves, with good reason, all these world-weary cowards and cross spiders!\r\n\r\nBut for all of them now the day is coming, the transformation, the judgement sword, the great noon: then much shall be revealed!\r\n\r\nAnd whoever pronounces the ego hale and holy and selfishness blessed, indeed, he tells what he knows, this foreteller: \u201cLook, it is coming, it is near, the great noon!\u201d\r\n\r\nThus spoke Zarathustra."}, "id": 71}, {"data": {"uuid": "c88d65d8-03c5-42c7-a5cd-d9b12f322493", "user": 1, "title": "On the Spirit of Gravity", "created_on": "2023-05-10 15:54:16.814659+00:00", "updated_on": "2023-05-11 17:14:27.799209+00:00", "article_html": "<h2>On the Spirit of Gravity</h2><h3>1</h3><p>My mouth \u2013 is of the people: I speak too crudely and sincerely for Angora rabbits. And my words sound even stranger to all cephalopods and pen pushers.</p><p>My hand \u2013 is a fool\u2019s hand: watch out, all tables and walls, and whatever else has space for foolish trim and foolish whim!</p><p>My foot \u2013 is a cloven foot; with it I clip-clop and trot over sticks and stones, crissing and crossing the countryside, and devilish fun is my fast run.</p><p>My stomach \u2013 it must be the stomach of an eagle? Because what it loves best is flesh of lamb. Certain at least, it is the stomach of a bird.</p><p>Nourished by innocent things and by a little, ready and impatient to fly, to fly away \u2013 that is just my way: why should there not be something of the bird\u2019s way in this!</p><p>And especially since I am the enemy of the spirit of gravity, that is the bird\u2019s way; and truly, deadly enemy, arch-enemy, ancient enemy! Oh where has my enmity not already flown and flown astray!</p><p>Of that I could even sing a song \u2013 and I want to sing it; even though I am alone in my empty house and have to sing it to my own ears.</p><p>There are other singers, to be sure, for whom only for a full house softens the vocal chords, makes the hands eloquent, the eyes expressive, the heart alert \u2013 I am not like those.</p><h3>2</h3><p>Whoever one day teaches humans to fly, will have shifted all boundary stones; for him all boundary stones themselves will fly into the air, he will christen the earth anew \u2013 as \u201cthe light one.\u201d</p><p>The ostrich runs faster than the fastest horse, but it also sticks its head heavily into the heavy earth; so too the human being who cannot yet fly.</p><p>Heavy do earth and life seem to him; and the spirit of gravity wants it so! But whoever wants to become light and a bird must love himself \u2013 thus I teach.</p><p>Not, to be sure, with the love of the sick and addicted, because among them even self-love stinks!</p><p>One has to learn to love oneself \u2013 thus I teach \u2013 with a hale and healthy love, so that one can stand oneself and not have to roam around.</p><p>Such roaming around christens itself \u201clove of the neighbor\u201d: these words so far have produced the best lying and hypocrisy, and especially from those whom all the world found heavy.</p><p>And truly, this is not a command for today and tomorrow, this learning to love oneself. Instead, of all arts this is the most subtle, cunning, ultimate and most patient.</p><p>For one\u2019s own, you see, all one\u2019s own is well hidden; and of all buried treasures, one\u2019s own is the latest to be dug up \u2013 this is the spirit of gravity\u2019s doing.</p><p>Almost from the cradle, grave words and values are imparted to us; \u201cgood\u201d and \u201cevil\u201d this dowry calls itself. For its sake we are forgiven for being alive.</p><p>And for this reason one lets the little children come to one, in order to restrain them early on from loving themselves: this is the spirit of gravity\u2019s doing.</p><p>And we \u2013 we faithfully lug what is imparted to us on hard shoulders and over rough mountains! And if we sweat, then we are told: \u201cYes, life is a heavy burden!\u201d</p><p>But only the human being is a heavy burden to himself! This is because he lugs too much that is foreign to him. Like a camel he kneels down and allows himself to be well burdened.</p><p>Especially the strong human being who is eager to bear and inherently reverent: too many foreign words and values he loads upon himself \u2013 now life seems a desert to him!</p><p>And true enough, much that is one\u2019s own is also a heavy burden! And much of what people are on the inside is like an oyster, namely disgusting and slimy and hard to grasp \u2013</p><p>\u2013 so that a noble shell with noble ornamentation must intercede for it. But one must also learn this art: to have a shell and seemly sight and clever blindness!</p><p>Once more what is deceiving about people is that many a shell is meager and sad and too much a shell. Much hidden goodness and strength is never guessed; the most exquisite delicacies find no tasters!</p><p>Women know this, the most exquisite ones: a bit fatter, a bit thinner \u2013 oh how much destiny lies in so little!</p><p>The human being is hard to discover and hardest still for himself; often the spirit lies about the soul. This is the spirit of gravity\u2019s doing.</p><p>But he will have discovered himself who speaks: \u201cThis is my good and evil.\u201d With this he has silenced the mole and dwarf who says: \u201cGood for all, evil for all.\u201d</p><p>Indeed, nor do I like those for whom each thing is good and this world seems the very best. Such types I call the all-complacent.</p><p>All-complacency that knows how to taste everything \u2013 that is not the best taste! I honor the obstinate, choosy tongues and stomachs, which have learned to say \u201cI\u201d and \u201cYes\u201d and \u201cNo.\u201d</p><p>But chewing and digesting everything \u2013 that is truly the swine\u2019s style! To always say hee-yaw \u2013 only the ass learned that, and whoever is of its spirit! \u2013</p><p>Deep yellow and hot red: this is what my taste wants \u2013 it mixes blood into all colors. But whoever whitewashes his house betrays to me a whitewashed soul.</p><p>One is in love with mummies, the other with ghosts; and both alike hostile to all flesh and blood \u2013 oh how they both offend my taste! For I love blood.</p><p>And I do not want to dwell and dawdle where everyone spits and spews: that is just my taste \u2013 I would rather live among thieves and perjurers. No one carries gold in their mouth.</p><p>But even more repugnant to me are all lick spittles; and the most revolting animal of a human being that I found I christened \u201cparasite\u201d: it did not want to love and yet wanted to live off love.</p><p>Damned I call all those who have only one choice: to become evil beasts or evil beast tamers: I would not build my hut among them.</p><p>Damned I also call those who must always wait \u2013 they offend my taste: all the publicans and grocers and kings and other shop- and country-keepers.</p><p>Indeed, I too learned to wait, and thoroughly \u2013 but only to wait for myself. And above all I learned to stand and walk and run and leap and climb and dance.</p><p>But this is my teaching; whoever wants to fly someday must first learn to stand and walk and run and climb and dance \u2013 one cannot fly one\u2019s way to flight!</p><p>On rope ladders I learned to climb to many a window, with agile legs I climbed up high masts: to sit atop tall masts of knowledge struck me as no small bliss \u2013</p><p>\u2013 to flicker like small flames atop tall masts; a small light, to be sure, and yet a great comfort for stranded sailors and shipwreck survivors!</p><p>By many a trail and manner I came to my truth; not on one ladder did I climb to my height, where my eye roams out into my distance.</p><p>And I never liked asking the way \u2013 that always offended my taste! I preferred to question and try the ways myself.</p><p>All my coming and going was a trying and questioning \u2013 and truly, one must also learn to answer such questioning! That, however \u2013 is my taste:</p><p>\u2013 not good, not bad, but my taste, of which I am no longer shameful nor secretive.</p><p>\u201cThis \u2013 it turns out \u2013 is my way \u2013 where is yours?\u201d \u2013 That is how I answered those who asked me \u201cthe way.\u201d The way after all \u2013 it does not exist!</p><p>Thus spoke Zarathustra.</p>", "article_json": {"type": "doc", "content": [{"type": "heading", "attrs": {"level": 2}, "content": [{"text": "On the Spirit of Gravity", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "heading", "attrs": {"level": 3}, "content": [{"text": "1", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "content": [{"text": "My mouth \u2013 is of the people: I speak too crudely and sincerely for Angora rabbits. And my words sound even stranger to all cephalopods and pen pushers.\n\nMy hand \u2013 is a fool\u2019s hand: watch out, all tables and walls, and whatever else has space for foolish trim and foolish whim!\n\nMy foot \u2013 is a cloven foot; with it I clip-clop and trot over sticks and stones, crissing and crossing the countryside, and devilish fun is my fast run.\n\nMy stomach \u2013 it must be the stomach of an eagle? Because what it loves best is flesh of lamb. Certain at least, it is the stomach of a bird.\n\nNourished by innocent things and by a little, ready and impatient to fly, to fly away \u2013 that is just my way: why should there not be something of the bird\u2019s way in this!\n\nAnd especially since I am the enemy of the spirit of gravity, that is the bird\u2019s way; and truly, deadly enemy, arch-enemy, ancient enemy! Oh where has my enmity not already flown and flown astray!\n\nOf that I could even sing a song \u2013 and I want to sing it; even though I am alone in my empty house and have to sing it to my own ears.\n\nThere are other singers, to be sure, for whom only for a full house softens the vocal chords, makes the hands eloquent, the eyes expressive, the heart alert \u2013 I am not like those.\n\n2\n\nWhoever one day teaches humans to fly, will have shifted all boundary stones; for him all boundary stones themselves will fly into the air, he will christen the earth anew \u2013 as \u201cthe light one.\u201d\n\nThe ostrich runs faster than the fastest horse, but it also sticks its head heavily into the heavy earth; so too the human being who cannot yet fly.\n\nHeavy do earth and life seem to him; and the spirit of gravity wants it so! But whoever wants to become light and a bird must love himself \u2013 thus I teach.\n\nNot, to be sure, with the love of the sick and addicted, because among them even self-love stinks!\n\nOne has to learn to love oneself \u2013 thus I teach \u2013 with a hale and healthy love, so that one can stand oneself and not have to roam around.\n\nSuch roaming around christens itself \u201clove of the neighbor\u201d: these words so far have produced the best lying and hypocrisy, and especially from those whom all the world found heavy.\n\nAnd truly, this is not a command for today and tomorrow, this learning to love oneself. Instead, of all arts this is the most subtle, cunning, ultimate and most patient.\n\nFor one\u2019s own, you see, all one\u2019s own is well hidden; and of all buried treasures, one\u2019s own is the latest to be dug up \u2013 this is the spirit of gravity\u2019s doing.\n\nAlmost from the cradle, grave words and values are imparted to us; \u201cgood\u201d and \u201cevil\u201d this dowry calls itself. For its sake we are forgiven for being alive.\n\nAnd for this reason one lets the little children come to one, in order to restrain them early on from loving themselves: this is the spirit of gravity\u2019s doing.\n\nAnd we \u2013 we faithfully lug what is imparted to us on hard shoulders and over rough mountains! And if we sweat, then we are told: \u201cYes, life is a heavy burden!\u201d\n\nBut only the human being is a heavy burden to himself! This is because he lugs too much that is foreign to him. Like a camel he kneels down and allows himself to be well burdened.\n\nEspecially the strong human being who is eager to bear and inherently reverent: too many foreign words and values he loads upon himself \u2013 now life seems a desert to him!\n\nAnd true enough, much that is one\u2019s own is also a heavy burden! And much of what people are on the inside is like an oyster, namely disgusting and slimy and hard to grasp \u2013\n\n\u2013 so that a noble shell with noble ornamentation must intercede for it. But one must also learn this art: to have a shell and seemly sight and clever blindness!\n\nOnce more what is deceiving about people is that many a shell is meager and sad and too much a shell. Much hidden goodness and strength is never guessed; the most exquisite delicacies find no tasters!\n\nWomen know this, the most exquisite ones: a bit fatter, a bit thinner \u2013 oh how much destiny lies in so little!\n\nThe human being is hard to discover and hardest still for himself; often the spirit lies about the soul. This is the spirit of gravity\u2019s doing.\n\nBut he will have discovered himself who speaks: \u201cThis is my good and evil.\u201d With this he has silenced the mole and dwarf who says: \u201cGood for all, evil for all.\u201d\n\nIndeed, nor do I like those for whom each thing is good and this world seems the very best. Such types I call the all-complacent.\n\nAll-complacency that knows how to taste everything \u2013 that is not the best taste! I honor the obstinate, choosy tongues and stomachs, which have learned to say \u201cI\u201d and \u201cYes\u201d and \u201cNo.\u201d\n\nBut chewing and digesting everything \u2013 that is truly the swine\u2019s style! To always say hee-yaw \u2013 only the ass learned that, and whoever is of its spirit! \u2013\n\nDeep yellow and hot red: this is what my taste wants \u2013 it mixes blood into all colors. But whoever whitewashes his house betrays to me a whitewashed soul.\n\nOne is in love with mummies, the other with ghosts; and both alike hostile to all flesh and blood \u2013 oh how they both offend my taste! For I love blood.\n\nAnd I do not want to dwell and dawdle where everyone spits and spews: that is just my taste \u2013 I would rather live among thieves and perjurers. No one carries gold in their mouth.\n\nBut even more repugnant to me are all lick spittles; and the most revolting animal of a human being that I found I christened \u201cparasite\u201d: it did not want to love and yet wanted to live off love.\n\nDamned I call all those who have only one choice: to become evil beasts or evil beast tamers: I would not build my hut among them.\n\nDamned I also call those who must always wait \u2013 they offend my taste: all the publicans and grocers and kings and other shop- and country-keepers.\n\nIndeed, I too learned to wait, and thoroughly \u2013 but only to wait for myself. And above all I learned to stand and walk and run and leap and climb and dance.\n\nBut this is my teaching; whoever wants to fly someday must first learn to stand and walk and run and climb and dance \u2013 one cannot fly one\u2019s way to flight!\n\nOn rope ladders I learned to climb to many a window, with agile legs I climbed up high masts: to sit atop tall masts of knowledge struck me as no small bliss \u2013\n\n\u2013 to flicker like small flames atop tall masts; a small light, to be sure, and yet a great comfort for stranded sailors and shipwreck survivors!\n\nBy many a trail and manner I came to my truth; not on one ladder did I climb to my height, where my eye roams out into my distance.\n\nAnd I never liked asking the way \u2013 that always offended my taste! I preferred to question and try the ways myself.\n\nAll my coming and going was a trying and questioning \u2013 and truly, one must also learn to answer such questioning! That, however \u2013 is my taste:\n\n\u2013 not good, not bad, but my taste, of which I am no longer shameful nor secretive.\n\n\u201cThis \u2013 it turns out \u2013 is my way \u2013 where is yours?\u201d \u2013 That is how I answered those who asked me \u201cthe way.\u201d The way after all \u2013 it does not exist!\n\nThus spoke Zarathustra."}, "id": 72}, {"data": {"uuid": "8fef4482-0c22-468b-9a2a-b76a8d32d3ee", "user": 1, "title": "On Old and New Tablets", "created_on": "2023-05-10 15:55:49.153202+00:00", "updated_on": "2023-05-10 15:55:49.191212+00:00", "article_html": "<h2>On Old and New Tablets</h2><h3>1</h3><p>Here I sit and wait, old broken tablets around me and also new tablets only partially written upon. When will my hour come?</p><p>\u2013 the hour of my going down, going under: for I want to return to mankind once more.</p><p>This is what I wait for now; signs must come to me first that it is my hour \u2013 namely the laughing lion with a swarm of doves.</p><p>Meanwhile I talk to myself as one who has time. No one tells me anything new, and so I tell myself to myself.</p><h3>2</h3><p>When I came to mankind, I found them sitting on an old conceit: they all conceited to have known for a long time what is good and evil for humanity.</p><p>To them all talk of virtue seemed an old worn out thing; and whoever wanted to sleep well even spoke about \u201cgood\u201d and \u201cevil\u201d before going to bed.</p><p>I disturbed this sleepiness when I taught: what is good and evil no one knows yet \u2013 except for the creator!</p><p>He, however, is the one who creates a goal for mankind and gives the earth its meaning and its future: This one first creates the possibility that something can be good and evil.</p><p>I told them to overthrow their old professorial chairs wherever that old conceit had sat; I told them to laugh at their great masters of virtue and their saints and poets and world redeemers.</p><p>I told them to laugh at their gloomy wise men and at any who ever perched in warning, like black scarecrows, in the tree of life.</p><p>I sat down alongside their great road of graves and even among carrion and vultures \u2013 and I laughed at all their yesteryear and its rotting, decaying glory.</p><p>Indeed, like preachers of repentance and fools I screamed bloody murder about all their great and small \u2013 that their best is so very small! that their most evil is so very small! \u2013 I had to laugh.</p><p>Thus my wild longing cried and laughed out of me, born in the mountains, a wild wisdom surely! \u2013 my great, winging, roaring longing.</p><p>And often it swept me off my feet and up and away, in the midst of my laughter, where I flew quivering, an arrow, through sun-drunken delight:</p><p>\u2013 off into distant futures not yet glimpsed in dreams, into hotter souths than any artist ever dreamed of; there, where dancing gods are ashamed of all clothing:</p><p>\u2013 so that I must speak in parables and limp and stutter like the poets; and truly, I am ashamed that I must still be a poet! \u2013</p><p>Where all becoming seemed to me the dance of gods and the mischief of gods, and the world seemed unloosed and frolicsome and as though it were fleeing back to itself:</p><p>\u2013 as an eternal fleeing from and seeking each other again of many gods, as the blissful contradicting, again-hearing, again-nearing each other of many gods:</p><p>Where all time seemed to me a blissful mockery of moments, where necessity was freedom itself, which played blissfully with the sting of freedom:</p><p>Where I once again found my old devil and arch-enemy, the spirit of gravity, and everything he created: compulsion, statute, necessity and consequence and purpose and will and good and evil:</p><p>For must there not exist something over which one dances, dances away? Must not, for the sake of the light and the lightest \u2013 moles and heavy dwarves exist? \u2013</p><h3>3</h3><p>It was there too that I picked up the word \u201coverman\u201d along the way, and that the human is something that must be overcome,</p><p>\u2013 that human being is a bridge and not an end; counting itself blessed for its noon and evening as the way to new dawns:</p><p>\u2013 the Zarathustra-words about the great noon, and whatever else I suspended above mankind like purple second sunsets.</p><p>Truly, I allowed them to see new stars together with new nights; and over clouds and day and night I even spread laughter like a colorful tent.</p><p>I taught them all my creating and striving: to carry together into one what is fragment in mankind and riddle and horrid accident \u2013</p><p>\u2013 as poet, riddle guesser and redeemer of chance I taught them to work on the future, and to creatively redeem everything that was.</p><p>To redeem what is past in mankind and to recreate all \u201cIt was\u201d until the will speaks: \u201cBut I wanted it so! I shall want it so \u2013\u201d</p><p>This I told them was redemption, this alone I taught them to call redemption. \u2013</p><p>Now I wait for my redemption \u2013 so that I can go to them for the last time.</p><p>And I want to go to mankind one more time: among them I want to go under, dying I want to give them my richest gift!</p><p>I learned this from the sun when it goes down, the super-rich one: it pours gold into the sea from its inexhaustible wealth \u2013</p><p>\u2013 such that even the poorest fisherman rows with golden oars! Because I saw this once and did not tire of my tears as I gazed on. \u2013</p><p>Zarathustra too wants to go under like the sun; now he sits and waits, old broken tablets around him and also new tablets \u2013 partially written upon.</p><h3>4</h3><p>Look here, here is a new tablet, but where are my brothers to help me carry it to the valley and into hearts of flesh?</p><p>This is what my great love of the farthest demands: do not spare your neighbor! Human being is something that must be overcome.</p><p>There are manifold ways and means of overcoming: you see to it! But only a jester thinks: \u201chuman being can also be leaped over.\u201d</p><p>Overcome yourself even in your neighbor; and you should not let anyone give you a right that you can rob for yourself !</p><p>What you do no one can do to you in turn. Observe, there is no retribution.</p><p>Whoever cannot command himself should obey. And though many a person can command himself, much is still missing before he also obeys himself !</p><h3>5</h3><p>This is how souls of the noble kind would have it: they want nothing for free, and life least of all.</p><p>Whoever is of the rabble wants to live for free; we others, however, to whom life gave itself \u2013 we always reflect on what we can best give in exchange!</p><p>And truly, it is a noble phrase that says: \u201cwhat life promises us, we want to keep \u2013 for life!\u201d</p><p>One should not want to enjoy where one gives nothing to enjoy. And, one should not want to enjoy!</p><p>Enjoyment and innocence, you see, are the most bashful things: both do not want to be sought. One should have them \u2013 but one should sooner seek guilt and suffering! \u2013</p><h3>6</h3><p>Oh my brothers, whoever is a firstborn is always sacrificed. But now we are the firstborns.</p><p>We all bleed on secret sacrificial altars; we all burn and broil in honor of old idols.</p><p>Our best is still young; that tempts old gums. Our flesh is tender, our hide is mere lambskin \u2013 how could we not tempt old idol priests!</p><p>Even in ourselves he still lives, the old idol priest, who roasts up our best for his banquet. Oh my brothers, how could firstborn not be sacrifices!</p><p>But our kind wants it so; and I love those who do not want to preserve themselves. Those who are going under I love with my whole love: because they are going over. \u2013</p><h3>7</h3><p>To be true \u2013 this few can do! And whoever can, does not yet want to! But least of all the good can do it.</p><p>Oh these good! \u2013 Good people never speak the truth; for the spirit, being good in this manner is a disease.</p><p>They give way, these good, they give themselves up, their heart repeats words, their ground obeys; but whoever obeys, he does not hear himself !</p><p>Everything that the good call evil must come together, in order to give birth to one truth; oh my brothers, are you also evil enough for this truth?</p><p>Audacious daring, long mistrust, the cruel no, surfeit, the cutting into what is alive \u2013 how rarely this comes together! But from such semen \u2013 truth is begotten!</p><p>Side by side with bad conscience all science has grown so far. Break, break me these old tablets, you seekers of knowledge!</p><h3>8</h3><p>If timbers span the water, if footbridges and railings leap over the river, then surely the one who says \u201cEverything is in flux\u201d has no credibility.</p><p>Instead, even the dummies contradict him. \u201cWhat?\u201d say the dummies, \u201ceverything is supposed to be in flux? But the timbers and the railings are over the river!</p><p>Over the river everything is firm, all the values of things, the bridges, concepts, all \u2018good\u2019 and \u2018evil\u2019 \u2013 all of this is firm!\u201d \u2013</p><p>But when the hard winter comes, the beast tamer of rivers, then even the wittiest learn to mistrust, and, sure enough, then not only the dummies say: \u201cShould everything not \u2013 stand still?\u201d</p><p>\u201cBasically everything stands still\u201d \u2013 that is a real winter doctrine, a good thing for sterile times, a good comfort for hibernators and stove huggers.</p><p>\u201cBasically everything stands still\u201d \u2013 but against this preaches the thaw wind!</p><p>The thaw wind, a bull that is no plowing bull \u2013 a raging bull, a destroyer that breaks ice with its wrathful horns! But ice \u2013 breaks footbridges!</p><p>Yes my brothers, is everything not now in flux? Have all railings and footbridges not fallen into the water? Who could still hang on to \u201cgood\u201d and \u201cevil\u201d?</p><p>\u201cWoe to us! Hail to us! The thaw wind is blowing!\u201d \u2013 Preach me this, oh my brothers, in all the streets!</p><h3>9</h3><p>There is an old delusion called good and evil. So far the wheel of this delusion has revolved around soothsayers and astrologers.</p><p>Once people believed in soothsayers and astrologers, and therefore they believed \u201cEverything is fate: you should, because you must!\u201d</p><p>Then later people mistrusted all soothsayers and astrologers, and there- fore they believed \u201cEverything is freedom: you can, because you want to!\u201d</p><p>Yes, my brothers, so far we have merely deluded ourselves, but not known about the stars and the future, and therefore we have merely deluded ourselves, but not known about good and evil!</p><h3>10</h3><p>\u201cThou shalt not rob! Thou shalt not kill!\u201d \u2013 such words were once held holy; before them one bent the knee, bowed the head and removed one\u2019s shoes.</p><p>But I ask you: where in the world have there ever been better robbers and killers than such holy words?</p><p>Is there not in all life itself \u2013 robbing and killing? And for such words to have been called holy, was truth itself not \u2013 killed?</p><p>Or was it a sermon of death that pronounced holy what contradicted and contravened all life? \u2013 Yes my brothers, break, break me the old tablets!</p><h3>11</h3><p>This is my pity for everything past, that I see it is abandoned \u2013</p><p>\u2013 abandoned to the favor, the spirit, the madness of each generation that comes along, and interprets everything that was as the bridge to itself!</p><p>A great despot could come along, a shrewd monster, who with his favor and disfavor could force and forge the whole past, until it became a bridge to him, and omen and herald and harbinger.</p><p>But this is the other danger and my other pity: whoever is of the rabble, their remembrance goes no further back than their grandfather \u2013 and with their grandfather time ends.</p><p>Thus all the past is abandoned; because it could happen one day that the rabble would become ruler and in its shallow water all time would drown.</p><p>Therefore, my brothers, we need a new nobility, which is the adversary of all rabble and all despotic rule and which writes anew the word \u201cnoble\u201d on new tablets.</p><p>Many noble ones are needed, to be sure, and many kinds of noble ones for nobility to exist! Or, as I once spoke in parables: \u201cPrecisely that is godliness, that there are gods but no God!\u201d</p><h3>12</h3><p>Oh my brothers, I consecrate and conduct you to a new nobility: you shall be my begetters and growers and sowers of the future \u2013</p><p>\u2013 to be sure, not to a nobility that you could buy like the shopkeepers and with shopkeepers\u2019 gold, for everything that has a price has little value.</p><p>Not where you come from shall constitute your honor from now on, but instead where you are going! Your will and your foot, which wants to go over and beyond yourself \u2013 let that constitute your new honor!</p><p>Certainly not that you served a prince \u2013 what do princes matter anymore! Or that you became a bulwark for what stands, to make it to stand more firmly!</p><p>Not that your kinfolk became courtiers at court, and learned to stand long hours like a colorful flamingo in shallow ponds.</p><p>\u2013 For being able to stand is a merit among courtiers; and all courtiers believe that part of blessedness after death is \u2013 being allowed to sit!</p><p>Nor that a spirit they called holy led your forefathers to promised lands, which I do not praise; because where the worst of all trees grew, the cross \u2013 there is nothing to praise about that land!</p><p>And truly, wherever this \u201choly ghost\u201d led its knights, in such cru- sades goats and geese and pious crisscrossing contradictors ran in front !</p><p>Oh my brothers, your nobility should not look back, but out there! You should be exiles from all father- and forefatherlands!</p><p>You should love your children\u2019s land; let this love be your new nobility \u2013 the undiscovered land in the furthest sea! For that land I command your sails to seek and seek!</p><p>You should make it up in your children that you are the children of your fathers; thus you should redeem all that is past! This new tablet I place above you!</p><h3>13</h3><p>\u201cWhy live? All is vain! Life \u2013 that is threshing straw; life \u2013 that is burning oneself and yet not getting warm.\u201d</p><p>Such archaic babble still passes for \u201cwisdom\u201d; but it is honored more highly because it smells old and musty. Even mustiness ennobles.</p><p>Children might speak like this: they fear fire because it burned them! There is much childishness in the old books of wisdom.</p><p>And whoever is always \u201cthreshing straw,\u201d why should he be allowed to revile threshing? One really should muzzle such oxen!</p><p>Such people sit down at the table and bring nothing along, not even a good appetite \u2013 and now they revile saying \u201cAll is vain!\u201d</p><p>But eating and drinking well, my brothers, is really no vain art! Break, break me the tablets of the never-glad!</p><h3>14</h3><p>\u201cTo the clean all is clean\u201d \u2013 that is what folks say. But I say to you: \u201cto swine all becomes swine!\u201d</p><p>This is why the rapturous and the head-hangers, whose hearts also hang down, preach: \u201cThe world itself is a filthy monster.\u201d</p><p>Because they are all unclean in spirit, especially those who have neither rest nor respite, unless they see the world from the hinter side \u2013 these hinterworldlings!</p><p>To their faces I say, even if it does not sound kind: the world resembles a human being in that it has a behind \u2013 that much is true!</p><p>There is much filth in the world: that much is true! But the world itself is not therefore a filthy monster!</p><p>There is wisdom in the fact that much in the world smells foul: nausea itself creates wings and water-divining powers!</p><p>Even in the best there is something that nauseates; and the best is still something that must be overcome!</p><p>Yes my brothers, there is much wisdom in the fact that there is much filth in the world! \u2013</p><h3>15</h3><p>Such sayings I heard the pious hinterworldlings speak to their conscience, and truly, without malice and falseness \u2013 even though there is nothing more false in the world, nor more malicious.</p><p>\u201cJust let the world be the world! Do not lift so much as a finger against it!\u201d</p><p>\u201cIf someone wants to strangle and stab and slice and dice the people, let him; do not lift so much as a finger against it! That way they will yet learn to renounce the world.\u201d</p><p>\u201cAnd your own reason \u2013 this you yourself should smother and strangle, because it is a reason of this world \u2013 that way you yourself will learn to renounce the world.\u201d \u2013</p><p>\u2013 Break, break me these old tablets of the pious, my brothers! Gainsay me the sayings of the world slanderers!</p><h3>16</h3><p>\u201cWhoever learns much, he forgets all vehement desire\u201d \u2013 today this is whispered throughout all dark lanes.</p><p>\u201cWisdom makes weary, nothing is worth it; thou shalt not desire!\u201d \u2013 this new tablet I found hanging even in the open markets.</p><p>Break, my brothers, break me this new tablet too! The world-weary hung it there and the preachers of death, and the jailers as well; just look, it too is a sermon for slavery!</p><p>The reason they have such ruined stomachs is because they learned badly and not what was best, and everything too early and everything too fast; and they ate badly \u2013</p><p>\u2013 you see, their spirit is a ruined stomach: it recommends death! Because truly, my brothers, the spirit is a stomach!</p><p>Life is a well of joy; but for those out of whom the ruined stomach speaks, the father of gloom, all wells are poisoned.</p><p>Knowing: that is joy to the lion-willed! But whoever has grown weary is himself merely being \u201cwilled,\u201d and all waves toss him around.</p><p>And so it always is with weak willed persons; they lose themselves along the way. And finally their own weariness asks: \u201cWhy did we ever embark on ways! It\u2019s all the same!\u201d</p><p>To their ears it is music when they hear preached: \u201cNothing is worth it! You shall not will!\u201d But this is a sermon for slavery.</p><p>Yes my brothers, as a fresh roaring wind Zarathustra comes to all who are weary of their way; many noses he will yet make sneeze!</p><p>My free breath also blows through walls, and down into prisons and imprisoned spirits!</p><p>Willing liberates because willing is creating: thus I teach. And you should learn only for creating!</p><p>And even this learning you shall first learn from me, namely learning-well! \u2013 He who has ears to hear, let him hear!</p><h3>17</h3><p>There sits the skiff \u2013 over there perhaps is the entryway to the great nothing. But who wants to board this \u201cperhaps\u201d?</p><p>None of you wants to board the death skiff! Then why do you want to be world-weary!</p><p>World-weary! And you have not even become earth-alienated yet! I found you still lusting for the earth, still in love with your own earthly weariness!</p><p>Not for nothing does your lip hang \u2013 a little earthly wish still sits on it! And in your eye \u2013 doesn\u2019t a little cloud of unforgotten earthly joy float there?</p><p>There are many good inventions on earth, some useful, others pleasant, for whose sake the earth is lovable.</p><p>And some of what is there has been invented so well that it is like a woman\u2019s breasts: useful and pleasant at the same time.</p><p>But you world-weary! You earth-lazy! You should be flogged with switches! With floggings you should be made to step lively again.</p><p>After all, if you are not misfits and moribund wretches of whom the earth is weary, then you are sly sloths or nibbling, creeping pleasure cats. And if you do not want to run again with gusto, then you should \u2013 pass away!</p><p>One should not try to be a physician for the incurable: thus Zarathustra teaches \u2013 and so you should pass away!</p><p>But it takes more courage to make an end than to make a new verse: that all physicians and poets know.</p><h3>18</h3><p>Oh my brothers, there are tablets created by weariness, and tablets created by rotten laziness; even though they talk the same, still they want to be heard differently.</p><p>See this languishing specimen here! He is merely one span away from his goal, but out of weariness he has laid himself defiantly here in the dust \u2013 this valiant man!</p><p>Out of weariness he yawns at the road and the earth and the goal and himself; not one more step will he take \u2013 this valiant one!</p><p>Now the sun burns on him and the dogs lick at his sweat; but he lies there in his defiance and would rather die of thirst \u2013</p><p>\u2013 die of thirst one span away from his goal! Truly, you will yet have to drag him to his heaven by the hair \u2013 this hero!</p><p>Better still, just let him lie where he has laid himself so that sleep can come to him, the comforter, with its cooling rushing rain:</p><p>Let him lie until he awakens on his own \u2013 until he renounces all weariness on his own and whatever weariness taught through him!</p><p>Only, my brothers, chase the dogs away from him, the lazy creepers and the whole raving rout \u2013</p><p>\u2013 the whole raving rout of \u201cthe educated\u201d that feasts on the sweat of every hero!</p><h3>19</h3><p>I draw circles around me and sacred borders; ever fewer climb with me on ever higher mountains \u2013 I build a range of mountains out of ever more sacred mountains.</p><p>But wherever you may climb with me, my brothers, see to it that a parasite does not climb with you!</p><p>Parasite: that is a worm, a crawling writhing worm that wants to glut itself on your infected nicks and niches.</p><p>And its art consists in guessing where climbing souls are weary; in your grief and dismay, in your tender modesty it builds its disgusting nest.</p><p>Where the strong is weak, the noble one all too mild \u2013 in that place it builds its disgusting nest; the parasite lives where the great person has little nicks and niches.</p><p>What is the highest species of all being and what is the least? The parasite is the least of species, but whoever is of the highest species nourishes the most parasites.</p><p>After all, the soul that has the longest ladder and reaches down farthest \u2013 how could it not have the most parasites clinging to it?</p><p>The most encompassing soul, which can run and stray and roam farthest within itself; the most necessary soul, which out of joy plunges itself into chance \u2013</p><p>\u2013 the soul that loves being, but submerges into becoming; the having soul that wants to rise to willing and desiring \u2013</p><p>\u2013 the soul that flees itself and catches up to itself in the widest circle; the wisest soul which folly persuades most sweetly \u2013</p><p>\u2013 the one that loves itself most, in which all things have their current and recurrent and ebb and flow \u2013 indeed, how could the highest soul not have the worst parasites?</p><h3>20</h3><p>Oh my brothers, am I perhaps cruel? But I say: if something is falling, one should also give it a push!</p><p>Everything of today \u2013 it is falling, it is failing: who would want to stop it! But I \u2013 I want to push it too!</p><p>Do you know the kind of lust that rolls stones down into steep depths? \u2013 These people of today; just look at how they roll into my depths!</p><p>I am a prelude of better players, my brothers! An exemplary play! Act according to my example!</p><p>And whomever you cannot teach to fly, him you should teach \u2013 to fall faster!</p><h3>21</h3><p>I love the valiant, but it is not enough to be a fierce combatant \u2013 one must also know whom to combat!</p><p>And often there is more valiance in someone controlling himself and passing by, so that he saves himself for the worthier enemy!</p><p>You should have only those enemies whom you hate, but not enemies to despise; you must be proud of your enemy: this I taught you already once before.</p><p>For the worthier enemy, my friends, you should save yourselves, and therefore you must pass by much \u2013</p><p>\u2013 especially pass by much rabble that thunders in your ears about folk and peoples.</p><p>Keep your eye clear of their pros and cons! There is much justice, much injustice here; whoever watches becomes angry.</p><p>Look around, beat them down \u2013 it\u2019s all the same here; therefore go away into the woods and lay your swords to sleep!</p><p>Go your ways! And let folk and peoples go theirs! \u2013 dark ways, to be sure, on which not a single hope flashes anymore!</p><p>Let the shopkeeper rule where all that is left to glitter \u2013 is shopkeepers\u2019 gold! The time of kings is no more; what calls itself a people today deserves no kings.</p><p>Just look at how these peoples themselves do the same as the shopkeepers; they pluck themselves the tiniest advantage from any dustpan!</p><p>They lie in wait for one another, they look in hate at one another \u2013 this they call \u201cgood neighbors.\u201d Oh happy distant time when a people said to themselves: \u201cI want to be ruler over peoples!\u201d</p><p>For the best should rule, my brothers, and the best also want to rule! And wherever the teaching says differently, there \u2013 the best are missing.</p><h3>22</h3><p>If they had bread for free, oh no! What would they clamor for! Their sustainment \u2013 that is their real entertainment, and they should have it hard!</p><p>They are beasts of prey: in their \u201cworking\u201d \u2013 preying is there too; in their \u201cearning\u201d \u2013 outwitting is there too! Therefore they should have it hard!</p><p>They should become better beasts of prey, more subtle, more clever, more human-like: the human being, after all, is the best beast of prey.</p><p>Human beings have already successfully preyed upon the virtues of all animals; this is because human beings have had the hardest time of all animals.</p><p>Only the birds are above him. And if human beings were to learn even to fly, watch out! How high \u2013 would his lust to prey fly!</p><h3>23</h3><p>This is how I want man and woman: fit for war the one, fit for bearing children the other, but both fit to dance in head and limb.</p><p>And let each day be a loss to us on which we did not dance once! And let each truth be false to us which was not greeted by one laugh!</p><h3>24</h3><p>In taking your wedding vows \u2013 see to it that you are not making your bedding vows. Vowing too quickly results in \u2013 breaking vows! And better vow breaking than vow bending and vow pretending! A woman once said to me: \u201cSure, I broke my wedding vows, but first my wedding vows broke \u2013 me!\u201d</p><p>The worst of the vengeful I always found to be the mismatched couples: they take it out on the whole world that they are no longer singles.</p><p>This is why I want honest people to speak honestly to one another: \u201cWe love each other; let us see to it that we keep loving each other! Or did we promise by mistake?\u201d</p><p>\u2013 \u201cGive us a trial period and a small marriage, so that we can see whether we are fit for a big marriage! It is a big thing to always be in twos!\u201d</p><p>Thus I counsel all honest people; and what then would my love for the overman be, and for everything else that is to come, if I counseled and conveyed otherwise!</p><p>Not merely to reproduce, but instead to surproduce \u2013 to that goal, my brothers, may the garden of marriage help you!</p><h3>25</h3><p>Whoever has become wise about ancient origins will surely, in the end, seek new wells of the future and new origins.</p><p>Yes my brothers, it will not be overly long and new peoples will originate and new wells will roar down into new depths.</p><p>An earthquake, after all \u2013 it buries many wells, it causes much dying of thirst: it also brings to light inner powers and secrets.</p><p>An earthquake reveals new wells. In an earthquake of ancient peoples new wells break out.</p><p>And whoever cries out there: \u201cLook, here is a fountain for many who thirst, a heart for many who long, a will for many tools\u201d \u2013 around him gathers a people, that is: many who try.</p><p>Who can command, who must obey \u2013 here it is tried! Indeed, with what long searching and guessing and lack of success and learning and trying again!</p><p>Human society: it is an experiment, this I teach \u2013 a long search: but it searches for the commander! \u2013</p><p>\u2013 an experiment, oh my brothers! And not a \u201ccontract!\u201d Break, break me such words of the soft hearted and half-and-halfs!</p><h3>26</h3><p>My brothers! In whom does the greatest danger lie for all of future humanity? Is it not in the good and the just?</p><p>\u2013 is it not in those who speak and feel in their hearts: \u201cWe already know what is good and just, and we have it too; woe to any who still search here!\u201d</p><p>And whatever harm the evil may do, the harm of the good is the most harmful harm!</p><p>And whatever harm the world slanderers may do, the harm of the good is the most harmful harm!</p><p>My brothers, there was a man who once looked into the hearts of the good and the just, and he spoke: \u201cThey are pharisees.\u201d But he was not understood.</p><p>The good and the just themselves were not permitted to understand him: their spirit is imprisoned in their good conscience. The stupidity of the good is unfathomably clever.</p><p>But this is the truth: the good must be pharisees \u2013 they have no choice!</p><p>The good must crucify the one who invents his own virtue! This is the truth!</p><p>The second one, however, who discovered their land, the land, hearts and soil of the good and just: he was the one who asked: \u201cWhom do they hate the most?\u201d</p><p>The creator they hate the most; he who breaks tablets and old values, the breaker \u2013 him they call the lawbreaker.</p><p>Because the good, you see \u2013 they can not create: they are always the beginning of the end \u2013</p><p>\u2013 they crucify the one who writes new values on new tablets, they sacrifice the future to themselves \u2013 they crucify all future huma- nity!</p><p>The good \u2013 they were always the beginning of the end. \u2013</p><h3>27</h3><p>Oh my brothers, have you even understood these words? And what I once said about the \u201clast human being?\u201d \u2013</p><p>In whom does the greatest danger lie for all of future humanity? Is it not in the good and the just?</p><p>Break, break me the good and the just! \u2013 Oh my brothers, have you even understood these words?</p><h3>28</h3><p>You flee from me? You are frightened? You tremble before these words?</p><p>My brothers, when I told you to break the good and the tablets of the good, then for the first time I launched mankind onto their high seas.</p><p>And only now the great fright comes to them, the great looking-around oneself, the great sickness, the great nausea, the great seasickness.</p><p>False coasts and false securities were taught you by the good; in the lies of the good you were born and bielded. Everything has been duplicitous and twisted from the ground up by the good.</p><p>But whoever discovered the land \u201chuman being\u201d also discovered the land \u201chuman future.\u201d Now you will be seafarers, brave and patient!</p><p>Walk upright for once, my brothers, learn to walk upright! The sea is stormy: Many want to right themselves again on you.</p><p>The sea is stormy: Everything is in the sea. Well then! Well now! You old salts!</p><p>What fatherland! There our helm wants to steer, where our children\u2019s land is! Out there, stormier than the sea, storms our great longing! \u2013</p><h3>29</h3><p>\u201cWhy so hard!\u201d \u2013 the kitchen coal once said to the diamond. \u201cAre we not close relatives?\u201d</p><p>Why so soft? Oh my brothers, this I ask you: for are you not \u2013 my brothers?</p><p>Why so soft, so retiring and yielding? Why is there so much denying and denial in your hearts? And so little destiny in your gazes?</p><p>And if you do not want to be destinies and inexorable, how could you triumph with me?</p><p>And if your hardness does not want to flash and undo and cut through, how could you one day create with me?</p><p>The creators are hard after all. And it must seem like bliss to you to press your hand upon millennia as if upon wax \u2013</p><p>\u2013 bliss to write upon the will of millennia as if upon bronze \u2013 harder than bronze, more noble than bronze. Only the most noble is perfectly hard.</p><p>This new tablet, my brothers, I place above you: become hard! \u2013</p><h3>30</h3><p>Oh you my will! You turning point of all need, you point of my necessity! Preserve me from all small victories!</p><p>You ordaining of my soul, that I call destiny! You in-me, over-me! Preserve and save me for a great destiny!</p><p>And your ultimate greatness, my will, save that for your ultimate \u2013 that you be inexorable in your victory! Indeed, who was not defeated in his victory!</p><p>Indeed, whose eye did not darken in this drunken twilight! Indeed, whose foot did not stagger and forget how to stand in victory!</p><p>\u2013 That I may one day be ready and ripe in the great noon; ready and ripe like glowing bronze, clouds pregnant with lightning and swelling udders of milk \u2013</p><p>\u2013 ready for myself and for my most hidden will; a bow burning for its arrow, an arrow burning for its star \u2013</p><p>\u2013 a star ready and ripe in its noon, glowing, skewered, blissful with annihilating arrows of the sun \u2013</p><p>\u2013 a sun itself and an inexorable will of the sun, ready for annihilating in victory!</p><p>Oh will, turning point of all need, you my point of necessity! Save me for a great victory! \u2013</p><p>Thus spoke Zarathustra.</p>", "article_json": {"type": "doc", "content": [{"type": "heading", "attrs": {"level": 2}, "content": [{"text": "On Old and New Tablets", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "heading", "attrs": {"level": 3}, "content": [{"text": "1", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "content": [{"text": "Here I sit and wait, old broken tablets around me and also new tablets only partially written upon.
