Indeed, who was not defeated in his victory!", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "content": [{"text": "Indeed, whose eye did not darken in this drunken twilight! Indeed, whose foot did not stagger and forget how to stand in victory!", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "content": [{"text": "\u2013 That I may one day be ready and ripe in the great noon; ready and ripe like glowing bronze, clouds pregnant with lightning and swelling udders of milk \u2013", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "content": [{"text": "\u2013 ready for myself and for my most hidden will; a bow burning for its arrow, an arrow burning for its star \u2013", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "content": [{"text": "\u2013 a star ready and ripe in its noon, glowing, skewered, blissful with annihilating arrows of the sun \u2013", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "content": [{"text": "\u2013 a sun itself and an inexorable will of the sun, ready for annihilating in victory!", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "content": [{"text": "Oh will, turning point of all need, you my point of necessity! Save me for a great victory! \u2013", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "content": [{"text": "Thus spoke Zarathustra.", "type": "text"}]}]}, "article_text": "On Old and New Tablets\r\n\r\n1\r\n\r\nHere I sit and wait, old broken tablets around me and also new tablets only partially written upon. When will my hour come?\r\n\r\n\u2013 the hour of my going down, going under: for I want to return to mankind once more.\r\n\r\nThis is what I wait for now; signs must come to me first that it is my hour \u2013 namely the laughing lion with a swarm of doves.\r\n\r\nMeanwhile I talk to myself as one who has time. No one tells me anything new, and so I tell myself to myself.\r\n\r\n2\r\n\r\nWhen I came to mankind, I found them sitting on an old conceit: they all conceited to have known for a long time what is good and evil for humanity.\r\n\r\nTo them all talk of virtue seemed an old worn out thing; and whoever wanted to sleep well even spoke about \u201cgood\u201d and \u201cevil\u201d before going to bed.\r\n\r\nI disturbed this sleepiness when I taught: what is good and evil no one knows yet \u2013 except for the creator!\r\n\r\nHe, however, is the one who creates a goal for mankind and gives the earth its meaning and its future: This one first creates the possibility that something can be good and evil.\r\n\r\nI told them to overthrow their old professorial chairs wherever that old conceit had sat; I told them to laugh at their great masters of virtue and their saints and poets and world redeemers.\r\n\r\nI told them to laugh at their gloomy wise men and at any who ever perched in warning, like black scarecrows, in the tree of life.\r\n\r\nI sat down alongside their great road of graves and even among carrion and vultures \u2013 and I laughed at all their yesteryear and its rotting, decaying glory.\r\n\r\nIndeed, like preachers of repentance and fools I screamed bloody murder about all their great and small \u2013 that their best is so very small! that their most evil is so very small! \u2013 I had to laugh.\r\n\r\nThus my wild longing cried and laughed out of me, born in the mountains, a wild wisdom surely! \u2013 my great, winging, roaring longing.\r\n\r\nAnd often it swept me off my feet and up and away, in the midst of my laughter, where I flew quivering, an arrow, through sun-drunken delight:\r\n\r\n\u2013 off into distant futures not yet glimpsed in dreams, into hotter souths than any artist ever dreamed of; there, where dancing gods are ashamed of all clothing:\r\n\r\n\u2013 so that I must speak in parables and limp and stutter like the poets; and truly, I am ashamed that I must still be a poet! \u2013\r\n\r\nWhere all becoming seemed to me the dance of gods and the mischief of gods, and the world seemed unloosed and frolicsome and as though it were fleeing back to itself:\r\n\r\n\u2013 as an eternal fleeing from and seeking each other again of many gods, as the blissful contradicting, again-hearing, again-nearing each other of many gods:\r\n\r\nWhere all time seemed to me a blissful mockery of moments, where necessity was freedom itself, which played blissfully with the sting of freedom:\r\n\r\nWhere I once again found my old devil and arch-enemy, the spirit of gravity, and everything he created: compulsion, statute, necessity and consequence and purpose and will and good and evil:\r\n\r\nFor must there not exist something over which one dances, dances away? Must not, for the sake of the light and the lightest \u2013 moles and heavy dwarves exist? \u2013\r\n\r\n3\r\n\r\nIt was there too that I picked up the word \u201coverman\u201d along the way, and that the human is something that must be overcome,\r\n\r\n\u2013 that human being is a bridge and not an end; counting itself blessed for its noon and evening as the way to new dawns:\r\n\r\n\u2013 the Zarathustra-words about the great noon, and whatever else I suspended above mankind like purple second sunsets.\r\n\r\nTruly, I allowed them to see new stars together with new nights; and over clouds and day and night I even spread laughter like a colorful tent.\r\n\r\nI taught them all my creating and striving: to carry together into one what is fragment in mankind and riddle and horrid accident \u2013\r\n\r\n\u2013 as poet, riddle guesser and redeemer of chance I taught them to work on the future, and to creatively redeem everything that was.\r\n\r\nTo redeem what is past in mankind and to recreate all \u201cIt was\u201d until the will speaks: \u201cBut I wanted it so! I shall want it so \u2013\u201d\r\n\r\nThis I told them was redemption, this alone I taught them to call redemption. \u2013\r\n\r\nNow I wait for my redemption \u2013 so that I can go to them for the last time.\r\n\r\nAnd I want to go to mankind one more time: among them I want to go under, dying I want to give them my richest gift!\r\n\r\nI learned this from the sun when it goes down, the super-rich one: it pours gold into the sea from its inexhaustible wealth \u2013\r\n\r\n\u2013 such that even the poorest fisherman rows with golden oars! Because I saw this once and did not tire of my tears as I gazed on. \u2013\r\n\r\nZarathustra too wants to go under like the sun; now he sits and waits, old broken tablets around him and also new tablets \u2013 partially written upon.\r\n\r\n4\r\n\r\nLook here, here is a new tablet, but where are my brothers to help me carry it to the valley and into hearts of flesh?\r\n\r\nThis is what my great love of the farthest demands: do not spare your neighbor! Human being is something that must be overcome.\r\n\r\nThere are manifold ways and means of overcoming: you see to it! But only a jester thinks: \u201chuman being can also be leaped over.\u201d\r\n\r\nOvercome yourself even in your neighbor; and you should not let anyone give you a right that you can rob for yourself !\r\n\r\nWhat you do no one can do to you in turn. Observe, there is no retribution.\r\n\r\nWhoever cannot command himself should obey. And though many a person can command himself, much is still missing before he also obeys himself !\r\n\r\n5\r\n\r\nThis is how souls of the noble kind would have it: they want nothing for free, and life least of all.\r\n\r\nWhoever is of the rabble wants to live for free; we others, however, to whom life gave itself \u2013 we always reflect on what we can best give in exchange!\r\n\r\nAnd truly, it is a noble phrase that says: \u201cwhat life promises us, we want to keep \u2013 for life!\u201d\r\n\r\nOne should not want to enjoy where one gives nothing to enjoy. And, one should not want to enjoy!\r\n\r\nEnjoyment and innocence, you see, are the most bashful things: both do not want to be sought. One should have them \u2013 but one should sooner seek guilt and suffering! \u2013\r\n\r\n6\r\n\r\nOh my brothers, whoever is a firstborn is always sacrificed. But now we are the firstborns.\r\n\r\nWe all bleed on secret sacrificial altars; we all burn and broil in honor of old idols.\r\n\r\nOur best is still young; that tempts old gums. Our flesh is tender, our hide is mere lambskin \u2013 how could we not tempt old idol priests!\r\n\r\nEven in ourselves he still lives, the old idol priest, who roasts up our best for his banquet. Oh my brothers, how could firstborn not be sacrifices!\r\n\r\nBut our kind wants it so; and I love those who do not want to preserve themselves. Those who are going under I love with my whole love: because they are going over. \u2013\r\n\r\n7\r\n\r\nTo be true \u2013 this few can do! And whoever can, does not yet want to! But least of all the good can do it.\r\n\r\nOh these good! \u2013 Good people never speak the truth; for the spirit, being good in this manner is a disease.\r\n\r\nThey give way, these good, they give themselves up, their heart repeats words, their ground obeys; but whoever obeys, he does not hear himself !\r\n\r\nEverything that the good call evil must come together, in order to give birth to one truth; oh my brothers, are you also evil enough for this truth?\r\n\r\nAudacious daring, long mistrust, the cruel no, surfeit, the cutting into what is alive \u2013 how rarely this comes together! But from such semen \u2013 truth is begotten!\r\n\r\nSide by side with bad conscience all science has grown so far. Break, break me these old tablets, you seekers of knowledge!\r\n\r\n8\r\n\r\nIf timbers span the water, if footbridges and railings leap over the river, then surely the one who says \u201cEverything is in flux\u201d has no credibility.\r\n\r\nInstead, even the dummies contradict him. \u201cWhat?\u201d say the dummies, \u201ceverything is supposed to be in flux? But the timbers and the railings are over the river!\r\n\r\nOver the river everything is firm, all the values of things, the bridges, concepts, all \u2018good\u2019 and \u2018evil\u2019 \u2013 all of this is firm!\u201d \u2013\r\n\r\nBut when the hard winter comes, the beast tamer of rivers, then even the wittiest learn to mistrust, and, sure enough, then not only the dummies say: \u201cShould everything not \u2013 stand still?\u201d\r\n\r\n\u201cBasically everything stands still\u201d \u2013 that is a real winter doctrine, a good thing for sterile times, a good comfort for hibernators and stove huggers.\r\n\r\n\u201cBasically everything stands still\u201d \u2013 but against this preaches the thaw wind!\r\n\r\nThe thaw wind, a bull that is no plowing bull \u2013 a raging bull, a destroyer that breaks ice with its wrathful horns! But ice \u2013 breaks footbridges!\r\n\r\nYes my brothers, is everything not now in flux? Have all railings and footbridges not fallen into the water? Who could still hang on to \u201cgood\u201d and \u201cevil\u201d?\r\n\r\n\u201cWoe to us! Hail to us! The thaw wind is blowing!\u201d \u2013 Preach me this, oh my brothers, in all the streets!\r\n\r\n9\r\n\r\nThere is an old delusion called good and evil. So far the wheel of this delusion has revolved around soothsayers and astrologers.\r\n\r\nOnce people believed in soothsayers and astrologers, and therefore they believed \u201cEverything is fate: you should, because you must!\u201d\r\n\r\nThen later people mistrusted all soothsayers and astrologers, and there- fore they believed \u201cEverything is freedom: you can, because you want to!\u201d\r\n\r\nYes, my brothers, so far we have merely deluded ourselves, but not known about the stars and the future, and therefore we have merely deluded ourselves, but not known about good and evil!\r\n\r\n10\r\n\r\n\u201cThou shalt not rob! Thou shalt not kill!\u201d \u2013 such words were once held holy; before them one bent the knee, bowed the head and removed one\u2019s shoes.\r\n\r\nBut I ask you: where in the world have there ever been better robbers and killers than such holy words?\r\n\r\nIs there not in all life itself \u2013 robbing and killing? And for such words to have been called holy, was truth itself not \u2013 killed?\r\n\r\nOr was it a sermon of death that pronounced holy what contradicted and contravened all life? \u2013 Yes my brothers, break, break me the old tablets!\r\n\r\n11\r\n\r\nThis is my pity for everything past, that I see it is abandoned \u2013\r\n\r\n\u2013 abandoned to the favor, the spirit, the madness of each generation that comes along, and interprets everything that was as the bridge to itself!\r\n\r\nA great despot could come along, a shrewd monster, who with his favor and disfavor could force and forge the whole past, until it became a bridge to him, and omen and herald and harbinger.\r\n\r\nBut this is the other danger and my other pity: whoever is of the rabble, their remembrance goes no further back than their grandfather \u2013 and with their grandfather time ends.\r\n\r\nThus all the past is abandoned; because it could happen one day that the rabble would become ruler and in its shallow water all time would drown.\r\n\r\nTherefore, my brothers, we need a new nobility, which is the adversary of all rabble and all despotic rule and which writes anew the word \u201cnoble\u201d on new tablets.\r\n\r\nMany noble ones are needed, to be sure, and many kinds of noble ones for nobility to exist! Or, as I once spoke in parables: \u201cPrecisely that is godliness, that there are gods but no God!\u201d\r\n\r\n12\r\n\r\nOh my brothers, I consecrate and conduct you to a new nobility: you shall be my begetters and growers and sowers of the future \u2013\r\n\r\n\u2013 to be sure, not to a nobility that you could buy like the shopkeepers and with shopkeepers\u2019 gold, for everything that has a price has little value.\r\n\r\nNot where you come from shall constitute your honor from now on, but instead where you are going! Your will and your foot, which wants to go over and beyond yourself \u2013 let that constitute your new honor!\r\n\r\nCertainly not that you served a prince \u2013 what do princes matter anymore! Or that you became a bulwark for what stands, to make it to stand more firmly!\r\n\r\nNot that your kinfolk became courtiers at court, and learned to stand long hours like a colorful flamingo in shallow ponds.\r\n\r\n\u2013 For being able to stand is a merit among courtiers; and all courtiers believe that part of blessedness after death is \u2013 being allowed to sit!\r\n\r\nNor that a spirit they called holy led your forefathers to promised lands, which I do not praise; because where the worst of all trees grew, the cross \u2013 there is nothing to praise about that land!\r\n\r\nAnd truly, wherever this \u201choly ghost\u201d led its knights, in such cru- sades goats and geese and pious crisscrossing contradictors ran in front !\r\n\r\nOh my brothers, your nobility should not look back, but out there! You should be exiles from all father- and forefatherlands!\r\n\r\nYou should love your children\u2019s land; let this love be your new nobility \u2013 the undiscovered land in the furthest sea! For that land I command your sails to seek and seek!\r\n\r\nYou should make it up in your children that you are the children of your fathers; thus you should redeem all that is past! This new tablet I place above you!\r\n\r\n13\r\n\r\n\u201cWhy live? All is vain! Life \u2013 that is threshing straw; life \u2013 that is burning oneself and yet not getting warm.\u201d\r\n\r\nSuch archaic babble still passes for \u201cwisdom\u201d; but it is honored more highly because it smells old and musty. Even mustiness ennobles.\r\n\r\nChildren might speak like this: they fear fire because it burned them! There is much childishness in the old books of wisdom.\r\n\r\nAnd whoever is always \u201cthreshing straw,\u201d why should he be allowed to revile threshing? One really should muzzle such oxen!\r\n\r\nSuch people sit down at the table and bring nothing along, not even a good appetite \u2013 and now they revile saying \u201cAll is vain!\u201d\r\n\r\nBut eating and drinking well, my brothers, is really no vain art! Break, break me the tablets of the never-glad!\r\n\r\n14\r\n\r\n\u201cTo the clean all is clean\u201d \u2013 that is what folks say. But I say to you: \u201cto swine all becomes swine!\u201d\r\n\r\nThis is why the rapturous and the head-hangers, whose hearts also hang down, preach: \u201cThe world itself is a filthy monster.\u201d\r\n\r\nBecause they are all unclean in spirit, especially those who have neither rest nor respite, unless they see the world from the hinter side \u2013 these hinterworldlings!\r\n\r\nTo their faces I say, even if it does not sound kind: the world resembles a human being in that it has a behind \u2013 that much is true!\r\n\r\nThere is much filth in the world: that much is true! But the world itself is not therefore a filthy monster!\r\n\r\nThere is wisdom in the fact that much in the world smells foul: nausea itself creates wings and water-divining powers!\r\n\r\nEven in the best there is something that nauseates; and the best is still something that must be overcome!\r\n\r\nYes my brothers, there is much wisdom in the fact that there is much filth in the world! \u2013\r\n\r\n15\r\n\r\nSuch sayings I heard the pious hinterworldlings speak to their conscience, and truly, without malice and falseness \u2013 even though there is nothing more false in the world, nor more malicious.\r\n\r\n\u201cJust let the world be the world! Do not lift so much as a finger against it!\u201d\r\n\r\n\u201cIf someone wants to strangle and stab and slice and dice the people, let him; do not lift so much as a finger against it! That way they will yet learn to renounce the world.\u201d\r\n\r\n\u201cAnd your own reason \u2013 this you yourself should smother and strangle, because it is a reason of this world \u2013 that way you yourself will learn to renounce the world.\u201d \u2013\r\n\r\n\u2013 Break, break me these old tablets of the pious, my brothers! Gainsay me the sayings of the world slanderers!\r\n\r\n16\r\n\r\n\u201cWhoever learns much, he forgets all vehement desire\u201d \u2013 today this is whispered throughout all dark lanes.\r\n\r\n\u201cWisdom makes weary, nothing is worth it; thou shalt not desire!\u201d \u2013 this new tablet I found hanging even in the open markets.\r\n\r\nBreak, my brothers, break me this new tablet too! The world-weary hung it there and the preachers of death, and the jailers as well; just look, it too is a sermon for slavery!\r\n\r\nThe reason they have such ruined stomachs is because they learned badly and not what was best, and everything too early and everything too fast; and they ate badly \u2013\r\n\r\n\u2013 you see, their spirit is a ruined stomach: it recommends death! Because truly, my brothers, the spirit is a stomach!\r\n\r\nLife is a well of joy; but for those out of whom the ruined stomach speaks, the father of gloom, all wells are poisoned.\r\n\r\nKnowing: that is joy to the lion-willed! But whoever has grown weary is himself merely being \u201cwilled,\u201d and all waves toss him around.\r\n\r\nAnd so it always is with weak willed persons; they lose themselves along the way. And finally their own weariness asks: \u201cWhy did we ever embark on ways! It\u2019s all the same!\u201d\r\n\r\nTo their ears it is music when they hear preached: \u201cNothing is worth it! You shall not will!\u201d But this is a sermon for slavery.\r\n\r\nYes my brothers, as a fresh roaring wind Zarathustra comes to all who are weary of their way; many noses he will yet make sneeze!\r\n\r\nMy free breath also blows through walls, and down into prisons and imprisoned spirits!\r\n\r\nWilling liberates because willing is creating: thus I teach. And you should learn only for creating!\r\n\r\nAnd even this learning you shall first learn from me, namely learning-well! \u2013 He who has ears to hear, let him hear!\r\n\r\n17\r\n\r\nThere sits the skiff \u2013 over there perhaps is the entryway to the great nothing. But who wants to board this \u201cperhaps\u201d?\r\n\r\nNone of you wants to board the death skiff! Then why do you want to be world-weary!\r\n\r\nWorld-weary! And you have not even become earth-alienated yet! I found you still lusting for the earth, still in love with your own earthly weariness!\r\n\r\nNot for nothing does your lip hang \u2013 a little earthly wish still sits on it! And in your eye \u2013 doesn\u2019t a little cloud of unforgotten earthly joy float there?\r\n\r\nThere are many good inventions on earth, some useful, others pleasant, for whose sake the earth is lovable.\r\n\r\nAnd some of what is there has been invented so well that it is like a woman\u2019s breasts: useful and pleasant at the same time.\r\n\r\nBut you world-weary! You earth-lazy! You should be flogged with switches! With floggings you should be made to step lively again.\r\n\r\nAfter all, if you are not misfits and moribund wretches of whom the earth is weary, then you are sly sloths or nibbling, creeping pleasure cats. And if you do not want to run again with gusto, then you should \u2013 pass away!\r\n\r\nOne should not try to be a physician for the incurable: thus Zarathustra teaches \u2013 and so you should pass away!\r\n\r\nBut it takes more courage to make an end than to make a new verse: that all physicians and poets know.\r\n\r\n18\r\n\r\nOh my brothers, there are tablets created by weariness, and tablets created by rotten laziness; even though they talk the same, still they want to be heard differently.\r\n\r\nSee this languishing specimen here! He is merely one span away from his goal, but out of weariness he has laid himself defiantly here in the dust \u2013 this valiant man!\r\n\r\nOut of weariness he yawns at the road and the earth and the goal and himself; not one more step will he take \u2013 this valiant one!\r\n\r\nNow the sun burns on him and the dogs lick at his sweat; but he lies there in his defiance and would rather die of thirst \u2013\r\n\r\n\u2013 die of thirst one span away from his goal! Truly, you will yet have to drag him to his heaven by the hair \u2013 this hero!\r\n\r\nBetter still, just let him lie where he has laid himself so that sleep can come to him, the comforter, with its cooling rushing rain:\r\n\r\nLet him lie until he awakens on his own \u2013 until he renounces all weariness on his own and whatever weariness taught through him!\r\n\r\nOnly, my brothers, chase the dogs away from him, the lazy creepers and the whole raving rout \u2013\r\n\r\n\u2013 the whole raving rout of \u201cthe educated\u201d that feasts on the sweat of every hero!\r\n\r\n19\r\n\r\nI draw circles around me and sacred borders; ever fewer climb with me on ever higher mountains \u2013 I build a range of mountains out of ever more sacred mountains.\r\n\r\nBut wherever you may climb with me, my brothers, see to it that a parasite does not climb with you!\r\n\r\nParasite: that is a worm, a crawling writhing worm that wants to glut itself on your infected nicks and niches.\r\n\r\nAnd its art consists in guessing where climbing souls are weary; in your grief and dismay, in your tender modesty it builds its disgusting nest.\r\n\r\nWhere the strong is weak, the noble one all too mild \u2013 in that place it builds its disgusting nest; the parasite lives where the great person has little nicks and niches.\r\n\r\nWhat is the highest species of all being and what is the least? The parasite is the least of species, but whoever is of the highest species nourishes the most parasites.\r\n\r\nAfter all, the soul that has the longest ladder and reaches down farthest \u2013 how could it not have the most parasites clinging to it?\r\n\r\nThe most encompassing soul, which can run and stray and roam farthest within itself; the most necessary soul, which out of joy plunges itself into chance \u2013\r\n\r\n\u2013 the soul that loves being, but submerges into becoming; the having soul that wants to rise to willing and desiring \u2013\r\n\r\n\u2013 the soul that flees itself and catches up to itself in the widest circle; the wisest soul which folly persuades most sweetly \u2013\r\n\r\n\u2013 the one that loves itself most, in which all things have their current and recurrent and ebb and flow \u2013 indeed, how could the highest soul not have the worst parasites?\r\n\r\n20\r\n\r\nOh my brothers, am I perhaps cruel? But I say: if something is falling, one should also give it a push!\r\n\r\nEverything of today \u2013 it is falling, it is failing: who would want to stop it! But I \u2013 I want to push it too!\r\n\r\nDo you know the kind of lust that rolls stones down into steep depths? \u2013 These people of today; just look at how they roll into my depths!\r\n\r\nI am a prelude of better players, my brothers! An exemplary play! Act according to my example!\r\n\r\nAnd whomever you cannot teach to fly, him you should teach \u2013 to fall faster!\r\n\r\n21\r\n\r\nI love the valiant, but it is not enough to be a fierce combatant \u2013 one must also know whom to combat!\r\n\r\nAnd often there is more valiance in someone controlling himself and passing by, so that he saves himself for the worthier enemy!\r\n\r\nYou should have only those enemies whom you hate, but not enemies to despise; you must be proud of your enemy: this I taught you already once before.\r\n\r\nFor the worthier enemy, my friends, you should save yourselves, and therefore you must pass by much \u2013\r\n\r\n\u2013 especially pass by much rabble that thunders in your ears about folk and peoples.\r\n\r\nKeep your eye clear of their pros and cons! There is much justice, much injustice here; whoever watches becomes angry.\r\n\r\nLook around, beat them down \u2013 it\u2019s all the same here; therefore go away into the woods and lay your swords to sleep!\r\n\r\nGo your ways! And let folk and peoples go theirs! \u2013 dark ways, to be sure, on which not a single hope flashes anymore!\r\n\r\nLet the shopkeeper rule where all that is left to glitter \u2013 is shopkeepers\u2019 gold! The time of kings is no more; what calls itself a people today deserves no kings.\r\n\r\nJust look at how these peoples themselves do the same as the shopkeepers; they pluck themselves the tiniest advantage from any dustpan!\r\n\r\nThey lie in wait for one another, they look in hate at one another \u2013 this they call \u201cgood neighbors.\u201d Oh happy distant time when a people said to themselves: \u201cI want to be ruler over peoples!\u201d\r\n\r\nFor the best should rule, my brothers, and the best also want to rule! And wherever the teaching says differently, there \u2013 the best are missing.\r\n\r\n22\r\n\r\nIf they had bread for free, oh no! What would they clamor for! Their sustainment \u2013 that is their real entertainment, and they should have it hard!\r\n\r\nThey are beasts of prey: in their \u201cworking\u201d \u2013 preying is there too; in their \u201cearning\u201d \u2013 outwitting is there too! Therefore they should have it hard!\r\n\r\nThey should become better beasts of prey, more subtle, more clever, more human-like: the human being, after all, is the best beast of prey.\r\n\r\nHuman beings have already successfully preyed upon the virtues of all animals; this is because human beings have had the hardest time of all animals.\r\n\r\nOnly the birds are above him. And if human beings were to learn even to fly, watch out! How high \u2013 would his lust to prey fly!\r\n\r\n23\r\n\r\nThis is how I want man and woman: fit for war the one, fit for bearing children the other, but both fit to dance in head and limb.\r\n\r\nAnd let each day be a loss to us on which we did not dance once! And let each truth be false to us which was not greeted by one laugh!\r\n\r\n24\r\n\r\nIn taking your wedding vows \u2013 see to it that you are not making your bedding vows. Vowing too quickly results in \u2013 breaking vows! And better vow breaking than vow bending and vow pretending! A woman once said to me: \u201cSure, I broke my wedding vows, but first my wedding vows broke \u2013 me!\u201d\r\n\r\nThe worst of the vengeful I always found to be the mismatched couples: they take it out on the whole world that they are no longer singles.\r\n\r\nThis is why I want honest people to speak honestly to one another: \u201cWe love each other; let us see to it that we keep loving each other! Or did we promise by mistake?\u201d\r\n\r\n\u2013 \u201cGive us a trial period and a small marriage, so that we can see whether we are fit for a big marriage! It is a big thing to always be in twos!\u201d\r\n\r\nThus I counsel all honest people; and what then would my love for the overman be, and for everything else that is to come, if I counseled and conveyed otherwise!\r\n\r\nNot merely to reproduce, but instead to surproduce \u2013 to that goal, my brothers, may the garden of marriage help you!\r\n\r\n25\r\n\r\nWhoever has become wise about ancient origins will surely, in the end, seek new wells of the future and new origins.\r\n\r\nYes my brothers, it will not be overly long and new peoples will originate and new wells will roar down into new depths.\r\n\r\nAn earthquake, after all \u2013 it buries many wells, it causes much dying of thirst: it also brings to light inner powers and secrets.\r\n\r\nAn earthquake reveals new wells. In an earthquake of ancient peoples new wells break out.\r\n\r\nAnd whoever cries out there: \u201cLook, here is a fountain for many who thirst, a heart for many who long, a will for many tools\u201d \u2013 around him gathers a people, that is: many who try.\r\n\r\nWho can command, who must obey \u2013 here it is tried! Indeed, with what long searching and guessing and lack of success and learning and trying again!\r\n\r\nHuman society: it is an experiment, this I teach \u2013 a long search: but it searches for the commander! \u2013\r\n\r\n\u2013 an experiment, oh my brothers! And not a \u201ccontract!\u201d Break, break me such words of the soft hearted and half-and-halfs!\r\n\r\n26\r\n\r\nMy brothers! In whom does the greatest danger lie for all of future humanity? Is it not in the good and the just?\r\n\r\n\u2013 is it not in those who speak and feel in their hearts: \u201cWe already know what is good and just, and we have it too; woe to any who still search here!\u201d\r\n\r\nAnd whatever harm the evil may do, the harm of the good is the most harmful harm!\r\n\r\nAnd whatever harm the world slanderers may do, the harm of the good is the most harmful harm!\r\n\r\nMy brothers, there was a man who once looked into the hearts of the good and the just, and he spoke: \u201cThey are pharisees.\u201d But he was not understood.\r\n\r\nThe good and the just themselves were not permitted to understand him: their spirit is imprisoned in their good conscience. The stupidity of the good is unfathomably clever.\r\n\r\nBut this is the truth: the good must be pharisees \u2013 they have no choice!\r\n\r\nThe good must crucify the one who invents his own virtue! This is the truth!\r\n\r\nThe second one, however, who discovered their land, the land, hearts and soil of the good and just: he was the one who asked: \u201cWhom do they hate the most?\u201d\r\n\r\nThe creator they hate the most; he who breaks tablets and old values, the breaker \u2013 him they call the lawbreaker.\r\n\r\nBecause the good, you see \u2013 they can not create: they are always the beginning of the end \u2013\r\n\r\n\u2013 they crucify the one who writes new values on new tablets, they sacrifice the future to themselves \u2013 they crucify all future huma- nity!\r\n\r\nThe good \u2013 they were always the beginning of the end. \u2013\r\n\r\n27\r\n\r\nOh my brothers, have you even understood these words? And what I once said about the \u201clast human being?\u201d \u2013\r\n\r\nIn whom does the greatest danger lie for all of future humanity? Is it not in the good and the just?\r\n\r\nBreak, break me the good and the just! \u2013 Oh my brothers, have you even understood these words?\r\n\r\n28\r\n\r\nYou flee from me? You are frightened? You tremble before these words?\r\n\r\nMy brothers, when I told you to break the good and the tablets of the good, then for the first time I launched mankind onto their high seas.\r\n\r\nAnd only now the great fright comes to them, the great looking-around oneself, the great sickness, the great nausea, the great seasickness.\r\n\r\nFalse coasts and false securities were taught you by the good; in the lies of the good you were born and bielded. Everything has been duplicitous and twisted from the ground up by the good.\r\n\r\nBut whoever discovered the land \u201chuman being\u201d also discovered the land \u201chuman future.\u201d Now you will be seafarers, brave and patient!\r\n\r\nWalk upright for once, my brothers, learn to walk upright! The sea is stormy: Many want to right themselves again on you.\r\n\r\nThe sea is stormy: Everything is in the sea. Well then! Well now! You old salts!\r\n\r\nWhat fatherland! There our helm wants to steer, where our children\u2019s land is! Out there, stormier than the sea, storms our great longing! \u2013\r\n\r\n29\r\n\r\n\u201cWhy so hard!\u201d \u2013 the kitchen coal once said to the diamond. \u201cAre we not close relatives?\u201d\r\n\r\nWhy so soft? Oh my brothers, this I ask you: for are you not \u2013 my brothers?\r\n\r\nWhy so soft, so retiring and yielding? Why is there so much denying and denial in your hearts? And so little destiny in your gazes?\r\n\r\nAnd if you do not want to be destinies and inexorable, how could you triumph with me?\r\n\r\nAnd if your hardness does not want to flash and undo and cut through, how could you one day create with me?\r\n\r\nThe creators are hard after all. And it must seem like bliss to you to press your hand upon millennia as if upon wax \u2013\r\n\r\n\u2013 bliss to write upon the will of millennia as if upon bronze \u2013 harder than bronze, more noble than bronze. Only the most noble is perfectly hard.\r\n\r\nThis new tablet, my brothers, I place above you: become hard! \u2013\r\n\r\n30\r\n\r\nOh you my will! You turning point of all need, you point of my necessity! Preserve me from all small victories!\r\n\r\nYou ordaining of my soul, that I call destiny! You in-me, over-me! Preserve and save me for a great destiny!\r\n\r\nAnd your ultimate greatness, my will, save that for your ultimate \u2013 that you be inexorable in your victory! Indeed, who was not defeated in his victory!\r\n\r\nIndeed, whose eye did not darken in this drunken twilight! Indeed, whose foot did not stagger and forget how to stand in victory!\r\n\r\n\u2013 That I may one day be ready and ripe in the great noon; ready and ripe like glowing bronze, clouds pregnant with lightning and swelling udders of milk \u2013\r\n\r\n\u2013 ready for myself and for my most hidden will; a bow burning for its arrow, an arrow burning for its star \u2013\r\n\r\n\u2013 a star ready and ripe in its noon, glowing, skewered, blissful with annihilating arrows of the sun \u2013\r\n\r\n\u2013 a sun itself and an inexorable will of the sun, ready for annihilating in victory!\r\n\r\nOh will, turning point of all need, you my point of necessity! Save me for a great victory! \u2013\r\n\r\nThus spoke Zarathustra."}, "id": 73}, {"data": {"uuid": "0e7f6615-3a34-4e60-93ab-1b5f39d6089f", "user": 1, "title": "The Convalescent", "created_on": "2023-05-10 15:56:52.816393+00:00", "updated_on": "2023-05-10 15:56:52.838987+00:00", "article_html": "<h2>The Convalescent</h2><h3>1</h3><p>One morning not long after his return to his cave, Zarathustra sprang from his bed like a madman, screamed with a terrifying voice and behaved as though someone else were lying on his bed, who did not want to get up. And Zarathustra\u2019s voice reverberated so much that his animals rushed to him frightened, and from every cave and hiding place neighboring on Zarathustra\u2019s cave, all the animals scurried away \u2013 flying, fluttering, crawling, leaping in whatever manner of foot or feather they were given. But Zarathustra said these words:</p><p>Up, abysmal thought, out of my depths! I am your rooster and dawn, you sleepy worm: up! Up! My voice will yet crow you awake!</p><p>Unsnap the straps of your ears: listen! Because I want to hear you! Up! Up! Here there is thunder enough to make even graves learn to listen!</p><p>And wipe the sleep and all that befogs and blinds you from your eyes! Hear me with your eyes too: my voice is a remedy even for those born blind.</p><p>And once you are awake, you shall remain awake eternally. It is not my manner to wake great-grandmothers from their sleep only to tell them \u2013 go back to sleep!</p><p>You stir, you stretch, you gasp? Up! Up! No gasping \u2013 you will speak to me! Zarathustra summons you, the godless one!</p><p>I, Zarathustra, the advocate of life, the advocate of suffering, the advocate of the circle \u2013 you I summon, my most abysmal thought!</p><p>Hail to me! You are coming \u2013 I hear you! My abyss speaks, I have unfolded my ultimate depth to the light!</p><p>Hail to me! Here now! Give me your hand \u2013 ha! Let go! Haha! \u2013 Nausea, nausea, nausea \u2013 oh no!</p><h3>2</h3><p>Scarcely had he spoken these words, however, when Zarathustra collapsed like a dead man and long remained as if dead. But when he came to he was pale and he trembled, still lying down, and for a long time he wanted neither to eat nor drink. This behavior lasted seven days; meanwhile, his animals did not leave his side day and night, unless the eagle flew out to fetch food. And whatever prey it fetched together it laid on Zarathustra\u2019s bed until eventually Zarathustra lay among yellow and red berries, grapes, red apples, aromatic herbs and pine cones. At his feet, however, two lambs were spread out, which the eagle with difficulty had taken as prey from their shepherds.</p><p>Finally, after seven days, Zarathustra sat up on his bed, picked up one of the red apples, smelled it, and found its aroma lovely. Then his animals believed the time had come to speak with him.</p><p>\u201cOh Zarathustra,\u201d they said. \u201cNow you have been lying like this for seven days, with heavy eyes: do you not want at last to get on your feet?</p><p>Step out of your cave: the world awaits you like a garden. The wind is playing with heady fragrances that make their way to you; and all brooks want to run after you.</p><p>All things long for you, while you have stayed alone for seven days \u2013 step out of your cave! All things want to be your physician!</p><p>Did perhaps some new knowledge come to you, something sour, heavy? You lay there like leavened dough, your soul rose up and swelled over all its rims. \u2013\u201d</p><p>\u2013 \u201cOh my animals,\u201d answered Zarathustra. \u201cJust keep babbling and let me listen! It invigorates me so when you babble: where there is babbling the world indeed lies before me like a garden.</p><p>How lovely it is that there are words and sounds; aren\u2019t words and sounds rainbows and illusory bridges between things eternally separated?</p><p>To each soul belongs another world; for each soul every other soul is a hinterworld.</p><p>Illusion tells its loveliest lies about the things that are most similar, because the tiniest gap is hardest to bridge.</p><p>For me \u2013 how would there be something outside me? There is no outside! But we forget this with all sounds; how lovely it is that we forget!</p><p>Have names and sounds not been bestowed on things so that human beings can invigorate themselves on things? It is a beautiful folly, speaking: with it humans dance over all things.</p><p>How lovely is all talking and all lying of sounds! With sounds our love dances on colorful rainbows.\u201d \u2013</p><p>\u2013 \u201cOh Zarathustra,\u201d said the animals then. \u201cTo those who think as we do, all things themselves approach dancing; they come and reach out their hands and laugh and retreat \u2013 and come back.</p><p>Everything goes, everything comes back; the wheel of being rolls eternally. Everything dies, everything blossoms again, the year of being runs eternally.</p><p>Everything breaks, everything is joined anew; the same house of being builds itself eternally. Everything parts, everything greets itself again; the ring of being remains loyal to itself eternally.</p><p>In every Instant being begins; around every Here rolls the ball There. The middle is everywhere. Crooked is the path of eternity.\u201d \u2013</p><p>\u2013 \u201cOh you foolish rascals and barrel organs!\u201d answered Zarathustra, smiling again. \u201cHow well you know what had to come true in seven days \u2013</p><p>\u2013 and how that monster crawled into my throat and choked me! But I bit off its head and spat it away from me.</p><p>And you \u2013 you have already made a hurdy-gurdy song of it? Now I lie here, weary still from this biting and spitting out, sick still from my own redemption.</p><p>And you looked on at all of this? Oh my animals, are you also cruel? Did you want to watch my great pain the way people do? For human beings are the cruelest animal.</p><p>Tragic plays, bullfights and crucifixions have always made them feel best on earth; and when they invented hell for themselves, see here \u2013 it was their heaven on earth.</p><p>When a great human being cries out \u2013 in a flash the little ones come running, and their tongues hang out with lasciviousness. But they call it their \u2018pity.\u2019</p><p>The little human being, especially the poet \u2013 how eagerly he puts his accusations against life into words! Hear him, but do not fail to hear the lust that is in all his accusing!</p><p>Such accusers of life are overcome by life in a blink of an eye. \u2018You love me?\u2019 says the flirt. \u2018Wait just a while longer, I don\u2019t have time for you yet.\u2019</p><p>The human being is the cruelest animal against itself; and with all those who call themselves \u2018sinner\u2019 and \u2018cross bearer\u2019 and \u2018penitent,\u2019 do not fail to hear the lust in such complaining and accusing!</p><p>And I myself \u2013 do I want therefore to be the accuser of mankind? Oh my animals, this alone have I learned so far, that for mankind their most evil is necessary for their best \u2013</p><p>\u2013 that whatever is most evil is their best power and the hardest stone for the highest creator; and that mankind must become better and more evil \u2013</p><p>The cross on which I suffered was not that I know human beings are evil \u2013 instead, I cried as no one yet has cried:</p><p>\u2018A shame that their most evil is so very small! A shame that their best is so very small!\u2019</p><p>My great surfeit of human beings \u2013 that choked me and crawled into my throat; and what the soothsayer said: \u2018All is the same, nothing is worth it, knowledge chokes.\u2019</p><p>A long twilight limped ahead of me, a tired to death and drunk to death sadness that spoke with a yawning mouth:</p><p>\u2018Eternally he returns, the human of whom you are weary, the small human being\u2019 \u2013 thus my sadness yawned and dragged its foot and could not fall asleep.</p><p>For me the human earth transformed into a cave, its chest caved in; everything living became human mold and bones and crumbling past.</p><p>My sighing sat upon all human graves and could no longer stand up; my sighing and questioning croaked and choked and gnashed and lashed day and night:</p><p>\u2013 \u2018alas, human beings recur eternally! The small human beings recur eternally!\u2019 \u2013</p><p>Naked I once saw them both, the greatest human and the smallest human: all too similar to one another \u2013 all too human still even the greatest one!</p><p>All too small the greatest one! That was my surfeit of humans! And eternal recurrence of even the smallest! \u2013 That was my surfeit of all existence!</p><p>Oh nausea! Nausea! Nausea!\u201d \u2013 Thus spoke Zarathustra and sighed and shuddered, because he remembered his sickness. But his animals did not allow him to continue.</p><p>\u201cSpeak no more, you convalescent!\u201d \u2013 answered his animals. \u201cRather go outside where the world awaits you like a garden.</p><p>Go outside to the roses and bees and swarms of doves! Especially to the song birds, so that you can learn to sing from them!</p><p>Singing after all is for convalescents, let the healthy person talk. And even if the healthy person also wants songs, he wants different songs than the convalescent.\u201d</p><p>\u2013 \u201cOh you foolish rascals and barrel organs, shut up!\u201d \u2013 answered Zarathustra, and he smiled at his animals. \u201cHow well you know which comfort I invented for myself in seven days!</p><p>That I must sing once again \u2013 this comfort I invented for myself and this convalescence; but do you want to make that into a hurdy-gurdy song right away too?\u201d</p><p>\u2013 \u201cSpeak no more,\u201d answered his animals again. \u201cInstead, you convalescent, fashion yourself a lyre first, a new lyre!</p><p>Behold oh Zarathustra! For your new songs new lyres are needed.</p><p>Sing and foam over, Zarathustra; heal your soul with new songs so that you can bear your great destiny, which was never before a human\u2019s destiny!</p><p>For your animals know well, oh Zarathustra, who you are and must become; behold, you are the teacher of the eternal recurrence \u2013 that now is your destiny!</p><p>That you must teach this teaching as the first \u2013 how could this great destiny not also be your greatest danger and sickness!</p><p>Behold, we know what you teach: that all things recur eternally and we ourselves along with them, and that we have already been here times eternal and all things along with us.</p><p>You teach that there is a great year of becoming, a monster of a great year; like an hourglass it must turn itself over anew, again and again, so that it runs down and runs out anew \u2013</p><p>\u2013 so that all these years are the same as each other, in what is greatest and also in what is smallest \u2013 so that we ourselves in every great year are the same, in what is greatest and also in what is smallest.</p><p>And if you wanted to die now, oh Zarathustra: behold, we know too how you would speak to yourself then: \u2013 but your animals beg you not to die yet!</p><p>You would speak and without trembling, rather taking a deep breath, blissfully; for a great weight and oppressiveness would be taken from you, you most patient one!</p><p>\u2018Now I die and disappear,\u2019 you would say, \u2018and in an instant I will be a nothing. Souls are as mortal as bodies.</p><p>But the knot of causes in which I am entangled recurs \u2013 it will create me again! I myself belong to the causes of the eternal recurrence.</p><p>I will return, with this sun, with this earth, with this eagle, with this snake \u2013 not to a new life or a better life or a similar life:</p><p>\u2013 I will return to this same and selfsame life, in what is greatest as well as in what is smallest, to once again teach the eternal recurrence of all things \u2013</p><p>\u2013 to once again speak the word about the great earth of noon and human beings, to once again proclaim the overman to mankind.</p><p>I spoke my word, I break under my word: thus my eternal fate wills it \u2013 as proclaimer I perish!</p><p>The hour has now come for the one who goes under to bless himself. Thus \u2013 ends Zarathustra\u2019s going under!\u2019\u201d \u2013</p><p>When the animals had spoken these words they fell silent and waited for Zarathustra to say something to them: but Zarathustra did not hear that they were silent. Instead he lay still, with eyes closed, like someone sleeping \u2013 even though he was not sleeping. Indeed, at this moment he was conversing with his soul. The snake and the eagle, however, finding him silent in this manner, honored the great stillness around him and cautiously slipped away.</p>", "article_json": {"type": "doc", "content": [{"type": "heading", "attrs": {"level": 2}, "content": [{"text": "The Convalescent", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "heading", "attrs": {"level": 3}, "content": [{"text": "1", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "content": [{"text": "One morning not long after his return to his cave, Zarathustra sprang from his bed like a madman, screamed with a terrifying voice and behaved as though someone else were lying on his bed, who did not want to get up. The snake and the eagle, however, finding him silent in this manner, honored the great stillness around him and cautiously slipped away.", "type": "text"}]}]}, "article_text": "The Convalescent\r\n\r\n1\r\n\r\nOne morning not long after his return to his cave, Zarathustra sprang from his bed like a madman, screamed with a terrifying voice and behaved as though someone else were lying on his bed, who did not want to get up. And Zarathustra\u2019s voice reverberated so much that his animals rushed to him frightened, and from every cave and hiding place neighboring on Zarathustra\u2019s cave, all the animals scurried away \u2013 flying, fluttering, crawling, leaping in whatever manner of foot or feather they were given. But Zarathustra said these words:\r\n\r\nUp, abysmal thought, out of my depths! I am your rooster and dawn, you sleepy worm: up! Up! My voice will yet crow you awake!\r\n\r\nUnsnap the straps of your ears: listen! Because I want to hear you! Up! Up! Here there is thunder enough to make even graves learn to listen!\r\n\r\nAnd wipe the sleep and all that befogs and blinds you from your eyes! Hear me with your eyes too: my voice is a remedy even for those born blind.\r\n\r\nAnd once you are awake, you shall remain awake eternally. It is not my manner to wake great-grandmothers from their sleep only to tell them \u2013 go back to sleep!\r\n\r\nYou stir, you stretch, you gasp? Up! Up! No gasping \u2013 you will speak to me! Zarathustra summons you, the godless one!\r\n\r\nI, Zarathustra, the advocate of life, the advocate of suffering, the advocate of the circle \u2013 you I summon, my most abysmal thought!\r\n\r\nHail to me! You are coming \u2013 I hear you! My abyss speaks, I have unfolded my ultimate depth to the light!\r\n\r\nHail to me! Here now! Give me your hand \u2013 ha! Let go! Haha! \u2013 Nausea, nausea, nausea \u2013 oh no!\r\n\r\n2\r\n\r\nScarcely had he spoken these words, however, when Zarathustra collapsed like a dead man and long remained as if dead. But when he came to he was pale and he trembled, still lying down, and for a long time he wanted neither to eat nor drink. This behavior lasted seven days; meanwhile, his animals did not leave his side day and night, unless the eagle flew out to fetch food. And whatever prey it fetched together it laid on Zarathustra\u2019s bed until eventually Zarathustra lay among yellow and red berries, grapes, red apples, aromatic herbs and pine cones. At his feet, however, two lambs were spread out, which the eagle with difficulty had taken as prey from their shepherds.\r\n\r\nFinally, after seven days, Zarathustra sat up on his bed, picked up one of the red apples, smelled it, and found its aroma lovely. Then his animals believed the time had come to speak with him.\r\n\r\n\u201cOh Zarathustra,\u201d they said. \u201cNow you have been lying like this for seven days, with heavy eyes: do you not want at last to get on your feet?\r\n\r\nStep out of your cave: the world awaits you like a garden. The wind is playing with heady fragrances that make their way to you; and all brooks want to run after you.\r\n\r\nAll things long for you, while you have stayed alone for seven days \u2013 step out of your cave! All things want to be your physician!\r\n\r\nDid perhaps some new knowledge come to you, something sour, heavy? You lay there like leavened dough, your soul rose up and swelled over all its rims. \u2013\u201d\r\n\r\n\u2013 \u201cOh my animals,\u201d answered Zarathustra. \u201cJust keep babbling and let me listen! It invigorates me so when you babble: where there is babbling the world indeed lies before me like a garden.\r\n\r\nHow lovely it is that there are words and sounds; aren\u2019t words and sounds rainbows and illusory bridges between things eternally separated?\r\n\r\nTo each soul belongs another world; for each soul every other soul is a hinterworld.\r\n\r\nIllusion tells its loveliest lies about the things that are most similar, because the tiniest gap is hardest to bridge.\r\n\r\nFor me \u2013 how would there be something outside me? There is no outside! But we forget this with all sounds; how lovely it is that we forget!\r\n\r\nHave names and sounds not been bestowed on things so that human beings can invigorate themselves on things? It is a beautiful folly, speaking: with it humans dance over all things.\r\n\r\nHow lovely is all talking and all lying of sounds! With sounds our love dances on colorful rainbows.\u201d \u2013\r\n\r\n\u2013 \u201cOh Zarathustra,\u201d said the animals then. \u201cTo those who think as we do, all things themselves approach dancing; they come and reach out their hands and laugh and retreat \u2013 and come back.\r\n\r\nEverything goes, everything comes back; the wheel of being rolls eternally. Everything dies, everything blossoms again, the year of being runs eternally.\r\n\r\nEverything breaks, everything is joined anew; the same house of being builds itself eternally. Everything parts, everything greets itself again; the ring of being remains loyal to itself eternally.\r\n\r\nIn every Instant being begins; around every Here rolls the ball There. The middle is everywhere. Crooked is the path of eternity.\u201d \u2013\r\n\r\n\u2013 \u201cOh you foolish rascals and barrel organs!\u201d answered Zarathustra, smiling again. \u201cHow well you know what had to come true in seven days \u2013\r\n\r\n\u2013 and how that monster crawled into my throat and choked me! But I bit off its head and spat it away from me.\r\n\r\nAnd you \u2013 you have already made a hurdy-gurdy song of it? Now I lie here, weary still from this biting and spitting out, sick still from my own redemption.\r\n\r\nAnd you looked on at all of this? Oh my animals, are you also cruel? Did you want to watch my great pain the way people do? For human beings are the cruelest animal.\r\n\r\nTragic plays, bullfights and crucifixions have always made them feel best on earth; and when they invented hell for themselves, see here \u2013 it was their heaven on earth.\r\n\r\nWhen a great human being cries out \u2013 in a flash the little ones come running, and their tongues hang out with lasciviousness. But they call it their \u2018pity.\u2019\r\n\r\nThe little human being, especially the poet \u2013 how eagerly he puts his accusations against life into words! Hear him, but do not fail to hear the lust that is in all his accusing!\r\n\r\nSuch accusers of life are overcome by life in a blink of an eye. \u2018You love me?\u2019 says the flirt. \u2018Wait just a while longer, I don\u2019t have time for you yet.\u2019\r\n\r\nThe human being is the cruelest animal against itself; and with all those who call themselves \u2018sinner\u2019 and \u2018cross bearer\u2019 and \u2018penitent,\u2019 do not fail to hear the lust in such complaining and accusing!\r\n\r\nAnd I myself \u2013 do I want therefore to be the accuser of mankind? Oh my animals, this alone have I learned so far, that for mankind their most evil is necessary for their best \u2013\r\n\r\n\u2013 that whatever is most evil is their best power and the hardest stone for the highest creator; and that mankind must become better and more evil \u2013\r\n\r\nThe cross on which I suffered was not that I know human beings are evil \u2013 instead, I cried as no one yet has cried:\r\n\r\n\u2018A shame that their most evil is so very small! A shame that their best is so very small!\u2019\r\n\r\nMy great surfeit of human beings \u2013 that choked me and crawled into my throat; and what the soothsayer said: \u2018All is the same, nothing is worth it, knowledge chokes.\u2019\r\n\r\nA long twilight limped ahead of me, a tired to death and drunk to death sadness that spoke with a yawning mouth:\r\n\r\n\u2018Eternally he returns, the human of whom you are weary, the small human being\u2019 \u2013 thus my sadness yawned and dragged its foot and could not fall asleep.\r\n\r\nFor me the human earth transformed into a cave, its chest caved in; everything living became human mold and bones and crumbling past.\r\n\r\nMy sighing sat upon all human graves and could no longer stand up; my sighing and questioning croaked and choked and gnashed and lashed day and night:\r\n\r\n\u2013 \u2018alas, human beings recur eternally! The small human beings recur eternally!\u2019 \u2013\r\n\r\nNaked I once saw them both, the greatest human and the smallest human: all too similar to one another \u2013 all too human still even the greatest one!\r\n\r\nAll too small the greatest one! That was my surfeit of humans! And eternal recurrence of even the smallest! \u2013 That was my surfeit of all existence!\r\n\r\nOh nausea! Nausea! Nausea!\u201d \u2013 Thus spoke Zarathustra and sighed and shuddered, because he remembered his sickness. But his animals did not allow him to continue.\r\n\r\n\u201cSpeak no more, you convalescent!\u201d \u2013 answered his animals. \u201cRather go outside where the world awaits you like a garden.\r\n\r\nGo outside to the roses and bees and swarms of doves! Especially to the song birds, so that you can learn to sing from them!\r\n\r\nSinging after all is for convalescents, let the healthy person talk. And even if the healthy person also wants songs, he wants different songs than the convalescent.\u201d\r\n\r\n\u2013 \u201cOh you foolish rascals and barrel organs, shut up!\u201d \u2013 answered Zarathustra, and he smiled at his animals. \u201cHow well you know which comfort I invented for myself in seven days!\r\n\r\nThat I must sing once again \u2013 this comfort I invented for myself and this convalescence; but do you want to make that into a hurdy-gurdy song right away too?\u201d\r\n\r\n\u2013 \u201cSpeak no more,\u201d answered his animals again. \u201cInstead, you convalescent, fashion yourself a lyre first, a new lyre!\r\n\r\nBehold oh Zarathustra! For your new songs new lyres are needed.\r\n\r\nSing and foam over, Zarathustra; heal your soul with new songs so that you can bear your great destiny, which was never before a human\u2019s destiny!\r\n\r\nFor your animals know well, oh Zarathustra, who you are and must become; behold, you are the teacher of the eternal recurrence \u2013 that now is your destiny!\r\n\r\nThat you must teach this teaching as the first \u2013 how could this great destiny not also be your greatest danger and sickness!\r\n\r\nBehold, we know what you teach: that all things recur eternally and we ourselves along with them, and that we have already been here times eternal and all things along with us.\r\n\r\nYou teach that there is a great year of becoming, a monster of a great year; like an hourglass it must turn itself over anew, again and again, so that it runs down and runs out anew \u2013\r\n\r\n\u2013 so that all these years are the same as each other, in what is greatest and also in what is smallest \u2013 so that we ourselves in every great year are the same, in what is greatest and also in what is smallest.\r\n\r\nAnd if you wanted to die now, oh Zarathustra: behold, we know too how you would speak to yourself then: \u2013 but your animals beg you not to die yet!\r\n\r\nYou would speak and without trembling, rather taking a deep breath, blissfully; for a great weight and oppressiveness would be taken from you, you most patient one!\r\n\r\n\u2018Now I die and disappear,\u2019 you would say, \u2018and in an instant I will be a nothing. Souls are as mortal as bodies.\r\n\r\nBut the knot of causes in which I am entangled recurs \u2013 it will create me again! I myself belong to the causes of the eternal recurrence.\r\n\r\nI will return, with this sun, with this earth, with this eagle, with this snake \u2013 not to a new life or a better life or a similar life:\r\n\r\n\u2013 I will return to this same and selfsame life, in what is greatest as well as in what is smallest, to once again teach the eternal recurrence of all things \u2013\r\n\r\n\u2013 to once again speak the word about the great earth of noon and human beings, to once again proclaim the overman to mankind.\r\n\r\nI spoke my word, I break under my word: thus my eternal fate wills it \u2013 as proclaimer I perish!\r\n\r\nThe hour has now come for the one who goes under to bless himself. Thus \u2013 ends Zarathustra\u2019s going under!\u2019\u201d \u2013\r\n\r\nWhen the animals had spoken these words they fell silent and waited for Zarathustra to say something to them: but Zarathustra did not hear that they were silent. Instead he lay still, with eyes closed, like someone sleeping \u2013 even though he was not sleeping. Indeed, at this moment he was conversing with his soul. The snake and the eagle, however, finding him silent in this manner, honored the great stillness around him and cautiously slipped away."}, "id": 74}, {"data": {"uuid": "6052493d-db6b-4b85-a0c7-e9e027fbec0d", "user": 1, "title": "On Great Longing", "created_on": "2023-05-10 15:57:32.890858+00:00", "updated_on": "2023-05-10 15:57:32.910642+00:00", "article_html": "<h2>On Great Longing</h2><p>Oh my soul, I taught you to say \u201ctoday\u201d and \u201conce\u201d and \u201cformerly,\u201d and to dance your round over all here and then and there.</p><p>Oh my soul, I redeemed you from all nooks, I swept dust, spiders and twilight off of you.</p><p>Oh my soul, I washed the petty bashfulness and the nook-virtue from you and persuaded you to stand naked before the eyes of the sun.</p><p>With the storm called \u201cspirit\u201d I blew over your choppy sea; I blew all clouds away, I even choked the choker who is called \u201csin.\u201d</p><p>Oh my soul, I gave you the right to say no like the storm and to say yes as the open sky says yes: still as light you now stand and even if you pass through storms of denial.</p><p>Oh my soul, I gave you back your freedom over what is created and uncreated: and who knows as you know the lust of future things?</p><p>Oh my soul, I taught you contempt that does not come like a gnawing worm, the great, loving contempt that loves most where it has the most contempt.</p><p>Oh my soul, I taught you to persuade such that you persuade even the grounds; like the sun that persuades even the sea into its heights.</p><p>Oh my soul, I took from you all obeying, knee-bending and sir-saying; I myself gave you the name \u201cturning point of need\u201d and \u201cdestiny.\u201d</p><p>Oh my soul, I gave you new names and colorful playthings, I called you \u201cdestiny\u201d and \u201ccompass of compasses\u201d and \u201cumbilical cord of time\u201d and \u201cazure bell.\u201d</p><p>Oh my soul, to your soil I gave all wisdom to drink, all new wines and also all old strong wines of wisdom from time immemorial.</p><p>Oh my soul, I poured every sun upon you and every night and every silence and every longing \u2013 then you grew up for me like a grapevine.</p><p>Oh my soul, super-rich and heavy you stand there now, a grapevine with swelling udders and crowded, brownish gold grapes \u2013</p><p>\u2013 crowded and crushed by your happiness, waiting out of superabun- dance and even bashful because of your waiting.</p><p>Oh my soul, nowhere now is there a soul that could be more loving and more compassing and encompassing! Where would future and past be closer together than in you?</p><p>Oh my soul, I gave you everything and all my hands have become empty on you \u2013 and now! Now you say to me smiling and full of melancholy: \u201cWho of us is supposed to be thankful?</p><p>\u2013 does the giver not have to give thanks that the receiver received? Is bestowing not a bare necessity? Is receiving not \u2013 mercy?\u201d</p><p>Oh my soul, I understand the smiling of your melancholy: your super- richness itself reaches out with longing hands!</p><p>Your fullness gazes out over roaring seas and searches and waits; the longing of over-fullness gazes smilingly from your sky-like eyes!</p><p>And truly, oh my soul! Who could see your smile and not melt into tears! The angels themselves melt into tears at the super-goodness of your smile.</p><p>It is your goodness and super-goodness that do not want to lament and weep; and yet, oh my soul, your smile longs for tears and your trembling mouth for sobs.</p><p>\u201cIs not all weeping a lamentation? And is not all lamentation an accusation?\u201d This is how you speak to yourself, and this is why, oh my soul, you would rather smile than pour out your suffering \u2013</p><p>\u2013 pour out your suffering in gushing tears over your fullness and over all the aching of the grapevine for the vintner and his knife!</p><p>But if you do not want to weep and weep out your purple melancholy, then you must sing, oh my soul! \u2013 Look, I too smile for telling you this in advance:</p><p>\u2013 sing with a roaring song until all seas become silent, to listen for your longing \u2013</p><p>\u2013 until the skiff floats over silent longing seas, the golden wonder around whose gold all good and bad and wonderful things hop \u2013</p><p>\u2013 even many great and small animals and everything that has light, wondrous feet, and can run on paths of violet blue \u2013</p><p>\u2013 over to the golden wonder, the voluntary skiff and to its master: but he is the vintner who waits with his diamond knife \u2013</p><p>\u2013 your great redeemer, oh my soul, the nameless one \u2013 for whom only future songs will find a name! And truly, your breath is fragrant already with future songs! \u2013</p><p>\u2013 already you glow and dream, already you drink thirstily at all deep, resounding wells of comfort, already your melancholy rests in the bliss of future songs! \u2013</p><p>Oh my soul, now I have given you everything and even my ultimate, and all my hands have become empty on you: \u2013 that I commanded you to sing, indeed, that was my ultimate!</p><p>That I commanded you to sing \u2013 speak now, speak: who of us now must be thankful? \u2013 Better yet: sing to me, sing oh my soul! I blew all clouds away, I even choked the choker who is called \u201csin.\u201d\r\n\r\nOh my soul, I gave you the right to say no like the storm and to say yes as the open sky says yes: still as light you now stand and even if you pass through storms of denial.\r\n\r\nOh my soul, I gave you back your freedom over what is created and uncreated: and who knows as you know the lust of future things?\r\n\r\nOh my soul, I taught you contempt that does not come like a gnawing worm, the great, loving contempt that loves most where it has the most contempt.\r\n\r\nOh my soul, I taught you to persuade such that you persuade even the grounds; like the sun that persuades even the sea into its heights.\r\n\r\nOh my soul, I took from you all obeying, knee-bending and sir-saying; I myself gave you the name \u201cturning point of need\u201d and \u201cdestiny.\u201d\r\n\r\nOh my soul, I gave you new names and colorful playthings, I called you \u201cdestiny\u201d and \u201ccompass of compasses\u201d and \u201cumbilical cord of time\u201d and \u201cazure bell.\u201d\r\n\r\nOh my soul, to your soil I gave all wisdom to drink, all new wines and also all old strong wines of wisdom from time immemorial.\r\n\r\nOh my soul, I poured every sun upon you and every night and every silence and every longing \u2013 then you grew up for me like a grapevine.\r\n\r\nOh my soul, super-rich and heavy you stand there now, a grapevine with swelling udders and crowded, brownish gold grapes \u2013\r\n\r\n\u2013 crowded and crushed by your happiness, waiting out of superabun- dance and even bashful because of your waiting.\r\n\r\nOh my soul, nowhere now is there a soul that could be more loving and more compassing and encompassing! Where would future and past be closer together than in you?\r\n\r\nOh my soul, I gave you everything and all my hands have become empty on you \u2013 and now! Now you say to me smiling and full of melancholy: \u201cWho of us is supposed to be thankful?\r\n\r\n\u2013 does the giver not have to give thanks that the receiver received? Is bestowing not a bare necessity? Is receiving not \u2013 mercy?\u201d\r\n\r\nOh my soul, I understand the smiling of your melancholy: your super- richness itself reaches out with longing hands!\r\n\r\nYour fullness gazes out over roaring seas and searches and waits; the longing of over-fullness gazes smilingly from your sky-like eyes!\r\n\r\nAnd truly, oh my soul! Who could see your smile and not melt into tears! The angels themselves melt into tears at the super-goodness of your smile.\r\n\r\nIt is your goodness and super-goodness that do not want to lament and weep; and yet, oh my soul, your smile longs for tears and your trembling mouth for sobs.\r\n\r\n\u201cIs not all weeping a lamentation? And is not all lamentation an accusation?\u201d This is how you speak to yourself, and this is why, oh my soul, you would rather smile than pour out your suffering \u2013\r\n\r\n\u2013 pour out your suffering in gushing tears over your fullness and over all the aching of the grapevine for the vintner and his knife!\r\n\r\nBut if you do not want to weep and weep out your purple melancholy, then you must sing, oh my soul! \u2013 Look, I too smile for telling you this in advance:\r\n\r\n\u2013 sing with a roaring song until all seas become silent, to listen for your longing \u2013\r\n\r\n\u2013 until the skiff floats over silent longing seas, the golden wonder around whose gold all good and bad and wonderful things hop \u2013\r\n\r\n\u2013 even many great and small animals and everything that has light, wondrous feet, and can run on paths of violet blue \u2013\r\n\r\n\u2013 over to the golden wonder, the voluntary skiff and to its master: but he is the vintner who waits with his diamond knife \u2013\r\n\r\n\u2013 your great redeemer, oh my soul, the nameless one \u2013 for whom only future songs will find a name! And truly, your breath is fragrant already with future songs! \u2013\r\n\r\n\u2013 already you glow and dream, already you drink thirstily at all deep, resounding wells of comfort, already your melancholy rests in the bliss of future songs! \u2013\r\n\r\nOh my soul, now I have given you everything and even my ultimate, and all my hands have become empty on you: \u2013 that I commanded you to sing, indeed, that was my ultimate!\r\n\r\nThat I commanded you to sing \u2013 speak now, speak: who of us now must be thankful? \u2013 Better yet: sing to me, sing oh my soul! And let me give thanks! \u2013\r\n\r\nThus spoke Zarathustra."}, "id": 75}, {"data": {"uuid": "adbecd4a-8e0e-43c9-a52a-5197aea6cc38", "user": 1, "title": "The Other Dance Song", "created_on": "2023-05-10 15:58:13.704965+00:00", "updated_on": "2023-05-10 15:58:13.724452+00:00", "article_html": "<h2>The Other Dance Song</h2><h3>1</h3><p>Into your eyes I looked recently, oh life: I saw gold gleaming in your night eyes \u2013 my heart skipped a beat at this thrill:</p><p>\u2013 I saw a golden boat gleaming on nocturnal waters, a sinking, drinking, winking golden rocking boat!</p><p>You cast a glance at my foot, at my dance-drunken foot; a laughing, asking, melting rocking glance:</p><p>Two times only your little hands shook their maracas \u2013 and already my dance-drunk foot began to rock. \u2013</p><p>I kicked up my heels, my toes fairly strained to hear you disclose: after all, a dancer has ears in his toes!</p><p>I leaped over to you; you dodged my advance, retreating deftly; and only the licking, fleeing, trailing tongues of your hair were left me!</p><p>I leaped away from your hair\u2019s lurid snaking; and there you stood, half facing me, your eyes afire with aching.</p><p>Your crooked gazes teach me \u2013 crooked running; on crooked paths my foot learns \u2013 crooked cunning!</p><p>I fear you up close, and I love you away; your leaving spells me, your seeking compels me \u2013 I suffer, but suffer gladly for you any day!</p><p>You whose coldness ignites, whose hate is alluring; whose fleeing invites, whose scorn is \u2013 stirring:</p><p>\u2013 who would not hate you, you great binder, and winder, temptress, attemptress, and finder! Who would not love you, you innocent, ardent one, wind-bride and child-eyed sinner!</p><p>Where are you pulling me now, you standout and upstart? And now you flee me again, sweet wildcat, thankless heart!</p><p>I dance after you, and follow your trail using any clue. Where are you? Give me your hand! Even a finger will do!</p><p>Here are caves and thickets, we could get lost in there! \u2013 Stop! Stand still! Do you not see owls and bats in the air?</p><p>You owls! You bats! This leaves you in stitches? Where are we? Such howling and yelping you learned from the bitches.</p><p>You gnash at me sweetly with little white teeth; your curly little mane, evil eyes peeking out from beneath!</p><p>This is a dance moving every which way; I am the hunter \u2013 are you my hound or my prey?</p><p>Next to me now! And quick, you evil little jumper! Up now! And over! \u2013 Oh no! I slipped and now I\u2019m on my rump here!</p><p>Oh see me lying, miss mischief, have mercy on me! There are paths to sweet places \u2013 where I would rather be!</p><p>\u2013 Paths of love through silent blooming plants! Or down there along the lake, where goldfish swim and dance!</p><p>Are you weary now? Over there are sheep and sunset-swoons; is it not sweet to sleep when shepherds play their tunes?</p><p>Are you so bitter weary! I will carry you there, just relax and let your arms sink! And if you thirst \u2013 I have something, but nothing you would drink! \u2013</p><p>\u2013 Oh this cursed clever, supple snake and slippery witch! Gone without a trace? But left behind, and left by hand, I feel two red spots on my face!</p><p>I am truly tired of always playing your sheepish shepherd pal! You witch, if I have so far sung for you, now you for me will \u2013 yell!</p><p>To the beat of my whip you will dance so and yell so! But did I forget the whip? \u2013 Oh no! \u2013</p><h3>2</h3><p>Then life answered me like this and covered her dainty little ears:</p><p>\u201cOh Zarathustra! Please do not crack your whip so fearfully! Surely you know: noise murders thoughts \u2013 and just now the most tender thoughts are coming to me.</p><p>We are both a couple of real do-no-goods and do-no-evils. Beyond good and evil we found our island and our green meadow \u2013 we two alone! Therefore we at least have to like each other!</p><p>And just because we do not love each other from the heart \u2013 must we grudge one another for not loving each other from the heart?</p><p>That I like you, and often too much, this you know; and the reason is that I am jealous of your wisdom. Ah, this crazy old fool of a wisdom!</p><p>If your wisdom ever ran away from you, oh! Then my love would also quickly run away from you too.\u201d \u2013</p><p>Then life looked pensively behind her and around her and said softly: \u201cOh Zarathustra, you are not faithful enough for me!</p><p>You do not love me nearly as much as you say; I know you are thinking of leaving me soon.</p><p>There is an old heavy, heavy growling bell: it growls at night all the way up to your cave \u2013</p><p>\u2013 when you hear this bell toll the hour at midnight, then you think between one and twelve about \u2013</p><p>\u2013 you think, oh Zarathustra, I know it, about how you will soon leave me!\u201d \u2013</p><p>\u201cYes,\u201d I answered, hesitating. \u201cBut you also know \u2013\u201d And I said something in her ear, right in it between her tangled yellow, foolish shaggy locks.</p><p>\u201cYou know that, oh Zarathustra? No one knows that.\u201d \u2013</p><p>And we looked at each other and gazed at the green meadow, over which the cool evening had just spread, and we wept together. \u2013 But at that moment I loved life more than I ever loved all my wisdom. \u2013</p><p>Thus spoke Zarathustra.</p><h3>3</h3><p><em>One!</em><br>Oh mankind, pray!<br><em>Two!</em><br>What does deep midnight have to say?<br><em>Three!</em><br>\u201cFrom sleep, from sleep \u2013<br><em>Four!</em><br>From deepest dream I made my way \u2013<br><em>Five!</em><br>The world is deep,<br><em>Six!</em><br>And deeper than the grasp of day.<br><em>Seven!</em><br>Deep is its pain \u2013,<br><em>Eight!</em><br>Joy \u2013 deeper still than misery:<br><em>Nine!</em><br>Pain says: refrain!<br><em>Ten!</em><br>Yet all joy wants eternity \u2013,<br><em>Eleven!</em><br>\u2013 wants deep, wants deep eternity!\u201d<br><em>Twelve!</em></p>", "article_json": {"type": "doc", "content": [{"type": "heading", "attrs": {"level": 2}, "content": [{"text": "The Other Dance Song", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "heading", "attrs": {"level": 3}, "content": [{"text": "1", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "content": [{"text": "Into your eyes I looked recently, oh life: I saw gold gleaming in your night eyes \u2013 my heart skipped a beat at this thrill:", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "content": [{"text": "\u2013 I saw a golden boat gleaming on nocturnal waters, a sinking, drinking, winking golden rocking boat!", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "content": [{"text": "You cast a glance at my foot, at my dance-drunken foot;
