Song\r\n\r\n1\r\n\r\nInto your eyes I looked recently, oh life: I saw gold gleaming in your night eyes \u2013 my heart skipped a beat at this thrill:\r\n\r\n\u2013 I saw a golden boat gleaming on nocturnal waters, a sinking, drinking, winking golden rocking boat!\r\n\r\nYou cast a glance at my foot, at my dance-drunken foot; a laughing, asking, melting rocking glance:\r\n\r\nTwo times only your little hands shook their maracas \u2013 and already my dance-drunk foot began to rock. \u2013\r\n\r\nI kicked up my heels, my toes fairly strained to hear you disclose: after all, a dancer has ears in his toes!\r\n\r\nI leaped over to you; you dodged my advance, retreating deftly; and only the licking, fleeing, trailing tongues of your hair were left me!\r\n\r\nI leaped away from your hair\u2019s lurid snaking; and there you stood, half facing me, your eyes afire with aching.\r\n\r\nYour crooked gazes teach me \u2013 crooked running; on crooked paths my foot learns \u2013 crooked cunning!\r\n\r\nI fear you up close, and I love you away; your leaving spells me, your seeking compels me \u2013 I suffer, but suffer gladly for you any day!\r\n\r\nYou whose coldness ignites, whose hate is alluring; whose fleeing invites, whose scorn is \u2013 stirring:\r\n\r\n\u2013 who would not hate you, you great binder, and winder, temptress, attemptress, and finder! Who would not love you, you innocent, ardent one, wind-bride and child-eyed sinner!\r\n\r\nWhere are you pulling me now, you standout and upstart? And now you flee me again, sweet wildcat, thankless heart!\r\n\r\nI dance after you, and follow your trail using any clue. Where are you? Give me your hand! Even a finger will do!\r\n\r\nHere are caves and thickets, we could get lost in there! \u2013 Stop! Stand still! Do you not see owls and bats in the air?\r\n\r\nYou owls! You bats! This leaves you in stitches? Where are we? Such howling and yelping you learned from the bitches.\r\n\r\nYou gnash at me sweetly with little white teeth; your curly little mane, evil eyes peeking out from beneath!\r\n\r\nThis is a dance moving every which way; I am the hunter \u2013 are you my hound or my prey?\r\n\r\nNext to me now! And quick, you evil little jumper! Up now! And over! \u2013 Oh no! I slipped and now I\u2019m on my rump here!\r\n\r\nOh see me lying, miss mischief, have mercy on me! There are paths to sweet places \u2013 where I would rather be!\r\n\r\n\u2013 Paths of love through silent blooming plants! Or down there along the lake, where goldfish swim and dance!\r\n\r\nAre you weary now? Over there are sheep and sunset-swoons; is it not sweet to sleep when shepherds play their tunes?\r\n\r\nAre you so bitter weary! I will carry you there, just relax and let your arms sink! And if you thirst \u2013 I have something, but nothing you would drink! \u2013\r\n\r\n\u2013 Oh this cursed clever, supple snake and slippery witch! Gone without a trace? But left behind, and left by hand, I feel two red spots on my face!\r\n\r\nI am truly tired of always playing your sheepish shepherd pal! You witch, if I have so far sung for you, now you for me will \u2013 yell!\r\n\r\nTo the beat of my whip you will dance so and yell so! But did I forget the whip? \u2013 Oh no! \u2013\r\n\r\n2\r\n\r\nThen life answered me like this and covered her dainty little ears:\r\n\r\n\u201cOh Zarathustra! Please do not crack your whip so fearfully! Surely you know: noise murders thoughts \u2013 and just now the most tender thoughts are coming to me.\r\n\r\nWe are both a couple of real do-no-goods and do-no-evils. Beyond good and evil we found our island and our green meadow \u2013 we two alone! Therefore we at least have to like each other!\r\n\r\nAnd just because we do not love each other from the heart \u2013 must we grudge one another for not loving each other from the heart?\r\n\r\nThat I like you, and often too much, this you know; and the reason is that I am jealous of your wisdom. Ah, this crazy old fool of a wisdom!\r\n\r\nIf your wisdom ever ran away from you, oh! Then my love would also quickly run away from you too.\u201d \u2013\r\n\r\nThen life looked pensively behind her and around her and said softly: \u201cOh Zarathustra, you are not faithful enough for me!\r\n\r\nYou do not love me nearly as much as you say; I know you are thinking of leaving me soon.\r\n\r\nThere is an old heavy, heavy growling bell: it growls at night all the way up to your cave \u2013\r\n\r\n\u2013 when you hear this bell toll the hour at midnight, then you think between one and twelve about \u2013\r\n\r\n\u2013 you think, oh Zarathustra, I know it, about how you will soon leave me!\u201d \u2013\r\n\r\n\u201cYes,\u201d I answered, hesitating. \u201cBut you also know \u2013\u201d And I said something in her ear, right in it between her tangled yellow, foolish shaggy locks.\r\n\r\n\u201cYou know that, oh Zarathustra? No one knows that.\u201d \u2013\r\n\r\nAnd we looked at each other and gazed at the green meadow, over which the cool evening had just spread, and we wept together. \u2013 But at that moment I loved life more than I ever loved all my wisdom. \u2013\r\n\r\nThus spoke Zarathustra.\r\n\r\n3\r\n\r\nOne!\r\nOh mankind, pray!\r\nTwo!\r\nWhat does deep midnight have to say?\r\nThree!\r\n\u201cFrom sleep, from sleep \u2013\r\nFour!\r\nFrom deepest dream I made my way \u2013\r\nFive!\r\nThe world is deep,\r\nSix!\r\nAnd deeper than the grasp of day.\r\nSeven!\r\nDeep is its pain \u2013,\r\nEight!\r\nJoy \u2013 deeper still than misery:\r\nNine!\r\nPain says: refrain!\r\nTen!\r\nYet all joy wants eternity \u2013,\r\nEleven!\r\n\u2013 wants deep, wants deep eternity!\u201d\r\nTwelve!"}, "id": 76}, {"data": {"uuid": "61c9c92d-f29d-487c-809e-999d78e38b3e", "user": 1, "title": "The Seven Seals (Or: the Yes and Amen Song)", "created_on": "2023-05-10 15:59:00.730143+00:00", "updated_on": "2023-05-10 15:59:00.750812+00:00", "article_html": "<h2>The Seven Seals (Or: the Yes and Amen Song)</h2><h3>1</h3><p>If I am a soothsayer and full of that soothsaying spirit that hikes on a high pass between two seas \u2013</p><p>hikes between the past and the future as a heavy cloud \u2013 the enemy of oppressive lowlands and everything that is weary and can neither die nor live:</p><p>ready in its dark bosom for lightning and for the redeeming ray of light, pregnant with lightning bolts that say Yes! and laugh Yes! to soothsaying bolts of lightning \u2013</p><p>\u2013 but blessed is the one who is pregnant like this! And truly, whoever will one day kindle the light of the future must hang long on the mountain like a heavy storm! \u2013</p><p>oh how then could I not lust for eternity and for the nuptial ring of rings \u2013 the ring of recurrence!</p><p>Never yet have I found the woman from whom I wanted children, unless it were this woman whom I love: for I love you, oh eternity!</p><p>For I love you, oh eternity!</p><h3>2</h3><p>If my wrath ever broke open graves, moved boundary stones and rolled old broken tablets down into steep depths:</p><p>If my scorn ever blew apart moldy words, and I came upon the cross spiders like a broom, and as a sweeping wind to old musty burial chambers:</p><p>If I ever sat jubilating where old gods lie buried, blessing the world, loving the world next to the monuments of ancient world maligners \u2013</p><p>\u2013 because I love even churches and God\u2019s graves once the sky\u2019s pure eye gazes through their broken roofs; gladly do I sit like grass and red poppies on broken churches \u2013</p><p>Oh how then could I not lust for eternity and for the nuptial ring of rings \u2013 the ring of recurrence!</p><p>Never yet have I found the woman from whom I wanted children, unless it were this woman whom I love: for I love you, oh eternity!</p><p>For I love you, oh eternity!</p><h3>3</h3><p>If ever a breath came to me of creative breath and of that heavenly necessity that forces even accidents to dance astral rounds:</p><p>If ever I laughed with the laugh of creative lightning that follows rum- bling but obediently the long thunder of the deed:</p><p>If ever I rolled dice with gods at the gods\u2019 table of the earth, so that the earth quaked and ruptured and snorted up rivers of fire \u2013</p><p>\u2013 because the earth is a gods\u2019 table, and it trembles with creative new words and gods\u2019 throws \u2013</p><p>Oh how then could I not lust for eternity and for the nuptial ring of rings \u2013 the ring of recurrence!</p><p>Never yet have I found the woman from whom I wanted children, unless it were this woman whom I love: for I love you, oh eternity!</p><p>For I love you, oh eternity!</p><h3>4</h3><p>If ever I drank my fill from that foaming mug of mixed spices, in which all good things are mixed:</p><p>If my hand ever poured the farthest to the closest and fire to spirit and joy to sorrow and the most wicked to the kindest:</p><p>If I myself am a grain of that redeeming salt that makes all things in the mixing mug mix well \u2013</p><p>\u2013 because there is a salt that binds good with evil; and even what is most evil is worthy as a spice and for the final foaming over \u2013</p><p>Oh how then could I not lust for eternity and for the nuptial ring of rings \u2013 the ring of recurrence!</p><p>Never yet have I found the woman from whom I wanted children, unless it were this woman whom I love: for I love you, oh eternity!</p><p>For I love you, oh eternity!</p><h3>5</h3><p>If I favor the sea and everything that is of the sea, and even favor it most when it angrily contradicts me:</p><p>If ever that joy of searching is in me that drives sails toward the undiscovered, if a seafarer\u2019s joy is in my joy:</p><p>If ever my jubilating cried: \u201cThe coast disappeared \u2013 now the last chain has fallen from me \u2013</p><p>\u2013 infinity roars around me, way out there space and time glitter, well then, what of it old heart!\u201d \u2013</p><p>Oh how then could I not lust for eternity and for the nuptial ring of rings \u2013 the ring of recurrence!</p><p>Never yet have I found the woman from whom I wanted children, unless it were this woman whom I love: for I love you, oh eternity!</p><p>For I love you, oh eternity!</p><h3>6</h3><p>If my virtue is a dancer\u2019s virtue and I often leaped with both feet into golden emerald delight:</p><p>If my malice is a laughing malice, at home beneath rosy slopes and lily hedges:</p><p>\u2013 for in laughter everything evil is together, but pronounced holy and absolved by its own bliss:</p><p>And if that is my alpha and omega, that all heaviness becomes light, all body dancer, all spirit bird \u2013 and truly, that is my alpha and omega! \u2013</p><p>Oh how then could I not lust for eternity and for the nuptial ring of rings \u2013 the ring of recurrence!</p><p>Never yet have I found the woman from whom I wanted children, unless it were this woman whom I love: for I love you, oh eternity!</p><p>For I love you, oh eternity!</p><h3>7</h3><p>If ever I spread silent skies above me and flew into my own sky with my own wings:</p><p>If I playfully swam in deep expanses of light, and my freedom\u2019s bird-wisdom came \u2013</p><p>\u2013 but bird-wisdom speaks like this: \u201cSee, there is no up, no down! Throw yourself around, out, back you light one! Sing! Speak no more!</p><p>\u2013 are not all words made for the heavy? Do not all words lie to the light? Sing! Speak no more!\u201d \u2013</p><p>Oh how then could I not lust for eternity and for the nuptial ring of rings \u2013 the ring of recurrence!</p><p>Never yet have I found the woman from whom I wanted children, unless it were this woman whom I love: for I love you, oh eternity!</p><p>For I love you, oh eternity!</p>", "article_json": {"type": "doc", "content": [{"type": "heading", "attrs": {"level": 2}, "content": [{"text": "The Seven Seals (Or: the Yes and Amen Song)", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "heading", "attrs": {"level": 3}, "content": [{"text": "1", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "content": [{"text": "If I am a soothsayer and full of that soothsaying spirit that hikes on a high pass between two seas \u2013", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "content": [{"text": "hikes between the past and the future as a heavy cloud \u2013 the enemy of oppressive lowlands and everything that is weary and can neither die nor live:", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "content": [{"text": "ready in its dark bosom for lightning and for the redeeming ray of light, pregnant with lightning bolts that say Yes! and laugh Yes! to soothsaying bolts of lightning \u2013", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "content": [{"text": "\u2013 but blessed is the one who is pregnant like this! rings \u2013 the ring of recurrence!\r\n\r\nNever yet have I found the woman from whom I wanted children, unless it were this woman whom I love: for I love you, oh eternity!\r\n\r\nFor I love you, oh toward the undiscovered, if a seafarer\u2019s joy is in my joy:\r\n\r\nIf ever my jubilating cried: \u201cThe coast disappeared \u2013 now the last chain has fallen from me \u2013\r\n\r\n\u2013 infinity roars around me, way out there space and time glitter, well then, what of it old heart!\u201d \u2013\r\n\r\nOh how then could I not lust for eternity and for the nuptial ring of rings \u2013 the ring of recurrence!\r\n\r\nNever yet have I found the woman from whom I wanted children, unless it were this woman whom I love: for I love you, oh eternity!\r\n\r\nFor I love you, oh eternity!\r\n\r\n6\r\n\r\nIf my virtue is a dancer\u2019s virtue and I often leaped with both feet into golden emerald delight:\r\n\r\nIf my malice is a laughing malice, at home beneath rosy slopes and lily hedges:\r\n\r\n\u2013 for in laughter everything evil is together, but pronounced holy and absolved by its own bliss:\r\n\r\nAnd if that is my alpha and omega, that all heaviness becomes light, all body dancer, all spirit bird \u2013 and truly, that is my alpha and omega! \u2013\r\n\r\nOh how then could I not lust for eternity and for the nuptial ring of rings \u2013 the ring of recurrence!\r\n\r\nNever yet have I found the woman from whom I wanted children, unless it were this woman whom I love: for I love you, oh eternity!\r\n\r\nFor I love you, oh eternity!\r\n\r\n7\r\n\r\nIf ever I spread silent skies above me and flew into my own sky with my own wings:\r\n\r\nIf I playfully swam in deep expanses of light, and my freedom\u2019s bird-wisdom came \u2013\r\n\r\n\u2013 but bird-wisdom speaks like this: \u201cSee, there is no up, no down! Throw yourself around, out, back you light one! Sing! Speak no more!\r\n\r\n\u2013 are not all words made for the heavy? Do not all words lie to the light? Sing! Speak no more!\u201d \u2013\r\n\r\nOh how then could I not lust for eternity and for the nuptial ring of rings \u2013 the ring of recurrence!\r\n\r\nNever yet have I found the woman from whom I wanted children, unless it were this woman whom I love: for I love you, oh eternity!\r\n\r\nFor I love you, oh eternity!"}, "id": 77}]}, {"data": {"uuid": "9d0467c9-388c-40aa-b02e-a23280947cf7", "user": 1, "title": "Fourth and Final Part", "created_on": "2023-05-10 16:48:16.166419+00:00", "updated_on": "2023-05-10 16:48:16.182604+00:00", "article_html": "<h1>Fourth and Final Part</h1>", "article_json": {"type": "doc", "content": [{"type": "heading", "attrs": {"level": 1}, "content": [{"text": "Fourth and Final Part", "type": "text"}]}]}, "article_text": "Fourth and Final Part"}, "id": 78, "children": [{"data": {"uuid": "6b94748e-da11-48da-a734-6578bc36b2cd", "user": 1, "title": "The Honey Sacrifice", "created_on": "2023-05-10 16:49:07.348676+00:00", "updated_on": "2023-05-10 16:49:07.364270+00:00", "article_html": "<h2>The Honey Sacrifice</h2><p>\u2013 And again moons and years passed over Zarathustra\u2019s soul and he took no notice of it; but his hair had turned white. One day as he sat on a stone before his cave and gazed outward \u2013 there where one looks out upon the sea and beyond twisting abysses \u2013 his animals walked around him pensively until finally they stood before him.</p><p>\u201cOh Zarathustra,\u201d they said. \u201cAre you perhaps on the lookout for your happiness?\u201d \u2013 \u201cWhat does happiness matter!\u201d he answered. \u201cI haven\u2019t strived for happiness for a long time, I strive for my work.\u201d \u2013 \u201cOh Zarathustra,\u201d said the animals again. \u201cYou say that as one who has had overly much of the good. Do you not lie in a sky-blue lake of happiness?\u201d</p><p>\u2013 \u201cYou foolish rascals,\u201d answered Zarathustra, smiling. \u201cHow well you chose your metaphor! But you also know that my happiness is heavy and not like a fluid wave of water; it presses me and will not leave me alone and it acts like melted tar.\u201d \u2013</p><p>Then the animals again walked around him pensively and once more they stood before him. \u201cOh Zarathustra,\u201d they said, \u201cis that why you yourself are becoming ever yellower and darker, even though your hair looks white and flaxen? Don\u2019t you see, you are bogged down in your misfortune!\u201d \u2013 \u201cWhat are you saying, my animals?\u201d said Zarathustra, and he laughed. \u201cTruly, I smeared when I used the word tar. What\u2019s happening to me is common to all fruits that ripen. It\u2019s the honey in my veins that makes my blood thicker and also makes my soul calmer.\u201d \u2013 \u201cIt will be as you say, oh Zarathustra,\u201d answered the animals, and they pressed up against him. \u201cBut do you not want to climb a high mountain today? The air is pure and today one sees more of the world than ever before.\u201d \u2013 \u201cYes, my animals,\u201d he answered. \u201cYour advice is superb and after my own heart: I do want to climb a high mountain today! But see to it that there is honey at hand for me there; yellow, white, good, icy fresh golden honey from the comb. Because know this: I want to offer the honey sacrifice up there.\u201d \u2013</p><p>But when Zarathustra was up on the summit he sent home the animals which had accompanied him, and he found that he was alone now \u2013 then he laughed with his whole heart, looked around and spoke thus:</p><p>That I spoke of sacrifices and honey sacrifices was merely a sleight of speech and, truly, a useful folly! Up here I may speak more freely than before hermits\u2019 caves and hermits\u2019 pets.</p><p>What sacrifice! I squander what was bestowed me, I the squanderer with a thousand hands: How could I call that \u2013 sacrificing!</p><p>And when I desired honey I merely desired bait and sweet ooze and mucus, for which even growling bears and odd, surly, evil birds lick with their tongues:</p><p>\u2013 the best bait, as it is needed by hunters and fishermen. Because if the world is like a dark jungle and a pleasure garden for all wild hunters, to me it seems even more, and preferably, an abysmal rich sea,</p><p>\u2013 a sea full of colorful fishes and crabs, for whose sake even gods would crave to become fishermen and net casters: so rich is the world in odd things great and small!</p><p>Especially the human world, the human sea \u2013 toward it I now cast my golden fishing rod and say: open up, you human abyss!</p><p>Open up and toss me your fishes and glittering crabs! With my best bait today I bait the oddest human fishes!</p><p>\u2013 my very happiness I cast far and wide, between sunrise, noon and sunset, to see if many human fishes learn to jiggle and wiggle on my happiness.</p><p>Until, biting on my sharp hidden hooks, they have to emerge into my height, the motliest gorge gudgeons to the most spiteful of all fishers of human fish.</p><p>That\u2019s what I am, after all, at bottom and from the start; reeling, reeling in, raising up, raising, a raiser, a cultivator and taskmaster who not for nothing once told himself: \u201cBecome who you are!\u201d</p><p>So now human beings may come up to me; you see, I am still waiting for the sign that it is time for my descent; I myself will not go under yet, as I must, and among human beings.</p><p>That\u2019s why I\u2019m waiting here, cunning and mocking on high mountains, not impatient, not patient, but instead one who has forgotten even forbearance \u2013 because he no longer \u201cbears.\u201d</p><p>My destiny leaves me time for this: surely it has forgotten me? Or does it sit behind a big rock in the shade, catching flies?</p><p>And really, I like my eternal destiny for not rushing and pressing me and for leaving me time for jests and spite, so that today I climbed this high mountain to catch fish.</p><p>Did a human being ever catch fish on high mountains? And even if what I want and do up here is folly, this is still better than becoming pompous and green and gold down there from waiting \u2013</p><p>\u2013 a swaggering wrath snorter from waiting, a holy, howling mountain storm, an impatient one who cries down into the valleys: \u201cHear me, or I shall whip you with the lash of God!\u201d</p><p>Not that I would grudge such angry men for it; they are good enough for me to laugh at! They have to be impatient anyway, these big noisy drums, who either get to speak today or never!</p><p>But I and my destiny \u2013 we do not speak to today, nor do we speak to never: we have patience enough and time and overtime for speaking. Because it must come someday and may not pass by.</p><p>What must come someday and may not pass by? Our great Hazar, that is our great distant human empire, the Zarathustra empire of a thousand years \u2013</p><p>How distant might such a \u201cdistance\u201d be? What do I care! But it is no less firm to me on that account \u2013 with both feet I stand firmly on this ground,</p><p>\u2013 on an eternal ground, on hard primeval rock, on this highest, hardest primeval mountain chain, to which all winds come as if to a weathershed, asking Where? and from Where? and Where to?</p><p>Laugh, laugh here my bright hearty spite! Throw down your glittering, mocking laughter from high mountains! Bait me the most beautiful human fish with your glittering!</p><p>And whatever in all the seas belongs to me, my actual me in all things \u2013 fish that out for me, bring that up to me \u2013 that\u2019s what I am waiting for, I the most spiteful of all fishermen.</p><p>Out, out my fishing rod! Into and down, bait of my happiness! Drip your sweetest dew, my heart\u2019s honey! Bite, my fishing rod, into the belly of all black gloom!</p><p>Out there, out there my eye! Oh how many seas surround me, what dawning human futures! And above me \u2013 what rosy red stillness! What cloudless silence!"}, "id": 79}, {"data": {"uuid": "36c6687f-dcdb-46d1-bb30-d8901f827351", "user": 1, "title": "The Cry of Distress", "created_on": "2023-05-10 16:49:45.445086+00:00", "updated_on": "2023-05-10 16:49:45.463168+00:00", "article_html": "<h2>The Cry of Distress</h2><p>The next day Zarathustra again sat on the stone before his cave, while the animals roamed about in the world to bring home new nourishment \u2013 and new honey too, because Zarathustra had spent and squandered the old honey to the last drop. But as he sat there like this, with a stick in his hand and tracing the outline of his shadow on the ground, reflecting and, truly, not about himself and his shadow \u2013 then all at once he was frightened and startled, because next to his own shadow he saw another shadow. And as he quickly looked around and stood up, there was the soothsayer standing next to him, the same one whom he had wined and dined at his table, the proclaimer of the great weariness who taught: \u201cAll is the same, nothing is worth it, the world is without meaning, knowledge chokes.\u201d But his face had transformed in the meantime; and when Zarathustra looked him in the eyes, his heart was frightened again \u2013 so many grave proclamations and ashen gray lightning bolts animated this face.</p><p>The soothsayer, who read what was going on in Zarathustra\u2019s soul, wiped his hand over his face as if he wanted to wipe it away; Zarathustra did the same. And when both had silently composed and strengthened themselves in this manner, they shook hands as a sign that they wanted to recognize one another.</p><p>\u201cWelcome,\u201d said Zarathustra, \u201cyou soothsayer of the great weariness; not for nothing were you once a guest at my table. Eat and drink with me today too, and forgive that a contented old man joins you at the table!\u201d \u201cA contented old man?\u201d answered the soothsayer, shaking his head. \u201cWhoever you are or want to be, oh Zarathustra, you\u2019ve been that long enough up here \u2013 in a short time your skiff will no longer be on the rocks!\u201d \u2013 \u201cAm I on the rocks then?\u201d asked Zarathustra, laughing. \u2013 \u201cThe waves around your mountain,\u201d answered the soothsayer, \u201crise and rise; the waves of great distress and gloom: soon they will lift your skiff as well and carry you away.\u201d \u2013 Zarathustra was silent on hearing this and surprised. \u2013 \u201cDo you not hear anything yet?\u201d continued the soothsayer. \u201cIs there not a rushing and roaring up from the depths?\u201d \u2013 Zarathustra kept silent and listened; then he heard a long, long cry that the abysses threw back and forth to each other, as if none wanted to keep it \u2013 so evil did it sound.</p><p>\u201cYou wicked proclaimer,\u201d spoke Zarathustra at last. \u201cThat\u2019s a cry of distress and the cry of a human being, even if it comes out of a black sea. But what is human distress to me! My final sin, the one saved up for me \u2013 do you know what it\u2019s called?\u201d</p><p>\u2013 \u201cPity!\u201d answered the soothsayer from his overflowing heart, and he raised both hands high \u2013 \u201coh Zarathustra, I come to seduce you to your last sin!\u201d \u2013</p><p>And scarcely had these words been spoken when the cry rang out again, and longer and more anxious than before, also much closer now. \u201cDo you hear? Do you hear, oh Zarathustra?\u201d cried the soothsayer. \u201cThe cry is meant for you, it calls you: come, come, come, it is time, it is high time!\u201d \u2013</p><p>Zarathustra was silent after this, confused and shaken; finally he asked, like one who hesitates inwardly: \u201cAnd who is it there that calls me?\u201d</p><p>\u201cBut you know it already,\u201d answered the soothsayer vehemently. \u201cWhy do you conceal yourself? It is the higher man who calls for you!\u201d</p><p>\u201cThe higher man?\u201d cried Zarathustra, seized by horror. \u201cWhat does he want? What does he want? The higher man! What does he want here?\u201d \u2013 And his skin was bathed in sweat.</p><p>But the soothsayer did not respond to Zarathustra\u2019s fear, and instead he listened and listened toward the depths. But after it was quiet there for a long time, he turned his glance back and saw Zarathustra standing and trembling.</p><p>\u201cOh Zarathustra,\u201d he began with a sad voice. \u201cYou do not stand there like one whose happiness makes him giddy: you will have to dance to keep from falling down!</p><p>But even if you were to dance before me and leap all your side-leaps, no one should be allowed to tell me: \u2018Look, here dances the last gay human being!\u2019</p><p>Anyone who came to this height looking for him would come in vain; caves he would find, to be sure, and hinter-caves, hiding places for hiders, but no shafts of happiness and treasure chambers and new golden veins of happiness.</p><p>Happiness \u2013 how could anyone find happiness among those who are buried away and hermits? Must I seek the last happiness far away on blessed isles between forgotten seas?</p><p>But all is the same, nothing is worth it, searching does not help, and there are no blessed isles anymore!\u201d \u2013</p><p>Thus sighed the soothsayer; but at his last sigh Zarathustra became bright and certain once more, like someone who comes from a deep chasm into the light. \u201cNo! No! No! Three times no!\u201d he cried in a strong voice, stroking his beard. \u201cThat I know better! There are still blessed isles! Be silent about that, you sighing sadsack!</p><p>Stop splashing about that, you rain cloud of the morning! Do I not already stand here soaked by your gloom and drenched like a dog?</p><p>Now I\u2019ll shake myself and run away from you, so that I can dry off again; that shouldn\u2019t surprise you! Do I seem discourteous to you? But this is my court.</p><p>But as far as your higher man is concerned: let\u2019s go! I\u2019ll search for him right now in those woods \u2013 from there his cry came. Perhaps he is beset by some evil beast.</p><p>He is in my territory, and in here he shall not come to harm! And truly, there are many evil beasts in my territory.\u201d \u2013</p><p>With these words Zarathustra turned to leave. Then the soothsayer spoke: \u201cOh Zarathustra, you are a rogue!</p><p>I already know that you want to get rid of me! You would rather run into the woods and pursue evil beasts!</p><p>But what will it help you? By evening you will have me again anyway, I will be sitting in your own cave, patient and heavy like a block \u2013 and I will be waiting for you!\u201d</p><p>\u201cSo be it!\u201d called Zarathustra over his shoulder as he departed. \u201cAnd whatever is mine in my cave, it belongs to you too, my guest!</p><p>But if you should find honey in there, good! Then just lick it up, you old growling bear, and sweeten your soul! Because by evening we will both want to be in a good mood,</p><p>\u2013 in a good mood and glad that this day came to an end! And you yourself will dance to my songs as my dancing bear.</p><p>You don\u2019t believe it? You shake your head? Well then! We\u2019ll see, old bear! But I too am \u2013 a soothsayer.\u201d</p><p>Thus spoke Zarathustra.</p>", "article_json": {"type": "doc", "content": [{"type": "heading", "attrs": {"level": 2}, "content": [{"text": "The Cry of Distress", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "content": [{"text": "The next day Zarathustra again sat on the stone before his cave, while the animals roamed about in the world to bring home new nourishment \u2013 and new honey too, because Zarathustra had spent and squandered the old honey to the last drop. And as he quickly looked around and stood up, there was the soothsayer standing next to him, the same one whom he had wined and dined at his table, the proclaimer of the great weariness who taught: \u201cAll is the same, nothing is worth it, the world is without meaning, knowledge chokes.\u201d But his face had transformed in the meantime; and when Zarathustra looked him in the eyes, his heart was frightened again \u2013 so many grave proclamations and ashen gray lightning bolts animated this face.\r\n\r\nThe soothsayer, who read what was going on in Zarathustra\u2019s soul, wiped his hand over his face as if he wanted to wipe it away; Zarathustra did the same. What does he want here?\u201d \u2013 And his skin was bathed in sweat.\r\n\r\nBut the soothsayer did not respond to Zarathustra\u2019s fear, and instead he listened and listened toward the depths. But after it was quiet there for a long time, he turned his glance back and saw Zarathustra standing and trembling.\r\n\r\n\u201cOh Zarathustra,\u201d he began with a sad voice. \u201cYou do not stand there like one whose happiness makes him giddy: you will have to dance to keep from falling down!\r\n\r\nBut even if you were to dance before me and leap all your side-leaps, no one should be allowed to tell me: \u2018Look, here dances the last gay human being!\u2019\r\n\r\nAnyone who came to this height looking for him would come in vain; caves he would find, to be sure, and hinter-caves, hiding places for hiders, but no shafts of happiness and treasure chambers and new golden veins of happiness.\r\n\r\nHappiness \u2013 how could anyone find happiness among those who are buried away and hermits? No! No! Three times no!\u201d he cried in a strong voice, stroking his beard. \u201cThat I know better! There are still blessed isles! Be silent about that, you sighing sadsack!\r\n\r\nStop splashing about that, you rain cloud of the morning! Do I not already stand here soaked by your gloom and drenched like a dog?\r\n\r\nNow I\u2019ll shake myself and run away from you, so that I can dry off again; that shouldn\u2019t surprise you! Do I seem discourteous to you? But this is my court.\r\n\r\nBut as far as your higher man is concerned: let\u2019s go! You would rather run into the woods and pursue evil beasts!\r\n\r\nBut what will it help you? By evening you will have me again anyway, I will be sitting in your own cave, patient and heavy like a block \u2013 and I will be waiting for you!\u201d\r\n\r\n\u201cSo be it!\u201d called Zarathustra over his shoulder as he departed. \u201cAnd whatever is mine in my cave, it belongs to you too, my guest!\r\n\r\nBut if you should find honey in there, good! Then just lick it up, you old growling bear, and sweeten your soul! Because by evening we will both want to be in a good mood,\r\n\r\n\u2013 in a good mood and glad that this day came to an end! And you yourself will dance to my songs as my dancing bear.\r\n\r\nYou don\u2019t believe it? You shake your head? Well then! We\u2019ll see, old bear! But I too am \u2013 a soothsayer.\u201d\r\n\r\nThus spoke Zarathustra."}, "id": 80}, {"data": {"uuid": "5709b7a3-5e22-4c31-953f-2dd39bac3be1", "user": 1, "title": "Conversation with the Kings", "created_on": "2023-05-10 16:50:27.248941+00:00", "updated_on": "2023-05-10 16:50:27.268744+00:00", "article_html": "<h2>Conversation with the Kings</h2><h3>1</h3><p>Zarathustra had been underway in his mountains and woods for not even one hour when all at once he saw a strange procession. On precisely the path he wanted to take down, two kings came walking, adorned with crowns and purple sashes and as colorful as flamingoes; before them they drove a burdened ass. \u201cWhat do these kings want in my kingdom?\u201d spoke Zarathustra to his astonished heart, and he hid himself quickly behind a bush. But when the kings caught up to him he said, half out loud like a person talking to himself: \u201cStrange! Strange! What rhyme or reason can this have? I see two kings \u2013 and only one ass!\u201d</p><p>Then the two kings stopped, smiled, looked toward the place from which the voice had come and then turned to face one another. \u201cSuch things are also thought among us,\u201d said the king to the right, \u201cbut one does not speak it.\u201d</p><p>But the king to the left shrugged his shoulders and answered: \u201cIt\u2019s probably a goatherd. Or a hermit who has lived too long among cliffs and trees. After all, no society at all also ruins good manners.\u201d</p><p>\u201cGood manners?\u201d retorted the other king indignantly and bitterly. \u201cThen what are we trying to run away from? Is it not \u2018good manners\u2019? Is it not our \u2018good society?\u2019</p><p>Better, truly, to live among hermits and goatherds than live with our gilded, fake, make-up wearing rabble \u2013 even if it calls itself \u2018good society,\u2019</p><p>\u2013 even if it calls itself \u2018nobility.\u2019 But there everything is fake and foul, starting with the blood, thanks to old diseases and even worse healers.</p><p>Best and dearest to me today is still a healthy peasant, coarse, cunning, stubborn, enduring: that is the most noble type today.</p><p>The peasant today is the best; and peasant-type should be ruler! But it is the kingdom of the rabble \u2013 I will not be deceived anymore. Rabble now, that means: mishmash.</p><p>Rabble mishmash: in it everything is jumbled together, saint and scoundrel and Junker and Jew and every beast from the ark of Noah.</p><p>Good manners! Everything among us is fake and foul. No one knows how to revere anymore \u2013 that precisely is what we are running away from. They are mawkish, obtrusive dogs, they are gilders of palm leaves.</p><p>This nausea chokes me, that we kings ourselves became fake, decked out and dressed up in old yellowed grandfathers\u2019 pomp, medals for the most moronic and the slyest and whoever the hell haggles today for power!</p><p>We are not the first \u2013 and yet we must signify that we are: it is this deception that we have finally had enough of, that nauseates us.</p><p>We got away from the riffraff, all these screamers and scribble-blowflies, all the shopkeeper stench, all the twitching ambition, all the bad breath \u2013 phooey to living among the riffraff,</p><p>\u2013 phooey to signifying the first among the riffraff! Oh nausea! Nausea! Nausea! What do we kings matter anymore!\u201d \u2013</p><p>\u201cYour old illness befalls you again,\u201d said now the king on the left. \u201cNausea befalls you, my poor brother. But you know too that someone is listening to us.\u201d</p><p>At once Zarathustra, whose ears and eyes had opened wide at this conversation, rose from his hiding place, approached the kings and began:</p><p>\u201cThe one who listens to you, who listens gladly to you, you kings, is called Zarathustra.</p><p>I am Zarathustra, who once spoke: \u2018What do kings matter anymore!\u2019 Forgive me, I was so pleased when you said to one another: \u2018What do we kings matter!\u2019</p><p>But here is my realm and my rule: what might you be seeking now in my realm? Or perhaps you have found along the way what I am seeking, namely the higher man.\u201d</p><p>When the kings heard this they beat their breasts and exclaimed with one voice: \u201cWe have been found out!</p><p>With the sword of your words you strike through our hearts\u2019 thickest darkness. You discover our distress, for behold! We are on our way to find the higher man \u2013</p><p>\u2013 the man who is higher than we, even though we are kings. To him we lead this ass. The highest man, you see, should be the highest ruler on earth.</p><p>There is no harder misfortune in all human destiny than when the powerful of the earth are not also the first human beings. Then everything becomes fake and crooked and monstrous.</p><p>And should they even be last and more beast than human; then the rabble rises and rises in price, until finally even rabble virtue speaks: \u2018Behold, I alone am virtue!\u2019\u201d \u2013</p><p>\u201cWhat did I just hear?\u201d answered Zarathustra. \u201cWhat wisdom among kings! I am delighted, and truly, I\u2019m already in the mood to make a rhyme of it: \u2013</p><p>\u2013 even if it turns out to be a rhyme that is not suitable for everyone\u2019s ears. Long ago I gave up being considerate of long ears. Well then! Well now!</p><p>(But here it happened that the ass too got in a word; and clearly and malevolently he said hee-yaw.)</p><p>Once \u2013 I think in anno domini one \u2013</p><p>The Sybil said, drunk, though wine she\u2019d had none:</p><p>\u2018Oh no, how badly things go!</p><p>Decline! Decline! The world has sunk so low!</p><p>Rome sank to whore and to a whorehouse too,</p><p>Rome\u2019s Caesar to beast, God himself \u2013 turned Jew!\u2019\u201d</p><h3>2</h3><p>The kings were enchanted by these rhymes of Zarathustra, but the king to the right spoke: \u201cOh Zarathustra, how well we did in going forth to see you!</p><p>For your enemies showed us your image in their mirror: there you were with your devil\u2019s grimace and laughing scornfully, such that we were afraid of you.</p><p>But what good did it do? Again and again you pricked our ears and hearts with your sayings, then we said at last: what does it matter how he looks!</p><p>We have to hear him, the one who teaches \u2018you shall love peace as a means to new wars, and the short peace more than the long one!\u2019</p><p>No one has ever spoken such warlike words: \u2018What is good? Being brave is good. The good war hallows any cause.\u2019</p><p>Oh Zarathustra, our fathers\u2019 blood stirred in our bodies at the sound of such words; it was like the speech of springtime to old casks of wine.</p><p>When swords ran every which way like red-stained snakes, our fathers warmed to life; the sun of all peace seemed limp and lackluster to them, but the long peace caused them shame.</p><p>How they sighed, our fathers, when they saw gleaming bright, dried up swords on the wall! Like them, they thirsted for war. For a sword wants to drink blood and sparkles with desire.\u201d \u2013</p><p>\u2013 As the kings talked in this manner and gabbed enthusiastically about the happiness of their fathers, Zarathustra was overcome by no small desire to mock their enthusiasm; after all, these were visibly very peaceful kings he saw standing before him, the kind with old and refined faces. But he restrained himself. \u201cWell then!\u201d he said. \u201cThe path leads there, Zarathustra\u2019s cave lies there, and this day shall also have a long evening! But now a cry of distress hurries me away from you.</p><p>It will honor my cave if kings want to sit and wait in it, but, to be sure, you will have to wait long!</p><p>Alright! What\u2019s the harm? Where does one learn to wait better today than at court? And the whole virtue of kings that is left to them \u2013 is it not today called: being able to wait?\u201d</p><p>Thus spoke Zarathustra.</p>", "article_json": {"type": "doc", "content": [{"type": "heading", "attrs": {"level": 2}, "content": [{"text": "Conversation with the Kings", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "heading", "attrs": {"level": 3}, "content": [{"text": "1", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "content": [{"text": "Zarathustra had been underway in his mountains and woods for not even one hour when all at once he saw a strange procession. On precisely the path he wanted to take down, two kings came walking, adorned with crowns and purple sashes and as colorful as flamingoes; before them they drove a burdened ass. \u201cWhat do these kings want in my kingdom?\u201d spoke Zarathustra to his astonished heart, and he hid himself quickly behind a bush. But when the kings caught up to him he said, half out loud like a person talking to himself: \u201cStrange! Strange! What rhyme or reason can this have? I see two kings \u2013 and only one ass!\u201d\r\n\r\nThen the two kings stopped, smiled, looked toward the place from which the voice had come and then turned to face one another. \u201cSuch things are also thought among us,\u201d said the king to the right, \u201cbut one does not speak it.\u201d\r\n\r\nBut the king to the left shrugged his shoulders and answered: \u201cIt\u2019s probably a goatherd. Or a hermit who has lived too long among cliffs and trees. After all, no society at all also ruins good manners.\u201d\r\n\r\n\u201cGood manners?\u201d retorted the other king indignantly and bitterly. \u201cThen what are we trying to run away from? Is it not \u2018good manners\u2019? Is it not our \u2018good society?\u2019\r\n\r\nBetter, truly, to live among hermits and goatherds than live with our gilded, fake, make-up wearing rabble \u2013 even if it calls itself \u2018good society,\u2019\r\n\r\n\u2013 even if it calls itself \u2018nobility.\u2019 But there everything is fake and foul, starting with the blood, thanks to old diseases and even worse healers.\r\n\r\nBest and dearest to me today is still a healthy peasant, coarse, cunning, stubborn, enduring: that is the most noble type today.\r\n\r\nThe peasant today is the best; and peasant-type should be ruler! But it is the kingdom of the rabble \u2013 I will not be deceived anymore. Rabble now, that means: mishmash.\r\n\r\nRabble mishmash: in it everything is jumbled together, saint and scoundrel and Junker and Jew and every beast from the ark of Noah.\r\n\r\nGood manners! Everything among us is fake and foul. No one knows how to revere anymore \u2013 that precisely is what we are running away from. They are mawkish, obtrusive dogs, they are gilders of palm leaves.\r\n\r\nThis nausea chokes me, that we kings ourselves became fake, decked out and dressed up in old yellowed grandfathers\u2019 pomp, medals for the most moronic and the slyest and whoever the hell haggles today for power!\r\n\r\nWe are not the first \u2013 and yet we must signify that we are: it is this deception that we have finally had enough of, that nauseates us.\r\n\r\nWe got away from the riffraff, all these screamers and scribble-blowflies, all the shopkeeper stench, all the twitching ambition, all the bad breath \u2013 phooey to living among the riffraff,\r\n\r\n\u2013 phooey to signifying the first among the riffraff! Oh nausea! Nausea! Nausea! What do we kings matter anymore!\u201d \u2013\r\n\r\n\u201cYour old illness befalls you again,\u201d said now the king on the left. \u201cNausea befalls you, my poor brother. But you know too that someone is listening to us.\u201d\r\n\r\nAt once Zarathustra, whose ears and eyes had opened wide at this conversation, rose from his hiding place, approached the kings and began:\r\n\r\n\u201cThe one who listens to you, who listens gladly to you, you kings, is called Zarathustra.\r\n\r\nI am Zarathustra, who once spoke: \u2018What do kings matter anymore!\u2019 Forgive me, I was so pleased when you said to one another: \u2018What do we kings matter!\u2019\r\n\r\nBut here is my realm and my rule: what might you be seeking now in my realm? Or perhaps you have found along the way what I am seeking, namely the higher man.\u201d\r\n\r\nWhen the kings heard this they beat their breasts and exclaimed with one voice: \u201cWe have been found out!\r\n\r\nWith the sword of your words you strike through our hearts\u2019 thickest darkness. You discover our distress, for behold! We are on our way to find the higher man \u2013\r\n\r\n\u2013 the man who is higher than we, even though we are kings. To him we lead this ass. The highest man, you see, should be the highest ruler on earth.\r\n\r\nThere is no harder misfortune in all human destiny than when the powerful of the earth are not also the first human beings. Then everything becomes fake and crooked and monstrous.\r\n\r\nAnd should they even be last and more beast than human; then the rabble rises and rises in price, until finally even rabble virtue speaks: \u2018Behold, I alone am virtue!\u2019\u201d \u2013\r\n\r\n\u201cWhat did I just hear?\u201d answered Zarathustra. \u201cWhat wisdom among kings! I am delighted, and truly, I\u2019m already in the mood to make a rhyme of it: \u2013\r\n\r\n\u2013 even if it turns out to be a rhyme that is not suitable for everyone\u2019s ears. Long ago I gave up being considerate of long ears. Well then! Well now!\r\n\r\n(But here it happened that the ass too got in a word; and clearly and malevolently he said hee-yaw.)\r\n\r\nOnce \u2013 I think in anno domini one \u2013\r\n\r\nThe Sybil said, drunk, though wine she\u2019d had none:\r\n\r\n\u2018Oh no, how badly things go!\r\n\r\nDecline! Decline! The world has sunk so low!\r\n\r\nRome sank to whore and to a whorehouse too,\r\n\r\nRome\u2019s Caesar to beast, God himself \u2013 turned Jew!\u2019\u201d\r\n\r\n2\r\n\r\nThe kings were enchanted by these rhymes of Zarathustra, but the king to the right spoke: \u201cOh Zarathustra, how well we did in going forth to see you!\r\n\r\nFor your enemies showed us your image in their mirror: there you were with your devil\u2019s grimace and laughing scornfully, such that we were afraid of you.\r\n\r\nBut what good did it do? Again and again you pricked our ears and hearts with your sayings, then we said at last: what does it matter how he looks!\r\n\r\nWe have to hear him, the one who teaches \u2018you shall love peace as a means to new wars, and the short peace more than the long one!\u2019\r\n\r\nNo one has ever spoken such warlike words: \u2018What is good? Being brave is good. The good war hallows any cause.\u2019\r\n\r\nOh Zarathustra, our fathers\u2019 blood stirred in our bodies at the sound of such words; it was like the speech of springtime to old casks of wine.\r\n\r\nWhen swords ran every which way like red-stained snakes, our fathers warmed to life; the sun of all peace seemed limp and lackluster to them, but the long peace caused them shame.\r\n\r\nHow they sighed, our fathers, when they saw gleaming bright, dried up swords on the wall! Like them, they thirsted for war. For a sword wants to drink blood and sparkles with desire.\u201d \u2013\r\n\r\n\u2013 As the kings talked in this manner and gabbed enthusiastically about the happiness of their fathers, Zarathustra was overcome by no small desire to mock their enthusiasm; after all, these were visibly very peaceful kings he saw standing before him, the kind with old and refined faces. But he restrained himself. \u201cWell then!\u201d he said. \u201cThe path leads there, Zarathustra\u2019s cave lies there, and this day shall also have a long evening! But now a cry of distress hurries me away from you.\r\n\r\nIt will honor my cave if kings want to sit and wait in it, but, to be sure, you will have to wait long!\r\n\r\nAlright! What\u2019s the harm? Where does one learn to wait better today than at court? And the whole virtue of kings that is left to them \u2013 is it not today called: being able to wait?\u201d\r\n\r\nThus spoke Zarathustra."}, "id": 81}, {"data": {"uuid": "8e15bb43-3ecb-4c83-aff7-e4197b3cfbf0", "user": 1, "title": "The Leech", "created_on": "2023-05-10 16:51:18.771273+00:00", "updated_on": "2023-05-10 16:51:18.790506+00:00", "article_html": "<h2>The Leech</h2><p>And Zarathustra walked on pensively, farther and deeper through woods and past swampy valleys; but as happens to anyone who reflects on grave matters, he unintentionally stepped on someone. And behold, all at once he was sprayed in the face with one scream of pain and two curses and twenty wicked invectives, such that in his fright he raised his staff and also started beating the man he had just stepped on. Immediately thereupon he gained his composure, and his heart laughed at the folly that he had just committed.</p><p>\u201cForgive me,\u201d he said to the man he had stepped on, who stood up grimly and then sat down. \u201cForgive and partake, above all, in a parable first.</p><p>Of how a wanderer who is dreaming of distant things unintentionally stumbles over a sleeping dog on a lonely lane, a dog lying in the sun:</p><p>\u2013 how both startle then, and attack each other like deathly enemies, these two who are scared to death: so it went with us too.</p><p>And yet! And yet \u2013 how little was missing and they would have caressed each other, this dog and this lonely man! Are they not after all both \u2013 lonely!\u201d</p><p>\u2013 \u201cWhoever you may be,\u201d said the stepped on man, still grimly, \u201cyou step on my dignity with your parable too, and not only with your foot!</p><p>See here, am I some kind of dog?\u201d \u2013 and then the sitting man got up and pulled his bare arm out of the swamp. Because at first he had lain stretched out on the ground, hidden and unrecognizable like those who lie in wait for swamp quarry.</p><p>\u201cBut what in blazes are you doing!\u201d cried Zarathustra, shocked. For he saw that much blood was flowing over the man\u2019s bare arm. \u201cYou wretch, did some wicked beast bite you?\u201d</p><p>The bleeding man laughed, but still angrily. \u201cWhat concern is it of yours!\u201d he said, and made to leave. \u201cHere I am at home and in my territory. Anyone who wants may question me, but I will hardly answer a stumbling fool.\u201d</p><p>\u201cYou are mistaken,\u201d said Zarathustra, with pity, and he held on to him. \u201cYou are mistaken: here you are not in your home, but in my realm, and in here no one comes to harm.</p><p>Meanwhile call me whatever you want \u2013 I am who I must be. I call myself Zarathustra.</p><p>Well then! Up there is the path to Zarathustra\u2019s cave; it isn\u2019t far \u2013 wouldn\u2019t you like to care for your wounds at my place?</p><p>Things have gone badly for you in this life, you wretch; first you were bitten by the beasts, and then \u2013 you were stepped on by a human being!\u201d \u2013</p><p>But when the stepped on man heard the name of Zarathustra, he transformed. \u201cWhat is happening to me!\u201d he cried out. \u201cWho concerns me anymore in this life other than this one person, namely Zarathustra, and that one animal that lives off blood, the leech?</p><p>For the leech\u2019s sake I lay here at this swamp like a fisher, and already my outstretched arm had been bitten ten times, then an even more beautiful leech bites on my blood, Zarathustra himself!</p><p>Oh happiness! Oh miracle! Praised be the day that lured me to this swamp! Praised be the best, liveliest cupping glass living today, praised be the great conscience-leech Zarathustra!\u201d \u2013</p><p>Thus spoke the stepped on man; and Zarathustra was pleased at his words and their fine, respectful manner. \u201cWho are you?\u201d he said, and offered him his hand. \u201cBetween us there is much to clear up and to cheer up; but already it seems to me the day is growing pure and bright.\u201d</p><p>\u201cI am the conscientious of spirit,\u201d answered the man, \u201cand in matters of the spirit one can hardly be more rigorous, vigorous and venomous than I, except the one from whom I learned it, Zarathustra himself.</p><p>Rather know nothing, than know much half way! Rather be a fool in one\u2019s own right than a wise man according to strangers. I \u2013 go to the ground of things:</p><p>\u2013 what does it matter whether it is big or small? Whether it is called swamp or sky? A hand\u2019s breadth of ground is enough for me, if only it is real ground and bottom!</p><p>\u2013 a hand\u2019s breadth of ground: on that one can stand. In proper science and conscience there is nothing great and nothing small.\u201d</p><p>\u201cSo perhaps you are the expert on the leech?\u201d asked Zarathustra. \u201cAnd you pursue the leech down to its ultimate grounds, you conscientious one?\u201d</p><p>\u201cOh Zarathustra,\u201d answered the stepped on man. \u201cThat would be a monstrous undertaking, how could I presume to such a thing!</p><p>What I am master and expert of, however, is the leech\u2019s brain \u2013 that is my world!</p><p>And it is a world too! But forgive me that my pride speaks up here, for in this matter I have no equal. That is why I said \u2018here I am at home.\u2019</p><p>How long already have I pursued this one thing, the brain of the leech, so that the slippery truth no longer slips away from me here? Here is my realm!</p><p>\u2013 this is why I threw away everything else, this is why all else is the same to me; and right next to my knowledge my black ignorance lurks.</p><p>My conscience of spirit wants of me that I know one thing and do not know everything else; I am nauseated by all halfness of spirit, all hazy, soaring, rapturous people.</p><p>Where my honesty ceases I am blind and also want to be blind. But where I want to know, I also want to be honest, namely venomous, rigorous, vigorous, cruel and inexorable.</p><p>That you once said, oh Zarathustra: \u2018Spirit is the life that itself cuts into life,\u2019 that induced and seduced me to your teaching. And truly, with my own blood I increased my own knowledge!\u201d</p><p>\u2013 \u201cAnd it shows too,\u201d interrupted Zarathustra; for blood was still flowing from the bare arm of the conscientious one. No fewer than ten leeches, after all, had bored themselves into it.</p><p>\u201cOh you weird fellow, how much is revealed to me by your appearance, namely you yourself! And maybe I should not pour all of it into your rigorous ears!</p><p>Well then! Let\u2019s part here! But I would like to find you again. Up there leads the path to my cave; tonight you shall be my dear guest there!</p><p>I would also like to make it up to your body that Zarathustra stepped on you with his feet; I\u2019ll be thinking about that. And behold, all at once he was sprayed in the face with one scream of pain and two curses and twenty wicked invectives, such that in his fright he raised his staff and also started beating the man he had just stepped on. Immediately thereupon he gained his composure, and his heart laughed at the folly that he had just committed.\r\n\r\n\u201cForgive me,\u201d he said to the man he had stepped on, who stood up grimly and then sat down. \u201cForgive and partake, above all, in a parable first.\r\n\r\nOf how a wanderer who is dreaming of distant things unintentionally stumbles over a sleeping dog on a lonely lane, a dog lying in the sun:\r\n\r\n\u2013 how both startle then, and attack each other like deathly enemies, these two who are scared to death: so it went with us too.\r\n\r\nAnd yet! And yet \u2013 how little was missing and they would have caressed each other, this dog and this lonely man! Are they not after all both \u2013 lonely!\u201d\r\n\r\n\u2013 \u201cWhoever you may be,\u201d said the stepped on man, still grimly, \u201cyou step on my dignity with your parable too, and not only with your foot!\r\n\r\nSee here, am I some kind of dog?\u201d \u2013 and then the sitting man got up and pulled his bare arm out of the swamp. Because at first he had lain stretched out on the ground, hidden and unrecognizable like those who lie in wait for swamp quarry.\r\n\r\n\u201cBut what in blazes are you doing!\u201d cried Zarathustra, shocked. For he saw that much blood was flowing over the man\u2019s bare arm. \u201cYou wretch, did some wicked beast bite you?\u201d\r\n\r\nThe bleeding man laughed, but still angrily. \u201cWhat concern is it of yours!\u201d he said, and made to leave. \u201cHere I am at home and in my territory. Anyone who wants may question me, but I will hardly answer a stumbling fool.\u201d\r\n\r\n\u201cYou are mistaken,\u201d said Zarathustra, with pity, and he held on to him. \u201cYou are mistaken: here you are not in your home, but in my realm, and in here no one comes to harm.\r\n\r\nMeanwhile call me whatever you want \u2013 I am who I must be. I call myself Zarathustra.\r\n\r\nWell then! Up there is the path to Zarathustra\u2019s cave; it isn\u2019t far \u2013 wouldn\u2019t you like to care for your wounds at my place?\r\n\r\nThings have gone badly for you in this life, you wretch; first you were bitten by the beasts, and then \u2013 you were stepped on by a human being!\u201d \u2013\r\n\r\nBut when the stepped on man heard the name of Zarathustra, he transformed. \u201cWhat is happening to me!\u201d he cried out. \u201cWho concerns me anymore in this life other than this one person, namely Zarathustra, and that one animal that lives off blood, the leech?\r\n\r\nFor the leech\u2019s sake I lay here at this swamp like a fisher, and already my outstretched arm had been bitten ten times, then an even more beautiful leech bites on my blood, Zarathustra himself!\r\n\r\nOh happiness! Oh miracle! Praised be the day that lured me to this swamp! Praised be the best, liveliest cupping glass living today, praised be the great conscience-leech Zarathustra!\u201d \u2013\r\n\r\nThus spoke the stepped on man; and Zarathustra was pleased at his words and their fine, respectful manner. \u201cWho are you?\u201d he said, and offered him his hand. \u201cBetween us there is much to clear up and to cheer up; but already it seems to me the day is growing pure and bright.\u201d\r\n\r\n\u201cI am the conscientious of spirit,\u201d answered the man, \u201cand in matters of the spirit one can hardly be more rigorous, vigorous and venomous than I, except the one from whom I learned it, Zarathustra himself.\r\n\r\nRather know nothing, than know much half way! Rather be a fool in one\u2019s own right than a wise man according to strangers. I \u2013 go to the ground of things:\r\n\r\n\u2013 what does it matter whether it is big or small? Whether it is called swamp or sky? A hand\u2019s breadth of ground is enough for me, if only it is real ground and bottom!\r\n\r\n\u2013 a hand\u2019s breadth of ground: on that one can stand. In proper science and conscience there is nothing great and nothing small.\u201d\r\n\r\n\u201cSo perhaps you are the expert on the leech?\u201d asked Zarathustra. \u201cAnd you pursue the leech down to its ultimate grounds, you conscientious one?\u201d\r\n\r\n\u201cOh Zarathustra,\u201d answered the stepped on man. \u201cThat would be a monstrous undertaking, how could I presume to such a thing!\r\n\r\nWhat I am master and expert of, however, is the leech\u2019s brain \u2013 that is my world!\r\n\r\nAnd it is a world too! But forgive me that my pride speaks up here, for in this matter I have no equal. That is why I said \u2018here I am at home.\u2019\r\n\r\nHow long already have I pursued this one thing, the brain of the leech, so that the slippery truth no longer slips away from me here? Here is my realm!\r\n\r\n\u2013 this is why I threw away everything else, this is why all else is the same to me; and right next to my knowledge my black ignorance lurks.\r\n\r\nMy conscience of spirit wants of me that I know one thing and do not know everything else; I am nauseated by all halfness of spirit, all hazy, soaring, rapturous people.\r\n\r\nWhere my honesty ceases I am blind and also want to be blind. But where I want to know, I also want to be honest, namely venomous, rigorous, vigorous, cruel and inexorable.\r\n\r\nThat you once said, oh Zarathustra: \u2018Spirit is the life that itself cuts into life,\u2019 that induced and seduced me to your teaching. And truly, with my own blood I increased my own knowledge!\u201d\r\n\r\n\u2013 \u201cAnd it shows too,\u201d interrupted Zarathustra; for blood was still flowing from the bare arm of the conscientious one. No fewer than ten leeches, after all, had bored themselves into it.\r\n\r\n\u201cOh you weird fellow, how much is revealed to me by your appearance, namely you yourself! And maybe I should not pour all of it into your rigorous ears!\r\n\r\nWell then! Let\u2019s part here! But I would like to find you again. Up there leads the path to my cave; tonight you shall be my dear guest there!\r\n\r\nI would also like to make it up to your body that Zarathustra stepped on you with his feet; I\u2019ll be thinking about that. But now a cry of distress hurries me away from you.\u201d\r\n\r\nThus spoke Zarathustra."}, "id": 82}, {"data": {"uuid": "f6be4397-471c-4d28-9b7f-12d6ec710b0c", "user": 1, "title": "The Magician", "created_on": "2023-05-10 16:52:21.551158+00:00", "updated_on": "2023-05-10 16:52:21.575843+00:00", "article_html": "<h2>The Magician</h2><h3>1</h3><p>But as Zarathustra made his way around a boulder he saw someone not far below him on the same path, flailing his limbs like a raving madman, who finally flopped belly-first to the ground. \u201cStop!\u201d said Zarathustra to his heart. \u201cThat one there must be the higher man, that awful cry of distress came from him \u2013 I\u2019ll go see if I can help.\u201d But when he ran to the spot where the person lay on the ground, he found a trembling old man with a fixed gaze; and as hard as Zarathustra tried to prop him up and stand him on his feet again, it was in vain. Nor did the unfortunate man seem to notice that someone was with him; instead he kept looking around with pitiful gestures, like someone who had been abandoned and left stranded by the whole world. At last, however, after much trembling and twitching and writhing he began to wail thus:</p><p>Who will warm me, who loves me still?<br>Give me hot hands!<br>Give me braziers for my heart!<br>Laid out, shuddering,<br>Like something half-dead whose feet one warms \u2013<br>Racked, oh! by unknown fevers,<br>Shivering from pointy icy arrows of frost,<br>Hunted by you, thought!<br>Unnameable! Disguised! Horrendous one!<br>You hunter behind clouds!<br>Struck down by your lightning,<br>You scornful eye that looks at me from darkness:<br>\u2013 I lie here,<br>Doubled up, writhing, tortured<br>By all eternal torments,<br>Struck<br>By you, cruelest hunter,<br>You unknown \u2013 god!</p><p>Strike deeper,<br>Strike one more time!<br>Skewer, smash this heart!<br>Why this torment<br>With blunt-toothed arrows?<br>Why do you look again,<br>Not weary of human agony,<br>With gloating gods\u2019 eyes flashing lightning?<br>You do not want to kill,<br>Only torment, torment?<br>Why torment me,<br>You gloating unknown god? \u2013</p><p>Aha! You sneak close?<br>At such midnight<br>What do you want? Speak!<br>You press me, squeeze me \u2013<br>Ha! too close already!<br>Away! Away!<br>You hear me breathing,<br>you listen to my heart,<br>You jealous one \u2013<br>But of what are you jealous?<br>Away! Away! Why the ladder?<br>Do you want in,<br>Into my heart,<br>To climb in, to climb into<br>My most secret thoughts?<br>Shameless one! Unknown \u2013 thief!<br>What would you gain by stealing,<br>What would you gain by eavesdropping,<br>What would you gain by torturing,<br>You torturer!<br>You executioner god!<br>Or should I, like a dog,<br>Roll over before you?<br>Devotedly, ecstatically beside myself<br>Wag love \u2013 to you?</p><p>In vain! Stab deeper,<br>Cruelest thorn! No,<br>Not dog, only your prey am I,<br>Cruelest hunter!<br>Your proudest captive,<br>You robber behind clouds!<br>Speak at last,<br>What do you want, waylayer, from me?<br>You disguised in lightning! Unknown one! Speak,<br>What do you want, unknown god? \u2013<br>What? Ransom?<br>Why do you want ransom?<br>Demand much \u2013 thus my pride counsels!<br>And speak briefly \u2013 thus my other pride counsels!</p><p>Aha!<br>Me \u2013 you want? Me?<br>Me \u2013 entirely?</p><p>Aha!<br>And you torment me, fool that you are,<br>Torment my pride?<br>Give me love \u2013 who will warm me still?<br>Who loves me still? \u2013 give me hot hands,<br>Give me braziers for my heart,<br>Give me, the loneliest one,<br>Whom ice, alas, sevenfold ice<br>Teaches to yearn,<br>To yearn even for enemies,<br>Give, yes give,<br>Cruelest enemy,<br>Give me \u2013 yourself! \u2013</p><p>Gone!<br>He himself fled,<br>My last, my only companion,<br>My great enemy,<br>My unknown,<br>My executioner god! \u2013</p><p>\u2013 No! Come back,<br>With all your torments!<br>To the last of all lonely ones<br>Oh come back!<br>All my rivers of tears flow<br>Their course to you!<br>And my last heart flames \u2013<br>For you they flicker!<br>Oh come back,<br>My unknown god! My pain! My last \u2013<br>happiness!</p><h3>2</h3><p>\u2013 But at this point Zarathustra could no longer restrain himself, grabbed his staff and began beating the wailing man with all his strength. \u201cShut up!\u201d he cried to him, with grim laughter. \u201cShut up, you actor! You counterfeiter! You liar from top to bottom! I recognize you well!</p><p>I\u2019ll give you warm legs, you wicked magician, I\u2019m very good at heating up people like you!\u201d</p><p>\u2013 \u201cDesist,\u201d said the old man and he leaped to his feet. \u201cBeat me no more, oh Zarathustra! I only did this as a game!</p><p>Such things belong to my art; you yourself I wanted to put to the test, when I gave you this test. And verily, you saw through me well!</p><p>But you yourself \u2013 you also tested me with no small sample of yourself: you are hard, you wise Zarathustra! You hit hard with your \u2018truths,\u2019 your cudgel forces this truth out of me!\u201d</p><p>\u2013 \u201cDo not flatter,\u201d answered Zarathustra, still upset and frowning darkly, \u201cyou actor from top to bottom! You\u2019re fake \u2013 why do you talk \u2013 of truth!</p><p>You peacock of peacocks, you sea of vanity, what are you playing before me, you wicked magician, in whom am I supposed to believe when you wail in this form?\u201d</p><p>\u201cThe penitent of the spirit,\u201d said the old man. \u201cHim I played: you yourself once coined this phrase \u2013</p><p>\u2013 the poet and magician who ultimately turns his spirit against himself, the transformed one who freezes to death from his own evil science and conscience.</p><p>And just admit it: it took you a long time, oh Zarathustra, before you saw through my art and lie! You believed in my distress when you cradled my head with both hands \u2013</p><p>\u2013 I heard you wail \u2018they loved him too little, loved him too little!\u2019 That I was able to deceive you to such an extent, that causes my malice to jubilate secretly.\u201d</p><p>\u201cYou may have deceived finer heads than me,\u201d said Zarathustra harshly. \u201cI am not on my guard for deceivers, I have to be without caution \u2013 my fate wants it so.</p><p>But you \u2013 have to deceive: that much I know about you! You always have to be e-quivocal, tri-, quad- and quinquivocal! Even what you just now confessed was not nearly true nor false enough for me!</p><p>You wicked counterfeiter, how could you do otherwise! You would even put make-up on your disease when you show yourself naked to your physician.</p><p>Just like you put make-up on your lie before me when you said \u2018I only did this as a game!\u2019 There was earnest in it, you are something of a penitent of the spirit!</p><p>I guessed you well: you became everyone\u2019s enchanter, but against yourself you have no lie and no guile left over \u2013 you are disenchanted of yourself!</p><p>You harvested nausea as your single truth. Not a word of yours is genuine anymore, except your mouth: namely the nausea that clings to your mouth.\u201d \u2013</p><p>\u2013 \u201cWho are you!\u201d yelled the old magician at this point, with defiance in his voice. \u201cWho is permitted to speak with me thus, the greatest person living today?\u201d \u2013 and an emerald bolt of lightning shot from his eye toward Zarathustra. But then he transformed immediately and said sadly:</p><p>\u201cOh Zarathustra, I am weary of and nauseated by my arts, I am not great, why do I pretend! But, you know it well \u2013 I sought greatness!</p><p>I wanted to represent a great human being and I persuaded many; but this lie was beyond my powers. On it I break down.</p><p>Oh Zarathustra, everything about me is a lie; but that I am breaking down \u2013 this breaking down is genuine!\u201d \u2013</p><p>\u201cIt does you honor,\u201d spoke Zarathustra somberly and glancing down to the side, \u201cit does you honor that you sought greatness, but it also betrays you. You are not great.</p><p>You wicked old magician, that is your best and most honest, and what I honor in you, namely that you wearied of yourself and said so: \u2018I am not great.\u2019</p><p>In that I honor you as a penitent of the spirit; and even if it was only for a whiff and a wink, for this one moment you were \u2013 genuine.</p><p>But tell me, what do you seek here in my woods and cliffs? And when you laid yourself in my path, what did you want to test in me? \u2013</p><p>\u2013 why did you research me?\u201d \u2013</p><p>Thus spoke Zarathustra, and his eyes flashed. The old magician was silent for a while, then he said: \u201cDid I research you? I merely \u2013 search.</p><p>Oh Zarathustra, I seek someone who is genuine, proper, simple, unequivocal, a human being of all honesty, a vessel of wisdom, a saint of knowledge, a great human being!</p><p>Do you not know it, oh Zarathustra? I seek Zarathustra.\u201d</p><p>\u2013 And here a long silence ensued between the two; but Zarathustra became deeply immersed in himself, such that he closed his eyes. But then, turning back to his interlocutor, he seized the hand of the magician and spoke, full of kindness and craftiness:</p><p>\u201cWell then! Up there leads the path, there lies the cave of Zarathustra. In it you may seek whomever you wish to find.</p><p>And ask my animals for advice, my eagle and my snake: they shall help you seek. But my cave is big.</p><p>For my part \u2013 I\u2019ve never seen a great human being. The eyes of the finest are too coarse today for what is great. It is the kingdom of the rabble.</p><p>Many a one I found already, who stretched and puffed himself up, and the people cried: \u2018See here, a great human being!\u2019 But what good are all bellows! In the end only wind comes out.</p><p>In the end a frog will burst if it puffs itself up too long: then only wind comes out. To stab a swollen person in the belly \u2013 that\u2019s what I call great fun. Hear me, you little boys!</p><p>Today belongs to the rabble; who knows anymore what is great, what is small! Who could successfully search for greatness! Only a fool \u2013 fools would succeed.</p><p>You seek great human beings, you queer fool? Who taught you that? Is the time for that today? Oh you wicked searcher \u2013 why do you research me?\u201d \u2013</p><p>Thus spoke Zarathustra, comforted in his heart, and off he went again on his way, laughing.</p>", "article_json": {"type": "doc", "content": [{"type": "heading", "attrs": {"level": 2}, "content": [{"text": "The Magician", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "heading", "attrs": {"level": 3}, "content": [{"text": "1", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "content": [{"text": "But as Zarathustra made his way around a boulder he saw someone not far below him on the same path, flailing his limbs like a raving madman, who finally flopped belly-first to the ground. \u201cStop!\u201d said Zarathustra to his heart. \u201cThat one there must be the higher man, that awful cry of distress came from him \u2013 I\u2019ll go see if I can help.\u201d But when he ran to the spot where the person lay on the ground, he found a trembling old man with a fixed gaze; and as hard as Zarathustra tried to prop him up and stand him on his feet again, it was in vain.
