Nor did the unfortunate man seem to notice that someone was with him; instead he kept looking around with pitiful gestures, like someone who had been abandoned and left stranded by the whole world. At last, however, after much trembling and twitching and writhing he began to wail thus:\r\n\r\nWho will warm me, who loves me still?\r\nGive me hot hands!\r\nGive me braziers for my heart!\r\nLaid out, shuddering,\r\nLike something half-dead whose feet one warms \u2013\r\nRacked, oh! by unknown fevers,\r\nShivering from pointy icy arrows of frost,\r\nHunted by you, thought!\r\nUnnameable! Disguised! Horrendous one!\r\nYou hunter behind clouds!\r\nStruck down by your lightning,\r\nYou scornful eye that looks at me from darkness:\r\n\u2013 I lie here,\r\nDoubled up, writhing, tortured\r\nBy all eternal torments,\r\nStruck\r\nBy you, cruelest hunter,\r\nYou unknown \u2013 god!\r\n\r\nStrike deeper,\r\nStrike one more time!\r\nSkewer, smash this heart!\r\nWhy this torment\r\nWith blunt-toothed arrows?\r\nWhy do you look again,\r\nNot weary of human agony,\r\nWith gloating gods\u2019 eyes flashing lightning?\r\nYou do not want to kill,\r\nOnly torment, torment?\r\nWhy torment me,\r\nYou gloating unknown god? \u2013\r\n\r\nAha! You sneak close?\r\nAt such midnight\r\nWhat do you want? Speak!\r\nYou press me, squeeze me \u2013\r\nHa! too close already!\r\nAway! Away!\r\nYou hear me breathing,\r\nyou listen to my heart,\r\nYou jealous one \u2013\r\nBut of what are you jealous?\r\nAway! Away! Why the ladder?\r\nDo you want in,\r\nInto my heart,\r\nTo climb in, to climb into\r\nMy most secret thoughts?\r\nShameless one! Unknown \u2013 thief!\r\nWhat would you gain by stealing,\r\nWhat would you gain by eavesdropping,\r\nWhat would you gain by torturing,\r\nYou torturer!\r\nYou executioner god!\r\nOr should I, like a dog,\r\nRoll over before you?\r\nDevotedly, ecstatically beside myself\r\nWag love \u2013 to you?\r\n\r\nIn vain! Stab deeper,\r\nCruelest thorn! No,\r\nNot dog, only your prey am I,\r\nCruelest hunter!\r\nYour proudest captive,\r\nYou robber behind clouds!\r\nSpeak at last,\r\nWhat do you want, waylayer, from me?\r\nYou disguised in lightning! Unknown one! Speak,\r\nWhat do you want, unknown god? \u2013\r\nWhat? Ransom?\r\nWhy do you want ransom?\r\nDemand much \u2013 thus my pride counsels!\r\nAnd speak briefly \u2013 thus my other pride counsels!\r\n\r\nAha!\r\nMe \u2013 you want? Me?\r\nMe \u2013 entirely?\r\n\r\nAha!\r\nAnd you torment me, fool that you are,\r\nTorment my pride?\r\nGive me love \u2013 who will warm me still?\r\nWho loves me still? \u2013 give me hot hands,\r\nGive me braziers for my heart,\r\nGive me, the loneliest one,\r\nWhom ice, alas, sevenfold ice\r\nTeaches to yearn,\r\nTo yearn even for enemies,\r\nGive, yes give,\r\nCruelest enemy,\r\nGive me \u2013 yourself! \u2013\r\n\r\nGone!\r\nHe himself fled,\r\nMy last, my only companion,\r\nMy great enemy,\r\nMy unknown,\r\nMy executioner god! \u2013\r\n\r\n\u2013 No! Come back,\r\nWith all your torments!\r\nTo the last of all lonely ones\r\nOh come back!\r\nAll my rivers of tears flow\r\nTheir course to you!\r\nAnd my last heart flames \u2013\r\nFor you they flicker!\r\nOh come back,\r\nMy unknown god! My pain! My last \u2013\r\nhappiness!\r\n\r\n2\r\n\r\n\u2013 But at this point Zarathustra could no longer restrain himself, grabbed his staff and began beating the wailing man with all his strength. \u201cShut up!\u201d he cried to him, with grim laughter. \u201cShut up, you actor! You counterfeiter! You liar from top to bottom! I recognize you well!\r\n\r\nI\u2019ll give you warm legs, you wicked magician, I\u2019m very good at heating up people like you!\u201d\r\n\r\n\u2013 \u201cDesist,\u201d said the old man and he leaped to his feet. \u201cBeat me no more, oh Zarathustra! I only did this as a game!\r\n\r\nSuch things belong to my art; you yourself I wanted to put to the test, when I gave you this test. And verily, you saw through me well!\r\n\r\nBut you yourself \u2013 you also tested me with no small sample of yourself: you are hard, you wise Zarathustra! You hit hard with your \u2018truths,\u2019 your cudgel forces this truth out of me!\u201d\r\n\r\n\u2013 \u201cDo not flatter,\u201d answered Zarathustra, still upset and frowning darkly, \u201cyou actor from top to bottom! You\u2019re fake \u2013 why do you talk \u2013 of truth!\r\n\r\nYou peacock of peacocks, you sea of vanity, what are you playing before me, you wicked magician, in whom am I supposed to believe when you wail in this form?\u201d\r\n\r\n\u201cThe penitent of the spirit,\u201d said the old man. \u201cHim I played: you yourself once coined this phrase \u2013\r\n\r\n\u2013 the poet and magician who ultimately turns his spirit against himself, the transformed one who freezes to death from his own evil science and conscience.\r\n\r\nAnd just admit it: it took you a long time, oh Zarathustra, before you saw through my art and lie! You believed in my distress when you cradled my head with both hands \u2013\r\n\r\n\u2013 I heard you wail \u2018they loved him too little, loved him too little!\u2019 That I was able to deceive you to such an extent, that causes my malice to jubilate secretly.\u201d\r\n\r\n\u201cYou may have deceived finer heads than me,\u201d said Zarathustra harshly. \u201cI am not on my guard for deceivers, I have to be without caution \u2013 my fate wants it so.\r\n\r\nBut you \u2013 have to deceive: that much I know about you! You always have to be e-quivocal, tri-, quad- and quinquivocal! Even what you just now confessed was not nearly true nor false enough for me!\r\n\r\nYou wicked counterfeiter, how could you do otherwise! You would even put make-up on your disease when you show yourself naked to your physician.\r\n\r\nJust like you put make-up on your lie before me when you said \u2018I only did this as a game!\u2019 There was earnest in it, you are something of a penitent of the spirit!\r\n\r\nI guessed you well: you became everyone\u2019s enchanter, but against yourself you have no lie and no guile left over \u2013 you are disenchanted of yourself!\r\n\r\nYou harvested nausea as your single truth. Not a word of yours is genuine anymore, except your mouth: namely the nausea that clings to your mouth.\u201d \u2013\r\n\r\n\u2013 \u201cWho are you!\u201d yelled the old magician at this point, with defiance in his voice. \u201cWho is permitted to speak with me thus, the greatest person living today?\u201d \u2013 and an emerald bolt of lightning shot from his eye toward Zarathustra. But then he transformed immediately and said sadly:\r\n\r\n\u201cOh Zarathustra, I am weary of and nauseated by my arts, I am not great, why do I pretend! But, you know it well \u2013 I sought greatness!\r\n\r\nI wanted to represent a great human being and I persuaded many; but this lie was beyond my powers. On it I break down.\r\n\r\nOh Zarathustra, everything about me is a lie; but that I am breaking down \u2013 this breaking down is genuine!\u201d \u2013\r\n\r\n\u201cIt does you honor,\u201d spoke Zarathustra somberly and glancing down to the side, \u201cit does you honor that you sought greatness, but it also betrays you. You are not great.\r\n\r\nYou wicked old magician, that is your best and most honest, and what I honor in you, namely that you wearied of yourself and said so: \u2018I am not great.\u2019\r\n\r\nIn that I honor you as a penitent of the spirit; and even if it was only for a whiff and a wink, for this one moment you were \u2013 genuine.\r\n\r\nBut tell me, what do you seek here in my woods and cliffs? And when you laid yourself in my path, what did you want to test in me? \u2013\r\n\r\n\u2013 why did you research me?\u201d \u2013\r\n\r\nThus spoke Zarathustra, and his eyes flashed. The old magician was silent for a while, then he said: \u201cDid I research you? I merely \u2013 search.\r\n\r\nOh Zarathustra, I seek someone who is genuine, proper, simple, unequivocal, a human being of all honesty, a vessel of wisdom, a saint of knowledge, a great human being!\r\n\r\nDo you not know it, oh Zarathustra? I seek Zarathustra.\u201d\r\n\r\n\u2013 And here a long silence ensued between the two; but Zarathustra became deeply immersed in himself, such that he closed his eyes. But then, turning back to his interlocutor, he seized the hand of the magician and spoke, full of kindness and craftiness:\r\n\r\n\u201cWell then! Up there leads the path, there lies the cave of Zarathustra. In it you may seek whomever you wish to find.\r\n\r\nAnd ask my animals for advice, my eagle and my snake: they shall help you seek. But my cave is big.\r\n\r\nFor my part \u2013 I\u2019ve never seen a great human being. The eyes of the finest are too coarse today for what is great. It is the kingdom of the rabble.\r\n\r\nMany a one I found already, who stretched and puffed himself up, and the people cried: \u2018See here, a great human being!\u2019 But what good are all bellows! In the end only wind comes out.\r\n\r\nIn the end a frog will burst if it puffs itself up too long: then only wind comes out. To stab a swollen person in the belly \u2013 that\u2019s what I call great fun. Hear me, you little boys!\r\n\r\nToday belongs to the rabble; who knows anymore what is great, what is small! Who could successfully search for greatness! Only a fool \u2013 fools would succeed.\r\n\r\nYou seek great human beings, you queer fool? Who taught you that? Is the time for that today? Oh you wicked searcher \u2013 why do you research me?\u201d \u2013\r\n\r\nThus spoke Zarathustra, comforted in his heart, and off he went again on his way, laughing."}, "id": 83}, {"data": {"uuid": "5a2e25e4-3a8a-480a-a630-c1bcf1d200db", "user": 1, "title": "Retired", "created_on": "2023-05-10 16:53:05.892633+00:00", "updated_on": "2023-05-10 16:53:05.915636+00:00", "article_html": "<h2>Retired</h2><p>Not long after he had freed himself from the magician, however, Zarathustra again saw someone sitting beside the path that he walked, namely a tall man in black with a gaunt, pale face: this man dismayed him tremendously. \u201cOh no,\u201d he spoke to his heart, \u201cthere sits depression in disguise, and its looks remind me of priests: what do they want in my kingdom?</p><p>What! Scarcely did I escape that magician, now another practitioner of black arts has to cross my path \u2013</p><p>\u2013 some kind of sorcerer with laying-on of hands, a dark miracle worker of God\u2019s grace, an anointed world slanderer, may the devil take him!</p><p>But the devil is never in place where he would be in the right place; he always comes too late, this damned dwarf and clubfoot!\u201d \u2013</p><p>Thus cursed Zarathustra impatiently in his heart and he considered how he might avert his gaze and slip by the man in black; but behold, it happened differently. For in the same moment the sitting man had already caught sight of him, and not unlike a person who has run into unexpected luck, he leaped to his feet and approached Zarathustra.</p><p>\u201cWhoever you may be, you wanderer,\u201d he said, \u201chelp a lost, seeking old man who could easily come to harm here!</p><p>This world here is foreign to me and far off, I even heard wild beasts howling; and the one who could have offered me protection, he himself no longer exists.</p><p>I sought the last pious human being, a saint and a hermit who alone in his woods had not yet heard what the whole world today knows.\u201d</p><p>\u201cWhat does the whole world know today?\u201d asked Zarathustra. \u201cThis perhaps, that the old God no longer lives, the one in whom the whole world once believed?\u201d</p><p>\u201cYou said it,\u201d answered the old man gloomily. \u201cAnd I served this old God until his final hour.</p><p>But now I am retired, without a master, and yet I am not free, nor merry for a single hour unless in my memories.</p><p>And so I climbed into these mountains to finally have a festival for myself, as is proper for an old pope and church father: for know this, I am the last pope! \u2013 a festival of pious memories and divine worship.</p><p>But now he himself is dead, this most pious human being, this saint in the woods who constantly praised his god with singing and growling.</p><p>I did not find him when I found his hut \u2013 but two wolves were in it, howling at his death \u2013 for all animals loved him. Then I ran away.</p><p>Did I arrive in vain in these woods and mountains? Then my heart resolved to seek another, the most pious of all those who do not believe in God \u2013 to seek Zarathustra!\u201d</p><p>Thus spoke the oldster and he looked with a sharp eye at the man who stood before him; but Zarathustra grasped the old pope\u2019s hand and regarded it admiringly for a long time.</p><p>\u201cSee here, you reverend one,\u201d he said then, \u201cwhat a beautiful and long hand! This is the hand of one who has always dispensed blessings. Now, however, it holds on to the one you seek, to me, Zarathustra.</p><p>I am he, godless Zarathustra, who speaks: who is more godless than I, that I may enjoy his instruction?\u201d \u2013</p><p>Thus spoke Zarathustra and with his gaze he penetrated the thoughts and secret thoughts of the old pope. At last the latter began:</p><p>\u201cThe one who loved and possessed him most has now also lost him most \u2013 :</p><p>\u2013 behold, perhaps I myself am now the more godless of us two? But who could take pleasure in that!\u201d \u2013</p><p>\u201cYou served him up until the end,\u201d said Zarathustra, pensively, after a deep silence. \u201cDo you know how he died? Is it true, as they say, that pity choked him to death,</p><p>\u2013 that he saw how the human being hung on the cross, and couldn\u2019t bear that his love for mankind became his hell and ultimately his death?\u201d \u2013</p><p>But the old pope did not answer, and instead he looked to the side awkwardly and with a pained and dark expression.</p><p>\u201cLet him go,\u201d said Zarathustra after a long thoughtful pause, while still looking the old man straight in the eye.</p><p>\u201cLet him go, he\u2019s gone. And even though it honors you that you speak only good of this dead one, still you know as well as I who he was; and that he walked queer ways.\u201d</p><p>\u201cFor our three eyes only,\u201d said the old pope cheerfully (because he was blind in one eye), \u201cin matters of God I am more enlightened than Zarathustra himself \u2013 and am permitted to be.</p><p>My love served him long years, my will followed his will in all things. But a good servant knows everything, and also some things that his master conceals from himself.</p><p>He was a concealed god, full of secretiveness. Indeed, even in getting himself a son he used nothing other than sneaky means. At the doorway of his faith stands adultery.</p><p>Whoever praises him as a god of love does not think highly enough of love itself. Did this god not also want to be judge? But the loving one loves beyond reward and retribution.</p><p>When he was young, this god from the East, then he was harsh and vengeful and he built himself a hell for the amusement of his favorites.</p><p>But at last he became old and soft and mellow and pitying, more like a grandfather than a father, but most like a wobbly old grandmother.</p><p>There he sat, wilted, in his nook by the stove, grousing about his weak legs, weary of the world, weary of willing, and one day he choked to death on his all too great pity.\u201d \u2013</p><p>\u201cYou old pope,\u201d said Zarathustra here, interrupting. \u201cDid you see that with your own eyes? It certainly could have happened that way; that way, and another way too. When gods die, they always die many kinds of death.</p><p>But well then! This way or that, this way and that \u2013 he\u2019s gone! He was offensive to the taste of my ears and eyes, I do not wish to speak anything worse of him.</p><p>I love everything that gazes brightly and speaks honestly. But he \u2013 you know it well, you old priest, there was something of your kind in him, something priest-like \u2013 he was equivocal.</p><p>He was also unclear. How he raged at us, this wrath snorter, because we understood him poorly! But why did he not speak more purely!</p><p>And if the fault was in our ears, why did he give us ears that heard him poorly? If mud was in our ears, well then \u2013 who put it there?</p><p>He failed at too much, this potter who never completed his training! But that he avenged himself on his clay formations and his creations because they turned out badly for him \u2013 that was a sin against good taste.</p><p>In piousness too there is good taste; it said at last: \u201cAway with such a god! Rather no god, rather meet destiny on one\u2019s own, rather be a fool, rather be a god oneself!\u201d</p><p>\u2013 \u201cWhat do I hear!\u201d spoke the old pope at this point with pricked up ears. \u201cOh Zarathustra, you are more pious than you believe, with such disbelief! Some kind of god in you converted you to your godlessness.</p><p>Is it not your very piousness that no longer allows you to believe in a god? And your overly great honesty will yet lead you away beyond good and evil!</p><p>Take a good look: what is left for you? You have eyes and hands and mouth that have been preordained for blessing since eternity. One does not bless with hands alone.</p><p>In your proximity, even though you claim to be the most godless man, I detect a secret, sacred and sweet aroma of long blessings: it makes me happy and it makes me hurt.</p><p>Let me be your guest, oh Zarathustra, for one single night! Nowhere on earth do I feel happier now than with you!\u201d \u2013</p><p>\u201cAmen! It shall be so!\u201d spoke Zarathustra with great astonishment. \u201cUp there leads the path, there lies the cave of Zarathustra.</p><p>Gladly, to be sure, I would guide you there myself, you reverend one, because I love all pious people. But now a cry of distress hurries me away from you.</p><p>In my realm no one shall come to harm; my cave is a safe harbor. And I would like nothing better than to place every sad person back on firm land and firm legs.</p><p>But who could take your melancholy off your shoulders? For that I\u2019m too weak. We may have to wait a long time, truly, before someone awakens your god again.</p><p>For this old god does not live anymore: he is thoroughly dead.\u201d \u2013</p><p>Thus spoke Zarathustra.</p>", "article_json": {"type": "doc", "content": [{"type": "heading", "attrs": {"level": 2}, "content": [{"text": "Retired", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "content": [{"text": "Not long after he had freed himself from the magician, however, Zarathustra again saw someone sitting beside the path that he walked, namely a tall man in black with a gaunt, pale face: this man dismayed him tremendously. \u201cOh no,\u201d he spoke to his heart, \u201cthere sits depression in disguise, and its looks remind me of priests: what do they want in my kingdom?", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "content": [{"text": "What! For in the same moment the sitting man had already caught sight of him, and not unlike a person who has run into unexpected luck, he leaped to his feet and approached Zarathustra.\r\n\r\n\u201cWhoever you may be, you wanderer,\u201d he said, \u201chelp a lost, seeking old man who could easily come to harm here!\r\n\r\nThis world here is foreign to me and far off, I even heard wild beasts howling; and the one who could have offered me protection, he himself no longer exists.\r\n\r\nI sought the last pious human being, a saint and a hermit who alone in his woods had not yet heard what the whole world today knows.\u201d\r\n\r\n\u201cWhat does the whole world know today?\u201d asked Zarathustra. \u201cThis perhaps, that the old God no longer lives, the one in whom the whole world once believed?\u201d\r\n\r\n\u201cYou said it,\u201d answered the old man gloomily. \u201cAnd I served this old God until his final hour.\r\n\r\nBut now I am retired, without a master, and yet I am not free, nor merry for a single hour unless in my memories.\r\n\r\nAnd so I climbed into these mountains to finally have a festival for myself, as is proper for an old pope and church father: for know this, I am the last pope! \u2013 a festival of pious memories and divine worship.\r\n\r\nBut now he himself is dead, this most pious human being, this saint in the woods who constantly praised his god with singing and growling.\r\n\r\nI did not find him when I found his hut \u2013 but two wolves were in it, howling at his death \u2013 for all animals loved him. But a good servant knows everything, and also some things that his master conceals from himself.\r\n\r\nHe was a concealed god, full of secretiveness. Indeed, even in getting himself a son he used nothing other than sneaky means. At the doorway of his faith stands adultery.\r\n\r\nWhoever praises him as a god of love does not think highly enough of love itself. Did this god not also want to be judge? But the loving one loves beyond reward and retribution.\r\n\r\nWhen he was young, this god from the East, then he was harsh and vengeful and he built himself a hell for the amusement of his favorites.\r\n\r\nBut at last he became old and soft and mellow and pitying, more like a grandfather than a father, but most like a wobbly old grandmother.\r\n\r\nThere he sat, wilted, in his nook by the stove, grousing about his weak legs, weary of the world, weary of willing, and one day he choked to death on his all too great pity.\u201d \u2013\r\n\r\n\u201cYou old pope,\u201d said Zarathustra here, interrupting. \u201cDid you see that with your own eyes? It certainly could have happened that way; that way, and another way too. When gods die, they always die many kinds of death.\r\n\r\nBut well then! This way or that, this way and that \u2013 he\u2019s gone! He was offensive to the taste of my ears and eyes, I do not wish to speak anything worse of him.\r\n\r\nI love everything that gazes brightly and speaks honestly. But he \u2013 you know it well, you old priest, there was something of your kind in him, something priest-like \u2013 he was equivocal.\r\n\r\nHe was also unclear. How he raged at us, this wrath snorter, because we understood him poorly! But why did he not speak more purely!\r\n\r\nAnd if the fault was in our ears, why did he give us ears that heard him poorly? If mud was in our ears, well then \u2013 who put it there?\r\n\r\nHe failed at too much, this potter who never completed his training! But that he avenged himself on his clay formations and his creations because they turned out badly for him \u2013 that was a sin against good taste.\r\n\r\nIn piousness too there is good taste; it said at last: \u201cAway with such a god! Rather no god, rather meet destiny on one\u2019s own, rather be a fool, rather be a god oneself!\u201d\r\n\r\n\u2013 \u201cWhat do I hear!\u201d spoke the old pope at this point with pricked up ears. \u201cOh Zarathustra, you are more pious than you believe, with such disbelief! Some kind of god in you converted you to your godlessness.\r\n\r\nIs it not your very piousness that no longer allows you to believe in a god? And your overly great honesty will yet lead you away beyond good and evil!\r\n\r\nTake a good look: what is left for you? You have eyes and hands and mouth that have been preordained for blessing since eternity. One does not bless with hands alone.\r\n\r\nIn your proximity, even though you claim to be the most godless man, I detect a secret, sacred and sweet aroma of long blessings: it makes me happy and it makes me hurt.\r\n\r\nLet me be your guest, oh Zarathustra, for one single night! Nowhere on earth do I feel happier now than with you!\u201d \u2013\r\n\r\n\u201cAmen! It shall be so!\u201d spoke Zarathustra with great astonishment. \u201cUp there leads the path, there lies the cave of Zarathustra.\r\n\r\nGladly, to be sure, I would guide you there myself, you reverend one, because I love all pious people. But now a cry of distress hurries me away from you.\r\n\r\nIn my realm no one shall come to harm; my cave is a safe harbor. And I would like nothing better than to place every sad person back on firm land and firm legs.\r\n\r\nBut who could take your melancholy off your shoulders? For that I\u2019m too weak. We may have to wait a long time, truly, before someone awakens your god again.\r\n\r\nFor this old god does not live anymore: he is thoroughly dead.\u201d \u2013\r\n\r\nThus spoke Zarathustra."}, "id": 84}, {"data": {"uuid": "947b9477-c8f3-4a9a-9507-85d38fb02895", "user": 1, "title": "The Ugliest Human Being", "created_on": "2023-05-10 16:54:35.834210+00:00", "updated_on": "2023-05-10 16:54:35.860729+00:00", "article_html": "<h2>The Ugliest Human Being</h2><p>\u2013 And again Zarathustra\u2019s feet ran through mountains and woods, and his eyes searched and searched, but nowhere to be seen was the one whom they wanted to see, the great sufferer of distress and crier of distress. But along the whole way he jubilated in his heart and was thankful. \u201cWhat good things,\u201d he said, \u201cthis day has bestowed on me, as compensation for having begun so badly! What strange interlocutors I found!</p><p>Now I want to chew on their words for a long time, as on good kernels; my teeth will grind and grate them down until they flow like milk into my soul!\u201d \u2013</p><p>But when the path disappeared again around a boulder, all at once the landscape changed and Zarathustra stepped into a realm of death. Here black and red cliffs jutted upward: no grass, no tree, no birdsong. For it was a valley that all animals avoided, even the predators; except for a species of hideous, thick, green snakes that would come here to die when they grew old. And for this reason the shepherds called this valley: Snake Death.</p><p>Now Zarathustra sank into a black reminiscence, for it seemed to him that he had already stood in this valley once before. And much graveness spread itself over his mind, such that he walked slowly and ever more slowly until finally he stood still. But then, when he opened his eyes he saw something sitting beside the path, shaped like a human but scarcely like a human, something unspeakable. And all of a sudden Zarathustra was overcome with great shame for having looked upon such a thing with his own eyes; blushing all the way up to his white hair, he averted his gaze and picked up his foot, intending to leave this wicked spot. But then a noise animated the dead wasteland; it welled up from the ground gurgling and rattling, like water gurgles and rattles at night through clogged water pipes, until finally it turned into a human voice and human speech \u2013 that sounded like this.</p><p>\u201cZarathustra! Zarathustra! Guess my riddle! Speak, speak! What is revenge against the witness?</p><p>I lure you back, there is slippery ice here! See to it, see to it that your pride does not break its legs here!</p><p>You consider yourself wise, you proud Zarathustra! Then go ahead and guess the riddle, you hard nut cracker \u2013 the riddle that I am! So tell me: who am I?\u201d</p><p>\u2013 But when Zarathustra had heard these words \u2013 what do you think took place in his soul? He was overwhelmed with pity; and he collapsed at once like an oak tree that has long withstood many wood cutters \u2013 heavily, suddenly, to the terror of even those who wanted to fell it. But right away he picked himself up from the ground and his face had become hard.</p><p>\u201cI recognize you alright,\u201d he spoke with a voice of bronze: \u201cYou are the murderer of God! Let me go.</p><p>You could not bear the one who saw you \u2013 who saw you always and through and through, you ugliest human being! You took revenge on this witness!\u201d</p><p>Thus spoke Zarathustra and wanted to leave; but the unspeakable one latched on to a corner of his garment and began again to gurgle and to search for words. \u201cStay!\u201d he said at last \u2013</p><p>\u2013 \u201cStay! Do not pass by! I guessed what kind of axe knocked you to the ground: Hail to you, oh Zarathustra, that you stand again!</p><p>You guessed, I know it well, how he who killed him feels \u2013 the murderer of God. Stay! Sit down here with me, it will not be in vain.</p><p>To whom did I want to go, if not to you? Stay, sit down! But do not look at me! Honor thus \u2013 my ugliness!</p><p>They persecute me; now you are my last refuge. Not with their hatred, not with their bailiffs \u2013 oh such persecution I would mock and be proud and glad!</p><p>Has not everything successful hitherto been done by the well-persecuted? And whoever persecutes well easily learns to succeed \u2013 after all he is already \u2013 after somebody! But it\u2019s their pity \u2013</p><p>\u2013 their pity is what I flee and why I flee to you. Oh Zarathustra, protect me, you my last refuge, you the only one to guess me:</p><p>\u2013 you guessed how he who killed him feels. Stay! And if you want to go, you impatient one: do not go the way that I came. That way is bad.</p><p>Are you angry with me that I\u2019ve already spoken broken words for too long? That I even counsel you? But know this, it\u2019s me, the ugliest human being,</p><p>\u2013 who also has the biggest, heaviest feet. Where I walked, the way is bad. I trample all ways to death and to ruin.</p><p>But that you passed me by, silently; that you blushed, I saw it well: that\u2019s how I recognized you as Zarathustra.</p><p>Any other would have tossed me his alms, his pity, with looks and speech. But for that \u2013 I am not beggar enough, you guessed that \u2013</p><p>\u2013for that I am too rich, rich in what is great, what is terrible, what is ugliest, what is most unspeakable! Your shame, oh Zarathustra, honored me!</p><p>With difficulty I managed to escape the throng of the pitying \u2013 to find the only one today who teaches \u2018pitying is obtrusive\u2019 \u2013 you, oh Zarathustra!</p><p>\u2013 Be it a god\u2019s, be it the pity of mankind: pitying is offensive to shame. And not wanting to help can be more noble than the virtue that leaps to help.</p><p>But today that is what passes for virtue itself among all small people, pity \u2013 they have no respect for great misfortune, for great ugliness, for great failure.</p><p>I look away over all these people like a dog looks away over the backs of teeming flocks of sheep. They are small, good-wooled and good-willed gray people.</p><p>Like a heron looks away contemptuously over shallow ponds, its head tossed back; thus I look away over teeming gray little waves and wills and souls.</p><p>They have been deemed to be right for too long, these small people; and so in the end they were given might too \u2013 now they teach: \u2018the only good is what small people call good.\u2019</p><p>And \u2018truth\u2019 today is what the preacher spoke, the one who himself came from among them, that odd holy man and advocate of small people who testified of himself: \u2018I \u2013 am the truth.\u2019</p><p>This immodest person has for a long time now caused small people to get big heads \u2013 he who taught no small error when he taught \u2018I \u2013 am the truth.\u2019</p><p>Was an immodest person ever answered more courteously? \u2013 But you, oh Zarathustra, passed him by and said: \u2018No! No! Three times no!\u2019</p><p>You warned against his error, you were the first to warn against pity \u2013 not all, not none, but yourself and your kind.</p><p>You are ashamed of the shame of the great sufferer; and indeed, when you say \u2018from pitying a great cloud is coming, beware, you human beings!\u2019</p><p>\u2013 when you teach \u2018all creators are hard, all great love is above pitying\u2019: oh Zarathustra, how well schooled you seem to me in predicting the weather!</p><p>But you yourself \u2013 warn yourself too against your pitying! Because many are on their way to you, many who are suffering, doubting, despairing, drowning, freezing \u2013</p><p>I warn you against me too. You guessed my best and worst riddle, me myself and what I did. I know the axe that fells you.</p><p>But he \u2013 had to die: he saw with eyes that saw everything \u2013 he saw the depths and grounds of human beings, all their hidden disgrace and ugliness.</p><p>His pitying knew no shame: he crawled into my filthiest nook. This most curious, super-obtrusive, super-pitying one had to die.</p><p>He always saw me: I wanted revenge on such a witness \u2013 or to no longer live myself.</p><p>The god who saw everything, even human beings: this god had to die! Human beings cannot bear that such a witness lives.\u201d</p><p>Thus spoke the ugliest human being. But Zarathustra rose and set about to leave, because he was chilled down to his entrails.</p><p>\u201cYou unspeakable one,\u201d he said, \u201cyou warned me against your way. Out of gratitude I now commend mine to you. Look, up there lies Zarathustra\u2019s cave.</p><p>My cave is big and deep and has many nooks; there the most hidden person will find a hiding place. And close by are a hundred burrows and tunnels for crawling, flapping and leaping wildlife.</p><p>You outcast, who cast himself out, you no longer want to dwell among human beings and human pity? Well then, do as I do! Thus you\u2019ll also learn from me; only the doer learns.</p><p>And speak first and foremost with my animals! The proudest animal and the wisest animal \u2013 they are surely the right counselors for both of us!\u201d \u2013</p><p>Thus spoke Zarathustra and continued on his way, pensive and even more slowly than before; because he had much to ask himself and knew no easy way to answer.</p><p>\u201cHow poor indeed is a human being!\u201d he thought in his heart, \u201chow ugly, how gasping, how full of concealed shame!</p><p>They tell me that human beings love themselves; oh, how great this self-love must be! How much contempt it has against it!</p><p>Even this man here loved himself, as he despised himself \u2013 to me he seems a great lover and a great despiser.</p><p>I\u2019ve never found anyone who despised himself more deeply; that too is elevation. Oh no, was he perhaps the higher man whose cry I heard?</p><p>I love the great despisers. Human being, however, is something that must be overcome.\u201d \u2013</p><p>The Voluntary Beggar</p><p>When Zarathustra had left the ugliest human being, he was freezing and he felt lonely; after all, so much that was cold and lonely went through his mind, to the point where even his limbs grew colder because of it. But as he climbed further and further, up, down, now past green meadows, but then also across wild stony deposits where previously an impatient brook might have laid itself to bed, then all at once his mood became warmer and more cordial.</p><p>\u201cWhat happened to me?\u201d he asked himself, \u201csomething warm and lively refreshes me, something that must be close to me.</p><p>Already I am less alone; unknown companions and brothers roam around me, their warm breath touches on my soul.\u201d</p><p>But when he peered about himself and searched for the comforters of his solitude, oddly enough, it was cows huddled together on a knoll; their nearness and smell had warmed his heart. Now these cows seemed engrossed in listening to someone speaking, and they paid no attention to the one who approached them. But when Zarathustra was quite near them he heard clearly how a human voice spoke from the midst of the cows; and evidently they had all turned their heads toward the speaker.</p><p>Then Zarathustra leaped up eagerly and pushed the animals apart, fearing that someone might have come to harm here, which could scarcely be remedied by the pity of cows. But in this he had deceived himself; for indeed, there sat someone on the ground and appeared to be persuading the animals to not be afraid of him, a peaceful man and mountain preacher from whose eyes goodness itself preached. \u201cWhat are you seeking here?\u201d cried Zarathustra, astonished.</p><p>\u201cWhat am I seeking here?\u201d he answered: \u201cThe same thing you seek, you trouble maker! Namely happiness on earth.</p><p>But for that I want to learn from these cows. And you should know, I\u2019ve already persuaded them half the morning, and just now they wanted to tell me for sure. Why do you have to disturb them?</p><p>Unless we are converted and become as cows, we will by no means enter the kingdom of heaven. For there is one thing that we ought to learn from them: chewing the cud.</p><p>And truly, what profit is it to a man if he gains the whole world, and did not learn this one thing, chewing the cud: what would it help? He would not be rid of his misery</p><p>\u2013 his great misery: which today is called nausea. Who today does not have heart, mouth and eyes full of nausea? You too! You too! But just look at these cows here!\u201d \u2013</p><p>Thus spoke the mountain preacher and then he turned his own gaze on Zarathustra \u2013 for till now his gaze hung lovingly on the cows \u2013 then, however, it transformed. \u201cWho is this with whom I speak?\u201d he cried, startled, and jumped up from the ground.</p><p>\u201cThis is the man without nausea, this is Zarathustra himself, the one who overcame great nausea, this is the eye, this is the mouth, this is the heart of Zarathustra himself.\u201d</p><p>And while he spoke thus he kissed the hands of the one to whom he spoke, and tears streamed from his eyes, and he behaved quite like someone to whom a precious gift and treasure falls unexpectedly from heaven. The cows, meanwhile, watched all of this and were amazed.</p><p>\u201cDo not speak of me, you odd, you lovely man!\u201d said Zarathustra and he restrained his tenderness. \u201cTell me first about yourself ! Are you not the voluntary beggar who once threw away great wealth \u2013</p><p>\u2013 who once was ashamed of his wealth and of the wealthy, and fled to the poorest people, to give them his fullness and his heart? But they did not accept him.\u201d</p><p>\u201cBut they did not accept me,\u201d said the voluntary beggar, \u201cyou know it already. So in the end I went to the animals and to these cows.\u201d</p><p>\u201cThen you learned,\u201d Zarathustra interrupted the speaker, \u201chow it is harder to grant right than to take right, and that bestowing well is an art and the ultimate, craftiest master-art of kindness.\u201d</p><p>\u201cEspecially nowadays,\u201d answered the voluntary beggar. \u201cNowadays, namely, where everything lowly has become rebellious and skittish and haughty in its own way: namely in a rabble way.</p><p>For the hour has come, you know it well, for the great, terrible, long, slow rabble and slave rebellion: it grows and grows!</p><p>Now the lowly are outraged by all benevolence and little charities; and the super-rich should be on their guard!</p><p>Whoever dribbles these days like portly bottles with all too narrow necks \u2013 people like to break the necks of such bottles today.</p><p>Lascivious greed, galling envy, aggrieved vengefulness, rabble pride: all of that leaped into my face. It is no longer true that the poor are blessed. But the kingdom of heaven is among the cows.\u201d</p><p>\u201cAnd why is it not among the wealthy?\u201d asked Zarathustra, temptingly, as he warded off the cows that trustingly snorted at the peaceful man.</p><p>\u201cWhy do you tempt me?\u201d he answered. \u201cYou yourself know it even better than I. What drove me to the poorest, oh Zarathustra? Was it not my nausea for our wealthiest people?</p><p>\u2013 for the convicts of wealth who cull their advantage out of every dustpan, with cold eyes, horny thoughts; for this mob that stinks to high heaven,</p><p>\u2013 for this gilded, fake rabble, whose fathers were pick-pockets or vultures or rag pickers, with women who were willing, lascivious, forgetful \u2013 all of them after all are not far from being whores \u2013</p><p>rabble above, rabble below! What do \u2018poor\u2019 and \u2018rich\u2019 mean anymore today! I forgot this difference \u2013 then I fled, farther, ever farther, until I got to these cows.\u201d</p><p>Thus spoke the peaceful man and he himself snorted and sweated at these words, such that the cows once again were amazed. But Zarathustra continued to look him in the face, smiling as he spoke so harshly, and he silently shook his head.</p><p>\u201cYou do violence to yourself, you mountain preacher, when you use such harsh words. Not for such harshness were your mouth or your eyes made.</p><p>Nor, it seems to me, your stomach itself: it resists all such raging and hating and foaming over. Your stomach wants gentler things: you are no butcher.</p><p>Rather, you seem to me a vegetarian and a root man. Perhaps you crunch grains. But certainly you are ill disposed toward pleasures of the flesh and you love honey.\u201d</p><p>\u201cYou guessed me well,\u201d responded the voluntary beggar, with relief in his heart. \u201cI love honey, I also crunch grains, because I sought what tastes lovely and makes for clean breath:</p><p>\u2013 also what takes a long time, a day\u2019s and mouth\u2019s work for gentle idlers and bums.</p><p>The ones who have excelled the most, to be sure, are these cows: they invented chewing the cud for themselves and lying in the sun. They also refrain from all weighty thoughts, which bloat the heart.\u201d</p><p>\u2013 \u201cWell then!\u201d said Zarathustra. \u201cYou should also see my animals, my eagle and my snake \u2013 their equal exists nowhere today on earth.</p><p>Look, there the path leads to my cave; be its guest tonight. And speak with my animals about the happiness of animals \u2013</p><p>\u2013 until I myself come home. Because now a cry of distress hurries me away from you. You\u2019ll also find new honey at my place, icy-fresh golden honey from the comb \u2013 eat it!</p><p>But now quickly take leave of your cows, you odd, you lovely man! Even if it is difficult for you. For they are your warmest friends and teachers!\u201d \u2013</p><p>\u201c\u2013 With the exception of one person, whom I love even more,\u201d answered the voluntary beggar. \u201cYou yourself are good and even better than a cow, oh Zarathustra!\u201d</p><p>\u201cAway, away with you! You nasty flatterer!\u201d cried Zarathustra with malice, \u201cwhy do you spoil me with such praise and flatter-honey?</p><p>Away, away from me!\u201d he cried once more and brandished his staff at the affectionate beggar, who ran away swiftly.</p>", "article_json": {"type": "doc", "content": [{"type": "heading", "attrs": {"level": 2}, "content": [{"text": "The Ugliest Human Being", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "content": [{"text": "\u2013 And again Zarathustra\u2019s feet ran through mountains and woods, and his eyes searched and searched, but nowhere to be seen was the one whom they wanted to see, the great sufferer of distress and crier of distress. You nasty flatterer!\u201d cried Zarathustra with malice, \u201cwhy do you spoil me with such praise and flatter-honey?", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "content": [{"text": "Away, away from me!\u201d he cried once more and brandished his staff at the affectionate beggar, who ran away swiftly.", "type": "text"}]}]}, "article_text": "The Ugliest Human Being\r\n\r\n\u2013 And again Zarathustra\u2019s feet ran through mountains and woods, and his eyes searched and searched, but nowhere to be seen was the one whom they wanted to see, the great sufferer of distress and crier of distress. But along the whole way he jubilated in his heart and was thankful. \u201cWhat good things,\u201d he said, \u201cthis day has bestowed on me, as compensation for having begun so badly! What strange interlocutors I found!\r\n\r\nNow I want to chew on their words for a long time, as on good kernels; my teeth will grind and grate them down until they flow like milk into my soul!\u201d \u2013\r\n\r\nBut when the path disappeared again around a boulder, all at once the landscape changed and Zarathustra stepped into a realm of death. Here black and red cliffs jutted upward: no grass, no tree, no birdsong. For it was a valley that all animals avoided, even the predators; except for a species of hideous, thick, green snakes that would come here to die when they grew old. And for this reason the shepherds called this valley: Snake Death.\r\n\r\nNow Zarathustra sank into a black reminiscence, for it seemed to him that he had already stood in this valley once before. And much graveness spread itself over his mind, such that he walked slowly and ever more slowly until finally he stood still. But then, when he opened his eyes he saw something sitting beside the path, shaped like a human but scarcely like a human, something unspeakable. And all of a sudden Zarathustra was overcome with great shame for having looked upon such a thing with his own eyes; blushing all the way up to his white hair, he averted his gaze and picked up his foot, intending to leave this wicked spot. But then a noise animated the dead wasteland; it welled up from the ground gurgling and rattling, like water gurgles and rattles at night through clogged water pipes, until finally it turned into a human voice and human speech \u2013 that sounded like this.\r\n\r\n\u201cZarathustra! Zarathustra! Guess my riddle! Speak, speak! What is revenge against the witness?\r\n\r\nI lure you back, there is slippery ice here! See to it, see to it that your pride does not break its legs here!\r\n\r\nYou consider yourself wise, you proud Zarathustra! Then go ahead and guess the riddle, you hard nut cracker \u2013 the riddle that I am! So tell me: who am I?\u201d\r\n\r\n\u2013 But when Zarathustra had heard these words \u2013 what do you think took place in his soul? He was overwhelmed with pity; and he collapsed at once like an oak tree that has long withstood many wood cutters \u2013 heavily, suddenly, to the terror of even those who wanted to fell it. But right away he picked himself up from the ground and his face had become hard.\r\n\r\n\u201cI recognize you alright,\u201d he spoke with a voice of bronze: \u201cYou are the murderer of God! Let me go.\r\n\r\nYou could not bear the one who saw you \u2013 who saw you always and through and through, you ugliest human being! You took revenge on this witness!\u201d\r\n\r\nThus spoke Zarathustra and wanted to leave; but the unspeakable one latched on to a corner of his garment and began again to gurgle and to search for words. \u201cStay!\u201d he said at last \u2013\r\n\r\n\u2013 \u201cStay! Do not pass by! I guessed what kind of axe knocked you to the ground: Hail to you, oh Zarathustra, that you stand again!\r\n\r\nYou guessed, I know it well, how he who killed him feels \u2013 the murderer of God. Stay! Sit down here with me, it will not be in vain.\r\n\r\nTo whom did I want to go, if not to you? Stay, sit down! But do not look at me! Honor thus \u2013 my ugliness!\r\n\r\nThey persecute me; now you are my last refuge. Not with their hatred, not with their bailiffs \u2013 oh such persecution I would mock and be proud and glad!\r\n\r\nHas not everything successful hitherto been done by the well-persecuted? And whoever persecutes well easily learns to succeed \u2013 after all he is already \u2013 after somebody! But it\u2019s their pity \u2013\r\n\r\n\u2013 their pity is what I flee and why I flee to you. Oh Zarathustra, protect me, you my last refuge, you the only one to guess me:\r\n\r\n\u2013 you guessed how he who killed him feels. Stay! And if you want to go, you impatient one: do not go the way that I came. That way is bad.\r\n\r\nAre you angry with me that I\u2019ve already spoken broken words for too long? That I even counsel you? But know this, it\u2019s me, the ugliest human being,\r\n\r\n\u2013 who also has the biggest, heaviest feet. Where I walked, the way is bad. I trample all ways to death and to ruin.\r\n\r\nBut that you passed me by, silently; that you blushed, I saw it well: that\u2019s how I recognized you as Zarathustra.\r\n\r\nAny other would have tossed me his alms, his pity, with looks and speech. But for that \u2013 I am not beggar enough, you guessed that \u2013\r\n\r\n\u2013for that I am too rich, rich in what is great, what is terrible, what is ugliest, what is most unspeakable! Your shame, oh Zarathustra, honored me!\r\n\r\nWith difficulty I managed to escape the throng of the pitying \u2013 to find the only one today who teaches \u2018pitying is obtrusive\u2019 \u2013 you, oh Zarathustra!\r\n\r\n\u2013 Be it a god\u2019s, be it the pity of mankind: pitying is offensive to shame. And not wanting to help can be more noble than the virtue that leaps to help.\r\n\r\nBut today that is what passes for virtue itself among all small people, pity \u2013 they have no respect for great misfortune, for great ugliness, for great failure.\r\n\r\nI look away over all these people like a dog looks away over the backs of teeming flocks of sheep. They are small, good-wooled and good-willed gray people.\r\n\r\nLike a heron looks away contemptuously over shallow ponds, its head tossed back; thus I look away over teeming gray little waves and wills and souls.\r\n\r\nThey have been deemed to be right for too long, these small people; and so in the end they were given might too \u2013 now they teach: \u2018the only good is what small people call good.\u2019\r\n\r\nAnd \u2018truth\u2019 today is what the preacher spoke, the one who himself came from among them, that odd holy man and advocate of small people who testified of himself: \u2018I \u2013 am the truth.\u2019\r\n\r\nThis immodest person has for a long time now caused small people to get big heads \u2013 he who taught no small error when he taught \u2018I \u2013 am the truth.\u2019\r\n\r\nWas an immodest person ever answered more courteously? \u2013 But you, oh Zarathustra, passed him by and said: \u2018No! No! Three times no!\u2019\r\n\r\nYou warned against his error, you were the first to warn against pity \u2013 not all, not none, but yourself and your kind.\r\n\r\nYou are ashamed of the shame of the great sufferer; and indeed, when you say \u2018from pitying a great cloud is coming, beware, you human beings!\u2019\r\n\r\n\u2013 when you teach \u2018all creators are hard, all great love is above pitying\u2019: oh Zarathustra, how well schooled you seem to me in predicting the weather!\r\n\r\nBut you yourself \u2013 warn yourself too against your pitying! Because many are on their way to you, many who are suffering, doubting, despairing, drowning, freezing \u2013\r\n\r\nI warn you against me too. You guessed my best and worst riddle, me myself and what I did. I know the axe that fells you.\r\n\r\nBut he \u2013 had to die: he saw with eyes that saw everything \u2013 he saw the depths and grounds of human beings, all their hidden disgrace and ugliness.\r\n\r\nHis pitying knew no shame: he crawled into my filthiest nook. This most curious, super-obtrusive, super-pitying one had to die.\r\n\r\nHe always saw me: I wanted revenge on such a witness \u2013 or to no longer live myself.\r\n\r\nThe god who saw everything, even human beings: this god had to die! Human beings cannot bear that such a witness lives.\u201d\r\n\r\nThus spoke the ugliest human being. But Zarathustra rose and set about to leave, because he was chilled down to his entrails.\r\n\r\n\u201cYou unspeakable one,\u201d he said, \u201cyou warned me against your way. Out of gratitude I now commend mine to you. Look, up there lies Zarathustra\u2019s cave.\r\n\r\nMy cave is big and deep and has many nooks; there the most hidden person will find a hiding place. And close by are a hundred burrows and tunnels for crawling, flapping and leaping wildlife.\r\n\r\nYou outcast, who cast himself out, you no longer want to dwell among human beings and human pity? Well then, do as I do! Thus you\u2019ll also learn from me; only the doer learns.\r\n\r\nAnd speak first and foremost with my animals! The proudest animal and the wisest animal \u2013 they are surely the right counselors for both of us!\u201d \u2013\r\n\r\nThus spoke Zarathustra and continued on his way, pensive and even more slowly than before; because he had much to ask himself and knew no easy way to answer.\r\n\r\n\u201cHow poor indeed is a human being!\u201d he thought in his heart, \u201chow ugly, how gasping, how full of concealed shame!\r\n\r\nThey tell me that human beings love themselves; oh, how great this self-love must be! How much contempt it has against it!\r\n\r\nEven this man here loved himself, as he despised himself \u2013 to me he seems a great lover and a great despiser.\r\n\r\nI\u2019ve never found anyone who despised himself more deeply; that too is elevation. Oh no, was he perhaps the higher man whose cry I heard?\r\n\r\nI love the great despisers. Human being, however, is something that must be overcome.\u201d \u2013\r\n\r\nThe Voluntary Beggar\r\n\r\nWhen Zarathustra had left the ugliest human being, he was freezing and he felt lonely; after all, so much that was cold and lonely went through his mind, to the point where even his limbs grew colder because of it. But as he climbed further and further, up, down, now past green meadows, but then also across wild stony deposits where previously an impatient brook might have laid itself to bed, then all at once his mood became warmer and more cordial.\r\n\r\n\u201cWhat happened to me?\u201d he asked himself, \u201csomething warm and lively refreshes me, something that must be close to me.\r\n\r\nAlready I am less alone; unknown companions and brothers roam around me, their warm breath touches on my soul.\u201d\r\n\r\nBut when he peered about himself and searched for the comforters of his solitude, oddly enough, it was cows huddled together on a knoll; their nearness and smell had warmed his heart. Now these cows seemed engrossed in listening to someone speaking, and they paid no attention to the one who approached them. But when Zarathustra was quite near them he heard clearly how a human voice spoke from the midst of the cows; and evidently they had all turned their heads toward the speaker.\r\n\r\nThen Zarathustra leaped up eagerly and pushed the animals apart, fearing that someone might have come to harm here, which could scarcely be remedied by the pity of cows. But in this he had deceived himself; for indeed, there sat someone on the ground and appeared to be persuading the animals to not be afraid of him, a peaceful man and mountain preacher from whose eyes goodness itself preached. \u201cWhat are you seeking here?\u201d cried Zarathustra, astonished.\r\n\r\n\u201cWhat am I seeking here?\u201d he answered: \u201cThe same thing you seek, you trouble maker! Namely happiness on earth.\r\n\r\nBut for that I want to learn from these cows. And you should know, I\u2019ve already persuaded them half the morning, and just now they wanted to tell me for sure. Why do you have to disturb them?\r\n\r\nUnless we are converted and become as cows, we will by no means enter the kingdom of heaven. For there is one thing that we ought to learn from them: chewing the cud.\r\n\r\nAnd truly, what profit is it to a man if he gains the whole world, and did not learn this one thing, chewing the cud: what would it help? He would not be rid of his misery\r\n\r\n\u2013 his great misery: which today is called nausea. Who today does not have heart, mouth and eyes full of nausea? You too! You too! But just look at these cows here!\u201d \u2013\r\n\r\nThus spoke the mountain preacher and then he turned his own gaze on Zarathustra \u2013 for till now his gaze hung lovingly on the cows \u2013 then, however, it transformed. \u201cWho is this with whom I speak?\u201d he cried, startled, and jumped up from the ground.\r\n\r\n\u201cThis is the man without nausea, this is Zarathustra himself, the one who overcame great nausea, this is the eye, this is the mouth, this is the heart of Zarathustra himself.\u201d\r\n\r\nAnd while he spoke thus he kissed the hands of the one to whom he spoke, and tears streamed from his eyes, and he behaved quite like someone to whom a precious gift and treasure falls unexpectedly from heaven. The cows, meanwhile, watched all of this and were amazed.\r\n\r\n\u201cDo not speak of me, you odd, you lovely man!\u201d said Zarathustra and he restrained his tenderness. \u201cTell me first about yourself ! Are you not the voluntary beggar who once threw away great wealth \u2013\r\n\r\n\u2013 who once was ashamed of his wealth and of the wealthy, and fled to the poorest people, to give them his fullness and his heart? But they did not accept him.\u201d\r\n\r\n\u201cBut they did not accept me,\u201d said the voluntary beggar, \u201cyou know it already. So in the end I went to the animals and to these cows.\u201d\r\n\r\n\u201cThen you learned,\u201d Zarathustra interrupted the speaker, \u201chow it is harder to grant right than to take right, and that bestowing well is an art and the ultimate, craftiest master-art of kindness.\u201d\r\n\r\n\u201cEspecially nowadays,\u201d answered the voluntary beggar. \u201cNowadays, namely, where everything lowly has become rebellious and skittish and haughty in its own way: namely in a rabble way.\r\n\r\nFor the hour has come, you know it well, for the great, terrible, long, slow rabble and slave rebellion: it grows and grows!\r\n\r\nNow the lowly are outraged by all benevolence and little charities; and the super-rich should be on their guard!\r\n\r\nWhoever dribbles these days like portly bottles with all too narrow necks \u2013 people like to break the necks of such bottles today.\r\n\r\nLascivious greed, galling envy, aggrieved vengefulness, rabble pride: all of that leaped into my face. It is no longer true that the poor are blessed. But the kingdom of heaven is among the cows.\u201d\r\n\r\n\u201cAnd why is it not among the wealthy?\u201d asked Zarathustra, temptingly, as he warded off the cows that trustingly snorted at the peaceful man.\r\n\r\n\u201cWhy do you tempt me?\u201d he answered. \u201cYou yourself know it even better than I. What drove me to the poorest, oh Zarathustra? Was it not my nausea for our wealthiest people?\r\n\r\n\u2013 for the convicts of wealth who cull their advantage out of every dustpan, with cold eyes, horny thoughts; for this mob that stinks to high heaven,\r\n\r\n\u2013 for this gilded, fake rabble, whose fathers were pick-pockets or vultures or rag pickers, with women who were willing, lascivious, forgetful \u2013 all of them after all are not far from being whores \u2013\r\n\r\nrabble above, rabble below! What do \u2018poor\u2019 and \u2018rich\u2019 mean anymore today! I forgot this difference \u2013 then I fled, farther, ever farther, until I got to these cows.\u201d\r\n\r\nThus spoke the peaceful man and he himself snorted and sweated at these words, such that the cows once again were amazed. But Zarathustra continued to look him in the face, smiling as he spoke so harshly, and he silently shook his head.\r\n\r\n\u201cYou do violence to yourself, you mountain preacher, when you use such harsh words. Not for such harshness were your mouth or your eyes made.\r\n\r\nNor, it seems to me, your stomach itself: it resists all such raging and hating and foaming over. Your stomach wants gentler things: you are no butcher.\r\n\r\nRather, you seem to me a vegetarian and a root man. Perhaps you crunch grains. But certainly you are ill disposed toward pleasures of the flesh and you love honey.\u201d\r\n\r\n\u201cYou guessed me well,\u201d responded the voluntary beggar, with relief in his heart. \u201cI love honey, I also crunch grains, because I sought what tastes lovely and makes for clean breath:\r\n\r\n\u2013 also what takes a long time, a day\u2019s and mouth\u2019s work for gentle idlers and bums.\r\n\r\nThe ones who have excelled the most, to be sure, are these cows: they invented chewing the cud for themselves and lying in the sun. They also refrain from all weighty thoughts, which bloat the heart.\u201d\r\n\r\n\u2013 \u201cWell then!\u201d said Zarathustra. \u201cYou should also see my animals, my eagle and my snake \u2013 their equal exists nowhere today on earth.\r\n\r\nLook, there the path leads to my cave; be its guest tonight. And speak with my animals about the happiness of animals \u2013\r\n\r\n\u2013 until I myself come home. Because now a cry of distress hurries me away from you. You\u2019ll also find new honey at my place, icy-fresh golden honey from the comb \u2013 eat it!\r\n\r\nBut now quickly take leave of your cows, you odd, you lovely man! Even if it is difficult for you. For they are your warmest friends and teachers!\u201d \u2013\r\n\r\n\u201c\u2013 With the exception of one person, whom I love even more,\u201d answered the voluntary beggar. \u201cYou yourself are good and even better than a cow, oh Zarathustra!\u201d\r\n\r\n\u201cAway, away with you! You nasty flatterer!\u201d cried Zarathustra with malice, \u201cwhy do you spoil me with such praise and flatter-honey?\r\n\r\nAway, away from me!\u201d he cried once more and brandished his staff at the affectionate beggar, who ran away swiftly."}, "id": 85}, {"data": {"uuid": "71a2c65d-c4c7-4ef2-8820-4d48240f0eeb", "user": 1, "title": "The Shadow", "created_on": "2023-05-10 16:56:10.320550+00:00", "updated_on": "2023-05-10 16:56:10.343237+00:00", "article_html": "<h2>The Shadow</h2><p>But scarcely had the voluntary beggar run away and Zarathustra was again alone with himself, than he heard a new voice behind him, crying \u201cStop! Zarathustra! Stop already! It\u2019s me, oh Zarathustra, me, your shadow!\u201d But Zarathustra did not wait, because he was suddenly overcome with annoyance at the excessive hustle and bustle in his mountains. \u201cWhere\u2019s my solitude gone?\u201d he said.</p><p>\u201cThis is really becoming too much for me; this mountain is teeming, my kingdom is no longer of this world, I need new mountains.</p><p>My shadow is calling me? What does my shadow matter! Let him run after me \u2013 I\u2019ll run away from him.\u201d</p><p>Thus Zarathustra spoke to his heart and ran away. But the one who was behind him continued to follow, so that soon three runners were after each other, namely the voluntary beggar in front, then Zarathustra and third and furthest behind, his shadow. Not long had they run in this manner when Zarathustra came to his senses about his folly and with one great effort shook off all that cloyed and annoyed him.</p><p>\u201cWhat!\u201d he said, \u201chaven\u2019t the most ridiculous things always happened among us old hermits and holy men?</p><p>Truly, my folly grew tall in the mountains! Now I hear six old fools\u2019 legs rattling along after each other!</p><p>But can Zarathustra afford to be afraid of a shadow? And it seems to me, when all\u2019s said and done, that he has longer legs than I.\u201d</p><p>Thus spoke Zarathustra, laughing with his eyes and his entrails, then he stopped, turned around abruptly \u2013 and behold, he almost hurled his successor and shadow to the ground \u2013 so closely did the latter follow on his heels, and so weak was he too. When he took a close look at him, he shrank back as if before a sudden ghost: so thin, blackish, hollow and outdated did this successor look.</p><p>\u201cWho are you?\u201d asked Zarathustra, intensely, \u201cwhat are you doing here? And why do you call yourself my shadow? I don\u2019t like you.\u201d</p><p>\u201cForgive me,\u201d answered the shadow, \u201cthat it is I; and if you do not like me, well then, oh Zarathustra, for that I praise you and your good taste! I am a wanderer, who has already walked much at your heels; always on my way, but without goal, without home too, such that very little is lacking, truly, and I would be the Eternal Jew \u2013 except that I am not eternal and neither am I Jew.</p><p>What? Must I always be on my way? Whirled by every wind, unsteady, driven out? Oh earth, you have become too round for me!</p><p>I\u2019ve already sat on every surface, like weary dust I have slept on mirrors and window panes: Everything takes from me, nothing gives, and I grow thin \u2013 I almost resemble a shadow.</p><p>But after you, oh Zarathustra, I\u2019ve flown and followed longest, and even when I concealed myself from you, I was still your best shadow: wherever you sat, I sat too.</p><p>With you I have haunted the remotest, coldest worlds, like a ghost that runs voluntarily over winter rooftops and snow.</p><p>With you I strived to enter everything forbidden, worst, remotest; and if anything of mine is a virtue, then it is that I have feared no ban.</p><p>With you I smashed anything my heart ever honored, I overthrew all boundary stones and images, I pursued the most dangerous wishes \u2013 indeed, I have passed over every crime once.</p><p>With you I unlearned my faith in words and values and great names. When the devil sheds his skin, does his name not fall off too? For it too is skin. Perhaps the devil himself is \u2013 skin.</p><p>\u2018Nothing is true, all is permitted\u2019: thus I persuaded myself. I plunged into the coldest waters, with head and heart. Oh how often I paid for it by standing there naked as a red crab!</p><p>Oh where has all my goodness and all my shame and all my faith in the good gone! Oh where has that mendacious innocence that I once possessed gone, the innocence of the good and their noble lies!</p><p>Too often, to be sure, I followed on the heels of truth: and it kicked me in the head. Sometimes I believed I was lying and behold \u2013 that\u2019s where I first hit \u2013 the truth.</p><p>Too much became clear to me, now it doesn\u2019t matter to me anymore. Nothing that I love lives anymore \u2013 how am I supposed to still love myself? \u2018Live as I please or don\u2019t live at all\u2019 \u2013 that\u2019s how I want it, and that\u2019s how the saintliest person wants it too. But alas, how could I still have \u2013 pleasure?</p><p>Do I \u2013 still have a goal? A harbor toward which my sail turns?</p><p>A good wind? Indeed, only the one who knows where he\u2019s sailing knows also which wind is good and which is his favorable wind.</p><p>What did I have left? A heart weary and insolent; a restless will; fluttering wings; a broken backbone.</p><p>Ever a visitor, searching for my home, oh Zarathustra, you well know, this visiting was my visitation, and it devours me.</p><p>\u2018Where is \u2013 my home?\u2019 I asked, and I search and searched for it, but I have not found it. Oh eternal everywhere, oh eternal nowhere, oh eternal \u2013 in vain!\u201d</p><p>Thus spoke the shadow, and Zarathustra\u2019s face lengthened at these words. \u201cYou are my shadow!\u201d he said at last, with sadness.</p><p>\u201cYour danger is no small one, you free spirit and wanderer! You\u2019ve had a bad day: see to it that you do not have an even worse evening!</p><p>To such restless ones as you even a jail ends up looking like bliss. Have you ever seen how captured criminals sleep? They sleep peacefully, they enjoy their new security.</p><p>Beware that you are not captured in the end by a narrow belief, a harsh, severe delusion! Because now you are seduced and tempted by anything that is narrow and solid.</p><p>You have lost your goal: indeed, how will you get rid of and get over this loss? Along with it \u2013 you have also lost your way!</p><p>You poor roamer and raver, you weary butterfly! Do you want to have a rest and a home this evening? Then go up to my cave!</p><p>There leads the path to my cave. And now I have to run away from you quickly again. Already it\u2019s as though I\u2019m covered in shadow.</p><p>I want to run alone, so that things clear up around me again. For that I\u2019ll yet have to be long on my legs and like it. But this evening at my place \u2013 there will be dancing!\u201d \u2013</p><p>Thus spoke Zarathustra.</p>", "article_json": {"type": "doc", "content": [{"type": "heading", "attrs": {"level": 2}, "content": [{"text": "The Shadow", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "content": [{"text": "But scarcely had the voluntary beggar run away and Zarathustra was again alone with himself, than he heard a new voice behind him, crying \u201cStop! Indeed, only the one who knows where he\u2019s sailing knows also which wind is good and which is his favorable wind.\r\n\r\nWhat did I have left? A heart weary and insolent; a restless will; fluttering wings; a broken backbone.\r\n\r\nEver a visitor, searching for my home, oh Zarathustra, you well know, this visiting was my visitation, and it devours me.\r\n\r\n\u2018Where is \u2013 my home?\u2019 I asked, and I search and searched for it, but I have not found it. Oh eternal everywhere, oh eternal nowhere, oh eternal \u2013 in vain!\u201d\r\n\r\nThus spoke the shadow, and Zarathustra\u2019s face lengthened at these words. \u201cYou are my shadow!\u201d he said at last, with sadness.\r\n\r\n\u201cYour danger is no small one, you free spirit and wanderer! You\u2019ve had a bad day: see to it that you do not have an even worse evening!\r\n\r\nTo such restless ones as you even a jail ends up looking like bliss. Have you ever seen how captured criminals sleep? They sleep peacefully, they enjoy their new security.\r\n\r\nBeware that you are not captured in the end by a narrow belief, a harsh, severe delusion! Because now you are seduced and tempted by anything that is narrow and solid.\r\n\r\nYou have lost your goal: indeed, how will you get rid of and get over this loss? Along with it \u2013 you have also lost your way!\r\n\r\nYou poor roamer and raver, you weary butterfly! Do you want to have a rest and a home this evening? Then go up to my cave!\r\n\r\nThere leads the path to my cave. And now I have to run away from you quickly again. Already it\u2019s as though I\u2019m covered in shadow.\r\n\r\nI want to run alone, so that things clear up around me again. For that I\u2019ll yet have to be long on my legs and like it. But this evening at my place \u2013 there will be dancing!\u201d \u2013\r\n\r\nThus spoke Zarathustra."}, "id": 86}, {"data": {"uuid": "ca08526c-4a25-4815-85a7-5431f8cef184", "user": 1, "title": "At Noon", "created_on": "2023-05-10 16:56:53.667839+00:00", "updated_on": "2023-05-10 16:56:53.688120+00:00", "article_html": "<h2>At Noon</h2><p>\u2013 And Zarathustra ran and ran and found no one anymore, and he was alone and found himself again and again, and he enjoyed and sipped his solitude and thought about good things \u2013 for hours. At the hour of noon, however, as the sun stood directly over Zarathustra\u2019s head, he passed by an old crooked and knotty tree, embraced by the luxurious love of a grapevine and hidden away from itself; from it hung abundant yellow grapes, trailing toward the wanderer. Then he got a craving to quench a slight thirst and to pluck himself a grape; but when he had already stretched out his arm to do so, then he got an even stronger craving to do something else, namely to lie down beside the tree, at the hour of perfect noon, and to sleep.</p><p>This Zarathustra did; and as soon as he lay on the ground, in the quiet and secrecy of the colorful grass, he quickly forgot about his slight thirst and fell asleep. For, as Zarathustra\u2019s proverb says, one thing is more needful than the other. Only his eyes remained open \u2013 because they did not tire of seeing and praising the tree and the grapevine\u2019s love. As he was falling asleep, however, Zarathustra spoke thus to his heart:</p><p>Still! Still! Didn\u2019t the world become perfect just now? What\u2019s happening to me?</p><p>Like a delicate wind, unseen, dancing on a paneled sea, light, feather light \u2013 thus sleep dances on me.</p><p>He does not close my eyes, he leaves my soul awake. Light is he, truly, feather light!</p><p>He persuades me, I don\u2019t know how. He pats me on the inside with flattering hand, he conquers me. Yes, he conquers me until my soul stretches out \u2013</p><p>\u2013 how she grows long and weary, my strange soul! Did a seventh day\u2019s evening come to her precisely at noon? Did she wander blissfully too long already between good and ripe things?</p><p>She stretches herself out, long \u2013 longer! She lies still, my strange soul. She\u2019s already tasted too much that is good, this golden melancholy oppresses her, she grimaces.</p><p>\u2013 Like a ship that sailed into its stillest bay \u2013 now it leans against the earth, weary of the long journeys and the uncertain seas. Is the earth not more faithful?</p><p>How such a ship moors and nestles itself to the land \u2013 now it\u2019s enough for a spider to spin a web to it from the land. It needs no stronger lines now. Like such a weary ship in the stillest bay, thus I too rest now close to the earth, faithfully, trusting, waiting, bound to it with the lightest threads.</p><p>Oh happiness, oh happiness! Do you want to sing, oh my soul? You lie in the grass. But this is the secret solemn hour when no shepherd plays his flute.</p><p>Stand back! Hot noon sleeps on the meadows. Do not sing! Still! The world is perfect.</p><p>Do not sing, you winged bug in the grass, oh my soul! Do not even whisper! Look here \u2013 still! Old noon is sleeping, he\u2019s moving his mouth: didn\u2019t he just drink a drop of happiness \u2013</p><p>\u2013 an old brown drop of golden happiness, golden wine? It flits over him, his happiness is laughing. Thus laughs \u2013 a god. Still! \u2013</p><p>\u2013 \u201cHappily, how little suffices for happiness!\u201d Thus I spoke once, and deemed myself clever. But it was a blasphemy: this I learned now. Clever fools speak better.</p><p>Precisely the least, the softest, the lightest, a lizard\u2019s rustling, a breath, a wink, a blink of an eye \u2013 a little is the stuff of the best happiness. Still!</p><p>\u2013 What happened to me: listen! Didn\u2019t time just fly away? Am I not falling? Did I not fall \u2013 listen! \u2013 into the well of eternity?</p><p>\u2013 What\u2019s happening to me? Still! Something is stinging me \u2013 oh no \u2013 in the heart? In the heart? Oh break, break, heart, after such happiness, after such a sting!</p><p>\u2013 What? Did the world not become perfect just now? Round and ripe? Oh the golden round ring \u2013 where is it flying to now? I\u2019ll run after it! Rush!</p><p>Still \u2013 (and here Zarathustra stretched and felt that he was sleeping).</p><p>\u201cGet up!\u201d he said to himself, \u201cyou sleeper! You noon sleeper! Well then, well now, you old legs! It\u2019s time and overtime, many a good piece of road is still waiting for you \u2013</p><p>Now you\u2019ve slept yourself out, for how long? Half an eternity! Well then, well now, my old heart! How long after such a sleep will it take you to wake yourself out?</p><p>(But then he fell asleep anew, and his soul spoke against him and resisted and laid itself down again) \u2013 \u201cLet me be! Still! Didn\u2019t the world become perfect just now? Oh the golden round ball!\u201d \u2013</p><p>\u201cGet up,\u201d spoke Zarathustra, \u201cyou little thief, you loafing thief! What? Still stretching, yawning, sighing, falling down into deep wells?</p><p>Who are you? Oh my soul!\u201d (and here he started, because a sunbeam fell down from the sky onto his face)</p><p>\u201cOh sky above me,\u201d he said, sighing, and sat upright. \u201cYou\u2019re looking at me? You\u2019re listening to my strange soul?</p><p>When will you drink this drop of dew that has fallen upon all earthly things \u2013 when will you drink this strange soul \u2013 when, well of eternity! You cheerful, dreadful noon abyss! When will you drink my soul back into yourself?\u201d</p><p>Thus spoke Zarathustra and he rose from his sleeping place at the tree as if from a strange drunkenness; and behold, the sun was still stand- ing straight over his head.
