But from this one might justifiably infer that Zarathustra had not slept long."}, "id": 87}, {"data": {"uuid": "8805dece-7614-44a1-8aa9-969f5ff3d947", "user": 1, "title": "The Welcome", "created_on": "2023-05-10 16:57:50.371931+00:00", "updated_on": "2023-05-10 16:57:50.395751+00:00", "article_html": "<h2>The Welcome</h2><p>It was not until late afternoon that Zarathustra returned home to his cave after much searching and roaming around in vain. But as he stood facing the cave, not more than twenty paces away from it, something happened that he least expected now: once again he heard the great cry of distress. And, amazingly, this time it came from his own cave! But it was a protracted, manifold, peculiar cry, and Zarathustra clearly differentiated that it was composed of many voices; even if, heard from a distance, it sounded like the cry of a single mouth.</p><p>Then Zarathustra bounded toward his cave, and behold, what an eyeful awaited him after this earful! Indeed, there sitting all together were the ones he had passed by during the day: the king on the right and king on the left, the old magician, the pope, the voluntary beggar, the shadow, the conscientious of spirit, the sad soothsayer and the ass; the ugliest human being, however, had donned a crown and draped two purple sashes around himself \u2013 for like all ugly people he loved to disguise himself and act beautiful. But in the midst of this gloomy company stood Zarathustra\u2019s eagle, bristling and restless because he was pressed to answer too much for which his pride had no answer; meanwhile the wise snake hung around his neck.</p><p>All of this Zarathustra observed with great amazement; then he examined each one of his guests with affable curiosity, read their souls and was amazed once more. In the meantime the assembled had risen from their seats and they waited respectfully for Zarathustra to speak. But Zarathustra spoke thus:</p><p>\u201cYou despairing ones! You strange ones! So it was your cry of distress I heard? And now I also know where to find the one whom I have sought in vain today: the higher man \u2013 :</p><p>\u2013 in my own cave he\u2019s sitting, the higher man! But why am I amazed? Did I myself not lure him to me with honey sacrifices and the cunning calls of my happiness?</p><p>Yet it seems to me you are not fit company for each other; sitting here together you strain each other\u2019s nerves, you criers of distress. First someone has to come,</p><p>\u2013 someone to make you laugh again, a good gay buffoon, a dancer and a wind and wildcat, some old fool \u2013 what do you think?</p><p>Forgive me please, you despairing ones, for speaking to you with such small words, unworthy, truly, of such guests! But you cannot guess what makes my heart so mischievous \u2013</p><p>You yourselves are responsible, and how you look, forgive me! After all, everyone who looks at a despairing person becomes mischievous. To give encouragement to someone who despairs \u2013 for that everyone thinks they\u2019re strong enough.</p><p>You yourselves gave me this strength \u2013 a good gift, my elevated guests! A righteous gift for your host! Well then, don\u2019t be angry now when I offer you something of my own.</p><p>This here is my kingdom and my dominion; but whatever is mine shall be yours for this evening and this night. My animals shall serve you; my cave shall be your resting place!</p><p>In my home and house no one shall despair; in my territory I protect everyone from his wild animals. And that is the first thing I offer you: security!</p><p>But the second thing is: my little finger. And once you\u2019ve got hold of it, just go ahead and take the whole hand! And my heart too! Welcome to this place, welcome, my guests! \u201d</p><p>Thus spoke Zarathustra and he laughed with love and malice. After this welcome his guests bowed repeatedly and maintained a respectful silence; then the king on the right responded in their name.</p><p>\u201cBy the manner, oh Zarathustra, that you offered us your hand and your greeting, we recognize you as Zarathustra. You humbled yourself before us; you almost offended our sense of respect \u2013</p><p>\u2013 but who is able to humble himself like you with such pride? That in itself uplifts us, it refreshes our eyes and hearts.</p><p>To behold this alone we would have gladly climbed higher mountains than this one here. We came hungry for something to behold, we wanted to see what brightens gloomy eyes.</p><p>And behold, already we have ceased all our crying of distress. Already our minds and hearts stand open and are delighted. Little is missing and our spirits will become spirited.</p><p>Nothing more delightful grows on earth, oh Zarathustra, than a tall, strong will: that is the earth\u2019s most beautiful plant. An entire landscape is invigorated by one such tree.</p><p>Whoever grows tall like you, oh Zarathustra, I compare to the stone-pine: long, silent, hard, solitary, of the most resilient wood, magnificent \u2013</p><p>\u2013 but in the end reaching out with strong green branches for its dominion, asking strong questions before the winds and weather and whatever else is at home in the heights,</p><p>\u2013 answering even more strongly, a commander, a victor: oh who would not climb high mountains to look upon such plants?</p><p>Even the gloomy, the failures are invigorated by your tree, oh Zarathustra, even the hearts of the unsteady are made sure and are healed at the sight of you.</p><p>And truly, many eyes today are trained on your mountain and tree; a great longing has opened up, and many have learned to ask: who is Zarathustra?</p><p>And those into whose ears you ever dripped your song and your honey: all the hidden ones, the solitary and the dualitary, said at once to their hearts:</p><p>\u2018Does Zarathustra still live? It\u2019s not worth it anymore to live, all is the same, all is in vain: or \u2013 we must live with Zarathustra!\u2019</p><p>\u2018Why does he not come, he who announced himself for so long?\u2019 thus many ask. \u2018Did solitude swallow him up? Or should we perhaps go to him?\u2019</p><p>Now it happens that solitude itself is becoming brittle and is breaking apart, like a grave that breaks open and can no longer contain its dead. Everywhere one sees the resurrected.</p><p>Now the waves rise and rise around your mountain, oh Zarathustra. And as high as your height may be, many must go up to you; your skiff shall not be on the rocks much longer.</p><p>And that we who despair have now come to your cave and no longer despair: this is merely a token and an omen that better ones are on their way to you \u2013</p><p>\u2013 for what is on its way to you is nothing less than the last remnant of God among human beings, that is: all human beings of great longing, of great nausea, of great surfeit,</p><p>\u2013 all who do not want to live unless they once again learn to hope \u2013 unless they learn from you, oh Zarathustra, the great hope!\u201d</p><p>Thus spoke the king on the right and he grasped Zarathustra\u2019s hand in order to kiss it; but Zarathustra rebuffed his veneration and stepped back startled, silent, and as if he were fleeing suddenly into remote distances. But after a brief while he was once again among his guests, looking at them with bright, piercing eyes, and he said:</p><p>\u201cMy guests, you higher men, I want to speak in German and intelligibly with you. Not for you did I wait here in these mountains.</p><p>(\u2018In German and intelligibly? May God have mercy!\u2019 said the king on the left, as an aside. \u2018One notices that he does not know our dear Germans, this wise man from the East!</p><p>But he really means \u201cin German and in-eptly\u201d \u2013 well then! Nowadays that is not the worst of tastes!\u2019)</p><p>\u201cYou may indeed be higher men, collectively,\u201d Zarathustra continued. \u201cBut for me \u2013 you are not high and strong enough.</p><p>For me, that is: for the inexorable that remains silent in me but will not always remain silent. And if you belong to me, then surely not as my right arm.</p><p>For whoever stands on sick and frail legs himself, as you do, wants above all to be spared, whether he knows it or conceals it from himself.</p><p>But I do not spare my arms and legs, I do not spare my warriors: how could you be fit for my war?</p><p>With you I would only ruin every victory. And many of you would already fall over just to hear the loud pounding of my drums.</p><p>Nor are you beautiful enough for me and wellborn. I need clean, smooth mirrors for my teachings; on your surfaces even my own image is distorted.</p><p>Your shoulders are weighed down by many a burden, many a memory; in your corners many a wicked dwarf crouches. There is hidden rabble in you as well.</p><p>And even if you are higher and of a higher kind: much in you is crooked and deformed. There\u2019s no smith in the world who could hammer you right and straight for me.</p><p>You are mere bridges \u2013 may higher people stride across on you! You represent steps \u2013 so do not be angered by the one who steps over you into his height!</p><p>From your seed perhaps a genuine son and perfect heir will grow someday for me; but that is far off. You yourselves are not the ones to whom my inheritance and my name belong.</p><p>Not for you do I wait here in these mountains, not with you shall I go down for the last time. You came to me only as an omen that higher ones are on their way to me \u2013</p><p>\u2013 not the people of great longing, of great nausea, of great surfeit and that which you called the remnant of God.</p><p>\u2013 No! No! Three times no! I wait for others here in these mountains and will not lift a foot from here without them,</p><p>\u2013 for higher, stronger, more victorious, more cheerful ones, those who are built right-angled in body and soul: laughing lions must come!</p><p>Oh my guests, you strange ones \u2013 have you not yet heard anything of my children? And that they are on their way to me?</p><p>Speak to me of my gardens, of my blessed isles, of my beautiful new species \u2013 why don\u2019t you speak to me of that?</p><p>This host\u2019s gift I beg of your love, that you speak of my children. It is for this that I am rich, for this that I became poor: what did I not give,</p><p>\u2013 what would I not give just to have this one thing: these children, this living plantation, these life-trees of my will and my highest hope!\u201d</p><p>Thus spoke Zarathustra and suddenly he stopped in his speech, because his longing overcame him, and his eyes and his mouth were closed by the turmoil in his heart. But as he stood facing the cave, not more than twenty paces away from it, something happened that he least expected now: once again he heard the great cry of distress. And, amazingly, this time it came from his own cave! But it was a protracted, manifold, peculiar cry, and Zarathustra clearly differentiated that it was composed of many voices; even if, heard from a distance, it sounded like the cry of a single mouth.\r\n\r\nThen Zarathustra bounded toward his cave, and behold, what an eyeful awaited him after this earful! Indeed, there sitting all together were the ones he had passed by during the day: the king on the right and king on the left, the old magician, the pope, the voluntary beggar, the shadow, the conscientious of spirit, the sad soothsayer and the ass; the ugliest human being, however, had donned a crown and draped two purple sashes around himself \u2013 for like all ugly people he loved to disguise himself and act beautiful. But in the midst of this gloomy company stood Zarathustra\u2019s eagle, bristling and restless because he was pressed to answer too much for which his pride had no answer; meanwhile the wise snake hung around his neck.\r\n\r\nAll of this Zarathustra observed with great amazement; then he examined each one of his guests with affable curiosity, read their souls and was amazed once more. In the meantime the assembled had risen from their seats and they waited respectfully for Zarathustra to speak. But Zarathustra spoke thus:\r\n\r\n\u201cYou despairing ones! You strange ones! So it was your cry of distress I heard? And now I also know where to find the one whom I have sought in vain today: the higher man \u2013 :\r\n\r\n\u2013 in my own cave he\u2019s sitting, the higher man! But why am I amazed? Did I myself not lure him to me with honey sacrifices and the cunning calls of my happiness?\r\n\r\nYet it seems to me you are not fit company for each other; sitting here together you strain each other\u2019s nerves, you criers of distress. First someone has to come,\r\n\r\n\u2013 someone to make you laugh again, a good gay buffoon, a dancer and a wind and wildcat, some old fool \u2013 what do you think?\r\n\r\nForgive me please, you despairing ones, for speaking to you with such small words, unworthy, truly, of such guests! But you cannot guess what makes my heart so mischievous \u2013\r\n\r\nYou yourselves are responsible, and how you look, forgive me! After all, everyone who looks at a despairing person becomes mischievous. To give encouragement to someone who despairs \u2013 for that everyone thinks they\u2019re strong enough.\r\n\r\nYou yourselves gave me this strength \u2013 a good gift, my elevated guests! A righteous gift for your host! Well then, don\u2019t be angry now when I offer you something of my own.\r\n\r\nThis here is my kingdom and my dominion; but whatever is mine shall be yours for this evening and this night. My animals shall serve you; my cave shall be your resting place!\r\n\r\nIn my home and house no one shall despair; in my territory I protect everyone from his wild animals. And that is the first thing I offer you: security!\r\n\r\nBut the second thing is: my little finger. And once you\u2019ve got hold of it, just go ahead and take the whole hand! And my heart too! Welcome to this place, welcome, my guests! \u201d\r\n\r\nThus spoke Zarathustra and he laughed with love and malice. After this welcome his guests bowed repeatedly and maintained a respectful silence; then the king on the right responded in their name.\r\n\r\n\u201cBy the manner, oh Zarathustra, that you offered us your hand and your greeting, we recognize you as Zarathustra. You humbled yourself before us; you almost offended our sense of respect \u2013\r\n\r\n\u2013 but who is able to humble himself like you with such pride? That in itself uplifts us, it refreshes our eyes and hearts.\r\n\r\nTo behold this alone we would have gladly climbed higher mountains than this one here. We came hungry for something to behold, we wanted to see what brightens gloomy eyes.\r\n\r\nAnd behold, already we have ceased all our crying of distress. Already our minds and hearts stand open and are delighted. Little is missing and our spirits will become spirited.\r\n\r\nNothing more delightful grows on earth, oh Zarathustra, than a tall, strong will: that is the earth\u2019s most beautiful plant. An entire landscape is invigorated by one such tree.\r\n\r\nWhoever grows tall like you, oh Zarathustra, I compare to the stone-pine: long, silent, hard, solitary, of the most resilient wood, magnificent \u2013\r\n\r\n\u2013 but in the end reaching out with strong green branches for its dominion, asking strong questions before the winds and weather and whatever else is at home in the heights,\r\n\r\n\u2013 answering even more strongly, a commander, a victor: oh who would not climb high mountains to look upon such plants?\r\n\r\nEven the gloomy, the failures are invigorated by your tree, oh Zarathustra, even the hearts of the unsteady are made sure and are healed at the sight of you.\r\n\r\nAnd truly, many eyes today are trained on your mountain and tree; a great longing has opened up, and many have learned to ask: who is Zarathustra?\r\n\r\nAnd those into whose ears you ever dripped your song and your honey: all the hidden ones, the solitary and the dualitary, said at once to their hearts:\r\n\r\n\u2018Does Zarathustra still live? It\u2019s not worth it anymore to live, all is the same, all is in vain: or \u2013 we must live with Zarathustra!\u2019\r\n\r\n\u2018Why does he not come, he who announced himself for so long?\u2019 thus many ask. \u2018Did solitude swallow him up? Or should we perhaps go to him?\u2019\r\n\r\nNow it happens that solitude itself is becoming brittle and is breaking apart, like a grave that breaks open and can no longer contain its dead. Everywhere one sees the resurrected.\r\n\r\nNow the waves rise and rise around your mountain, oh Zarathustra. And as high as your height may be, many must go up to you; your skiff shall not be on the rocks much longer.\r\n\r\nAnd that we who despair have now come to your cave and no longer despair: this is merely a token and an omen that better ones are on their way to you \u2013\r\n\r\n\u2013 for what is on its way to you is nothing less than the last remnant of God among human beings, that is: all human beings of great longing, of great nausea, of great surfeit,\r\n\r\n\u2013 all who do not want to live unless they once again learn to hope \u2013 unless they learn from you, oh Zarathustra, the great hope!\u201d\r\n\r\nThus spoke the king on the right and he grasped Zarathustra\u2019s hand in order to kiss it; but Zarathustra rebuffed his veneration and stepped back startled, silent, and as if he were fleeing suddenly into remote distances. But after a brief while he was once again among his guests, looking at them with bright, piercing eyes, and he said:\r\n\r\n\u201cMy guests, you higher men, I want to speak in German and intelligibly with you. Not for you did I wait here in these mountains.\r\n\r\n(\u2018In German and intelligibly? May God have mercy!\u2019 said the king on the left, as an aside. \u2018One notices that he does not know our dear Germans, this wise man from the East!\r\n\r\nBut he really means \u201cin German and in-eptly\u201d \u2013 well then! Nowadays that is not the worst of tastes!\u2019)\r\n\r\n\u201cYou may indeed be higher men, collectively,\u201d Zarathustra continued. \u201cBut for me \u2013 you are not high and strong enough.\r\n\r\nFor me, that is: for the inexorable that remains silent in me but will not always remain silent. And if you belong to me, then surely not as my right arm.\r\n\r\nFor whoever stands on sick and frail legs himself, as you do, wants above all to be spared, whether he knows it or conceals it from himself.\r\n\r\nBut I do not spare my arms and legs, I do not spare my warriors: how could you be fit for my war?\r\n\r\nWith you I would only ruin every victory. And many of you would already fall over just to hear the loud pounding of my drums.\r\n\r\nNor are you beautiful enough for me and wellborn. I need clean, smooth mirrors for my teachings; on your surfaces even my own image is distorted.\r\n\r\nYour shoulders are weighed down by many a burden, many a memory; in your corners many a wicked dwarf crouches. There is hidden rabble in you as well.\r\n\r\nAnd even if you are higher and of a higher kind: much in you is crooked and deformed. There\u2019s no smith in the world who could hammer you right and straight for me.\r\n\r\nYou are mere bridges \u2013 may higher people stride across on you! You represent steps \u2013 so do not be angered by the one who steps over you into his height!\r\n\r\nFrom your seed perhaps a genuine son and perfect heir will grow someday for me; but that is far off. You yourselves are not the ones to whom my inheritance and my name belong.\r\n\r\nNot for you do I wait here in these mountains, not with you shall I go down for the last time. You came to me only as an omen that higher ones are on their way to me \u2013\r\n\r\n\u2013 not the people of great longing, of great nausea, of great surfeit and that which you called the remnant of God.\r\n\r\n\u2013 No! No! Three times no! I wait for others here in these mountains and will not lift a foot from here without them,\r\n\r\n\u2013 for higher, stronger, more victorious, more cheerful ones, those who are built right-angled in body and soul: laughing lions must come!\r\n\r\nOh my guests, you strange ones \u2013 have you not yet heard anything of my children? And that they are on their way to me?\r\n\r\nSpeak to me of my gardens, of my blessed isles, of my beautiful new species \u2013 why don\u2019t you speak to me of that?\r\n\r\nThis host\u2019s gift I beg of your love, that you speak of my children. It is for this that I am rich, for this that I became poor: what did I not give,\r\n\r\n\u2013 what would I not give just to have this one thing: these children, this living plantation, these life-trees of my will and my highest hope!\u201d\r\n\r\nThus spoke Zarathustra and suddenly he stopped in his speech, because his longing overcame him, and his eyes and his mouth were closed by the turmoil in his heart. And all his guests were silent as well, and they stood still and dismayed; except that the old soothsayer made signs and gestures with his hands."}, "id": 88}, {"data": {"uuid": "0c4c9fbe-d518-48d4-a1c2-53881f1494c5", "user": 1, "title": "The Last Supper", "created_on": "2023-05-10 16:58:32.873873+00:00", "updated_on": "2023-05-10 16:58:32.894397+00:00", "article_html": "<h2>The Last Supper</h2><p>At this point, however, the soothsayer interrupted the welcome of Zarathustra and his guests; he pushed forward like someone who has no time to lose, grabbed Zarathustra\u2019s hand and shouted: \u201cBut Zarathustra!</p><p>One thing is more needful than the other, so you yourself say: well then, one thing is more needful to me now than everything else.</p><p>A word at the right time: did you not invite me to supper? And here are many who traveled a long way. Surely you do not intend to feed us with speeches?</p><p>Also, you have all given too much thought already to freezing, drowning, suffocating and other bodily emergencies: but no one has thought about my emergency, namely starving \u2013\u201d</p><p>(Thus spoke the soothsayer; but when Zarathustra\u2019s animals heard these words, they ran away terrified, seeing that whatever they had brought home by day would not suffice to stuff even this one soothsayer.)</p><p>\u201cIncluding dying of thirst,\u201d continued the soothsayer. \u201cAnd even though I hear water splashing here, like the speeches of wisdom, namely abundantly and tirelessly, I want \u2013 wine!</p><p>Not everyone is a born water drinker, like Zarathustra. Nor is water fit for the weary and the wilted: we deserve wine \u2013 only it provides sudden convalescence and instant health!\u201d</p><p>At this opportunity, since the soothsayer demanded wine, it happened that the king on the left, the silent one, also spoke up at last. \u201cWe have taken care of the wine,\u201d he said, \u201cI together with my brother, the king on the right: we have wine enough \u2013 an entire ass-load. So nothing is lacking but bread.\u201d</p><p>\u201cBread?\u201d countered Zarathustra, and he laughed. \u201cBread is the one thing hermits do not have. But man does not live by bread alone, but also on the meat of good lambs, of which I have two:</p><p>\u2013 These we\u2019ll quickly slaughter and spice with sage; that\u2019s how I love it. And we do not lack for roots and fruits, good enough even for sweet-tooths and big eaters; nor for nuts and other riddles to crack.</p><p>And so we\u2019ll make a good meal in short order. But whoever wants to share in the eating must also lend a hand, even the kings. In Zarathustra\u2019s home, even a king may be a cook.\u201d</p><p>This suggestion appealed to the hearts of everyone, except that the voluntary beggar objected to meat and wine and spices.</p><p>\u201cJust listen to this glutton Zarathustra!\u201d he said jokingly. \u201cIs that why people go into caves and high mountains, to prepare such meals?</p><p>Now indeed I understand what he once taught us: \u2018Praised be a small poverty!\u2019 And why he wants to get rid of beggars.\u201d</p><p>\u201cCheer up,\u201d answered Zarathustra, \u201cas I am cheered. Stick to your custom, you excellent man, crunch your grains, drink your water, praise your cuisine \u2013 if only it makes you cheerful!</p><p>I am a law only for my own, I am no law for everyone. But whoever belongs to me must be of strong bones, also light of foot \u2013</p><p>\u2013 must be eager for wars and festivals, no gloomy Gus, no dreamy Joe, just as ready for what is hardest as for his festival, healthy and hale.</p><p>What\u2019s best belongs to mine and to me; if one doesn\u2019t give it to us, then we take it \u2013 the best food, the clearest sky, the strongest thoughts, the most beautiful women!\u201d \u2013</p><p>Thus spoke Zarathustra; but the king on the right retorted: \u201cThat\u2019s odd! Did anyone ever hear such clever things from the mouth of a wise man?</p><p>And truly, the oddest thing about a wise man is when, on top of everything else, he is also clever and not an ass.\u201d</p><p>Thus spoke the king on the right and he was amazed; but the ass responded to his remarks malevolently with \u201chee-yaw.\u201d And this was the beginning of that long meal which is called \u201cthe last supper\u201d in the history books. During the same, however, nothing was discussed but the higher man.</p>", "article_json": {"type": "doc", "content": [{"type": "heading", "attrs": {"level": 2}, "content": [{"text": "The Last Supper", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "content": [{"text": "At this point, however, the soothsayer interrupted the welcome of Zarathustra and his guests; he pushed forward like someone who has no time to lose, grabbed Zarathustra\u2019s hand and shouted: \u201cBut Zarathustra!", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "content": [{"text": "One thing is more needful than the other, so you yourself say: well then, one thing is more needful to me now than everything else.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "content": [{"text": "A word at the right time: did you not invite me to supper? And here are many who traveled a long way. Surely you do not intend to feed us with speeches?\r\n\r\nAlso, you have all given too much thought already to freezing, drowning, suffocating and other bodily emergencies: but no one has thought about my emergency, namely starving \u2013\u201d\r\n\r\n(Thus spoke the soothsayer; but when Zarathustra\u2019s animals heard these words, they ran away terrified, seeing that whatever they had brought home by day would not suffice to stuff even this one soothsayer.)\r\n\r\n\u201cIncluding dying of thirst,\u201d continued the soothsayer. \u201cAnd even though I hear water splashing here, like the speeches of wisdom, namely abundantly and tirelessly, I want \u2013 wine!\r\n\r\nNot everyone is a born water drinker, like Zarathustra. Nor is water fit for the weary and the wilted: we deserve wine \u2013 only it provides sudden convalescence and instant health!\u201d\r\n\r\nAt this opportunity, since the soothsayer demanded wine, it happened that the king on the left, the silent one, also spoke up at last. \u201cWe have taken care of the wine,\u201d he said, \u201cI together with my brother, the king on the right: we have wine enough \u2013 an entire ass-load. So nothing is lacking but bread.\u201d\r\n\r\n\u201cBread?\u201d countered Zarathustra, and he laughed. \u201cBread is the one thing hermits do not have. But man does not live by bread alone, but also on the meat of good lambs, of which I have two:\r\n\r\n\u2013 These we\u2019ll quickly slaughter and spice with sage; that\u2019s how I love it. And we do not lack for roots and fruits, good enough even for sweet-tooths and big eaters; nor for nuts and other riddles to crack.\r\n\r\nAnd so we\u2019ll make a good meal in short order. But whoever wants to share in the eating must also lend a hand, even the kings. In Zarathustra\u2019s home, even a king may be a cook.\u201d\r\n\r\nThis suggestion appealed to the hearts of everyone, except that the voluntary beggar objected to meat and wine and spices.\r\n\r\n\u201cJust listen to this glutton Zarathustra!\u201d he said jokingly. \u201cIs that why people go into caves and high mountains, to prepare such meals?\r\n\r\nNow indeed I understand what he once taught us: \u2018Praised be a small poverty!\u2019 And why he wants to get rid of beggars.\u201d\r\n\r\n\u201cCheer up,\u201d answered Zarathustra, \u201cas I am cheered. Stick to your custom, you excellent man, crunch your grains, drink your water, praise your cuisine \u2013 if only it makes you cheerful!\r\n\r\nI am a law only for my own, I am no law for everyone. But whoever belongs to me must be of strong bones, also light of foot \u2013\r\n\r\n\u2013 must be eager for wars and festivals, no gloomy Gus, no dreamy Joe, just as ready for what is hardest as for his festival, healthy and hale.\r\n\r\nWhat\u2019s best belongs to mine and to me; if one doesn\u2019t give it to us, then we take it \u2013 the best food, the clearest sky, the strongest thoughts, the most beautiful women!\u201d \u2013\r\n\r\nThus spoke Zarathustra; but the king on the right retorted: \u201cThat\u2019s odd! Did anyone ever hear such clever things from the mouth of a wise man?\r\n\r\nAnd truly, the oddest thing about a wise man is when, on top of everything else, he is also clever and not an ass.\u201d\r\n\r\nThus spoke the king on the right and he was amazed; but the ass responded to his remarks malevolently with \u201chee-yaw.\u201d And this was the beginning of that long meal which is called \u201cthe last supper\u201d in the history books. During the same, however, nothing was discussed but the higher man."}, "id": 89}, {"data": {"uuid": "fc31366e-c780-4eb7-96dd-2a2d7645ed4d", "user": 1, "title": "On the Higher Man", "created_on": "2023-05-10 16:59:29.626832+00:00", "updated_on": "2023-05-10 16:59:29.654230+00:00", "article_html": "<h2>On the Higher Man</h2><h3>1</h3><p>When I came to mankind for the first time, I committed the hermit\u2019s folly, the great folly: I situated myself in the market place.</p><p>And when I spoke to all, I spoke to none. But by evening my companions were tightrope walkers, and corpses, and I myself almost a corpse.</p><p>But with the new morning a new truth came to me; then I learned to say: \u201cWhat do the market place and the rabble and the rabble noise and long rabble ears matter to me!\u201d</p><p>You higher men, learn this from me: in the market place no one believes in higher men. And if you want to speak there, well then! But the rabble blinks \u201cwe are all equal.</p><p>You higher men\u201d \u2013 thus blinks the rabble \u2013 \u201cthere are no higher men, we are all equal, human is human, before God \u2013 we are all equal!\u201d</p><p>Before God! \u2013 Now, however, this God has died. But we do not want to be equal before the rabble. You higher men, go away from the market place!</p><h3>2</h3><p>Before God! \u2013 But now this god has died! You higher men, this god was your greatest danger.</p><p>It is only now, since he lies in his grave, that you are resurrected. Only now the great noon comes, only now the higher man becomes \u2013 ruler!</p><p>Have you understood these words, oh my brothers? You are frightened; do your hearts become dizzy? Does the abyss yawn before you here? Does the hell hound yelp before you here?</p><p>Well then! Well now! You higher men! Only now is the mountain in labor with humanity\u2019s future. God died: now we want \u2013 the overman to live.</p><h3>3</h3><p>Those who care most today ask: \u201cHow are human beings to be preserved?\u201d But Zarathustra is the only one and the first one to ask: \u201cHow shall human being be overcome?\u201d</p><p>The overman is in my heart, that is my first and my only concern \u2013 and not human beings; not the neighbor, not the poorest, not the most suffering, not the best \u2013</p><p>Oh my brothers, what I am able to love in human beings is that they are a going over and a going under. And in you, too, there is much that makes me love and hope.</p><p>That you despise, you higher men, that makes me hope. For the great despisers are the great reverers.</p><p>That you have despaired, there is much to revere in that. For you did not learn how to surrender, you did not learn petty prudence.</p><p>For today the little people have become ruler: they all preach surrender and resignation and prudence and industry and consideration and the long etcetera of little virtues.</p><p>What is effeminate, what comes from the servant\u2019s ilk and especially the rabble mishmash: that now wants to become ruler of all human destiny \u2013 oh nausea! Nausea! Nausea!</p><p>That asks and asks and does not tire: \u201cHow do human beings preserve themselves best, longest, most pleasantly?\u201d With that \u2013 they are the rulers of today.</p><p>Overcome these rulers of today for me, oh my brothers \u2013 these little people: they are the overman\u2019s greatest danger!</p><p>Overcome for me, you higher men, the little virtues, the little prudence, the sand-grain sized considerations, the detritus of swarming ants, the pitiful contentedness, the \u201chappiness of the greatest number\u201d!</p><p>And despair rather than surrender. And truly, I love you for not knowing how to live today, you higher men! For thus you live \u2013 best!</p><h3>4</h3><p>Do you have courage, oh my brothers? Are you brave of heart? Not courage before witnesses, but the courage of hermits and eagles, which not even a god looks at anymore.</p><p>Cold souls, mules, the blind, the drunk \u2013 these I do not call brave of heart. Whoever has heart knows fear, but conquers fear; sees the abyss, but with pride.</p><p>Whoever sees the abyss, but with eagle\u2019s eyes, whoever grasps the abyss with eagle\u2019s talons: he has courage. \u2013</p><h3>5</h3><p>\u201cHuman beings are evil\u201d \u2013 thus spoke all the wisest to comfort me. Oh, if only it were still true today! Because evil is a human being\u2019s best power.</p><p>\u201cMankind must become better and more evil\u201d \u2013 thus I teach. What is most evil is necessary for the overman\u2019s best.</p><p>It may have been good for that preacher of the little people that he suffered and labored under the sins of mankind. But I enjoy the greatest sin as my greatest comfort. \u2013</p><p>But such things are not said for long ears. Every word does not belong in every snout. These are fine and faraway things: sheeps\u2019 hooves should not reach for them!</p><h3>6</h3><p>You higher men, do you think I am here to make good what you made bad?</p><p>Or that I have come henceforth to bed you suffering ones more comfortably? Or to show new, easier paths to those of you who are unsteady, lost, and have climbed astray?</p><p>No! No! Three times no! Ever more, ever better of your kind shall perish \u2013 for you shall have it ever worse and ever harder. Only thus \u2013</p><p>\u2013 only thus do human beings grow into that height, where lightning strikes and breaks them: high enough for lightning!</p><p>My mind and my longing are trained on the few, the long, the distant: what do I care about your many little brief miseries?</p><p>You do not suffer enough in my opinion! For you suffer from yourselves, you haven\u2019t yet suffered from human beings. And you would be lying if you said otherwise! All of you do not suffer from what I suffered. \u2013</p><h3>7</h3><p>It is not enough for me that lightning no longer causes damage. I do not want to divert it: it shall learn to work \u2013 for me.</p><p>My wisdom has gathered itself for a long time like a cloud, it becomes stiller and darker. Thus does every wisdom that shall one day give birth to lightning.</p><p>To these people of today I do not want to be light, nor be called light. Them \u2013 I want to blind: lightning of my wisdom \u2013 put out their eyes!</p><h3>8</h3><p>Will nothing beyond your capacity: there is a wicked falseness among those who will beyond their capacity.</p><p>Especially when they will great things! For they arouse mistrust against great things, these fine counterfeiters and actors \u2013</p><p>\u2013 until at last they are false before themselves, cross-eyed, white-washed worm food, cloaked by strong words, by showy virtues, by gleaming false works.</p><p>Be very careful there, you higher men! For I regard nothing more precious and rare today than honesty.</p><p>Is this today not of the rabble? But rabble does not know what is great, what is small, what is straight and honest: it is innocently crooked, it always lies.</p><h3>9</h3><p>Have a good mistrust today, you higher men, you brave-hearted, you open-hearted ones! And keep your grounds secret! For this today is of the rabble.</p><p>What the rabble once learned to believe without grounds, how could anyone overthrow that with grounds?</p><p>In the market place one convinces with gestures. But grounds make the rabble mistrustful.</p><p>And if ever truth was victorious there, then ask yourselves with good mistrust: \u201cWhich strong error fought for it?\u201d</p><p>And beware also of the scholars! They hate you, because they are sterile! They have cold, dried up eyes; before them every bird lies plucked.</p><p>Such types boast that they do not lie: but powerlessness to lie is by no means love for the truth. Beware!</p><p>Freedom from fever is by no means knowledge! I do not believe spirits that have cooled down. Whoever cannot lie does not know what truth is.</p><h3>10</h3><p>If you want to climb high and beyond, then use your own legs! Do not let yourselves be carried up, do not seat yourselves on strangers\u2019 backs and heads!</p><p>But you mount your horse? You ride swiftly up to your goal? Well then, my friend! But your lame foot is also mounted on your horse!</p><p>When you\u2019ve reached your goal, when you leap from your horse, precisely at your height, you higher man \u2013 you will stumble!</p><h3>11</h3><p>You creators, you higher men! One is pregnant only with one\u2019s own child.</p><p>Do not let yourselves be misled and spoon-fed! Who after all is your neighbor? And even if you act \u201cfor your neighbor\u201d \u2013 still you don\u2019t create for him!</p><p>Unlearn this \u201cfor,\u201d you creators; your virtue itself wants that you do nothing \u201cfor\u201d and \u201cin order\u201d and \u201cbecause.\u201d You should plug your ears against these false little words.</p><p>\u201cFor your neighbor\u201d is the virtue of only small people; there they say \u201cbirds of a feather\u201d and \u201cone hand washes the other\u201d \u2013 they have neither the right nor the strength to your self-interest.</p><p>In your self-interest, you creators, are the precaution and providence of the pregnant! What no one yet has laid eyes on, the fruit: your whole love shelters and spares and nourishes it.</p><p>Where your whole love is, with your children, there too your whole virtue is! Your work, your will is your \u201cneighbor\u201d \u2013 do not let yourself be spoon-fed any false values!</p><h3>12</h3><p>You creators, you higher men! Whoever must give birth is sick; but whoever has given birth, is unclean.</p><p>Ask women: one does not give birth because it is enjoyable. Pain makes hens and poets cackle.</p><p>You creators, in you there is much that is unclean. That\u2019s because you had to be mothers.</p><p>A new child \u2013 oh how much new filth also came into the world! Step aside! And whoever has given birth should wash his soul clean!</p><h3>13</h3><p>Do not be virtuous beyond your strengths! And will nothing of yourselves that is contrary to probability!</p><p>Walk in the footsteps where your fathers\u2019 virtue walked before! How could you climb high if your fathers\u2019 will did not climb with you?</p><p>But whoever would be a firstling should see to it that he does not also become a lastling! And where the vices of your fathers are, there you should not pretend to be saints!</p><p>If your fathers took to women and strong wine and boar swine, what would be the use of demanding chastity of yourself?</p><p>It would be a folly! To me it truly seems like much if such a man belonged to one or two or three women.</p><p>And if he founded monasteries and wrote above the door: \u201cThis way to sainthood\u201d \u2013 I would still say: What for! It\u2019s a new folly!</p><p>He founded himself a guardhouse and safeguard: good for him! But I don\u2019t believe in it.</p><p>Whatever one brings into solitude grows in it, even the inner beast. On this score, solitude is ill-advised for many.</p><p>Was there ever anything filthier on earth than saints of the wilderness? Around them not only hell broke loose \u2013 but pigs too.</p><h3>14</h3><p>Timid, ashamed, awkward, like a tiger whose leap has failed; thus, you higher men, I often saw you slinking aside. A throw failed you.</p><p>But what does it matter, you dice throwers! You did not learn to gamble and banter as one should gamble and banter! Are we not always sitting at a great bantering and gaming table?</p><p>And when something great failed you, are you yourselves therefore \u2013 failures? And if you yourselves failed, did humanity therefore fail? But if humanity failed: well then, well now!</p><h3>15</h3><p>The higher its kind, the more seldom a thing succeeds. You higher men here, haven\u2019t all of you \u2013 failed?</p><p>Be of good cheer, what does it matter! How much is still possible! Learn to laugh at yourselves as one must laugh!</p><p>And no wonder that you failed and half succeeded, you half-broken ones! Does humanity\u2019s future not push and shove within you?</p><p>What is most distant, deepest, highest to the stars in humanity, its prodigious power: does all that not foam against each other in your pot?</p><p>No wonder many a pot breaks! Learn to laugh at yourselves as one must laugh! You higher men, oh how much is still possible!</p><p>And truly, how much has succeeded already! How rich is this earth in small, good, perfect things, in things that turned out well!</p><p>Place small, good, perfect things around you, you higher men! Their golden ripeness heals the heart. Perfection teaches us to hope.</p><h3>16</h3><p>What was the greatest sin here on earth until now? Was it not the words of him who spoke: \u201cWoe to you who laugh now!\u201d</p><p>Did he himself find no reasons to laugh on earth? Then he searched badly. Even a child finds reasons here.</p><p>He \u2013 did not love enough; or else he would have loved us too, we who laugh! But he hated and heckled us, howling and gnashing of teeth he heralded for us.</p><p>Must one curse right away where one does not love? That \u2013 seems to me in bad taste. But that is how he acted, this unconditional one. He came from the rabble.</p><p>And he himself just did not love enough; or else he would have been less angry that people did not love him. All great love does not want love \u2013 it wants more.</p><p>Get out of the way of all such unconditional ones! That is a poor sick kind, a rabble kind; they look harshly at this life, they have the evil eye for this earth.</p><p>Get out of the way of all such unconditional ones! They have heavy feet and sultry hearts \u2013 they do not know how to dance. How could the earth be light to them?</p><h3>17</h3><p>Crookedly all good things approach their goal. Like cats they arch their backs, they purr inwardly with their impending happiness \u2013 all good things laugh.</p><p>A person\u2019s stride betrays whether one is striding on his course: just look at me walk! But whoever approaches his goal dances.</p><p>And truly, I have not become a statue, I do not yet stand there stiff, stunned, stony, a column; I love swift running.</p><p>And even though there are bogs and thick depressions on earth, who- ever has light feet runs over and past the mud and dances as if on clean- swept ice.</p><p>Lift up your hearts, my brothers, high! higher! And don\u2019t forget your legs either! Lift up your legs as well, you good dancers, and better still: stand on your heads too!</p><h3>18</h3><p>This crown of the laughing one, this rose-wreath crown \u2013 I myself put on this crown, I myself pronounced my laughter holy. I found no other strong enough for it today.</p><p>Zarathustra the dancer, Zarathustra the light one who waves with his wings, the flightworthy, waving to all birds, worthy and ready, a blissful lightweight \u2013</p><p>Zarathustra the soothsayer, Zarathustra the soothlaugher, not impatient, not unconditional, someone who loves capers and escapades; I myself put on this crown!</p><h3>19</h3><p>Lift up your hearts, my brothers, high! higher! And don\u2019t forget your legs either! Lift up your legs as well, you good dancers, and better still: stand on your heads too!</p><p>Even in happiness there are heavy creatures, there are born ponderipedes. Quaintly they struggle, like an elephant struggling to stand on its head.</p><p>But it is better to be foolish with happiness than foolish with unhappiness, better to dance ponderously than to walk lamely. So learn this wisdom from me: even the worst thing has two good reverse sides \u2013</p><p>\u2013 even the worst thing has good legs for dancing: so learn from me, you higher men, to stand yourselves on your right legs!</p><p>So unlearn moping and all rabble sadness! Oh how sad even today\u2019s rabble clowns seem to me! But this today is of the rabble.</p><h3>20</h3><p>Make like the wind when he plunges from his mountain caves: he wants to dance to his own pipe, the seas tremble and skip under his footsteps.</p><p>Praised be this good unruly spirit who gives wings to asses and milks the lionesses, who comes upon all that is today and all rabble like a storm wind \u2013</p><p>\u2013 who is hostile to thistle-heads and hair-splitters and all wilted leaves and weeds: praised be this good, free storm spirit, who dances on bogs and depressions as upon meadows!</p><p>Who hates the rabble\u2019s mindless swindlers and all botched gloomy brood: praised be this spirit of all free spirits, the laughing storm who blows dust into the eyes of all fusspots and pus-pots!</p><p>You higher men, your worst part is that all of you have not learned to dance as one must dance \u2013 dance over and past yourselves! What does it matter that you didn\u2019t turn out well?</p><p>How much is still possible! So learn to laugh over and past yourselves! Lift up your hearts, you good dancers, high! higher! And don\u2019t forget good laughter either!</p><p>This crown of the laughing one, this rose-wreath crown: to you, my brothers, I throw this crown! But by evening my companions were tightrope walkers, and corpses, and I myself almost a corpse.\r\n\r\nBut with the new morning a new truth came to me; then I learned to say: \u201cWhat do the market place and the rabble and the rabble noise and long rabble ears matter to me!\u201d\r\n\r\nYou higher men, learn this from me: in the market place no one believes in higher men. And if you want to speak there, well then! But the rabble blinks \u201cwe are all equal.\r\n\r\nYou higher men\u201d \u2013 thus blinks the rabble \u2013 \u201cthere are no higher men, we are all equal, human is human, before God \u2013 we are all equal!\u201d\r\n\r\nBefore God! \u2013 Now, however, this God has died. But we do not want to be equal before the rabble. You higher men, go away from the market place!\r\n\r\n2\r\n\r\nBefore God! \u2013 But now this god has died! You higher men, this god was your greatest danger.\r\n\r\nIt is only now, since he lies in his grave, that you are resurrected. Only now the great noon comes, only now the higher man becomes \u2013 ruler!\r\n\r\nHave you understood these words, oh my brothers? You are frightened; do your hearts become dizzy? Does the abyss yawn before you here? Does the hell hound yelp before you here?\r\n\r\nWell then! Well now! You higher men! Only now is the mountain in labor with humanity\u2019s future. God died: now we want \u2013 the overman to live.\r\n\r\n3\r\n\r\nThose who care most today ask: \u201cHow are human beings to be preserved?\u201d But Zarathustra is the only one and the first one to ask: \u201cHow shall human being be overcome?\u201d\r\n\r\nThe overman is in my heart, that is my first and my only concern \u2013 and not human beings; not the neighbor, not the poorest, not the most suffering, not the best \u2013\r\n\r\nOh my brothers, what I am able to love in human beings is that they are a going over and a going under. And in you, too, there is much that makes me love and hope.\r\n\r\nThat you despise, you higher men, that makes me hope. For the great despisers are the great reverers.\r\n\r\nThat you have despaired, there is much to revere in that. For you did not learn how to surrender, you did not learn petty prudence.\r\n\r\nFor today the little people have become ruler: they all preach surrender and resignation and prudence and industry and consideration and the long etcetera of little virtues.\r\n\r\nWhat is effeminate, what comes from the servant\u2019s ilk and especially the rabble mishmash: that now wants to become ruler of all human destiny \u2013 oh nausea! Nausea! Nausea!\r\n\r\nThat asks and asks and does not tire: \u201cHow do human beings preserve themselves best, longest, most pleasantly?\u201d With that \u2013 they are the rulers of today.\r\n\r\nOvercome these rulers of today for me, oh my brothers \u2013 these little people: they are the overman\u2019s greatest danger!\r\n\r\nOvercome for me, you higher men, the little virtues, the little prudence, the sand-grain sized considerations, the detritus of swarming ants, the pitiful contentedness, the \u201chappiness of the greatest number\u201d!\r\n\r\nAnd despair rather than surrender. And truly, I love you for not knowing how to live today, you higher men! For thus you live \u2013 best!\r\n\r\n4\r\n\r\nDo you have courage, oh my brothers? Are you brave of heart? Not courage before witnesses, but the courage of hermits and eagles, which not even a god looks at anymore.\r\n\r\nCold souls, mules, the blind, the drunk \u2013 these I do not call brave of heart. Whoever has heart knows fear, but conquers fear; sees the abyss, but with pride.\r\n\r\nWhoever sees the abyss, but with eagle\u2019s eyes, whoever grasps the abyss with eagle\u2019s talons: he has courage. \u2013\r\n\r\n5\r\n\r\n\u201cHuman beings are evil\u201d \u2013 thus spoke all the wisest to comfort me. Oh, if only it were still true today! Because evil is a human being\u2019s best power.\r\n\r\n\u201cMankind must become better and more evil\u201d \u2013 thus I teach. What is most evil is necessary for the overman\u2019s best.\r\n\r\nIt may have been good for that preacher of the little people that he suffered and labored under the sins of mankind. But I enjoy the greatest sin as my greatest comfort. \u2013\r\n\r\nBut such things are not said for long ears. Every word does not belong in every snout. These are fine and faraway things: sheeps\u2019 hooves should not reach for them!\r\n\r\n6\r\n\r\nYou higher men, do you think I am here to make good what you made bad?\r\n\r\nOr that I have come henceforth to bed you suffering ones more comfortably? Or to show new, easier paths to those of you who are unsteady, lost, and have climbed astray?\r\n\r\nNo! No! Three times no! Ever more, ever better of your kind shall perish \u2013 for you shall have it ever worse and ever harder. Only thus \u2013\r\n\r\n\u2013 only thus do human beings grow into that height, where lightning strikes and breaks them: high enough for lightning!\r\n\r\nMy mind and my longing are trained on the few, the long, the distant: what do I care about your many little brief miseries?\r\n\r\nYou do not suffer enough in my opinion! For you suffer from yourselves, you haven\u2019t yet suffered from human beings. And you would be lying if you said otherwise! All of you do not suffer from what I suffered. \u2013\r\n\r\n7\r\n\r\nIt is not enough for me that lightning no longer causes damage. I do not want to divert it: it shall learn to work \u2013 for me.\r\n\r\nMy wisdom has gathered itself for a long time like a cloud, it becomes stiller and darker. Thus does every wisdom that shall one day give birth to lightning.\r\n\r\nTo these people of today I do not want to be light, nor be called light. Them \u2013 I want to blind: lightning of my wisdom \u2013 put out their eyes!\r\n\r\n8\r\n\r\nWill nothing beyond your capacity: there is a wicked falseness among those who will beyond their capacity.\r\n\r\nEspecially when they will great things! For they arouse mistrust against great things, these fine counterfeiters and actors \u2013\r\n\r\n\u2013 until at last they are false before themselves, cross-eyed, white-washed worm food, cloaked by strong words, by showy virtues, by gleaming false works.\r\n\r\nBe very careful there, you higher men! For I regard nothing more precious and rare today than honesty.\r\n\r\nIs this today not of the rabble? But rabble does not know what is great, what is small, what is straight and honest: it is innocently crooked, it always lies.\r\n\r\n9\r\n\r\nHave a good mistrust today, you higher men, you brave-hearted, you open-hearted ones! And keep your grounds secret! For this today is of the rabble.\r\n\r\nWhat the rabble once learned to believe without grounds, how could anyone overthrow that with grounds?\r\n\r\nIn the market place one convinces with gestures. But grounds make the rabble mistrustful.\r\n\r\nAnd if ever truth was victorious there, then ask yourselves with good mistrust: \u201cWhich strong error fought for it?\u201d\r\n\r\nAnd beware also of the scholars! They hate you, because they are sterile! They have cold, dried up eyes; before them every bird lies plucked.\r\n\r\nSuch types boast that they do not lie: but powerlessness to lie is by no means love for the truth. Beware!\r\n\r\nFreedom from fever is by no means knowledge! I do not believe spirits that have cooled down. Whoever cannot lie does not know what truth is.\r\n\r\n10\r\n\r\nIf you want to climb high and beyond, then use your own legs! Do not let yourselves be carried up, do not seat yourselves on strangers\u2019 backs and heads!\r\n\r\nBut you mount your horse? You ride swiftly up to your goal? Well then, my friend! But your lame foot is also mounted on your horse!\r\n\r\nWhen you\u2019ve reached your goal, when you leap from your horse, precisely at your height, you higher man \u2013 you will stumble!\r\n\r\n11\r\n\r\nYou creators, you higher men! One is pregnant only with one\u2019s own child.\r\n\r\nDo not let yourselves be misled and spoon-fed! Who after all is your neighbor? And even if you act \u201cfor your neighbor\u201d \u2013 still you don\u2019t create for him!\r\n\r\nUnlearn this \u201cfor,\u201d you creators; your virtue itself wants that you do nothing \u201cfor\u201d and \u201cin order\u201d and \u201cbecause.\u201d You should plug your ears against these false little words.\r\n\r\n\u201cFor your neighbor\u201d is the virtue of only small people; there they say \u201cbirds of a feather\u201d and \u201cone hand washes the other\u201d \u2013 they have neither the right nor the strength to your self-interest.\r\n\r\nIn your self-interest, you creators, are the precaution and providence of the pregnant! What no one yet has laid eyes on, the fruit: your whole love shelters and spares and nourishes it.\r\n\r\nWhere your whole love is, with your children, there too your whole virtue is! Your work, your will is your \u201cneighbor\u201d \u2013 do not let yourself be spoon-fed any false values!\r\n\r\n12\r\n\r\nYou creators, you higher men! Whoever must give birth is sick; but whoever has given birth, is unclean.\r\n\r\nAsk women: one does not give birth because it is enjoyable. Pain makes hens and poets cackle.\r\n\r\nYou creators, in you there is much that is unclean. That\u2019s because you had to be mothers.\r\n\r\nA new child \u2013 oh how much new filth also came into the world! Step aside! And whoever has given birth should wash his soul clean!\r\n\r\n13\r\n\r\nDo not be virtuous beyond your strengths! And will nothing of yourselves that is contrary to probability!\r\n\r\nWalk in the footsteps where your fathers\u2019 virtue walked before! How could you climb high if your fathers\u2019 will did not climb with you?\r\n\r\nBut whoever would be a firstling should see to it that he does not also become a lastling! And where the vices of your fathers are, there you should not pretend to be saints!\r\n\r\nIf your fathers took to women and strong wine and boar swine, what would be the use of demanding chastity of yourself?\r\n\r\nIt would be a folly! To me it truly seems like much if such a man belonged to one or two or three women.\r\n\r\nAnd if he founded monasteries and wrote above the door: \u201cThis way to sainthood\u201d \u2013 I would still say: What for! It\u2019s a new folly!\r\n\r\nHe founded himself a guardhouse and safeguard: good for him! But I don\u2019t believe in it.\r\n\r\nWhatever one brings into solitude grows in it, even the inner beast. On this score, solitude is ill-advised for many.\r\n\r\nWas there ever anything filthier on earth than saints of the wilderness? Around them not only hell broke loose \u2013 but pigs too.\r\n\r\n14\r\n\r\nTimid, ashamed, awkward, like a tiger whose leap has failed; thus, you higher men, I often saw you slinking aside. A throw failed you.\r\n\r\nBut what does it matter, you dice throwers! You did not learn to gamble and banter as one should gamble and banter! Are we not always sitting at a great bantering and gaming table?\r\n\r\nAnd when something great failed you, are you yourselves therefore \u2013 failures? And if you yourselves failed, did humanity therefore fail? But if humanity failed: well then, well now!\r\n\r\n15\r\n\r\nThe higher its kind, the more seldom a thing succeeds. You higher men here, haven\u2019t all of you \u2013 failed?\r\n\r\nBe of good cheer, what does it matter! How much is still possible! Learn to laugh at yourselves as one must laugh!\r\n\r\nAnd no wonder that you failed and half succeeded, you half-broken ones! Does humanity\u2019s future not push and shove within you?\r\n\r\nWhat is most distant, deepest, highest to the stars in humanity, its prodigious power: does all that not foam against each other in your pot?\r\n\r\nNo wonder many a pot breaks! Learn to laugh at yourselves as one must laugh! You higher men, oh how much is still possible!\r\n\r\nAnd truly, how much has succeeded already! How rich is this earth in small, good, perfect things, in things that turned out well!\r\n\r\nPlace small, good, perfect things around you, you higher men! Their golden ripeness heals the heart. Perfection teaches us to hope.\r\n\r\n16\r\n\r\nWhat was the greatest sin here on earth until now? Was it not the words of him who spoke: \u201cWoe to you who laugh now!\u201d\r\n\r\nDid he himself find no reasons to laugh on earth? Then he searched badly. Even a child finds reasons here.\r\n\r\nHe \u2013 did not love enough; or else he would have loved us too, we who laugh! But he hated and heckled us, howling and gnashing of teeth he heralded for us.\r\n\r\nMust one curse right away where one does not love? That \u2013 seems to me in bad taste. But that is how he acted, this unconditional one. He came from the rabble.\r\n\r\nAnd he himself just did not love enough; or else he would have been less angry that people did not love him. All great love does not want love \u2013 it wants more.\r\n\r\nGet out of the way of all such unconditional ones! That is a poor sick kind, a rabble kind; they look harshly at this life, they have the evil eye for this earth.\r\n\r\nGet out of the way of all such unconditional ones! They have heavy feet and sultry hearts \u2013 they do not know how to dance. How could the earth be light to them?\r\n\r\n17\r\n\r\nCrookedly all good things approach their goal. Like cats they arch their backs, they purr inwardly with their impending happiness \u2013 all good things laugh.\r\n\r\nA person\u2019s stride betrays whether one is striding on his course: just look at me walk! But whoever approaches his goal dances.\r\n\r\nAnd truly, I have not become a statue, I do not yet stand there stiff, stunned, stony, a column; I love swift running.\r\n\r\nAnd even though there are bogs and thick depressions on earth, who- ever has light feet runs over and past the mud and dances as if on clean- swept ice.\r\n\r\nLift up your hearts, my brothers, high! higher! And don\u2019t forget your legs either! Lift up your legs as well, you good dancers, and better still: stand on your heads too!\r\n\r\n18\r\n\r\nThis crown of the laughing one, this rose-wreath crown \u2013 I myself put on this crown, I myself pronounced my laughter holy. I found no other strong enough for it today.\r\n\r\nZarathustra the dancer, Zarathustra the light one who waves with his wings, the flightworthy, waving to all birds, worthy and ready, a blissful lightweight \u2013\r\n\r\nZarathustra the soothsayer, Zarathustra the soothlaugher, not impatient, not unconditional, someone who loves capers and escapades; I myself put on this crown!\r\n\r\n19\r\n\r\nLift up your hearts, my brothers, high! higher! And don\u2019t forget your legs either! Lift up your legs as well, you good dancers, and better still: stand on your heads too!\r\n\r\nEven in happiness there are heavy creatures, there are born ponderipedes. Quaintly they struggle, like an elephant struggling to stand on its head.\r\n\r\nBut it is better to be foolish with happiness than foolish with unhappiness, better to dance ponderously than to walk lamely. So learn this wisdom from me: even the worst thing has two good reverse sides \u2013\r\n\r\n\u2013 even the worst thing has good legs for dancing: so learn from me, you higher men, to stand yourselves on your right legs!\r\n\r\nSo unlearn moping and all rabble sadness! Oh how sad even today\u2019s rabble clowns seem to me! But this today is of the rabble.\r\n\r\n20\r\n\r\nMake like the wind when he plunges from his mountain caves: he wants to dance to his own pipe, the seas tremble and skip under his footsteps.\r\n\r\nPraised be this good unruly spirit who gives wings to asses and milks the lionesses, who comes upon all that is today and all rabble like a storm wind \u2013\r\n\r\n\u2013 who is hostile to thistle-heads and hair-splitters and all wilted leaves and weeds: praised be this good, free storm spirit, who dances on bogs and depressions as upon meadows!\r\n\r\nWho hates the rabble\u2019s mindless swindlers and all botched gloomy brood: praised be this spirit of all free spirits, the laughing storm who blows dust into the eyes of all fusspots and pus-pots!\r\n\r\nYou higher men, your worst part is that all of you have not learned to dance as one must dance \u2013 dance over and past yourselves! What does it matter that you didn\u2019t turn out well?\r\n\r\nHow much is still possible! So learn to laugh over and past yourselves! Lift up your hearts, you good dancers, high! higher! And don\u2019t forget good laughter either!\r\n\r\nThis crown of the laughing one, this rose-wreath crown: to you, my brothers, I throw this crown! I pronounced laughter holy; you higher men, learn \u2013 to laugh!"}, "id": 90}, {"data": {"uuid": "d6b45c68-7347-444c-a1a1-10995d79c8e5", "user": 1, "title": "The Song of Melancholy", "created_on": "2023-05-10 17:00:28.540205+00:00", "updated_on": "2023-05-10 17:00:28.558726+00:00", "article_html": "<h2>The Song of Melancholy</h2><h3>1</h3><p>As Zarathustra made these speeches he stood close to the entrance of his cave; with the last words, however, he slipped away from his guests and fled for a short while into the open.</p><p>\u201cOh clean fragrance around me,\u201d he cried out, \u201coh blissful stillness around me! But where are my animals? Come here, come here my eagle and my snake!</p><p>Tell me, my animals: these higher men all together \u2013 do they perhaps not smell good? Oh clean fragrances around me! Only now do I know and feel how I love you, my animals.\u201d</p><p>\u2013 And Zarathustra spoke again. \u201cI love you, my animals!\u201d But the eagle and snake pressed up against him as he spoke these words, and they looked up at him. In such a manner the three of them together sniffled and sipped the good air. For the air here outside was better than among the higher men.</p><h3>2</h3><p>But scarcely had Zarathustra left his cave when the old magician stood up, looked around cunningly and said: \u201cHe\u2019s gone out!</p><p>And already, you higher men \u2013 if I may tickle you with this complimentary and flattering name, even as he did \u2013 already my wicked deceiving and magic spirit befalls me, my melancholy devil,</p><p>\u2013 who is an adversary of Zarathustra from the ground up: forgive him! Now he wants to conjure before you, right now is his hour; I wrestle in vain with this evil spirit.</p><p>All of you, whatever honors you may give yourselves with words, whether you call yourselves \u2018the free spirits\u2019 or \u2018the truthful\u2019 or \u2018penitents of the spirit\u2019 or \u2018the unbound\u2019 or \u2018the great longing ones\u2019 \u2013</p><p>\u2013 all of you who suffer from the great nausea like me, for whom the old God died and no new god is lying yet in cradles and crib clothes \u2013 all of you are favored by my evil spirit and magic devil.</p><p>I know you, you higher men, I know him \u2013 I also know this monster whom I love against my will, this Zarathustra: he himself often seems to me like a beautiful mask of a saint,</p><p>\u2013 like a new wondrous masquerade in which my evil spirit, the melancholy devil, enjoys himself \u2013 I love Zarathustra, so it often seems to me, for the sake of my evil spirit. \u2013</p><p>But already he befalls me and forces me, this spirit of melancholy, this evening twilight devil; and truly, you higher men, he is fond \u2013</p><p>\u2013 just open your eyes! \u2013 he is fond of coming naked, whether male or female I do not yet know; but he is coming, he is forcing me, oh no! Open your senses!</p><p>The day is winding down, to all things evening now is coming, even to the best things; listen now and see, you higher men, what kind of devil, whether man or woman, this spirit of evening melancholy is!\u201d</p><p>Thus spoke the old magician, glanced around cunningly and then reached for his harp.</p><h3>3</h3><p>When the air grows dim,<br>When already the dew\u2019s consolation<br>Wells down to earth,<br>Invisible, and unheard \u2013<br>For delicate shoes wears<br>The dewy consoler, like all who mildly console \u2013<br>Do you recall then, do you recall, hot heart,<br>How once you thirsted,<br>For tears from the sky and dribbles of dew,<br>Parched and weary, thirsted<br>While on yellow grass paths<br>Malicious evening sun glances<br>Ran through black trees around you,<br>Blinding sun-ember glances, delighting in your pain?</p><p>\u201cThe wooer of <em>truth</em>? You?\u201d \u2013 thus they mocked \u2013<br>\u201cNo! Mere fool!<br>A beast, a cunning, preying, creeping beast<br>That must lie,<br>That must knowingly, willingly lie:<br>Lusting for prey,<br>Camouflaged,<br>A mask to itself,<br>Prey to itself \u2013<br><em>That</em> \u2013 the wooer of truth?<br>No! Mere fool! Mere poet!<br>Merely speaking colorfully,<br>From fools\u2019 masks shouting colorfully,<br>Climbing around on lying word bridges,<br>On colorful rainbows,<br>Between false skies<br>And false earths,<br>Roaming around, hovering around \u2013<br><em>Mere</em> fool! <em>Mere</em> poet!</p><p><em>That</em> \u2013 the wooer of truth?<br>Not still, stiff, smooth, cold,<br>Turned to statue,<br>To a pillar of God,<br>Not erected before temples,<br>A god\u2019s gatekeeper:<br>No! Hostile to such statues of truth,<br>More at home in any wilderness than before temples,<br>Full of feline mischief,<br>Leaping through every window<br>Swish! into every chance,<br>Sniffing toward every jungle,<br>Greedily, longingly sniffing,<br>So that in jungles<br>Among dappled beasts of prey<br>You could run, sinfully healthy and colorful and beautiful,<br>With lusty lips,<br>Blissfully mocking, blissfully hellish, blissfully bloodthirsty,<br>Run preying, creeping, lying \u2013</p><p>Or, like the eagle that long,<br>Long gazes fixedly into abysses,<br>Into its <em>own</em> abysses \u2013<br>Oh how they wind downward here,<br>Down low, down into,<br>Into ever deeper depths! \u2013<br>Then,<br>Suddenly, straight and tight,<br>You spring to flight,<br>Pounce on lambs,<br>Steeply down, ravenously,<br>Lusting for lambs,<br>Wroth to all lamb souls,<br>Grimly wroth to everything that looks<br>Sheepish, lamb-eyed, curly wooled,<br>Gray, with lamb and sheep benevolence!</p><p>Thus<br>eagle-like, panther-like<br>Are the poet\u2019s longings,<br>Are <em>your</em> longings beneath a thousand masks,<br>You fool! You poet!</p><p>You who viewed mankind<br>As god and sheep \u2013 :<br><em>Tearing</em> to <em>pieces</em> the god in mankind,<br>Like the sheep in mankind,<br>And <em>laughing</em> while tearing \u2013</p><p><em>That</em>, <em>that</em> is your bliss!<br>A panther\u2019s and eagle\u2019s bliss!<br>A poet\u2019s and fool\u2019s bliss!\u201d \u2013</p><p>When the air grows dim,<br>When already the moon\u2019s sickle<br>Creeps along green, between<br>Purple reds, and jealously:<br>\u2013 hostile to day,<br>With every step secretly<br>Scything away at rosy hammocks<br>Until they sink,<br>Sink down into night, sink down, pale \u2013</p><p>Thus I myself once sank<br>From my own truth-madness,<br>From my longings of the day,<br>Weary of the day, sick from light,<br>\u2013 sank downward, eveningward, shadowward:<br>By one truth<br>Burned and thirsty:<br>\u2013 do you still recall, do you recall, hot heart,<br>How you thirsted then? \u2013<br>To be banned<br>From <em>all</em> truth,<br>Mere fool!<br>Mere poet!</p>", "article_json": {"type": "doc", "content": [{"type": "heading", "attrs": {"level": 2}, "content": [{"text": "The Song of Melancholy", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "heading", "attrs": {"level": 3}, "content": [{"text": "1", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "content": [{"text": "As Zarathustra made these speeches he stood close to the entrance of his cave; with the last words, however, he slipped away from his guests and fled for a short while into the open.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "content": [{"text": "\u201cOh clean fragrance around me,\u201d he cried out, \u201coh blissful stillness around me!
