"text"}]}]}, "article_text": "The Song of Melancholy\r\n\r\n1\r\n\r\nAs Zarathustra made these speeches he stood close to the entrance of his cave; with the last words, however, he slipped away from his guests and fled for a short while into the open.\r\n\r\n\u201cOh clean fragrance around me,\u201d he cried out, \u201coh blissful stillness around me! But where are my animals? Come here, come here my eagle and my snake!\r\n\r\nTell me, my animals: these higher men all together \u2013 do they perhaps not smell good? Oh clean fragrances around me! Only now do I know and feel how I love you, my animals.\u201d\r\n\r\n\u2013 And Zarathustra spoke again. \u201cI love you, my animals!\u201d But the eagle and snake pressed up against him as he spoke these words, and they looked up at him. In such a manner the three of them together sniffled and sipped the good air. For the air here outside was better than among the higher men.\r\n\r\n2\r\n\r\nBut scarcely had Zarathustra left his cave when the old magician stood up, looked around cunningly and said: \u201cHe\u2019s gone out!\r\n\r\nAnd already, you higher men \u2013 if I may tickle you with this complimentary and flattering name, even as he did \u2013 already my wicked deceiving and magic spirit befalls me, my melancholy devil,\r\n\r\n\u2013 who is an adversary of Zarathustra from the ground up: forgive him! Now he wants to conjure before you, right now is his hour; I wrestle in vain with this evil spirit.\r\n\r\nAll of you, whatever honors you may give yourselves with words, whether you call yourselves \u2018the free spirits\u2019 or \u2018the truthful\u2019 or \u2018penitents of the spirit\u2019 or \u2018the unbound\u2019 or \u2018the great longing ones\u2019 \u2013\r\n\r\n\u2013 all of you who suffer from the great nausea like me, for whom the old God died and no new god is lying yet in cradles and crib clothes \u2013 all of you are favored by my evil spirit and magic devil.\r\n\r\nI know you, you higher men, I know him \u2013 I also know this monster whom I love against my will, this Zarathustra: he himself often seems to me like a beautiful mask of a saint,\r\n\r\n\u2013 like a new wondrous masquerade in which my evil spirit, the melancholy devil, enjoys himself \u2013 I love Zarathustra, so it often seems to me, for the sake of my evil spirit. \u2013\r\n\r\nBut already he befalls me and forces me, this spirit of melancholy, this evening twilight devil; and truly, you higher men, he is fond \u2013\r\n\r\n\u2013 just open your eyes! \u2013 he is fond of coming naked, whether male or female I do not yet know; but he is coming, he is forcing me, oh no! Open your senses!\r\n\r\nThe day is winding down, to all things evening now is coming, even to the best things; listen now and see, you higher men, what kind of devil, whether man or woman, this spirit of evening melancholy is!\u201d\r\n\r\nThus spoke the old magician, glanced around cunningly and then reached for his harp.\r\n\r\n3\r\n\r\nWhen the air grows dim,\r\nWhen already the dew\u2019s consolation\r\nWells down to earth,\r\nInvisible, and unheard \u2013\r\nFor delicate shoes wears\r\nThe dewy consoler, like all who mildly console \u2013\r\nDo you recall then, do you recall, hot heart,\r\nHow once you thirsted,\r\nFor tears from the sky and dribbles of dew,\r\nParched and weary, thirsted\r\nWhile on yellow grass paths\r\nMalicious evening sun glances\r\nRan through black trees around you,\r\nBlinding sun-ember glances, delighting in your pain?\r\n\r\n\u201cThe wooer of truth? You?\u201d \u2013 thus they mocked \u2013\r\n\u201cNo! Mere fool!\r\nA beast, a cunning, preying, creeping beast\r\nThat must lie,\r\nThat must knowingly, willingly lie:\r\nLusting for prey,\r\nCamouflaged,\r\nA mask to itself,\r\nPrey to itself \u2013\r\nThat \u2013 the wooer of truth?\r\nNo! Mere fool! Mere poet!\r\nMerely speaking colorfully,\r\nFrom fools\u2019 masks shouting colorfully,\r\nClimbing around on lying word bridges,\r\nOn colorful rainbows,\r\nBetween false skies\r\nAnd false earths,\r\nRoaming around, hovering around \u2013\r\nMere fool! Mere poet!\r\n\r\nThat \u2013 the wooer of truth?\r\nNot still, stiff, smooth, cold,\r\nTurned to statue,\r\nTo a pillar of God,\r\nNot erected before temples,\r\nA god\u2019s gatekeeper:\r\nNo! Hostile to such statues of truth,\r\nMore at home in any wilderness than before temples,\r\nFull of feline mischief,\r\nLeaping through every window\r\nSwish! into every chance,\r\nSniffing toward every jungle,\r\nGreedily, longingly sniffing,\r\nSo that in jungles\r\nAmong dappled beasts of prey\r\nYou could run, sinfully healthy and colorful and beautiful,\r\nWith lusty lips,\r\nBlissfully mocking, blissfully hellish, blissfully bloodthirsty,\r\nRun preying, creeping, lying \u2013\r\n\r\nOr, like the eagle that long,\r\nLong gazes fixedly into abysses,\r\nInto its own abysses \u2013\r\nOh how they wind downward here,\r\nDown low, down into,\r\nInto ever deeper depths! \u2013\r\nThen,\r\nSuddenly, straight and tight,\r\nYou spring to flight,\r\nPounce on lambs,\r\nSteeply down, ravenously,\r\nLusting for lambs,\r\nWroth to all lamb souls,\r\nGrimly wroth to everything that looks\r\nSheepish, lamb-eyed, curly wooled,\r\nGray, with lamb and sheep benevolence!\r\n\r\nThus\r\neagle-like, panther-like\r\nAre the poet\u2019s longings,\r\nAre your longings beneath a thousand masks,\r\nYou fool! You poet!\r\n\r\nYou who viewed mankind\r\nAs god and sheep \u2013 :\r\nTearing to pieces the god in mankind,\r\nLike the sheep in mankind,\r\nAnd laughing while tearing \u2013\r\n\r\nThat, that is your bliss!\r\nA panther\u2019s and eagle\u2019s bliss!\r\nA poet\u2019s and fool\u2019s bliss!\u201d \u2013\r\n\r\nWhen the air grows dim,\r\nWhen already the moon\u2019s sickle\r\nCreeps along green, between\r\nPurple reds, and jealously:\r\n\u2013 hostile to day,\r\nWith every step secretly\r\nScything away at rosy hammocks\r\nUntil they sink,\r\nSink down into night, sink down, pale \u2013\r\n\r\nThus I myself once sank\r\nFrom my own truth-madness,\r\nFrom my longings of the day,\r\nWeary of the day, sick from light,\r\n\u2013 sank downward, eveningward, shadowward:\r\nBy one truth\r\nBurned and thirsty:\r\n\u2013 do you still recall, do you recall, hot heart,\r\nHow you thirsted then? \u2013\r\nTo be banned\r\nFrom all truth,\r\nMere fool!\r\nMere poet!"}, "id": 91}, {"data": {"uuid": "0f9df103-aa0f-49ae-ac91-7506061b6ff1", "user": 1, "title": "On Science", "created_on": "2023-05-10 17:01:14.586599+00:00", "updated_on": "2023-05-10 17:01:14.605977+00:00", "article_html": "<h2>On Science</h2><p>Thus sang the magician; and all who were together went unwittingly, like birds, into the net of his cunning and melancholy rapture. Only the conscientious of spirit was not captured; he snatched the harp away from the magician and cried: \u201cAir! Let in the good air! Let Zarathustra in! You make this cave sultry and poisonous, you wicked old magician!</p><p>You seduce us, you faker, you fine one, to unknown desires and wildernesses. And watch out when such as you start making speeches and fuss about truth!</p><p>Woe to all free spirits who are not on their guard for such magicians! Their freedom is done for: you teach and tempt us back into prisons \u2013</p><p>\u2013 you old melancholy devil, out of your lament rings a bird call; you resemble those who secretly incite sexual desires with their praise of chastity!\u201d</p><p>Thus spoke the conscientious one; but the old magician looked around, enjoyed his triumph, and for its sake swallowed the annoyance that the conscientious one caused him. \u201cBe quiet!\u201d he said with a modest voice. \u201cGood songs want to reverberate well; one should remain silent for a long time after good songs.</p><p>That is what all these do, the higher men. But you perhaps have under- stood little of my song? In you there is little of a magic spirit.\u201d</p><p>\u201cYou praise me,\u201d retorted the conscientious one. \u201cIn so far as you distinguish me from yourself, well good! But you others, what do I see here? You\u2019re all still sitting there with lusting eyes \u2013</p><p>You free souls, where is your freedom now? Almost, it seems to me, you resemble those who have long watched wicked, dancing naked girls: your very souls are dancing!</p><p>In you, you higher men, there must be more of that which the magician calls his evil magic and deceiving spirit \u2013 we must surely be very different.</p><p>And truly, we spoke and thought enough together, before Zarathustra came home to his cave, to let me know that we are different.</p><p>We are seeking something different up here too, you and I. I for one am seeking more security, that is why I came to Zarathustra. For he is still the most solid tower and will \u2013</p><p>\u2013 today, when everything is wobbling, when the whole earth is quaking. But you, when I look at the eyes that you make, it almost seems to me you are seeking more insecurity,</p><p>\u2013 more thrills, more danger, more earthquakes. What you are fond of, I almost suppose, but forgive my posing, you higher men \u2013</p><p>\u2013 what you are fond of is the worst, most dangerous life, the one that frightens me the most; the life of wild animals, woods, caves, steep mountains and labyrinthine gorges.</p><p>And not the leaders away from danger do you like best, but instead those who lead you astray from all paths, the seducers. But, if such fondness is real in you, then it seems to me impossible nonetheless.</p><p>Fear, after all \u2013 that is a human being\u2019s original and basic feeling; from fear everything can be explained, original sin and original virtue. From fear my virtue also grew, it is called: science.</p><p>For the fear of wild animals \u2013 it was bred longest in human beings, including the animal that he conceals within himself and fears \u2013 Zarathustra calls it \u2018the inner beast.\u2019</p><p>Such a long old fear, refined at last, made spiritual, intellectual \u2013 today, it seems to me, it is called: science.\u201d \u2013</p><p>Thus spoke the conscientious one; but Zarathustra, who had just returned to his cave and heard and guessed the last speech, tossed a hand full of roses to the conscientious one and laughed at his \u201ctruths.\u201d \u201cWhat!\u201d he cried. \u201cWhat did I hear just now? Truly, it seems to me, you are a fool or I myself am one; and your \u2018truth\u2019 I stand wham-bam on its head.</p><p>Fear you see \u2013 is our exception. But courage and adventure and pleasure in uncertainty, in what is undared \u2013 courage seems to me humanity\u2019s whole prehistory.</p><p>He envied and robbed the wildest, most courageous animals of all their virtues: only thus did he become \u2013 human.</p><p>This courage, refined at last, made spiritual, intellectual, this human courage with eagle\u2019s wings and snake\u2019s cleverness: it, it seems to me, today is called \u2013 \u201d</p><p>\u201cZarathustra!\u201d cried everyone sitting together, as if with one mouth, and they raised a great laughter then, and it rose from them like a heavy cloud. Even the magician laughed and said cleverly: \u201cWell then, he\u2019s gone, my evil spirit!</p><p>And did I myself not warn you about him when I said that he was a deceiver and a cheat- and deceit spirit?</p><p>Especially, you see, when he shows himself naked. But what can I do about his tricks! Did I create him and the world?</p><p>Well then! Let\u2019s be good again and be cheerful! And even though Zarathustra looks angry \u2013 just look at him, he grudges me \u2013</p><p>\u2013 before night comes he will learn again to love and laud me, he cannot live long without committing such follies.</p><p>He \u2013 loves his enemies: this art he understands best of all whom I have seen. But he takes revenge for it \u2013 on his friends!\u201d</p><p>Thus spoke the old magician, and the higher men applauded him, such that Zarathustra went around and shook the hands of his friends with malice and love \u2013 like someone who has to make up for something and apologize to everyone. But when in doing so he reached the door of his cave, then once again he had a craving for the good air outside and for his animals \u2013 and he wanted to slip out.</p>", "article_json": {"type": "doc", "content": [{"type": "heading", "attrs": {"level": 2}, "content": [{"text": "On Science", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "content": [{"text": "Thus sang the magician; and all who were together went unwittingly, like birds, into the net of his cunning and melancholy rapture. Only the conscientious of spirit was not captured; he snatched the harp away from the magician and cried: \u201cAir! Let in the good air! Let Zarathustra in! You make this cave sultry and poisonous, you wicked old magician!\r\n\r\nYou seduce us, you faker, you fine one, to unknown desires and wildernesses. And watch out when such as you start making speeches and fuss about truth!\r\n\r\nWoe to all free spirits who are not on their guard for such magicians! Their freedom is done for: you teach and tempt us back into prisons \u2013\r\n\r\n\u2013 you old melancholy devil, out of your lament rings a bird call; you resemble those who secretly incite sexual desires with their praise of chastity!\u201d\r\n\r\nThus spoke the conscientious one; but the old magician looked around, enjoyed his triumph, and for its sake swallowed the annoyance that the conscientious one caused him. \u201cBe quiet!\u201d he said with a modest voice. \u201cGood songs want to reverberate well; one should remain silent for a long time after good songs.\r\n\r\nThat is what all these do, the higher men. But you perhaps have under- stood little of my song? In you there is little of a magic spirit.\u201d\r\n\r\n\u201cYou praise me,\u201d retorted the conscientious one. \u201cIn so far as you distinguish me from yourself, well good! But you others, what do I see here? You\u2019re all still sitting there with lusting eyes \u2013\r\n\r\nYou free souls, where is your freedom now? Almost, it seems to me, you resemble those who have long watched wicked, dancing naked girls: your very souls are dancing!\r\n\r\nIn you, you higher men, there must be more of that which the magician calls his evil magic and deceiving spirit \u2013 we must surely be very different.\r\n\r\nAnd truly, we spoke and thought enough together, before Zarathustra came home to his cave, to let me know that we are different.\r\n\r\nWe are seeking something different up here too, you and I. I for one am seeking more security, that is why I came to Zarathustra. For he is still the most solid tower and will \u2013\r\n\r\n\u2013 today, when everything is wobbling, when the whole earth is quaking. But you, when I look at the eyes that you make, it almost seems to me you are seeking more insecurity,\r\n\r\n\u2013 more thrills, more danger, more earthquakes. What you are fond of, I almost suppose, but forgive my posing, you higher men \u2013\r\n\r\n\u2013 what you are fond of is the worst, most dangerous life, the one that frightens me the most; the life of wild animals, woods, caves, steep mountains and labyrinthine gorges.\r\n\r\nAnd not the leaders away from danger do you like best, but instead those who lead you astray from all paths, the seducers. But, if such fondness is real in you, then it seems to me impossible nonetheless.\r\n\r\nFear, after all \u2013 that is a human being\u2019s original and basic feeling; from fear everything can be explained, original sin and original virtue. From fear my virtue also grew, it is called: science.\r\n\r\nFor the fear of wild animals \u2013 it was bred longest in human beings, including the animal that he conceals within himself and fears \u2013 Zarathustra calls it \u2018the inner beast.\u2019\r\n\r\nSuch a long old fear, refined at last, made spiritual, intellectual \u2013 today, it seems to me, it is called: science.\u201d \u2013\r\n\r\nThus spoke the conscientious one; but Zarathustra, who had just returned to his cave and heard and guessed the last speech, tossed a hand full of roses to the conscientious one and laughed at his \u201ctruths.\u201d \u201cWhat!\u201d he cried. \u201cWhat did I hear just now? Truly, it seems to me, you are a fool or I myself am one; and your \u2018truth\u2019 I stand wham-bam on its head.\r\n\r\nFear you see \u2013 is our exception. But courage and adventure and pleasure in uncertainty, in what is undared \u2013 courage seems to me humanity\u2019s whole prehistory.\r\n\r\nHe envied and robbed the wildest, most courageous animals of all their virtues: only thus did he become \u2013 human.\r\n\r\nThis courage, refined at last, made spiritual, intellectual, this human courage with eagle\u2019s wings and snake\u2019s cleverness: it, it seems to me, today is called \u2013 \u201d\r\n\r\n\u201cZarathustra!\u201d cried everyone sitting together, as if with one mouth, and they raised a great laughter then, and it rose from them like a heavy cloud. Even the magician laughed and said cleverly: \u201cWell then, he\u2019s gone, my evil spirit!\r\n\r\nAnd did I myself not warn you about him when I said that he was a deceiver and a cheat- and deceit spirit?\r\n\r\nEspecially, you see, when he shows himself naked. But what can I do about his tricks! Did I create him and the world?\r\n\r\nWell then! Let\u2019s be good again and be cheerful! And even though Zarathustra looks angry \u2013 just look at him, he grudges me \u2013\r\n\r\n\u2013 before night comes he will learn again to love and laud me, he cannot live long without committing such follies.\r\n\r\nHe \u2013 loves his enemies: this art he understands best of all whom I have seen. But he takes revenge for it \u2013 on his friends!\u201d\r\n\r\nThus spoke the old magician, and the higher men applauded him, such that Zarathustra went around and shook the hands of his friends with malice and love \u2013 like someone who has to make up for something and apologize to everyone. But when in doing so he reached the door of his cave, then once again he had a craving for the good air outside and for his animals \u2013 and he wanted to slip out."}, "id": 92}, {"data": {"uuid": "3ab17cb3-ac2f-43af-987c-252b78601022", "user": 1, "title": "Among Daughters of the Desert", "created_on": "2023-05-10 17:02:02.228810+00:00", "updated_on": "2023-05-10 17:02:02.253005+00:00", "article_html": "<h2>Among Daughters of the Desert</h2><h3>1</h3><p>\u201cDo not go away!\u201d said the wanderer who called himself the shadow of Zarathustra. \u201cStay with us, or else our old dull depression could befall us again.</p><p>Already that old magician has regaled us with his worst, and just look, the good pious pope there has tears in his eyes and once again he\u2019s completely shipped out on the sea of melancholy.</p><p>These kings may well put on a good face before us; of all of us today they learned that best after all! But if they did not have witnesses, I bet that the evil game would begin again with them too \u2013</p><p>\u2013 the evil game of drifting clouds, of damp melancholy, of veiled skies, of stolen suns, of howling autumn winds,</p><p>\u2013 the evil game of our howling and crying in distress; stay with us, oh Zarathustra! Here there is much hidden misery that wants to speak, much evening, much cloud, much musty air!</p><p>You nourished us with strong, manly fare and strong sayings: do not permit the wimpy womanish spirits to befall us again for dessert!</p><p>You alone make the air around you strong and clear! Have I ever on earth found such good air as here with you in your cave?</p><p>Many lands indeed have I seen, my nose learned to test and assess many kinds of air; but in your cave my nostrils taste their greatest treat!</p><p>Unless \u2013 unless \u2013 oh forgive an old memory! Forgive me an old dessert song that I once composed among daughters of the desert \u2013</p><p>\u2013 for among them there was likewise good, bright, oriental air; there I was furthest from cloudy, damp, melancholy old Europe!</p><p>Back then I loved such Oriental girls and a different blue sky, over which no clouds and no thoughts hang.</p><p>You wouldn\u2019t believe how decently they sat there when they weren\u2019t dancing; deep, but without thoughts, like little secrets, like beribboned riddles, like dessert nuts \u2013</p><p>colorful and foreign to be sure! but without clouds; riddles that can be guessed: as a favor to such girls I then thought up a dessert psalm.\u201d</p><p>Thus spoke the wanderer and shadow; and before anyone answered him, he had already grasped the old magician\u2019s harp, crossed his legs and looked around dignified and wisely; but with his nostrils he slowly and questioningly inhaled the air like someone in new lands who savors the new, strange air. Then he began to sing with a kind of roaring voice.</p><h3>2</h3><p><em>The desert grows: woe to him who harbors deserts!</em></p><p>\u2013 Ha! Solemn!<br>Indeed solemn!<br>A worthy beginning!<br>African solemn!<br>Worthy of a lion,<br>Or of a moral howling monkey \u2013<br>\u2013 but nothing for you,<br>My most lovely lady friends,<br>At whose feet I,<br>For the first time,<br>A European among palm trees,<br>Am permitted to sit. Selah.</p><p>Wonderful truly!<br>Here I sit now,<br>Near the desert and already<br>So distant again from the desert,<br>Even in this nothingness ravaged:<br>Namely swallowed<br>By this smallest oasis \u2013<br>\u2013 it just now yawned wide open<br>Its lovely mouth.<br>The most fragrant of all little mouths:<br>Then I fell in,<br>Down, down through \u2013 among you,<br>My most lovely lady friends! Selah.</p><p>Hail, hail to that whale<br>If he thus let his guest<br>Be comfortable! \u2013 you understand<br>My learned allusion?<br>Hail to his belly<br>If it was thus<br>Such a lovely oasis belly,<br>Like this one: which I doubt, however,<br>\u2013 that\u2019s why I come from Europe,<br>Which is more doubt ridden than all<br>Elderly married women.<br>May God improve it!<br>Amen!</p><p>Here I sit now,<br>In this smallest oasis,<br>Like a date,<br>Brown, sweetened through, oozing gold, lusting<br>For a rounded maiden\u2019s mouth,<br>But even more for maidenly<br>Ice-cold snowy-white incisor<br>Front teeth: for these, after all,<br>Languish the hearts of all hot dates. Selah.</p><p>To the aforementioned southerly fruits<br>Similar, all too similar<br>I lie here, little<br>Winged bugs<br>Dancing and playing around me,<br>Likewise even smaller<br>More foolish malicious<br>Wishes and fantasies \u2013<br>Besieged by you,<br>You silent, you foreboding<br>She-cats,<br>Dudu and Suleika,<br>\u2013 <em>besphinxed</em>, to stuff much feeling<br>Into a single word:<br>(Forgive me God<br>This sin of language!)<br>\u2013 I sit here, sniffing the best air,<br>Paradise air truly,<br>Bright light air, streaked with gold,<br>Air as good as ever<br>Fell down from the moon \u2013<br>Whether by chance,<br>Or did it happen from mischief,<br>As the ancient poets tell?<br>I the doubter, however,<br>Doubt it; that\u2019s why I come<br>From Europe,<br>Which is more doubt ridden than all<br>Elderly married women.<br>May God improve it!<br>Amen!</p><p>Drinking this most beautiful air,<br>With nostrils swollen like cups,<br>Without future, without memories,<br>Thus I sit here, my<br>Most lovely lady friends,<br>And watch the palm tree<br>As she, like a dancer,<br>Sways and dips and swivels her hips,<br>\u2013 one does it too if one watches too long!<br>Like a dancer who, it seems to me,<br>Already too long, dangerously long<br>Always, always stood on one foot only?<br>\u2013 which is why she forgot, it seems to me,<br>The other leg?<br>In vain, at least<br>I looked for the missing<br>Twin jewel<br>\u2013 namely the other leg \u2013<br>In the holy proximity<br>Of her most lovely, most delicate<br>Little fan and flutter and flitter tinsel skirt.<br>Indeed, my beautiful lady friends, if you would<br>Believe me entirely:<br>She\u2019s lost it!<br>It\u2019s gone!<br>Forever gone!<br>The other leg!<br>Oh what a shame about this other lovely leg!<br>Where \u2013 might it while and grieve forlorn?<br>The lonely leg?<br>In fear perhaps of a<br>Grim golden blond-locked<br>Lion monster? Or perhaps even<br>Gnawed off, nibbled away \u2013<br>Miserable, oh no! oh no! Nibbled away. Selah.</p><p>Oh do not weep,<br>Soft hearts!<br>Do not weep, you<br>Date hearts! Milk bosoms!<br>You licorice-heart<br>Little pouches!<br>Weep no more,<br>Pale Dudu!<br>Be a man, Suleika! Courage! Courage!<br>\u2013 Or is perhaps<br>Something fortifying, heart-fortifying<br>Called for here?<br>An anointed saying?<br>A solemn exhortation? \u2013</p><p>Ha! Up now, dignity!<br>Blow, blow again,<br>Bellows of virtue!<br>Ha!<br>Roar once more,<br>Roar morally!<br>As a moral lion<br>Before daughters of the desert, roar!<br>\u2013 For the howling of virtue,<br>My most lovely lady friends,<br>Is more than all<br>European fervor, European voraciousness!<br>And here I stand already,<br>As a European,<br>I cannot do otherwise, God help me!<br>Amen!</p><p><em>The desert grows: woe to him who harbors deserts!</em></p>", "article_json": {"type": "doc", "content": [{"type": "heading", "attrs": {"level": 2}, "content": [{"text": "Among Daughters of the Desert", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "heading", "attrs": {"level": 3}, "content": [{"text": "1", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "content": [{"text": "\u201cDo not go away!\u201d said the wanderer who called himself the shadow of Zarathustra. \u201cStay with us, or else our old dull depression could befall us again.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "content": [{"text": "Already that old magician has regaled us with his worst, and just look, the good pious pope there has tears in his eyes and once again he\u2019s completely shipped out on the sea of melancholy.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "content": [{"text": "These kings may well put on a good face before us; of all of us today they learned that best after all! But if they did not have witnesses, I bet that the evil game would begin again with them too \u2013\r\n\r\n\u2013 the evil game of drifting clouds, of damp melancholy, of veiled skies, of stolen suns, of howling autumn winds,\r\n\r\n\u2013 the evil game of our howling and crying in distress; stay with us, oh Zarathustra! Here there is much hidden misery that wants to speak, much evening, much cloud, much musty air!\r\n\r\nYou nourished us with strong, manly fare and strong sayings: do not permit the wimpy womanish spirits to befall us again for dessert!\r\n\r\nYou alone make the air around you strong and clear! Have I ever on earth found such good air as here with you in your cave?\r\n\r\nMany lands indeed have I seen, my nose learned to test and assess many kinds of air; but in your cave my nostrils taste their greatest treat!\r\n\r\nUnless \u2013 unless \u2013 oh forgive an old memory! Forgive me an old dessert song that I once composed among daughters of the desert \u2013\r\n\r\n\u2013 for among them there was likewise good, bright, oriental air; there I was furthest from cloudy, damp, melancholy old Europe!\r\n\r\nBack then I loved such Oriental girls and a different blue sky, over which no clouds and no thoughts hang.\r\n\r\nYou wouldn\u2019t believe how decently they sat there when they weren\u2019t dancing; deep, but without thoughts, like little secrets, like beribboned riddles, like dessert nuts \u2013\r\n\r\ncolorful and foreign to be sure! but without clouds; riddles that can be guessed: as a favor to such girls I then thought up a dessert psalm.\u201d\r\n\r\nThus spoke the wanderer and shadow; and before anyone answered him, he had already grasped the old magician\u2019s harp, crossed his legs and looked around dignified and wisely; but with his nostrils he slowly and questioningly inhaled the air like someone in new lands who savors the new, strange air. Then he began to sing with a kind of roaring voice.\r\n\r\n2\r\n\r\nThe desert grows: woe to him who harbors deserts!\r\n\r\n\u2013 Ha! Solemn!\r\nIndeed solemn!\r\nA worthy beginning!\r\nAfrican solemn!\r\nWorthy of a lion,\r\nOr of a moral howling monkey \u2013\r\n\u2013 but nothing for you,\r\nMy most lovely lady friends,\r\nAt whose feet I,\r\nFor the first time,\r\nA European among palm trees,\r\nAm permitted to sit. Selah.\r\n\r\nWonderful truly!\r\nHere I sit now,\r\nNear the desert and already\r\nSo distant again from the desert,\r\nEven in this nothingness ravaged:\r\nNamely swallowed\r\nBy this smallest oasis \u2013\r\n\u2013 it just now yawned wide open\r\nIts lovely mouth.\r\nThe most fragrant of all little mouths:\r\nThen I fell in,\r\nDown, down through \u2013 among you,\r\nMy most lovely lady friends! Selah.\r\n\r\nHail, hail to that whale\r\nIf he thus let his guest\r\nBe comfortable! \u2013 you understand\r\nMy learned allusion?\r\nHail to his belly\r\nIf it was thus\r\nSuch a lovely oasis belly,\r\nLike this one: which I doubt, however,\r\n\u2013 that\u2019s why I come from Europe,\r\nWhich is more doubt ridden than all\r\nElderly married women.\r\nMay God improve it!\r\nAmen!\r\n\r\nHere I sit now,\r\nIn this smallest oasis,\r\nLike a date,\r\nBrown, sweetened through, oozing gold, lusting\r\nFor a rounded maiden\u2019s mouth,\r\nBut even more for maidenly\r\nIce-cold snowy-white incisor\r\nFront teeth: for these, after all,\r\nLanguish the hearts of all hot dates. Selah.\r\n\r\nTo the aforementioned southerly fruits\r\nSimilar, all too similar\r\nI lie here, little\r\nWinged bugs\r\nDancing and playing around me,\r\nLikewise even smaller\r\nMore foolish malicious\r\nWishes and fantasies \u2013\r\nBesieged by you,\r\nYou silent, you foreboding\r\nShe-cats,\r\nDudu and Suleika,\r\n\u2013 besphinxed, to stuff much feeling\r\nInto a single word:\r\n(Forgive me God\r\nThis sin of language!)\r\n\u2013 I sit here, sniffing the best air,\r\nParadise air truly,\r\nBright light air, streaked with gold,\r\nAir as good as ever\r\nFell down from the moon \u2013\r\nWhether by chance,\r\nOr did it happen from mischief,\r\nAs the ancient poets tell?\r\nI the doubter, however,\r\nDoubt it; that\u2019s why I come\r\nFrom Europe,\r\nWhich is more doubt ridden than all\r\nElderly married women.\r\nMay God improve it!\r\nAmen!\r\n\r\nDrinking this most beautiful air,\r\nWith nostrils swollen like cups,\r\nWithout future, without memories,\r\nThus I sit here, my\r\nMost lovely lady friends,\r\nAnd watch the palm tree\r\nAs she, like a dancer,\r\nSways and dips and swivels her hips,\r\n\u2013 one does it too if one watches too long!\r\nLike a dancer who, it seems to me,\r\nAlready too long, dangerously long\r\nAlways, always stood on one foot only?\r\n\u2013 which is why she forgot, it seems to me,\r\nThe other leg?\r\nIn vain, at least\r\nI looked for the missing\r\nTwin jewel\r\n\u2013 namely the other leg \u2013\r\nIn the holy proximity\r\nOf her most lovely, most delicate\r\nLittle fan and flutter and flitter tinsel skirt.\r\nIndeed, my beautiful lady friends, if you would\r\nBelieve me entirely:\r\nShe\u2019s lost it!\r\nIt\u2019s gone!\r\nForever gone!\r\nThe other leg!\r\nOh what a shame about this other lovely leg!\r\nWhere \u2013 might it while and grieve forlorn?\r\nThe lonely leg?\r\nIn fear perhaps of a\r\nGrim golden blond-locked\r\nLion monster? Or perhaps even\r\nGnawed off, nibbled away \u2013\r\nMiserable, oh no! oh no! Nibbled away. Selah.\r\n\r\nOh do not weep,\r\nSoft hearts!\r\nDo not weep, you\r\nDate hearts! Milk bosoms!\r\nYou licorice-heart\r\nLittle pouches!\r\nWeep no more,\r\nPale Dudu!\r\nBe a man, Suleika! Courage! Courage!\r\n\u2013 Or is perhaps\r\nSomething fortifying, heart-fortifying\r\nCalled for here?\r\nAn anointed saying?\r\nA solemn exhortation? \u2013\r\n\r\nHa! Up now, dignity!\r\nBlow, blow again,\r\nBellows of virtue!\r\nHa!\r\nRoar once more,\r\nRoar morally!\r\nAs a moral lion\r\nBefore daughters of the desert, roar!\r\n\u2013 For the howling of virtue,\r\nMy most lovely lady friends,\r\nIs more than all\r\nEuropean fervor, European voraciousness!\r\nAnd here I stand already,\r\nAs a European,\r\nI cannot do otherwise, God help me!\r\nAmen!\r\n\r\nThe desert grows: woe to him who harbors deserts!"}, "id": 93}, {"data": {"uuid": "a63cedfc-addc-4a02-8618-9c9ccf55bfff", "user": 1, "title": "The Awakening", "created_on": "2023-05-10 17:02:43.728697+00:00", "updated_on": "2023-05-10 17:02:43.755331+00:00", "article_html": "<h2>The Awakening</h2><h3>1</h3><p>After the song of the wanderer and shadow all at once the cave became full of noise and laughter; and because the assembled guests all spoke at the same time, and even the ass no longer kept quiet amidst such encouragement, Zarathustra was overcome by a slight aversion and a bit of scorn for his visitors, even though he was glad for their cheerfulness. This, it seemed to him, was a sign of their convalescence. And so he slipped out into the open and spoke to his animals.</p><p>\u201cWhere is their distress now?\u201d he said, and already he himself was relieved of his minor annoyance. \u201cIn my company, it seems to me, they have unlearned their crying in distress!</p><p>\u2013 Though unfortunately, not their crying.\u201d And Zarathustra covered his ears, for just then the hee-yaw of the ass blended oddly with the noisy jubilation of these higher men.</p><p>\u201cThey\u2019re having fun,\u201d he began again, \u201cand who knows? Perhaps at the expense of their host; and if they learned to laugh from me, then still it is not my laughing that they learned.</p><p>But what does it matter? They\u2019re old people; they convalesce in their way, they laugh in their way: my ears have endured worse already without becoming testy.</p><p>This day is a triumph; he is already retreating, he\u2019s fleeing, the spirit of gravity, my old arch-enemy! How well this day wants to end, which began so badly and so hard!</p><p>And it wants to end. Already evening is coming; over the sea he rides, this good rider! How he sways, the blissful, homecoming one, in his purple saddle!</p><p>The sky looks on clearly, the world lies deep; oh all you strange people who came to me, it\u2019s worth it indeed to live with me!\u201d</p><p>Thus spoke Zarathustra. And again the cries and laughter of the higher men came from the cave, so he began again.</p><p>\u201cThey are biting, my bait is working, their enemy is retreating from them too, the spirit of gravity. Already they\u2019re learning to laugh at themselves: do I hear correctly?</p><p>My manly fare is working, my vim and vigor sayings; and truly, I did not nourish them with gassy vegetables! But with warrior fare, with conqueror fare \u2013 I awakened new desires in them.</p><p>New hopes live in their arms and legs, their hearts expand. They are finding new words, soon their spirit will breathe mischief.</p><p>Such fare may not be for children, to be sure, nor for longing little women, old and young; their entrails are persuaded differently, their physician and teacher I am not.</p><p>Nausea retreats from these higher men \u2013 well then! That is my victory. In my kingdom they\u2019re becoming secure, all their stupid shame runs away, they\u2019re pouring themselves out.</p><p>They\u2019re pouring out their hearts, good hours are returning to them, they celebrate and ruminate \u2013 they\u2019re becoming grateful.</p><p>That I take as the best sign; they\u2019re becoming grateful. It won\u2019t be long now and they will invent festivals and erect monuments to their old joys.</p><p>They are convalescing!\u201d Thus spoke Zarathustra gaily to his heart and he gazed outward; but his animals pressed up against him and honored his happiness and his silence.</p><h3>2</h3><p>Suddenly, however, Zarathustra\u2019s ears were startled; for the cave which up till now had been full of noise and laughter became deathly still all at once \u2013 but his nose sensed an aromatic smoke and incense, as of burning pine cones.</p><p>\u201cWhat is happening? What are they doing?\u201d he asked himself and crept closer to the entrance, in order to watch his guests surreptitiously. But, wonder of wonders! What did he have to behold with his own eyes?</p><p>\u201cThey\u2019ve all gone pious again, they\u2019re praying, they\u2019re mad!\u201d \u2013 he said and he was amazed beyond measure. And, in truth, all these higher men, the two kings, the retired pope, the wicked magician, the voluntary beggar, the wanderer and his shadow, the old soothsayer, the conscientious of spirit and the ugliest human being \u2013 they all kneeled there like children and devout little old women, and they worshiped the ass. And just then the ugliest human being began to gurgle and snort as though something unspeakable wanted to get out of him; but when he actually put it into words, behold, it was a pious, remarkable litany praising the worshiped and censed ass. This litany, however, sounded thus:</p><p>Amen! And praise and honor and wisdom and thanks and glory and strength be to our god, from everlasting to everlasting!</p><p>\u2013 But to this the ass brayed Hee-yaw.</p><p>He carries our burden, he adopted the form of a servant, he is patient from the heart and never says No; and whoever loves his god, chastises him.</p><p>\u2013 But to this the ass brayed Hee-yaw.</p><p>He does not speak, unless it be to say Yaw to the world that he created; thus he praises his world. It is his slyness that does not speak; this way he is rarely found to be wrong.</p><p>\u2013 But to this the ass brayed Hee-yaw.</p><p>Homely he walks through the world. Gray is the body color in which he cloaks his virtue. If he has spirit, then he conceals it; but everyone believes in his long ears.</p><p>\u2013 But to this the ass brayed Hee-yaw.</p><p>What hidden wisdom is it, that he has long ears and always says Yaw and never No! Has he not created the world in his image, namely as stupid as possible?</p><p>\u2013 But to this the ass brayed Hee-yaw.</p><p>You walk ways that are straight and crooked; it matters little to you what seems straight or crooked to us human beings. Your kingdom is beyond good and evil. It is your innocence not to know what innocence is.</p><p>\u2013 But to this the ass brayed Hee-yaw.</p><p>See now, how you push no one away, not the beggars, not the kings. The little children you let come to you, and when the mean boys bait you, then you simplemindedly say Hee-yaw.</p><p>\u2013 But to this the ass brayed Hee-yaw.</p><p>You love she-asses and fresh figs, you are no picky eater. A thistle tickles your heart if you happen to be hungry. Therein lies the wisdom of a god.</p><p>\u2013 But to this the ass brayed Hee-yaw.</p>", "article_json": {"type": "doc", "content": [{"type": "heading", "attrs": {"level": 2}, "content": [{"text": "The Awakening", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "heading", "attrs": {"level": 3}, "content": [{"text": "1", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "content": [{"text": "After the song of the wanderer and shadow all at once the cave became full of noise and laughter; and because the assembled guests all spoke at the same time, and even the ass no longer kept quiet amidst such encouragement, Zarathustra was overcome by a slight aversion and a bit of scorn for his visitors, even though he was glad for their cheerfulness. This, it seemed to him, was a sign of their convalescence. And so he slipped out into the open and spoke to his animals.\r\n\r\n\u201cWhere is their distress now?\u201d he said, and already he himself was relieved of his minor annoyance. \u201cIn my company, it seems to me, they have unlearned their crying in distress!\r\n\r\n\u2013 Though unfortunately, not their crying.\u201d And Zarathustra covered his ears, for just then the hee-yaw of the ass blended oddly with the noisy jubilation of these higher men.\r\n\r\n\u201cThey\u2019re having fun,\u201d he began again, \u201cand who knows? Perhaps at the expense of their host; and if they learned to laugh from me, then still it is not my laughing that they learned.\r\n\r\nBut what does it matter? They\u2019re old people; they convalesce in their way, they laugh in their way: my ears have endured worse already without becoming testy.\r\n\r\nThis day is a triumph; he is already retreating, he\u2019s fleeing, the spirit of gravity, my old arch-enemy! How well this day wants to end, which began so badly and so hard!\r\n\r\nAnd it wants to end. Already evening is coming; over the sea he rides, this good rider! How he sways, the blissful, homecoming one, in his purple saddle!\r\n\r\nThe sky looks on clearly, the world lies deep; oh all you strange people who came to me, it\u2019s worth it indeed to live with me!\u201d\r\n\r\nThus spoke Zarathustra. And again the cries and laughter of the higher men came from the cave, so he began again.\r\n\r\n\u201cThey are biting, my bait is working, their enemy is retreating from them too, the spirit of gravity. Already they\u2019re learning to laugh at themselves: do I hear correctly?\r\n\r\nMy manly fare is working, my vim and vigor sayings; and truly, I did not nourish them with gassy vegetables! But with warrior fare, with conqueror fare \u2013 I awakened new desires in them.\r\n\r\nNew hopes live in their arms and legs, their hearts expand. They are finding new words, soon their spirit will breathe mischief.\r\n\r\nSuch fare may not be for children, to be sure, nor for longing little women, old and young; their entrails are persuaded differently, their physician and teacher I am not.\r\n\r\nNausea retreats from these higher men \u2013 well then! That is my victory. In my kingdom they\u2019re becoming secure, all their stupid shame runs away, they\u2019re pouring themselves out.\r\n\r\nThey\u2019re pouring out their hearts, good hours are returning to them, they celebrate and ruminate \u2013 they\u2019re becoming grateful.\r\n\r\nThat I take as the best sign; they\u2019re becoming grateful. It won\u2019t be long now and they will invent festivals and erect monuments to their old joys.\r\n\r\nThey are convalescing!\u201d Thus spoke Zarathustra gaily to his heart and he gazed outward; but his animals pressed up against him and honored his happiness and his silence.\r\n\r\n2\r\n\r\nSuddenly, however, Zarathustra\u2019s ears were startled; for the cave which up till now had been full of noise and laughter became deathly still all at once \u2013 but his nose sensed an aromatic smoke and incense, as of burning pine cones.\r\n\r\n\u201cWhat is happening? What are they doing?\u201d he asked himself and crept closer to the entrance, in order to watch his guests surreptitiously. But, wonder of wonders! What did he have to behold with his own eyes?\r\n\r\n\u201cThey\u2019ve all gone pious again, they\u2019re praying, they\u2019re mad!\u201d \u2013 he said and he was amazed beyond measure. And, in truth, all these higher men, the two kings, the retired pope, the wicked magician, the voluntary beggar, the wanderer and his shadow, the old soothsayer, the conscientious of spirit and the ugliest human being \u2013 they all kneeled there like children and devout little old women, and they worshiped the ass. And just then the ugliest human being began to gurgle and snort as though something unspeakable wanted to get out of him; but when he actually put it into words, behold, it was a pious, remarkable litany praising the worshiped and censed ass. This litany, however, sounded thus:\r\n\r\nAmen! And praise and honor and wisdom and thanks and glory and strength be to our god, from everlasting to everlasting!\r\n\r\n\u2013 But to this the ass brayed Hee-yaw.\r\n\r\nHe carries our burden, he adopted the form of a servant, he is patient from the heart and never says No; and whoever loves his god, chastises him.\r\n\r\n\u2013 But to this the ass brayed Hee-yaw.\r\n\r\nHe does not speak, unless it be to say Yaw to the world that he created; thus he praises his world. It is his slyness that does not speak; this way he is rarely found to be wrong.\r\n\r\n\u2013 But to this the ass brayed Hee-yaw.\r\n\r\nHomely he walks through the world. Gray is the body color in which he cloaks his virtue. If he has spirit, then he conceals it; but everyone believes in his long ears.\r\n\r\n\u2013 But to this the ass brayed Hee-yaw.\r\n\r\nWhat hidden wisdom is it, that he has long ears and always says Yaw and never No! Has he not created the world in his image, namely as stupid as possible?\r\n\r\n\u2013 But to this the ass brayed Hee-yaw.\r\n\r\nYou walk ways that are straight and crooked; it matters little to you what seems straight or crooked to us human beings. Your kingdom is beyond good and evil. It is your innocence not to know what innocence is.\r\n\r\n\u2013 But to this the ass brayed Hee-yaw.\r\n\r\nSee now, how you push no one away, not the beggars, not the kings. The little children you let come to you, and when the mean boys bait you, then you simplemindedly say Hee-yaw.\r\n\r\n\u2013 But to this the ass brayed Hee-yaw.\r\n\r\nYou love she-asses and fresh figs, you are no picky eater. A thistle tickles your heart if you happen to be hungry. Therein lies the wisdom of a god.\r\n\r\n\u2013 But to this the ass brayed Hee-yaw."}, "id": 94}, {"data": {"uuid": "27ca741f-5d43-4da8-ae2a-cc24eaadc5bf", "user": 1, "title": "The Ass Festival", "created_on": "2023-05-10 17:03:32.201336+00:00", "updated_on": "2023-05-10 17:03:32.228658+00:00", "article_html": "<h2>The Ass Festival</h2><h3>1</h3><p>At this point in the litany, however, Zarathustra could no longer control himself, cried Hee-yaw himself even louder than the ass, and leaped into the midst of his guests, who had gone mad. \u201cBut what are you doing, you mortal children?\u201d he cried, as he pulled the praying men off the floor and to their feet. \u201cWatch out that someone other than Zarathustra should see you:</p><p>Anyone would conclude that with your new faith you were the most vicious blasphemers or the most foolish of all old little women!</p><p>And you yourself, you old pope, how can you reconcile for yourself that you worship this ass here as God?\u201d \u2013</p><p>\u201cOh Zarathustra,\u201d responded the pope, \u201cforgive me, but in matters of God I am more enlightened even than you. And that\u2019s how it should be.</p><p>Better to worship God in this form, than in no form at all! Think about this dictum, my exalted friend; you will quickly realize that there is wisdom in such a dictum.</p><p>He who said \u2018God is a spirit\u2019 \u2013 he took the biggest step and leap ever on earth toward disbelief: such words are not easy to rectify on earth!</p><p>My old heart leaps and skips at the fact that there is still something to worship on earth. Forgive, oh Zarathustra, an old pious pope\u2019s heart! \u2013\u201d</p><p>\u2013 \u201cAnd you,\u201d said Zarathustra to the wanderer and shadow, \u201cyou call and consider yourself a free spirit? And yet here you perform such idolatry and popery?</p><p>Your performance here is more wicked indeed than it is with your wicked brown girls, you wicked new believer!\u201d</p><p>\u201cWicked enough,\u201d answered the wanderer and shadow, \u201cyou\u2019re right; but what can I do about it? The old God lives again, oh Zarathustra, say what you will.</p><p>The ugliest human being is to blame for everything; he has awakened him again. And when he says that he once killed him: death is always a mere prejudice among gods.\u201d</p><p>\u2013 \u201cAnd you,\u201d said Zarathustra, \u201cyou wicked old magician, what have you done! Who in these liberated times is supposed to believe in you anymore, if you believe in such asinine divinities?</p><p>What you did was a stupidity; how could you, you clever one, commit such a stupidity!\u201d</p><p>\u201cOh Zarathustra,\u201d replied the clever magician, \u201cyou\u2019re right, it was a stupidity \u2013 and it\u2019s been hard enough for me.\u201d</p><p>\u2013 \u201cAnd you most of all,\u201d said Zarathustra to the conscientious of spirit, \u201clean your head on your hand and consider! Doesn\u2019t anything here go against your conscience? Isn\u2019t your spirit too clean for this praying and the steam of these Holy Joes?\u201d</p><p>\u201cThere is something about it,\u201d answered the conscientious one, leaning his head on his hand, \u201cthere is something about this spectacle that actually does my spirit good.</p><p>Maybe because I am not allowed to believe in God; but it is certain that God in this form seems most believable to me.</p><p>God should be eternal, according to the witnessing of the most pious; whoever has that much time, takes his time. As slowly and as stupidly as possible: that way such a one can indeed go very far.</p><p>And whoever has too much spirit, he may well become a fool even for stupidity and folly. Think about your own case, oh Zarathustra!</p><p>You yourself \u2013 indeed! Even you could well become an ass from super-abundance and wisdom.</p><p>Does a perfectly wise man not like to walk on crooked paths? Appearances would indicate this, oh Zarathustra \u2013 your appearance!\u201d</p><p>\u2013 \u201cAnd finally you yourself,\u201d said Zarathustra and he turned toward the ugliest human being, who still lay on the floor, reaching up with his arm to the ass (for he was giving it wine to drink). \u201cSpeak, you unspeakable one: what have you done here!</p><p>You seem transformed to me, your eyes glow, the cloak of the sublime lies about your ugliness: What have you done?</p><p>Is what they say true after all, that you awakened him again? And why? Were there not good grounds for killing and getting rid of him?</p><p>You yourself seem awakened to me; what have you done? Why did you revert? Why did you convert? Speak, you unspeakable one!\u201d</p><p>\u201cOh Zarathustra,\u201d replied the ugliest human being, \u201cyou are a rogue! Whether he still lives or lives again or is thoroughly dead \u2013 which of us two knows that best? I ask you.</p><p>But I know one thing \u2013 it was from you yourself that I once learned, oh Zarathustra: whoever wants to kill most thoroughly, laughs.</p><p>\u2018One kills not by wrath, but by laughter\u2019 \u2013 thus you once spoke. Oh Zarathustra, you hidden one, you annihilator without wrath, you dangerous saint \u2013 you are a rogue!\u201d</p><h3>2</h3><p>But then it happened that Zarathustra, astounded by the sheer number of such roguish answers, bounded back to the door of his cave and, facing all of his guests, cried out with a strong voice:</p><p>\u201cOh you foolish rascals, the lot of you, you jesters! Why do you dissemble and disguise yourselves before me?</p><p>How the hearts of each of you squirmed with glee and malice that at last you had become as little children again, namely pious \u2013</p><p>\u2013 that at last you did again as children do, namely prayed, folded your hands and said \u2018dear God!\u2019</p><p>But now leave me this nursery, my own cave, where today all manner of childishness is at home. Cool your hot children\u2019s mischief and your heart\u2019s noise out here!</p><p>To be sure, unless you become as little children, you shall not enter that kingdom of heaven. (And Zarathustra gestured upward with his hands.)</p><p>But we do want to enter the kingdom of heaven at all: we have become men \u2013 and so we want the kingdom of the earth.\u201d</p><h3>3</h3><p>And once again Zarathustra began to speak. \u201cOh my new friends,\u201d he said \u2013 \u201cyou strange, you higher men, how well I like you now \u2013</p><p>\u2013 since you\u2019ve become gay again! All of you have truly blossomed; it seems to me that flowers such as you require new festivals,</p><p>\u2013 a small brave nonsense, some kind of divine worship and ass festival, some kind of old gay Zarathustra fool, a sweeping wind that blows your souls bright.</p><p>Do not forget this night and this ass festival, you higher men! This you invented in my cave, this I take as a good omen \u2013 such things are invented only by the convalescing!</p><p>And if you celebrate it again, this ass festival, do it for your own sake, do it also for my sake! And in remembrance of me!\u201d</p><p>Thus spoke Zarathustra.</p>", "article_json": {"type": "doc", "content": [{"type": "heading", "attrs": {"level": 2}, "content": [{"text": "The Ass Festival", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "heading", "attrs": {"level": 3}, "content": [{"text": "1", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "content": [{"text": "At this point in the litany, however, Zarathustra could no longer control himself, cried Hee-yaw himself even louder than the ass, and leaped into the midst of his guests, who had gone mad. \u201cBut what are you doing, you mortal children?\u201d he cried, as he pulled the praying men off the floor and to their feet. \u201cWatch out that someone other than Zarathustra should see you:", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "content": [{"text": "Anyone would conclude that with your new faith you were the most vicious blasphemers or the most foolish of all old little women!", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "content": [{"text": "And you yourself, you old pope, how can you reconcile for yourself that you worship this ass here as God?\u201d \u2013", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "content": [{"text": "\u201cOh Zarathustra,\u201d responded the pope, \u201cforgive me, but in matters of God I am more enlightened even than you. And that\u2019s how it should be.\r\n\r\nBetter to worship God in this form, than in no form at all! Think about this dictum, my exalted friend; you will quickly realize that there is wisdom in such a dictum.\r\n\r\nHe who said \u2018God is a spirit\u2019 \u2013 he took the biggest step and leap ever on earth toward disbelief: such words are not easy to rectify on earth!\r\n\r\nMy old heart leaps and skips at the fact that there is still something to worship on earth. Forgive, oh Zarathustra, an old pious pope\u2019s heart! \u2013\u201d\r\n\r\n\u2013 \u201cAnd you,\u201d said Zarathustra to the wanderer and shadow, \u201cyou call and consider yourself a free spirit? And yet here you perform such idolatry and popery?\r\n\r\nYour performance here is more wicked indeed than it is with your wicked brown girls, you wicked new believer!\u201d\r\n\r\n\u201cWicked enough,\u201d answered the wanderer and shadow, \u201cyou\u2019re right; but what can I do about it? The old God lives again, oh Zarathustra, say what you will.\r\n\r\nThe ugliest human being is to blame for everything; he has awakened him again. And when he says that he once killed him: death is always a mere prejudice among gods.\u201d\r\n\r\n\u2013 \u201cAnd you,\u201d said Zarathustra, \u201cyou wicked old magician, what have you done! Who in these liberated times is supposed to believe in you anymore, if you believe in such asinine divinities?\r\n\r\nWhat you did was a stupidity; how could you, you clever one, commit such a stupidity!\u201d\r\n\r\n\u201cOh Zarathustra,\u201d replied the clever magician, \u201cyou\u2019re right, it was a stupidity \u2013 and it\u2019s been hard enough for me.\u201d\r\n\r\n\u2013 \u201cAnd you most of all,\u201d said Zarathustra to the conscientious of spirit, \u201clean your head on your hand and consider! Doesn\u2019t anything here go against your conscience? Isn\u2019t your spirit too clean for this praying and the steam of these Holy Joes?\u201d\r\n\r\n\u201cThere is something about it,\u201d answered the conscientious one, leaning his head on his hand, \u201cthere is something about this spectacle that actually does my spirit good.\r\n\r\nMaybe because I am not allowed to believe in God; but it is certain that God in this form seems most believable to me.\r\n\r\nGod should be eternal, according to the witnessing of the most pious; whoever has that much time, takes his time. As slowly and as stupidly as possible: that way such a one can indeed go very far.\r\n\r\nAnd whoever has too much spirit, he may well become a fool even for stupidity and folly. Think about your own case, oh Zarathustra!\r\n\r\nYou yourself \u2013 indeed! Even you could well become an ass from super-abundance and wisdom.\r\n\r\nDoes a perfectly wise man not like to walk on crooked paths? Appearances would indicate this, oh Zarathustra \u2013 your appearance!\u201d\r\n\r\n\u2013 \u201cAnd finally you yourself,\u201d said Zarathustra and he turned toward the ugliest human being, who still lay on the floor, reaching up with his arm to the ass (for he was giving it wine to drink). \u201cSpeak, you unspeakable one: what have you done here!\r\n\r\nYou seem transformed to me, your eyes glow, the cloak of the sublime lies about your ugliness: What have you done?\r\n\r\nIs what they say true after all, that you awakened him again? And why? Were there not good grounds for killing and getting rid of him?\r\n\r\nYou yourself seem awakened to me; what have you done? Why did you revert? Why did you convert? Speak, you unspeakable one!\u201d\r\n\r\n\u201cOh Zarathustra,\u201d replied the ugliest human being, \u201cyou are a rogue! Whether he still lives or lives again or is thoroughly dead \u2013 which of us two knows that best? I ask you.\r\n\r\nBut I know one thing \u2013 it was from you yourself that I once learned, oh Zarathustra: whoever wants to kill most thoroughly, laughs.\r\n\r\n\u2018One kills not by wrath, but by laughter\u2019 \u2013 thus you once spoke. Oh Zarathustra, you hidden one, you annihilator without wrath, you dangerous saint \u2013 you are a rogue!\u201d\r\n\r\n2\r\n\r\nBut then it happened that Zarathustra, astounded by the sheer number of such roguish answers, bounded back to the door of his cave and, facing all of his guests, cried out with a strong voice:\r\n\r\n\u201cOh you foolish rascals, the lot of you, you jesters! Why do you dissemble and disguise yourselves before me?\r\n\r\nHow the hearts of each of you squirmed with glee and malice that at last you had become as little children again, namely pious \u2013\r\n\r\n\u2013 that at last you did again as children do, namely prayed, folded your hands and said \u2018dear God!\u2019\r\n\r\nBut now leave me this nursery, my own cave, where today all manner of childishness is at home. Cool your hot children\u2019s mischief and your heart\u2019s noise out here!\r\n\r\nTo be sure, unless you become as little children, you shall not enter that kingdom of heaven. (And Zarathustra gestured upward with his hands.)\r\n\r\nBut we do want to enter the kingdom of heaven at all: we have become men \u2013 and so we want the kingdom of the earth.\u201d\r\n\r\n3\r\n\r\nAnd once again Zarathustra began to speak. \u201cOh my new friends,\u201d he said \u2013 \u201cyou strange, you higher men, how well I like you now \u2013\r\n\r\n\u2013 since you\u2019ve become gay again! All of you have truly blossomed; it seems to me that flowers such as you require new festivals,\r\n\r\n\u2013 a small brave nonsense, some kind of divine worship and ass festival, some kind of old gay Zarathustra fool, a sweeping wind that blows your souls bright.\r\n\r\nDo not forget this night and this ass festival, you higher men! This you invented in my cave, this I take as a good omen \u2013 such things are invented only by the convalescing!\r\n\r\nAnd if you celebrate it again, this ass festival, do it for your own sake, do it also for my sake! And in remembrance of me!\u201d\r\n\r\nThus spoke Zarathustra."}, "id": 95}, {"data": {"uuid": "3a3d336e-bd27-4182-9dcc-b306fdf55b44", "user": 1, "title": "The Sleepwalker Song", "created_on": "2023-05-10 17:04:31.061704+00:00", "updated_on": "2023-05-10 17:04:31.087927+00:00", "article_html": "<h2>The Sleepwalker Song</h2><h3>1</h3><p>Meanwhile, however, one after another had stepped outdoors into the open and into the cool, pensive night; but Zarathustra himself led the ugliest human being by the hand, to show him his night world and the big round moon and the silver waterfalls near his cave. There at last they all stood together, nothing but old people, but with comforted, brave hearts and inwardly amazed that they felt so good on earth; but the mystery of the night came closer and closer to their hearts. And Zarathustra thought again to himself: \u201cOh how well I like them now, these higher men!\u201d \u2013 but he did not say it aloud, for he honored their happiness and their silence. \u2013</p><p>But then something happened that was the most amazing thing of that amazing long day: the ugliest human being began once more and for the last time to gurgle and to snort, and when he had managed to put it in words, behold, a question leaped round and ready from his mouth, a good, deep, clear question, which moved the hearts of all who were listening to him.</p><p>\u201cMy friends, all of you,\u201d spoke the ugliest human being, \u201cwhat do you think? For the sake of this day \u2013 I am satisfied for the first time that I have lived my entire life.</p><p>And it\u2019s still not enough for me to attest as much as I do. It\u2019s worth it to live on earth: one day, one festival with Zarathustra taught me to love the earth.</p><p>\u2018Was that \u2013 life?\u2019 I want to say to death. \u2018Well then! One More Time!\u2019</p><p>My friends, what do you think? Do you not want to say to death, as I do: Was that \u2013 life? For Zarathustra\u2019s sake, well then! One More Time!\u201d \u2013</p><p>Thus spoke the ugliest human being; but it was not long before midnight. And what do you think happened then? As soon as the higher men had heard his question, all at once they became aware of their transformation and convalescence, and of who gave it to them. Then they rushed toward Zarathustra, thanking, honoring, caressing him, kissing his hands, each in his own manner; such that some laughed, some wept. But the old soothsayer danced with joy; and even if, as some chroniclers opine, he was full of sweet wine at the time, then he was certainly even more full of sweet life and he had renounced all weariness. There are even some who say that the ass also danced then; not for nothing, after all, had the ugliest human being earlier given it wine to drink. Now this may have happened thus or otherwise, and if in truth on that evening the ass did not dance, then clearly even greater and rarer wonders took place there, than the dancing of an ass would have been. In sum, as Zarathustra\u2019s saying goes: \u201cWhat does it matter!\u201d</p><h3>2</h3><p>But as this went on with the ugliest human being, Zarathustra stood there like a drunken man; his tongue slurred, his feet faltered. And who could even guess what thoughts were speeding then through Zarathustra\u2019s soul? Visibly, however, his spirit receded and flew ahead and was in remote distances and at the same time \u201cupon a high ridge,\u201d as it is written, \u201cbetween two seas,</p><p>\u2013 between the past and the future, wandering as a heavy cloud.\u201d Gradually, however, as the higher men held him in their arms, he came to himself a bit and used his hands to fend away the throng of the revering and the worrying; yet he did not speak. All at once though he quickly turned his head, because he seemed to hear something: then he put his finger to his lips and said: \u201cCome!\u201d</p><p>And immediately it became still and mysterious all around; but from the depths the sound of a bell rose slowly. Zarathustra listened for it, as did the higher men; then he put his finger to his lips once more and said again: \u201cCome! Come! It\u2019s going on midnight!\u201d \u2013 And his voice had changed. But still he did not stir from his place; then it grew even more still and mysterious, and everything listened, even the ass, and Zarathustra\u2019s animals of honor, the eagle and the snake, and also the cave of Zarathustra and the big cool moon and the very night. But Zarathustra put his hand to his lips for the third time and said:</p><p>\u201cCome! Come! Come! Let us walk now! It is the hour: let us walk now into the night! \u201d</p><h3>3</h3><p>You higher men, it\u2019s going on midnight; I want to whisper something in your ears, like that old bell whispers it into my ear \u2013</p><p>\u2013 as secretly, as terribly, as cordially as that midnight bell, which has experienced more than any human, says it to me:</p><p>\u2013 which long ago tallied the heartbeat beatings of your fathers \u2013 oh! oh! how it sighs! How it laughs in dream delight, the old, the deep deep midnight!</p><p>Still! Still! Then things are heard that by day may not be said; but now, in the cool air, where the noise of your hearts has fled \u2013</p><p>\u2013 now it speaks, now it listens, now it creeps into nocturnal, over-awake souls \u2013 oh! oh! how it sighs! How it laughs in dream delight!</p><p>\u2013 don\u2019t you hear, how it secretly, terribly, cordially speaks to you, the old, the deep deep midnight?</p><p>Oh mankind, pray!</p><h3>4</h3><p>Woe to me! Where has time gone? Did I not sink into deep wells? The world sleeps \u2013</p><p>Alas! Alas! The dog howls, the moon shines. I would sooner die, die, than tell you what my midnight heart is thinking right now.</p><p>Now I\u2019ve died already. It\u2019s gone. Spider, why do you spin around me? Do you want blood? Oh! Oh! The dew falls, the hour comes \u2013</p><p>\u2013 the hour when I shiver and freeze, which asks and asks and asks: \u201cwho has enough heart for it?</p><p>\u2013 who shall be the ruler of the earth? Who wants to say: thus you shall flow, you great and little streams!\u201d</p><p>\u2013 the hour approaches: oh mankind, you higher men, pray! This speech is for fine ears, for your ears \u2013 what does deep midnight have to say?</p><h3>5</h3><p>It carries me away, my soul dances. Day\u2019s work! Day\u2019s work! Who shall be ruler of the earth?</p><p>The moon is cool, the wind is silent. Alas! Alas! Have you flown high enough? You dance: but a leg is not a wing.</p><p>You good dancers, now all joy is gone, wine became resin, every cup became brittle, the graves stammer.</p><p>You did not fly high enough; now the graves stammer: \u201cRedeem the dead! Why is it night for so long? Does the moon not make us drunk?\u201d</p><p>You higher men, redeem the graves, awaken the corpses! Oh, why does the worm still bore? It approaches, the hour approaches \u2013</p><p>\u2013 the bell growls, the heart still rattles, the wood worm still bores, the heart worm. Alas! Alas! The world is deep!</p><h3>6</h3><p>Sweet lyre! Sweet lyre! I love your tone, your drunken, sunken croaking tone! \u2013 From how long ago, from how far away your tone comes to me, from afar, from ponds of love!</p><p>You old bell, you sweet lyre! Every pain tore into your heart, father pain, fathers\u2019 pain, forefathers\u2019 pain, your speech grew ripe \u2013</p><p>\u2013 ripe like golden autumns and afternoons, like my hermit\u2019s heart \u2013 now you speak: the world itself became ripe, the grape turns brown,</p><p>\u2013 now it wants to die, die of happiness. You higher men, do you not smell it? A fragrance wells up mysteriously,</p><p>\u2013 a fragrance and aroma of eternity, a rosy blissful, brown golden wine aroma of ancient happiness,</p><p>\u2013 of drunken, midnight, dying happiness, which sings: the world is deep and deeper than the grasp of day!</p><h3>7</h3><p>Let me be! Let me be! I am too pure for you. Do not touch me! Did my world not just become perfect?</p><p>My skin is too pure for your hands. Let me be, you stupid, clumsy, stifling day! Is midnight not brighter?</p><p>The purest shall be rulers of the earth, the least known, strongest, the midnight-souled, who are brighter and deeper than any day.</p><p>Oh day, you grope for me? You fumble for my happiness? I seem rich to you, lonely, buried treasure, a chamber of gold?</p><p>Oh world, you want me? Am I worldly to you? Am I spiritual to you? Am I godlike to you? But day and world, you are too crude \u2013</p><p>\u2013 have smarter hands, reach for deeper happiness, for deeper unhappiness, reach for some kind of god \u2013 do not reach for me:</p><p>\u2013 my unhappiness, my happiness is deep, you strange day, but still I am no god, no god\u2019s hell: deep is its pain.</p><h3>8</h3><p>God\u2019s pain is deeper, you strange world! Reach for god\u2019s pain, not for me! What am I? A drunken sweet lyre \u2013</p><p>a midnight lyre, a bell-toad that no one understands, but that must speak, before the deaf, you higher men! For you do not understand me!</p><p>Gone! Gone! Oh youth! Oh noon! Oh afternoon! Now evening\u2019s come and night and midnight \u2013 the dog howls, the wind:</p><p>\u2013 is the wind not a dog? It whimpers, it yelps, it howls. Alas! Oh how midnight sighs, how it laughs, how it rattles and wheezes!</p><p>How she speaks soberly just now, this drunken poetess! Perhaps she overdrank her drunkenness? She became over-awake? She ruminates?</p><p>\u2013 she ruminates her pain, in dream, the old deep midnight, and even more her joy. Because joy, even if pain is deep: Joy is deeper still than misery.</p><h3>9</h3><p>You grapevine! Why do you praise me! I cut you! I am cruel, you bleed \u2013 what does your praise want of my drunken cruelty?</p><p>\u201cWhat became perfect, everything ripe \u2013 wants to die!\u201d so you speak. Blessed, blessed be the vintner\u2019s knife! But everything unripe wants to live, alas!</p><p>Pain says: \u201cRefrain! Away, you pain!\u201d But everything that suffers wants to live, to become ripe and joyful and longing,</p><p>\u2013 longing for what is farther, higher, brighter. \u201cI want heirs,\u201d thus speaks all that suffers, \u201cI want children, I do not want myself \u201d \u2013</p><p>But joy does not want heirs, not children \u2013 joy wants itself, wants eternity, wants recurrence, wants everything eternally the same.</p><p>Pain says: \u201cBreak, bleed, heart! Walk, legs! Wings, fly! Up! Upward! Pain!\u201d Well then, well now, old heart! Pain says: \u201cRefrain! \u201d</p><h3>10</h3><p>You higher men, what do you think? Am I a soothsayer? A dreamer? A drunk? A dream interpreter? A midnight bell?</p><p>A drop of dew? A haze and fragrance of eternity? Do you not hear it? Do you not smell it? Just now my world became perfect, midnight is also noon \u2013</p><p>Pain is also a joy, a curse is also a blessing, night is also a sun \u2013 go away or else you will learn: a wise man is also a fool.</p><p>Have you ever said Yes to one joy? Oh my friends, then you also said Yes to all pain. All things are enchained, entwined, enamored \u2013</p><p>\u2013 if you ever wanted one time two times, if you ever said \u201cI like you, happiness! Whoosh! Moment!\u201d then you wanted everything back!</p><p>\u2013 Everything anew, everything eternal, everything enchained, entwined, enamored, oh thus you loved the world \u2013</p><p>\u2013 you eternal ones, love it eternally and for all time; and say to pain also: refrain, but come back! For all joy wants \u2013 eternity!</p><h3>11</h3><p>All joy want the eternity of all things, wants honey, wants resin, wants drunken midnight, wants graves, wants tomb-tears\u2019 solace, wants gilded sunset \u2013</p><p>\u2013 what does joy not want? It is thirstier, heartier, hungrier, more terrible, more mysterious than all pain, it wants itself, it bites into itself, the ring\u2019s will wrestles in it \u2013</p><p>\u2013 it wants love, it wants hate, it is super-rich, bestows, throws away, begs for someone to take it, thanks the taker, it would like to be hated \u2013</p><p>\u2013 so rich is its joy that it thirsts for pain, for hell, for hate, for disgrace, for the cripple, for world \u2013 this world, oh you know it well!</p><p>You higher men, it longs for you, does joy, the unruly, blissful one \u2013 for your pain, you failures! All eternal joy longs for failures.</p><p>For all joy wants itself, and therefore it wants all misery too! Oh happiness, oh pain! Oh break, my heart! You higher men, learn this, joy wants eternity,</p><p>\u2013 Joy wants the eternity of all things, wants deep, wants deep eternity!</p><h3>12</h3><p>Have you now learned my song? Have you guessed what it means? Well then! Well now! You higher men, then sing me my new roundelay!</p><p>Sing me this song yourselves now, whose name is \u201cOne More Time,\u201d whose meaning is \u201cin all eternity!\u201d \u2013 sing, you higher men, Zarathustra\u2019s roundelay!</p><p>Oh mankind, pray!<br>What does deep midnight have to say?<br>\u201cFrom sleep, from sleep \u2013<br>From deepest dream I made my way: \u2013<br>The world is deep,<br>And deeper than the grasp of day.<br>Deep is its pain \u2013,<br>Joy \u2013 deeper still than misery:<br>Pain says: Refrain!<br>Yet all joy wants eternity \u2013<br>\u2013 Wants deep, wants deep eternity.\u201d</p>", "article_json": {"type": "doc", "content": [{"type": "heading", "attrs": {"level": 2}, "content": [{"text": "The Sleepwalker Song", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "heading", "attrs": {"level": 3}, "content": [{"text": "1", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "content": [{"text": "Meanwhile, however, one after another had stepped outdoors into the open and into the cool, pensive night; but Zarathustra himself led the ugliest human being by the hand, to show him his night world and the big round moon and the silver waterfalls near his cave.
