Have you guessed what it means? Well then! Well now! You higher men, then sing me my new roundelay!", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "content": [{"text": "Sing me this song yourselves now, whose name is \u201cOne More Time,\u201d whose meaning is \u201cin all eternity!\u201d \u2013 sing, you higher men, Zarathustra\u2019s roundelay!", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "content": [{"text": "Oh mankind, pray!", "type": "text"}, {"type": "hardBreak"}, {"text": "What does deep midnight have to say?", "type": "text"}, {"type": "hardBreak"}, {"text": "\u201cFrom sleep, from sleep \u2013", "type": "text"}, {"type": "hardBreak"}, {"text": "From deepest dream I made my way: \u2013", "type": "text"}, {"type": "hardBreak"}, {"text": "The world is deep,", "type": "text"}, {"type": "hardBreak"}, {"text": "And deeper than the grasp of day.", "type": "text"}, {"type": "hardBreak"}, {"text": "Deep is its pain \u2013,", "type": "text"}, {"type": "hardBreak"}, {"text": "Joy \u2013 deeper still than misery:", "type": "text"}, {"type": "hardBreak"}, {"text": "Pain says: Refrain!", "type": "text"}, {"type": "hardBreak"}, {"text": "Yet all joy wants eternity \u2013", "type": "text"}, {"type": "hardBreak"}, {"text": "\u2013 Wants deep, wants deep eternity.\u201d", "type": "text"}]}]}, "article_text": "The Sleepwalker Song\r\n\r\n1\r\n\r\nMeanwhile, however, one after another had stepped outdoors into the open and into the cool, pensive night; but Zarathustra himself led the ugliest human being by the hand, to show him his night world and the big round moon and the silver waterfalls near his cave. There at last they all stood together, nothing but old people, but with comforted, brave hearts and inwardly amazed that they felt so good on earth; but the mystery of the night came closer and closer to their hearts. And Zarathustra thought again to himself: \u201cOh how well I like them now, these higher men!\u201d \u2013 but he did not say it aloud, for he honored their happiness and their silence. \u2013\r\n\r\nBut then something happened that was the most amazing thing of that amazing long day: the ugliest human being began once more and for the last time to gurgle and to snort, and when he had managed to put it in words, behold, a question leaped round and ready from his mouth, a good, deep, clear question, which moved the hearts of all who were listening to him.\r\n\r\n\u201cMy friends, all of you,\u201d spoke the ugliest human being, \u201cwhat do you think? For the sake of this day \u2013 I am satisfied for the first time that I have lived my entire life.\r\n\r\nAnd it\u2019s still not enough for me to attest as much as I do. It\u2019s worth it to live on earth: one day, one festival with Zarathustra taught me to love the earth.\r\n\r\n\u2018Was that \u2013 life?\u2019 I want to say to death. \u2018Well then! One More Time!\u2019\r\n\r\nMy friends, what do you think? Do you not want to say to death, as I do: Was that \u2013 life? For Zarathustra\u2019s sake, well then! One More Time!\u201d \u2013\r\n\r\nThus spoke the ugliest human being; but it was not long before midnight. And what do you think happened then? As soon as the higher men had heard his question, all at once they became aware of their transformation and convalescence, and of who gave it to them. Then they rushed toward Zarathustra, thanking, honoring, caressing him, kissing his hands, each in his own manner; such that some laughed, some wept. But the old soothsayer danced with joy; and even if, as some chroniclers opine, he was full of sweet wine at the time, then he was certainly even more full of sweet life and he had renounced all weariness. There are even some who say that the ass also danced then; not for nothing, after all, had the ugliest human being earlier given it wine to drink. Now this may have happened thus or otherwise, and if in truth on that evening the ass did not dance, then clearly even greater and rarer wonders took place there, than the dancing of an ass would have been. In sum, as Zarathustra\u2019s saying goes: \u201cWhat does it matter!\u201d\r\n\r\n2\r\n\r\nBut as this went on with the ugliest human being, Zarathustra stood there like a drunken man; his tongue slurred, his feet faltered. And who could even guess what thoughts were speeding then through Zarathustra\u2019s soul? Visibly, however, his spirit receded and flew ahead and was in remote distances and at the same time \u201cupon a high ridge,\u201d as it is written, \u201cbetween two seas,\r\n\r\n\u2013 between the past and the future, wandering as a heavy cloud.\u201d Gradually, however, as the higher men held him in their arms, he came to himself a bit and used his hands to fend away the throng of the revering and the worrying; yet he did not speak. All at once though he quickly turned his head, because he seemed to hear something: then he put his finger to his lips and said: \u201cCome!\u201d\r\n\r\nAnd immediately it became still and mysterious all around; but from the depths the sound of a bell rose slowly. Zarathustra listened for it, as did the higher men; then he put his finger to his lips once more and said again: \u201cCome! Come! It\u2019s going on midnight!\u201d \u2013 And his voice had changed. But still he did not stir from his place; then it grew even more still and mysterious, and everything listened, even the ass, and Zarathustra\u2019s animals of honor, the eagle and the snake, and also the cave of Zarathustra and the big cool moon and the very night. But Zarathustra put his hand to his lips for the third time and said:\r\n\r\n\u201cCome! Come! Come! Let us walk now! It is the hour: let us walk now into the night! \u201d\r\n\r\n3\r\n\r\nYou higher men, it\u2019s going on midnight; I want to whisper something in your ears, like that old bell whispers it into my ear \u2013\r\n\r\n\u2013 as secretly, as terribly, as cordially as that midnight bell, which has experienced more than any human, says it to me:\r\n\r\n\u2013 which long ago tallied the heartbeat beatings of your fathers \u2013 oh! oh! how it sighs! How it laughs in dream delight, the old, the deep deep midnight!\r\n\r\nStill! Still! Then things are heard that by day may not be said; but now, in the cool air, where the noise of your hearts has fled \u2013\r\n\r\n\u2013 now it speaks, now it listens, now it creeps into nocturnal, over-awake souls \u2013 oh! oh! how it sighs! How it laughs in dream delight!\r\n\r\n\u2013 don\u2019t you hear, how it secretly, terribly, cordially speaks to you, the old, the deep deep midnight?\r\n\r\nOh mankind, pray!\r\n\r\n4\r\n\r\nWoe to me! Where has time gone? Did I not sink into deep wells? The world sleeps \u2013\r\n\r\nAlas! Alas! The dog howls, the moon shines. I would sooner die, die, than tell you what my midnight heart is thinking right now.\r\n\r\nNow I\u2019ve died already. It\u2019s gone. Spider, why do you spin around me? Do you want blood? Oh! Oh! The dew falls, the hour comes \u2013\r\n\r\n\u2013 the hour when I shiver and freeze, which asks and asks and asks: \u201cwho has enough heart for it?\r\n\r\n\u2013 who shall be the ruler of the earth? Who wants to say: thus you shall flow, you great and little streams!\u201d\r\n\r\n\u2013 the hour approaches: oh mankind, you higher men, pray! This speech is for fine ears, for your ears \u2013 what does deep midnight have to say?\r\n\r\n5\r\n\r\nIt carries me away, my soul dances. Day\u2019s work! Day\u2019s work! Who shall be ruler of the earth?\r\n\r\nThe moon is cool, the wind is silent. Alas! Alas! Have you flown high enough? You dance: but a leg is not a wing.\r\n\r\nYou good dancers, now all joy is gone, wine became resin, every cup became brittle, the graves stammer.\r\n\r\nYou did not fly high enough; now the graves stammer: \u201cRedeem the dead! Why is it night for so long? Does the moon not make us drunk?\u201d\r\n\r\nYou higher men, redeem the graves, awaken the corpses! Oh, why does the worm still bore? It approaches, the hour approaches \u2013\r\n\r\n\u2013 the bell growls, the heart still rattles, the wood worm still bores, the heart worm. Alas! Alas! The world is deep!\r\n\r\n6\r\n\r\nSweet lyre! Sweet lyre! I love your tone, your drunken, sunken croaking tone! \u2013 From how long ago, from how far away your tone comes to me, from afar, from ponds of love!\r\n\r\nYou old bell, you sweet lyre! Every pain tore into your heart, father pain, fathers\u2019 pain, forefathers\u2019 pain, your speech grew ripe \u2013\r\n\r\n\u2013 ripe like golden autumns and afternoons, like my hermit\u2019s heart \u2013 now you speak: the world itself became ripe, the grape turns brown,\r\n\r\n\u2013 now it wants to die, die of happiness. You higher men, do you not smell it? A fragrance wells up mysteriously,\r\n\r\n\u2013 a fragrance and aroma of eternity, a rosy blissful, brown golden wine aroma of ancient happiness,\r\n\r\n\u2013 of drunken, midnight, dying happiness, which sings: the world is deep and deeper than the grasp of day!\r\n\r\n7\r\n\r\nLet me be! Let me be! I am too pure for you. Do not touch me! Did my world not just become perfect?\r\n\r\nMy skin is too pure for your hands. Let me be, you stupid, clumsy, stifling day! Is midnight not brighter?\r\n\r\nThe purest shall be rulers of the earth, the least known, strongest, the midnight-souled, who are brighter and deeper than any day.\r\n\r\nOh day, you grope for me? You fumble for my happiness? I seem rich to you, lonely, buried treasure, a chamber of gold?\r\n\r\nOh world, you want me? Am I worldly to you? Am I spiritual to you? Am I godlike to you? But day and world, you are too crude \u2013\r\n\r\n\u2013 have smarter hands, reach for deeper happiness, for deeper unhappiness, reach for some kind of god \u2013 do not reach for me:\r\n\r\n\u2013 my unhappiness, my happiness is deep, you strange day, but still I am no god, no god\u2019s hell: deep is its pain.\r\n\r\n8\r\n\r\nGod\u2019s pain is deeper, you strange world! Reach for god\u2019s pain, not for me! What am I? A drunken sweet lyre \u2013\r\n\r\na midnight lyre, a bell-toad that no one understands, but that must speak, before the deaf, you higher men! For you do not understand me!\r\n\r\nGone! Gone! Oh youth! Oh noon! Oh afternoon! Now evening\u2019s come and night and midnight \u2013 the dog howls, the wind:\r\n\r\n\u2013 is the wind not a dog? It whimpers, it yelps, it howls. Alas! Oh how midnight sighs, how it laughs, how it rattles and wheezes!\r\n\r\nHow she speaks soberly just now, this drunken poetess! Perhaps she overdrank her drunkenness? She became over-awake? She ruminates?\r\n\r\n\u2013 she ruminates her pain, in dream, the old deep midnight, and even more her joy. Because joy, even if pain is deep: Joy is deeper still than misery.\r\n\r\n9\r\n\r\nYou grapevine! Why do you praise me! I cut you! I am cruel, you bleed \u2013 what does your praise want of my drunken cruelty?\r\n\r\n\u201cWhat became perfect, everything ripe \u2013 wants to die!\u201d so you speak. Blessed, blessed be the vintner\u2019s knife! But everything unripe wants to live, alas!\r\n\r\nPain says: \u201cRefrain! Away, you pain!\u201d But everything that suffers wants to live, to become ripe and joyful and longing,\r\n\r\n\u2013 longing for what is farther, higher, brighter. \u201cI want heirs,\u201d thus speaks all that suffers, \u201cI want children, I do not want myself \u201d \u2013\r\n\r\nBut joy does not want heirs, not children \u2013 joy wants itself, wants eternity, wants recurrence, wants everything eternally the same.\r\n\r\nPain says: \u201cBreak, bleed, heart! Walk, legs! Wings, fly! Up! Upward! Pain!\u201d Well then, well now, old heart! Pain says: \u201cRefrain! \u201d\r\n\r\n10\r\n\r\nYou higher men, what do you think? Am I a soothsayer? A dreamer? A drunk? A dream interpreter? A midnight bell?\r\n\r\nA drop of dew? A haze and fragrance of eternity? Do you not hear it? Do you not smell it? Just now my world became perfect, midnight is also noon \u2013\r\n\r\nPain is also a joy, a curse is also a blessing, night is also a sun \u2013 go away or else you will learn: a wise man is also a fool.\r\n\r\nHave you ever said Yes to one joy? Oh my friends, then you also said Yes to all pain. All things are enchained, entwined, enamored \u2013\r\n\r\n\u2013 if you ever wanted one time two times, if you ever said \u201cI like you, happiness! Whoosh! Moment!\u201d then you wanted everything back!\r\n\r\n\u2013 Everything anew, everything eternal, everything enchained, entwined, enamored, oh thus you loved the world \u2013\r\n\r\n\u2013 you eternal ones, love it eternally and for all time; and say to pain also: refrain, but come back! For all joy wants \u2013 eternity!\r\n\r\n11\r\n\r\nAll joy want the eternity of all things, wants honey, wants resin, wants drunken midnight, wants graves, wants tomb-tears\u2019 solace, wants gilded sunset \u2013\r\n\r\n\u2013 what does joy not want? It is thirstier, heartier, hungrier, more terrible, more mysterious than all pain, it wants itself, it bites into itself, the ring\u2019s will wrestles in it \u2013\r\n\r\n\u2013 it wants love, it wants hate, it is super-rich, bestows, throws away, begs for someone to take it, thanks the taker, it would like to be hated \u2013\r\n\r\n\u2013 so rich is its joy that it thirsts for pain, for hell, for hate, for disgrace, for the cripple, for world \u2013 this world, oh you know it well!\r\n\r\nYou higher men, it longs for you, does joy, the unruly, blissful one \u2013 for your pain, you failures! All eternal joy longs for failures.\r\n\r\nFor all joy wants itself, and therefore it wants all misery too! Oh happiness, oh pain! Oh break, my heart! You higher men, learn this, joy wants eternity,\r\n\r\n\u2013 Joy wants the eternity of all things, wants deep, wants deep eternity!\r\n\r\n12\r\n\r\nHave you now learned my song? Have you guessed what it means? Well then! Well now! You higher men, then sing me my new roundelay!\r\n\r\nSing me this song yourselves now, whose name is \u201cOne More Time,\u201d whose meaning is \u201cin all eternity!\u201d \u2013 sing, you higher men, Zarathustra\u2019s roundelay!\r\n\r\nOh mankind, pray!\r\nWhat does deep midnight have to say?\r\n\u201cFrom sleep, from sleep \u2013\r\nFrom deepest dream I made my way: \u2013\r\nThe world is deep,\r\nAnd deeper than the grasp of day.\r\nDeep is its pain \u2013,\r\nJoy \u2013 deeper still than misery:\r\nPain says: Refrain!\r\nYet all joy wants eternity \u2013\r\n\u2013 Wants deep, wants deep eternity.\u201d"}, "id": 96}, {"data": {"uuid": "af39d895-9ff1-46bd-9880-4210eac69932", "user": 1, "title": "The Sign", "created_on": "2023-05-10 17:05:15.573350+00:00", "updated_on": "2023-05-10 17:05:15.593663+00:00", "article_html": "<h2>The Sign</h2><p>But in the morning after this night Zarathustra sprang from his sleeping place, girded his loins and came out from his cave, glowing and strong, like a morning sun that emerges from dark mountains.</p><p>\u201cYou great star,\u201d he said, as he had said before, \u201cwhat would all your happiness be if you did not have those for whom you shine?</p><p>And if they stayed in their rooms while you are already awake and come and bestow and distribute \u2013 how would your proud shame be angered!</p><p>Well then! They\u2019re sleeping still, these higher men, while I am awake: they are not my proper companions! Not for them do I wait here in my mountains.</p><p>I want to go to my work, to my day; but they do not understand what the signs of my morning are, my step \u2013 is not a wake up call for them.</p><p>They are sleeping still in my cave, their dream still ruminates on my midnights. The ear that hearkens for me \u2013 the heeding ear is still lacking in their limbs.\u201d</p><p>\u2013 Thus Zarathustra spoke to his heart as the sun was rising; then he glanced questioning into the heights, for he heard above him the sharp call of his eagle. \u201cWell then!\u201d he shouted upward, \u201cthus it pleases and suits me. My animals are awake, because I am awake.</p><p>My eagle is awake and like me he honors the sun. With eagle\u2019s talons he grasps for the new light. You are my proper animals; I love you.</p><p>But I still lack the proper human beings!\u201d \u2013</p><p>Thus spoke Zarathustra; but then it happened that he suddenly heard himself swarmed and fluttered around as if by countless birds \u2013 but the whirring of so many wings and the thronging around his head was so great that he had to close his eyes. And truly, like a cloud it descended upon him, like a cloud of arrows pouring down upon a new enemy. But see, here it was a cloud of love, and it poured over a new friend.</p><p>\u201cWhat is happening to me?\u201d thought Zarathustra in his astonished heart, and he sat down slowly on the big stone that lay near the exit of his cave. But as he reached with his hands around and above and below himself, warding off the affectionate birds, something even more extraordinary happened to him: he reached unwittingly into a thick, warm tangle of hair, and at the same time a roar sounded before him \u2013 a soft, long lion\u2019s roar.</p><p>\u201cThe sign is coming\u201d said Zarathustra and his heart transformed. And in truth, as it grew brighter around him, there at his feet lay a yellow, powerful beast, and it pressed its head against his knee and did not want to leave him out of love, acting like a dog that finds its old master again. And the doves with their love were no less eager than the lion; and each time when a dove flitted over the nose of the lion, the lion shook its head and was amazed and laughed.</p><p>To all of this Zarathustra had only one thing to say: \u201cMy children are near, my children\u201d \u2013 then he became completely mute. But his heart was freed, and from his eyes tears dropped down and fell onto his hands. And he heeded nothing more and sat there, unmoving and not even warding off the animals. Then the doves flew back and forth and lighted on his shoulders and caressed his white hair and did not tire of tenderness and jubilation. But the strong lion kept licking the tears that fell onto Zarathustra\u2019s hands, roaring and growling bashfully. Thus acted these animals. \u2013</p><p>All this lasted a long time, or a short time: for, properly speaking, there is no time on earth for such things \u2013. Meanwhile, however, the higher men in Zarathustra\u2019s cave had awakened and were forming a procession, in order to approach Zarathustra and offer their morning greeting. For they had discovered, when they awakened, that he was no longer among them. But as they reached the door of the cave, and the noise of their footsteps preceded them, the lion started violently, turned suddenly away from Zarathustra and leaped, roaring wildly, toward the cave; and the higher men, when they heard it roaring, all cried out as if with one voice, and fled back and disappeared in a flash.</p><p>Zarathustra himself, however, dazed and disoriented, rose from his seat, looked around, stood there astonished, questioned his heart, reflected, and was alone. \u201cWhat did I hear?\u201d he said at last, slowly, \u201cwhat just happened to me?\u201d</p><p>And right away he remembered, and he grasped in a single glance all that had transpired between yesterday and today. \u201cHere is the stone,\u201d he said, stroking his beard, \u201cthat\u2019s what I sat on yesterday morning; and here\u2019s where the soothsayer approached me, and here\u2019s where I first heard the cry that I heard just now, the great cry of distress.</p><p>Oh you higher men, it was your distress that this old soothsayer foretold yesterday morning \u2013</p><p>\u2013 to your distress he wanted to seduce and tempt me. Oh Zarathustra, he said to me, I come to seduce you to your last sin.</p><p>\u201cTo my last sin?\u201d cried Zarathustra, and laughed scornfully at his own words. \u201cWhat has been left me now as my last sin?\u201d</p><p>\u2013 And once more Zarathustra became immersed in himself and sat down again on the great stone, and he reflected. Suddenly he jumped to his feet \u2013</p><p>\u201cPity! Pity for the higher men!\u201d he cried, and his face transformed to bronze. \u201cWell then! That \u2013 has its time!</p><p>My suffering and my pity \u2013 what do they matter! Do I strive for happiness? I strive for my work!</p><p>Well then! The lion came, my children are near, Zarathustra became ripe, my hour came \u2013</p><p>This is my morning, my day is beginning: up now, up, you great noon! \u201d \u2013</p><p>Thus spoke Zarathustra and he left his cave, glowing and strong, like a morning sun that emerges from dark mountains.</p><p>\u2217\u2217\u2217</p><p>The end of Thus Spoke Zarathustra</p>", "article_json": {"type": "doc", "content": [{"type": "heading", "attrs": {"level": 2}, "content": [{"text": "The Sign", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "content": [{"text": "But in the morning after this night Zarathustra sprang from his sleeping place, girded his loins and came out from his cave, glowing and strong, like a morning sun that emerges from dark mountains.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "content": [{"text": "\u201cYou great star,\u201d he said, as he had said before, \u201cwhat would all your happiness be if you did not have those for whom you shine?", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "content": [{"text": "And if they stayed in their rooms while you are already awake and come and bestow and distribute \u2013 how would your proud shame be angered!", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "content": [{"text": "Well then!
